description:
This has been my favorite sushi experience in SF so far. The chefs, the services, the quality of fish, and the originality of the dishes were superb. This is definitely a place that adds its own special touch, and you get a lot more than just nigiri when doing omakase.

We came here on a week night with a reservation requesting bar seating. I loved having our own personal sushi chef (shout out to Shin) and being able to constantly give feedback as to what we were in the mood for. A lot of the dishes were something I would have never imagined to order myself, but were also some of the most delicious. The rice of the nigiri was perfectly seasoned and none of the pieces were overwhelmingly wasabi-y where I could no longer taste the fish.

I definitely recommend to everyone who wants an amazing sushi night in SF to come to Akiko's. I would also lend a word of warning that we spent  a LOT more than we thought, so definitely give the staff a heads up regarding how much you're want to spend (for Omakase). Overall, I really have no complaints because everything was so delicious and service was amazing.

I would love to return for another go.
author: Arezou A.

description:
How I ended up here:
Sean - let's get sushi tonight and have date night
Me: okay, got any particular spot you want to try or shall we let Yelp guide us

(Yelp guided us)
With date nights in the city I try not spending too much time to search, cause what I want is usually not what we end up getting. 
So here we are walking over to Akiko's talking about harassment at work and the parameters of appropriate and inappropriate behavior and walk in and we're like okay this place is a little warm, why aren't there any fans. got seated but got told "hey, you can only have this table till 7 PM"(its 5:43 PM) - fair enough we didn't have reservations. Open the menu and immediately I was like hhhmmm this might be something both of us might have to pay for tonight if we are indulging. 

And let me tell you we did! This place is not for your average joe to come and order 6-8 rolls of sushi and get away with a $70- $100 bill. No my friend you are getting seasonal fish that are artistically hand crafted and cut. And it was out of this world! If you're not too big on your fish knowledge, let you server make the suggestions cause they do it well. 

We ordered doubles of a few sashimis and beers and two rolls and the bill was close to about $200 which we expected so not mad. 

Favorites: ji-kinmedai (smoked snapper), nama sake (salmon), tennen sawara (mackerel) and the yazu (yellowtail) 

I'm hoping to bring my dad back next year for his b'day to explore their summer menu.
author: Ankita C.

description:
Super fresh and yummy! This is as good as it gets!!

Maybe I am biased​ because​ I love anything with sashimi in it! The fish was very fresh and the salmon melted in my mouth! I came here to celebrate my birthday and I had a great experience!

We made a reservation through the phone and when we got to the restaurant​, we were seated immediately! The server was very polite and gave us pretty good suggestions on what to order. 

Definitely,​​ recommend their sashimi platter!

There was a 10-minute​ wait in between each dish ( we probably were so hungry that we devoured each dish in minutes as it was served).  

The price was on the higher end but I thought it was worth the price for the quality​ of sashimi that I was getting! 

***********My overall ratings************

Taste: 5 stars

Price: 4 stars 

Environment & Cleanliness: 4 stars 

Service: 5 stars
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
Really delicious sushi. I got the sashimi moriawase. The seared sea bream was exquisite, and the tuna and king salmon were also very good. My wife got the nigiri moriawase and enjoyed hers as well. We also tried a salmon avocado roll, which had really nice salmon in it the blended so well with the avocado and marinated rice.

I think my wife would have liked her nigiri better if the rice was more of a typical sushi rice as it was a bit too salty for her, but I personally liked the addition.

The place is pretty pricy, though, so be forewarned!
author: Matt H.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant in SF. Great sake list and amazing foods. I recommend sitting at the sushi bar and have the chef makes sushi for you. They're so creative and delicious. We had excellent service. What a treat every time I get to eat here.
author: Kayla N.

description: You're not going to get traditional rolls here at a typical sushi joint. The menu seemed more sashimi and nigiri based. High fish quality, but also pricey.
author: Annie L.

description:
Finally got a seat without reservation during weekday dinner time! I highly recommend people make a reservation before coming in. I've tried both lunch and dinner times during weekday and was finally able to get two seats by the bar this time. We were asked to finish within x minutes which we were fine with since we were headed to places afterward anyways.

Food:
+ Chawanmushi with uni was awesome! It was tender and fresh, amazing
+ Sashimi pieces and sushi roll: Taste okay, the selection is too limited

Overall, I would come in again if craving for sushi in FiDi, but not worth a trip.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Such an amazing dinner experience! We had a reservation to sit at the bar. Our sushi chef Sammy (Sammie?) was super friendly, which contributed to our great experience. Customer service was great! 

We went for the omakase chef's choice of course, accompanied by a sake bottle! Each piece was exquisite! I can't even begin to describe how amazing each piece was. I mean gold flakes on sushi?! My favorites were uni, toro, and wagyu! It tasted so fresh and soft/buttery! The starters were also so yummy! The oyster shell holder was also super cool looking. Can't go wrong with any of the options. They also have many other things on the menu but we were so full from the omakase already. 

Prices are a little steep but definitely worth a try!
author: Kim N.

description:
The fish here was fantastic but the service rubbed me the wrong way.

I walked in on a Monday night around 7:30p. There was a couple ahead of me getting seated. When she returned I told her it was just me and asked if I could sit at the bar (there are about 8 seats). Two seats were open but it looked like they were reserved. She told me it would be a little bit. Maybe it's just me, but she didn't smile and wasn't pleasant. I think that's 90% of your job as a hostess - make your customer feel good about dropping $$$$ on small pieces of raw fish. 

It took about 10 minutes for me to get seated. When I sat down I noticed not just one but both of my chopsticks were crooked. The sushi chef noticed I was playing with them and asked if I wanted another pair but I told him I'd just ask the waitress when she came. When she got to me, I mentioned this to her and instead of just getting me another pair, she told me I was probably mistaken because their chopsticks twirled at the base (the irony of an Asian being questioned, by another Asian, about his familiarity with chopsticks doesn't escape me). She stood there and stared at me for a few seconds so I stood the chopsticks up and showed her that the tips of chopsticks shouldn't touch and form a wishbone shape at the base...

Things sailed smoothly after that. I ordered some sashimi from the chef and he was nice and polite. The fish came out in good time and it was tasted as good as it looked. 

A beer ($9) and the sashimi ($39) after tax and tip ended up being $62! If you can get a seat here and put up with the rough around the edges service then this place is worth a visit.
author: Tran C.

description:
Food: Delicious

Service: exceptional - so sweet, kind, attentive and knowledgeable of the menu of food and drinks. Recommendations also turned out well.

Atmosphere: so cute and warm. Everything from the plates, cups, and seats were well made.

Location: middle of everything in downtown sf. Also 2 blocks to a BART/Muni station
author: Michelle B.

description:
I came here for dinner one night because I was craving sushi in SF. There are so many places and I was glad I made a reservation because this place was busy.

I was able to get a seat at the sushi bar and got to watch the sushi chefs at work. 

What I was served by the chef:
-sunazuri (yellowtail belly)
-umi masu (ocean trout)
-hotate (hokkaido scallop)
-tennen hirame (wild fluke)
-akamutsu (rosy seabass)
-sawara (spanish mackerel)
-yazu (young yellowtail)
-kinki (channel rockfish)
-ankimo (monkfish liver)
-kinmedai (golden eye snapper)
-unagi (freshwater eel)

The sushi was fresh and delicious. The service was great and I loved the decor. Overall, a great place for a date or to enjoy an authentic omakase meal.
author: Lily Y.

description:
First time here at Akiko's and I had a great experience. My friend and I made a reservation at 8:45 but the host was able to sit us an hour earlier! :) TY!! We had 2 servers, unfortunately we didn't get the name of our waitress. She was very attentive and explained all of our dishes while our other waiter literally just left the food on our table and left...we had no idea what we ate half the time. 

We got the chef's choice omasake (about 15 pieces) and there were 2 that they ran out :(

Overall it was a great experience! 
omasake 4/5
Service 4/5
author: Jenny L.

description: Expensive and limited selection, portion small and fish is average fresh. And they don't use tradition white rice most of nigiri already pre-sauced maybe to cover up the not so fresh taste of fish. If you want tradition good sushi suggest to go somewhere else
author: Pumpkin K.

description:
Small Japanese restaurant close to the Financial District, a few blocks from Montgomery BART station.

I arrived before opening time without a reservation and managed to get a seat at the bar when it opened. By the time the restaurant opened, there was a sizeable crowd gathered behind me, and the restaurant filled up quickly.

Service was efficient. Quality of fish is good. Expensive.
author: Tom S.

description:
It was great surprised to have such high quality Nigiri in San Francisco. 
Each "Neta( fish meal )" has done lots of preparation before they make. 
They use " aka-su" vinegar for "Shari ( rice )" which is rare even in Japan.
author: Hiro M.

description:
Pros:  quick and friendly atmosphere 
           Pretty presentation
           Intimate atmosphere 

Cons:  food was ok
author: Bayarea K.

description:
I've been to Akiko's several times and my last trip there merits a review. My wife and I went for our anniversary and had a gift card there that really allowed us to explore the menu and try a lot of different dishes and Akiko's did not disappoint. 

The restaurant is small with probably around 20 tables and it can be cramped. We ended up sitting next to two couples who were much rowdier and noisy than the rest of the crowd, but it didn't dampen the experience too much. However, don't expect to have a ton of space or fancy decor, it's pretty barebones when it comes to that. 

We were presented with a menu of both regular dishes and the fresh nigiri flown in from Japan. We focused on the latter and ordered a variety of nigiri dishes, as well as the grilled black cod. Let me just say: order the black cod. The flavor is complex but consistent and the texture is fantastic and the fish melts in your mouth. The dish is served very simply without sides, but the seasoning and the sauce really accentuate the flavors.

Onto the nigiri. We tried both the ensui "unprocessed" uni, which came in a little spoon without rice and the more traditional uni "nigiri" with rice and seaweed. Both were excellent and my wife preferred the unprocessed uni for pure uni flavor, while I preferred the nigiri for a more balanced uni flavor with the rice and seaweed. It was a good problem to have as both were fantastic.

The fish in the other nigiri we ordered was stellar and came preseasoned (no dipping in soy sauce here)...the salmon (sake) and the toro (tuna) both stood out as being perfectly seasoned and flavored while having a wonderful texture. 

Overall, a fantastic culinary experience. For what Akiko's lacks in frills, it more than makes up for in high quality, well seasoned, and delicious fish. Certainly a great place for a special occasion to try something special.
author: Marat M.

description:
What can I say. Wow... Lost for words...
Had the best omakase experience from Chef Alex. His attention to details of his craft was simply unworldly. The pace of the dinner matches perfectly to my partner and my speed. We're pretty fast eaters; however, we never had to wait too long till the next course is ready. Chef Alex offered us many fishes I had never tried before including the ayu (sweet fish), overnighted scallop, and unprocessed sea urchin. Each nigiri was seasoning perfectly with a variety of garnishes. Cherry blossom on sea bream! One of the favorites. Another one is the otoro (fatty tuna belly). It just melted in my mouth like butter. Mmm. My partner loved their unprocessed sea urchin and sanma (pike mackerel). The sea urchin was so creamy and sweet! Chef Alex provided us such an intimate and delicious omakase.  Thank you so much! Can't wait to come back!
author: Jenny D.

description: The sushi was very delicious, customer serve was great. The only thing, is that the place is very very tiny. It really fits a small amount of people. I did like the fact that is a very intimate place to eat; however it's hard to have a conversation because you're literally so close to other tables. I totally recommend this place to eat good good sushi
author: Dorys P.

description: This place has the same aesthetic as Jiro's subterranean joint in Tokyo, at least as far as the lightly stained wood panels are concerned. I have never been to Tokyo so I can't compare the food but Akiko's is a solid spot for legitimate sushi. There's a lot of competition in the city and it's nice to have a healthy assortment of places trying their hardest to win your business.
author: Vahe M.

description:
Akiko's definitely fits in San Francisco.  While Akiko's a bit trendy and seems to attract the hip-downtown-metro crowd, underneath it all is true craftsmanship and a dedication to serving a high quality product.  Being a first timer I sat at the bar and order a few pieces off their standard menu and a few pieces off their seasonal menu - both were fresh and balanced, however the brown rice just isn't the same as good sushi rice.  Then I order the collar , and it made the evening - the piece was well seasoned and perfectly grilled (crisp skin and moist meat).   It was love at first bite. 

Overall Akiko's offers a pleasant experience and it's great for being seen - I would just skip the sushi and go straight for the sashimi next time.
author: Nate K.

description:
This is one of the sushi restaurants I have been wanting to go since quite long time ago.. I have tried to walk in several times but had never gotten a seat and finally.. I am here! Thanks to my date :)
This restaurant is family owned restaurant, inside is quite narrow, has wooden interior furnitures, the atmosphere is quite intimate.
However, they serve classic, traditional sushi. Their sushi quality is very fresh, they offer so many variety of fish.

Having omakase is probably best, just let the sushi chefs pick the best sushi and exercise their creativity on the plate. We were sitting at the corner of the restaurant, put ourselves at the mercy of the sushi chef, asked no questions, waited eagerly to see what he produced for us. Each meal was flowing seamlessly, tasted wonderful.

They also offer wide variety of sake. The server was quite friendly and willing to explain each dish thoroughly together with the history of the restaurant :)
What a great experience.
author: Irene X.

description:
OMAKASE lunch the other week.

Honestly so so fresh. The place is small and intimate. Second meal here

Service was frosty and the lady did not really bother to introduce thoroughly what nigiri was what.. turn off

In time, close to tip time, she amazingly warmed up and actually cracked a smile.. imagine that!!!!
author: Jana C.

description:
The first and main stop of our SF restaurant hopping. I knew it wasn't going to be cheap, but I still wasn't prepared for it. Lol

Ika (tempura squid with spicy aioli) $11
This was lightly battered and fried to perfection. A good appetizer. 

Large Orion beer cuz Sapporo is too common and I was wearing an Orion shirt. It was sweeter than I remembered.

4.5/5 - Sashimi Moriawase (12 pieces of sashimi) $39. Great quality sashimi with excellent flavor. It was not icy cold like some restaurants that do not even thaw sashimi properly. 

4/5 - Nama Hotate (Hokkaido) at $9 each. The scallop almost melted on my chopsticks. So tender and fresh. 

4.5/5 Otoro bluefin tuna belly @ $15 a piece. Half of it disintegrated on my chopsticks and definitely melted away in my mouth. I should have gotten nigiri so that rice would have accentuated it. 

4/5 Murasaki uni @ $12.50 a piece. It was great sea urchin, but it did not blow me away. Perhaps I expected too much. 

4.5/5 Wagyu with truffle slices @ $12.50. To be honest, this was my first time eating truffle. Although I've always liked truffle flavored things like fries, pasta, etc, but never tried the real thing. Thus, I had to taste the truffle by itself first. Not what I had expected - much more subtle in flavor. Then I downed the whole wagyu nigiri with delight.

4/5 Ankimo nigiri (Monk Fish foie) @ $6.50. Nice smooth flavor, but think the seaweed and bonito fish flavor overpowered it.

This was a nice restaurant with good service, ambiance and great tasting food. Just not very affordable to an ordinary consumer like me. Could be back, but only on special occasions.
author: Lon H.

description:
Business trips can be a mixed blessing, in this instance,​ it was a blessing. ​My colleagues and I visited this highly recommended Japanese restaurant towards the end of April this year. We had made reservations several weeks in advance. Wow, this place was incredible, I don't know whether quaint is the correct word for the interior setup, but it seems apt. You can see further details in regards to the restaurant itself in many of the other reviews, they properly describe the establishment itself. Also to another's comment, it took us a couple of minutes to find the place as we kept walking past it thinking it was a pub or some such​ due to the odd placement of signage on the exterior.

Anyway, the food was wonderful. We had a variety of sashimi, all incredibly fresh, tasty and expertly prepared. The presentation​ was very nice as well. The Fried crispy soft shell crab was incredible. The grilled miso black cod was good, but not the best I ever had, probably one of two items I had for dinner that was​ not in the category of "stellar", IMHO.

Also had the grilled yellowtail​ collar. It was very good, but a little too much work to get to the fish. Maybe it's just me.

The friend crispy silken tofu was wonderful! I highly recommend that dish as well.

All of the sashimi​/sushi​ that we ordered were off the charts, that includes, yellowtail, amberjack, bigeye and bluefin tuna, king salmon (not a big salmon as sashimi fan), and halibut.

The edamame was very good and though I did not try it, a friend had the grilled beef and said it was delicious. 

We did not have dessert as we were full and happy.

This was a wonderful dining​ experience, I would recommend to others, wish this place was in my neighborhood.
author: Robert P.

description: Hiro, you are a master with your hands. Some may enjoy Michael Mina's Pabu as the high-class SF sushi spot, but really, you'll get a far better omakase dinner with Hiro at the helm for half the price, and you'll still have plenty of good sake and cold beer. The fish quality here is amazing, and if you have a friend who only eats cooked fish, they'll still accommodate you. How wonderful is that? Cold smoked snapper? Killer. A-5 wagyu? Beautiful and decadent. Creative plays with tamago, especially with a warm crab concoction and your nori-wrapped tamago finish? Faaaantastic. Some of the nigiri might be a little heavy with wasabi, but these guys are preparing some grade-A food, and it isn't going unnoticed. Just be sure to make a reservation and not overlook the fact that the Irish Bank sign above actually refers to a bar in the alley, not the amazing sushi spot underneath the blade sign.
author: Danny C.

description:
Akiko's sashimi quality is stellar. Having lived in Japan, I can tell you that this is the real deal. Yes, it can be on the pricier side if you order per piece but I would recommend doing the sashimi moriawase which is a 12 piece sashmi tasting. At 39 dollars, it is definitely more economical than ordering 12 individual pieces (ranging from 4-7 dollars per piece). 

The sashimi here is really fresh. The Hokkaido scallops and kanpachi were my favorites. I came here with two friends who also lived in Japan and they were highly impressed.

Note: I would definitely make reservations as it is almost impossible to just walk in.
author: Joan S.

description:
Just a warning there's no sign that says Akiko. We walked by it a couple of times before we finally found it. On the top, it says "The Irish Bank" with an arrow indicating towards that restaurant. This place is situation right under. 

We came here for a business lunch and got the omakase menu. Legitly the best sushi I have ever had in my life. The fish tasted so fresh and high quality. I didn't expect to get this much food either. I thought we would be done earlier but we still had a few more pieces to try! 

I tried gold flakes on top of uni on top of trout. Never thought I would try gold flakes before. Honestly the gold flakes added nothing to the flavor since the fish and uni already had so much flavor but it definitely added to the aesthetic. 


I was super happy and satisfied after. I'm not sure how much it costs since I didn't take a look at the menu or check. Definitely will want to come back though!
author: Becky H.

description:
Fresh sushi, really enjoyed the tuna. the beef teriyaki was good too. Not a big fan of the red bean mochi.

Not enough waiters around...service was slow.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Really incredible sushi and sashimi. 

I definitely recommend getting the tasting menu from the chef. It's a bit pricey, but freakin delicious!!

Agedashi tofu was also great, but maybe a little more authentic and less typical (less deep fry).
author: Ryan B.

description: Amazing, fresh, delicious sushi!! It's a cozy restaurant with a great ambiance. Best sushi I have ever had! I expected freshness getting it in the bay, but it was even better than I imagined!
author: Carrie B.

description:
The best sushi spot in Fidi, so it's the perfect place to grab lunch or dinner with friends in the area after work.

Appetizer: Ordered the octopus and it was so freakin good. The inside octopus is perfectly chewy and the outer part is perfectly crispy.

Entree: I got the Sake roll (which has salmon in it) which I get every time I come. And I always get 2 pieces of the Uni. I love my uni and the uni here is really fresh.

My friend's sushi pieces looked super fresh and she got the yellow tail roll. I cannot comment on the taste but she loved it and comes here all the time.

Dessert: We shared the black sesame ice cream. The scoop was literally so tiny but we were full anyway, so it was a good bite.
author: Alex C.

description:
Located near the intersection of Bush and Kearney is Akiko's restaurant. You can easily miss the signage since there is a sign for a pub that kind of gives you the impression that Akiko's is the pub.

Once you enter the door you see a small sushi bar but then realize that there is another seating section around the corner. The lights are turned down low they have some cool acoustic music in the background. Very date-night-ish vibe even during a workday lunch.

Your boy was feenin (like Jodeci of course) some Sashimi so I pulled up this place on my bookmarks and strolled on through.

For me it came down to two options the Chef's Choice Omakase which on the menu it says "MP" this essentially means that you tell the chef what your budget is whether it's $60 , 80 ,100, 200 you get the idea and the Chef makes the choices for you. 

I was seated at the bar so I was able to see the sushi chefs get down with the get down and it was impressive to see their craft and precision. This place in particular (like most higher end sushi places) puts a high emphasis on the presentation so there is a certain precision/art to it that you don't see at your average run of the mill sushi joint.

Back to the option I settled on...I didn't get the Chef's Omakase because on this day I didn't feel like spending a ton of sashimi so I settled on their 12 piece "Sashimi Moriawase" for $39 before tax.  

Did I like the Sashimi? Yes it was good, but not leaps and bounds better than the many other sushi spots I've gotten it at.

Why go to Akikos? Like I mentioned if I was single , it would probably be a good spot to bring a date given the vibe, good service and presentation of the food.   

Why did it I give it 3 stars? Just for me it wasn't a venue that I personally would return to given the quality of food and price/value prop.
author: Rod M.

description:
The sushi is good as the nigiri and toro roll were delicious, keep in mind prices for nigiri is for 1 piece and not two and portions are small for everything. A place to get a good snack but not one to go to if you're starving as you'll be spending over $200 per person without alcohol, taxes or tip.

So is it worth it? I would say no because unless you're a connoisseur you won't appreciate the difference between this and another affordable place.

For the price I would go to a fancy steak and seafood restaurant and be satisfied and full.
author: N A.

description:
Sushi is everything. 

I probably walked pass the restaurant 5 times. It's unmarked and says THE IRISH BANK over it. Rest assured there is some magic waiting for you inside.

I can only speak for the omakase nigiri that we ordered and it was AMAZING. Very fresh and high quality that you can taste. It was lightly brushed with just enough shoyu and I think citrus (depending on the type of fish) - with small specs of wasabi. My only complaint was that I thought the nigiri pieces were too small. Usually my mouth is full in between chews but at Akiko's I found the nigiri to be on the skippy side. Nonetheless I loved it. Yes it's expensive but you get what you pay for. Quality and freshness always take precedent.
author: Caye Q.

description:
Akiko's flies an entire menu of fish straight in from Japan!  The restaurant is small and busy, so make sure you make reservations!  They hold empty tables for their reservations.  We sat at the only window table and heard several people being turned away despite empty seats around us that were being held for 6:30 pm reservations.

Our waiter was attentive and made excellent suggestions.  He encouraged us to order a few items at a time.  He then checked in to see if we wanted more.  There was zero pressure to keep ordering.

I took pics of most of the items we ordered.  I don't remember the names of each fish.  Sushi purists are going to hate me, but my favorite dish was the salmon roll.  I found it delectable.  My second favorite was a cherry fish from Japan and the butterfish.  My husband like everything we ordered.  The pacing of our dishes was excellent.

Our meal came out to be about $250 with 1 glass of unfiltered sake and no dessert. 

Note:  They allow children, but this is not a family restaurant.  One of the sushi restaurants we first tried to eat at did not allow kids, so I hope this helps parents.  My son was very pleased with his bowl of rice and edamame.  Akiko's is NOT a place for kids that cannot sit still and might knock over plates because all the stoneware seemed very pricey.
author: Kat M.

description:
My husband & I had reservations (necessary) and were seated at the sushi bar, which was nice because we got to talk and compare dishes with other diners at the bar & watch at the sushi chefs worked their magic, hand-crafting each piece. 

We came in for a lunchtime meal and not looking to stuff ourselves and this was the perfect fuel for us. I got a Nigiri Sampler plate to start off with and each piece of fish was fresh, melted-in-your-mouth and served on excellent sushi rice. Each bite was a different with a complex set of flavors! My husband got the Sashimi Sampler plate, but I would highly recommend getting nigiri here because they craft such great bites! We finished with a few individual pieces of nigiri that we either saw other diners eating or the sushi chef recommended to us & these ended up being some of the best bites. Our absolute favorites were the Sake (king salmon & part of the sampler), Hotate (scallop) and Shiro Toro (white tuna belly). 

They have a wide array of sake and our server was able to provide us with great recommendations for each my husband and my own different preferences. 

It was worth it in our opinion, but still not cheap. We finished our lunch satisfied (and slightly buzzed from our sake), but paid over $200 for the experience.
author: Allison J.

description:
Came to Akiko's looking for an authentic Sushi experience. Overall, Akiko's was very good, but in my opinion overpriced. 

Our server was very nice, though not very helpful. We got a couple of tastings and a steak dish (one person in our party is not a Sushi lover but the steak was cooked to perfection and expertly seasoned); everything was excellent. Was hoping to sample a few types of Saki and a couple of chef's choice tastings. Unfortunately, our server was unable to guide us through the menu according to our preferences so we ended up with a more a la carte experience and no Saki. The table next to us had a couple of chef's tastings and the experience looked far superior to our own. 

When all was said and done the food was excellent, but the prices don't really match what you get - they're exorbitantly high. What I figure they include, but we didn't get, was the experience. Perhaps it would have been better if we had sat at the bar. Nonetheless, the same experience should be included throughout the restaurant if the same menu is offered.
author: Nik G.

description:
Was super excited and intrigued in trying this restaurant but it ended up being a sad disappointment. 

Started with trying to get reservations the day before for a Saturday night. Hostess tells me that the sushi bar was sold out for the night and the absolute only reservation they had was for 5:30pm. Fine. 

Was running late, called at 5:15, lovely different hostess let me know she could seat us at the sushi bar (originally wanted/requested) at 6:30. Great!

Now we've tried Sushi Ran, Robin, etc. Sitting at the sushi bar should be an experience for everyone and anyone. You should walk out of that restaurant with some gained knowledge. 

Alex (we think) was our sushi chef and truly just awkward and completely unfriendly. When we asked how much the omakase started at, he told us $120. A bit steep for 8 pieces?? Regardless the fish was decent, fresh and pretty tasty but the awful experience at the sushi bar really just kills the entire time. We luckily got out paying $80 a person but really should've stopped after the first couple of pieces. He didn't even introduce himself and could not even keep eye contact when serving our pieces and naming them. 

Spend your money elsewhere. Won't be back.
author: Bella L.

description:
Best sushi in San Francisco! Friend took me here for birthday dinner. LOVE this place. I'm absolutely obsessed! The sushi is SO delicious! Also loved the miso cod and the steak. And it's fast too. And unpretentious. 

It's tiny, very few tables, so make a reservation!
author: Karen r.

description: Great little place I found, once again, thru Yelp.  I sat at the bar which is the best place to watch the chefs do their magic with fresh fish.  The food was great (if expensive) and the fish cut to perfection.  The only reason I am not giving this place 4 stars it is because it does not pack their fish in cellophane after usage, meaning that some fish touch others or at touched by a chef trying to get to another chefs.  The best sushi places I have been to, from Tokyo to San Francisco, protect their fish as if it were gold.
author: Cornel F.

description:
The restaurant gave me a reminder call the day prior. Which I do appreciate since I might have forgotten

The place is small and tight so I would suggest to make a reservation if you plan to eat here. While leaving at 1:30pm, there is a wait at the door, walk-ins perhaps?

Service was very good. A good amount of staff for the amount of tables. Ordered omakase and food came out at a good rate.  If you're bound to a 60 minute lunch you might want to tell your server as it took 1.5 hrs total

The food was overall good, but it didnt blow me away. The only dislike was the uni as it tasted weird. It wasnt bad but it's not what I am use to having
author: Henry T.

description:
Omakase here is VERY overpriced for its quality. Some recent reviews mention that there are set omakases ($60, $80, etc.,) but when I asked the waitress about this, she denied this existed and said the only option was to eat until you were full/wanted to stop. I thought this was unethical, because the restaurant can easily rack up your bill (which indeed was what happened.) I noticed the tables next to us were analyzing their bills too, likely because they were shocked by the hefty sum. 

We agreed to have 12 courses first and then evaluate if we wanted to continue with more courses. The dishes here were of average quality; the sushi pieces were small, and the fish taste and texture were not memorable. Because of the quality, we stopped at 12 courses even though we were not full. Our bill came out to be almost $200 per person! This was the most expensive, yet unworthy meal I've had. I would NOT recommend coming here.
author: Christine L.

description:
4-stars for the food, 3-stars when you factor in the price

Overall, good quality sushi, but seems really overpriced relative to other places in San Francisco. We got the fried baby octopus, black miso cod, sake, negihama, and negitoro rolls, and salmon, hamachi, unagi, and uni nigiris. Mostly, I enjoyed my meal, but I wouldn't recommend the negitoro roll, as you couldn't really taste the tuna belly much. As I mentioned before, it was pretty pricey for what you got. I have no problem dropping $$$ for sushi, but I've been to similar quality places that aren't as expensive or similarly priced places that in my opinion were better. I probably won't come back.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
My friend and I came here and made reservations because we saw the reviews and decided to check this place out. I'll start off by saying that you definitely need to make reservations. We made a reservation for 7:45pm (it was one of the only ones they had) and we showed up a bit earlier to see if they had any tables and we had to wait until 7:45. 

The two of us both got the sashimi tasting - 12 piece plate and we were served some of the standard fish (salmon, tuna), but also some more interesting fish (like sea bream). Overall, I think it was a pretty good value for the price, maybe just a little bit too pricey for my taste. The meal filled us up and we thought it was the perfect amount of food, the fish tasted fresh, and the cuts were great.

Overall, I think it was a great meal and I'd highly recommend you make a reservation and try it out for yourself! The reason I'm not giving a 5 star rating is because I've had better sushi that's similarly priced, but it's definitely a place I would go to again.
author: Michael L.

description:
Oh. My. God. 

I went here for my wife's birthday and was expecting it to be better than average - it ended up being the best sushi I have ever eaten. 

We walked in about five minutes before our schedule reservation and the hostess told us to hangout and they would have a place for us in a few minutes. About five minutes later she said they were running behind and we should come back in about 45 minutes. I was annoyed and hungry at this point plus we had a flight that we needed to catch in less than 8 hours so we wanted to sleep. We ended up walking around town and coming back 45 minutes later. She greeted us again and informed us a table directly in front of us would be ready shortly. It was cleared, reset and she grabbed menus and was about to walk over to it when two men walked in. She happily greeted them both by name, leaned over to me and apologized saying they requested this specific table so she had to give it to them, then told us to go back to waiting. Overall we waited nearly an hour and twenty minutes. It was horrible. I'm super easy going but this was pushing my limits. 

They ended up finally seating us in the back of the restaurant and gave us the menu - we noticed they had several different types of uni, including a few overnighted directly from Japan. We figured we'd get a bit of everything and see what we liked. 

After I had my first bite, I realized why there was such a wait. We ended up ordering so much more than we were going to initially because it was so truly incredible. All in all it was about $400 for dinner including no alcohol but it really was a small price to pay for such amazing food. 

We ended up loving it so much we booked a trip to Tokyo just to get the uni from the source. I'm confident this is the best available sushi in North America. Looking forward to coming back already!
author: Nicholas D.

description:
Akiko's was probably one of the biggest let downs of 2017 for me. The quality, cut, size, flavor profile and options were not reflective of the high price point. The chefs who came from Sushi Ran and Ota are long gone and it seems the quality and consistency left with them. 

First of all, this is not a true Omakase style and everything is à la carte. It's a good concept as you can choose what you want but the problem is, what you are choosing between isn't worth it. 

The prices are similar to others such as Kusakabe and Omakase ($15 uni, $12 Toro, etc.) so you can easily end up with a $200 per person bill without trying too hard. The issue? The flavor profile, complexity and options are not even remotely close. Not even in the same universe. Mentioning them in the same sentence is offensive.  

The rice was subpar; that's nigiri 101 basics. If the base is not on point, it ruins everything. The cuts were inconsistent with some pieces being too small, others too large, some too thin, others too fat. The seasoning was off, often lacking saltiness and failing to bring the full flavor out of the fish. The sauces and wasabi underneath were often inconsistent, either leaving the piece too bland or just completely overpowering the fish and actually taking away from the experience. It just lacked the sophistication and masterful preparation one has come to expect at the price point. Nigiri is more than just slapping on high quality grade fish on top of rice. You can tell they don't source their fish from the same places either; they clearly don't get top grade. 

Additionally, for à la carte, the options were quite limited. They didn't have many bluefin tuna cuts, no wagyu, and nothing quite interesting. It's good that they had Russian uni but they only had one type of Hakkaido uni (and it wasn't as good as others I've had so probably wasn't as fresh). I even saw that they sometimes run out of Toro... I can go get my usual salmon and tuna cuts elsewhere without paying $10-20 a piece. Give us options!

The actual place was nice but service was subpar and slow. One would expect better. The person in charge of tea was the only one on point. 

Anyone that tells you Akiko's is the best sushi they've ever had either hasn't gone there in years, or worse - has no idea what they are talking about and has had their taste buds thoroughly burned right before they ate. Don't get me wrong, the food is good but at that price point, it does not deliver the complexity in flavor, sophistication and consistency one should expect.

For half the price it would be solid run of the mill 4/4.5 sushi joint; as it stands - the mediocre service, inconsistent quality, lack of choice, and simplistic flavors make it an easy pass! Plenty of better choices in the city!
author: Mario B.

description: Amazing and inventive sushi! They combine unique flavors with their sushi that provides your palette a fun and delicious experience. Can't wait to go back again.
author: Dana M.

description:
We made reservations to come in on a Monday evening and luckily we did because the first walk in availabilities they had was for after 9:30PM. There was a little mix up with our online reservation, but they were able to handle it quickly and professionally. The host apologized for the mix up and was able to us to our table quickly. The service this time was great and the servers were very attentive and answered all of our questions, from the sake to what was their favorites on the menu.

We tried a lot of the Chef's Specials on the menu and none of the items disappointed. 

I would highly recommend the following dishes:

Tamago
Hotate
Kuromaguro
Hon Maguro
Managatsuo
Sunomono with Scallops - We both should have known we were going to get a second helping of this dish, next time we'll probably get our own
Uni - I had to get a second order because it was that good

This last visit to Akiko's was amazing and we will definitely be back. I would highly recommend visiting if you're in the area and want some delicious Nigiri and Sake.
author: Camera P.

description:
Okay so... This was pretty disappointing. Not sure what is with all the hype here, but I've had better sushi at small unknown restaurants. 
We ordered:
Hamachi sushi roll -- saturated with salt; so, so salty.
6 piece nigiri -- very small fish slices, and none outstanding with flavor.
Blue fin tuna nigiri -- small.. Not memorable.
1 glass of unfiltered sake  -- $14 for a small cup? Geeze. 

I literally came here for some toro,  but lo and behold they did not have any that day! What a disappointment. 
Interior looks good, and service is nothing special. It took almost 20 minutes for our sushi roll to come out as well. We were waiting at the table with no food for much longer than we were eating. A place like this should have real wasabi as well.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Wow, I totally dig this place. It's been in my cousin's list of "Places To Go Before I Die". Before I continue, please know she is not dying. She is quite the opposite: perfect health and she even has a perfect 20/20 vision at the age of fortysomething. But yes, she carries around her bucket list everywhere she goes. So when she asked me to meet her there on my most recent SFO overnight, how could I say no to an item from a bucket list? 

We were seated right away in this highly sought after restaurant for what would be a 2-hour lunch. Reservation is highly recommended not only for dinner, but also for lunch. We had the lovely Elizabeth as our waitress. She was friendly, knowledgable, and most gracious. My cousin who is the sushi expert did all the ordering for us. The only request I had was Uni. And please don't hold back on the Uni either....the more Uni, the better. And also Sake, hot Sake. Can't have sushi without Sake. 

Hands down, the BEST sushi I have ever had in my life. I don't like when restaurants put all that fancy stuff on top of their sushi as edible ornaments, or marinate the fish in some secret sauce, then expect me to pay an arm and a leg for sushi that I couldn't even taste. So Akiko's did not disappoint at all. I paid an arm and a leg for eating the freshest sushi period. No nonsense, unadulterated sushi. I think the only thing they must've done was massage the fish to make them so buttery delicious. By far, the most expensive lunch I've ever had. After splitting the bill 50/50, we each paid $120 total. Ouch. Ouch. Ouch. It's all good though, after all there's no such thing as a cheap bucket list. Now let's just hope my husband doesn't see my credit card statement because he'll be like "You paid how much for lunch?? I thought you said you split the bill??"
author: Mariani D.

description:
The food was great! The chef at the sushi bar was nice! However the front lady was RACIST!!!  

About a week ago I was visiting SF, and decided to have lunch over there. When I walked in, the front lady asked me do I have reservation, I told her no, she then told me they don't have empty spot for me. I saw there were a lot of spaces at the bar area so I asked her can I sit at the bar? She checked their system and told me I can sit at the bar but I have to finish in 1 hour, so I rushed my lunch for her "time line". 

HOWEVER, there was another white lady walked in right after me and sat right next to me at the bar, when we were eating we chatted a little bit, she told me she didn't have any reservation as well but no one told her that she has to finish in 1 hour. 

I would say their sea urchin r the best I had so far and their wagyu beef was great! However I had a bad experience because of the front lady! They should really get a better front person!
author: Fang Y.

description:
Decent food, but chilly service (and front seating!)

We'd made a reservation several weeks in advance for a birthday dinner. I don't mind if the waitstaff is overly polite but not the most friendly, but there were way too many instances (perks of watching them interact with customers who wanted to walk in) of downright impoliteness. I get that it's a super popular restaurant, and thus hard to accommodate walk-ins given limited seating, but put a sign on the door or be more gracious when turning people away-- word spreads.

We got the wagyu nigiri (miyazaki) with truffle, nama uni (hokkaido), gyu (beef), and ika (tempura monterey squid). I was under the impression that the squid would come out first, since we had indicated that was an appetizer, but they brought out the order as nigiri to beef to squid. Not a problem normally, but was expecting more professional service at a high end spot. 

The wagyu nigiri (+$5 for shaved truffle) was beautiful to look at, with a buttery beef taste (not from fat you could see, but from the well distributed marbling). Emphasis on buttery beef. I think they must have torched the bottom of the piece, as the cooked taste of beef did come through, even though the top portion I saw was red. Very little sinew as I chewed through. The truffle complimented the taste of the meat, but on its own, it reminded me of vegetarian / grass, which is in line with other truffle I've had. Good meat to rice ratio, but the piece certainly could have been ~30% larger. 4/5 on taste, 3/5 on value.

The nama uni (they were kind to explain the differences between the four different types of uni they had that evening)-- and I settled on the processed one (meaning there is salt added) because it makes the texture of the flesh sweeter. Certainly very fresh (unfresh uni is really bad), creamy, and sweet, though I wasn't in love. Same comment as the wagyu on size. 3.75/4 on taste, 3/5 on value.

The gyu was nicely presented, with the meat on one slab, and an assortment of veggies in small interconnected bowls. The meat itself was very tender, little sinew, and had that beefy taste I look for in beef. The last piece in the bunch was quite sinewy though, and not in a good way. The veggies all had very distinct flavors that were a good contrast to the beef. The brussel sprouts were in a vinegary sauce and lightly crisped. The kimchi wasn't spicy at all, but very crisp vacuoles. The pea sprouts were refreshing and also had crispy vacuoles. The only thing about pea sprouts is that if you're actually at a high end (Chinese) spot, they remove the stems since those parts are a bit older than the young leaves. Nice garlic flavor on these though. The soy marinade accompanying this was very...I'm not sure how describe it, but it reminded me of sauces I've had in Japan, in a good way. A bit overpowering for the delicate taste of the steak though. 4/5 on taste, 3.75/5 on fancy restaurant value.

Almost forgot about the squid! This was my least favorite dish. While it looked beautiful, the delicate taste of squid was completely drowned out by the unidentified sauce they put on it-- the little dollops of mayo (no particular flavor) were no match for the sauce. The sauce reminded me of a pork sauce for spareribs at a Chinese place close to home, which isn't bad, but didn't match what I envisioned squid to be. The squid itself was tough, the breading was a bit hard, and...yeah, I'd pass on this. 3/5, thought it was one of the larger portion sizes.

They were a bit pushy for us to order more (do you need to see the menu, do you want dessert)-- a quick glance of Yelp reviews suggests that most tables of 2 spend ~$200. While the dessert did sound enticing (yuzu and sesame ice creams), we had a cake waiting for us. The seat right next to the door (literally less than 2 feet) made it quite chilly as well. I'd definitely ask for a spot at the bar or in the back next time around.
author: Nicole H.

description:
This is a small place and was super packed for lunch. I loved it and the fresh was all fresh. The sushi chefs are nice too and try to engage with you. I sat at the sushi bar and it's was a little tight. 
I don't remember seeing a sign so just go inside because it looks like a pub. 
I almost forgot to take a picture but I love the chef's choice.
author: Myle D.

description:
This is probably some of the best sushi I've had in the states. It's melt in the mouth fish that's delicious. The ebi is hands down the best I've ever had. 

Now to the negative. The hostess is cold as ice -- making us feel unwelcome off the bat. Kind of put a damper on the rest of the evening. Our server was pleasant but extremely slow. It took 10 minutes for us to be acknowledged and to get some water. I watched other tables get seated and served right away. The other interesting bit was we asked about omasake pricing and the server said it ranged anywhere from $100-200. Never have we been to a sushi bar where the omasake price was TBD. Normally it's a set price for a set amount of pieces. Seemed dishonest. 

Would I return here? Maybe if I was feeling more tolerant of bad service.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Grab a seat everyone. I found another favorite sushi spot in another city. 

Was visiting SF and friends spoke highly of this place, so I knew i had to stop in. All dinner reservations were booked 2 weeks out, so I got a reservation in for lunch at opening. Showed up, let them know I had a reservation and was seated right away. (do yourself a favor and just make a reservation)

Sat down tried the Nigiri Sampler, and damn every piece was buttery, fresh, and the rice here is on another level. The perfect amount of rice too. Not too much, and not too little. Added on some Scallops and botan Ebi, and man the shrimp was so sweet and buttery, but my top for the day was the scallop. Some otherworldly buttery smoothness to a scallop I've never experienced before. Along with that I had the hamachi kama which they give a nice big piece that's cooked to perfection. Crispy on the outside and juicy meat on the inside. The best Hamachi Kama I've had. 

You know you're having an amazing experience when every piece of food you put in your mouth puts a smile on your face. 

This is the freshest most buttery sushi I've had outside of Tsukiji Market in Japan. 

Akiko's Restaurant is it.
author: Rickey M.

description: My first time seeing the negitoro this big... they were as big as the size of the tea cup.  Taste wasnt too special; or, it wasnt like the real negitoro.  Definitely made by non-Japanese.  Plus, it had a sharp bone that hit my palate.  Tables were very close to one another, so we got to hear everyones business... My sushi that I ordered never came, so I had to cancel the order eventually - somehow it was a good thing that it never came...
author: Jeannie Y.

description:
This is not a true omakase place. Everything is a la carte. When you tell the sushi chef omakase, you will tell them your likes and dislikes and they will start providing you with different dishes until you're full. I can definitely see and taste the freshness of the fish. Each fish was prepared very prettily, but inconsistent with the seasoning. Mostly, it was lacking salt, so each fish's taste wasn't as highlighted. Each slice wasn't as precise as other places either. Some pieces were thinner and some were thicker. For dessert, they gave us complementary ice-cream, coconut and Thai green curry. The coconut ice-cream was amazing. Full of fresh coconut flavors and not too sweet. The Thai green curry was interesting, slightly salty and sweet. I couldn't get any curry flavors, probably because it was too cold. 

Overall high points for freshness, but because of the lack of appropriate amount of seasoning, it lacked flavor. For 2 people, the bill was over $450 for just sushi, it's not worth it for us. There are many sushi restaurants in SF that offer a better value for better taste.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I'm very disappointed to have to write this review. I had been looking forward to having the time and opportunity to try Akiko's for years.

Main takeaway: Not worth the price. 

Really truly. I was pretty satisfied until we received the final bill. $400+ with tip. For the quality of food and drink we consumed, I really expected it to be $100 less.

Qualifier: I eat a lot of sushi. It's like a separate food group to me, and I always rate base on value. You can get decent fast cheap sushi in a pinch, or you can spend hundreds on a memorable experience. Akiko's doesn't rate highly for value. The quality is well above average, but the price deserves something I'd dream about months later. I will not be dreaming about you Akiko's sushi any time in the near or far future.

The variety of flavors is nothing to write home about either. No big risks here.

Summary: Spend your money at Kusakabe instead.
author: Sonya I.

description: Super affordable place and generous servings. I love the fresh sushi ingredients, you can literally feel it in your mouth. Really good quality and so delectable. The service was impressive too. Everyone is attentive and genuinely helpful. Will definitely be going back soon.
author: Ricky L.

description: they have the best cod that I​ ever had before!! The nigiri is okay, I'm​ not a fan of it, the fish is a ​little bit skinny, i mean the size of the nigiri is small...
author: Faye L.

description: Loved every plate put in front of me here at Akiko's.  The sushi was incredible!  Small plates of cooked foods were equally as impressive.  Service was attentive from start to finish.  Expensive but worth it.  Very close to Union Square.
author: John O.

description:
I mistakenly reserved this restaurant thinking it was Roka Akor, but all good. Overall, had a great experience here. The fish in the nigiri were all really high quality, and really great, but the rolls were a bit lacking (though good to eat to fill you up)

Minus 2 stars for various reasons:
-location, hard to find. There is no obvious sign and very easy to miss. Look for the sign that says Irish pub (weird), and then you are there.
-pricey for what it is
-I had an unfortunate wasabi situation

Note to all, they serve you soy sauce and wasabi
Even though their nigiri is fully dressed already (comes with soy sauce and wasabi already in it). Problem is I hate wasabi, ruins the sushi for me. High end sushi bars usually already add wasabi to the nigiri, and this is my fault, but I didn't associate this place with those authentic sushi places for some reason. Thus, I didn't ask for them to remove the wasabi because I didn't think it would be fully dressed. Sushi came, I had to remove all the wasabi from each piece of sushi before consuming. Sad. Really ruins the enjoyment as construction by a lot.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
If you are looking for a sushi restaurant in San Francisco that provides you with a full-sensory experience (e.g. aesthetics, ambiance, sound, taste, smell, and touch), there's really only one place in the city that delivers: Akiko's Restaurant. 

A few months ago I caught wind of Akiko's Restaurant from my sister, who raved about this place. Even though this place isn't reservation-exclusive, you can't get in on a normal day without calling a few weeks in advance. That's because many people have high regard for Akiko's. This place is known for providing a modern and artistic take to traditional sushi. It's even been mentioned on food ranking lists such as Bay Area 7x7's 100 things to eat in SF! 

With such hype, my girlfriend and I decided to come for our anniversary since this place was one of the few "good" sushi joints in the city that took reservations. To give you a sense of how early you need to call in, I contacted them 2-3 weeks before our planned date (a Saturday dinner in August) and only two options were left: 5:30pm when they open and 8:30pm. So RESERVE EARLY! 

Akiko's Restaurant is located on 431 Bush Street right outside Chinatown. This place is NOT to be confused with Akiko's Sushi Bar. Parking can be horrendous, and so I recommend public transportation. Else, be prepared to pay for parking if you come before 6pm. Now, the restaurant is right in the middle between Kearny and Grant. You won't see a sign outside (because sign=too many people) and so you'll have to count the numbers. Basically, it's next to the Irish Pub.

Right when we arrived, we experienced the first sensory experience: Ambiance. One of the best features about this restaurant and why so many people pay $$$ to eat here is because it's intimate HEAVEN. The place is TINY, and so it will never get too loud. The place is split into one area with the sushi counter, one dimly-lit back area with 4-5 tables, and two tables up front near the window (where it's brighter). We ended up getting seated at the front. I love the fact that here at Akiko's, you can really get that sense of privacy with your friend/significant other. With low noise, check off sound (or lack thereof) as a sensory experience too! 

In terms of the menu, Akiko's prides itself in quality over quantity. They have 9 different appetizers (I heard soft-shelled crab good), 4 different grilled items. The most important one is the Saba (Mackerel), which is apparently a "must eat." Next, they only have like 6 rolls, since this place is mostly about the fresh sushi/fish from the bar. And in terms of fresh fish, they have A LOT (they also have a rotating menu based on seasonal catch too). And if you want drinks, they have a separate HUGE menu too. We ended up getting the 12 piece sashimi moriwase to sample their fish, the negi toro and sake rolls, and the Saba.

-Sashimi Moriwase (9/10). Aesthetics as the third sensory experience? Major check! As you probably already saw from Yelp, Akiko's is Instagram heaven. Their plating is SO beautiful. We first noticed this with the sashimi sampler. The fish looked amazingly fresh, and I love how their plates were 1. perfectly sized and 2. high-quality. In terms of taste, man was their fish so soft and clean! You know how at some sushi restaurants you need some wasabi to get rid of extra bacteria? Here, just shove it straight in your mouth because it's THAT PERFECT. I wouldn't say this was the best sashimi I've had, but dang it was delicious. $35 was a bit too high, but that salmon was especially... And knock off another sensory experience for touch because the sashimi was so soft!

-Negi Toro/Sake (8/10). Both rolls (x5 each) had really fresh fish inside (tuna belly omfg+delicious salmon), but I'd avoid rolls if you are here; the experience really is with the sashimi/nigiri and it'd be a waste if you spend your $$ on seaweed and daikon/avocado filling. But, if you want cheaper alternatives, rolls are fine...

-Saba (10/10). There is a reason why people rave so much about the mackerel. This dish is truly both a taste+smell sensory experience for the ages. First off, the fish gives off such an aromatic "grilled" flavor that begs for it to be eaten. Second, the combination of soy sauce, lemon, and daikon provide the fish with the perfect blend of salty and sour. But best part was the fish was SO JUICY. GET THIS PLEASE.

Would I say Akiko's is the BEST sushi restaurant in the city? No, because you will be paying $$$ (we spent $110) for great quality fish, but nothing "out of this world." People come here more for the experience, and that's what I'd rate Akiko's highly for. If you want an intimate  adventure that teases your senses, Akiko's is for you. Otherwise, I recommend spending the same amount on another place such as Tataki because you'd probably get more bang for your buck. But all in all, I give Akiko's a "nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy." Don't forget to use the nice bathroom!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: Very rude to possible customers at restaurant. (a sushi bar with empty seats are still not available for walk-ins.) And the owner goes out of his way to be rude to the reviewers on Yelp. "You're not welcome here." was the reply we got.
author: peter j.

description:
Food is really good nearly Michelle standard.
They have many variety of fish from all over the world besides Japan.
Price is a bit high but is near market price.
author: E W.

description:
No signage when arriving here. You've been warned! I had the most amazing omakase with a client. The chef picked around 12 servings for us. They were all incredible with different fish I have never tried or even heard of before...and I've had a lot of omakases! Omakase is a phrase that means "i'll leave it up to you" and just know, you can trust them here! Service was great as well. I love the relaxed and intimate atmosphere. 
My only complaint is that the bathroom doesn't have a mirror.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
Honestly not impressed at all. I brought my best friend when she was visiting SF and I regret wasting one of her limited meals here. My friend C had warned me that it was mediocre, and I should know better than to ignore his advice, but I'll never make that mistake again.

We ordered double the 6 pc sashimi tasting featuring the usual suspects- big eye tuna, albacore tuna, mackerel, king salmon, and halibut. We also added octopus and spinach. All tasted aite, but nothing special. For the price we paid, I've had much better meals at other restaurants in town.

Hard pass.
author: Karen S.

description:
Ambiance: 4/5
The interior design is modern with a rustic feel. Their ceramic plates are so elegant and exquisite. I really like it! But the restaurant is really small and can fit only around 20 people. Make a reservation before you go. 

Food: 5/5 
We ordered 6-piece nigiri tasting that has all the standard fish like salmon, yellowtail, tuna and etc. Also ordered uni, hotate, crab and sweet shrimp nigiri. First of all, the quality of the fish is definitely top-notch. Every piece is fresh. Also, the pieces in nigiri tasting were seasoned specially. Really unique and flavorful.

I was actually hesitating because last time I went for lunch and was not impressed by anything. Now I realized it was because I got a lot of hot dishes. Their non-sushi dishes are mediocre but the quality of their fish is definitely one of the highest in SF. This is the place to go for sushi. The only reason I gave 4 stars is because the nigiri size is really small given the price.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
**Summary: Rushed service, unclear ordering, sticker shock for good quality omakase **

I came back recently on a Saturday night and was disappointed with how Akiko's has changed since my last visit four years ago.

-Ordering: Other reviews have mentioned the "eat until you're full" philosophy at Akiko's and I understand that's how it is done in Japan. What I felt was missing was the waitress trying to gauge how hungry we were. Without asking, our waitress seemed to expect us to each have 15-18 dishes. My sister and I, who only ate 11 pieces, risked either 1)missing the best end pieces (Wagyu, Toro) or 2)overeating.

-Atmosphere: The restaurant felt crowded, with people standing at the doors and outside. That unfortunately translated to a rushed feeling from the staff. From ordering to dish pacing to the waitress describing the dishes, I felt as if the staff was trying to turn the table as quickly as possible. Our 15 dishes were done in around an hour and 20 minutes, with the bill coming quickly after the last dishes were cleared and without any dessert menu. That's not quite the experience I expect for $200/person.

-Food: Quality of the food was good, but not outstanding. The chutoro and wagyu w/truffle were standouts.

-Value: My bill came out to around $200/person for around 12 dishes, without any alcohol. I spent $225 here 5 years ago for a 15 piece sushi omakase plus a nice bottle of sake, so diminished value for diminished quality. The "eat until you're full" style at market price also contributed to the sticker shock, so either come one an expense account or be prepared to pony up!

There are plenty of omakases in SF/Bay Area that offer as good or better quality food and atmosphere for the price.
author: Louis Y.

description:
Still not sure how I managed to rack up a bill on omakase. I guess I expected something like Kusakabe where they tell you the set prices. I should've known better when the drunk man told me he just dropped $200 on sushi...

Pros:
- Quality fish
- Comes at a cost $$$
- Friendly servers
- Variety of sake selections 


Cons:
- Limited seating; try your luck or make rezzies

Recommendations:
+ Omakase if you love nigiri! No disappointments!


All the pieces served were great. The one piece I'd actually pass on is the gizzard shad (kohada). See pics for names of fish.

Total w/o tip: $278/2 people. DEAD.
author: Fanny W.

description:
Maybe 1 star is a bit too harsh. But in my rating system 1 star means I will never re-visit this place. So I had to give 1 star. But let me be fair, it was not that bad. I wouldn't be surprised if they lose costumers and close soon.

Pros:
-the front part of the restaurant looks really nice. 
-if you have reservation you can enjoy your dinner.
-fish was fresh and tasted good. 

Cons:
-pricy for the taste. Sushi was not outstanding, melting in your mouth kind. Especially with the mushy rice it was pretty below average.
-the back of the restaurant looks like a basement of a psycho kidnapper. If you're claustrophobic make sure you reserve a table from the front side, or sit at the bar. Back is nightmare-land. Whoever picked that decor must be blind or has no taste. 
-they prepare sushi with brown rice. In my experience this has never been the case. Some restaurants would have the brown rice option but they would ask out of respect. This one prepared everything with brown rice without asking or double checking. Weird.
-Rice was mushy and pasty and too warm almost hot, that made the sushi experience really bad.
-Space is too tiny, the tables are too tiny, and there are too many of them placed way too close to each other, very uncomfortable environment.
-Service was horrible. Especially the lady with tattoos, I am not sure if she is racist or just rude by nature but I've never felt so unwelcome in a restaurant. 

Going into more detail about that last part. This lady made us feel unwanted there. And she's the main reason we will never visit this place again. She acted like she was doing us a favor by getting us a table, when half the restaurant was empty. She did not smile. Did not make eye contact. Had a selfrighteous attitude. She said she can get us a table but we have to leave in an hour cause we don't have a reservation with a bossy tone. We said "sure" then she said "then follow me", and we said "thank you" she didn't respond. Then we came to our table, while sitting, we said again "thank you" she said nothing, instead put the silverware like throwing on the table, with a frowning face. My husband again said thank you one last time, loudly, looking at her face. She completely ignored and left. We ended up ordering only a few pieces of nigiri and left. I actually wish we left without ordering anything. It was a horrible experience. 

When ordering we saw the table right next to us had handrolls brought to them, and we couldn't see it on the menu, so i asked. They said it was a special case for that table. Another discrimination! When I asked why can't we get any, they paused for a while but couldn't come up with a smart explanation so said okay with a big frown in their face and left.

I want to assume she was not racist, which kind of makes it worse, cause that means you'll all get the same treatment. She doesn't like costumers, she doesn't like her job, she doesn't like her life, she's not welcoming, she's self righteous, and god knows why she's the front face of this restaurant. Some person who does not understand how to work with costumers thought it would be a good idea to put a snobby, bossy, rude woman at front desk to welcome costumers. But after reading the reviews of the owner saying "you're not welcome here" to costumers, I'm not surprised how she's so rude. Monkey see monkey do.

If you don't mind being treated horribly and feeling unwelcome, and if you like mediocre sushi with warm brown rice, and you don't mind eating in a non-ventilated humid basement like tiny space, and pay a lot of money, I do recommend trying this place. But if these kind of things matters to you, while spending so much money on sushi, you might as well find a place that treats you like a valued costumer and make you feel welcome. 

Overall I do not recommend this place. The service and food is NOT worth the money.
author: Selen A.

description: Enjoyed a nice dinner with my sons.  We had the Omakase sushi for the three of us.  I was delighted with the chefs choices.  And the quality did not disappoint.  Beware; they are pretty serious about the Omakase (to the extent that they removed our soy and wasabi from the table after instructing us that it is to be eaten as dressed by the chef which we would have honored with the removal).  They were out of our first choice of sake so we chose another bottle at the suggestion of the waitress and were pleased with the suggestion.   Trendy old world decor with a quality product and service.  I will gladly go for round two.
author: Dare D.

description:
This is my first Omakase experience so I can't tell the difference between Akiko and other places. I heard great things about the food and I was not disappointed. The fish was fresh. The presentation was on point. 
We made a reservation at 730 but were not seated until 830. I understand that the place is small and they have limited seats but ... - 1 star
The price was not cheap. Around $500/2 people. But I will do it again if I have a chance
author: Ten D.

description: OMG so so so good. I've had this restaurant on my to try list and I finally had time to come in by myself :( hahah but sitting at the sushi bar was awesome. The sushi chefs were so nice and the nigiris were incredible. They serve them with a twist like with caramelized onion or lemon zest.
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description:
I think I've been ruined forever. I'm not sure what to do next time I get a sushi craving, since I live across the country.

What a treat to get to eat here! We somehow got in even only emailing for a reservation on the same afternoon. I should have bought a lottery ticket! 

My only complaint was that we had to wait 30 minutes for our table because the people eating there wouldn't get up. I know the restaurant can't do much about it, but it would have been nice if they compensated us with an appetizer or something for the wait.

Other than that, my experience was completely perfect. Their separate list of fish from Japan (most flown in fresh, without being frozen) was the real treat of the evening. We got the blue fin tuna, scallops, and grouper. All were incredible and melted in the mouth, but the tuna stole the show. Let's say we ordered another serving of that... or two... 

We also got several nigiri. Even though the menu says you can get a serving of 2, they brought out 3 since there were three of us, so we didn't end up with odd numbers of things. The most memorable was the salmon, which was essentially butter, in the best way possible. The mackerel was also delicious. All portions of fish were respectable perfect cuts. We also got a salmon roll, which was great, but I preferred the nigiri because it has so much flavor already.

Overall:
-make a reservation. All walk ins were turned away that night I was there
-go for a special occasion because $
-try something from their special menu
-don't put too much wasabi and soy sauce on because you'll drown out the divine flavor of the fish
Enjoy!
author: Marleigh S.

description: This restaurant is much worse than 4 years ago. The food quality is comparatively lower than any other same star restaurant. The scallop is very soft and moist but tasteless. The santa barbara sea urchin taste good, but they are from the packaged box. I feel like the food is nothing special any more. The first impression when I arrive is that they have a bad front  reception lady. She is so pushy on certain orders that makes me feel like I have to order that when it is not necessary. None of their staff smile. Conclusion: not worth waiting, skow service, and you always get a better choice for same star restaurants in bay area.
author: Jen C.

description:
Expensive but worth the money. The fish was deliciously fresh and I can't complain that I spent $20 for a roll and a couple of nigiri pieces at all. My friend and I made a reservation for 5:30 PM, which is right when the restaurant opened, and were seated immediately upon arriving. They also serve complimentary hot tea, which is always a plus in my book. I ordered the sake roll and two pieces of albacore tuna nigiri. The fish had that melt-in-your-mouth kind of fresh texture to it--which I loved. 

I think the only downside is the fact that they informed us we had to be out of there by 6:30, but I guess that's understandable considering the minuscule size of the restaurant. Would love to come back and try more from their menu!
author: Allison T.

description:
Overview: Akiko's Restaurant is a small sushi restaurant near Union Square that serves a wide variety of sushi/sashimi at relatively high prices.

The Food: I came here the day after going to Tsubasa Sushi in Hayes Valley and was sorely disappointed. I ordered variety platter and most had weak flavors, small portions, and were presented unexceptionally. 

The Service: Our server was friendly but I kept getting the impression that he was avoiding our table because we looked like tourists. 

The Establishment: Fairly small with tight quarters.

Conclusions: I don't have many nice things to say about Akiko but I will say that if money is no object, Akiko's would be a decent place to dine if you're in the Union Square area.
author: Andrew H.

description: Quite possibly the best restaurant experience I've had in SF was lunch at Akiko's. I had omakase of course and it was pricey but worth every penny if you love sushi. A great experience and I'll go back again and again.
author: Nicholas D.

description:
One of the better omakases we've had! The chef's selection of fish was unique and nicely paired with their signature sauces or just a hint of Meyer lemon and salt. My favorites of the day were the red snapper, creamy texture with a great clean finish. And the Miyazaki wagyu was simply melt-in-your-mouth-eyes-rolled-to-the-back-of-your-head-died-and-gone-to-heaven-good. 

The service was normal but we found it hard to hear what the waitress was saying as she explained the different types of nigiri that came out. As we sat there, we saw a lot of people get turned away from the restaurant as reservations are highly recommended and they are solidly booked up. Definitely a great sushi restaurant with unique flair and excellent quality.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
The flavors were great, but the service was a little slow. We only got 7 pieces in a course of more than 2 hours. While the flavors were great, the presentation was a little lacking. I was expecting a little moreflash, and a little more communication from the chef. I'd go to a different omakase spot next time.
I'd easily give 5* for the taste, but by the time piece #7 has come to us, we all had enough time to digest piece #1. We had to leave and feed my man something, because I felt that he was getting hungrier from waiting 
I've done more than 10 omakase experiences before, all of them in similar sushi bars, but have never once left hungry... and I'm pretty easy to fill...
author: Anna P.

description: I would rate this place as $$$ or even $$$$ but not $$ for sure! Portions are tiny and the food is pretty basic. My friend and I had lunch with $130 bill. The restaurant was also out of a lot of meals. Would not recommend this place...
author: Alena S.

description:
Came here by chance with a friend visiting from out of town and was very pleasantly surprised. 

We mostly ordered sushi, and while not as cheap as some other sushi joints around SF, the fish quality was excellent. Make sure you snag a reservation though, since the last few times I checked they don't allow walk ins.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Omg!!
I'm from Toronto and there is a huge selection of sushi but this place far exceeds it!
Their selection is fresh and delightful. We had made reservations and by 6 the place was packed. It is a small tucked in restaurant. We even had a hard time finding the sign and kept walking past it. 

Again if you're looking for fresh sashimi and sushi this is where you need to go. Price is mid to a little upper but you get what you paid for. Oh and the waiters were always available and they were spot on with refilling our water!
author: Jax W.

description: My wife and visited here for our anniversary. We made reservations for 8:30 and had to wait 20 minutes longer outside. The staff was nice, service was good. The sushi was on point, we had the 12 piece sashimi, six piece sushi, and the tuna belly roll (nothing to jump up and down about, I had the unprocessed uni (was fresh and sweet) not sure what the unprocessed was about. We also had the cold smoked tuna (nice), sake was awesome (but over price. The restaurant is small and loud. Over all we had a good experience, the best part was the chef prepared nigiri.
author: John W.

description: We were visiting SF and found this restaurant based on reviews. Very fresh fish and reasonable prices for the city.
author: ML T.

description:
Akiko's is the first and only restaurant where some of the highest quality sushi I've ever had in my life was met with some of the most depressing service I've ever experienced. This is a landmark where their sushi chefs are as talented as the best I've ever known and where you're treated to an experience that spits you out worse off than you came in. Was it a matter of demographic prejudice? Why would I write this review if I hadn't thought otherwise.
