I found that good restaurants strive for consistency -- that everything their servers, chefs, and sushi chefs are proud of rests on their ability to deliver an experience like their motto. Their motto struck me as: "quality, attention, uniqueness". However it's an utterly bitter truth that their good side rests solely on the demographic they are trying to serve: The businessmen/women of San Francisco whose $80 lunch check is a drop in the bucket to their otherwise astronomical monthly apartment rental and salary. The ugly becomes apparent when you walk in without a reservation, in clothes that don't command a sense of formality -- the common man's presence.

- They don't welcome you, your first experience is intimidating. You're an outsider stepping into their house: "come in and pay if we must have you" the first mood rang.

- They will make a scene in front of other customers if they need to move you. A custom of curtesy felt handled more like being prioritized behind the first class -- those who reserved ahead of time. You will feel the entire restaurant look towards you like it was your fault.

- They will forget some of your order, and charge you for it. Simple mistake done with little repercussions.

- They will make you wait 15 minutes for your check after you've finish your last bite. This took four attempts, once from me, twice from two different sushi chefs who knew how long it had been, and one more from me.

- They will forget you if you're not a person of interest. I'd ask if you do decide to go that you dress up to attire, even if you start feeling a little pretentious and entitled. This will be a magnet of attraction to them and I promise you'll get better service. 

-$50 was spent for this lunch. I don't know anyone who could afford that price range and didn't feel sensitive to being marginalized by economic status. 

Akiko's felt more like a new age San Francisco restaurant than it did a Japanese restaurant. They follow a culture of serving those they seem fit to be served. If you've ever felt ignored, like a kid eating alone in a cafeteria, or a college student suffering from depression, it'll just be a reminder of that painful experience. If you're upper class and you're not worried about siphoning money into an experience similar to a nightclub bottle service, the sushi was incredible and the meal itself was pure. Money will be their undoing -- it is their true motto behind a remarkably aesthetic facade. 

And if this review does anything to your restaurant, it's to say that common people still have a voice, even if we can't express it through our status.
author: Clark F.

description:
These are the detailed files of the sushi dining experiences of raw flesh fish meat in your mouth, cocaine white rice rolled, sake booze infested pouring, spaces of the hobo dwelling, pigeon pooping, pan handling extravaganza, no sun shining, city of the bay San Francisco riceroni secret treats.

We called to request Japanese friend Nao, to our dismay & utter disappointment, it appeared that he had left the premises, walking the earth in search for a more suitable establishment to practice his fine skills of fish fisting in pale pie holes..

We were ashamedly presented with a Roger, who would soon take many hundreds of dirty laundered money, we were about to pay the price for dining with our non oriental, unborn from the rising sun, compadre. We were greeted by yet another creature of the deep to serve us yet more imitation experiences of booze from the orient.

We throated the entire establishment's flesh fish of sushi toro, it went down fast, hard, wet, juicy, dripping, & full of man made sauces that had been fondled on to the fleshy meat that just slid down our throats & glistened on our tongues as we licked every last morsel off of our bodies, faces, and lips. We were simply dripping, & pining for more,we wanted the meat, we needed it bad deep inside of us, we knew the meats would cum, and it did,over and over again..all over us, inside of us, in our mouths, throats, lips, bodies, and it even touched part of our souls.  We wanted to capture this moment of orgasmic climax, but wanted to keep the high rolling for multiple orgasmic blows, so we quickly called over the pale dancing jovial American to pour us more booze, & to get our hands on yet another big load to drip down our thirsty, dry, throats.  She was simply ecstatic & proceeded to deliver the liquids down our bodies, we started upon more of the flesh in the mouth extravaganzas.

We ordered the hamach, salmon, yellowtail, tamago, unagi, anago, sweet shrimp with the busted nut head charred & slightly molested in the deep fried man goop, the spoon full of Mary's poppins' it in your mouth hole crab, & we topped the whole orgy flesh fisted delight in our mouths with what is dubbed by our non samurai, un-miyagi like unborn from the rising sun chef as the uni sex change converter....Fun times, the flesh fish was slightly a finer mix than you might find at your local Vons, but here, our imitation ronin, delivered random flesh fish cumming seared, & coated in man juices, and other unpleasantries that ruined the experience of getting the flesh raw, deep, unfiltered, uncut, penetrating your flesh filled throat hole. We prefer to have the penetrations as raw & as direct as possible & having these trinkets & tinkles on our manhood man flesh fish slices was not to our desires, & simply left us pining for our return to our homelands to get the raw penetration in our mouths & tongues that we were lusting after prior to our reservation arrivals.  To our dismays we were among friends whose motto is pride keeps it in the mouth, & gives me the courage to swallow, we were not converted to these slightly infested imperfected flesh fish penetrations in our mouths...sure we still got that hint of the sea breeze, musty wind between the legs goodness that we were cat calling for, but we just did not get the full reach around experience that we had longed for all week & for the remainder of our night.
Lastly, we wrapped up with some fun, as we deep throated the final bottles of serum syrups to get completely blitzed out of our minds, we chose to select the man made creams of the ice scoops to help massage & numb our throats from all of the raw crusted, adulterated, seared, smoked, flesh fish meats that had left our throats, lips, tongues, & cheeks sore for the night. The butter, pale white sesame, creams oozed in our mouths as we came to ecstasy, dripping, leaking down our lips and exposed bodily parts....maybe it was because this setup had been prepared by our friends from the rising sun, that it tasted so good in our mouths and throats, their dances of delight, prayers, to the mighty Buddha himself created the creams in the cups, it was simply a treat of satisfaction in our mouths, like a big fat cow rolling around in the countryside after it has been pampered & ready for a slow unpainful wagyu creating death for consumption by only the wealthiest of the wealthy to stomach & throat with butter down their lard filled esophaguses. 
Sure this isn't the best place to get sushi in the land of the golden suns californications but that doesn't mean you should not take a gander, get completely blitzed out of your skull,throat all of these flesh fish meats drizzled n jizzled with whatever nonsense they may put on it, one can still cum to ecstasy, blow a minds & weeks load from the sheer mass of the meats & raw flesh.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Honestly I'm upset I didn't eat here earlier. I could've been here dozens of times by now! The service was professional, friendly, and knowledgeable. We both had the 12 piece omakase with a side of Hokkaido Uni. The Omakase was super fresh - daresay the freshest I've had in the city. Favorites include the sea bream and of course, the salmon. Fresh, real wasabi is a plus. Uni is something I've never liked, but our server taught us how Hokkaido Uni is different from what we usually have, and it was so so good. No regrets. Coming back soon
author: Caroline N.

description:
I booked a reservation here while on a weekend getaway with my boyfriend because I love sushi and this place had great reviews. Warning: It's tough to find this place because there is no sign out front. 

The interior decor was beautiful and we were seated right away since we had a reservation. The restaurant is very small, and I had been turned away the last time I was in SFO because I tried walking in, so I knew a reservation was a must. 

My boyfriend and I ordered omakase and sake based on waitress recommendations. I am always suspicious when the recommendation is the most expensive sake on the menu, so when she recommended exactly that sake, I was a little annoyed. For the rest of the meal, I felt like we were treated as less important or less intelligent diners because we were young. The staff was not as friendly to us as they were to the people around us, and the offerings seemed very bland. Overall, I've gotten much better sushi in Austin for half the price of this sushi dinner. If I'm going to pay that much, I don't want to feel like I'm an inferior customer based on my treatment. I'd rather pay slightly more and eat at Otoko in Austin or else pay less and eat at Uchiko in Austin. I never thought the seafood would taste better in a landlocked city than in SFO, but that was definitely my experience. Though, I will say I ate at Elephant Sushi in SFO last time, and it was amazing!

Overall, I was incredibly underwhelmed and dissatisfied with this dining experience.
author: Lauren B.

description: Food is good, but serious downsides are the hostess and prices.  She is a snob who simply does not want to be helpful.  If you are going to pay this much, there are truly so many Japanese restaurants that offer a much better dining experience and value.  Do the research, it will be worth it.
author: John L.

description:
This place ruined my boyfriend and my date night for $100. Now, we expected it to be expensive, however we expected at least good customer service, high quality food, and attentiveness from the server for that price, especially since we were still hungry when we left.

My boyfriend and I try to go to SF for sushi once a month as a date night (our favorite is a place called Domo, however they don't take reservations and can get busy since it's a small place) so we decided to try somewhere new to avoid a wait.

We found Akiko's and used maps to get us there (we were walking). It said it was a 5 minute walk but ended up taking almost 30 because we walked past it 4 TIMES. This is because THEY DO NOT HAVE A SIGN IN FRONT - instead there's a sign for the Irish pub that's behind it out front, so we overlooked it many times. Finally, we figured it out when we saw some other people go in and noticed a sushi bar inside - if they hadn't opened the doors we probably wouldn't have found it.

When we went inside it took several minutes for a hostess to even acknowledge us - when she did she told us that we would only be able to able to eat for 45 minutes to an hour because they had another party coming and we agreed. 

We were seated and were surprised by the limited number of rolls - it was mostly sashimi which we love, however the prices were extremely high. We thought it'd come with 2 pieces but it came with only one, so we paid $15 for once piece of fish.

For 2 rolls and 4 pieces of sushi it ended up being $85 (we only ordered water and I had a miso as well). The waitress only came to check in on our table to leave the check (it's a very small restaurant and she checked on other tables much more often). When we asked her questions about the fish, she was very unknowledgeable and couldn't even tell us what cut of Toro the fish was.

When it came time to pay my boyfriend gave his card and she came back to say it had been declined. She asked for another card and he said it was fine, he had cash. Her response was "Good" in a very snooty manner. When he checked his wallet he realized he only had $70, but he knew he had plenty of money in his account (we checked his bank app) and asked her to run it again. She said she had already tried it three times and in his bank account it SHOWED that it had gone through and then been returned 3 times. Her response was, "We haven't had issues with any other cards tonight so it must be a problem with your funds." 

We asked to talk to the manager and my boyfriend said he could go to the ATM and I could wait there. The manager said "Well, I'll just take the cash you have." We were relived that someone was finally being nice to us until he said, "That way I know you aren't just going to leave." 

We were treated like crap and disrespected all night, and additionally there was no other party coming for our table - they just wanted us out of there for better spenders. 

Overall, the fish was pretty good, but definitely not worth what we spent. I could've eaten a lot more and been a lot happier somewhere else for half the price. The fish didn't taste as fresh as I expected and one of our rolls was overly salty. This place would not be memorable at all had they not been so rude. 

Huge let down and a waste of money.
author: Haley A.

description: I've been here a couple times for lunch with my bf. We were very satisfied. The fish were fresh and very tasty. We will definitely be back again!
author: Beatriz K.

description: This is my favorite sushi place and I was really psyched to take my friends from out of town here. However, when we got to the front door they told us that our party was too large (we were a group of 5) which is understandable, but the woman who informed us was one of the rudest people I have ever encountered. She was just ridiculously unhelpful and condescending. She went into a long,  nonsensical explanation on what was wrong with our party and their policy and it was just unnecessary. She didn't even say sorry. She was just a (excuse my language, but the word describes her perfectly) bitch about the whole thing. Your restaurant can be 5 star rated all you want but if you're going to be disrespectful to your loyal and paying customers then what's the point of being a business that serves people?
author: Anna C.

description: Was so excited to eat here given the good reviews but was very disappointed. Not only was the wait very long, but the food was lacking. We ordered several types of nigiri and fish quality was just ok. It was also pricey. For the price I'd rather go to other omakase specialty restaurants in the city where the quality is much higher.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Came back here for dinner and it was rather mediocre...which was disappointing because the first time I came here, I remember it being great! 

BUT, the service and atmosphere are still great, so if I were to review just the service, it would still be a 5-star in my book! But in terms of the sashimi and nigiri--not sure if it was just a bad night or what--the quality was underwhelming. 

We had two seats at the bar--I loved hearing the kitchen conversations and conversing with the sushi master! Again, 5-stars for the atmosphere. :)

For drinks, weordered a bottle of Ginjo sake (Dewazakura Dewasansan)--which I highly recommend others to order if you're looking for a smooth and bright sake. :)

For our meal, we started off with the sashimi moriawase--6 different types of sashimi (2pcs each). Nothing very memorable or impeccable--is it bad that I can't remember the fishes we were served? Yes.

We then had the omakase--again, nothing very memorable or special. There was a tare-tare + caviar + nori chip, which was an interesting concept and we were intrigued to try it! However, while it sounded and looked like a promising course, the flavor was blah and there was really no texture contrast. The tare-tare and caviar basically mushed together (and not in a good way), while the nori chip didn't provide much added crunch or flavor. :( Maybe my taste buds are defective.

Sigh, bummed that this experience was so much different than the first time I came to Akiko's a few years back! Nevertheless, the price for a meal here is still pretty fair and again, the service and atmosphere are still great. 

Would come back again, but probably not unless I was out of options.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Excellent sushi, attentive staff, and an amazing Omakase experience. Fish was fresh and some of them even came straight from Japan! Yes, it wasn't cheap but I felt like I ate and got what I paid for. I would even dare say that the quality is on par with Shiro's in Seattle. Everything we ate here was good and presented nicely. Juicy, tender, chewy, tasty and sushi that melts in your mouth is all we asked for. The intimate ambiance and casual decor made it a nice place to celebrate or spend time with friends or your significant other.

The Girlfriend's review: So good, Five Stars.

I would suggest making a reservations as to ensure a table for your party and less waiting time. Will definitely come back for future special occasions!
author: Alex L.

description:
Quite possibly one of the best omakase places in SF. That remains to be seen, but for the lunch and dinner times I've been here I have yet to be disappointed. A reservation is definitely needed for dinner, but lunch is more flexible, although I would make a reservation anyway. I know it's not typically done this way - but in the instances I have been here for omakase - our group had elected to sit at a table instead of the bar (you can request one or the other when you make your reservation), but on every occasion I have left utterly satisfied with my meal and the service. 

The place is not the easiest place to find - I have gotten lost twice thus far coming here - once because there is a similar restaurant called Akira's that is also on Bush and one small typo can result in a 20 minute walk through hilly SF blocks, potentially in the rain, and another because my GPS actually put Akiko's at another location 4 blocks away (why google?! why!). Hopefully neither of those instances will happen to you and you'll be able to find it without a hitch, despite the Irish bar and Guiness signs pretty much right where the restaurant is cleverly cloaking a superb japanese restaurant. 

All in all - if you do decide to come and try the food - I recommend you to go with the omakase because it's fantastic every time. It may put a dent in your wallet, but it will be worthwhile. It really does not disappoint - all the fish are fresh and delicious, flavored intelligently and purposefully, and when the servers recommend sake to you - they know what they are talking about. The sake that I have been recommended has been light and delicious - combining amazingly with the fish the chef prepares. Some of my favorite items here are the blue fin tuna, barracuda, and uni. Once I recover from all the other times I've visited - I think I'll be back again for more!
author: Deanna S.

description:
Amazing Japanese restaurant. Hidden gem in the city.

Casual with a classy feeling. Perfect place to impress anyone. 

I highly recommend the omakase (chef's special). It's pricy ($100), but you'll really get the full experience.
author: Elsa T.

description:
Hawaii is home to a lot of amazing sushi restaurants so I'm always a little weary when it comes to sushi restaurants on the mainland.  Thanks to Yelp and so many great yelpers, I found Akiko's and made a reservation on Open Table.  

By the time we ordered, the restaurant was already out of wagyu and otoro, but I had the kinmedai and ensui uni.  The ensui uni was from Hokkaido and is served unfiltered; the freshest they have.  It was amazing.  Like creamy butter, it melted in my mouth with no unwelcomed weird ocean taste that yucky uni has.  It was like the best dream!  

If you love sushi, forgo the rolls and order sashimi or nigiri.  If you have room go for the omakase!
author: Nadia K.

description: This the best sushi that I have had for a long time--if not ever. I am one of those who only sits at the bar with a max of one or two close friends. Sometimes you go with a vegetarian which is a challenge for any sushi chef. But thanks to Chef Alex last night, the mix and choice of preparation was completely INSANE. And oh so surprise the vegetarian dish was also at that level. Thank you again Chef Alex. It was an outstanding experience.
author: Bertrand W D.

description: First I never write yelp reviews. But I am writing this one review strictly because of the service of this restaurant. It was horrible! I would give this restaurant -5 stars if I could. We wanted to walk out once we got seated but we really wanted to try the sushi so therefore we stayed. We sat in the sushi bar and was ready to enjoy our meal until the sushi chef's attitude made us change our minds. I didn't get his name but he seemed to be the youngest one out of the 3 chefs that were there that Monday night. He wasn't friendly, didn't treat us with respect, pretty much seemed like he didn't wanna be there. He had no smile and he looked at us like we were dead. I don't think he's fully japanese or had any japanese decent in him. Anyways horrible attitude with customers. We sat right in front of the bar where we could see every move the chef makes. In the middle of our meal we saw him started making sushi for himself and ate it! He kept making pieces of sushi and going into the main kitchen to eat them thinking no one will probably see him! Ridiculous! We ordered a few pieces of uni sushi and as he was making our pieces he took some uni and put it on his hand and ate it! Very sneaky! He did this a few times that night! What kind of chef does this? So unprofessional. We only caught him doing this because we sat right in front of the bar where we can see everything the chef does. Rude attitude and unprofessional chefs. If I could take my tip back from this restaurant I would.
author: Michelle H.

description:
I was looking forward to try this restaurant after reading all the positive reviews but it unfortunately disappointed. Nothing i had was specially tasty, it was all just ok, for a very expensive price that is definitely not worth it. 
The service was good tho.
author: Hanine C.

description:
Came in for lunch and sat by the sushi bar. Wished I had ordered the omakase because the sampling of the nigiri that I did have ($36 for 6 pieces) was absolutely delicious. 

We ordered the nigiri sampling, miso cod, and uni nigiri. Every single bite and morsel of food we had was beyond delicious. The fish tasted fresh and the nigiri did not require any soy sauce because it was delicious on its own. That being said, I saw a fish in a vacuum sealed plastic wrapping handed to my sushi chef, who immediately ripped it open and started to slice it and place on nigiri pieces, which makes me wonder as to the freshness of the fish served here. 

Regardless, I had such a great experience here! Will come back!
author: Jin C.

description:
4.5 stars 

Pretty great experience overall. A bit of a bummer that we specifically asked to be seated at the bar (we also confirmed via phone that we would be seated at the bar several hours prior to our arrival) and they weren't able to accommodate that even with an 8:45 reservation. When ordering omakase I love to be able to watch the chef prepare the meal. It adds so much to the experience.

Beautiful ambiance and excellent service otherwise. One funny thing was that we were served miso soup without ordering it and were charged for it later. It was negligible so not a big deal but just something to note. 

We got:

Black dragon sake
Another more floral sake

Golden eye snapper
Deep sea grouper - smoky delicious

Spanish mackerel - savory and melt in your mouth
Horse mackerel

Toro - melty melty yum yum
Bluefin tuna belly - one more please!!

Barracuda - loved the yuzu on top

Shrimp
Scallop

Snow crab legs
Uni - nomnomnom

Fried shrimp heads - surprisingly delicious 

Waygu beef - another five courses please

Add on squid



Green tea mochi 
Red bean mochi - probably the best red bean flavor I've had
author: Vanessa S.

description: I read rave reviews about this place, so my expectations were sky high. I can happily report that my expectations were exceeded. We had the Omakase. I can't recommend doing that enough. We tried so many special pieces of nigiri. This place minds the details meticulously from the decor, ambiance, service, all the way through to the food. One little touch I particularly enjoyed was that the restaurant let's you select your own cup from a tray brought to your table for sake. These cups are all hand made here in the area and some are from Seattle.
author: Chris J.

description:
Had a pleasantly surprising omakase experience here sitting at the bar. This is hands down my favorite place for high end sushi in SF, and will blow other places out of the water. 

Fish was very fresh, tender and I enjoyed the unique garnishes. I especially enjoy when citrus flavors are added. There were consistent amounts of more flavorful, smoky, seared and light, buttery selections.

We finished off with sweet local uni, a generous portion of tamago and the black cod dish. Black cod was prepared with squid ink, a really intriguing egg yolk topping and roe. A hefty price for the dish, but portion size and quality definitely matched up.

Love the casual bar style setting. Service was slow towards the end of the omakase and I do wish the waiters were more attentive to refilling drinks. I do recommend sitting at the bar, decided to move my reservation an hour later to do so.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Some of the best Sushi I've ever had outside Japan, and I've been eating sushi in SF and Oakland for 20 years.  The uni in particular: sublime.  

Elegant and unpretentious atmosphere and service.

There's no sign, but the entrance is right on the street, next to the Irish Bank sign.

Get a reservation, even for lunch.
author: Timothy J.

description:
Akiko a is well known for their sushi. I learned after my last review that in order to get the best sushi, you have to get here early!!

Making a reservation is possible but unless you want to dine at awkward times, make that reservation couple weeks in advance. 

What I wanted to point out in this review is their amazing hamachi Kama!! I'm a huge fan of hamachi Kama and I always order it whenever it's on the menu and the one here is probably the best I've had! It's as good if not better than the one made at that one famous sushi place in Sausalito. 

The Kama is also reasonably priced at around $20 which is comparable to other SF Japanese restaurants. I highly recommend this. Their sushis and sashimi are much much pricier but I thought their cooked foods are just as delicious and much more economical
author: Annie Z.

description:
We were very lucky to get seats here, we came here on a Thursday at around 7pm and had to wait like 10 minutes to get a seat. It's a small restaurant and we were able to get seats at the bar.

The sushi chefs are really friendly and it's a great experience to be served right away, watch your meal be prepared and also chat a bit with the chef. They also explain how they prepared the dish and a brief description which enhances the experience greatly.

We tried several sushis such as the salmon belly, tuna, spider roll crab and they were all really tasty. The only problem is this place is a bit pricey for the portions you get. But you kind of pay for the experience because the service is quite good, and it feels like a nice and relaxing atmosphere.
author: Christopher L.

description: WOW! First off, this was THE BEST Salmon roll ive ever had in my life! My husband and I are visiting from Santa Rosa for the weekend. The first Sushi place we looked up ended up being non existent... or we just couldn't find it. Other places were closed and by this time we were STARVING !!!! Jessica informed us that the restaurant was opening in about 30 mins (so we grabbed a beer at that Irish Pub, which was also great) we didn't have reservations because well... we kinda just googled the nearest sushi place... but Jessica took down our names and we came back at 530 and she made sure we got a table! The line was crazy so make reservations for sure. The food was AMAZING!!!! We only got the Sake Roll & Edamame... but seriously the best salmon roll I've ever had. Everyone was so amazing and nice from the second we walked into the door from the second we left! High recommend this restaurant! We will be coming back!!! Thank you SO MUCH for such great service! And again a big THANK YOU to Jessica!!!!!
author: Ashton K.

description: After enjoying the artistry of seattle's sushi chefs for almost 2 decades now, akiko did not live up to the hype.  its attempts at exclusivity (30 seats, restaurant name not displayed outside), i believe,  will just serve to perhaps enable future undeserved scrutiny.
author: Cris S.

description:
Just get the chief's choices. You will be surprised by every course.
Also remember to book an appointment firsth
author: Yang C.

description:
I almost don't want to tell you about this one. Akiko's is a local's secret. Large pieces of the freshest fish, delishhhhhhhh. A bit on the expensive side but so worth it. 

This place is a treat.
author: Tracey L.

description: Akiko is my to-go sushi restaurant whenever I'm in San Francisco. Their food is heavenly and authentic with a creative touch. I usually go with the chef's choice (omakase) but everything off the menu is just as amazing. Love, love the place!
author: Ye G.

description:
Sashimi is my favorite!!!!!!!!
Nice to meet the chef and having fun talk with him ～asking for one more one more and last two more please!!!!! 
Really tasty! And good service and nice smile ，love this place 
The omakase is to die for , I feel that i was like a homeless who haven't ate for a long time 
really nice！
author: Tiffany X.

description: It's a warm and cozy place. I went here for celebrating my birthday. I really enjoy their food. There was asian girl who was very kind and friendly. Will come back here!! Thanks for your kindness!! :-)
author: Jaden L.

description:
Super disappointed in my recent experience! I've been here a handful of times and have enjoyed it but recently sat at the bar and left unsatisfied. Why? 

1) I ordered some nigiri and the fish was not fresh nor flavorful. The texture of the fish was mushy 
2) The sushi rice was a brown blended rice that wasn't very sticky and lacked that slight vinegary taste 
3) Found a fish bone in my sushi roll 

The meal was extremely overpriced and overhyped!
author: Michelle L.

description: From nyc.   The best sushi I ever had.   Truly amazing.    Had 15 courses.   One better than the next
author: Richard P.

description:
I had such high hopes for Akiko's after not only reading amazing reviews here but also hearing great things from friends who live in the city. But I will be totally honest, I left Akiko's completely disappointed. 
So service was pretty sub par, it took forever to initially get any service and when I did it was beyond spotty. I thought it was cute that they let you choose your own Sake cup but I wish they put a little more effort into their food and service then into unnecessary elements like that. 
I ordered the omakase, and the coursing was super fast at some points and really lagging during other portions. I always believe that at high end sushi restaurants that the meal should play out like a beautiful symphony.  That was not the case at Akiko's. 
The fish was fresh and some items were more flavorful than others. The cut of the fish was on par to sushi restaurants of a lesser stature and their flavor profiles were not reflective of their extremely high price point, their rice was even missing the note. 
I was also not a fan that no one seemed to care that they served me a piece of Amaebi with shell still on the shrimp. I literally almost choked on it. As this place stands I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone, I would be inclined if they lowered their prices and did a little development on their menu and selection of fish. 
Skip it.
author: Roxy H.

description:
Rude
Tried for lunch but turned away. I guess not rich enough for the hostess....should have not dropped bags off at the Ritz
author: Drew J.

description: Could be one of the sushi in San Francisco. Excellent service, amazing food presentation and extremely fresh sushi.  Your crazy if you go to San Francisco and don't stop there!
author: Frank D.

description:
Fantastic sushi experience! Great quality sushi with great service at fair price.

We sat at the sushi bar so our experience was with the sushi chef (shout out Wayne!) and a few servers. Service was great from both sides - super friendly and quick and unobtrusive. Easily on par or better than some Michelin spots in town.

The nigiri was fantastic! Great selection from around the world and quite fresh/clean tasting. Each piece is dressed/sauced ready to eat and That Rice! Perfectly delicate texture. 

Standouts:
Cold smoked golden eye snapper
Japanese crab
Striped jack
Salmon belly 
Hotate scallop
Fried baby mackerel 
Black cod (better than Nobu!)

Decent Japanese beer selection (bring Coedo back!) and some tasty diaginjo sake.

Great sushi at an even better price/quality! A special experience - we will soon be back!
author: Nathan L.

description:
The restaurant is a little tough to find because there's a large Irish Pub sign on the side of the building. And I don't recall seeing a sign for the restaurant. 

The restaurant is a quaint so be prepared to be seated very close to other diners. Definitely not a spot for large groups. 

The food is decent but the proportions are really small. For two people we ordered the large sashimi chef's choice, two rolls, edamame, and the soft shell crab.
author: Marfel L.

description: ordered hot sake and salmon roll at the bar with a friend and enjoyed both. the eel roll that my neighbor got smelled delicious, can't wait to try it! got to come back here on a date.
author: Meryam B.

description:
Wow! That's what it is all about.

Great beef with soba noodle soup....and real hot! The California roll really hit the spot, too.

Service superb..... and don't laugh, the cleanest bathroom in all of San Francisco!
author: Pat H.

description:
The best omakase in town. 
A few of us around the sushi table got to taste the freshest and the best uni and fish that arrived that very morning from Japan. The taste was pretty unreal! Highly recommended for those who like their Japanese food Japanese style (aka. Not recommended for Californian roll, volcanos, dragons, and the alike) because they have incredible seafood to work with and they are so creative in presenting the dishes.
author: Maria M.

description:
COMPLETELY DISCRIMINATED by the hosts.  Despite being perfectly on time and being the first ones there, we were placed at the worst table by the door with wind blowing into our heads.  I complained twice just to be moved to the table stuck by the bathroom.  I looked around there were some 4 ppl tables left so I thought they had 4 ppl reservations, just to find out the remaining parties were all 2ppl.  I voiced my concern, the host came by and basically told me that my mom and I were just unlucky.  It is especially upsetting because I ordered Omakase, which is much more expensive than what others ordered.  Very unfortunate, because the WAITRESSES WERE REALLY NICE, BUT THE HOSTS HAVE HORRIBLE ATTITUDE, COMPLETELY UNACCEPTABLE. 

On the food side, presentation and quality are nice but not outstanding compared to other well known restaurants in the city.  Akiko does not offer true omakase, it's just a combination of a la cart items on the menu.  

I will never go back and will advice anyone I know not to risk getting terrible treatments by the hosts.  IT'S NOT WORTH IT.

Kusakabe, Omakase, Saru, Ijji, Roka Arko, Wako are all much better choices!!!  I don't understand how they can get 4/5 rating on yelp.
author: Shannon J.

description:
Akiko is amazing. I think the two dollar signs is misleading as I would definitely give this place $$$ (spent over $200 for a two person boozy lunch), but it is worth every penny nevertheless.

1. Obviously get toro, did you really need me to tell you that?

2. Get the A5 wagyu with the shaved truffle. May not be on the menu, just ask.

3. Get another round of 1 and 2.

4. The soft-shell crab tempura. I mean I think they call it a tempura? It's not really a tempura. But who cares, it's dynamite.

5. Obviously the miso gindara (black cod). I think it may be the best version of miso gindara I've ever had (including Nobu and from izakayas in Tokyo).

6. Their booze is surprisingly cheap, maybe that's why they're saying $$?

--

To set the scene again, the only other couple who was there eating lunch there had two large Hermes shopping bags. I think the food is totally worth every penny here and would say it's probably the best in SF for Japanese, but I highly disagree with it being listed as at the same price-point as Round Table Pizza (literally).
author: Ryan J.

description: I always pass by this place and never realized it was a restaurant till I Yelp the area. I ordered 4 pieces of sashimi, soft shell crab and rice. The presentation is spot on. Sashimi was fresh, the Soft Shell Crab (OMG so good) it's mouthwatering that I loved the sauce, and Rice ( It was just plain rice. It had like this seaweed seasoning on it.). It's a must recommended spot. The soft shell crab got me wanting to come back.
author: Shirley A.

description:
My new favorite Sushi restaurant in San Francisco!!! I'm a sushi snob, n eat sushi 3-5 times a week. I love coming to a restaurant where the sushi chef really knows their fish, the freshness, how it needs to be prepared n what goes well with it. Akikos whole team is amazeballs!!! From their kitchen food to their sushi bar, it's hands down my favorite place to come for sushi. Have attached pics of some of my favorite Sushi.
 
But First: 
1. Get sake
2. Try the sushi chef's nigiri
3. Get the black cod from the kitchen 
4. N more Sake 

I have done the chef specials omakaze, n or just ordering what the chef recommends from the sushi, nigiri or sashimi, n can't stop coming back for more.
author: ThuZ W.

description: Great food, but they have the worst service that any restaurant could possibly have. The waiter is arrogant, impatient, and rude. It's a pity that the restaurant offers such high level sushi but horrible service.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
A very solid and affordable japanese restaurant that I wouldn't mind coming back to again!

Had to email in for reservations, but surprisingly scored at 7:30pm slot on a Friday night. Unfortunately we were a bit delayed, but the restaurant accommodated us and pushed our restaurant reservation to 8pm when our whole party didn't arrive at 7:30. Restaurant is decently sized for a Japanese restaurant -  there is bar seating at the front and maybe 6-8 tables in the back area.

They had both a regular menu as well as a special menu for the day - lots of options. We wanted to get the omakase, but the ordering for it was a bit more complicated than we would have wanted. The price of the omakase is all to the chef's discretion depending on what they decide to serve you. Also, you could request certain fish to be included if you want to, and the chef would prorate it to the amount of people at your table/the number of people who want to participate. We decided to opt out and just order everything that we wanted. 

Some highlights included the uni (very good portion), albacore, halibut, and the toro. Some things I would skip on next time would be the rolls - only about 5 pieces each, but the negi toro roll (tuna belly) was pretty good. 

To much of our disappointment, the dessert options were slim pickings. They didn't have a menu and only said they had 3 options for mochi icecream, so we left our dessert stomachs for another place. Another downside was that service was not the best. Had to flag down the waiters and waitresses to put in extra orders and to get our check.
author: Megan K.

description:
I tried to go here on three other occasions and they were booked from reservations.  It didn't matter what time of day I tried, lunch or dinner. I happened to be walking by one day and they said they could get me in 30 minutes later, woo hoo!  It ended up being an hour but I was committed by then anyway. 

It's a pretty small place, maybe 30 seats including the sushi bar. The service was really good. They were around when I needed them and didn't stop by too often. The table next to me was full of sushi novices but they were treated like regulars. Sometimes challenging to do. I liked the look and feel of the place. Japanese style but not overdone. 

I ordered a 12 piece sashimi, the grilled Saba, miso soup and a large bottle of Orion beer. Total out the door was about $90. The majority of the menu is a la carte per piece and is a little overpriced. The 12 piece sashimi for $36 was a good value though. $3 per piece versus an average of $8 on the a la carte menu. 

How was it???  The miso soup was maybe the best I've ever had. Seriously, that good. The grilled Saba was really good as well as the sashimi. All of it was worth the money. The sake menu was super high end. I think the lowest priced bottle was $45 and went up to $600. I opted for the beer instead as I don't know enough about sake to make a decision like that. 

Overall I totally understand why it's though to get in here but it's worth it for a good not super high end sushi restaurant.
author: Scott M.

description: This is a $$$$ omakase style place. Dropped by after 1pm for their lunch, regular dining area was booked, so they offered me the sushi bar. Good thing was I can see how sushi was made and talk to the chef on the sushi bar. Bad thing was I do not have the chance to try their lunch menu. Nigiri style of sushi is fresh! And they have already put sauce on top of sashimi, no need of soy sauce. Toro nigiri is excellent($15), salmon nigiri is also excellent! This is a very expensive place for lunch (my lunch by itself w/o tips cost me over $50)
author: Nina H.

description: Had dinner here for my birthday and tried an array of things.  Our server, Karina, was really knowledgeable and everything we had was great. My favorite was the ottro and the waygu. Amazing!
author: Angela B.

description:
They used to have a hearty sushi + entree lunch deal that was $20ish. Now it's been replaced with sushi sets that are about $4 per thumb-sized piece of nigiri (often mixed with standard fare like tuna / salmon / hamachi ). Since they're now only interested in courting $$$-$$$$ customers, I feel like I need to use a more demanding rubric on them.

-Wandering off the omakase menu could mean $6-12 per tiny half-bite, and a man with an average appetite would need like 20 pieces to be full. So that's like a $120-240 meal? You better be on Kiss Seafood / Ijji Sushi's level for that, but sadly Akiko does not compare to these. It's more like Pabu, somewhere to bring Bob from Accounts Payable visiting from the HQ from Charlotte or Orange County.

-The sushi rice seems mushy, warm and not vinegared enough.

-Their saucing on the omakase nigiri also seems too bland to bring out the natural sweetness of the fish. Every piece had a light brush of weak, thin soy sauce that seems lacking compared to, say, the creative sauce brush of Ijji Sushi or the traditional mastery of Kiss Seafood / Kusakabe.

-Their fried seafood items were extremely good and worth it, though!

The space is cute and charming and the staff is very friendly, but again, I don't feel like being taxed an extra 25% for my mild enjoyment of edison bulbs and polished wood.

I'd say a better value quickie lunch can be found in nearish-by Sanraku, and better taste+value full dinner omakase can be found at Kiss Seafood / Ijji / Saru / Kusakabe. It's stuck somewhere in between high and mid-grade in terms of price and target clientele...
author: Ken H.

description: We made the effort to find this place when we were in San Francisco, and unfortunately for us, we did not enjoy it at all.  The food quality was poor to average.  The Uni sashimi served on a wooden spoon was  far from worthy of another try.  The spoon was dry so when you put it in your mouth to eat the Uni, it was just unpleasant.  It should have been lightly oiled or moisten.  The Uni was so tiny, served single, barely an inch long and 1/2 inch wide, very flat, not plump.  The Yellow Tail Roll was fishy and the rice was dried and tasted like it was a day old.  We had few other orders too but not worthy my time to get into.  We will not return :(
author: Julie L.

description: I came to Akiko's for dinner today. The service was excellent as was the food. Great chill atmosphere. I recommend it to anyone who is visiting San Fran and are looking for a good dinner. I would recommend making a reservation. I was able to get a table right away but noticed that they were all booked up starting at 7pm.
author: Maggie S.

description: This is Japanese cuisine at its finest. Everything is excellent here but sometimes you get extra special  stuff like 8 different kinds of scallops or urchins.
author: Alex J.

description:
This is hidden away without much of a sign from outside. We walked right past it at first.

The waitress was friendly, but not very knowledgeable nor listened well. I ordered omakase and some a la carte items. The seafood was decent as far as freshness goes, but the chef did not do a great job at maximizing flavor. Also, standard tuna and salmon should not show up in omakase anywhere in my opinion.

Probably won't ever come back again for standard food that cost $200.
author: Kevin K.

description:
I think 3.5 stars is the appropriate rating for this restaurant, but they're not good enough to round up.

I've never been hungry after ordering omakse before, but this place managed to give me a new first. And they managed to do it for an impressive price.

But that's not even what really bothered me. I took my girlfriend to dinner for her birthday, and it was just bland. The nigiri rice was warm, and so was the fish. In the end I feel like they could have just given us 3 dishes and been done with it. The rest were repeats. I remember one dish with a little imagination. There was some sushi served with extremely small and extremely sour seeds. I think this was the saving grace of the meal.

There was no soup and no warm dishes. All in all this place just lacked imagination. Using brown rice is imaginative, it's trendy. I'll never come back. And I don't recommend you waste your time or your money here.
author: JWest M.

description:
Walked in here once without knowing much. Here's what I learned:

-more like $$$$ 
-service is the perfect balance of attentive but not intrusive
-by far the best soy sauce I've ever had
-nigiri is amazing, although portions left much to be desired.
author: Nick C.

description:
Went here back in 2011 but reviewed the wrong place - whoops!
Here's the review:
For some reason we had a hard time finding Akiko's walking over from the Angelic Pretty store down the street. Once we found it though, we felt stupid, even though it does seem like a tiny hole-in-the-wall at first glance!

The inside is a beautiful industrial modern little restaurant. We ordered way too much food, but the presentation was beautiful. The sushi was great, the udon was great, the tempura was great. All over, a great place! I'm sorry I'm not in SF more often, I'd definitely make this a regular stop.
author: Nicole M.

description:
EVENT: my sister is visiting from a far, far away land... and her favorite cuisine is Japanese... and so we made reservations for 3 people at 8pm.

LOCATION: a cute little place... we couldn't find the sign for the restaurant and we assumed... it was at this place! It kinda looked a Japanese place we thought.. lol

PARKING: close to Union Square, so we decided to take an Uber... plus we wanted to have some drinks.

SERVICE: we had an AWESOME water guy... we were soooo thristy! He kept on coming back to pour us more water! LOVE the water boy! 5 stars to him!

FOOD: we weren't as hungry cause we were kinda starving at 6pm... so we had a little snack before heading to this place. But - here's what we got...

(1) Sashimi Tasting, $34: came in five different fish... in 12 pieces. 
(2) Nigiri Tasting, $24: six piece of nigiri... love it how they use just a little bit of rice... is it brown rice? The fish looks really shiny when it came out!
(3) Negi Toro Roll, $20: this is one of my favorites! Toro with shiso leaf in a sushi... loveeee! 5 stars!
(4) Negihama Roll, $10: yellow tail with some cucumber sushi - very simple and clean
(5) Asahi 20oz, $9: pretty good price for a restaurant! 

**OVERALL - must get the Negi Toro Roll and Sashimi Tasting!
author: Mindy Y.

description: Best sushi  in my life! I know I'm only 31 but seriously amazing! If your ever in San Francisco this is a must! Top quality and the flavors are one of a kind! There's no sign so make sure you look  out for it. It's right by the tavern. Even the music is spot on! Great ambiance and vibes. Make sure to make reservations! We got lucky and they took us in. But do not chance it! Can't wait to go back.
author: Alexandra M.

description: OH MY GODDNESS THE NIGIRI HERE  I ordered the chefs omasake and we were seated on bar stools as the chef was making everything by hand I front of us! It was such an art to watch him create flavour, and then his colleague was decorating it beautifully with garnish. I don't remember all the names as they were in Japanese, but our chef explained to us in English of what type of fish it was and what texture/flavour it has! I love how fresh the fish was and it was definitely very refreshing to eat!
author: Shan N.

description:
Best. Sushi. Ever.

#1 sushi location in San Francisco as far as I'm concerned. The owners,Ray and Allen, have made it so that whenever I'm there I feel like their only customer. The sushi is made to perfection and Ray's desserts are the bomb. After going to Robin, Wako, Kusakabe and Kinjo, I feel like I can safely say this is probably the best sushi restaurant in the city...and as soon as I figure out how to post pictures I'll add them too XD
author: Arthur W.

description:
Not particularly impressed by the sushi here, but it may be because I went in with high expectations. The rice texture was a bit too loose for me and did not have the together-ness I was looking for. The fish also didn't seem to be as fresh and left a slight fishy aftertaste. 

I'm not a sushi person so my judgements may not be too helpful. But I definitely thought it wasn't a bad experience and the price wasn't too far off for what the restaurant provided.
author: Love L.

description: This is my second time dining here, just as excellent as my first visit! I forgot the server's name but he was very informative as we ordered the omakase. Great place to grab omakase during lunch. Highly recommended even better than some of the 1 star Michelin Japanese Restos in the Bay Area. Highlights were the oyster caviar, hokkaido uni and the marinated tuna. The wagyu truffle was a bit of a letdown but everything else was perfect.
author: Fredric A.

description:
Good Nigiri. On the expensive side. Price is per piece. Quality fish but some slices are too small. 
Nice service. No name on the door. Need to look for the address.
author: Thien B.

description:
Everybody dies, but not everybody lives to try sushi this gewwwd (*.*)

So if you're standing up, sit down 
Make a reservation for dinner at Akiko's
Come hungry...

...and order the omakase. I've tried several omakase around the city, including Ichi in the Mission and Sanraku (also a big fan of other infamous spots like Sushi Zone and Tao Sushi, and because we are sushi fiends we scour the city for the best bang for your buck). The menu price says A.Q. but we paid ~$90 for the pleasure. Do it.

Stuff-of-legend. I highly recommend eating everything with your eyes closed for the full-body experience.

-First came the snapper and grouper, incredible.
-Second we were transported to Japan and fed their amazing tuna from the Gods. Praise.
-Third came the barracuda, tried it for the first time and was wholly impressed. 
-Fourth came the oysters which were soaked in their own oyster water, unique to perfection.
-Fifth came the scallops and clams; immediately transported to a dinner with Neptune.

-Sixth was when I found religion - their sweet shrimp is now enshrined in my greatest hits album. Difficult to describe with prose; maybe a painting? Was it a dream? Do not. leave. this strange planet. without trying the sweet shrimp.

-Seventh came the heads of those sweet, delicious shrimp fried to flawless crisp. Total bliss.
-Eighth came the snow crab, which made my crab-loving friends taste buds tremble in awe.

-Ninth came without warning, and like the 1906 earthquake, it left me with nothing but the memories of a life before the moment I tried the uni. Words simply are unworthy to describe. Just know this - cherish those fleeting moments you have with Akiko's uni.

-Tenth came the beef, which single-handedly revolutionized my concept of 'beef'. Ne'er did I dream beef could make me feel that way. The sea salt sprinkled on top shewk my soul.

We ordered the tekka and the sake roll, both were heavenly with the tekka roll coming out ahead in the electoral college. We ended the meal with the black tuna, which I must type with a lover's sigh of longing. 

I rarely ever give a 5 star review - Akiko's pulled it off with outstanding and attentive service. Their interior was at once modern, seductive, and eclectic (we sat in front of an exposed, corroded, and polished concrete load-bearing wall). As we stepped in, we were greeted as the hostess had been expecting our arrival just before another group arrived reservation-less. On that Wednesday night, Akiko's was fully booked and they were turned away. 

Don't be them. Move on this, folks. You'll thank yourselves.

Visited on 3/15/17
author: Christian P.

description:
This was my first time to Akiko's restaurant and I wasn't impressed with the initial service. I had a 5:45 reservation, and my husband was running 15 minutes late. Although there were plenty of open tables, the host asked me to sit on the high chairs in the corner until I made a decision about whether we wanted the sushi bar or tables. Once I said tables, I still waited on the high chairs in the corner for 10 minutes - I was seated at 5:50. 

However, the host redeemed this initial feeling by asking me if I wished to wait at a table. I immediately took him up on the offer, ordered a glass of Sancerre, and awaited my delayed beau. 

After that, the service from the waitress was strangely abrupt and blunt. She kept refusing to let us keep a menu for further drink and food orders, and then didn't give us a menu for some time after we asked for it - it was literally a hand's reach away from us.... So, my husband just reached behind him and took one. THEN she took our menu away without asking whether we wanted to order anything else. We practically had to chase her down. Really odd service.

The food more than made up for the service. Really delicious sushi.
author: S O.

description: Simply amazing and delicious sushi. We ordered both the Saki and Negeritoro rolls with a crab appetizer and they were excellent - the rolls will melt in your mouth! Phenomenal service and an intimate venue makes it a great place to bring a date. Highly recommended!
author: Krishna S.

description: This place is tiny. Food was absolutely amazing though. The fish was incredibly fresh and everything we ordered was melt in your mouth. Just good, simple, Japanese food.
author: Debs C.

description:
I have been here many times with friends and colleagues. I usually order the Omakase and never had a bad experience. The fish is always fresh and delicious. 

The sushi is served with the right amount of fish vs. rice ratio. The staff is super professional and there to answer any questions. Allan is the guy who knows it all!

I sat at the bar a few times, the sushi chefs are always really friendly and it's a great experience to be served right away. 

The Uni at Akiko's is one of the best in the city - fresh, different variations and super tasty.
author: Meli.Lars M.

description:
Came for dinner with reservations for 4 on a Friday night, place was pretty packed. Friends did prix fixe menu of omakase fish but I'm not the biggest raw fish person. 

Tried their some of their dishes and it was very flavorful and unique. Snow crab nigiri - super fresh and tasty. Futomaki - good though nothing out of the ordinary. 

Friends' highlights: wagyu beef nigiri, scallop nigiri

TLDR: highly attentive service, great place for raw fish lovers!
author: Kristie C.

description: Choices are excellent if you have finicky pallet. Service is great. You are paying for the location and atmosphere.
author: H L.

description: Hidden gem. Took a bit to find it but it was worth it. Good sushi - still working my way thru the menu. Good service. Nice setting.
author: Matt L.

description:
A bit on the pricier side (refer to the pictures I posted; that came out to about $95).
Very small restaurant, but when you are traveling for business, you have the option to sit at the sushi bar ;) and not wait long for a table. Score !
author: Loni L.

description: Had such a lovely meal here after a long day. Unfortunately, I have no photos because I ate it all before I remembered.
author: JJ L.

description: Considering my favorite food is Sake Nigiri you'd think I would have been to a lot of fancy sushi places. I'm more of a mid range eater and this was out of my typical price range. A friend chose it for lunch and their $35 special for 12 pieces was a steal. Easily the best white tuna I have ever had. Also did a side order of their uni which was delicious and then, possibly over did it with the collar (can't remember which fish). An expensive lunch no doubt but o boy their selection of fish from Japan was incredible. Next time ordering at least one which as high as $25 for a single piece.
author: Jason P.

description:
This is one of my favorite sushi places when I visit SF.

I try and go there every time I visit. Thing is, I don't always get reservations, so I show up at dinner time right when the doors open and try to get a seat at the bar, or at a small table.

I've been here a half a dozen times and only had one reservation all those times. Also, keep in mind, I have tried to get in here a half dozen other times without reservations to no avail.

The sushi is always fresh. The sake is delicious. I highly recommend this place. I've been to Japan a couple times, and this is right up there with sushi in Tokyo.
author: Holland C.

description:
I had dinner reservations at 6pm. I arrived a couple minutes early and the friendly hostess seated me immediately. My friend came in about 3-4 minutes after. The waiters stood in a row and tried to stop him from walking in, until I waved to him and he pointed that he was with me.

The ambiance is really small and loud. The table is plated nicely and artistically. The waiters were very attentive with refilling my water cup as soon as I took a sip.

We ordered:
--12 piece sashimi tasting $34
It consisted of assorted tunas, salmon and other exotic fishes. It was a nice thin portion for sashimi. Each piece was juicy and melted in my mouth. My favorite might've been the fatty salmon.

--Tekka Roll $12
Tekka Roll consisted of tuna, scallion, avocado, crispy shiso, pickled carrot and sesame. This roll was new and interesting to me. The tuna was fatty and juicy. The rice had the perfect texture and the crispy shiso gave the sushi a nice crunch. It was delicious

--Green Tea and Black Sesame Mochi $2.50 each piece
I'm not sure if these were made in-house but they were creamy and perfectly sweetened. The mochi skin was thick and sticky and paired really well with the ice cream.

The food was decent, but the service was meh (except for the hostess). No friendly smiles or thank you or goodbyes as we were leaving. Maybe they didn't want to say bye so they could look forward to saying hello if we return
author: Linda K.

description: Delicious and delightful. Wonderful service and absolutely amazing sushi. I will definitely be back. Thank you!!
author: Tom B.

description:
Wow! 

My date and I tried the omakase where you tasted 12 exotic bites/sea creatures. 

And wow... the taste was unbelievable. This review is purely for the bougie. I had money, had s good career upgrade, therefore was willing to go a little ham. 

We had an oyster, followed with halibut, then tuna and salmon sashimi, then tuna shoulder and barracuda, sweet shrimp, over night scallop and sea urchin from Russia. 

The course was designed to start you off refreshing then savory intensify, ending with something refreshing. 

It was a little hard to find the place at first, but that made me feel good. I like my unique spots to be kinda low key. 

Our waitress was very nice. Hence tipping her 40 bucks. She was definitely educated in that "sushi" realm. 

We were still a little hungry so we also ordered the omelette and fatty tuna. 

I. Have. No. Regrets. 



Great for date nights.
But don't waste it on gold diggers or unappreciative Gurls/guys.
author: Huy H.

description:
Clean and fresh sashimi. Serves seemed busy but they were very nice and attentive at the same time. I recommend sitting at the bar or rocky walks; if you want to have more privacy, the tables near the entrance and next to restroom would good. 

Small restaurant. Seems mostly good for 2-4 parties.
author: Timothy Y.

description:
3.5 STARS

Long overdue review. The gf made a reservation here on a Tuesday night at 7:30pm for our sushi date. There was some difficulty locating this place cause the restaurant had no sign or name! Turns out it was a tiny corner restaurant with open-windows that looks kinda like a cute coffee shop at a quick glance.

Upon arrival, we were seated promptly in a back dining area. The ambiance of the restaurant was very cozy, hip, and modern. I loved how the place was dimly lit and quite romantic; perfect for date night.

The gf and I both opted for the omakase.

O M A K A S E:

- Ohitashi (2 for $8): marinated spinach. 
- Akami Sashimi(2pc for $12.80): tuna sashimi. Cut thin but nothing special. 
- Umimasu Nigiri (2pc for $6): ocean trout. very fresh and buttery. enjoyed it very much.
- Tennen Hirame Sashimi (2pc for $10.80): wild fluke. usually one of my favorite fishes, but this one was quite stringy when bitten apart.
- Kuromutsu (2pc for $12): fish looked a bit oily than others, but taste was delicious.
- Shima Aji Nigiri (2pc for $15): farmed striped mackerel. Pretty good & Fresh
- Kinmedai Nigiri (2pc for $20): "cold smoked" aged wild golden eye snapper. This one was torched so it gave off a delicious seared smokey taste. Only downside was I didn't like the texture that much. 
- Kamasu Nigiri (6pc for $36): wild young barracuda. the gf and i LOVED this one so much we ordered seconds! 
- Ankimo Nigiri (2pc for $8.50): loved this one also. The ankimo was soft and delicious.
- Russian Uni Nigiri (2pc for  $25): the uni was delicately small and sweet! Absolutely yummy. Pretty impressed at how they just topped the uni on top of the rice without any seaweed wrap. 


A L A  C A R T:

- Negi Toro Roll ($20): this roll was utterly disappointing. definitely not worth $20 cause it was very plain and tasteless. Made American-style and the roll was kinda loose. nothing special... cept the price.
- Nama Hotate Nigiri (2pc for $15): over nighted, unprocessed fresh scallops. The gf and I are scallop fanatics and these babies did not disappoint! Definitely fresh. 
- Ikura Nigiri (2pc for $8): the gf ordered this and said it was good.
- Uni Nigiri (2pc for $12): sea urchin. 
- Ebodai (2pc for $12): Wild butterfish. Didn't order this but it came out and we drunkenly ate it :(
- Tsuri Aji Nigiri (2pc for $14): Wild horse mackerel. Also didn't order this but ate it once again. (face palm)


D R I N K S:

- Okuden Kanisukuri (300ml for $28)
- Groth Sauvignon Blanc BTL (Bottle for $50)


S E R V I C E:
Our waitress gave us both mixed feelings. She was sweet and always smiling and came to us when we waived her down. But she was also very confusing. Where do I even start :(  So we asked for the omakase and after number of nigiris were out already,  she came up to us and asked if we would like to "continue". When she said that, we thought she was just checking in on us and asknig if we would like to continue with our omakase with whatever nigiri's were left or if we were going onto dessert, so we said yes. Then ten minutes later, she comes back to our table with a whole set of nigiri's again from the omakase, so we told her we already got those. She then looked hella confused and said: "Oh, i thought you guys wanted another round of omakase". My friend and I just looked at each other shocked and told her no.... She continued to look at us really confused but took the nigiri's back. We then told her that if we were done with our omakase, we would like to order a la carte. From there on, there was even more confusion. Our nigiri's were all mixed up and we were getting fishes that we didn't order and we got the kamasu three times when we only asked for seconds. Towards the end and a few drinks in, my friend and I were pretty tipsy and disappointed to continue so we asked for the tab and left still in shocked with all the mix-ups and the fact that we racked up our bill by drunkenly eating some nigiri's that we didn't order. 

Another factor we found very interesting was the fact that the omakase was no different from ordering a la carte. When we asked for the omakase, we thought it was gonna be a set price (not listed) for a set menu. But when we looked at our bill, we were charged by the items on the omakase individually and at the SAME price as ordering them a la carte... so what's the point of an omakase?!? If we knew this, we would've definitely not have gotten the omakase cause there were some items we didn't like as much. Our bill came out to be $340 for two people pre-tips. 

Our experience at Akiko's was ok. Although there was a lot of mix up and confusion from the waitress to the menu's, we did enjoy the atmosphere and the nigiri's. Our visit was a few months back so hopefully it's better now cause I do wish to return someday...... one day
author: Anissa D.

description:
Seriously the sashimi was amazinggggg!! Melt in your mouth, I need some more amazing :DD

Been here before with a small group of friends 3-4 and decided to come back for a friend visiting. We each ordered our own dishes but overall was pretty impressed with how fresh the fish was and how great the servers were.

Also noted, the bathroom hand soap was super soft!!

Would recommend again to get some yummy sushi but of course ready to pay for that fresh fish!
author: Anh C.

description: We came here for a quick lunch and were seated very quickly.  We had some amazing yellow tail and tuna rolls.  The service was good, but a little abrupt.  We ordered something with the waiter and then he left so we placed it with the chef and he suggested the grouper nigiri.  The waiter stormed off a little when he came back and found out. But that fff menu grouper nigiri was amazing.  We'll definitely come back.
author: Richard T.

description:
Pros: Food was amazing! The Sushi is extremely fresh & the service was excellent! Relaxed atmosphere w/ low noise level & nice ambient lighting. Perfect place to continue ordering throughout the meal, very accommodating.

Cons: Needs a little more space, but what place in SF doesn't?
Little pricey, but you get what you pay for & it's well worth it. 
We didn't receive 1 of the items we ordered, but the waitress comped our sake!

Fixes: Expand to a larger location. Add another restroom.
author: Baxter B.

description:
Came in to do the omakase and basically just asked for the most interesting/colorful/weird fish they had. Here's what I got!

1) Japanese Thai 
2) Copper river salmon 
3) Halibut 
4) Striped trivali jack (hamachi) 
5) Ai Yu - in chinese markets, they usually have fried trout without teeth... this is the sashimi version. Funky and I like it. I can still taste that salty/fishy flavor but in a different texture. 
6) Baby barracuda - first time having barracuda! Yum.. 

They were all good and reasonably priced for omakase. 

Ended it with with two of my favorites in one... 
"Chu-uni" = slightly seared Chu-toro (fatty tuna) topped with Hokkaido uni. 

I will say that it isn't the best fatty tuna I've had but that's not what they're known for, so it is what it is! 

Service was amazing. I felt like I was having a conversation with the chef even though I wasn't sitting at the sushi bar...which is how omakase is supposed to feel like, a chef taking you on a journey.
author: Inga C.

description:
Food was , but if you looking for a reasonably priced sushi bar with good amount if food go elsewhere. Felt like bird good. 

Dates, yes.
Impress someone, yes. 
Munchies or starving, nah.
author: Marie Y.

description: Seasonally offered fish, everything I tasted was solid. The price is a little high, but you're in SF so what do you really expect. I still say the best fish in the bay comes out of the SOUTH bay though. If I'm in sf and this place is considered I would have no hesitation going again!
author: Sam R.

description:
Pretty good sushi place. The quality of fish and other ingredients are all top notch although the dishes are quite a bit more pricey than the two dollar signs on Yelp might suggest.

The menu options are pretty limited (especially if you like rolls) and most of the dishes are small so we ended up ordering most of the menu.

Sashimi / sushi - Very high quality fish and nice thick cuts. (4.5/5)

Mushroom + seafood soup - Clean and simple seafood flavor. (3.5/5)

Scallop + cucumber salad - Fresh scalops and cucumber in a soy based sauce. A bit underwhelming for its price. (3/5)

Grilled Hamachi collar - Incredibly well cooked. Very flavorful and juicy and served with a delicious sauce. Best thing I ate here. (5/5)

Grilled mackerel - Very juicy for mackerel and flavorful. (4.5/5)

Miso marinated black cod - Like most of the items, very fresh, well cooked, and flavorful. Flavor is a bit too sweet for me though and was very pricy for the small size. (4/5)

Fried tofu - It was supposed to come with salmon roe but they didn't have any so they gave it to us without us and without saying anything until we asked. The tofu was nicely fried with a light breading in a soy based sauce. Underwhelming and overpriced overall. (2.5/5)

Fried soft shell crab - very similar to the tofu dish but crab works well on its own unlike the tofu. (3.5/5)

Rolls - Average. Rolls were very simple with seaweed wrapping the rice and fish tartare on the inside (not whole fish on outside). (3/5)

Overall the food was good but pricier than expected. The limited selection of rolls can be a big con for some.
author: Austin L.

description:
One of my favorite sushi restaurants in town. Difficult to get a table without a reservation, and even harder to find (they dont have their name displayed outside). Great for a date night or small groups (4 max) as the restaurant is small itself. 

Everything is fresh and very delicious! Ive never had a dish here that I wouldnt order again!

Some of my favorites are:
Unprocessed uni
Amaebi 
Wagyu beef with black truffle 
Baby barracuda
author: Claire W.

description:
definitely $$$ if you go the sushi route.. which of course i always do!

came here this week for a business lunch and was thoroughly satisfied (though not really full given $$$) with the selection of 5 nigiri that i chose. all the fish was super fresh and the sushi rice lightly seasoned to my stomach's delight. 

to be honest, wasn't really impressed with the selection of appetizers (edamame and fried squid) and rolls that our table got to share. but i'll let that one slide since apps and rolls really aren't a selling point for me anyways. seriously - it is all about the sushi and sashimi here.

must come back for omakase on some other special occasion. we inquired about omakase price and it is actually on par with a lot of sushi places in the city - about 13 pieces that is listed as "market price" but typically starting over $100 per person.
author: Yiwen S.

description:
Just wow! I have no idea why this restaurant did not get a Michelin star. Damn. But I guess it is good for us since the price will go up surely if they get a star. This is the #1 Sushi restaurant in town for me. Better than Kusakabe (previously #1 on my list).

This restaurant has around 30 seats, 8 at the bar. Very good atmosphere with nice decor. The chefs and staff are very friendly. I was seated at the bar with chef Alex who is very friendly - we had a very good conversation.

Let's go to the food. The rice is really good! Seasoned with akazu vinegar (red vinegar) giving a very nice subtle vinegary flavour. The texture is a bit al-dente - very nice. The fish here is fabulous with amazing flavor and texture. Awesome.

Definitely try this restaurant. You will be very pleased! 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here's the note I took during the meal.

Omakase

- oyster with Russian stergion caviar - The saltiness of caviar paired beautifully with the oyster
- shima aji with fermented yuzu zest - Excellent. Firm texture. The yuzu zest cut through the fattyness very nicely.
- aradashi tofu
- kinmedai - even better than the last piece.
- scallop from hokkaido and sea urchin. The scallop is really fresh sweet - the chef told us that the scallop is not entirely dear i.e. The muscle reflex is still there.
- zuke bluefin tuna (akami) from Nagasaki - wonderful red meat tuna. The best akami I had in the US
- uni in ocean water from hoggaido - wow! Not bitter at all. Very creamy and smooth.
- king salmon - really good flavor with a little bit of yuzu zest.
- kani (hairy crab from hoggaido and uni donburi with seaweed from tsukiji. The crab is seasoned with miso butter which go very well with the crab.
- zuke chutoro marinated over night lightly torched. Fantastic! This is wonderfully tender tuna. Almost melt in your mouth but still have the flavour of red meat. Very nice.
- shiro toro from higgaido with mustard - torched. Wonderful flavor. Never had better shiro maguro.
- black grouper with onion ponzu
- scallop marinated in unagi sauce.

Addition orders
- iwashi (sardine) with young finger and chive - recommend by chef. What I like about this is it has some fishiness but in a very good way. Wonderful
- ayu with lime zest
- kohada
- saba - marinade in vinegar. The flavour is very clean. You can forget the saba you had in other sushi restaurant around here.
- hokkaido shiro murasaki sea urchin - great! The texture is like that of a custard and had a little bit of eggy flavor. Very nice. This is a very expensive sea urchin (25$ per piece) and it is the same one used in sukiyabashi jiro and sushi saito. Is it worth 25$/piece? I think my pallet is not good enough to distinguish it.
- miyazaki wagyu topped with foie gras and white truffle. Not quite sure if I detected the smell of the white truffle but it give a nice chewy/crunchy texture.  Foie gras and wagyu beef is a holy combination. I'm in heaven!
author: Thanapat W.

description:
We got the omikase. The meal was good but somewhat inconsistent. They served a few dishes with way too much wasabi. It actually burned my nose and I could not taste the dish. I complained to the waiter but all they did was apologize without offering to do anything about it. For that expensive of a meal they definitely could have done more to right the situation.

Some of the fish, like the aged bluefin tuna, was prepared and packed with a lot of flavor. However, other dishes, like the Spanish mackerel, were not good at all. It appeared that the fish that were sourced were quite inconsistent, which clearly didn't reflect the price point of the meal. Overall, it left much to be desired.
author: David Y.

description:
I've been meaning to come here forever, and I'm not sure why I never made it here.  Note: this place is different from Akiko's Sushi Bar.

Since our friend knew chef Ray, we got to meet him before the dinner, and he personally brought out some amazing salt and pepper octopus on lollipop sticks for us. He was super down to earth and clearly excited and passionate about the food they were making. 

Then, we were lucky enough to get the prime sushi bar seats on the end (there are only 2), so we could look at everything going on behind the counter.  

Our sushi chef was Roger, who was super personable, and the sake expert, Jessica was very knowledgeable and took great care of us. Chef Ray also made a couple of appearances, which was really nice. 

To start: 
1. Wagyu tartare on a nori chip: the nori chip was super crisp and savory, and the wagyu kind of melts in your mouth - a good combination of textures. 
2. Matsutake mushroom soup: light clear broth with mushrooms and squid 
3 Spanish mackerel sashimi: seared and cold smoked - there were quite a few pieces on the dish 

Onto sushi:
(All the pieces were great, but * = favorites that I would order a la carte as add-ons)
1. *Hotate with crystallized soy, citrus, and charcoal infused salt
2. Halibut with seaweed and a sort of mussel on top 
3. Kinmedia (golden eye snapper), torched, with a special salt on top 
4. Kawahagi (trigger fish): an unusual find, served with its own liver sauce 
5. *Japanese barracuda, torched, with grated ginger, lemon, and an intense pure tasting sesame oil 
6. *Shima aji with kombu infused seaweed and Japanese mustard (loved these flavors together)
7. Kohada with shiso and sesame 
8. *Akamutsu (Japanese throat fish) with Japanese fermented chili 
9. Blue fin tuna: the lean part as a hand roll in fresh nori - this was a very generous portion
10. Wild winter yellowtail, torched 
11. New Zealand salmon with shiso flower, sea kelp, salt crystals - super rich but also with texture from the salt - a good mix of sweet and savory
12. *Bonito with chopped wasabi stem 
13. Otoro aged 10 days in house
14. *Otoro marinated in a jalapeño soy, torched
15. Uni in a natural brine, super sweet and fresh, served on rice in a wooden spoon 

Dessert: a friend who I completely trust for food told me that with all of her world travels, she thought the best ice cream ever was that made by Ray, and it did not disappoint.  We had a non-fish shaped taiyaki (thin and flaky outside) filled with smoked buttermilk ice cream and shiso ice cream. The texture on the ice cream was good - dense and rich, and the flavors were basically as described. 

We definitely had some more interesting selections for the sushi, such as the trigger fish and throat fish, which was a nice change from the regular stuff. Again, I love anything torched and made sure Roger knew that, and I really liked that the fish was torched while sitting on a salt block for extra flavor.  I was really happy with all of the sushi pieces - the flavor combinations were interesting, the cuts of fish were consistent and good, and the shari was good.

Make sure you get a sushi bar seat for the omakase.
author: Marilyn H.
