description: I ordered the omakase and came back again to get a la carte. There is definitely a quality difference between the two. If you order the omakase you'll get fresher pieces at a higher cost.
author: Alan C.

description: The best sushi ever . This is my go to place every time I go to San Francisco . I love all kind of chef selection menu . All kind of good . Highly recommend to everyone. Make sure to make reservations because it always busy and hard to get in without reservation
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Overall just average sushi and rather overpriced even by sushi standards. The coating on the soft shelled crab appetizer was far too thick and greasy and sadly all crab flavor was lost. Had 9 different types of nigiri, salmon was the tastiest but most others were just lacking flavor. The flavor of the yellowtail almost tasted watered down. Rice in the nigiri was over-seasoned. Also tried the negihama but again, couldn't even tell there was fish in it by taste alone. Sad too because at first glance they seem to have a good variety of fish. Just difficult to justify when only half of what you're eating tastes good.
author: Alana C.

description:
Top-notch fish! i.e. possibly among the closest I've gotten in my life to the sushi that Jiro dreams of. Comparable in quality to those uber-authentic sushi places in LA's Little Tokyo.

The fish menu was amusingly similar to wine, with the name of the fish, place of origin, and categorization of white fish ("mild, clean") vs vibrant fish ("full flavor, buttery"). To extend the analogy to wine flights, they do offer omakase and sashimi tasting for the undecisive and/or high-maintenance. 

Sake king salmon (Marlborough, New Zealand, $8 nigiri): The salmon taste and fattiness was more attenuated than I had expected, based on my experiences with cooked king salmon. It's different from your typical sake, though it does require some thought and patience to notice the subtle complexities: first an interestingly firm texture, then unraveling nuanced salmon flavors, and a buttery finish. I was slightly disappointed with the small cut, but this was a pretty memorable piece of fish.

Spider roll ($10): One bite and you feel like all the previous spider rolls you've ever eaten was a hoax fabricated of batter and sauce. Akiko's version puts the softshell crab boldly in the spotlight (for once), supplemented by touches of tempura, soy sauce, avocado, and sushi rice that had a stronger mirin taste than usual.

Saba shio-yaki with chives, ponzu-daikon,charred lemon ($12): I'm usually not a huge fan of saba, but I was a huge fan of this dish! The saba is everything you expect of saba shioyaki (robust, roasty, buttery), minus the usual negatives (overly fishy, salty, greasy). The additional ingredients synergistically contributed tangy and umami overtones. The texture was well constructed as well, with the fish infused with the sauce, a layer of soft daikon, topped with fine strings of (what I believe are) chives (but looked like moss). And props to the decent sized portion!

Akiko's has fantastic attention to detail, which really brings the overall dining experience to the next level. There are numerous little things, such as chilled soy sauce, fresh authentic i.e. very strong wasabi, and quality wooden chopsticks (so you don't taste raw wood or plastic with every bite). 

The main aspect of Akiko's that didn't fly was its hodgepodge ambiance. First of all, they initially seated us in this random table right by the entrance next to a pillar, even though we had a reservation. After asking to move to the back area where there were tables open, we noticed that the room appeared very confused--three walls are covered in a wallpaper print that looked European, while the fourth wall was bare stone with exposed metal pipes. It also didn't meld well with the restaurant as a whole: the other sections consisted of an haute gastropub-like sushi bar and a bright atrium with a few tables (including the random one in the hallway) and a giant octopus painting.

Tip: If you're like me and not well versed in know how to fully appreciate fancypants fish, I highly recommend the rolls. The nigiri selection has some seriously exquisite options, but personally I don't find it worthwhile to spend so much $$$ on a bite unless you're a connoisseur. The rolls, on the other hand, are mostly priced similarly to other sushi places, except the quality is superb. The caveat? It will be a challenge to go back to regular sushi. I never liked cheap sushi in the first place, but I think now I will be utterly disgusted. Akiko's redefines your concept of fish.
author: Edna C.

description:
I said I would never come back after my previous experience, but I gave Akiko's a second chance, and I am very glad that I did. I learned from my first experience, and decided to do omakase at the bar this time. Skip everything else, and go straight for the fish, there's no point in wasting your stomach. Shit, the fish here is fresh AF. The highlights were:

Uni
Toro
Ankimo
Ebi
Wagyu with truffle shavings = ultimate mouthgasm
author: Jessica L.

description: Really enjoyed this sushi restaurant! Compared to other places in sf prices are good too. Get nigiris and please don't leave without trying the miso sea bass!
author: Maria Fernanda G.

description: We love the sushi here. Like their customer service too. The chefs were very sweet and nice. We definitely want to come back sometimes.
author: Meichelle L.

description:
I came here for lunch with a few friends and it was packed! I was concerned about possible slow service based on other reviews but our waiters were pretty good. They checked up on us multiple times and our orders came out in good timing. 

Now onto the food! I was able to try the lunch tonkatsu with nigiri as well as the five piece fatty tuna sashimi. The tonkatsu had good crunch and came with this thick dark sauce to dip in. From my home chef tastebuds, it tasted like a vinegar and honey concoction. However, it was delicious and I would eat again. The pork cut was on the thinner side though.  The combo also came with four nigiri pieces, which were decent. I wasn't blown away at the quality of fish but it's the side dish to the tonkatsu plate so I wasn't expecting much. But the fatty tuna is really the star. When the plate was placed in front of me, I was so happy. Color was a nice pink and it looked so fresh and clean.  When it hit my tongue, I felt all the troubles in life melt away. Yeah, that good!

This all came with a price and 45 dollars for lunch isn't cheap by any means. I mean I normally don't even spend 45 for dinner! But sometimes you just have to splurge a little.
author: Quoc N.

description:
Dinner review.

Nigiri dishes - 4/5 - Good variety
Gindara - 4/5 
Hamachi Kama - 3/5
Ika - 3/5
Negi Toro roll - 3/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: I don't eat sushi very often, but when I do I try to go to the best and Akikos definitely hit that mark. The sushi was amazing and the service was great! They were accommodating of allergies too. This place definitely deserves their reputation as one of the best (if not the best) sushi in SF.
author: Tori Z.

description:
This is not about the food, but the service. 

My party and I didn't have a reservation. I was the first to arrive at 7 and was told immediately there is a table for two until 8:15. I said ok and my friend is on his way. The host asked me to wait as they prepares table. During the waiting time the same host seated another party who has reservation. Then at 7:10 after 10 mins of waiting, the host came over and told me they won't be able to accommodate if my friend arrive after 7:15. 

While I am totally cool with the resteraunt reservation and seating rule. Waiting for 10 mins right inside next to the tiny entrance was not at all comfortable, let alone see her walked by multiple times and knowing she had all the chances to tell me that shouldn't be the kind of service any resteraunts should have.
author: Ken L.

description:
Just ate here for dinner and spent over a hour enjoying my omakase meal :) I was not expecting such an authentic Japanese style place in downtown SF. I almost did not go in!!! I sat at the bar and had an awesome variety of nigiri and sashimi prepared for me. I tried things I have never tried before like barracuda, eel fish, hokkaido scallop, and more. 

I outlasted a couple that was already eating when I came in and another couple came in during my meal and I outlasted them as well. I just kept wanting to try more and was excited to see what else the chef would put together. My chef was a cute lil japanese guy who did not say much, but you could see the care he took in making each nigiri (you didn't even need soy sauce...just their VERY delish wasabi). My meal cost $116 (without tip and I had hot tea) and it was money well spent. I would come back here again for sure!!!

I was told that 70% of the fish here is imported from Japan. They even import from Hawaii as well.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
After trying this place for 4 times, I am very very disappointed with the service of Chief Ricky. 

Importantly, I can say their nigiri selections are the best with various options of fishes and perfect tastes (even though it is a high-end sushi). However, if the service in a high-end restaurant is bad, I don't see the need to come here. 

So I made a reservation to seat at the bar with my boyfriend. Seriously, there was only one couple seating far from us and Ricky was the only one serving us. However, his attitude and service was just unacceptable. I never had a chief, who does not greet us as we seat. So we were ready to order and no one was ready to take the order and no water was served as well. After calling out for a waitress, she told us to order directly to the chief, who doesn't even bother to serve us. So I said "Excuse me, we are ready to order." Then finally he said "what do you want?"

Hmmmm.... Excuse me.... We just wanted to get out right there. Seriously, who would serve a customer like that. But their nigiri are good and with that cold weather and time, we didn't want to find another dinner place. So we told him what we wanted thinking that he's having a bad day. But mostly the point of seating at the bar is to get a detailed service from a chief. WOW!! Seriously, he served us with 5-7 sushi at a time (instead of one by one) and explained too fast that we didn't hear which fish is what. Seriously, if you are having a bad day, don't express it out when that is your job!!!! 

So usually when we go eat sushi, it takes about 1:30 - 2 hours. But it took us 40 minutes to finish our meal. Although the food is good, if the service is this bad I wouldn't come back here AT ALL. 

By the way, after we finished our nigiri, an "important" couple seat next to us. And wow, Ricky's service was totally different. It looked like they were their regular customer by he knows what they wanted. But seriously, treating customers should not be that much different. Oh well, not coming back here but people should know to not seat at the bar or not even come here for their unacceptable service.
author: Alice C.

description:
We were there at lunch, ordered Omakase, sake and few items from Omakase we've had(because they were awesome). Roughly around 200 per person. We were sitting at the bar, watching chef preparing our food. Overall it was a fun experience. Good food. Good service. 
Btw, I was told that dinner is by reservations only.
author: Matt R.

description: I came here for our anniversary dinner and ended up ordering an additional order of the sake sushi instead of dessert because it was that good. A week later I went to a Michelin star sushi restaurant for my birthday and it was actually disappointing after having sushi from Akiko. You spoiled us!
author: Joanna L.

description:
Excellent sushi for a pretty decent price (and by Montgomery). The omakaze is ~$100 for 13 pieces of nigiri.

There is no sign here so it was kinda hard to find but my friend and I managed to find it after walking back and forth a couple of times. We made it 10 mins before Akiko opened and we were the first in line. We were seated right away but 10 mins after we were seated, the whole place was packed and people had to wait. All the tables were reserved!

So glad we were early! It was so cold outside tooo

After we were seated, I got the omakaze and my friend ordered some rolls. The rolls were pretty cheap for like $10-15. 

The omakaze was so bomb, it was beautifully presented and the waiter explained each nigiri to us. My favorite was the mackeral and the wagyu beef nigiri. 

Everything was really delicate and I especially liked that they made cuts into some of fish so that it wrapped around the rice really well. Also, the little sauce they added in were able to seep into the cuts, making each piece taste better! 

Love the attention to detail and will definitely come back!
author: Janet K.

description:
Sushi is fresh and good here but def not $$ as it says on yelp.  
I personally prefer just going to Kusakabe if I have to spend $100 on sushi here.
author: C M.

description: You better have made a reservation because this place is usually busy and small.  At first it was hard to find, kind of hidden.  The interior was great, a nice warm cozy feeling.  We were tucked away in a small corner of the restaurant, you will be sitting pretty close to other guests too.  Maybe some of the best sushi I've had.  Their selection varies by the season but everything we ordered was great.  I love the brown rice for the nigiri, perfectly balanced acidity with the vinegar.  It's definitely on the pricier side but you are paying for freshness and quality of fish/rice.
author: Bax T.

description:
A tucked away gourmet, sushi and sashimi spot in FiDi!

I love the feel to this hole in the wall and prefer to sit either near the windows or chef's table to watch them roll up the orders! 

Do order up their omakase!  Their selections of sashimi, nigiris and uni, exudes freshness that one can surely taste and treasure.  I love their Russian uni.  The taste and texture, was surely atypical and delightful to the palate.  Something different was their cooked, black cod.  It was rich with omega 3. 

I simply loved all the servings.  The downfall was that the service time, took quite some time.  It took awhile for the dishes to be out and the turnover of tables, but it is a small place afterall.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
This review is specifically about the omakase experience, I can't speak to the a la cart menu:

Absolutely delicious sushi. 5 Star food; Taste, presentation and quality all top notch.

The service is not what I would expect from a 5 star spot so all in all, 4 stars. Would have been 5 with a little more attentive front of house staff (except the dude who cosntantly refilled our water, he was excellent).

Still, I'll be back for the fish.
author: Dennis A.

description: Very good... expensive, but very good! The flavor was exceptional as well as the presentation. We had Horshoe crab, tamago, uni (which I don't really like but I figured if I was going to have it again anywhere I would try it here), ikura, aji, saba, toro and a few others.... it was a very good experience.
author: E. V.

description: If you don't have a reservation, the hostess won't even let you wait, so don't even try coming here without one. Rude.
author: Kelsey V.

description: Delicious! The sashimi tasted very fresh and the cod was also really good.  The wine pours seemed small and the atmosphere was a little stuffy, but overall a nice dinner.
author: Janelle F.

description: Fresh off the boat...literally. All my sashimi had just come in from Japan. WOW!
author: Al R.

description: Very good sushi.  Interesting combinations and some unusual combinations.  The presentation of the dishes was​ excellent!
author: John F.

description:
Easily my go-to sushi restaurant in SF. The lack of pretension combined with exceptional sushi has me looking forward to coming back. Game plan for next visit:
 - Reorder: More from that Nama menu, Futo Roll, Both mackerel dishes from the kitchen. Ask for Ponzu instead of Soy
 - Try: Mix in a few more kitchen items. 
 - Avoid: forgetting to make a res early

Note to self: Allen is solid. Need to control menu choice and go easy on Nama
author: Jeff F.

description:
This is a fantastic omakase restaurant.  We were here for 2hrs and were treated like royalty. The best spot in the house is at the bar right next to the prep-chef.  Order omakase and they do the rest...fish I've never heard of from all over the world.  Who's ever had Japanese trigger fish?  Or fatty tuna belly or wagu beef with a truffle slice.  Our taste buds had a party tonight and we were not disappointed.   We will be back!
It is a time place without a sign so remember the address...431 as it is the only indication that you e arrived.  The staff is very friendly and should you arrive early, they'll send you down the street, at a recommended bar, for a quick drink...
Literally a "must try" if you're a foodie.  I'll never look at sushi the same way.  
...be back soon...
author: Dio S.

description: This is the freshest sushi I have ever had. I'm from LA and this place beets anything from LA. The only criticism I have is their service, it's super slow. And the place is super cramped. It's the best sushi place for those who appreciate fish and rice though. Their saki was also really good. Their fish is very fresh and they have a good variety. I didn't go here to get full, however, I went here full. If I was starving I wouldn't recommend it because it is fairly pricey
author: Natalie K.

description: One of the best I've had....and I have devoured a lot of really great sushi. Pricey so don't come famished. Come here for the enjoyment of the flavors...not just for the purpose of getting full.
author: Estella G.

description: Went to sf for vacation , and stop by at this place .and I'm indulge my self trying their uni's, it was phenomenal experience , the hostess is very nice , and the chef is very helpful (I forgot his name ) give me an idea and information about the fish, if you sushi lover,I suggest sitting in the bar , you will see the art of the sushi making , and they gladly help you out what is fresh for today .
author: Mecca A.

description:
This was a great spot for sushi lunch. I had a standard salmon roll, but I also got a piece of wild eel sushi. It was literally the BEST eel I have had. 

I also had the soft shell crab appetizer and it was delicious too.


Now, I'm no sushi expert, but for the average American like me, this place was absolutely amazing.

The next time I go, I would want to try the tasting menu.
author: Jon U.

description: Even if I haven't seen the world! I've never really eaten such a good Japanese cuisine!
author: Renee Z.

description: Ate here the other night. Food was good and staff was good about refilling waters. The good aspects end there. Service was dismal, especially for the price point. They brought out a dish that we didn't order. I understand the confusion: we ordered masaba (nigiri); they thought we wanted saba (shio). However, the server never confirmed what we ordered. Most frustrating was that they gave us a lot of trouble about sending it back, insisting it was what we ordered. Another server tried to give it to us again saying it was what we ordered, then rolled her eyes at us. The original server never checked on us, except to ask if we were done after having only agedashi tofu and 4 pieces of nigiri. When I noted that the food was talking a long time (all the tables around us who ordered multiple rounds of food after us were already getting their food) the waitress made a long winded excuse about the mix-up, in effect blaming us for their rude and slow service. Having a cold server would have been fine had our order been correct. In addition, the servers seemed to be going out of their way to be hyper-attentive to the tables beside us. The hostess and the runner were accomodating. But, I've never felt such open disdain from the waitstaff. We would never come back here given how rudely we were treated.
author: shro t.

description: I fail to see what all the hype is about.   I've eaten here a few times over the years.  Akiko's sushi is average and uninspired.  What's worse, their tsunami of 5 star reviews (most of which are written by out of towners) have GONE TO THEIR HEADS.  FOH is chirpingly elitist and selective as to who they want to seat.  BOH are arrogant, desultory and just plain rude.   Recently, they refused to seat us even though we were there at opening.   There are MANY other GREAT sushi places in the City, even close to Union Square.   This place is passé.   It's JUST NOT WORTH THE EFFORT.
author: Max K.

description: There is not a large place but we were lucky to get a seat at the sushi bar. The fish portions were huge and excellently prepared with use of smoke flavors for several items.
author: Joseph W.

description:
Awful service from disinterested server

Vague descriptions of items

Poorly constructed rolls

Chewy, bad seaweed

Expensive

Sad
author: Jonny H.

description:
Solid 3,5 stars. 

We ordered omakase to avoid planning and choosing.  Out of our 15-course dinner we did enjoy 3 or 4 pieces, other than that it was okay.

Service was not good. Throughout my dinner I had empty water glass - nobody cared. My dining companion ordered sake and by the 4th course was done with it - nobody asked him if he wants another one until we got the last plate in. 

Total cost was $300 for 2 with one sake glass.
author: Anelya S.

description: Oh my God this was the best sushi I've had in my life. I took my bf here and he loved it. I mean LOVED it. He's really into art and sushi, so I got him both!
author: Hannah S.

description: Very good food, also very welcoming restaurant. The waitress was very attentive to make sure we had what we needed and the it was actually quite cheap compared to most restaurants around the area. We ordered the seaweed salad and it was delicious with a hint of spicy and perfect seasoning. Both rolls were very good and filling but refreshing st the same time (California and Philadelphia.) my favorite was the warm sake
author: Nicole K.

description:
Man this place is tricky to find when you're tipsy lol....I definitely got lost because there's no clear sign. If you see an Irish Pub sign pointing towards a direction, that's basically exactly where this is located.

Great food and service, definitely on the pricier side but treat yourself, you do you!. The raw fish here are very fresh and their cooked dishes are quite tasty also. The highlight of my night was their Hokaido Uni, LIFE CHANGING, best uni hands down. I had climaxed and didn't eat anything after that just to end on a good note. Their seared salmon sashimi and white tuna belly were also my other favorites of the night.

Their omakase is pretty pricey here, though they don't tell you the set price on the menu which is tricky and can be quite dangerous. I'd advise just ordering what you know you like on the menu to save some money.
author: Kathy L.

description: Make a reservation.  Single guy tied to enter 40 minutes before closing. 3 seats recently vacated at the sushi bar. Hostess basically told me to go away and there would be nothing for me.  Not typical for bar service but whatever.... got a snotty story about how I should reserve etc etc.  oh well....
author: Doug R.

description: This is the best traditional sushi restaurant in town!! The selection was amazing and really unique. The food tasted incredible and everything was fresh and made with care. The service was amazing, the setting was nice, and the servers were very kind and helpful. I would totally recommend this place if you're up for an authentic sushi experience.
author: Chloe Z.

description: My husband and I ate here for dinner and had the best experience! The service was amazing with fine dining feel, the freshest sushi we have ever had...literally...was so yummy. We will be back next time we visit SF. The miso soup was the best I've ever had...and I've had alot of miso...
author: Natalie K.

description:
I was expecting it to be expensive, which it was. I was not expecting tiny sushi pieces for the price. Not good service. Not good quality. Very disappointed. Sushi experience lessened by staff speaking Chinese.
 Maybe a better review if was cheaper. Should be $$$$ not $$$.
 Better choices nearby.
author: joe n.

description:
The food was delicious. The service was by a young woman who would have rather been anywhere else but here. As soon as I finished one dish, she was ready to give me my check. Nothing else. Everyone who came in, had 1 if not 2 pieces, and then were shuffled out.

Will I go back? no. Good luck
author: Lynda W.

description: Best Sushi. Unbelievable variety of fish. An absolute must try if you are in San Francisco.
author: Randal G.

description:
Akiko's is my go to lunch spot when I want both superb Japanese food and to be able to have a conversation with the person sitting across from me. I especially enjoy the salmon teriyaki but I've also liked the tonkatsu, udon and beef teriyaki (all of which come with miso soup and four pieces of nigiri or sashimi). Akiko's never disappoints!

Though not cheap, I find Akiko's to be great value given the quality of the ingredients and care with which they are prepared. 

Reservations are a must at this tiny restaurant.
author: Miriam W.

description: Make sure to make a reservation! No space available even on a Wednesday evening for one, even at the bar. Hostess made me feel crazy for not having a reservation. Warranted? not sure.
author: Bryan C.

description: Totally RIDICULOUS - stopped in on a Wednesday at 7p - multiple open tables and numerous seats at the bar but was told everything was spoken for and we couldn't be seated until at least 9p.  For real?? What a JOKE!   Don't care how good the food might be - any restaurant that doesn't accommodate walk ins shouldn't be in business.  Do yourself a BIG a favor - PASS on this overhyped establishment!
author: David C.

description:
The best thing I had in Akiko is their tea. We ordered the Nigiri sampler and the rice was dried and hard. The fish had no flavor and it tasted old. It feels like they just slapped a piece of fish on rice. I honestly don't know where the 4 stars are coming from. Considering the price which should be $$$ instead of $$, the sushi was extremely disappointed and overpriced. I feel like I wasted my money here and probably could've gone to a cheaper place where the sushi could be 5 times better.

The interior is nice though, but there's really nothing going on with the food.
author: Jing W.

description:
Nice decor and service. I thought the sushi was very fresh and quite delicious, but the udon was another story. Broth was pretty tasteless, and they use thinner noodles that didn't fulfill my udon craving :( 

Service was also pretty slow, but my waitress brought extra tempura to compensate for it, which was a nice touch. I would give the place a second chance if I were in the neighborhood. 

3.5 stars
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
This place is BS!!  I've tried to go there on SEVERAL occasions and when we walked in the door, we were told we couldn't be served until after 9:00 pm or later. YET, there were NUMEROUS seats without people in them. THAT is total BS!.

There should be a law passed in San Francisco AGAINST reservation only restaurants!!!

If I can't just walk into a restaurant that has open seats and sit down, then this restaurant needs to be banned from operating!!!
author: mary p.

description:
Okay. Not really sure where to start with this. I came here for lunch a few months ago and it was a total 5 star experience for me -- felt like I was mindblown by how high quality the food was and how delicious it was. But I came here last night for the omakase and was severely underwhelmed by how mediocre the entire omakase experience was. Unfortunately, I'm writing this review post that recent experience so my review will be a little less than desirable, but eh. What happens happens.

Akiko's is a reservation only restaurant -- all you do is email the restaurant to make a reservation. It's not particularly hard to get them e.g. I've always emailed a few days in advance and had no problems. The crowd is definitely FiDi business people lunch eating kind of atmosphere, so it's classy etc. 

The lunch set I had was quite simple -- some rice and some sashimi pieces. I've uploaded photos for my dinner --there were quite a variety of things -- scallops, black cod, mackeral, salmon, yellowtail, lean tuna, etc. Interesting mix of sashimi and some other raw fish with some nigiri pieces. Overall... it just wasn't an amazing experience. The sushi was okay, but I was pretty intrigued by the rice since it looked like brown rice but didn't have the texture of it? I was confused. I also found it really weird that for an omakase they didn't give us our own place. For one dish, we were served one cooked black cod which is fine because I was with a friend, but what if we were coworkers? That would have been a bit awkward and strange if we had to split the fish with our chopsticks and share off of it. 

Another odd thing -- they made a specific deal about asking us about what we didn't like. My friend said she didn't like cilantro. Then the first dish they served us ... had cilantro. Like why?? What was the point of asking if you weren't going to honor it? Or did you already forget? Unclear.

Anyways, each fish was above average I guess... but the final omakase was $125 after tax and tip. You can get a Jiro's apprentice omakase for $125 in NYC ... I'd much rather eat that than eat here. Fish was generally fresh and good, but I just wish there was more nigiri since I left pretty hungry but didn't feel like adding more to the baseline omakase since I knew it was going to be $$$$. In retrospect, we should have just customized our omakase and ordered fish on our own rather than letting the chef choose. 

tldr; lunch is better than dinner, imho. it's cheaper too. make sure to email in for reservations cause you're unlikely to get in by walking
author: Jasmine X.

description:
One of my favorite sushi places in the city! The price justifies the quality of the fish. We ordered the Omakase - chef's sushi special, 8-9 sushi pieces total. 

My friend and I ate at the bar and enjoyed watching the chefs make our sushi. It was like a mini fire show we enjoyed talking with the chefs who explained the different sushi to us noobs. 

I liked how the miso soup wasn't too salty. A lot of sushi restaurants in the city serve extremely salty miso soups. At the end, we got the 5 piece sashimi - white maguro. I felt each piece literally melting in my mouth. I would def come here again. Love the vibe as well!
author: Christine C.

description: Chef Alex gave me a really good Omakase for my Christmas Eve dinner.  All the pieces were amazing and they had four different kinds of uni that night.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Ok, this is overdue for an update. Look, it's still good, the quality (I think) is great, the flavors are sensational. But the days of spending $40 for a light-ish dinner for two are long, long, long gone, as were the rolls in my prior review. San Francisco, right? I guess they still have rolls, but not those other (cheaper/more filling) ones. No more scallop dumplings or horsehair crab! 

In sum, pricey, quality restaurant, but now with more traditional flavors.
author: B Y.

description: This is a small traditional sushi restaurant who get their fish flown in from Japan! They even have live prawn sashimi but unfortunately it had sold out before we got there. Enough said... for the real sushi connoisseur this place delivers but yes you will pay for it. Best seat is at the bar where you can interact with the chef's and watch the sushi being made. Don't get it confused with another nearby restaurant called Akiko's Sushi and Bar or something like that. Will for sure be back to this place.
author: Minh T.

description:
Orders were very small but delicious. Sunomono was so small as to be barely shareable. 
Unagi was perfect. No sugary sauce. 
Smoked sesame ice cream was delightful. 
I love the tea cups, such great weight and texture. 
Ordered sake that never arrived. Wasn't on the bill so didn't have to argue, just skipped it.
author: Alexa H.

description:
My new crush: Akiko's!!!

I've been here twice: once as a walk in with one other person (a la carte) and the second time with a group reservation for omakase (the max is 4 per party and is recommended that you rsvp in advance). 

And oh my gashe (see what I did there?)! Both times the food was delightful. I especially recommend the deep sea red grouper, sea trout, uni, and... well, basically everything! 

My friend and I each had about 11 pieces of nigiri and paid ~$60 plus sake. We were both pretty satisfied. Not hungry until later into the night when we got some golden boy from North Beach. My friend and I were lucky in that we came in on a Saturday at 8pm and the guy was able to seat us in 15 minutes. Apparently, this is atypical. 

Omakase was $130/person (pictures are on their way up here). I would say my only disappointment (other than the fact that I will never have an endless river of sushi flow before my eyes and into my mouth -- this will only happen in my dreams), is that usually I enjoy hearing what everything actually is; we had a hodgepodge of wait people, and several of them mumbled or didn't even explain. Super sad face. But all is forgiven in light of the quality fish meats! 

Fidi, so parking is rough, but if you take bart BART, Akiko's is definitely walkable. Also... omakase well get you ice cream mochi for dessert!
author: Michelle K.

description: 1st we couldn't find it by the address because there is no sign. Then they asked if we has a reservation. It was lunch time. The food was fair a little above average but the menu was very limited. The prices were high for what we had (For goodness sakes your not Nobu), the service was good but not memorable.
author: Paul A.

description:
The best sushi you can get during lunch in FiDi. Took the husband here for a belated Father's Day lunch, and we decided to splurge on the omakase ($100-$120 depending on the day's offerings). It was very, very good, especially if you are lucky enough to get the wagyu beef with truffle in the end. All the fish selections were fresh and delicious, especially the Hokkaido uni and amaebi (sweet shrimp). 

I do agree with another reviewer that the rice didn't seem to hold together well (a couple of our nigiris would just fall apart) and some of the fish had too much wasabi. It needs some more finesse to compete with Wako and Kusakabe (still our top favorites) but it's a great spot for weekday lunch and I wouldn't hesitate to come back.
author: Jen K.

description:
My best friend and I spontaneously came across this restaurant while yelping for a good place to eat walking distance from Union Square. 

We walked into Akiko and were immediately greeted. However, what caught us by surprise was that the greeter asked us if we had a reservation. I did not read other yelpers' tips prior to walking in, so I had no idea that we had to have a reservation. I explained to her that we just came across the restaurant on Yelp and it was just for the two of us. She looked around and seated us right away. (Yay! Granted, we did walk in at 5:30PM on a Thursday, so it wasn't THAT crowded) ((Note to future self: make a reservation beforehand!!!))

Our friendly waiter, Alan, offered us water and gave us ample time to go over the menu. 

What we initially ordered:
1 edamame
2 Ji-kinmedai nigiri (nice salty & buttery taste!)
2 Amaebi nigiri (crunchy and buttery taste!)
1 order Kuromatsu nigiri (meaty & the melt-in-your-mouth type of fish!)
1 Spider roll (nice and crispy taste without that weird shellfish after taste!)
2 Sayuri sake 

First round of nigiri was so good, flavorful and buttery! However, what really stole our hearts was the Kuromatsu nigiri. My best friend said we should order another nigiri, but I opted for the 5-piece sashimi. When it came out, the dish legit sparkled with the fish oil and they were presented on the shishio leaf with radish. It was so good, my friend and I totally forgot about our sake! Turns out, Alan had forgotten to bring it out to us.  

He apologized and brought it out for us and said the sake was on him. We were surprised and felt that he truly did care about the experience we were getting at Akiko. 

Long story, short:
(+) excellent quality of food
(+) amazing service (ask for Alan! He gives great eating tips and can provide you with really good recommendations.)
(+) great selection of sake/wine/
(+) menu organization between different fish with clear descriptions 
(+) presentation of each dish was on point

(-) a bit pricey, but it's San Francisco. $10 for one nigiri was a little over my head since I hail from LA. 
(-) no complimentary edamame or miso soup

Overall, I would give this place 4.5 stars, but bumping it up for Alan's amazing service, tips and the quality of food! Will definitely come back... with a reservation next time! Thank you for the awesome dinner and experience!
author: Nicole Q.

description: Nice restaurant but we did not have a good server and he greatly affected our experience
author: Robin H.

description: Extremely rude girl as the hostess. After her attitude I couldn't care less how good the food is. Will not be back.
author: Rob F.

description: I am regular here. One of the best sushi spots in this neighborhood.  A little more expensive than some of the other nearby sushi places, but the selection, preparation, and presentation of the fish is better. More better!
author: Peyton M.

description: I was looking forward to having dinner at Akiko's with my BF last Saturday as we've been to Akiko's before but We were so disappointed. We came at 5:30pm and requested if we could be accommodated earlier than the 7:15 seating that my BF has reserved online. We were told that there were no seats available for us until our reserved time. However, their website was accepting reservations for several slots at 15-min increments way prior to our 7:15 reservation. (It was already 6:20 when I checked Yelp to see if Akiko is still accepting reservations and there were several slots open at 15-min increments starting at 6:30pm). We cancelled our Akiko reservation upon seeing the open slots online and ended up at PABU by Michael Mina.  At PABU we had the omakase plus the supplement and it was a great dinner starting from the happy spoon to the foie gras (all of them great tasting) and ending with the monaka dessert. My BF and I decided we will never go back to Akiko as I don't think they really care about retaining customers. There are so many restaurants out there that are way much better than Akiko.
author: A S.

description: We had a fabulous time this evening. The service was amazing and the food tasted so fresh. The ambience was perfect. Loved it. Can't wait to return!
author: Briana W.

description: Visited on a Friday night.  Ordered omakase.  Highlights were scallop, Australian sea trout with fragrant smoke emanating when dome covering it was opened, and surprisingly, chawanmushi.  Many of the sushi offerings tasted under seasoned, with no soy sauce offered to season to our tasting; many sushi restaurants who do this have perfect seasoned sushi that doesn't need additional seasoning by the patron.  The bill was $300 for 2 people, no alcohol.  If we do return, may do a la carte.
author: E C.

description: Very fresh fish, but small portions & expensive for what you get. We literally left hungry and had extremely slow service. There are only about five options for sushi rolls, which was a disappointment because their menu you link to through Yelp shows 11 rolls. In fact, it's a completely dIfferent menu. That should be updated. The table next to us was being served Omakase (chef's choice). That looked pretty exciting & their food came out regularly & frequently. We were told MP on Omakase was around $120 pp though!
author: Andrea R.

description: Really good sushi and fresh fish. This place is for sushimi and nigiri to taste the fresh fish. Not really a roll type of place. My favorite is the ocean trout. Yum
author: Devin H.

description:
Had Lunch here and loved it. Fresh sushi that melts in your mouth. Service was fast too which is great for lunch. Fish Portions are a bit small so you'll just have to do a carb loaded last dish. 

I'll be back for dinner
author: VIOLA L.

description:
I have tried to go here several times. Even on an off day you need a reservation or you can forget about it.  Today I happened by about 15 min before they closed after lunch and managed to walk in. 

The place is small and snug but a nice atmosphere. You won't get private but you will get intimate if you want. The service was polite and efficient. They came quickly, didn't chit chat too much, and got things done. 

The fish was amazing!!  I had the nigiri sampler.  There were 6 pieces and all were different.  The presentation was precision and generally fantastic. Plus, it was the best piece of big eye tuna I have EVER had.  The menu isn't large but there is a nice selection of top quality fish. 

Prices are a bit high but not out of line for the quality. The sampler was $26, 6 pieces and nothing else. Sashimi comes on sets of 3 for about $12-15, rolls are $10 or so. Obviously some things are much more and not much less.  

Last words:  this place is worth the cost. Fantastic, I will be back and you should too.
author: John Z.

description: I read an article that this sushi place was in the top 10 for sushi places in San Francisco. You know damn well that I was going to try it especially since I was in Japan 3 months ago. I wasn't disappointed. Obviously the fish was fresh since you are paying top dollar. I was sitting at the sushi bar and I had my own sushi chef. Unfortunately he wasn't Japanese but he was still a nice dude originally from the Phillipines. I suggest you arrive at 11:30 sharp for a seat. Don't try to go inside sooner or else the hot host will yell at you. They mean business here. Overall I was happy and so was my tummy. I would go again. Even King Neptune would be happy. Go forth and do good things.
author: Edward M.

description:
Small place, showed up around 12pm
on a Monday. Everything was delicious, especially the hamachi belly and house roll.
author: Seth E.

description: The food was amazing! Real Japanese food. So far, best sushi I have eaten. I totally recommend it
author: Clacla H.

description: Karina was a wonderful waitress she took us through a wonderful flight of omakasa. Could not recommend it enough. Smoked fish and wagu were the best. Home made sesame ice cream to finish was out of this world.
author: Emma F.

description: Delicious sushi, accommodating! We had a great omakase experience here! Our waiter was extremely friendly and our entire dinner was absolutely lovely!
author: Kimberlie Y.

description:
Akiko's is overpriced for the quality of sushi they serve. There's an $85 minimum per person, which I'm happy to pay for excellent sushi, but Akiko's is not worth it. I would much rather go to Maruya for authentic high quality sushi. If you a TRUE sushi aficionado and you have lived in Japan, you will know the difference. Otherwise, you might think Akiko's sushi is really good (as demonstrated by my American friends' raving recommendations). 

The restaurant itself is very chic and modern. It's well decorated and has a good atmosphere for date night. I saw a lot of couples here. The restaurant is pretty small, so I would not come with a big group. Probably 2-4 people is ideal. It was a little bit hard to find at first since there's no sign outside that says Akiko's. 
I came on a Saturday night with 4 other people and the restaurant was full. We had a reservation at 7 and we arrived 10 minutes early and had to wait till 7 to be seated. 

We sat for about 15 minutes and were not served water or given menus until I asked someone for the menu. Our waiter did not do a good job of explaining their offers. He asked us if we were all doing the omakase and when I asked if that was our only option, he said yes. But since my boyfriend's dad doesn't eat a lot of raw fish, we asked if we could see the menu and if he could order off of the menu instead and then he said that would be fine as long as he hit the $85 minimum. Then why did you say we HAD to do the omakase!!  -_- We were very confused as to why the menu offered so many food options from the kitchen if everyone was required to do the omakase. 

We waited quite a while for our food. The first 2 dishes were an avocado mixed greens salad and an octopus cucumber salad. They were both average and pretty small. Then we were served Hamachi kama and were confused if this was part of the omakase or not since the server didn't say anything. I was under the assumption that the omakase was for sashimi and sushi. I wasn't expecting Hamachi Kama so I asked the waiter to walk us through what is included in the omakase. He probably should have told us in the beginning or given us an omakase menu. 

Next, we were served assorted sashimi which included salmon, Hamachi, and other fish. Nothing too impressive. After the sashimi we probably waited 20 minutes or more before they finally served us the nigiri. The timing was all off. While we waited a long time between each course, when they started bringing the nigiri out, they brought out the next piece before we were even done with the first few pieces they brought out. In a real sushi restaurant, the chef should serve each piece individually and wait till you are finished with one before serving the next so that each piece is served fresh. 

The uni (sea urchin) and hotate (scallops) were decently good, but not the best.  The gindara was probably the best thing I ate there. It wasn't part of the omakase though. 

At the end of the meal, our server didn't even ask us if we wanted desert...Our total bill came out to $525 including tip. Pretty pricey for mediocre sushi. 

In conclusion, our experience was sub par and I will not be going back to Akiko's when I can get better quality fish and service at Maruya for the same price.
author: Mai Y.

description:
Live dangerously. #iamthedanger

No Cottonmouth. #snowscalp
No Copperhead. #heartstab
No Sidewinder. #briefcase
No Mountain. #squishy
No Bill. #spoiler #deathmove

No RSVP. #rsvpsareforbasicfoodies
No Shave. #scruffypitcrew #nobromo
No A la carte. #goomakaseorgohome
No Leftovers. #eatallthefoods
No Change. #makeitrain #dripdrop
author: Dan B.

description: Came here on a Wednesday night for dinner with coworkers as it was recommended by one of my friends. It was a small restaurant and we had to wait for 20 minutes even with our reservation. I was amazed by the items offered on their menu, including unprocessed uni and black tuna (I still don't know what a black tuna is, but it tasted good..) . So I ordered the scallop, black tuna, unprocessed uni, and some white fish sushi. I have to say that unprocessed uni was great, but not to the Santa Barbara red uni that I once had. I might not be comparing apples to apples, but in my mind, that was the top quality uni that I used as the standard. The other sushi were great quality stuff, but a bit over priced in my opinion. Great restaurant, good service, but I will probably try other places if I'm around the area again.
author: Felix K.

description: Horrible service. Completely rude. They had plenty of empty seats. Wouldn't entertain seating us. They said "they're full." Can't imagine turning down paying customers. But they did. I don't care how many stars they have. I would not ever attempt to eat here again!
author: Haitham A.

description:
Sushi: 5, fish was so fresh!! 
Service: 3, staff was super friendly but the service was SOOOO SLOW. Omg. 6 pieces of nigiri took 2 hours. 

Def recommend coming here, but make sure you have time.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Fantastic ! Taste as good as it looks! Amazing !
Sugoi Oishi! Pricey but worth it. Very very fresh fish. The Uni flight is also amazing .
author: Miguel G.

description:
I LOVE the interior of Akiko's - it's very unassuming from the street (you would miss it, if you don't know it's there), but once you walk in the charming exposed brick and cozy tables are very welcoming. 

As far as the food goes, I left happy but not wowed. I thought the black tuna was fresh but overpriced, the agedashi tofu I would not order again (not enough flavor, the texture was a bit off), but I did REALLY like the uni special roll we got. That was probably the best uni I've ever had. The 'hara sake' (seared salmon belly) was also very good.

Other rolls fell somewhere in the middle - good (we finished them!), but not super memorable. 

They do have a nice variety of sake, and their service is extremely attentive and on-point.
author: Catie F.

description: Probably a top 3 sushi spot for me.  I recommend booking resi's as they commonly can't work in walk-ins.  The fish is always high quality and the staff is always friendly.  A little on the pricier side though.
author: Bryan G.

description:
This is one of the best sushi restaurants in San Francisco. Every single thing on their well curated menu is incredible and delicious. If you're celebrating, their omakase is superb and well thought out.

One fun discovery during one lunch one day was that the entire restaurant team had "gone fishing" at the market in Japan. It was on a note on the door and it is that level of dedication to excellence as a team that makes Akiko's an impeccable experience.
author: Tina H.

description:
fish is fresh enough
the way dealing with fish is ok
nice service
decoration is ok
some unique dishes is a plus
author: Xuyu Z.

description: No doubt that Akiko's is authentic. My husband and I came at about 7:30 with no reservation, and we were seated at the sushi bar. There are only about 4 tables + 4 seats at the sushi bar and this little hole in the wall. We spent most of dinner closely watching the chef artistically create sushi rolls with technique and perfection. My husband tried the dish with 5 pieces of nigiri and 5 pieces of sashimi, and I got the Philadelphia roll. Both were delicious! The miso soup and seaweed salad were also tasty. I ordered the mango mochi , which came with whipped cream and chocolate drizzle, a shock to me as this is not how I usually eat mochi. It was also pretty melted from the start. I gave Akiko's four stars because of the mochi, slow service and cramped environment (this may just be characteristic of SF though).
author: Lauren G.

description:
Quality fish from Jap
High end sushi bar that I can tell .
Price is definitely $$$+
I and my gf ( she only ate a little) spend 200$ 

Sushi is like 
[


                           that big


                                                                   ]

The width of your iPhone 6

Not place you can get big portion of foods.

Taste is definitely wonderful.
author: Yuanren P.

description: Fantastic sushi, chef Wayne was awesome. We are very picky and this was excellent sushi. We did omakase  it was absolutely fantastic
author: Kelsie D.

description:
Buttery, light fish. Unique flavors and amazing sake for the table ( only $16 but so much light rice flavor) 

$4-$7 vegetarian rolls and $10 sake rolls. 

Great offering and we made a reservation in advance. 

Intimate setting ( about 25-30 people).
author: Steph M.

description: This is a nice location with great ambiance (if you don't mind a small place).  My wife and I enjoyed the food, it was of great quality and flavor.
author: PJ L.

description:
Went in for dinner with the family a few days ago. The sushi is excellent quality, but I thought the sashimi cuts were a little skimpy for the price. The service was pretty good, but the waitress we had definitely had attitude. Maybe she was having a bad night or maybe she didn't like it that we had kids with us. Whatever, we're paying customers and a smile would have been in order. 

My son loves poke bowls and when I asked her if they could make one, she looked at me like I was crazy and never offered to ask the chef if he could make one. I get it this is a "refined" sushi restaurant, but give me a break. The chef could definitely put one together and considering I was there dropping a couple hundred bucks, you'd think she would have been a bit more accommodating. The place is tiny and it's definitely not ideal for kids, but mine are very well behaved and we take them to lots of upscale restaurants. 

I'd give it another go if I was in Union Square, but I'd sit at the bar for sure.
author: KC C.

description:
Akiko's is a very real threat to my weight and my wallet.

My friend and I snagged day-of reservations on OpenTable to satisfy some spur of the moment sushi cravings. We requested seats at the sushi bar but we ended up sitting in the back area instead. The interior can get somewhat hot and stuffy, but honestly, it's totally worth it for the delicious sushi.

They have unique types of fish that are difficult to find at other restaurants, so if you're looking to try something new you should definitely give Akiko's a shot. 

Our dishes:
- Boiled Spinach in Dashi Stock
- Agedashi Tofu
- Fried Cod Belly
- Sashimi (Black Tuna, Ocean Trout, Kanpachi, Red Grouper)
- Uni (Russian and Hokkaido)
- Snow Crab
- Scallop
- Miso Black Cod
- Shima-Aji
- Masaba
- Kasugodai
- Chu-Toro
- Ji-Kinmedai
- Ankimo
- A5 Wagyu
- Complimentary Mochilato Dessert

Everything was delicious, but the Russian Uni, Black Cod, Chu-Toro, and A5 Wagyu were outstanding. The A5 Wagyu in particular was exceptionally well done - one side was seared with salt and pepper, and it was topped with  dehydrated egg. Our server (who was a super awesome guy, by the way! He was very friendly and knowledgeable) mentioned that they used to serve it with truffle, but changed it up to better highlight the quality and flavor of the wagyu itself. 

I will definitely be back for another omakase adventure!
author: Kelly L.

description:
One word explains it all... FRESH!  This is not your typical Japanese sushi restaurant/bar, this place is an evolving restaurant fitting peoples needs.  Right when I walked in, I knew this place was different from others.  From the welcoming staff to the rustic setting and brick walls, this place was definitely different.

We got here at 11:30am right when they opened. Hostess, Karina (super friendly and accommodating) had to check with manager cause you usually have to make reservations. Thank goodness that she was able to take us in and kindly asked if we could just make sure to be done by 12:30... Absolutely, that's is plenty of time!

Menu was different, a few rolls, a few kitchen items but most definitely a lot of fresh Sashimi/Nigiri selection.  Oh they also have OMAKASE and SASHIMI TASTING, which I definitely want to try next time.  Since I am not familiar with all the different things on the menu, our server was definitely very helpful on explaining everything.   I tried a few different seared sashimi and it taste so buttery (does that even make sense!?) LOL!  It was very fresh!

We will definiltey come here again!
author: Kathy B.

description:
Great decor, good service, amazing food. 
They are short on space, you won't have much space to move around.
author: LuisD M.

description:
Very small Japanese restaurant. Friendly hostess. Waiter didn't crack a smile throughout our meal. 

Onto the food.  The kitchen items were tasty.
* Great sauce with the soft shelled crab. 
 * Tasty fried baby mackerels.  
 * Grilled Saba was juicy and flavorful! Not too fishy
 * The one disappointing item was the sunomono -  it was beautifully plated, but underdressed for my taste. Did they forget the vinegar?

Onto the sushi.  The nirigi were beautiful and well constructed. One bite each and no concerns about rice falling apart. 

The scallop was as sweet and wonderful as the ones I had in Hokkaido.  Medium fat maguro was yum!  The Hokkaido hairy crab, which was smoked, was beautifully executed, but such a tiny portion.  I'll be looking to try the snow crab leg next time.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
I don't usually write reviews but i feel like i have to do it with this one. 
Pros: 
- The service was great! I have to admit 
- The food plating was also really nice
- The atmosphere of the restaurant was amazing 

Cons:
- The restaurant was a bit hard to find since there is no sign (that has the name of the restaurant) outside so we had to actually got in and asked if we are at the right place 
- The restaurant was pretty small
- THE FOOD i think were OVERRATED!!! At that price point i was hoping to eat something that is mind blowing but it turned out that it was just "ok". I actually am pretty disappointed. I think i can eat something like that with WAY cheaper price at other Japanese restaurant
- The waitress was also didn't take notes of our order and ended up forgetting some of our orders and we had to called him and asked again if he put the order down
author: Yesenia L.

description:
Akiko's has been on my list for quite some time. I definitely thought it was excellent - from going a la carte or doing the omakase - everything here is optimal.

I decided to go with the Omakase and told them up front that my budget was $60. Definitely on the pricier side since I only got 8 pieces + 1 spoonful of Russian Uni. I later looked at the receipt and noted that the Toro and Uni were $11 a piece.

Regardless, the nigiri here is absolutely delicious - from the perfectly crafted sushi-rice to the perfectly-sized topped pieces of fish.

Service is excellent and fast. There's a bar that seats about 8-12 people, two or three small tables at the front, and about 7 more tables in the interior dining room. Go for a special treat!
author: Veronica S.

description:
Made a reservation for 8:45pm Friday night for 3 people. We were seated promptly. Even though the official closing time is 9:00pm the restaurant was still packed and when we left at 10 there were still a few parties staying there.

#Soft Shell Crab: B+.
If anything I would say it was not crispy enough. But overall I could still feel the crab meat structure and taste.

#Amaebi Nigiri: B+.
It was quite fresh. But again the fried shrimp head was not crispy enough.

#Sashimi Tasting: B.
We all got one order each, and before we ordered we were really struggling to decide between this and omakase. All of us really regretted it though - the fish selection was very ordinary (albacore tuna, big eye tuna, sea bass, king salmon, yellowtail). The freshness was okay but it's on the same level as any ordinary Japanese joints in the Bay Area. And it's $34 not cheap at all. Not sure if the omakase would be any better though. 

Overall, I think I would only go back for an omakase experience and see if it justifies for an additional star. Not very impressed with the rest of the menu though.
author: Simon C.

description:
Akiko's Restaurant, not to be mistaken by Akiko's Sushi Bar, has snagged chefs who have worked at some of the country's best sushi meccas (Sushi Ran, Ota, etc.) and boasts of amazing sushi and sushi accouterments such as Japanese applewood-aged soy sauce.

The boyfriend and I made reservations via open table.  While it was raining hard AF and I was recovering from a minor cold, I didn't want to reschedule.  I had been wanting to try out Akiko's for some time, and no one, not even monsoon rain and ebola could stop me.

We arrived and noticed the quaint cozy intimate restaurant.  There are like three random tables near the entrance, right before you see the high top sushi bar (which I recommend you request) - then there is an inner restaurant section with more tables.  We were graciously served by our waiter, whose name I can't remember, but his recommendations I will have in memory forever.  Their menu changes daily, and you can tell they take pride in using the finest quality of local and seasonal fresh fish.  Apparently- the fish arrive daily from local purveyors and Japan's Tsukiji Fish Market (insert swoon).

The beau and I opted for miso soup, edamame, their scallop roll, tekka roll, Hara Sake, Amaebi, Hotate, Negihama, and this amazing house salmon roll they had.  OMG the Amaebi and house Salmon roll were amazeballs!  

Totally worth it!
author: Luarnie B.

description:
Anytime someone asks the question, "What do you want to eat," my answer would be Japanese or French food. They can be iffy about my selection, but by the end of the night, they'll want to thank me. 

We ordered the omakase:

1) Kani-age = fried soft shell crab 
2) Hamachi kama = broiled yellowtail collar with ponzu sauce 
3) Kanpachi nigiri = amberjack
4) Hokkaido Hotate  = scallop
5) Nama sake = Copper River salmon
6) Nama uni = sea urchin
7) Kuro maguro = otoro
8) Kegani = horsehair crab
9) Miyazaki wagyu = A5 wagyu beef with truffle
10) Shiro toro = white tuna belly

The variety is sublime, from fresh sea urchin to A5 wagyu to scallop to Copper River salmon and more. Each bite was packed with freshness. 

Service was slow, but friendly. Finding this place at night can be tough due to their dark hidden barely noticeable sign. 

 I hope you give this delectable place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description: Did omakase. Some of the major high lights i say would be Jack fish, ocean trout, horse mackerel and their santa cruz uni. As fatty and fresh as any other fish you try in the top japanese restaurant. Four stars for the restaurant and the missing star for the service. One of the servers came over to brig us warm okuden saki while eating and chewing sth in his mouth, and our server came over to order for us with hands across chest. I think it is kind of important to not mind not to bring any manner to work and honestly any customer wouldn't appreciate this attitude.The food is worth 5 five stars and but the service, nah.
author: Mofy M.

description:
one of the over rated japanese restaurant.
for the price vs quality 
great service, but if you are looking for great sushi with less $ look other place.
author: Rudy W.

description: Okay first off two dollar signs?! I have never been to a sushi restaurant that one piece of sushi is 10$. I LOVE sushi and am always down to splurge but this pricing is just rediculous. The toro was good but I've had just as good in LA for half the price. It's so small inside you're basically sitting with the people next to you. If you want to spend 200$ to get full off overpriced sushi go here I guess...
author: Caitlin B.

description: Great sushi! So fresh that it melts in your mouth. The fried squid was delicious also and we loved the smoked baracuda and sashimi variety.
author: Judith M.

description:
3 months for one lunch reservation? What is this? The Japanese French Laundry?

The fish was decent, but at these upscale prices, it wasn't enough to wow me.

For the prices they charge, ALL the fish hold be flown from Japan, and have that fresh buttery taste, which it did not.

The waiter was slow with the tea and the dishes, and when I ordered the unagi roll, it wasn't even warm, or at room temperature, but tasted like it had been sitting at the sushi bar waiting to be served to the first sucker.

And that sucker would be me.

My co-worker had the chicken bento which was excellent, but once again, at double the price, that's the least of my expectations.

The toro roll had more rice than anything, which I'm never a fan of.

The uni was good, and the salmon and hamachi nigiri were okay.

And with lunch coming out to around $80, is it really worth it?

Honestly, with so many great Japanese restaurants out there, I don't see Akiko's as being in one of my top 10 restaurants.
author: Jack R.

description: We were walking through san fransisco today and we saw this place called the Irish bank and we were like that looks good and so we went into the door. The door was actually for akikos and so rather than going to the Irish bank, we just ate there. One of the reasons I rated this place so high was because they seated us even though we didn't have a reservation. This place has some of the best sushi I have ever tasted. We got 4 rolls from the menu and the yellow tail. I would highly recommend this dish. It's taste plain or with the lemon are both exceptional. It's boneless and cuts easily. Perfectly cooked.
author: Odin S.

description:
First time at akikos. It was hard to find because there is no sign, even using google maps, I wasn't sure if I was walking into the wrong place. Ambience is very romantic, though the restaurant is very small. Staff is very professional, attentive, and friendly. Staff introduced all the food that we ordered as it came and staff even reorganized setting and plating our table to be more ergonomically efficient. 

Food here was amazing! Scallops must have been the more fresh and tender piece of seafood I have ever eaten. Every sashimi piece was cut perfectly as they melted in my mouth. Rice on the rolls were so light. I felt like I barely had to chew for the entire meal. Everything we ordered was AMAZING! Hot sake was smooth and came in a hot pot to keep it warm. 

I loved the entire eating portion of this meal. 
The only negative is the pricing. Yelp has it listed as $$, however, the price range was definitely $$$, considering you would not get full off of  a few plates. We ordered 2 hot sakes and 4 plates and bill came out to be about $150 for 2 people. This was a snack and not dinner by the way. 

Food is definitely worth the experience though.
author: Kind 1.

description: Having tried omakase in other restaurants, the omakase here is very underwhelming. I had high expectations after reading all the good reviews. Alas, we left disappointed. Without the a5 wagyu, I would've given this place 1 star. The only other good thing is that they have fresh wasabi. Total for 2 omakase incl tax and tip is $292. Save your $ and try omakase elsewhere!
author: Prisilia P.

description: Awful service, awful sushi, way overpriced, snobby service for fake upscale food, disgusting and waste of a meal and money. Did I mention the sushi pieces were  itsy bitsy and tasted gross and chewy hard. You guys suck 100 percent yuck . Get air conditioning. Should be able to pay for it with the amount of money you are taking from people for such poor quality food. This experience ruined our night out and we felt ripped off and had to go get a second dinner to finally get full . It was gross sushi!!!
author: Gooz O.

description: A very small place. Wait time can be long,  but service is very fast. Very solid sushi, rolls were small but well made. Worth a visit. Very good, but not amazing.
author: Ali R.

description:
I've been dying to come here forever, but it's almost impossible to make a reservation. We walked in on a random weeknight and were told we could have a table around 8:15pm - perfect! 

Though we prefer to eat at the sushi bar for these types of sushi restaurants, the table side experience was still great. We tried a variety of sashimi and nigiri, plus a hamachi kama that was exceptional. The only reason why this is 4 stars instead of 5 is because it's very expensive, and though the quality is outstanding, i'm not convinced that it's worth the price point. Definitely try out this well known establishment if you appreciate quality sushi (not rainbow rolls and dragon rolls) and are willing to drop some coin on some delicious fresh fish.
author: Amy Y.

description:
I can't rate since I was unable to eat there.

I made a reservation for one for last Saturday. I requested a corner table due to my severe fragrance sensitivity. Friday they called me to confirm and reviewed notes. No indication any problem.

But when I arrived Saturday, the hostess and someone else got into a consultation while I stood there wondering what was going on. Other people got seated. Explained to me they only seat single diners at the bar. I know some people like sitting there so they can watch the prep but it looked uncomfortable & crowded. I could see they have small capacity, had they told me that Friday I would have just cancelled but they told me everything was OK. I said no, I had asked for a table and been told I would be seated at one. More consultations. They they showed me a table smack in the middle with others tightly crowded around it. I absolutely have to avoid tight crowds, one person wearing scent means I have to leave. Explained again, feeling very embarrassed and unwelcome. They had a corner table, just what I wanted, but a couple was seated there, already eating. They asked if I wanted to ask the couple to leave. No, I did not. I had no desire to drag in other customers. At that point I said I felt very unwelcome there and left. They gave perfunctory apology but looked relieved.

I walked to Bluestem Brasserie where, without reservation, they were able to seat me quite comfortably in lounge.
author: Carol S.

description:
We've been wanting to go to Akiko's for some time now, hearing about the quality sushi and food.  Finally made it the other evening, and it didn't disappoint.  In fact it was quite the experience and we were amazed and impressed with everything we ate.

The menu is extensive, definitely not a newbie sushi kind of place.  We thought we knew our sushi until we saw the daily special menu of fish from Japan, most of which we have never heard of.  So being our first time we leaned on our waiter to put together omokase selection for us based on a few preferences and some selection from the specials.  The 6 sashimi's and 4 nigiri sushi's were incredible, and afterwards said it will be hard to eat sushi anywhere else after this.  Everything was so fresh, clean tasting, we actually never ended up using the wasabi, ginger and soy sauce on the side, didn't need it.  Along with the sushi, we got cod and fried squid, both were amazing in themselves.  The squid (ika) was prepared so the hard portion of the shell is removed, but rest of the head, tentacles and legs were still intact and fried whole.  Crazy as it sounds, everything was edible, even the spiny legs.

Not cheap yet not over the top expensive either.  About $200 for omokase sushi, with 2 glasses of sake.  Make reservations far in advance to get in, definitely worth a visit if strolling around the Union Square areas.  I believe lunch offers more hot food in addition to the sushi.
author: Tom S.

description:
Came in on Monday for an omakase lunch and ended up staying for almost 2 hours. Be sure to reserve a spot beforehand because it does get full and you might not be able to get a spot at the bar. I believe our sushi chefs name is Alex. Alex was really good at explaining to us what each fish was and where it came from. One thing I really appreciated was that he noticed I was left handed and was placing the sushi in an angle that was easy for me to pick up. 

Me and my friends had about 18-20 pieces. Some stand outs were the golden eye fish, the uni, cooked black cod and the A5 wagyu. On this particular day, they had 5 different unis. For one of the dishes, we had an uni tasting platter and then Alex combined all 5 unis together into one thing and served it. That made all the difference because we were able to taste all the individual flavors while they were together cause we were able to recognize the flavor profiles of each. 

They import a lot of fish from Japan as well as from around the country. The service was really good, everything was extremely clean.
author: Colin F.

description: Some pretty impressive sushi. Definitely on the expensive side. You pay for 1 piece of nigiri what you would pay for 2 pieces elsewhere but worth it. Would go back for more.
author: Jc B.

description: The first time I went to Akiko's with a friend, it was great.  I got the omakase and it was high quality.  So impressed that I decided to take my wife.  They must have changed their menu because two times I asked what the omakase was for the day (once on the phone and again with the waitress) and both times they said "it's the chef's choice and you basically eat until you are full and want to stop".  Our omakase meal ended up being an endless array of nigiri that eventually cost $300 plus tip when we were full and also your waiters didn't know anything about the ingredients or why it was special.  Consider that omakase is a set menu to avoid confusion with your customers.
author: Marcus M.

description:
Just had lunch here and cannot wait to come back sometime for dinner. Amazing food, fresh fresh fish, and incredible service. 

My friend and I walked in around 1:30pm on a Friday figuring they wouldn't be so busy. Not so - there were several reservations all the way up until 2pm. We had to wait about 5 minutes for a table to clear. 

Our waiter was very helpful in helping us pick what to eat. We decided to share the sashimi tasting and the get a few pieces of nigiri. Before the food comes out, the waiter brought out a small dish of fresh grated wasabi and pours soy sauce into a small dish for each person. Each dish is placed precisely on the table in a prescribed pattern.

Sashimi - Good variety of fish. Every piece was fresh and melt in your mouth. Sashimi is presented with nasturtium in addition to the usual shiso and daikon. Our waiter recommended we dip the nasturtium in a bit of soy sauce as it's peppery and a bit like wasabi.

Uni Nigiri - fresh, sweet, airy, and creamy on just a small ball of perfectly done sushi rice.

Katsuo - lightly smoked, brushed with a bit of soy marinade, and topped with a bit of grated ginger. This fish just melted in our mouths with amazing flavor. Katsuo is one of those fish that can get that bad "fishy" taste, but there wasn't a hint of that here.

Umimasu (Ocean Trout) - my favorite. buttery with a small sakura leaf to add complexity. 

There was a smoked sashimi dish at a couple of the tables around us that I'd like to try next time.
author: Judy C.

description: The Omakase was pretty good but it's a bit pricey for me.  Also it's a first time I've had a Omakase, so it's hard to compare this to other ones.  My boyfriend felt bad about ordering small pieces of sushi since it's really pricey here.  The sushi here is good but I think I can get the same quality of sushi at places like Ginto for a cheaper price.  This is more of a traditional fancy sushi place, so that threw me off a bit coming here.
author: Rebecca V.

description: Absolutely amazing - my boyfriend and I sat at the sushi bar and Hiro was our sushi chef. Best sushi we've had in San Francisco (possibly better than some of what we had in Tokyo!). Highly recommend!
author: Haley M.

description:
I've been here twice now (though I didn't realize I was going to the same place the second time I went til I actually sat down). I'll make this short and sweet:

-Make reservations. The place is small, and the place is packed for lunch and dinner alike.
-Service is so-so. Other staff comes and checks on you more than the waiter, which is odd, but I guess it works.
-You can't have a group of more than 4, so if you have a big group, go somewhere else
-Get the sashimi or nigiri. The salmon and tuna were sublime. I wish I had tried more than just a few sashimi types, but that's life.
-The rolls SUCK. I'm aware 'true sushi' isn't rolls, but why bother having them on the menu if they're not good? 5 pieces per roll as well, so they're small.

All in all, come here for the sashimi/nigiri, but you pay for what you get.
author: Akshay A.

description: I've been fortunate that I have met people that enjoy food as much as I do. It's been a treat eating here too. To that person, thank you. We had the omakase. We had about 10 dishes that were nigiri with salmon, other fish, crab, and uni. We also had some small plates too. I loved it! I think the other person enjoyed it too! At least, that's what I thought! You would need to make a reservation and be on time! They are always full of people.
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
5 stars!

Delicious food.  Attractive plating.  Great service.  Reasonable prices for lunch.  Was able to get a seat without a reservation.

The lunch sets are great!  I got the salmon teriyaki.  Try it, you won't be let down.  It also came with a choice of sashimi or nigiri.  I got 4 pieces of nigiri all of them were excellent.  Salmon, Tuna, Sea Bass, and maybe another type of tuna, all were delicious.  The salmon entree was a very good portion and had fried leaves of some green leafy vegetable, I think there were also bits of fried salmon skin mixed in, the dish was very inventive and tasty, I've never had anything like it before.

The space is small and cozy and has interesting art work and exposed brick, it is romantic in its own way, but I was here for a work lunch, so there was no romance in the air.  :)

The service was excellent from beginning to end.  Everyone was polite and attentive.  Water was filled constantly as well as tea.  I left with a good taste in my mouth in more than one way.

I can't believe it took me so long to try this place.  It is only a block away from where I work.  I will return and I suggest that anyone reading this give it a try.
author: Ty C.

description:
OMG sushi heaven!!! Can I say Foodgasm?!?!

Came here on our first night in San Fran straight from the airport. We wouldn't have made our 9pm reservation if we checked into our hotel first so we called and asked if we can bring our suitcases into the restaurant and they accommodated on short notice. When we got there, even with the four of us lugging our suitcases inside, they were still very welcoming. It's not a big place at all, but they still made space for us. 

We all got the omakase, which we were very excited for. They have such a huge variety of fish. We wanted to try everything! And yes everything they served us was so fresh. Couldn't have asked for a better place for our first night. We were impressed by every piece. 

For starters we were served spinach. Whoever thought spinach could taste so good? The dashi (soup) in the spinach went very well with the spinach. The sashimi platter came with sea bass, sea trout, katsuo, chu toro, hamachi, and shima aji. We also ate Hokkaido sea urchin, Hokkaido scallops, zuwaigani, mirugai, Ayu, Kohada, Saba, kamasu, aji, akamutsu, Nagasaki black tuna with Santa Barbara uni, wagyu, butterfish with Jidori shaved egg, and unprocessed Hokkaido Uni. I'd have to say the UNPROCESSED Hokkaido Uni was my fave. It just melts in your mouth. 

By the time we were done eating, we wanted to eat it all over again. The service was excellent and by the end of the night we became friends with Allen, whom we assumed was the manager, so we asked if we can get a res for 3 nights later which was our last night in San Fran. And yes he came through! So again we ate there, on our last night, which made it an excellent way to end our vacay. 

We still got the omakase on our 2nd night, but asked to be served some different things from our first night. 

This time we were served octopus with cucumber to start, then for sashimi we had shima aji, black tuna, madai, scallops, and mirugai. And for the nigiri's: ankimo, Ayu, Arctic char, kamasu, unprocessed Hokkaido Uni, ebodai, New Zealand king salmon, akamutsu, black tuna, red snapper, golden eye snapper, Kohada, tuna belly, zuke maguro, ootoro with Uni, unagi, yellow tail belly, ikura, and wagyu.
