We did ask for couple of the same things from our first night that we thought were really good, but as you can see they have a huge variety. 

I will definitely be back without a doubt on my next trip to San Fran!
author: Ann S.

description: O.M.G. Wow! My husband and I came here for our honeymoon and his 29th birthday.  If he could eat sushi every day he would. It is by far the best sushi restaurant we have ever been to.  My husband did the Omekase and I ordered the Gyu (beef teriyaki).  There are honestly too ma y good things to say about this place, from their service to the food. Just do yourself a favor and come eat here. You won't regret it!
author: Melissa W.

description:
Really enjoyed our experience here. Definitely make a reservation. They are not large and we once made the mistake of trying to walk-in on a weeknight and they didn't have anything until late in the evening.

The waiter was really friendly and willing to explain their menu and items. Given that their fish is rare and unique, we were not familiar with many of them. We took his advice to let the chef choose our options, letting him know any that we knew for sure we wanted to avoid. He recommended 7 pieces each of either sashimi or nigiri (depending on what the chef felt was best) at $5-10 a piece. We really loved the options we received:

-Black tuna: soooo good. This was our favorite
-Kanpachi
-Rock fish
-Trout: really buttery; looked like salmon
-Halibut: this one was plainer than the others. Good texture but not our fave
-Baby barracuda: the fishiest of them all
-28 day aged blue fin tuna shoulder: so tender

After that though, we were definitely still hungry, so the waiter recommended the Ikiko (sp?) roll that is not on the menu. It had pretty standard ingredients: shrimp tempura, avo, seaweed wrap, rice, salmon, lemon. Even so, it was delicious!
author: Susan G.

description: Delicious. No sauce and soy sauce needed. Special house vinegar sauce is mixed with the rice - it's good! Chef are not Japanese from Japan but they are good, passionate and knowledgable about sushi.
author: Gloria T.

description:
If you like sushi then you will love this place. Literally every thing they serve is as high-quality as I've seen anywhere in my life.   Their uni is to die for. 

Make a reservation or you're unlikely to get seated. Trust me, it's worth it.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Swung by Akiko's with my mentee for lunch today and wow, I was absolutely swept off my feet with the quality of fish here. Everything was extremely succulent and slightly sweet. 

We ordered 3 nigiri (uni, scallop, toro) & 2 rolls (spider, teka), which came out to ~$27 per person. Not bad! 

Probably the highlight of the meal was the uni. Despite being a huge sushi and seafood fan, it was actually my very first time eating uni and I was completely blown away! It was slightly sweet and tasted almost like...  Ocean? Definitely something I recommend to any seafood lover, particularly if you enjoy clams or mussels. 

The scallop was quite nice and tender-- like someone mentioned in an earlier review, I wish it was just a tad sweeter. 

The toro was "okay". I feel like I've had better elsewhere. The flavor today wasn't quite as rich as other fatty tuna I've had, so that was a slight disappointment. 

I think the rolls were probably the most worthwhile, around $10-12 for 5 pieces. Not to mention that  2 rolls were the perfect accompaniment to help fill us up. 

Overall, quite a good experience! I don't know that I would ever order the omakase here, after hearing how pricey it was, but that uni? UGH definitely.
author: Lucy C.

description:
Great service!
We ate here at a party of 4.  Definitely call ahead and get a table.  This place is busy. 
The sushi is exceptionally fresh, as Sushi should be. 
I also ordered a soft-shell crab dish that was a nice compliment to my sashimi and nigiri orders. 
One of the sashimi pieces I enjoyed was their mackerel.  It was perfect!

I'll come back here and some again and again.
author: Travis C.

description: This was one of the best sushi experiences that I've had! The  sushi is unpretentious, bursting with flavor, and fresh! Can you say oishi? What made the lunch experience a 5 star is  the people who creates the sushi and welcomes you. The energy in the restaurant is comforting like you're going to a friend's restaurant. They are attentive but don't rush you. Ray, the owner, was there when I lunched and he was talking about "Saba skins." I asked him what it was and he asked if I wanted to try it. I said "sure." It was onolicious. The texture, flavors, and the presentations made my tongue dance. I was surprised when I saw the bill.. he didn't charge me for it. I didn't expect that and i am so thankful that he shared his creation with me. I definitely want to go back one more time this week! I'll be coming back for sure! It was fun chatting and making. New friends. Mahalo! Salamanca, Arigato  !
author: Tokidoki F.

description:
Good thing my plane got delayed massively. Or otherwise I wouldn't have tried this place.

The façade of the restaurant reminds me of an Irish pub rather than a Japanese restaurant. I had to do a double take making sure I was at the right place. 

Came in at 11:35, and the place was already busy. I was seated right away at the Sushi bar. Took a glance inside the menu but already knew I was gonna do Omakase. Omakase it was. "Oma" the sushi chefs shouted in succession. 

Series of Nigiri sushi came out in interval. With my omakase order I did not get any hot food, and I was fine with that. I don't remember even quarter of the name of the fish presented to me. These are some of the ones I remember: Hirame, Kinmedai, Kanpachi, Soy-sauce infused Tuna, Shima Aji, ... (blanking out right now). Anyway, nearly all of the Nigiri were seasoned with some kind of sauce or torched to perfection to bring out the Umami. 

Towards the end on the 16th Nigiri, the chef asked me if I wanted some more. I decided to wrap up the luxurious lunch with all 4 types of Unis that they had (really good decision).

The first Uni presented on a wooden spoon, was Uni which had been soaked in Salt water (or so I thought I heard). The second Uni was from California. The third from Hokkaido (smaller compared to California ones). The last, which I thought was the piece de la Resistance, was Russian Uni (I assume it's from Russia), presented in a nice wooden bowl. I found the progression was deliberate; first Uni to the last - start with milder, simpler tasting to more complex, more nutty and more explosive.

Enjoyed my Omakase experience here at Akiko's. There were not a single miss, all hits. I've already recommended this Sushi place to my Bay area friends.

It is easily one of the best Sushi place I've been to.

P.S: I was a tad skeptical that there wasn't any Japanese sushi chef behind the counter. Rest assured, I did not have to worry about that at all.
author: Arie R.

description: Sushi is not fresh, and the waitress is not nice, Waitress Teresa is not nice to us, and make our dinner unhappy:(. I'll not coming back to this place.
author: Sisiliu S.

description: Absolutely my favorite sushi place in the bay area so far. I would recommend sitting at the sushi bar to get the best experience. The staff here are so friendly and knowledgeable about sushi and crafting amazing sushi. You can truly taste the freshness and uniqueness of the sushi/nigiri here if you order the omakase. Every bite is happiness.
author: Jenny H.

description: I normally do not write reviews but this place makes me feel inclined to do so. Prior to the visit, I refused to eat raw fish and only went for the cooked stuff. Well, you don't really have an option here as 90% of the menu are raw delicacies. Now I'm officially a convert. My favorite part is when the waiter/waitress serves your order, they explain everything in details. Most dishes come pre-seasoned so don't be surprise when you don't see soy sauce on the table, lol. Overall, I was extremely satisfied with both the food and the service. I would highly recommend this place.
author: Richie K.

description: My bf and I snagged two seats at the sushi bar at the start of dinner time!!! A great time to slide through, when it is not super busy!  We ordered the omakase, chefs selection. We ate till we were full, trying the wide variety of Japanese imported fish. Everything was exceptional! Watching the sushi chefs create their art was an experience!
author: Liz D.

description: It is difficult to find the place because there is no signs. However, Google map exactly guided me to the place. About sushi,  hmm...it is dilicious, but not exact sushi. It's more like sushi-similar thing. Also, I don't want to recommend tamago.
author: Jung K.

description: As the suggestion of my BFF Peep, I ventured over to The City to try Akiko's. First off and losing a star is that there is no signage. Kinda a speakeasy sushi bar? However, once inside, you had better have a reservation, since it is packed! Started with Umni Masu, Scallop, Tako, and Shiro Maguro nigeri. Followed up at ta Tekka roll, Scallop Sunomono, and Deep Fried Softshell Crab. All were good and the service was attentive. Servings of the fish were on the smaller side, not what you get in Japan, however well prepared. With the abundance of sushi in San Francisco, Akiko's is a reliable stop.
author: David N.

description:
I will admit I just stopped in there because I had been on a long walk and needed some motivation!

It is a bit tricky to find with the Yelp map - which cant QUITE place it - but if you open your eyes and rejoin the actual world... there it is. 

Once you are inside you find relaxing oasis in the no-mans land between china town and the lonely financial zone by the sea... 

The fish was well portioned and very very smooth and flavorful. 

I drank some tea... ate some sashimi... and ventured on - I would stop by again if my wanders so permitted.

Still on the fence whether I would try omakase here...
author: Eric T.

description: You must make a reservation which can be annoying when you just want to do sushi last minute. Not because they won't accept walk ins but because they are that busy. That said, this place is amazing. A must try.
author: Dayris F.

description:
The best sushi cuts in the city.

Super solid date place where you can truly enjoy the best cuts of your favorite fish prepared in unique and incredibly delicious ways.

Walked in on a Friday night at 5:40pm and got reservations for 2 at 8:30pm. 

I WISH THEY USED YELP RESERVATIONS so we could make reservations online, otherwise you have to email them and pray for a response.

We sat at the sushi bar (DO THIS) because you're able to speak with the behind the sushi bar and ask for their recommendations. Everything they suggested (salmon belly flight, golden trout, some magic white fish) was outrageously good.

Dinner for 2 ended up being roughly $200 with tip.

Woot!
author: Cole S.

description: Get a reservation. This should be at the top of your list. This establishment is small and fills up quickly. There is no sign so if you see people standing around the location your map takes you. This is it. We were seated promptly and a server greeted us immediately. We opted for a beer and some tea. Our real server made his way to our table and we basically ate according to his recommendations. The Salmon was the star to me. It was the best Salmon I've had.Rich and delicate. In fact, everything was good and fresh. Spinach app was great as was the octopus and cucumber salad. The server was awesome and knowledgable. They have great offerings from around the globe. A must when in San Fran. Sorry, missing some pics here.
author: Vanessa A.

description:
Came here for yet again a business lunch. Easy to miss as it looks like an Irish pub or just a regular eatery, not like your typical Japanese restaurant, whatever that means to you. 

We got seated right away - I had a reservation - and ordered nigiri a la cart. The quality of the sushi is super high. I had the smoothest ankimo I've ever had since living in Japan 20 years ago. Unbelievable. Everything was top notch. 

Service was good, the waitstaff attentive and while he was making recommendations from off the list items, he let us know most of those orders ranged between $6 and $12 per order and recommended 7-9 pieces. 

Of course it's expensive! Top notch sushi in FiDi, duh! But. Worth it. I will be back.
author: Massimo M.

description: Staff was kind of snooty and appeared to be bothered we were there. Very expensive for what you got and yes - we walked away still hungry. Fish was very fresh but way too expensive. Won't go back.
author: Marcia L.

description:
YELP, HOW CAN YOU LEAD ME ASTRAY #DISAPPOINT

Since I am not a sashimi expert nor lover, this review is for all you regular sushi lovers! ~2.5 Stars but rounded down to 2 Stars because the heavy disappointment is still strongly lingering...
TL;DR?? If you enjoy fresh quality raw fish/sashimi, definitely stop by here. If you want big portioned rolls that are fulfilling, then skip this place because each specialty roll came in about 5 small pieces. Your wallet will hurt tenderly if you're hungry.

My friend and I came here for Weds dinner around 6PM and snagged a tiny table in the corner of the restaurant. I immediately noticed the minimalistic vibe of the restaurant. There were not many decorations and everything was made of light brown wood and had a nature color scheme. We ordered edamame and 3 specialty rolls, total bill was $32 (excluding tax and tip). I spent ~$20 for 6-7 pieces of sushi...Not. Worth. It. 

SPIDER $7...SOFT SHELL CRAB, AVOCADO, SCALLION, SOY PAPER
Grade C: There was simply not. enough. crab. This was actually one of the worst spider rolls I've ever had. The crab was in such small quantity that it got lost because the fresh avocado was so overwhelming. 

TEKKA $12...TUNA, SCALLION, AVOCADO, CRISPY SHISO, PICKLED CARROT, SESAME
Grade B: Definitely the busiest roll I ate. There were many components to this specialty roll and somehow the chefs still managed to downsize it to tiny itty bitty pieces. The tuna and veggies made this roll the crispiest one. Tasty but not worth $12.

SAKE $10...FRESH SALMON, AVOCADO, SCALLION, YUZU JALAPENO, TARE, TOASTED SESAME
Grade A: My favorite roll of the night! By far, the salmon had the FRESHEST taste to it! It was so exhilarating that I wish I had more to eat :) The Yuzu jalapeno definitely gives it a nice feisty kick in your mouth! Nothing too spicy so don't be alarmed. The pieces of avocado however were unusually large in this roll, although the salmon cuts were also proportionally large. Love love love!

[[PROS]]
++ FRESH fresh fresh Fish! The salmon and tuna were both excellent cuts and the texture was perfect enough to melt in your mouth. Hands down, quality freshness.

+ Fresh Avocado and Veggies. All their avo & vegs were crisp and had no signs of browning or mushy texture. Perfecto again.

+ Efficient Service for sure. Friendly? Sort of, depending on who you get. My water and teas were always refilled and our table was cleaned after every consumed roll, bravo.

+ Minimalistic Ambiance. I find beauty in simply things and the abstract yet quaint set-up of the restaurant was mesmerizing and much appreciated. The careful choosing and pairings of the candle, water glasses, tea cups, chopstick holder, etc. are a harmonious cohesion.

[[CONS]]
-- Not ENOUGH FOOD! Argh, my friend and I ordered an appetizer and 3 rolls (total= $32) and STILL left so hungry ugh. Each specialty roll we ordered consisted of 5-6 TINY pieces! How frustrating considering the prices...but their quality is spectacular though.

- Too Pricey for the Food portions. I do enjoy and appreciate good quality but not at the expense of quantity and leaving the restaurant hungry. How embarrassing.

- Crowded/Small Restaurant. I got lucky eating dinner at 6PM but I cannot tell you how many people waited or left during dinner time because there were simply not enough chairs or open spots at the bar.
author: Donna T.

description:
Good omakase, but puts a dent in your wallet. 

Akiko's is a small but nicely decorated sushi spot in Union Square. I highly recommend making a reservation. I noticed everyone who came as a walk in was told they're unable to take them and need to make a reservation for another day. I tried making a reservation online but there wasn't anything for the day I wanted. I emailed them and asked if I can get a reservation that day and they were able to squeeze me in. Send them an email if you want to eat on a particular day. Request a seat at the sushi bar so you can chat it up with the sushi chef.

The one thing I noticed about Akiko's omakase was the slice of each fish. It was extremely small compared to other omakase experiences. The omakase was delicious and I enjoyed what the chef selected for us. However, pretty sad that I spent twice as much considering the portion of each fish. I don't plan on coming here again because it's expensive. I think the price point should be updated on its Yelp page.
author: Gina H.

description:
Overall an ok experience. But for the price, only one time visit.

Although Yelp posts it as a two dollar sign restaurant, it's very pricey, more so than even many of the Michlin starred Japanese restaurants in SF. At least $$$ to $$$$. The sushi are ok, not mind blowing. Pretty much have nothing to write home about. The black cod, pretty good, but I had a similar quality dish at Mokutanya in Burlingame and at Hakkasan in SF at almost half the price. Squid is fresh but rice is not spectacular.

Service: seems to have only one server, or captain. The others are mainly bussers. Not quite friendly. Had better foods, service, and experience at Wako and at Kusakabe. Guest service quality is lacking. 

Atmosphere: small but cozy, simple and elegant. Bathroom could improve a little bit.
author: S N.

description:
Best thing was the shiro maguro in my $23 6pc nigiri.  Everything else was either chewy, rubbery and/or fishy.  

I understand the sushi chefs are making items for the tables also, but my nigiri set shouldn't have taken 15 minutes to complete.

That was AFTER I finished my wakame salad, which was your standard neon green stuff with some fancy micro greens placed delicately on top.  Enjoyed the yuzu.  Not impressed.  

Loved the hooks under the sushi bar!

Really obnoxious 'regulars' that are allowed to rant and rave, just topped off the experience.  

$40 for a truly forgettable lunch.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Great sushi spot for lunch, lots of wonderful sushi and other tasty options. The cuts of fish were perfectly fresh and well seasoned. Great service.
author: Tiama H.

description:
Sushi is so important to LIFE and great sushi means EVERYTHING!

Akiko's is definitely on top of my list as one of the best sushi restaurants in the bay area. You HAVE to make reservations in order to get seated but as long as you call a week in advance, you're guaranteed to get a table. 

I highly recommend getting chef choice - omakase to get the freshest and best quality sushi of the day. It's definitely not cheap, you are looking at around $180 per person with drinks and tax. 

I'll definitely be back!
author: Sandy L.

description: I was pretty disappointed eating here... I am not from San Fran and have enjoyed many different Japanese restaurants but this one was just average food wise. The number one reason I am giving this place two stars is the customer service was HORRIBLE. The woman that served us was rude from the minute we sat down and told my Chinese friend that he needed to mix the wasabi with the soy sauce... I made many attempts to try to be nice to this server and she was inattentive and had a bad attitude towards us. If you are in the mood for bad energy with a side of sushi this is the place for you.
author: Alyson S.

description: A very nice little Restaurant.  We walked over from the Nikko Hotel.  The Cucumber Salad and our sushi choices were delicious.  Their take on the Lion King roll is our favorite to date.
author: Maury C.

description:
Favorite sushi place in San Francisco.

I am not a big fan of the neighborhood when it comes to finding good food, but this is with no doubt the exception.

The place is small and full of charm, with walls of exposed brick and few tables, giving it an intimate and cozy atmosphere. It almost feels like you've teleported to Japan, specially because of their not typical sushi menu. 

You won't find american style sushi rolls, but you'll find the best rolls! The tuna melted in the mouth, all the sashimi we ordered was great, even the miso soup was perfect. At risk of being repetitive, the rolls were different and delicious.

A bit pricey, careful with ordering items not priced on the menu. 
But really looking forward to go back.
author: Marta V.

description: Fresh selection of fish choices for sushi, if you are tired of just tuna, salmon, shrimp, but instead want to try barracuda, golden eye snapper, Australian trout, then this might be a good fit.  Try the mameaji appetizer, nice and crispy.   But be prepped to spend some money, 2 adults and one drink each can end up 2-300$ depending on how you splurge.
author: shun p.

description:
Writing this review after my second visit to Akiko's. My first time I sat at a table in the back and had an assortment of nigiri and the second time I sat at the sushi bar in front of Chef Alex. These two experiences were very different, and my second time here doing omakase at the sushi bar is what drives this 5-star review.

The nigiri that Chef Alex prepared was absolutely delicious and included hotate, mirugai, madai, otoro, kani, hamachi, kanpachi, uni, ika, aji, and anago, to name a few. I think overall we had ~23 pieces of nigiri. The sushi I had here wasn't the very traditional kind you'll find in Japan, or at certain other restaurants here in the city (Maruya, for example, is more on the traditional side in my opinion). The chef used a variety of ingredients to mix things up and add his own interpretation of the nigiri, all of which were received very well. Some pieces were very flavorful and others simply melted in your mouth. The rice was also good too - not sticky, good texture on the individual grains.

Overall a great time at Akiko's and just the omakase itself that night was ~$165. They also have some great sake too, but of course that will easily bump you up into the $250+ per person range.
author: Gore S.

description:
One Yelper called Akiko's a "world-class" sushi joint.  I think that's a very exaggerated assessment of the sushi served here.

I spent 15 years in Japan, so I know my sushi, but that said, I'm def not a sushi snob.  

3 of us came, and one of us ordered OMAKASE.  The other two of us ordered assorted nigiri-style.  

No doubt, the sushi quality was good, but the cuts of the fish were undersized.  The waitress said a lot of their fish is flown in from Japan. We had hamachi, tuna, kanpachi and a bunch of the other usual suspects.

The problem is, if you're going to pay this much, the quality and experience for me needs to be off-the-chart.  And it wasn't.  It was just good, maybe *very good*, but then you look at the bill and then shake your head.  The value wasn't there.

I've been to the other $$$$ places, Morimoto, Nobu and the rest.  And when I leave there, it's a different feeling.  I don't feel ripped off because my enjoyment level was such that I don't care about the money.  At Akiko's, I resented the amount of the bill because the experience wasn't worth it.

We also had some pretty mediocre agedashi-dofu.  And the miso soup was WAY under par, watered down and lacking flavor.

Bottom line, I would rather take the money I spent on this meal, put it toward a plane ticket to go to eat at Sugarfish in LA.  You'll pay a total of $100 for 3 people at Sugarfish and you will leave completely and utterly satisfied.  

Sugarfish in LA.  If nothing else, you got an awesome tip from reading this review!
author: Darien R.

description: Pretty good but a little overrated. They ran out of multiple things on their menu. Cool spot but a little over hyped
author: Dan A.

description:
Yay! Awesome sushi! This place is full every time I walk past so I was super happy that I managed to make a reservation on Open Table for lunch just 20 min in advance. 

I had the 4 piece nigiri sushi sampler with saba shio-yaki. The sushi was amazing and the fish extremely fresh. Definitely wish I had more!

The saba shio-yaki took forever to be served after we were done with the sushi. My friend had already finished with her 6pcs nigiri tasting selection AND 2 cups of miso soup before my fish was served. 

The fish itself was seasoned perfectly, though I found it to be just slightly overcooked so the fish dried out. Definitely coming back again another time for the omakase!
author: Christina N.

description: Excellent sushi, very expensive for what you get. We had the omikase & it left me hungry. It was not 13 courses but 13 small, albeit delicious pieces of fish. No desert was ever offered. Service was good, nice sake selection.
author: Robin G.

description:
Being big fan of authentic Japanese food, we had high expectations for this restaurant given its Yelp reviews and reading from other news sources. However, I think it's a rip off.

I found them sneaky with their pricing.

First off, right after we sat down, the server came and asked "Would you like some edamame and miso? Would you like me to bring you one of each?" Usually, when someone offers you "would you like XXX" like "would you like some bread?", it is assumed to be complementary service. And often times, edamame is complementary at Japanese restaurants. So that's what we assumed. However, we later found out this was not the case here, in fact they charged ~$15 for a bowl of edamame and "miso". This is the first time I've ever paid for edamame at a restaurant. The way the server posed the question was extremely misleading and never made us aware of the fact it was not complementary.

We were also confused what exactly he meant by "miso." That's the first time we heard someone offering "miso" as is. Turns out, the server meant miso SOUP. Here's a tip - "miso" means fermented bean paste. So I assumed you meant your edamame comes with some innovative miso paste for dipping. Miso SOUP is what you offered me - a diluted bow of water with barely any scallions. Don't try to be too hipster when it actually makes no sense. Please study up on your menu and language. Do you say "Would you like some soy?" 

Then the omakase - nothing spectacular and some of the fish was so cold and a bit hard. I knew right away it was frozen then defrosted. Apparently our reservation was too early (5:45) that they haven't fully finished defrosting?

Finally the bill... Turns out their "omakase" isn't a real omakase but a "Let the chief just pick some items from our existing menu and give to you suckers who can't order yourselves". Usually, the omakase menu comes at a particular fixed price and offer items not on the regular menu (that's the whole point of Omakase - to enjoy something off the menu). However, here every item on the omakase was charged SEPARATELY and it turns out, they just cherry picked a bunch of random items off their regular menu. Then what's the point of ordering omakase? We could've just ordered off your menu and actually picked items we liked. That's NOT the purpose of omakase/chief's special!
author: Sam C.

description:
I'm a planner.  I've been wanting to check out Akiko's for ages and so when our company decided to send me to Box Works for their annual conference, I jumped at making reservations.  Score!  

So when on the Sunday prior the event, my boss texted me to add her husband to the reservation, it physically pained me .  I tried calling the restaurant and Open Tabling Akiko's for the next two days with no success of connecting to them.  This is not good news to a planner.  Eeks!

We arrived to Akiko's 27 minutes early and with an extra person in our party.  After speaking with the hostess, it was not looking good for me.  I completely get it, but I couldn't help but want to try.  Luckily, after some pleading with some of the kind Akiko folks, they made some magic happen to accommodate us at the scheduled time.  We gladly grabbed a drink around the corner and came back for dinner.  

And what a dinner it was!  Our server, Jack (along with the rest of the wait staff) and the chefs were on perfect point.  The food was AMAZING!  The quality and flavors were impeccable.  The conference made for a loooong day and this was a great reward.  My boss said it was the best black cod she's had in her life!  There were many closing of the eyes as we enjoyed the different selections presented to us.  We all agreed this is the best sushi we've all had in a long time, if not ever.

Thanks Akiko's for making me look good and my belly feel great.  Highly recommended!
author: Miss Bonnie B.

description:
I'm just going to say it...100% the best sushi I have ever had in the city. EVER.
Let's get it straight here, you are not coming to Akiko's to order rolls and chicken udon (oops, sorry...my inner snootiness is showing). I'm sure they keep these things on the menu to appease the general public but if you're going to shell out $$$$ prices you at least should know why you're paying the big bucks. You are paying for amazing quality fish and unforgettable nigiri. Yes, it's only one bite, but it's one bite you'll be thinking about for days to come.

Our group of 4 was initially not planning on getting the omakase but the menu was a little difficult to navigate so we ended up opting for the omakase due to our insufficient sushi IQ. It was nice to just let the sushi chef do the thinking for us and sit back, relax and let the food magically appear on the table. BUT, lucky for you, I took diligent notes throughout the meal and now you can get the highlight of the omakase for 70% of the cost (yes, I did the math). Our omakase cost $120 (it depends on what/how many dishes they bring out) and you can have the greatest hits for roughly $80! Yes, you are very welcome!

I've thought this out a lot...here are the must haves in ranking order:
1. Ji-kinmedai (cold smoked golden eye snapper): I have never had or heard of this before but the cold smoke mild flavor paired with the mild fattiness of the fish...ridiculous. 
2. Otoro (fatty tuna): This one I did not see on the menu but it was heavenly...texture and flavor spot on
3. Giant clam: Another one that was not on the menu but the texture had some bite on it and it had a mild sweet flavor
4. Nama hotate (over-nighted fresh scallop): Crisp, fresh scallop at it's best
5. Ensui uni (sea urchin): This was not your usual sea urchin, it was unprocessed and served on a spoon with rice. Sweeter flavor and less fishiness than your usual sea urchin.
5. Sanma (pike mackeral): A little more of that fishy flavor but still smooth and not off-putting
6. Managatsuo (silver pomfet butterfish): It has a light sear on it but even the raw parts have that smooth buttery flavor
7. Salt water eel: Another one off menu, didn't have as much of that cloyingly sweet sauce so you could actually taste the subtle flavor of the eel. Different texture from fresh water eel.
8. Kuro Maguro (black tuna): Really nice texture as far as tunas go. I'm less of a fan of tuna but this is definitely one of the best ones I've had.
9. Kanpachi (amberjack): Good but less unique than everything else, it's all relative.

Extra not nigiri orders:
1. Hamachi kama was good and at only $15 it's a good way to fill up the belly a bit
2. A5 Wagyu with truffle: This was a nice way to close out the meal but it has really strong flavors and textures. For the omakase it was $50 for 4, I would get it once for the experience but probably not again.

Other throwaways on the omakase was an agedashi tofu and a salad with octopus on it that are not really worth having.

Well, there you go! Consider yourself a professional nigiri orderer now although, I'll be honest, I mainly wrote this review for my own use so when I go again I can easy navigate the menu. Have fun!
author: Christina L.

description:
Came here for my boyfriends bday a few weeks ago. It definitely lived up to all the good reviews. Do make reservations and try omakase, it's worth it.


My boyfriend and I love getting omakase at different sushi places, we always like trying new and exotic fishes. We had a 15 different items and the nigiri was so fresh and good. The best ones were the Chu toro, Russian uni, scallop, local king salmon and kinmedai.  The uni was the best I have ever had, it was creamy and had no taste of the ocean. The Chu toro was so buttery and rich, it was perfect. Akikos ranks in one of my top 5 omakase  places. If you love fresh nigiri and sashimi this place is worth a try! 

Total for 2 with tax and tip: $249
author: Stella J.

description:
Akiko's is a whole other level of sushi. In the past I've been to places which I felt were good, but they're in a different category. I always thought it people were exaggerating when they would talk about melt in your mouth, tender sushi. Now I know they are not. I got the nigiri sampler plus a couple of other items and everything was so fresh and full of flavor.

I will definitely visit again.
author: Gerry M.

description:
My inner paranoia came out when we initially entered Akiko's because I was convinced they were having a good laugh at me. I must have walked past the windows of the restaurant at least half a dozen times trying to find it since they have no exterior sign. If you're having any trouble searching it out - just keep an eye out on the street numbers and look for The Irish Bank sign!

When we finally did find it, they asked if we had a reservation. It was a Thursday night... and they were very, very busy. My advice to you? Regardless of what day of the week it is: MAKE A RESO. Fortunately for us, they were able to squeeze us in (albeit next to the bathroom). The interior decor was very clean and simple (the art on the wall was gorgeous, though and really stood out against that exposed brick). Seems pretty trendy and hip here, too.

Drinks:
- Iced Tea: They ran out. What the... HOW DO YOU RUN OUT OF ICED TEA?! Tsk. Tsk. I've read through other reviews and it seems this is a common problem. 

Eats:
+ Edamame ($4): Pretty delicious, standard edamame. Can't go wrong with this! Just make sure you're putting the sucked on pod in the discard bowl if you're sharing with a friend (sorry, Emily C!).
+ Tamago ($5): Egg omelette. My first time trying this anywhere and it was surprisingly dense and delicious. Definitely excited to try this elsewhere now that I know it's veg-safe.
+ Kappa roll ($4): English cucumber with sesame. So refreshing!
+ Avocado roll ($4): Avocado with sesame. Can't go wrong with avocado!
+ Futo roll ($6): Egg omelette, avocado, cucumber, spinach, with sesame. It was like taking the aforementioned three things and putting them in one roll. Again - so flavorful and hearty.

Usually I'm still hungry after what seems like a bounty of sushi, but not here. This was plenty of food for this little pig. Oh, and on a side note,  I think the prices here are awesome. I'm used to MUCH more expensive, less delicious sushi on the East Coast. So - right on!

+/- Service:
A little spotty; they got our food out insanely fast but seemed a little disinterested in us as customers. Took some serious work to get their attention for water refills and our check.
author: Steff D.

description: The sushi and rolls were just ok. The man who took my order who made sushi was almost rude; what a disappointment. The person who refilled my water and dishes was engaging and pleasant.  Food wasn't anything exciting but the eel was delicious. I've definitely had better sushi in a better environment.
author: Sue P.

description: Such wild, diverse types of fish and unique takes on traditional sushi. The most amazing bites of fish you'll ever take, so fresh and clean tasting, the garnishes also completely make the taste.
author: Aryan R.

description:
We have been here a few times now. Experience has been mixed. If you sit in the back dining room, the service can be a bit slow. Also, the nigri portions can vary..but for the most part, the food is always fresh and delicious.

They are on list of top 5 sushi places in in SF.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Attempted to make reservations online but found it was booked up until the end of the week, we show up right when it opens at 5:30 on a Monday night and was told we could only sit at the sushi bar and cannot order the sushi/dinner sets. You can show up and wait for no-shows and obtain a seat that way too.

We ordered:
Fried Ika ($8)
Saba Shio Yaki ($11)
12 pcs sashimi ($34)
Kanpachi sashimi ($23)
Kuro maguro Akami ($15)
Kuro Maguro- Otoro ($25)
Negi Toro sushi roll ($20)
Uni ($9)

The slices of fish are very generously thick. The only thing I have to complain about besides the rice being a little too hard/distracting with it's brownish color is the uni we got. This was my first time trying uni and we watched the sushi chef take the last piece from the box that was very slimey and put it on the rice and for the other he grabbed a brand new uni piece from a different box that looked more fresh. I didn't want to complain or ask about it because sushi chef knows best... (see pic) 

Make sure you get the Nama Selection menu (that's where the premium stuff is). We didn't know about it until the sushi chef told us. They serve you the sushi roll last so you have room in your stomach to order more nigiri/sashimi or to prevent you from being too full to enjoy the good stuff.

Service was good even coming from the sushi bar. I think we had more fun sitting there than a regular table because we got to order whenever we felt like it and watched the chef meticulously slice the fish and prep the other orders.

This place isn't authentically Japanese but they do get all their fish from Japan so it's very fresh.
author: Lauren K.

description: Yummy!  Thanks Yelp for sending use to a great little spot.  Server was nice and support staff never let me need anything. I recommend this place if you can get in.
author: Dale D.

description:
I'm dreaming of when I can return to Akiko's, the unlabeled, unassuming dark wood restaurant on the edge of Union Square.  It's been a couple weeks since my phenomenal birthday dinner...and I'm still dreaming of sushi, Jiro style.  Okay maybe not as masterfully and eloquently as Jiro, but I do still dream longingly for the sashimi I savored at Akiko's. According to my boyfriend, Akiko's is notoriously known for their practice of turning away folks without reservations.  Fortunately, he remembered to make birthday reservations for us (that's a big deal for him!), and we were seated at what we consider the best table in the entire restaurant.

We sat in a semi-private alcove at the front of the restaurant, near large window panes with natural, filtered light pouring in.  The hostess gave us a choice of sitting at the bar so we could talk to the chef during our meal, or a private table for quieter conversation.  This choice was most likely offered because we requested the omakase menu on our online reservation.  Service was top notch throughout the meal, and I appreciated how informative our server was when presenting each plate of nigiri.  It has been said many times before, but the fish at Akiko's is a step or two above the rest.  The fish is extraordinarily fresh, tasty, and served at the appropriate sea level temperature (this is not true for most other sushi restaurants).  Their attention to detail and commitment to simple elegance in plating and decor is so refreshing.  

From the light jasmine tea we drank, which complemented the sushi so well without overpowering the flavor of the fish, to the carefully selected pre-seasoned plates of sushi with wasabi and different varieties of soy sauce layered into the rice, I could tell that Akiko's understands authentic Japanese sushi.

Our omakase menu - stars denote my favorites of the night :)

-Green salad
-Agedashi tofu
-Kani-age (fried soft shell crab)
-Copper river salmon*
-Shima-aji (mackerel)
-Maguro (tuna)
-Umimasu (trout)*
-Uni
-Hotate (scallop)*
-Amaebi
-Suzuki (sea bass)
-Ume-madai (snapper)
-Kamasu (barracuda)
-A5 Wagyu with truffle garnish*
-Red bean mochi

Our bill was hefty ($210 pre-tip), but the experience was memorable in all the right ways.  Akiko's simply serves up the best sashimi I've ever had.  We will be back again!
author: Brittany N.

description: The quality of the fish is definitely the star here, which should be the case for sushi right?  My husband and I shared the sashimi sampler, which was simple, clean and varied, as well as some nigiri specials and a roll.  All were prepared well, including their house sauces.  I also liked that it wasn't very formal, where you wouldn't necessarily have to come for a special occasion and maybe even just after a day of shopping would suffice.  The place is small, holding about 20 ppl, so not great for large parties but maybe even appropriate for a double date.  The only issue I had was the service with the waitress(es).  I always like to hold onto my menu during sushi, so I could order as I eat, but seriously, every 10 minutes, a waitress would come by asking to take the menu.  I know I'm being picky but it did disrupt our meal.
author: Sheri H.

description:
My Personal Sushi Constitution:

Get there early
Wait for the bar
Omakase only - don't bother with anything else if you want the best fish
Leave the restrictions at home, you'll miss out if you don't
Have a conversation with the chef, I've learned something new every time
Do not waste my time or calories on salmon
Chopsticks are not made for picking up sushi, your fingers are
Everything in one bite only
It doesn't need soy sauce
If you still think the fish needs soy sauce, fine, but the rice doesn't
Ginger is your friend and makes the next bite tastier
East the Shiso
Your eyes are bigger than your stomach - that rice expands
Make space for uni and tomago - these are the real tests

These rules only apply if I'm in a rock solid legit sushi bar that knows what they're doing like Akiko's. The bar is cozy and the service is solid. A very respectable omakase that will run you ~ $100-125 pp if you are an oinker like me.
author: Snuffles B.

description: I went here with my husband for dinner. We had reservation and was seated right away. The service and atmosphere were good. They had a very limited menu for maki rolls, but the food tasted really good and we liked what we got. I think more adventurous sushi lovers will appreciate the menu better.
author: Pegah S.

description:
The food and service were absolutely exceptional, there's no doubt about that. We had the omakase and each dish was basically perfect. 

The only reason for a reduced star is the cost. I know I'm fighting a losing battle here, but my objection to the spiraling cost of restaurants in SF continues. Two pieces of wagyu beef nigiri from the a la carte menu cost $25. That's $12.50 per piece. 

Don't get me wrong, it was perfect. If was amazing. But it feels almost immoral to pay that much money for what couldn't have been much more than 4 ounces of food (including the rice, which was also perfect).
author: Jack K.

description: Small but awesome. The selection and perfection of fish is perfect for a restaurant this size. Service and knowledge of the staff is perfect. I recommend this spot for sushi lovers.
author: John P.

description: Very fresh and unique sushi options. Limited menu for lunch and pricey.  Service was okay. Can't say I would break my neck to return when San Francisco has so many great sushi choices
author: Sidney H.

description: Oh the fish here is so fresh. The place is very cute too, but small, so make sure you make reservation ahead if you are coming at dining hours. It is on the pricer side, so prepare to spend some bucks here.
author: Julia Z.

description:
This place is great, sushi is fresh and a good selection of sushi. The hamachi Kama was a bit salty but other that everything is pretty good. 

I am in sf for 3 nights and spent 2 nights going to Akiko for dinner. Last night the food was great, a four star but the sushi chef is terrible. I did Omakase and He didn't even tell me what I am eating and didn't even want to ask me anything. I have over 20 pieces and it was around $140. I ate so many pieces but didn't know what kind of fish to reorder. Next time I will look another place. 4 star for sushi but 1 star for service.
author: Min X.

description: Busy busy place on a Monday night at 9 pm! Authentic menu with attention to detail. Tasty rolls including a breakfast roll which I haven't seen before. Octopus with a nice flavor. Attentive staff!
author: Sarah S.

description: Great food, great service.  Very impressed by the level of skill and knowledge displayed.  Will have to return for more.
author: Ryan F.

description:
3.5 STARS

For the longest time I though the unlabeled Akiko's Restaurant was an Irish Bar (in fact, there is one around the corner). I've heard such great things about Akiko's for years, I had let myself imagine so many incorrect details. There was no old man sushi chef, and no little old lady wife serving a few small tables - there were hipster white people cutting sashimi and searing fish. The place was not especially Japanese or traditional, but rather modern and new. 

All the dishes were ordered were pretty good, the fish was really fresh and didn't leave me extremely hangry... just a little hangry. I enjoyed the food here, but it doesn't meet the hype. 

* SHRIMP TEMPURA ($8) - 3.5 STARS:
Lightly battered and flash fried, 4 piece tiger prawns with ginger broth. 
I typically don't like tempura but this was nice because it tasted like it was freshly battered and fried. The tiger prawns were on the small side, which ultimately was a good thing because it was delicate in texture. The overall taste was good but it wasn't mind blowing.

* DEEP FRIED SOFT SHELL CRAB ($??) - 3.5 STARS:
Lightly battered and flash fried. This was delicious, fresh and tasty just like the tempura shrimp. 

* TUNA SHOULDER NIGIRI ($12) - 3.5 STARS:
This sashimi special was nice and marbled, it reminded me of Saru and Ichi because it was so overpriced, but comparatively the flavor and quantity was miles ahead. It was good, but I've still had better.

* SASHIMI SAMPLER 12 PC ($35) - 3 STARS:
There were definitely highlights (trout wow), average pieces (salmon, yellow tail), and passable pieces (octopus so chewy). This chef's special is fixed, too bad....

* RAINBOW ROLL ($??) - 4 STARS:
The rainbow roll was good, better than your standard rainbow roll (ahem We Be Sushi). It comes with 8 pieces and is decently portioned compared to most other Japanese restaurants in the city (ahem Saru, Ichi....). But again, it wasn't particularly mindblowing. To me a good rainbow roll is large, has fresh fish, and delicious sauces on top. It was good but nothing to return for.

* SAKE FLUKE ($??) - 5 STARS:
This was a 5-piece roll, a concoction of radish, avocado, salmon sashimi and several items I can't remember, topped with unagi sauce. One of the favorites of the night. 

Overall Akiko's was good, an upscale sushi restaurant with fresh fish and tops other famous Japanese sushi spots in the city. Perhaps the thing to get is the Omakase (ranges $99-110). While I enjoyed my experience here, I don't think the value was there. I still prefer Wayo for something more traditional.
author: Jess C.

description: Reservations are a must - and weeks in advance. We did the OMAKASE (chef's selection/tasting menu). The freshest, best tasting,simple but beautifully presented sushi I have had. The staff were friendly, but the hostess (Arian???) was, sweet, knowledgeable and attentive. And went above and beyond our expectations. She also gave us some great ideas of less touristy sites to visit around SF.
author: Todd R.

description:
Akiko's offers simple, high quality Japanese food. And don't be fooled...while the prices don't look bad on the menu, the portions are very petite! If you're an AYCE sushi type of person this ain't the place for you.

My 4 stars all go to the quality of the food, everything else was pretty average.

Tip: the restaurant is a little hard to find because it's tiny and there is no sign outside! Once you see The Irish Bank, the door to the left will be the magical gateway to Akiko's.
author: Vivian W.

description:
hard to find as there is no signage outside with the restaurant's name.I passed by it thinking that it was an Irish pub(behind it around the corner).Food was good.Sashimi fresh. Omakase cost $100 though!
Reservation can be made very easily on your smartphone.
author: Tom T.

description:
We had the king salmon, salmon belly, white tuna and ocean trout nigiri, along with cucumber octopus salad and the salmon roll. Every bite melts in your mouth. Service was excellent. I cannot say enough!

Great hidden gem in Fidi and definitely top 3 favorite sushi spot in SF. Mmmm!
author: Erin S.

description: First time her was great . Small place call for sure. Food is good . Fresh but for the price it was a small portion.
author: Erik H.

description:
This place was totally unexpected!  

Came here on a Thursday night after a Fred Lyon show at the Leica store.  Opened up my trusty Yelp to see what restaurants were near by.  Akiko was close and the pictures of the food looked amazing!

We had no reservations.  Checked in with the hostess and we were in luck!  There was a table available, only if we promised to be out by 745 PM.  

{ STAFF :: 5 stars }
* waiter was extremely knowledgeable and provided great suggestions based on what we expressed for preferences
* hostess was so friendly and she's cute too
* everyone else, so attentive.  We never had to ask for water and plates were removed as we devoured them 

{ FOOD :: 5 stars}
* we ordered soooo many items and everything was so fresh and had flavorful w/o being overpowering
* some favorites were the black tuna, unprocessed uni, saba shio (they de-bone it for you)

{ THINGS TO KNOW }
* place is small so make reservations
* although the prices were extremely reasonable, I wouldn't necessarily categorize it as $$, at least not the way we order

I think this is my new favorite sushi place! can't wait to come back.

happy eating!
author: Tina F.

description:
I'm going to chalk this up as, I didn't come here for dinner, I didn't come with the right people, I didn't sit at the bar, and I didn't have as good of a time.

I actually know plenty of people who love this place, everyone on the side bar of my review as I am looking have given it between 4 - 5 stars ... yet I was a little disappointed. I came here last year for lunch after a whirlwind week at I/O. It wasn't too hard to get into, and the restaurant was nice, ambiance was good, and the service was friendly.

I got some nigiri dishes because I wanted to try their nigiri, but in the end it was adequate at best. Nothing was super fresh, very tasty or even memorable. I do want to come back especially since the chef posts up so many awesome things on IG and I literally drool when I see their fresh fish deliveries, but for now this place is a 3-star for me.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Went there with my aunt and uncle they both came here for vacation from Hong Kong. Both of them love Japanese food and travel there ever year. I wanted to take them to some place for some good sushi. And I travel here from Baltimore for vacation. Got there 5:15 waited for them to open. We were the 4th group waiting in line. The third couple told us they don't have reservation, and so did us. I thought we were there so early, maybe we could get a table. And no no no luck for us. Hostess told us everyone had reservations! I guessed those couple lie to us then...? 
She told us they are fully booked till next month. So I went online. Guess what I found! Openings! Openings!!! Openings?!?! What next month?! So the hostess was lying to us!!! Booked one for myself, since my uncle and aunt were can't go.
Now I really want to see what they offer. 
Got there just on time. I got a bar seat since I'm by myself. They said u have to request it ahead of time if u want bar seat. 

Service - 2 stars:
I only saw a server once for water from start to finish. I guess no need to serve someone who doesn't order drink, right? Then come the awkward caucasian chef kept staring at me then kept looking away... Finally he asked do u have any question. I looked at him back asked should I order from him or just wait more. He said order from him is fine too. Two stars included the dishonest hostess...

Food - 5 stars:
I tried their Agedashi "fried tofu with roe on top" $9 (nicely done love it) and Sashimi tasting- 12 pc $34 (very fresh fishes)
Wanted to order more, but with 88 + degrees outside. I better not over eat for my own good. 

Overall food is good but overpriced. I can get the same food at my local sushi place for much more reasonable price. Horrible service, which I can also get at my local place! Lol! No need to travel here to get that;)
author: Peggy W.

description:
I rarely give 5 stars but this place commands 5 big ones.

Dining here was hands down the best sushi experience I've ever had in my life. The omokase price is $80-100 depending on what you're served (it will be itemized on your receipt). They say you'll need at least 2 hours there for the omokase experience but that's only when it's really busy like 5+ people ordering at the same time. From the time we arrived at 6PM, we finished everything by 7:30PM.

Anyway, back to the important issue, is this price worth it? Absolutely. If you're going to throw down $100 on dinner for one person, this is well worth it, especially if you're a sushi lover and you want to experience one of the best sushi meals. I haven't been to Jiro Ono's restaurant in Japan, but I bet this place will make you want to go just to know in your heart you've tried some of the best sushi ever.

The omokase consists of an appetizer, 6 pieces sashimi and 10 pieces nigiri. I don't know the exact naming of everything I ate, but here is the list from my receipt and I also posted the pictures of my meal on Yelp. 

1) Ohitashi
2) Sunomono Octopus
3) Umimasu
4) Hamachi
5) Shiromaguro
6) Shiroebi
7) Uni
8) Kanpachi
9) Tai
10) Katsuo
11) Kamasu
12) Kinmedai
13) Aka Mutsu
14) Hara Sake
15) Kuro Maguro

Make sure you make a reservation because I don't even think they take walk-ins. Also, parking is almost impossible in this downtown area so take public transportation and plan accordingly. Service was excellent, the servers were knowledgable and my water glass was never empty. You will be 100% satisfied with your meal here if you are one to appreciate delicious/fresh fish.
author: Marlon T.

description: This was my first sushi restaurant experience for my first time in SF. I had a reservation for 1 that I got only 2 hours before through OpenTable. I ordered the Nigiri Moriawase to start which was super tasty. Then I asked the sushi chef (because I sat at the bar) for 10 more nigiri pieces of his choosing. He chose a really nice and fresh variety that included scallop, uni, mackerel, crab and toro. This was seriously great sushi! Afterwards I ended with one piece of the wagyu which was incredibly rich and flavorful. It was pricey as I think my bill totaled $170. I also realize I probably could have ordered Omakase which would have been a little cheaper, but I'm rarely in SF and this was more of an experience. I would definitely return as this experience was pretty close to perfect.
author: Rajeev B.

description: While traveling for work, I found myself with an uncontrollable craving for sushi after a long cross-country flight. But not the kind of sushi that has ridiculously-named rolls like "Fiery Fury Balls" or "Spiked Eel Dream". Akiko's offers authentic and quality dishes, with flavors that aim to complement the fish (versus layers of hot sauce, cream cheese and mayonnaise that are then fried beyond recognition). And that's just the rolls, of which there were only six (perfectly crafted) on the menu. The nigiri was extremely fresh and elegantly presented, again with just a hint of a complementary flavor or subtle accompaniment. (I'm not sure how they prepared the octopus, but I wish they would explain it to every other establishment attempting to serve octopus because it is absolutely how it should be served.) The staff obviously knows what they're doing and are as accommodating as they can be when you don't have a reservation (you should definitely get one, by the way). While the neighborhood isn't the most charming, it was close to my office and hotel, which made it easy to enjoy a short walk "home", sans that should-not-have-selected-so-much-tempura feeling.
author: Ann H.

description:
We made a reservation on the only available time which was 9pm. Arriving at 9 we had to wait a little and then were seated. After 45minutes were told that they were closing and getting the last orders.
You shouldnt give reservation time for 9pm if you are not a fast food restaurant.
Also my ten year old son was sitting and playing on my phone with no sound when one of the waiters came and told us to mute the sound. Sitting next to him there was no sound.
The waiter serving us was nice, but the other one wouldnt even look at us while leaving. They were all also very busy serving one couple not sure what was so special about them.
Well the food was ok but not good enough to be treated like that.
Won't go back.
author: Mihriban E.

description: Undercover gem.  So happy we tried this place. We asked for the works and they responded with barracuda, uni, grouper, you name it.  The bill totaled 900 for 3 people but so be it, worth every
author: Lawrence V.

description:
One of my friends is quite the regular here so we get the Yakuza treatment when Im tagging along. Sit at the bar and go Omakase. I'd recommend that at any traditional old school sushi bar. However Akiko's is not completely that type of place. At the bar they may serve that tradition, where you sit, the way you eat, etc, but it ends there. They've got a good mix of tradition and modernity that is fitting of a San Francisco restaurant. 

There are some places I go to when I want complete tradition. This is not it. The folks here understand said tradition but have put their own tasteful modern touches to the cuisine. I had way too many courses to remember them all but I think I've uploaded enough pics for you to figure it out. The hospitality, quality and taste are as good as any Edo influenced sushi place I've been to. If you love Japanese food, you owe it to yourself to get yourself to the bar and let them take care of you.
author: Kim N.

description: This is how ocean should taste like. If you're happy with local budget sushi boat places, you gotta come here at least once in your life.
author: Ji R.

description:
I came here with my girlfriend for her birthday and I was thoroughly impressed with both food and service. The best sushi I've had in the city is Kusakabe - which recently received a Michilin star actually, and while Akiko's did not exceed Kusakabe, it was nonetheless *very* good.

Between the two of us, we ordered two rolls, the sashimi sampler, about 8 pieces of nigiri, and two plates from the kitchen and we were stuffed. 

- The agedashi tofu here is delicious and I would highly recommend it. The broth that it's served in is very light, has great flavor, and isn't too salty. The dish is served with roe, so if you're not a fan of it, you may want to pass.

- Tuna here is great! We tried a few different cuts and each one tasted very fresh. The only nigiri that I wasn't impressed by was the scallops. Scallops were not as sweet as I would've liked them to be. Maybe next time. 

- King crab roll/friend crab: you must order one of these. Fried to perfection, and every bite will leave you wanting more.

Akiko's does not break the bank so don't feel like you have to come here only to celebrate a special occasion. Get a reservation for sure, since you might be turned away otherwise.
author: Austin W.

description: Spectacular sushi.  Expect to pay for what you get and it will not disappoint.   It is the type of place I wish were in St. Pete and a check mark reason to live in SFO!
author: Joseph S.

description: First and foremost before we went to this sushi restaurant we had high expectations. We had Omakase and the taste of each bite was beyond delicious. The only place we could imagine of back home is Sasabune. To our surprise dinner was over. Over meaning the Omakase was minimal plates served. Nothing like what we have at home like Sasabune. Needless to say we left hungry and disappointed.
author: Kosta N.

description:
I ordered sushi, some rolls and fried squid. The food all tasted very good. However, there were some peculiar quirks:

- they sprinkle sesame seeds on sushi (nigri). I've never had sesame seeds on my nigri before, not even in Japan.
- the nigri portions are very small. For the price you pay ($6+ per piece), I'd expect the slices of fish to be a little larger. Comparatively speaking, they are about the same price and quality of Sushi Ran in Sausalito, but 2/3rds the size.
author: Reza H.

description:
I've had the pleasure of coming here 3 times, and each time I was served with delicious, fresh sushi. It's a small shop that serves premium sushi so it's pretty hard to get a reservation so remember to book at least a week ahead.

The first time I ventured to Akikos was lunch with my coworkers. I ordered the rainbow roll so I could try as much of their fresh fish as I could. I was pleasantly surprised with the variety I was served. It truly was a rainbow roll, and not the generic three fish roll you get at any other sushi place. 

The second time I came to Akikos was with my parents visiting from out of town. We ordered the special fatty toro sashimi. SO FRESH & BUTTERY DELICIOUS. We also ordered a few different rolls including the rainbow roll. This rainbow roll we received was completely different from the first. Though I was a little disappointed at first, I actually ended up really appreciating that their rainbow roll is always just a variety of their fresh selection of fish for the day.

The last time I went was for my birthday Lunch with my office. We ordered the omakase. Everything served, from the sashimi to the nigiri to the specialty rolls was amazing. I tried so many fish I had never really seen before on a menu anywhere. I'm not an uni person and I was hoping that trying the uni here would change that, but I guess uni is just something I will never grow to appreciate. But to each their own!
author: Nancy T.

description: Absolutely incredible. Foie gras and wagyu nigiri were an explosion of flavour. The meat and fish were super fresh, tender and meticulously prepared. It was one of the best meals I've had in the past year and definitely the best I've had in San Francisco since I moved here from the UK. It's totally worth a visit.
author: Lety C.

description:
If you are looking for a unique sushi dining experience where you can sample a wonderful array of rare and exotic fishes then look no further than Akiko's. 

Omakase is the only way to go but be warned it can add up quickly. I totally believe it was worth every penny and would gladly go back for another special occasion.

Side note: BEST Agadashi Tofu I have had to date! 

Overall Thoughts

Come to Akiko's with an open mind and an open wallet and I promise you won't leave disappointed!
author: Eddie W.

description:
I was excited to try this sushi place as I've always walked by on my way to work.  I came in here for lunch and saw that the menu had quite a few sashimi and nigiri options that I was unfamiliar with.  I asked the waiter to recommend some things for my friend and I to order.  He recommended a few pieces of sashimi, and so we agreed.  We didn't know how many pieces would be reasonable, so we asked him to recommend some.  He asked us a couple of questions about any allergies or dislikes, and then determined some plate to bring to us.  

Overall, I was not impressed with the quality of the fish.  Some of it did not taste fresh at all and it was not particularly flavorful.  Additionally, the waiter recommended way too many pieces for a lunch order, and when we realized this and asked to cancel the last plate of 3 bites before it arrived, he said we could not.  At no point during this process did the waiter notify or warn us of the price, nor were the prices listed on the menu.  Given our obvious unfamiliarity with the menu and restaurant, the waiter should have informed us of the high prices.  We ultimately received the bill and it came out to over $200 for two people.  We felt robbed after this experience for mediocre fish and essentially dishonesty by the waiter.  We trusted the waiter to make a reasonable recommendation for lunch, and he basically sought to maximize his tip without regard for our wallets or appetites.
author: Radha K.

description:
Bold statement time. Akiko's is my favorite sushi restaurant in SF. Three of us were craving sushi and fortunately my wonderful man dates have frequented, and we happen to all work, in very close proximity to Akiko's. We came close to lunch hour closing so there was no wait. First thing I noticed was how cute the place is. It's tiny, narrow, and you would probably pass it a hundred times without noticing (those are my favorite kind of spots). Very clean and nice overall, props on the Aesop hand soap in the bathroom (but no mirror... weird).

Feeling indecisive, we opted for omakase, but with a special instruction to keep bringing out more until we decided we were satiated. Three different kinds of uni, shrimp, tuna, salmon, more tuna, more uni later, we pumped the brakes. The fish was so fresh. I couldn't get enough. For as ham as we went, I was shocked the bill wasn't more - not cheap, but very reasonable IMO. I will definitely be back!
author: Corrina S.

description:
This place is overrated.  Our friends and I ordered the omakase, but I wasn't impressed.  Did not wow me at all.  For the price, I'd rather go to Maruya for authentic, high quality Japanese food.  

The things I remember about this place were the annoying flies that continuously kept flying around our table and of the restroom as it was in an awkward place right next to some tables.  If you have to wait for the restroom, you have to stand around next to other people eating so I felt sorry for the people who had to sit nearby.
author: Erica S.

description:
Firstly, right through the door, we're told our party of 5 cannot be accommodated as the restaurant has a max 4 ppl per party maximum. The restaurant is half empty. The hostess then proceeds to suggest we try a different sushi restaurant about a 10min walk away. In the rain. Do they really not want our money that badly?

Thanks to high school math we suggest:

"How about we sit 3 on one table and 2 on another table?"

Our robot of a hostess pauses to think if this violates the prime directive...

"Yes ok that is possible but you won't be seated close to each other."

"Er... Ok but how about that table for 4 next to an empty table of 2 over there?"

The seater refuses and says that particular table for two (near the back by the bathroom) is reserved so two of us will have to sit a couple tables down. At an identical table for two. At this point things were getting silly and if it wasn't still pouring down outside we would have left but we took our seats, in different parts of the restaurant. 

Eventually after promising that we'll pay on two separate checks, we were allowed to sit next to one another. But had to order separately and weren't allowed to share dishes...

The rest of this dining experience was not much better. The service was ok. The sushi was slightly better. Fish was fresh but the rice was on the cold/firm side. Miso was also available and was good. However the price was definitely not worth it. You can find better for a lot less.

The one star is for the decor. That's the only thing this place has going for it. It's all lovely wood. Even down to the bowls and chopsticks. Handy as this place needs to be burnt to the ground to make room for a better restaurant.  

FTP.
author: Wayne C.

description:
Sat by the window on bush. 

Very good sushi as you would expect. The service was not as I would expect...but don't worry. It was awesome.
author: Jess B.

description: I really liked it. Super small place, but the service was great, and the sushi was even better. Also tried the uni which was interesting. The people were super friendly, and it's a great little spot for tasty sushi.
author: Jason D.

description: Official new favorite spot. The service was amazing and the sushi exceeded my expectations. I normally don't eat salmon sushi, but the salmon sushi here melted in my mouth. For any Uni lovers I recommend the Japanese uni sushi. It was beyond amazing. Coming back again!
author: Lyds Y.

description: Little jem in the wall. This restaurant has 3-4 tables and 4 seats at it sushi bar. I popped in solo for a quick bite and was greeted by friendly staff who served a delicious round of yellowtail and salmon sashimi with hot green tea. Highly recommend if you can get in.
author: Robin J.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet.  I've been here several times over many years. I think this is the sushi restaurant in SF (definitely in downtown) if you like classic sushi without a lot of fluff or extra flavoring.
author: Buddha B.

description: Fantastic upscale and great peaceful ambiance. Can walk up from Market or park your car at the union square garage.  We sat at the Sushi Bar and  had some fabulous custom made vegetarian rolls and some nice  vegetable tempura. The cold saki was excellent. Very nice staff and would go back again.
author: Glam K.

description: My husband and I have been coming here for the last year and last time they gave us a hard time about adding to a waitlist. Today, we were once again being added it to the waitlist (and we were ok with it) but when we asked to use their restroom, she looked us up and down and said we were not "paid customers". In my opinion, bad customer service and treating us like that means you will lose our business forever.
author: Rebecca A.

description: This place is definitely my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city!!! Every dish is almost perfect!! Uni is amazingly fresh and sweet! Definitely a spot that you don't wanna miss in sf if you're a Japanese food lover!!
author: Maggie L.

description: Is this place for real? Salty flavorless sushi that we expected to be phenomenal based on all the hype surrounding this place and the two week reservation list. This place just looks fancy; the food is horrible and overpriced.
author: Lalaland651 ..

description:
My updated review would have been a zero star if it weren't for the fact that I had a really sweet server and there were a few great pieces of fish.

The complaints:
1) I ordered two Asahi Blacks w/ my server. Another server stops by later and tell us that they only have the tall bottles of Asahi Black. We say, okay that's fine, we'll take one of that instead. A third server comes back and pours us our beer while we were talking. He finishes and I look at my cup and realize this is not Asahi Black but just regular Asahi. This is extremely annoying, and shows the disconnect and lack of communication amongst the staff here. I don't mind paying a lot of $ to eat good food, but if I'm spending that much, I do expect the restaurant to have their $h*t together. This was not acceptable, but they remedied the situation by taking away the regular Asahi and bringing out two short bottles of Asahi Black (because they only have this size in the Black). 

2) Omakase here is "AQ' - based on what's available that day. I guess that day was a sucky day because although there were a few great pieces, the overall meal experience was extremely subpar. I was not satiated and desired more, so I ordered more a la carte. Even that was disappointing. What probably made everything worse was...

3) There were flies throughout our entire meal. It was the weirdest (and alarming!) thing. They were small -- bigger than fruit flies, kind of like a gnat. And they were buzzing around our face. A shoo here and there, and I figured I could get over it. But when it was landing on our plates at the end of our meal, that really killed everything for me. What's worse was that it wasn't just one or two. There were 5 flies in my glass of beer. And not just hanging out on the rim, but inside my glass, currying around. I was livid, and tried my best to not make a scene. I showed the third server the glass and he gave me a half-hearted apology.

We spent $300 that night for the worst meal ever. All I could think about was, "if there are that many flies out here...what does it look like where the rest of the fish is?"

For omakase, I'd suggest going to Kusakabe.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Fish is very fresh, probably the best quality fish I've had in SF.

Price range is definitely not $11-$30 as it says on Yelp, and this is the main reason I'm only giving this place 2 stars, because this is extremely misleading. I paid $180 for 2 people for what I consider average order size. I would say the place is slightly overpriced for the fish quality, so my main problem here is the misleading price on Yelp. Not sure if that's the restaurant's fault I guess, but it did mar my experience -- this was a first date so I couldn't change venue after arriving and discovering this. Fix this please.

Most of the stuff we ordered came very plain. I realize they want us to taste the high quality fish, but having some variety in flavors would have been appreciated.

Service was regular and professional, but also felt a bit cold and snobby. Also it was hard to hear the waitress, and even after saying "pardon?" multiple times she made no attempt to move closer or raise her volume. I felt discouraged from asking for recommendations, which may be related to previous point about plain stuff.
author: H K.

description:
Amazingly fresh seafood. This place is small so make reservations. The food is simply delicious. Every fish brought out was mouth watering and melts at every bite. The service is great and the suggestions were excellent. I've tried the omakase and ordered from the menu. I'd say I'd probably do the omakase again next time I go so I don't have to think much. Just send me what's delicious and I'll eat it. 

Have a saketini there. It's delicious!
author: Marlene T.

description:
What a unexpected lovely dining experience I had at Akiko's. A friend and I were just doing a casual stroll in Chinatown, got hungry, was craving sushi, and stumbled on this cute little restaurant. We arrived right at 2pm without a reservation and was seated immediately at a window seat. The place itself is a well kept and has a modern hip woody-aesthetic. 
We decided to go with the $20-30 lunch pre-fixed sashimi + main entree meals. Each of the dishes came with a 6 piece sashimi appetizer followed by a main dish of your choosing. So right to the food - the sashimi was out of this world, very fresh and just melted like butter in my mouth. As for the main course I had the tonkatsu was crisp and delicious but not the best I've had. My friend had the Saba Shio-Yaki which is grilled mackerel which he seemed to enjoy a lot. The service was timely and water was filled regularly, but not exceptional service.
Overall, Akiko's was a pleasant restaurant to visit during lunch, I would come back for dinner but am not in the area. Maybe next time!
author: Lynn K.

description:
Hmm, another OVER-HYPED and RATED place:  no surprise in this city.  I'd give 3 stars for the quality of the sushi, but the service struck out for 1 less star.  

I'm seeing a trend here:  when the restaurant gets so much media coverage (e.g. Eater SF, Sfgate, etc),  for some reasons, the wait staff gets so much snobbier and less personal.   Also, the decor was AWFUL...

I'm Japanese, so I'm picky when it comes to sushi, but still, when there are SO many other mediocre sushi places in town, this place offers no additional points why you should pick this place other than if you happen to be walking by or staying at a nearby hotel.
author: Peaceful S.

description:
2 stars rating  = "Meh. I've experienced better"

Went for lunch alone. Sat on the bar. Ordered:
*    Glass of Tedorigawa Kinka sake for $14.00
*    Hirame (halibut from Canada). 5 pieces sashimi for $27.00
*    Shiro Toro (white tuna belly). 2 pieces nigiri for $10.00
*    Ankimo (monkfish liver). 2 pieces nigiri for $8.50
*    Negihama Roll. Hamachi (yellowtail). 1 roll for $10.00
Total balance due before tip: $75.00 (add $10 more)

Quality of fish was good, but not exceptional
Monkfish liver nigiri was interesting
Shiro toro was just OK
Negihama roll was made with shiso leaf inside (!). It overpowered the taste of hamachi and I couldn't enjoy the fish. I do love shiso, but not with every bite.
Hirame sashimi was cut paper-thin. It got warm fast and I like my sashimi cold. Also, for almost $30.00 I was expecting way more generous cuts.

So, fish is OK, well plated dishes, environment is pleasant, but
portions are small and overall quality to price does not make any sense to me. Not getting back.
author: Cencal F.

description: Wonderful experience coming here. Probably some of the best sushi I've ever tasted. Presentation was gorgeous, excellent service. We managed to get in despite it being reservation only for the most part (which is not really obvious from the yelp page)
author: Marie S.

description: lemme tell y'all something, ion even like sushi. honestly, i'm fkn vegan. but, i did come here w my rap duo once and we had like 4 pieces of sushi. muthafka wanted to charge me like $70 or sum but it was coo cuz they flew me out a barracuda from some third world country and lemme tell u that that sht was super gross. BUT, i know it that was sum real culture sht cuz i could that chefs 36 years of behind a kitchen experience. i ain't ever had that many flavors in my mouth and i've put a lot of things in my mouf before. this the g spot no joke and y'all gotta make a reservation. this something outta chefs table on the real. thank u based god
author: Jose S.

description:
We three people went to this place. I will review on food, service, and price.

Food: I think the food is good. I enjoyed the sushi and sashimi.

Price: this place should definitely be 3 $ if not 4 $ sign. Not sure why yelp gives it only 2 $. We ordered several sushi dishes. Each of us had a cup of red wine. It costs us $300 (not including tips).

Service: I didn't really like the service. The waitress was impatient and not that friendly, given the price we paid. We are not very good at ordering Japanese food and she definitely wasn't patient and friendly enough to explain to us. We understand it is busy, but for the price we paid, it definitely not the kind of service we expected (main reason for 2 stars reviews)
author: Fantasy F.

description: Came here for my 5th anniversary and loved it. I highly recommend the omakase by Alex. He made so many beautifully creative nigiri it was very difficult to say which pieces we liked best. Of course good sushi places will have fresh fish -- that's a given.
