But what sets this place apart is the creativity and the chef's ability to build such beautifully complex and multidimensional flavors. If you're open and looking for something different, truly leave it up to the chef. You will experience so much more that way. We left everything up to the chef and we're glad that we did. Thank you again Alex, for making our anniversary dinner amazing!
author: Alyssa R.

description:
Four stars for the food but three stars for how outrageously overpriced it was. We love sushi and have been to many sushi spots. We also do not mind spending money on great food and truly appreciate food experiences. 

We came here with high expectations and while the food was good, it wasn't amazing and certainly not worth the $350 we spent on two omakases (8-10). It is true that you'll find different types of fish here and that's wonderful but the experience itself was not worth the high price tag and I am 100% positive I can eat the same quality of fish with a better experience for much less.
author: Shireen J.

description: Flew all the way to california just to try this place. pretty good. not bad
author: Tucker S.

description:
Excellent sushi one of the best places we visited in San Francisco 

You can go wrong, we just had lunch and I am sure will be back for dinner before we leave Here
author: Jorge G.

description: Love this place. Their restaurant is pretty unmarked and subtle, which I love. The Omakase was absolutely spectacular and pretty reasonably priced. Their special rolls were simple and delicious. The service was surprisingly very formal and great - loved it.
author: Jo W.

description: That A5 nigiri with dehydrated fat is a supreme..... The Omakase is such a treat! From my stance, this is one of the best sushi bar in the Bay Area that you must give it a try.
author: Annabelle L.

description:
Meh.

Not sure why this place has such high ratings.  Felt it was pretty overpriced(even for SF) for such a blah product.  I've given this place two chances and left unimpressed, still hungry and solid size bill.  The interior looks amazing but pretty difficult to find the place as it doesn't really have an exterior sign.  I'm sure they get a ton of business from travelers and its location(right outside of Chinatown).  There are better places in the city so if you're local, PASS
author: Tim H.

description:
Either make a reservation or go there after rush hour. I went to Akiko's on a Saturday night around 8.30pm with no reservation and there were a lot of tables available.

I'm not really happy with my experience at Akiko's. The menu wasn't rich of choices and extremely hard to understand. I ordered a nigiri dish and a roll, which would usually completely fill me up in whatever other sushi place, but the portions were ridiculously small. Besides that, EVERYTHING WAS SPICY. I was very disappointed on this because I can't stand spicy food and I always make sure that what I'm ordering is not even slightly spicy. The menu wasn't clear about it at all and everything my friend and I ordered was so spicy that we could barely eat it. 

Everything was also overpriced and I really don't think the food was worth the money.

To be honest, the only reason why I'm giving this restaurant more than one star is the service, which was just impeccable.
author: Valentina C.

description: Claims to be open until 9. Came in at 8:30 and they said they stopped serving "walk-ins" already. This is a "very" early time to stop serving dinner in an urban city like SF. This should be mentioned on the web site so as to not waste people's time making the journey to this restaurant.
author: Sam R.

description:
In my opinion, they put too much wasabi on the sushi. They are too strong!! I ordered the omakase. My first time here so maybe the chef's is a bit off today.

I don't recommend this place if you want to eat sushi, I think you can go with the sashimi instead. Not to mention the price, it won't be worth it.
author: Steven H.

description:
First time here, and we didn't realize it was reservations only.

BUT Felix was soooooo awesome and really wanted us to try their food, so he made it work.

The food is AMAZING. Great sushi, nice staff and good prices.
author: Mel L.

description: Good sushi. Traditional. Don't come here looking for saucy rolls. But do come here for good fresh fish with a variety of selections.
author: Jesse J.

description:
You must get here once it opens are make reservations, yes even for lunch!  I arrived at 11:35 and got the last table.  I ordered the sashimi sample that the chef picks out, ($56) yeah I splurged on this lunch.  It came with 6 different kinds of fish, 2 pieces each.  All were really tender and flavorful.

The waitstaff was attentive and informative.  This is totally a 30 min lunch if you get a table right away.  I must say the fish is really good, though the fish I had the previous day for a third of the cost tasted similar or even better.
author: Darika S.

description: Sashimi was good but not at the cost to quality ratio offered at competing sushi restaurants in the area. Server was pretentious about their quality compared to other options. Waitress could have been more warm and friendly.
author: Michael K.

description: Akiko's was a solid, and fun experience. We had a young man named Alex, slicing us up some of the tastiest hotate, aji, umimasu...and the list goes on and on and on. He was playful with the complimentary flavors of yuzu, dashi and ginger, as well as his conversation. Akiko's is a very visually beautiful place, with its exposed facade and soft,  warm wood sushi counter. A wonderful foray into  sushi if you've never tried it before, or want to step off on the right foot, without breaking the bank. Highly recommend this place and really look forward to going back!
author: jamie h.

description:
Excellent sushi.  The four of us came here and had the omakase.  We got:

Spinach in dashi broth
Kanpachi (Amberjack)
Sake (Salmon)
Bafun Hokkaido uni (sea urchin)
Smoked Hamachi (yellowtail)
Hokkaido hotate (scallops)
Kamasu (barracuda)
Akamutsu with pate (grouper aka red fish)
Tairagai (pen shell clam)
Kegani (horsheair crab)
Saba (mackerel)
Wagyu beef sushi with truffle shavings

Everything was amazing!  Even the fresh wasabi and the housemade ginger were delicious.  However, it is hefty on the wallet compared to some other quality omakase, and service was incredibly slow.  Overall, I'd recommend for a nice dinner with some friends who would appreciate great sushi!  Not for those who are roll fans, or a place I would frequent simply due to distance and price.
author: Carol L.

description: Horrible customer service.  I saw how they treated another couple who was asking to use the bathroom. I will never return.
author: Matt S.

description:
Small spot with a big presence. Close to Union Square and shopping. Great spot for that sushi fix. Very friendly service and nicely prepared sushi and sashimi. Started with Unami salad, awesome. Followed with an assortment of sashimi. 
This spot is now bookmarked for future reference !
author: Bruce B.

description:
I've been debating this for a while.

The sushi was fantastic, there is no doubt about that. I'm still a novice in the non-lunch special sushi offerings, but there wasn't a bite that wasn't out of this world to me. I went with the Omakase, and really that is where my issues began. Omakase isn't cheap, and as such I was hoping to not only get great food but also great service. For whatever reason, the sushi chef just didn't seem to want any part of dealing with me. His explanations were short and any followup questions lead to answers with attitude. I take fault with perhaps not being as vocal about wanting more knowledge as a Omakase neophyte, but I just never felt welcome at the counter. I've been fortunate to have experienced Omakase in NYC and also Washington D.C. and in each of those experiences the sushi chefs went out of their way to make a newb like me feel welcome.
author: Eric W.

description:
I was in San Francisco for business when I stumbled upon Akiko's. I sat at closing time at the sushi counter and ordered many things. I also came back the very next day at opening time and sat at the sushi counter as well.

First off I will start by saying that I don't think this restaurant is only two $$ in price. It's definitely more expensive. For just a party of 1 (me) my bill was $100+ on the first night. Yes, this was partly due to the fact that I didn't realize the kinmedai sushi was $20 for two pieces and I ordered 4 pieces (whoops). Even though it's outrageous to pay $40 for 4 pieces of sushi, kinmedai is my favorite, so my bad. 

Secondly, I have to mention how hard I laughed at the crowd that dines at this place. They are the white people crowd that think they are sushi experts AKA they had a California roll one time 4 years ago. When I hear someone ordering rolls with pride, my blood boils. I shrink in my seat and whisper when I order rolls. I swear to you this woman came in, made a big deal about sitting at the sushi counter and then said "I'll do the omakase - chefs choice and let him choose my sushi". Then she said "btw I don't eat" and listed 400 things). She also then said how she definitely knows he can make her a good roll. Uhhhh. Omakase sushi at the counter DOESN'T EQUAL ROLLS. It equals a piece of raw fish sitting on top of rice, period. I laughed so hard I almost damn near fell off my chair. 

I ordered:
+ Uni (just the uni over rice). He put this soy sauce glaze on the top and it literally melted in my mouth. It was one of the best pieces of uni I ever had in my life (now that says a lot).
- Octopus sunomono - I'd pass on this. The scallop one was much better.
+ Scallop sunomono - MUST. ORDER. Wowzers
+ Tekka roll
+ Kinmedai sushi - They torch it and honestly this is soooooooo good

I can't remember what else I ordered. I will definitely be back!
author: Melanie A.

description:
Got the omakase. 3-star experience on the whole: the service was slow and unprofessional; the space and ambiance were subpar; and the sushi quality was entirely underwhelming.  A place like this would never be able to cut it in LA or NY.  

BUT the fatty tuna belly and seared wagyu were so mindblowingly amazing that I'll be sure to come back for them (and them only).
author: Nobody X.

description:
Came across this spot while wandering through SF many months ago and found it around lunch time. Wandered in to be asked if we had a reservation, the answer to which was presumably quite obvious due to our casual attire and touristy exhausted looks. Of course we did not have one - so the host looked through his computer and found someone that was very late for theirs, so, voila, we have a table. Absolutely sensational experience. I crushed a ton of food, but also asked the waitress what she would recommend most and she provided a black cod dish that was to die for. Probably one of the best single plates I've ever had if memory serves. Wine list was on point as well. Tried again on a different day and no such luck. Definitely worth a stop if the space is available.

One quick edit - I didn't read the other reviews first, and now notice a lot of people mentioning price. My share was well over $100 for lunch and I do not regret a single penny. But yes, I ate a lot and we also had wine :)
author: Daniel M.

description:
How I love San Francisco - the fresh seafood, the city, the climate, the awesome stop over on the way to Napa. 
Akikos is always a solid sushi spot. The fish is fresh, the chefs choice is the way to go. Overall a solid sushi oasis in a great city. Although pricey for what one gets it is a solid meal!
Recommend without thinking about it too much!
author: G R.

description:
I've been here quite a number of times.  Each time I've left satisfied, full, and anticipating my next excuse to return.  The sushi is really fresh and delicious.  I've always ordered the special rolls.  Be prepared to drop over $50 here for 2 people for a decent meal/delicious rolls.  GET THE 49er Special Roll = you'd think lemon slices on sushi may taste weird, but its the perfect blend for what they put in it!  You will not be disappointed with it!  I usually get the baked, spicy, crunchy, or warm rolls, those are my sushi of choice.

Con:  It's really cramped and gets booked very quickly, be sure to book your reservation ahead of time!  Also, the staff seem to have this snotty attitude without justification.  On many occasions I've seen them turn customers away simply because they did not have a reservation, even though many tables were clearly empty and had nobody there/prior reservations.  Service is also quite bad, you're lucky enough to get a refill of your water!  Once the service becomes more friendly/attentive, I'll add the 5th star!
author: Ali N.

description:
The older I get, the more impatient I get.
 
Even when it comes to the horizontal mambo, I'm like "Hurry the f*ck up, Iron Chef is about to start in 2 minutes!"
 
Any sushi aficionado knows that most solid, authentic sushi restaurants don't take reservations. If you want one of the coveted 10-12 seats at sushi bars like Sushi Zone, Tekka, and Yume, you sometimes have to wait up to 2+ hours BEFORE they even open. Been there, done that numerous times so while others don't appreciate Akikio's "reservations only" policy, I DO.
 
Akiko is the only sushi restaurant in the Bay Area that I've been to that carries an array of very rare and exotic fishes like Keiji Sake Salmon (1 found in 10,000 catches), Kindai Toro (Sustainable Bluefin Tuna belly), and Russian Uni (Sea Urchin). Most are sourced from Japan. They even carry A5 Wagyu which only 2 other restaurants in SF that I know of do (Alexander's and 5A5). 

Considering this, be prepared to forgo your first born or bring your sugar daddy/mama here for one of the most amazing omakases you'll ever have! What they excel in is their extensive uber fresh fish offerings so please don't come here trying to order teriyucki chicken or a bento box. That's what Sushi Rock and Kiki are for. Plus, you won't be able to get a true appreciation for what Akiko has to offer if you order such Americanized items. 

Being located in the Financial District, Akiko is swankier than your typical sushi restaurant located in Japantown, The Richmond, and Sunset which is perfect for bringing a hot date or to impress a client. Definitely request a seat at the sushi bar when making reservations and entrust in the sushi chef to prepare a series of courses a la omakase that will woo your eyes and your taste buds. 
 
O M A K A S E
Our omakase was $113/person but the price will depend on how hungry you are. You can always give the sushi chef a general budget and they can work around that. 

Omakase took over 2 hours because there was about 5 people doing omakase at the same time so don't come here if you're in a rush.
 
*Tuna Poke Salad: http://bit.ly/Z00lhM
*Kindai Toro (Sustainable Bluefin Tuna Belly): http://bit.ly/10GvRVr
*Hamachi Toro (Yellowtail Belly): http://bit.ly/ZIpBeM
*Umimasu (Ocean Trout): http://bit.ly/YaXTWM
*Walu: (Wild Escolar): http://bit.ly/YaXT96
*Kanburi (Wild Winter Yellowtail): http://bit.ly/13W1iQg 
*Tenen Hirame (Fluke): http://bit.ly/WHFiXc
*House Cured Ikura (Salmon Roe): http://bit.ly/WnsxPg 
*Plum Snapper: http://bit.ly/10Gxjr4
*Sawara (Spanish Mackerel): http://bit.ly/Z00CkO
*Masaba (Mackerel): http://bit.ly/YnIkNM
*Kuruma Ebi (Black Imperial Shrimp): http://bit.ly/13W0ZFo, Fried Heads: http://bit.ly/12PGtGN
*Russian Uni (Sea Urchin): http://bit.ly/X74RMj
*Ankimo aka Foie Gras of the Sea (Monkfish Liver): http://bit.ly/16s7mPT
*Santa Barbara Uni w/ Quail Egg & Ikura: http://bit.ly/15MHVY7
*Kinmedai (Golden Eye Snapper): http://bit.ly/15MHFbv
 
Each beautiful bundle of a gem is brushed with an accompanying nikiri sauce and topped with a garnish (wasabi included). This is what seasoned sushi chefs do so that you don't go dunking your nigiri in a sushi pool and masking the delicate flavor of the fish. I gave Mr. NSS the evil eye when he attempted to do this. I'm trying to get my multiple foodgasm on so don't get us kicked out, buddy!
 
I wish I could say I had a favorite but EVERYTHING was insanely fresh with a melt-in-your-mouth butteryness and a clean finish. I told the sushi chef that I hate Hirame (Fluke) and asked that he not include it on the omakase. He was insistent that I try his version. Okie, fine. Boy, let me tell you...the raw Hirame against the torched Hirame fin was ridiculously good. The torched fin gave a rich smokiness that was mouthwatering and was unlike anything I've seen prepared before.  Kudos for wildly creative nigiris.
 
After slowly savoring 15 pieces, I was ready for the happy ending....
 
*Drum roll*
 
THE A5 JAPANESE WAGYU: http://bit.ly/14X0sPi
 
HOLY F*CK! Where has A5 Wagyu been all my life? Oh yah, chugging beer and getting massages since I'm not balling out of control and have no sugar daddy. The $25 for two pieces (included in the omakase) is worth every penny just to have every one of your taste buds luxuriously caressed by this holy grail of beef. 

The A5 Wagyu is seriously the BEST thing I've ever put in my mouth though someone would pervertedly beg to differ. Sorry but "sausages" have nothing on A5 Wagyu; kielbasas included.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Pretty good for what it is. The food can be on the expensive end (omakase - $100) but worth it if you're a baller. The quality of the fish is pretty good and the staff are great. The rolls are pretty good and check out the agedashi (kitchen section) if you can! Delicious if you don't let it drench in sauce (lose the crispiness - but that's just me). Can get pretty busy during lunch.
author: Nance D.

description:
My wife and I dined at this restaurant while visiting the West Coast back in early Nov, 2016, and had a relatively nice evening.  The food was good and the service was fine, though a bit abrupt.  Sushi was high quality, and the prices were reasonable. 

The reason for my terrible review is that when we received our credit card bill a few weeks later we realized that the restaurant had overcharged us by an even $100.00.  No problem, mistakes can happen.  However, all attempts to reach the restaurant to have this rectified have been fruitless.  I have called multiple times a day for two weeks, left numerous messages, and have not received any response.  We have also emailed the restaurant multiple times, and still received no response.  This lack of professionalism is very alarming given the amount of money we were overcharged.  Any respectable restaurant would at least have the decency to respond and make the situation right, but Akiko's is clearly not a respectable establishment.  Very disappointing. 

I highly recommend that you avoid this restaurant or you may be overcharged and ignored like we have been.
author: Steve S.

description:
I don't agree with $$. This is definitely $$$ but it's so worth it.  I love the modern yet comfortable decor of the restaurant. My friend and I arrived early and sat at the sushi bar.

My friend ordered the sashimi combination and everything was absolutely delicious. I was under the weather and decided to order a combo dinner with udon and 4 pieces of nigiri. The nirigi that came with the combo was unfortunately, not as great as the nigiri pieces I had ordered separately. Next time, I will do omakase or place individual nigiri orders. Yum!
author: Yi Z.

description:
In all the places I've been to in the U.S., it's been extremely difficult to find a legitimate sushi place that actually has real sushi as their calling card.  Yes, that means the nigiri and sashimi take center stage over rolls.  If you want some legitimately fresh fish, you HAVE to come to Akiko's.

And for a guy that has a serious toro addiction, this is exactly the spot.  Both the shiro toro and negitoro were pretty much as good as expected.  Extremely fresh, melted in my mouth, not much else I have to say.  And the uni...damn.  Seriously, I could pretty much eat uni all day and not get tired of it.  This uni was quite memorable and is a definite automatic selection.

The place itself is pretty small, but that's to be expected of San Francisco.  Especially in the back, everyone is crammed together pretty close.  I can understand that they need to fit as many people as they can, but it does make it a bit uncomfortable.  The bigger problem was actually trying to find the place, since there isn't even a sign with Akiko's name on it!  If I hadn't known the actual address, I would've kept walking around like a god damn headless chicken.  

In any case, now that I actually know where this is, I'm definitely going have to come here a lot more from now on.  You can't compete against the freshness, quality, and different cuts of fish there are here.  Next time, way more sashimi and way more everything for sure.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
Came here at 5:30pm on a Friday for a party of 2 without a reservation and SUPER LUCKY we didn't have to wait! The hostess just said they would need the table back before 7pm (which was plenty of time to eat).

We ordered:
Hara Sake (seared salmon belly) 
Kuro Maguro (black tuna)
Sake (king salmon) 
Uni (sea urchin) 
Negi Toro (tuna belly roll)
[& one more nigiri that I can't remmeber...]

My top 2 favorites were the Hara Sake and Uni. The salmon belly literally melted in my mouth and I felt like I was floating the sky doing cartwheels. The uni was so fresh, nice and creamy that I didn't want to drink water or eat anything else so that taste can stay in my mouth forever. 

There are actually different types of uni so make sure to ask your server! *kudos to them too because they are super helpful and patient in explaining the different types too. At the end, I just told the server to decide for us because we couldn't choose on our own haha. 

The serving size is definitely a little smaller than what you may be used to in other Japanese restaurants but the quality is definitely top notch. Besides, remember this restaurant is in SF and literally by Union Square. It explains the $$ but I thought it was pretty worth.
author: Lingyee W.

description: Really hip aesthetic, small quaint, very fast service.  Food is very fresh and delish!
author: Summer B.

description: First, this restaurant is real small, with only the tables and 3 bar stools. Ordered Sushi and Sashimi sampler, $23. The sushi rice is more on sweet side versus vinegar, well textured. The platter comes with basic pieces. Salmon, tuna and spicy tuna. The fish was OK, just average. Was expecting more.
author: Lee H.

description: I tried Omakase tonight! It was so great and delicious! Most impressive is uni from different places, Hokkaido, Russia, and California. Actually I prefer hokkaido's uni which is the best!!! Also I love their A5 level beef sushi! After the experience in wako, I think Akiko's did a fantastic job too! And the server is excellent! He gave us many advices, which is really helpful! About price, I think for their freshest and finest food material, the price is good too! Overall, it must be a impressive sushi night! I will definitely go back for more different seasonal sushi!
author: Sylvia T.

description: Sashimi here is wonderful and melt in your mouth. I often get the sashimi tasting here. I don't think the rolls here are that great. I think the udon noodle sets and other items on the menu are very good but it changes from time to time. If you have a group over 4 then this may not be a place for you. Agashi tofu was great here.
author: Lily P.

description:
I already wrote a review on Yelp about this place, but today's experience just took Akiko's to the next level. Felix greeted us at the front and set the stage for a delightful sushi performance. I would greatly recommend sitting at the bar. (As I have only sat at tables before).

Steve was our chef and was a total delight! We put our hunger in his hands and he provided a delightful spread of sashimi and explained each piece. The total experience was perfect. We will be back...and maybe when they re-open for dinner.
author: Matheson J.

description:
Visited SF from Chicago. After a long work and travel week, I was seeking a low key, relaxing place for dinner. This was it.

The place seats less than 15, including the sushi bar which was where I sat. The server took good care of me. The quality of the sushi was good; not unbelievable. Overall, I enjoyed Akiko's.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Came here for a New Year's Eve dinner after hearing all of the rave reviews, and boy, did it live up to its reputation.

***One disclaimer ***This isn't a sushi restaurant for those who like deep fried California rolls covered in sauce and cream cheese. If your one of those people, please do us a favor and save your time, money and the space you would consume to make room for the rest of us, and go to sushi boat. 

This is a small restaurant with high quality fish, expert sushi chefs with top notch knife skills where each piece of sashimi melts in your mouth with the cleanest of flavors. I would recommend the yellow tail, tuna belly, sake salmon as tried and true options. Also, try the black sesame ice cream for dessert - amazing!

Overall, this is one of the best sushi spots in a city known for great food. Highly recommend and will definitely be returning.
author: Eric B.

description: This was the best sushi experience of my life! I literally stumbled into this place with 2 girl friends while we were exploring San Fransisco. They were able to seat us immediately at the bar. I hear it's usually pretty hard to get a reservation here. We chose the Omakase option on the menu and a chef was with our group for the entire dining experience. He made a point to get to know us and what we liked or disliked. We were pretty open minded and adventurous. We tried some amazing scallops, uni, salmon, etc. He seasoned each piece to perfection and it was served to us individually on a stone. Then we went on to make the next piece. The ingredients were the best of the best, the service was excellent, the taste was out of this world. I highly recommend!
author: Alisa L.

description:
-Tekka roll was good and huge - fresh, yummy, 6 big slices
-Ika - just wow - perfect crunch and sauce; it was one of the best calamaris I've ever had, absolutely spectacular
-Excellent drink selection-

Totally dig the vibe of Akiko! It's a small, intimate, and cozy restaurant. I sat at the bar and just hung out while listening to the really soothing jazz music they had on. The service was quick and attentive.
author: Nin A.

description: If you don't have reservations, you can just forget getting a table. We kept seeing customers being turned away because of it. My wife had the omakase menu and really the quality and freshness of the fish. I just went along and had a dragon roll and avocado roll .
author: Alain T.

description: Unforgettable sushi experience. Visiting from Hawaii we have some pretty decent sushi joints. I specifically wanted to try Akiko's because their unique selection of fish which is different from what I'm used to. The timing and order of every dish was perfect. The chefs did a great job at describing each dish before serving them to us. Come with an open mind and do the omakase. I'm definitely making a reservation here anytime I'm in the city.
author: Patrick N.

description: Right next to the Chinatown gate, small and quaint with excelent servers and good, fresh seafood beat enjoyed at the bar with chef Nao.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I can't say enough wonderful words about this inconspicuous sushi restaurant in the middle of Union Square. When you walk in, the sushi bar with the high stools are very inviting, allowing you to watch the sushi masters work their magic. The owners are always watching carefully, making sure the customers are happy with their selections. The fish is so fresh... Yellowtail, salmon, uni, and my fave...the toro. All melt in your mouth. 
If you're looking to take that special someone on a date, come by yourself and grab a few rolls or for a business meeting, this place is good for all. I will definitely be back!!!
author: Chet T.

description:
I don't even know where to begin with Akikos. My favorite japanese restaurant is still hands down Tekka in SF for their simple authentic japanese dishes but when I come to Akikos I definitely get more variety and twist to my sushi.

I've been here twice and both times had omakase (chefs choice) and they were both times amazing

The only difference is the first time I sat at a table and because of that the waiter chooses what fish you will be served

It's better to sit at the bar because then it will really be chefs choice since they do the cutting and serving

Here's a list of what we ate and everything was just so delicious!

Umimasu nigiri
Kamasu nigiri
Chu toro
Kinedai nigiri
Akei mitsu nigiri
Ensui UNi nigiri
Kanpachi nigiri
Nama hotate nigiri
Amami nigiri
Sayori nigiri
Russian UNi nigiri
Tennen hirame nigiri
Baby anago

Tip: always sit at the bar for omakase and make a reservation ahead of time they're always booked for dinner especially on weekends!

Enjoy!
author: Joanne K.

description:
Ugh... Once I have money I will come back for the omakase with the uni sampler! Being from southern California, I am biased on how much quality sushi should cost. So I'm told that the lunch specials here are very affordable for sf!

I got the tempura lunch set with sashimi and it came with the basic fishes: salmon, hamachi, and tuna for $20. It was quite filling since it came with a bowl of rice. Nothing was extraordinary so I recommend that you do the tonkatsu! I tried my friend's and it was soooo yummy and crispy!

We opened for the black tuna and Russian uni. YESSSSS get this! I never tried any of these before and was blown away. Black tuna melted in my mouth the same way a toro would but still retained its fishiness. The Russian uni is a lot smaller than the Santa Barbara but each bite was so concentrated in the classic uni taste (which I describe as a sweet delicate ocean taste ahhhh). And you know a place is legit if they serve you real wasabi ;)
author: Lisa T.

description: Akiko's you're amazing!  Seriously some of the best sushi I've ever had.  We got the omakase and everything was a WOW.  Our server was great and noted our likes/dislikes so that the chef's choice would be catered more to our likes.  Everything was super fresh and perfect.  This is now my favorite sushi spot!  Already wishing we could eat here again soon!
author: Nancy H.

description: Was looking to get some sushi for dinner and spotted the restaurant near my hotel, ordered the omakase and I was impressed by one of the best value for money sushi meals. You normally only find this kind of quality in places that cost twice the price. Loved the no frills sushi bar and relaxed atmosphere too.
author: Nipei L.

description: Came here a few months ago. I wasn't impressed but it's probably because I go to Japan pretty often. Most sushi restaurants in SF are fake. Don't trust sushi establishments that are not run by a Japanese chef. This place is a fraud and the people who are giving reviews probably haven't had real sushi before.
author: Swanson U.

description:
It's hard to say that this place is authentic.  Do they have decent sushi?  Yes, but the service and timing of the omakase is incredibly slow.

Also, as opposed to a price fixed omakase, they tell you it'll vary depending on what you like.  When I asked for an estimate, the estimate of $100 is grossly under what the actual bill will come out to.  We ended up dropping $200 per person that evening.  You're also served by a white guy that looks and talks like a fan out of AT&T park.  

For a flawless sushi experience, instead head to Pabu.  If you're looking for an overpriced, mediocre sushi joint, head here.
author: Cindy P.

description:
Tonight was the second time we've visisted Akiko's. The first time we went was while spontaneously walking by it but were rejected due to not having a reservation.

The place isn't very big and also kind of hard to find since there's really no signage outside. Just look for the house number.

The food is honesty, mediocre and over-priced. Saw so many of my friend's posts about this place and raving about the quality of the fish that I was really excited to try it. The A5 wagyu nigiri was good but having tasted A5 in Tokyo, for some reason it didn't match up to my previous experience (maybe the transport diluted the taste =P). The nigiri and sashimi were also just meh. The toro barely had that fatty taste to it. All in all, would not go here again. I don't mind paying money for quality, but this place is not up to par with some of the other better Japanese establishments within the City or Silicon Valley.
author: Edison T.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for dinner on a Monday night. We decided to go with the omakase based on majority of the existing Yelp reviews.

Ambiance: It is definitely a nice place to go for dinner, but keep in mind the restaurant is quite small.

Sushi: The sushi is quite fresh and i liked the three nigiri's that came from Hokkaido (scallop, shrimp, and uni) and the A5 wagyu. Those items were quite delicious, but the other nigiri's that were included in the omakase didn't really create a wow factor. Reading all of the existing reviews really put my standards sky high and I just wasn't that impressed. Maybe I came on a bad day? I don't know, but this dining experience definitely made myself think I'd rather go to another Japanese restaurant that offered a much better Omakase dinner.

Price: The grand total including tax and tip was about $250, so if you're not ready to splurge, then this is probably not a spot you would want to go to.

Service: The service was great and very attentive.

Tip: The sushi chef that served us suggested to come on a Tuesday or Wednesday because they usually received their shipments on those days, so there would be more variety for the Omakase dinner set.
author: Denise K.

description:
Oops, we did it again.  Didn't make reservations.  I knew better this time but I was itching for some yum-a$$ sushi!  Open Table said next avail was at 2pm, that was out of the question.  Me and my sissy walked over there with hopes and dreams of getting a seat without reservations.  This time, Allen (same dude as last time), didn't hesitate and said 1 second but within 45 seconds, we were seated.  SCORE!

First thing I noticed, the cherry blossoms were gone gone gone.  It's now a blank canvas screaming and kicking for decoration or color.  Where did my pretty blossoms go?  Oh well.  I can live without them.

We ordered our favorite delicate CLEAN and SIMPLE tasting sashimi of sake, shiro maguro, walu, and Allen recommended an off the menu item, uni something but its translated as salmon trout fish.  Plus, we also ordered 2 orders of unagi nigiri and a rainbow roll.  

Hot damn!  All the sashimi pieces were so good.  The unagi nirgiri was warm and had a slight smoke flav to the top.  I believe the flavor and experience of their sashimi and nirgiri messed up our tastebuds for the rainbow roll.  Because the rainbow roll was wasted on our buds.  But I must give props to the way they make their rice, it was cooked perfectly.

After we were done, the YIKES! factor comes into play.  The bill..oh the bill...the bill puts a dent in our wallets.  But for some reason, that doesn't stop us from attempting to come back.  But since then we placed a rule to our budget and limited ourselves from coming back once per quarter... or maybe every 5-6 months.  The strategy is to spread it out further to avoid the pain of spending so much for lunch.  

See ya soon Allen and Akiko!
author: Jenny T.

description: This place was amazing!  It was difficult to find though because there's no name on the outside anywhere. We ended up in an alley first and the guy working at a restaurant there knew exactly what we were looking for before we even asked. He must get that a lot lol. We walked in and they couldn't seat us at first. Because we didn't have a reservation. We were about to walk out but he checked his list and they had a cancelled reservation so he sat us right away. The place is very small. But quaint. One bathroom to share with each gender. Doesn't bother me though. We ordered our food and within five to ten minutes it was already all at the table ready to go. I was shocked at how quick it was. The sushi was fantastic. So fresh! Probably the best sushi I've had in a very long time. If you can get in to this place, do it. You won't regret it.
author: Kristen K.

description: Stop by on way to a play and was completely and utterly impressed!! Very small Sushi bar but what they lack in size they make up for in flavor.  Melt in your mouth sushi and beef.
author: Chip S.

description:
Great one on one with the chief on what you really care about.   No fillers but just one great sushi after another.  A bit on the pricy side compared to other places.  

Best experience is to sit at the sushi bar.
author: Tom V.

description:
Amazing quality fish, really surprised and impressed by the quality of food here. The servers and sushi chefs all seemed both competent and friendly. 

Make sure you make a reservation here, as the restaurant is tiny and there are almost never empty tables for walk-ins.
author: Andrew T.

description: Had lunch with a friend for the first time.  Got there when it opened, Sushi is the freshest and service is great.  Sat at the bar
author: May M.

description:
I had the chefs choice for lunch. He created an 11-piece set for me. What I love about akiko is the diverse set of tastes and texture relative to other sushi places. Their house made soy sauce is stellar. I thought their rice worked well with certain types of fish but not for others. 

Try their kinki - lightly toasted monk fish river and red snapper. The best piece I had at Akiko ($10 a piece)!
author: Paul L.

description: Had the omakase tasting a few months ago on a Friday evening.  You need to make reservations ahead of time as there was no availability for drop ins.  I was pleasantly surprised but he selection of sushi coming fresh from Japan.  Think the sushi chef gave me 4 different kinds of Uni which were all yummy.  Probably would not go again given the price as there are better options for the price.  Dinner for two for a ton of sushi and even more drinks came to $520.
author: Joe P.

description: Bad on many levels... Really poor service...part of order forgotten...when asked where things were, we were then told that they were sold out.  Some fish was decent, but not exceptional. Miniscule slivers. Too many sweet adornments.  Uni was not fresh -- actually, downright rank. The menu offers a 12-piece chef's selection; what it fails to tell you is that it's actually 6 different, unimaginative fish, but 2 pieces of each. Not sure why much of the fish is flown in from Japan -- which is a trend, but perplexing considering all the fresh fish available on either US coast.  All this was orchestrated with the delish background music of the toilet seat CONSTANTLY being dropped (we all know that familiar sound), coming from the nearby rest room.  How does nearly $150/person grab you for all this?
author: N S.

description:
I'm writing this review for the omakase only.  I've come here 3 times and every time that I've come here, I've had an amazing meal.

If you're like and you don't like to make decisions, don't worry about it here at Akiko's- they will take care of you.  This is definitely not a cheap meal, but I've never left here hungry.  Make sure that you make a reservation though because this is definitely a very busy restaurant.

I'm not a sushi purist, but I do like traditional sushi flavors- soy, miso, shiso, dashi, yuzu- your omakase will cover all of these with maybe a slight twist here or there.  My favorite is sitting at the bar and having the sushi chef tell you what you're getting.  Their uni is bomb.  Their fish is fresh and their service is great.

I will say that this place is a bit on the pricey side and probably best for a special occasion unless your just dropping dollar bills on fancy sushi on the regular...if that's the case then this is the place for you.  OR if you're on like a 6th date and really want to impress them, Akiko's will probably do the job.

Anyway, love this place!  I'll definitely be back
author: Rachel K.

description: Best sushi i've ever had. Everything is fresh and well executed. With a restaurant that has no sign board but always crowded, its really not a surprise akikos get such high ratings from sushi lovers.
author: Rudy S.

description: Make a reservation and then find this hidden place! We were on vacation wondering around SF and found this place on yelp. We walked in circles a couple of times around it and then found the line waiting for the doors to open. Sashimi was fantastic! Fresh and beautiful! We sat at the sushi bar and sushi chef was very friendly. This is how sashimi was meant to be enjoyed.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Because we wanted to order everything on the menu we went with the Omakase.  We found ourselves in the same situation trying to select a Saki from the extensive list so we asked for a pairing and our super duper server graciously obliged (he was so awesome I wanted to take him home but my husband said we probably couldn't afford him).  The fish is the freshest of the fresh and I can't believe I am going to praise rice, but this sushi rice had a sublime texture and temperature.  Our list of tasty fish was:

Hamachi Kama Yakimono
Kanpachi
Shiro Toro
Sake
Chu Toro
Uni (my fav)
Kegani
Nama Hotate
Madai
Tennen Sawara
Kuromutse
Kamasu - barracuda was a new experience for me
Kinmedai

The three fabulous saki's were:

Tobiou (honey)
Yamahi (full body with honey)
Trapeza (Lychee)

We definitely dropped some coin but it was worth it!
author: Heather D.

description:
One night at boxing, oppa almost punched me in the face. Thank goodness I never let my guard down.
So, for nearly punching me in the face, I said we would be eating sushi after boxing. I dragged his ajusshi arse in here for omakase. We were warned that it would take nearly 2 hours. Oppa didn't want to sit around through that but I said too bad!

Yes omakase really does take that long. Yea you need a reservation.  No, the rice isn't tinted with soy sauce. Their sushi rice is seasoned with a red vinegar. Hen did not care for it but I liked it. I felt like Akiko's is a great mix of traditional with a slight modern twist on sushi. If you can, splurge on the wagyu w. truffles. It wasn't in the cards for me that night but perhaps maybe in the future.

favorites: kani miso nigiri - winter crab mixed with "miso butter" aka crab guts but best known as CRAB BUTTA! This needs to be in my life, constantly. 
shiro ebi - white prawn from Japan. amazing texture, really. incredibly sweet and tender
kinmedai - golden eye snapper from Japan
kinki - thorny head


While Akiko's isn't necessarily a place for a random tuesday night when you almost get punched in the face, it can be great for a special occasion or if you want to impress a sushi snob on a date.
author: Susy C.

description: Located in fidi. The restaurant is really small and pretty easy to miss. Reservations only, and they don't take parties bigger than 5 people I think. Ordered sushi rolls and nigiri. The sashimi is pretty fresh and the rolls are pretty creative. Will definitely come back to try their omakase.
author: Cate L.

description:
Possibly the best sushi I've had short of Tokyo.  They import fantastic selections.  
Lined up Russian, Japanese and Santa Barbara Uni for example.
Not cheap but so good.
author: Jason R.

description: Came here for lunch. Very friendly owner and service. We had the salmon and tuna sashimi, gyu and shio saba. Everything was really good without being outstanding. The sashimi was really fresh, but the highlight was the perfectly-seared beef. A little on the pricey side, but overall quite good. Hope to be back!
author: Tian B.

description: This place was amazing, fish was fresh and so good. Make sure to call ahead if you are planning on eating there because it fills up quick and they don't take walk ins.
author: Daniel V.

description:
I'd been wanting to check out Akiko's for a while and I finally got the chance to last Saturday. I tried to make a reservation a week prior but it seemed like the restaurant didn't take reservations on weekends (there were consistently no weekend slots on open table). 

I got there at 7pm and the hostess informed me that they actually do take reservations on weekends, but it's usually booked weeks ahead of time. Regardless, it didn't turn out to be a problem; the hostess was super nice and was able to accommodate an 8pm table for my friend and I. We grabbed drinks at a bar close by and when we came back at 7:50pm, we were seated right away, which is pretty amazing. 

Our order was:

(1) Saba Shio-Yaki (Mackerel)
(1) Uni Nigiri
(2) Spider Roll
(1) Sake Roll

We shared everything and honestly, it was just the right amount for two people (my friend's a guy). We weren't stuffed (which I never aim to be), but we were both satisfied after the meal. Needless to say everything was delicious. The Uni and the Mackerel were the highlights of the night and the rolls were quite unique in flavor--I've been to many sushi places in San Francisco and around the world and I've never had anything quite like these. 

Things to note: 
- There is no restaurant sign and the sign above it is for an Irish Pub, which is confusing and made it somewhat tricky to find.
- Akiko's is open for dinner between 5:30-9pm, so by the time we were seated, they were out of a couple of menu items. 

Overall, an excellent experience for both my friend and I. I'll definitely come back soon.
author: Rafaella S.

description:
Sushi quality: 6 stars.  The best we have ever had anywhere in any country 
Decor: 5 stars, very well done.  Boutique and cool 
Service: 3.5 stars at most 
Price: $$$. How this was listed as $$ is beyond me.  For my 10 year old son and I, including 2 glasses of saki for me, the bill was $100. We each had the sashimi tasting (12 pieces for $34, a la carte was much more expensive), and two bowls of miso soup. 

The only reason I gave this four stars instead of five is due to the service.  That being said, I'll definitely eat here again when back in the Bay Area. If you decide to try it though, be sure to make reservations.
author: Steve G.

description: I consider myself to be a bit of a sushi snob. Akiko's is simply the best sushi I have ever had. Ever. In my life. This place is for people who are serious about their sushi. I love that there is no soy sauce...the chef seasons to perfection. It takes sushi to a level that few, if any, can match. There are two Akiko's in SF...be sure to go this one...on Bush. Make a reservation.
author: P G.

description:
Like other reviewers before me, Akiko's is some of the best sushi I have ever had.


Be warned though that this is a lot pricier than reported and definitely a treat to go to. Sat at the sushi bar and the chef, Chris, is fantastic. We were having trouble deciding so he just starting feeding us! He was sensitive about my shellfish allergy and checked in with us to make sure the tasting timing was comfortable. The server, knowing chef was taking care of us, gave a good amount of space.

Days later, i was still thinking about the deliciousness of the fish. The sushi was sub par, very fresh and melt in your mouth fantastic.

We didn't have a reservation and the wait was about an hour....we went to the Irish Bank for a drink during that time. If I could afford out, I'd frequent this place.
author: Zara S.

description:
This may be a good restaurant but they WILL NOT accommodate walk -ins. 

I was turned away on a Monday night. Not a good level of customer service. This was very annoying as the restaurant was virtually empty at 6:45!!
author: David S.

description:
I've been here a few times, and I've always left here satisfied with the taste of deliciously FRESH sushi. My only issue is with the service at times. A co-worker and I came here after making reservations earlier that day, and when we entered the hostess made us wait for nearly 30 minutes to sit at the sushi bar because our reservations were made only that day and there was another party expected to come who made reservations way in advance(does that matter?), and the other side of the sushi bar was off limits because the sushi chef was new.. Turns out that "special" party never came, and shortly after we were seated the hostess allowed another party to sit in those exact seats. Lame.

Pretentiousness aside, we ordered some sake to celebrate the fact that it was Friday and we were about to get our sushi on. The chef was friendly, helpful and informative on the different types of sushi they had available that day. We would've kept eating if it wasn't for our bellies being full. The bill was about $70 each, but given we had the drinks along with a lot of the specials it didn't feel overpriced. I'd say 5 stars (6 really) for the sushi and 1 star for the hostess. Not going to knock the entire restaurant down for her attitude, but only because the food more than made up for it.
author: Laura G.

description:
Food was great, one of the best Sushi meals I have had. The Miso soup was cold when we got it and we were told that we wouldn't pay for it. When the bill came we had to remind them. Small detail but still worth mentioning.

The service was strange, I felt I was being served by obedient robots instead of people. I also noticed the waitress was fighting with one of the servers.

If the service would have been more friendly and relaxed it would have been a great experience deserving 5 Stars.
author: Guido W.

description: I really don't like giving any bad reviews of a Japanese restaurant of this class. But unfortunately tonight's dinner ended on a sour exit. The food was great nonetheless, seeing how booked this place everyday. The fish is very fresh. The service was fine except like i had mentioned when we were pretty much asked to leave as they had two reservations after. I just wanted to make it clear that we ate pretty quickly, getting there at 5:30 and leaving by 6:45. A chunk of the time is waiting for our sushi to arrive. Anyways, right after the last dish, we asked for the check and got it instantly. We paid it instantly and decided to chat for a bit to catch up. 5 minutes in, we got the "there are two other parties with reservations after you." I have never experienced this at a Japanese restaurant and having given then nearly 20% tips on top of the 4.5% health tax, thought that was just not right. Worse yet is the reason why we thought it was fine to stay a little longer was because there were empty tables when I glanced over. So to summarize, food would be a 4, atmosphere is a 4, and service have to be a 2. Price is $$ to $$$. Reason why I say $$$ is because they price per nigiri whereas most places are for 2 pieces. But it comes out relatively the same for a fancier Japanese restaurant.
author: Amy T.

description:
Make sure to make a reservation on the weekends.  They book up completely.  That being said, hands down the best sushi we have ever had...and I have pretty high sushi standards.  

Wagu, toro and Australian sea trout are all a must try.  

Yellowtail, toro and salmon rolls were wonderful too!
author: Allie S.

description:
We were visiting SF for the weekend and want to start off with a good Japanese meal. We found great review on Yelp and decide to dine here. 

Without reservation on Friday noon, we had to wait for ~40 minutes but the hostess was friendly and helpful. The restaurant texted when the seat was ready. 

We both ordered Chirashi which is not on the lunch menu($30). The selection of fish were plain and the rice were mediocre. Overall, the quality is fair but I definitely had better at the price range. 

p.s: We love sushi and had sushi at Tokyo, New York and LA multiple times in past couple years. Akiko was not memorable.
author: David W.

description:
I have never had a negative experience at Akiko, and last night was certainly no exception.  Even the most basic of items like Miso soup, Edamame and wasabi are excellent!  The ngiri is always so fresh and absolutely delicious.  The service is always impeccable.  While attempting to order 2 orders of our favorite ngiris Toro and Salmon our waiter suggested delicious and similar alternatives to keep the meal slightly more diverse and give us the opportunity to try additional fish.  His suggestions were very on point.  

Loved ending the meal with the green tea mochi, as a delicious palette cleanser.

The restaurant has such a great ambiance and I always leave with the most delicious of vibes.
Thanks for another great meal Akiko!
author: Brynn K.

description:
We were looking for a nice sushi place that wasn't to expensive, and found it with Akiko's! 

They have a really small place (it fits 15people max.) but really good sushi! 

The price is in the midrange for sushi and absolutely worth the sushi that you are getting for it :) 

Good waitress, quick and nice.

Will come back! 

P.s. Their menu has mostly smoked ingredients just FYI :)
author: Debbie G.

description:
This is for their lunch review only.  

I was very excited to find a seemingly high quality sushi restaurant that opens for lunch.  However, I was sorely disappointed.    

Two order of chirashi ($30/each), a toro nigiri, and mochi dessert cost close to $100 for lunch! The chirashi came in a large bowl but rather small portion.  Variety of fish they gave you consisted of the typical salmon, tuna, white fish, eggs, yellow tail, and octopus.  If only they would give you some higher quality and variety of fish, their price is so steep for what they offer you, I simply cannot recommend this place for lunch.  

Perhaps their dinner is better but don't bother coming here for lunch.  For $50/pp, you can get much better lunch else where.
author: Shirley H.

description: Went here due to all the good reviews and was really craving top notch sushi.  The sushi itself was quite good (not great, but quite good), but definitely not commensurate with the prices they charged.  What really ruined the experience though was an extremely cold staff.  Our waiter was fine, but the hostess had, in the words of my wife, "resting b***** face" and everyone else was similarly unfriendly.  It just felt very pretentious and I've had better sushi at those prices.
author: Tarek S.

description:
Reservation required it seems. Hard to find location! I walked right by it at first. Thankfully the chopstick using patron the window gave it away. Amazing fish! Freshh and some of the best in the city. It is pricey, but I had a great experience here that seemed to be off the beaten path and pretty secluded to enjoy your food!

I will never forget the table next to me that ordered a bottle of wine and then got into a diatribe with the waitress about how the bottle was tart and had her fancy son agree that they've had many bottles of this wine and theirs was tainted. Seriously no shame. The waitress did her best to appease them, but what a son and mother shitshow. A whole opened bottle of wine gone. I'll pass judgment and figure they were sommeliers of some sort, but maam you're here for the sushi not the wine. Hope you got your rocks off on that.

Cheers!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Yes, I was a fan of the FOOD but there were some things that made me NOT love this place. It's a shame because Akiko's could really be great. I was impressed with their quality of rice, a lot of places get that wrong and it is an integral park of nigri. 

All the fish was fresh and tasty, they had a nice selection of just in special seafood which I enjoyed. Small place and I sat at the sushi bar. No complaints about food and thought it was very good sushi. Also, I do think you could get out of there without spending a fortune if you watch what you order. 

That said there were quite a few things I noticed at the bar that made this sushi spot seem not of the highest caliber. At any truly good sushi restaurant sitting at the bar is an interactive experience and you can really watch the chefs work their magic. I did watch and saw what I felt were negatives: 

-I could NOT get over that one of the chefs doing sashimi had what looked like dirty finger nails. I can't imagine he did .. how in hell could a decent sushi place have a guy with dirty nails working????? I looked at the other chefs.. their nails were totally clean. Could it have been from the fish? I just don't see how the fresh fish could have made the outlines and underneath his nails black. I just could not get over this.. three carafes of sake later I did get over it but I just can't understand. It was SO BIZARRE I wanted to say something but didn't see any GM around. 

-Sushi chef with dirty ass nails also had old rubber bands around his wrist.. I felt they shouldnt have any jewelry on (aside from a wedding wring) when handling raw fish. 

-Sushi chefs were swigging from snapple bottles. Why not put it in a glass and keep it at a certain class level? 

Overall from sitting at the sushi bar if the chefs could tighten up their visual and performance game to have a true high end experience it be a lot better.
author: Nala P.

description:
***600th Review for Maile N.***  :)

Solid Japanese food - not totally traditional but yummy yummmm....  Our party of five really enjoyed our dining experience here last night!  We had just finished the San Francisco Great Urban Race - we were so tired and hungry.  Akiko's was a right place for us to enjoy a wonderful, tasty meal together after a long but fun day.  

We ordered some edamame (good, tender, not too salty) and the sashimi sampler to start with - the sashimi was a lovely variety and was super fresh, mmm!  This was gone in seconds!  Next, we got a couple orders of the nabeyaki udon and had it split up among our friends - these were healthy servings even though it was split up.  Loved the seafood, noodles, onions and the taste of the broth!  

Then, we ordered some rolls: Dragon (my favorite, so tasty, I wanted this all to myself, ha!), Spicy Tuna (mmm, tasty), Volcano (a little too spicy for me but my friends loved it),  Spider (good, mmm).  

And we got an order of shrimp tempura (mmm, tasty, super crispy!!) and an order of vegetable tempura (nice variety, we loved this, gone in seconds!).  I test Japanese restaurants based on their tempura batter on how thin and crispy it is.  Akiko's tempura batter is a bit thicker than usual and I loved how crispy it is!  It was hard not to eat all the tempura myself, haha.

My friends, bf and I will totally come back to Akiko's in a heartbeat.  The service was so nice to us - we completely appreciated this!    

And yes, definitely make a reservation.  Thank you, Akiko's!!  I can't wait to come back!!
author: Maile N.

description: Although everything we ordered was very good, the broiled yellowtail collar and monkfish liver stood out as exceptional and memorable. You can't go wrong with this place. Order several plates to share.
author: Tyler P.

description:
Akiko's knows tuna.

At the Fallfest event yesterday (a food+wine event benefiting Meals on Wheels SF) I ate food from Akiko's for the first time. They served a chopped tuna belly marinated in 2-year-old, aged soy sauce that was soaking in applewood...what???? Yup, 2-year old soy sauce as a marinade. This makes the soy sauce not so salty and the flavor of the marinade really enhances the tuna. The fish sits atop a soft roll of sushi rice.

Outstanding! really really fantastic.

There was also a second bite of slice raw tuna which was silken and also wonderful.
If I go out in the near future which, of course I will (!), and I'm in the mood for tuna; I'm going to make a bee-line for Akiko's Restaurant.
author: Joanna T.

description: By far the best sushi I've had in SF. We sat at the sushi bar and ordered from chef Adam who was super friendly and an amazing sushi chef. We asked him to make us whatever he thought we would like, which worked out so perfectly. We enjoyed every single bite. All the fish is really fresh, buttery and melts in your mouth. Love this place!
author: Celine P.

description:
I have been to Akiko's twice now, and I actually had fairly different experiences both times. I am not sure whether I was at opposite ends of a spectrum, or whether one was more in line with the norm. 

Anyway, the pros: tremendous, memorable selection of fish (e.g. barracuda and some delicious marinated toro), and everything was very fresh and tasty. Also, not all that expensive, really. 

The cons: the nigiri/sashimi was the only part of the menu that I thought was creative. The rolls I had this time were a bit unimaginative and only marginally better than the average sushi joint. 

The first time I ate here, our waiter offered to make recommendations and I think he might have gone off-menu for some rolls. They were amazing and unique, and he paired them with other dishes to boot. This time, our waiter seemed hurried and did not offer (and I did not ask, which admittedly is on me). But then he forgot part of our order. 

Anyway, Akiko's is still quite good and worth making a reservation at, if you know you're going to in the area. I would definitely go back, and I'm still giving it 4 stars because even my second visit was really quite good.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Is it the Battle of the Akiko's? I keep picturing the competing chefs in ninja outfits having a mano-a-mano kendo stick match, probably on Claude Lane, in front of indifferent French diners I assume. Do they truly compete or is it more like the Battle of the Network Stars where they throw nerf balls at each other in a bouncy house? One Akiko is a modest, tight-fitting sushi bar on the lower part of Nob Hill on Mason. The other is this place, which is sleek, posh and also tiny. Or maybe the other place is the other place. Oh I don't know except this one does produce some mighty fine sashimi, sushi and nigiri, the standard delectables from my homeland. This is definitely not the Akiko's I remember from a decade back. No no, that one was a lot more like the other Akiko's.

This one places a lot of focus on a beautifully immaculate presentation with exceeding freshness. For what was supposed to be a leisurely lunch with colleagues, I was blown away. We threw caution to the wind and let the chef perform his magic for us. It started with a polished, rustic-edged board upon which laid a half-dozen world-class trios of sashimi slices - Umimasu (Ocean Trout, $4.50), Hara Sake (Fresh Salmon, $6), Sunazuri (Yellowtail Belly, $6.60), Tenen Hirame (Fluke, $8.10), and Kodai (Red Snapper, $3.60), and Kuro Maguro (Pacific Bluefin Tuna, $9.60) (photo: http://bit.ly/1jchNtW). Simple and ocean fresh, devoured by us in a matter of minutes like it was Chicken of the Sea which would be ironic since Charlie was a tuna, wasn't he?

Next came the sushi starting with the jewels in the crown rolled in nori - a pair of the mouth-popping Ikura (Wild Salmon Roe, $4) and a pair of the impossibly luscious Ankimo (Monkfish Liver, $4.25), which I've gotten to know intimately at the must-go Ino Sushi (photo: http://bit.ly/1jJbrrT). The nigiri followed with a couple of Kuro Maguro (Chutoro) (Fatty Tuna, $10) and a couple of Kamasu (Barracuda, $6), a nice discovery for me and a new favorite (photo: http://bit.ly/1lHwrea). Arriving almost like a late-meal amuse bouche were two spoons of the Kan Kani (Crab, $5), perhaps the only slightly marginal taste of the bunch (photo: http://bit.ly/1jci6ow). But all was quickly forgiven at the end with the pair of Kuro Maguro (Otoro) (Tuna Belly, $12.50) (photo: http://bit.ly/1gVvG5F) and the pair of Managatsuo (Japanese Butterfish, $7.50) with dabs of liver on top (photo: http://bit.ly/1lHwyGK).

We kept the libations to a minimum with a $13 glass of the Omachi Sake (photo: http://bit.ly/1nxND8G). Yes, it was quite steep for such a small amount, but it has a subtle flavor infused with rice, herbs and anise that made for a smooth ride down the gullet. The check did give us an audible gasp, a total of $116 for the three of us, and as you can see from the price tags above, we are talking about fish that runs quite a cost range. I assume the Fatty Tuna came in chauffeur-driven fish tanks. Alas, that is the price we pay for the quality. You can always go to the nearest sushi boat operation or maybe some franchise like Sushi-R-Us if you are balking at our bill. But if you treat yourself on those rare occasions and you're not in J-Town, then come here. But for Akiko's sake, make a reservation in advance. Drop-bys are near-impossible. Or go to the other Akiko's if you're that desperate.

FOOD - 5 stars...world-class fish even if it is a lot of do-re-mi (...that's Japanese for "I lost my wallet")
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...small place but if you can get a table, you're in like bluefin (photo: http://bit.ly/1jB8eJB)
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...very kind and serviceable wait staff
TOTAL - 5 stars...best sushi in the FiDi...but make sure you're at the right Akiko's when you make that reservation
author: Ed U.

description:
Bottom Line: Top sushi spot in the city

My fiancée took me here for my birthday and it was awesome. I have been Pretty sure reservation is a must but maybe you can walk-in and grab a seat at the bar.

We had the 6 pc nigiri tasting, octopus sunomono, salmon nigiri, 2 pc uni, salmon roll, and blue crab. I asked the server for some recommendations on the rice wine and got some direction but could be better. 

The nigiri tasting had your usual suspects but all were very high quality. Honestly, everything was great so just go to Akiko's!  Well the blue crab was just good. The crab portion was a bit small to share so order your own. With so many terrible, bad and ok sushi in the city this is an easy 5 star for SF.
author: Matthew T.

description:
My newbie yelp elite friend recommended that we eat here.... strangely we had an overall underwhelming meal.  There was something off about the sushi that day and it was a bit overpriced to be honest.  Ok let me back up... first of all the restaurant is difficult to find because there is no sign outside and it is very small.  

We did not order much food to be honest; just enough.  Spider Roll (see pic) - this was recommended by our server who strangely didn't really know exactly what to recommend to us LOL.  Tekka - was pretty good but the portion was a bit small and flavors were not bold.  They don't do the whole crazy sauce thing here like you might find at the more Americanized sushi places in the South Bay but definitely cleaner more subtle roll setups.  

The SAKE which was $10 had some pretty fresh tasting salmon which for sure was one of the better dishes out of everything we had.  Overall the service was very good, and it is NOT the worst sushi I've ever had.  I've had some really bad sushi in the south bay.  Shoot, I had worst sushi last weekend in SF.  I'll review the place soon enough, I don't even remember the name of it. 

The ambiance of the place is nice and they play kinda cool music... we got stuck strangely in a claustrophobic spot in front by the window which I guess is more desirable location in SF....? not really sure haha.  Anyhow the highlight of the night was that Mike Epps was filming a movie outside the restaurant in the alley way which we had a clear view of right from our table, hehe.  I have pics of it.  

We later realized that we could have gotten a much more satisfying meal elsewhere for less money.  I joked around about it, but I think my friend took it a little more seriously than me haha.  I'm not a big fan of sushi unless its during the summer.  And for me it's often a question of how fresh the fish is.  If the ingredients in the roll aren't fresh, I try to stay away.  If the fish isn't good quality I'm never coming back.  If there are truly better sushi options around Nob Hill or Union Sq., I am yet to find it.
author: Kenny P.

description:
Had the omakase. It was almost all nigiri. Highest quality fish I have ever had.

Sat at the bar. Service was great. Sushi chefs were great company. Total bill came to 230 before tip for 2 people. We had about 14 pieces each.

Will def come again!
author: T. B.

description: We finally tried this little gem not far from the hotel we always stay in.  Everything we tried besides the sushi, was delicious. The miso soup, seaweed salad, grilled eggplant appetizer and potstickers, were all exceptionally good.  We ordered a rainbow roll and it was very bland in flavor.  We did order a two piece of salmon sushi and that was good.  This place is very tiny but the server was extremely nice and gave us free hot tea.  I definitely return but probably not for the sushi.
author: Mary Anne B.

description:
I absolutely love Akiko's. If you truly love Sushi, please try this place. The only con I can think of is price. It can get very expensive. There was a unique order of two-piece sushi that was about $32 which was really delicious but I think you get the point.. I don't even remember what it tasted like now.

The receive fish overnight from Japan and they are extremely fresh and cut perfectly. Presentation enhanced tasting experience as wells as the ambiance.

Servers really know their fish, it's taste, and do not hesitate to recommend other fish that you may enjoy.
author: Sarah K.

description: Loved it! I sat at the sushi bar and was taken care of from the moment I sat down. Plates don't sit, water is always filled, they don't miss a beat. And the sushi is fresh, creative, lovely to look at, and at the bar you get a wonderful sense of how careful the sushi chefs are with their craft. It was some of the best sushi I've had - highly recommend!!
author: Kelly C.

description: This place is an absolute ripoff......$175 (with tip) for 6 nigiris  for 2 people each,a bowl of baby makeral, a tiny glass of sake and a large Sapporo.....we got up and left half way through..,Sushi was nothing to write home about...I told the server twice we didnt want wasabi and he put it on everytime....Who the hell pays $25 for 2 nigiris?....
author: Captain C.

description:
TL;DR: 
Pros: Good food
Cons: terrible/ ssssslllllllooooooowwwwwww/ inefficient service

If this were a review based solely on the taste of the food, I'd give it a 4. But the service is so terrible that there's no way Akiko's is anywhere near multiple stars. They have a long way to go and a lot of inefficiencies that need to be addressed.   

We came here on a Thursday night with reservations. I noticed some people being turned away because they didn't have reservations. I also noticed that people were waiting in line when 2-3 tables were open just because they were reserved by people late for their reservations. Inefficiencies abound; they had maybe 4 bus-boys but only one guy taking real orders. 

It took 30 minutes to finally get a waiter to come to us; we asked 3 different bus-boys to place or order but they all said they weren't waiters and that they'd call over the waiter. The one waiter would walk by avoiding eye contact and go to another table each time we tried waving him down.  

We ordered some entrees and some sushi, but sashimi took forever to come out; in fact our order of uni took 1 hour and 30 minutes. We asked the waiter once, and the bus-boys twice for our order of uni. Later on the receipt we were double counted for our uni. 

We ordered two volcano rolls, one with fake crab and the other without; we explained that our friend was allergic to crab and didn't want to risk it (even if it was fake crab). The first volcano roll came out in 15 minutes, the second took an hour. When the "crabless" one came, it was the same as our volcano roll only they sprinkled the crab on top rather than frying it in. We explained that we didn't want to risk the crab-allergy but the waiter simply said "it's just fake crab don't worry eat at and you'll see." Sure it ended up being fine, but there was no need for it to be sprinkled on top (when it's usually fried into the volcano roll toppings). 

They offered the roll on the house, but they put a random $15 dollar roll we didn't order on our bill anyways. We didn't check our bill close enough; we caught the double order of uni mistake but we didn't catch that they included a random roll into our bill. 

The dining experience was from 7pm to 9:30pm. Most of that time was us trying to catch a waiters attention, being avoided by bus-boys who knew they couldn't help us, and waiting for our single order of uni and crab-sprinkled volcano roll.  

Extremely disappointed because what's the use of good food when the service is horrendous and the wait time is a few hours for fish to be sliced.
author: Jennie C.

description:
So happy about my meal here. Came after work around 6pm and there was ok wait for two people. We ordered cucumber salad, agendashi tofu, salmon and Australian trout sashimi, scallops, monk fish liver and sea urchin nigiri and lastly mackerel grilled fish. Everything was super delicious. I could probably do without the agedashi tofu and the grilled fish (was pretty dry). It is also a bit hard to locate the place as they don't really have any sings outside. You may mistakenly  recognize it as an Irish bar, there is a giant sign that points to an alley with the Irish bar right over where akiko is residing. 

Anyway I would highly recommend and may the feasting odds be ever in your favor ;)
author: Katya O.

description:
It's my first review, but this place deserves it! 

1. Excellent service - we walked in a few minutes before closing but we were greeted warmly. One of the tables was clearing out so we were seated pretty quickly. The servers were polite, friendly and incredibly professional. They even took the time to carefully arrange our plates right before the food was about to arrive! Great attention to detail. 

2. Fresh and delicious fish. We ordered a couple of nigiri and also some of the rolls. The salmon roll is so delicious! It's 5 pieces but every piece has large, juicy buttery fresh fish which is perfectly seasoned. The scallops nigiri was probably one of the most fresh and tasty scallops I've had (and I loveeee scallops!) It was so juicy, had great texture and bursting with that delicious scallop taste! Halfway through the meal and we knew we were coming back. 

In summary, great food, great service! Will definitely become part of our regular rotation of places to eat near the financial district.
author: Hyejin S.

description:
Amazing fish quality (amazing is an understatement) and superb overall service with awesome chef's.
Must sit at the bar and order omakase! Thanks again Allen!
author: Ruslan T.

description: The food here is realllllly good, but the service is realllllly slow.  My fiancé and I made the mistake of coming here for lunch, and it took an hour and a half to get edamame, sashimi, and a roll.  This would have been fine if it was like that night and we were trying to have a leisurely dinner, and we had drinks to distract us, but it was really annoying at lunch time.  The staff was just not communicating with each other, sometimes the hostess served us, sometimes a waiter, and we saw our food prepared and sitting at the sushi bar with no one knowing who was supposed to get it. Also, it wasn't busy, so there was really no reason.
author: Salini N.

description:
One of the better sushi restaurants in the bay area.
This place is hip and modern. The sushi chefs wear button downs, chambray shirts, etc.

The fish is pretty fresh and very firm (came on Tuesday lunch so the variety was somewhat limited because they just got their fish in and some were still being "processed".) So we knew that was the freshest it's probably going to be here.

Kinda pricey for the quality but I guess this is as good as it gets here.
author: Heejin L.

description:
I've been trying to go to Akiko's Restaurant for awhile now, and I tried a same-day reservation, but they were all booked. Thankfully, I just happened to be in the Chinatown/Financial District neighborhood around 11:30 AM, which is exactly the time that they opened. My business colleague and I walked in and asked for a table. Although they asked if we had a reservation, and we said no, they accommodated us, with the caveat that they needed the table back at 12:30 PM. I didn't take this as a slight but, rather, as a sign of how in-demand and exciting this place is.
I ordered the lunch only sashimi with salmon teriyaki, as well as two pieces of the Uni (or sea urchin) from Santa Barbara. For information purposes, the lunch sashimi comes with four pieces of sashimi and, honest to god, every cut of fish tasted so fresh, so buttery and just out of this world. Even my cooked salmon teriyaki had beautiful flakes of tasty skin sprinkled on it, as well as this nice sauce. 
Moreover, the servers were always attentive. My only gripe was that the tables were a little too close for comfort, as I had a hard time exiting the table, and I'm not even an overweight person.
author: Andrew J.

description:
I came with a group of 5 for an early lunch and the place was maybe half-full. The restaurant is pretty small, so I'd recommend a reservation, especially for dinner. There's no actual sign outside with the restaurant name so it's easy to miss, but it's right by the Irish Bank.

Food is a little pricey here, but not outrageous, especially given the high quality of the fish. Definitely worth the spend, though I probably wouldn't suggest coming here if you were really hungry. I had the Sashimi Tasting, which was 12 pieces of amazing sashimi for $34, and would definitely recommend it.

Service is great here - friendly and attentive - and the atmosphere is pretty cozy.

==============================

SASHIMI TASTING (12pc) $34 - 5/5
[2 pc salmon, 2 pc tuna, 2 pc mature snapper, 3 pc white tuna, 3 pc yellowtail]
The sashimi is AMAZING here! Super fresh, really great texture and pretty generous cuts. My favorites of the five were the white tuna and the yellowtail. Both were incredibly soft and basically melts in your mouth. The other sashimi were definitely good quality too, but had a little more of a chew to them
author: Jessie L.

description:
What would I do without you Yelp?

My friend and I happened to both be in SF for work and managed to meet for an impromptu lunch. I pulled up ye' 'bible' and did a quick search for sushi that was open now (12pm), up to two $$, and within reasonable distance.

Akiko. Bingo!!

As time was of the essence, I grabbed a cab and bee lined it over, from Moscone West to the venue was roughly 10 min.

Storefront is nondescript and homie had to slow his roll to find this little gem. I located my friend at the sushi bar and settled in. Oooh, purse hooks - gal's best friend! Of course I felt giddy inside, little things like this excite me. 

I quickly surveyed the place - it's definitely on the smaller side. Sushi bar is L-shaped and seats 8-10 give or take. I'm not too sure how many patrons can sit down for a table but it looked like it could accommodate 5 different parties. Luckily you can call to make a reservation or do it online.

Sushi chefs and wait staff provided top notch service, even though they teased me a little while I was taking my foodie photos :P
