The food was great, all very fresh and reasonably priced! I ordered the Duo: with 4pc nigiri and saba-shio yaki and it was dee-licious!! $21 for all that + miso soup. My friend got a Duo as well but opted for salmon and sashimi. While waiting for our order we spied on a dish that looked utterly amazing, we couldn't contain our oogling so inquired what it was: a ha! Poki bowl!

We caved and ordered one but judiciously decided to split. At first I was sad inside because I knew it was going to be bomb dot com and was feeling too greedy to share BUT in the end I was glad we went halvesies.

Their hot green tea was a smart choice for an afternoon lunch and when you have to go back to work, although the sake + beer was quite tempting!!

Anyway, whenever I'm back in SF and craving sushi + yummy saba - you'll be sure to find my ass parked on one of their bar stools, this time with hot sake+beer in hand, oh yeah.
author: Ailyne V.

description:
One of my goals for my vacation to San Francisco was to have "real" sushi. Akiko's was definitely the right choice for that. A tiny little sushi bar tucked away a block away from the China Gate without any sort of signage, it's exactly the sort of gem everyone tries to find.

I went for a light lunch while waiting for a friend and was seated right away without a reservation, despite the tiny size. They had a VERY impressive sake selection; unfortunately I only had time for one glass. I ate the Hokkaido scallop sashimi, and a spicy tuna roll. Service was very quick and attentive, and prices very reasonable for good quality sushi. A perfect spot to pop into for a quick lunch, or for catching up with a friend over several glasses of sake. I'd return in a heartbeat.
author: Chris M.

description: In all seriousness about this place.... hands down my favorite sushi restaurant in the whole... the WHOLE USA. Incredible service.... food quality, best selection and cuts and trims. Worth every penny, and it ain't cheap either. Thank you guys for the wonderful experience and a long lasting impression you've made. Oh get reservations, or you're shit out of luck.
author: Dang D.

description:
My boyfriend and I had dinner here two weeks ago and it was the best sushi meal we've ever had! We both did omakase and while it was pricey, it was worth every cent. We have been blessed (or cursed, depending on how you see it) with really big appetites so our omakase meal ended being something like 24 courses. And oh my lord, it was good.

We started off with a sashimi trio, followed by endless rounds of nigiri. Each plating was beautiful and delicious. I'm a big fan of the sushi chef seasoning for you instead of dunking it in wasabi and soy sauce yourself. Everything was perfectly balanced, and I could still taste the different, delicate flavors of each piece of fish. My favorites were the scallops, Hokkaido uni, Russian uni, crab, salmon roe, wagyu, mackerel, and basically everything else we had. It was all perfect.

We sat at the sushi bar, which is my favorite because we chatted with the chef and he selected some pieces for us based on what we said we liked. We also chatted with some of the other patrons and the overall atmosphere at the sushi bar is very friendly. It's definitely the way to go.
author: Jessie L.

description:
The Omakase experience here is definitely worth it. Got to try so many fish you can't find elsewhere. Their menu changes often depending what fish they can get their hands on... but I can tell you all their fish are FRESH!!! That texture from each one gives your mouth a surprised feeling. Whether it melts in your mouth, firm yet soft when you bite into it, or whatever. Hope that description didn't come off a lil dirty but I can't describe it enough! Ranging from $90-$100/person with a very generous portion. My omakase started off with a spinach salad, then oysters, then many pieces of sashimi and nigiri. It was enough to be full for the night leaving a lil room for dessert.

Few items that highlighted my night was the monkfish liver... this was creamy, buttery, and reminds me a lot of Uni but taste totally different. Tried two different types of mackerel, and can't forget the Toro!! The wagyu beef nigiri was awesome being the last piece that complimented my entire meal. It was just amazing.

This place is reservations ONLY so please reserve on OpenTable so you won't be disappointed by being a walk-in. Reserve at least a week in advance for a good time slot. Only regret is I should've called to request seats at the bar. I missed all the action from the sushi chef. Until next time.
author: Nancy N.

description:
I hate writing bad reviews, but my experience was absolutely horrible at Akiko's. I had great meals here in the past (prior to the chef changeover), so I took two friends to their first omakase there. And we will never go back.

+ The sushi was mediocre. Bland, a little chewy at times- a couple bites were unique, but nothing that blew your socks off like Kusakabe.

+ We were seated at the sushi bar... at the chokepoint of the restaurant. We had reservations, so they knew we were coming, yet our seating was such that we were right next to the servers' station and we got bumped and jostled the whole time. 

+ We got the bill, and it was pricey for the sushi we got (no toro, no uni, no drinks, and still $150 per). So I asked to clarify a charge. They said yes, they made a mistake... they had *undercharged* us. They took the bill, and ADDED nearly $100 to the bill.

+ The service overall was haughty and rude. Water splashed on me at the beginning, had to repeatedly request ginger, no menus until we requested, and the servers' attitude was what you'd expect from pimply high school students- snickering, pointing, absent when you needed them. 

If you want to spend $150+ on bad sushi with bad service, by all means, book a seating at Akiko's. I was wondering why reservations were so easy to get- now I know.
author: Cyn K.

description:
If you are looking for an all-in experience, the Omakase (dishes selected by the chef) at Akiko's is a pretty terrific option. It's actually the best I had in San Francisco.

We started our dinner with a cucumber & octopus salad that was followed by a sashimi platter (6 fishes) and then a farandole (~12 different kind) of nigiri  including Otoro Nigiri (fat belly tuna), Kinmedai Nigiri (golden Eye snapper) or Ankimo Nigiri (Fish Foie Gras).

We also had a flight of sake that was really good. And our server (Allen) was very knowledgable and answer any questions we had. To wrap up what ended up being a really expensive meal ($$$) the chef gave us a free plum sake. Perfect touch of sweetness to end the day.
author: Cedric L.

description: Some of the best sushi I've had in SF! Make sure to make reservations, even during lunch. This place gets packed. Had the miso soup, avocado roll and spider roll. So good.
author: MacKenzie B.

description: This place is so unique and intimate.  The taste of fish and everything they make is divine. Plan a dinner in advance, it is something to look forward to.
author: Elena P.

description:
Seriously the best sushi we've ever had. Went all out and got the omakase. Totally worth the $264 for the two of us, 18 bites each with 2 large Asahi's! Some of the best tastes ever and actually left pleasantly full. The quality of the fish here ruined every sushi restaraunt we have back at home. Standouts were the bluefin, mackerel, barracuda, sea urchin, and king salmon. We will definitely come back on future trips to San Francisco. 

If you love sushi, go, and omakase your heart out.
author: Ryan J.

description: The environment is really good, but every thing are so tiny and expensive, the beef is amazing.
author: Tony S.

description:
A tad heavy-handed on the wasabi, but overall our omakase meal at sushi bar was wonderful until it was time to pay. Who knew that our gentle reminder for the check would trigger World War III between the staff? Although the argument was not directed at us, we were put in an extremely uncomfortable situation and sprinted out of there as soon as we finished paying. 

I would love to return for another omakase experience but I'm just so scurred!!!!
author: Suany W.

description: We were excited to have sushi on the West Coast - we live in Colorado, so this is going to be a treat. The restaurant staff was not overly friendly, the sushi was no better than landlocked quality, the portions small, And the bill skyhigh.
author: Lisa L.

description:
The food is a definite five star but some of their attitudes stink here.

First off, no restaurant sign??! How were we supposed to know to enter a door labeled Irish Bank?! Too good for signs, I suppose. I had to call and the hostess ran outside to wave us in. Golly. There was maybe one or two friendly faces the whole time we were there.

Anyway, small details like when one of the waiters were setting our table, he rudely picked up my phone and set it aside so he could situate the sauce bowl ever so perfectly by the side of my plate. What place have you been that they're allowed to touch your property without asking??? Unbelievable. And he kept coming back to adjust my sauce bowl whenever I moved it. Come on.

I was steaming already.

The other waiter and the busboy were quite friendly and the food was expertly crafted. However, when you piss off your patrons square off the bat, it's hard to not see red for the rest of the time. 

I ordered everything I wanted to taste and it was masterful and divine. Expensive, yes, but the food is worth it. Just.... Up the service people.
author: Helen D.

description: Akiko offers some of the freshest fish sushi I have ever eaten. This establishment is clean, and rustic-elegant in decor. Both the food and inside are artistically inspired. They serve a variety of nigiri and sashimi, perhaps six different types of rolls, some beef, fresh roe, tofu dishes and more. We enjoyed everything we ate and highly recommend this restaurant. Also, the service is very professional. Their menu changes daily, depending on the chef's preference and what is fresh (the fish arrives fresh nearly every day).
author: Gaya G.

description:
Good not great (as is most sushi in San Francisco), I'd be comfortable giving it 4 stars if were less expensive. Pricy for a sushi place that isn't outstanding, but you'll get a nice meal. 

Reservations are recommended because this location has very limited seating, but two of us went around 7pm on a Thursday and got seated right away. They have a selection of sake. Fresh fish, the waiters will happily tell you what the best cuts of the day are. If you're looking to fill yourself up (always a drain on your wallet when talking sushi), expect to pay $30-50 a head. 

My sushi-expert (I'm not one) friend says this place typically does great nagiri and less great sashimi, so my advice is go for whatever the day's selection of fresh nagiri is.
author: Bud P.

description: Phenomenal sushi and excellent service. We came for lunch but we're too late to get seats, so they suggested we come back for dinner. We did, and it was an incredible experience I won't forget. You will pay a lot, but it's worth it.
author: Michael K.

description:
This place is definitely a $$$$ place, not $$! 
We got lucky to have the table right away without reservation on Fri night. The place is small but totally modern and warm. We ordered the nigiri on the special menu and THEY ARE ALL GOOD! The must-try one is Wagyu beef with truffle.
However, I dont really impress with the negi toro roll. It is a bit soggy to me.
Our service is friendly and nice. He came back to our table ( or his table) to check on us frequently.
I think Akiko's price completely beats sushi Ran but not sure about the quality. They both have an excellent fine dishes but I obsessed more with sushi Ran's rolls and small dishes.
author: Loan L.

description: My favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. This place always make me happy and it always have fresh and good food. Very important to make reservations. Always busy and packed. I been a customer here for over 10 years every time I am in San Francisco I will always go have a bite here. I highly recommend you give it a shoot great for bring a date.
author: Wen L.

description:
(from 8/26/2013)

The best sushi I've ever had. Admittedly, I'm from the Midwest, where great sushi is hard to come by.

After two visits here, the staff was overall better the second time around. They were pretty on the spot (no less than 5 people came by at regular intervals to check on us). One of our beers arrived a little tardy, which wasn't that big of a deal but one of the staff seemed distressed about that and didn't charge for it.

Cool setting, all-around great experience. Foresee going here every time I'm in SF.
author: Steve G.

description:
We came here for my wife's birthday and were really impressed with what we got.  We ordered the omakase and it consisted of a plethora of selection from Japan including two types of uni, wagyu beef, aji, and much more.  The omakase also included a beautifully done black cod which was done in a way that I have never tried before in a Japanese restaurant.  The restaurant is small and intimate and they were great to accomodate our little one.  What I was surprised by was the rolls weren't that expensive ($10 to $12).  

I'm giving this four stars instead of five because 1) the food took longer than expected, there were times we were waiting for half an hour it seemed for the next thing to come out and 2) when we asked how much the omakase costs, they said starting at $100.  That could be a bit scary, as you don't know how high the price can go to.  Basically they just serve you what you want from the special selections menu and price it that way.

I thought the type of sushi we got was probably better than Kusakabe and if I were to go all out on getting some delectable sushi, I'd most likely come back here.
author: Pierre L.

description: I hosted a work dinner in their back room. Amazing! One of our best client dinners. The team at Akiko's worked with us to make sure everything was perfect. the guests couldn't stop raving about the delicious Omakase.
author: Julia M.

description: Sushi was good. Service slow. The kicker though is that two out of the three of us had dashes to the bathroom about 20 min after we left.  Not comfortable the rest of the day, so basically mind food poisoning.  Given that, I can't give a high rating when the food was either contaminated or bad. We think it had to have been the silken tofu as that was the only shared dish.  Overall it was a small offering in terms of menu options and we were underwhelmed.
author: Kelly H.

description: Wait, how have I not left a review for my favorite sushi spot of all time, this is slightly ridiculous. Every time I want to indulge and have the best sushi god created I come here. Omakase. Hands down. All day. Every day. If it was just me I'd probably eat up the bill until it reaches $500 because their Omakase is charged per piece/eat until you're full-style. The chefs are really friendly and they cater to what you want to try as well. I love you Akikos. T_T
author: Fiona W.

description: Tried this place with a friend per his recommendation and I was not disappointed. Only tried a few things but they're were great. Main highlight would be the uni sampler, which was delicious.  It's a very small shop with no sign, so it can be difficult to find while walking by. I will say it is very pricy though.
author: Matthew B.

description:
What really stands out from all the other similar Nigiri/omakase Japanese restaurants in the city was their "A5 Wagyu" the taste was amazing, the cuts was thick enough to taste it's A5 grades. 

We ordered nigiri from the a la carte, they go by 2pc per order. price for the quality are worth it. I didn't get since they use expensive red sushi rice vinegar why does their rice for sushi was on the low quality side? 

Hamachi kama was extremely tender...A+
Gindara, it didn't cooked well or marinated well, but the miso aka su reduction sauce was tasty C

But over all, the experience was professional & attentive.
author: Le Chef

description: This is my goto every time I visit San Fran. Thoroughly enjoy the omakase at the sushi bar. Alex is my favourite chef. He is amazing!
author: Victor H.

description: Best sushi I have ever experienced.  Get a seat at the sushi bar and watch Roger work his magic! A word to the wise, be brave and let the chefs guide you through the selection of fish, you won't regret it.
author: Roger S.

description:
You definitely get what you pay for in terms of quality not quantity. I came here during lunch with a friend and had a wonderful culinary experience. 
I ate all their sashimi options. Yum! 
Service was a little slow but very helpful and nice. When I've got money to blow I'll go here. 

Parking is simple when you head straight to the garage near by. Just call and ask where!
author: Ariadna C.

description: Undoubtedly our favorite place to eat in all of California. Honestly - it's my wife's favorite restaurant in the US. We always sit with Allen. He's a great waiter. We don't even order. We just tell Allen to bring us whatever. We want to try everything. Allen puts together an amazing sushi meal for us and just keeps the food and drinks coming. 2.5 hours later - we're stuffed and walking back to the hotel with one of the most amazing dinner experiences one could possibly have hoped for. I could recommend this place more highly. We brought friends from Chicago this time to share in the experience. This place is a must. Ask for Allen.
author: Jack C.

description:
The last few weekends have been all about sushi for us.  We have been to Koo in the Sunset 3 times, our No. 1 favorite sushi restaurant for years.  We love you Koo!  And then we went to the beautiful Wako, a new, small sushi place on Clement.  Last weekend we went to Kusakabe which is also new.   It is a kaiseki style restaurant that we just adored.  Elegant dining with a emphasis on great fish.

Then last night we returned to Akiko on Bush.  I have to say it was really a great night!  Before we got there I had decided to try at least 1 of their cooked dishes but then as we ate one incredible fish after another, I realized I was enjoying all the nigiri too much to stray.

We sat with Chef Geoff again and he thrilled us with his omakase!  LOL.  We started with amber jack and a succulent Hokkaido scallop.  It always best to start with really good fish and we did!  But it was at the 3rd bite where he had us.  It was a tasty bite of Japanese Blue snapper, aodai, with a salted cherry leaf.  It was really blue too!  LOL.  We loved it. And we loved how different it was.  My husband and I glanced at each other with the nod and we knew we were in for a great evening.

In fact much of what we had was so different.  Some were served cold, some were warm, all were put together with a twist.  Such interesting blends of flavors yet you could taste the so fresh fish.  Really gourmet sushi.

Maybe the best all night was their house cured Ikura cups.  Not only were they so dramatic looking they were genius.  I will be dreaming of them for weeks.  The so fresh ikura was salty with the eggs just popping in my mouth. They cure the eggs in concentrated dashi and truffles.  But then they smother the ikura in shaved frozen ankimo.  This piled high savory confection was so creamy rich yet so light; oddly it did not taste that cold.  They freeze the ankimo in a "super" freezer (one of only 2 in California) at 82 degrees below zero and then grate it into an airy pile.  You have to eat it before the ankimo starts to melt.  LOL This over the salty eggs was just perfection

Also a delight was a spoonful of Hokkaido crab mixed with miso butter and lightly seared.  So good.  We had 2 kinds of uni, the first Hokkaido little yellow tongues and then later Russian uni.  Both great and so mild.

After 16 pieces of nigiri, I cried UNCLE!  I could eat no more.  I was way too full and stayed like that till I went to bed. My husband on the other hand felt we should have had more!  LOL 

We ended the night with a really big piece of A5 wagyu which was piled high with shaved truffles.  I think this is Akiko's signature finish.  And a perfect finish it is!
author: Kell M.

description: Great and amazing Fancy Gourmet Sushi.  Gary Danko of Japanese Food.  Fantastic Service!!  The combination of the meal with best tasting Sake is phenomenal.  The service is amazing.  I highly recommend this restaurant. A bit pricey compare to any sushi restaurant, but worth every bite.  A great place to celebrate a special occassion.
author: Beth S.

description: Food was mediocre. Service was outrageous. We asked the girl with the smokey eyes what we should get and she was reluctant to answer. Service throughout was horrible and she simply looked like she didn't want to be there. Won't be coming back that's for sure ;)
author: Roro B.

description:
One of the best sushi and sashimi experiences in SF. Came here for a friend's bday and it had the perfect ambiance for a small, intimate setting and excellent service.

We ordered the omakase and truly enjoyed each dish and experience topped off wagu beef that I'm still dreaming about!

All the nigiri/sashimi was super tasty and fresh! 

Also, I brought in a couple desserts for the birthday girl and not only did they NOT charge a fee for outside desserts but they even plated them beautifully for us!!! This really is the perfect place for special occasions- highly recommend!
author: Kimberly W.

description:
Trendy place in union square. 

Monkfish liver nigiri is so fresh and it's like melting in your mouth. Highly recommended. $8.5. 

Tekka is also delicious! Got avocado and tuna inside. The crispy soft crab inside is nice touch. Enjoy it a lot. They had a mistake and gave us another order of the same. 

Ika - we ordered fried squid but cannot wait until it comes we already feel very full cuz of the duplicate order of Tekka.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Definitely a $$$ !!!
Unless you're versed enough in Japanese gastronomy to appreciate a $10 sushi I wouldn't recommend this place. We spent $50 each and waited waaaay too long for raw fish to leave the restaurant hungrier than we entered it.
author: Hugo F.

description:
We had a large quantity of ngiri sushi and it was all top notch.  We just told the waiter to keep it coming at his choice.  Word from several sushi enthusiasts is that this is the best sushi they've had.  The highlight of the evening was the last thing they brought out.  It was one of the only rolls we had for the night.  Eating each piece was like a little journey.  The flavors kept getting more interesting and delicious as you chewed.  There was a slight lemon tinge and they best description was that it felt fresh.  It was one of the best things I've EVER eaten.  

We asked the name of the roll and appropriately it was named the Akiko roll.
author: Sammy O.

description:
I came at the dinner opening without a reservation and was able to be seated right away. I would recommend booking ahead though, they filled up fast and we were lucky to get a table.

For dinner we ordered the tamago, spider, tekka and negihama rolls. The fish was very fresh! Very delicious. We also got the ika - which was fried squid. It was incredible, crunchy without being overly greasy. They have mochi available for dessert, and we tried the black sesame. It was perfect, not too sweet and great texture. Overall was a very pleasant dinner!
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Great service, small quaint restaurant that has amazing rolls! The spicy tuna is extra spicy :)
Love the vibe and the uni is to die for
author: Alice P.

description: I think I made a mistake not going for omakase. I got sashimi platter which was very fresh but nothing stood out. Then I asked the chef to make me one nigiri and so he did! $13.5 for one piece of nigiri!!! Are you kidding me? I even don't pay this much for this little piece of food in 3 Michelin star restaurants! It tasted good though but I totally feel ripped off!
author: Tina Z.

description:
Definitely a hidden gem! When there's no name on the restaurant, but it still continues to be fully booked, you know you've come to the right spot.

Thank you Yelp for helping me find Akiko's. We lucked out and were standing and waiting at the door right when they opened.  We were lucky enough to get a table but I noticed that time and time again, they were turning people away because they were fully booked. So definitely make a reservation!

We opted for omakase on this trip and it did not disappoint. The server started off by asking about food allergies and of course our likes and dislikes. First couple of dishes were definitely "starters".  I won't even begin to try and list everything we had, because there's no way that I can even remember. First dish was spinach with an amazing sauce. Also had a scallop and cucumber salad - everything else after that is just a blur. There were only a few items that came on rice but either way, everything was fantastic. One of the hubby's favorites was what they described as "the foie gras of the sea". 

The hubby also decided to have the server pair sake for him with dinner.  He had 3 different sakes ranging in price from $10 a glass to $13. 

The service was fantastic. Our water was never half empty, our dishes were constantly changed out, the table was always being tidied up - in addition to all that, every server was knowledgable and provided great suggestions.

Being that it's sushi and omakase, I wasn't surprised to see our bill... before tip it was $250 (yikes!!). So, be warned, definitely pricey - but definitely in the top handful of sushi places I've ever been. There were a couple of pieces that we had where it was $10 per piece! But hey, you get what you pay for. 

...buuuut we did leave and get a little snack before heading to bed. 

Would I go back? Definitely - but not too often or I'll be in the poor house!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Get the Russian uni! It's heaven on a spoon. 
Great sushi restaurant! Staff and chef is friendly and the ambience is modern.
author: Katie N.

description: I had the most amazing omakase at Akikos tonight. The fish was super fresh and each piece was crafted with simple ingredients that made each bite exquisite. I have eaten omakase at Micheline star restaurants but this far exceeded my previous experiences. Will definitely be back.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
SASHIMI Heaven!

The restaurant is quietly located at the top of union square on bush st. The restaurant doesn't take walk in so reservations are required, which is great because there won't be any wait to have some fantastic sushi here.

The restaurant appears small but there are table settings hidden away at the back. There is also bar seating available where the sushi chefs prepare their dishes.

FOOD: We ended up having the chef provide an assorted 20 piece sashimi combo. The potions were fresh and melted in your mouth. My favorite pieces were definitely the salmon and tuna belly.

Also if you want sake to drink, there is a brand called dewasasan. It's crisp sweet and refreshing.

Overall, I'll be coming back next time to try the other dishes the restaurant orders.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Get a reservation for bar seating, enjoy a delightful kaiseki style dinner with the wonderful chefs.

The omakase menu is updated on their website so there's no need to go into all the items and order that you'll be served, but it is absolutely the best fine-dining experience I have had so far! 

You will definitely notice the superbness of all the ingredients that are used, from the soy sauce to the toro. I did not find any of the items lackluster, every piece was a beautiful mix of flavors. A few of the new flavors I experienced here was the kelp konbu cha, a surprisingly sweet and buttery scallop, truffle with unagi wrapped in egg, and the zuke chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce). 

Another a la carte item I encourage people to try is the BBQ white eel. I found this very special since most of the unagi you will eat in your life is pre-packaged and frozen. The chefs at Kusakabe buy their own eel and prepare it themselves. Even the sauce is prepped in-house, eel-based. 

I can't stop thinking about the experience I had here, I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Do M.

description:
Akiko's Restaurant is by far the best sushi restaurant I have been to in a long time and is now my go to sushi place. The decor, ambiance, quality of the fish, skill of the chefs and professionalism/politeness of the owner and staff is astounding. Never have I been to a sushi place that serves fish of this quality and, on occasion, special rare types of fish.

Every bit of fish they serve is so soft, fresh and has so much flavor. Not only do they serve incredibly high quality fish but, if you're lucky, you may find yourself there on a night when they have certain rare items on the menu such as the Russian Uni and the Keiji Salmon. I have never been an Uni eater but Akiko's turned me around. Their Russian Uni, and even their other types which they have frequently are so creamy and tasty that anyone could love it. One night there I asked the chef for a creative dish using Uni. I was given a Uni nigiri with salmon roe, a quail egg yolk and grated ankimo on top, absolutely amazing.

Another favorite of mine was the Keiji Salmon, a $140/lb fish that is found in about 1 out of every 10,000 salmon that is caught and has a higher fat content than toro! I had a few pieces of this and they also fried up the head for me. Definitely the best salmon I have ever eaten and quite possibly the best fish in general. It was so amazingly soft with so much flavor, I barely even had to chew it. It was so good that I even came back the very next night for another round. 

One final thing you can always find there and is a must have is the A5 BMS10+ wagyu beef covered in sliced and shaved fresh truffle. A seared piece of only the highest grade beef covered with truffle slices and a mountain of shaved fresh truffle. Usually the last course you will have if you put yourself in the chefs hands and is absolutely incredible, and who doesn't like truffle?!?!

Akiko's is an amazing restaurant, one of the few where I am continually astounded every time I come, my only complaint is that they have completely ruined my palate and as such I am no longer interested in any of the other sushi places I use to frequent. Their quality of fish, amazing staff and skilled chefs (especially Ricky) makes this restaurant an incredible place to be. For the best experience, sit at the bar and put yourself entirely in the chefs hands, you will not be disappointed (unlike some other reviewers below me leaving 2 and 3 star reviews when all they ordered was a rainbow roll and some shrimp tempura), even when the bill comes at the end, if anything you'll just walk out wanting to come right back!
author: Ian P.

description:
Perfect! Ask for omakase and sit at the sushi bar! You wont regret!
I am amazed with every dish. They're pricer though, since they're made of only the best things. I am just crazy for all of them, especially the uni with crab fat on top roll!
author: Gofelin K.

description:
Probably the best Japanese restaurant I've been to. They serve the freshest sushi it's a party in your mouth. I can't remember much of the names of what we ate because it's all in Japanese, but I remember everything being so fresh and delicious. Ask your server what's fresh that day, and what he recommends and get that! It's really high quality and you'll taste the difference. 

My favorite is the uni with ankimo shavings on top. My top tip would be to ask your server what's fresh today. 

Also, good service in terms of attentiveness. However, you'll have to wait a while for York food, about 30 minutes. But the wait can't even persuade me to take off a star.
author: Rae C.

description: Cute little Japanese restaurant tucked away in FiDi. I was glad that I made a reservation ahead of time because they definitely got busy even on a weeknight! Reasonably priced menu with a pretty good selection and service. (Took away one star though for lack of dessert choice.) Would come back!
author: Mel L.

description:
I had a great omakase (chef's choice) around 120 USD 
Very well good selection, good products and chef 
Had better, but was great 

Great desert
author: Gal R.

description:
Best Omakase in town. Awesome variety of fish, with a fresh selection featuring the best of the season. Come here if you want the best. 

Btw this place is not cheap. It's definitely $$$$. Look elsewhere for a cheap sushi place.
author: TJ Y.

description:
This place is too expensive for pity food and slow service, at least on Mondays.

I gave a 2 star instead of 1 because their monk fish liver nigiri and wagyu with black truffle are delicious. But that's all the pros I can think of. Here comes the why-so-bad.

Since Akiko is so famous for its uni, we came on an empty stomach and with great expectation of uni. However, upon our arrival, we are informed there is NO UNI, NO TORO, NO ANYTHING FANCY! They don't even have broiled black cod. Because their supplies depend on shipments and deliveries doesn't come in on Mondays. THEN DON'T OPEN ON MONDAYS FOR GOD SAKE!

We started with sashimi. 1. They didn't ration according to party size, so we have to negotiate who eats what, who does not get to eat what. Great that's considerate of the chefs! 2. Their sashimi tasted like they have been sitting in air for too long: dry exterior!

Then, a 30 minute wait......... till the next set of nigiri. ARE YOU KIDDING ME! We basically sat there, and became hungry again. Then we started to munch on the ginger. It was like hell! During the 30 minute, the adjacent table paid a check; a new table came in, and got served TWICE!

So here come the nigiri, pretty mediocre, except the monk fish liver and wagyu, which probably stood out due to the mediocrity of everything else.

Yeah then we got some hot dish like agedashi tofu and hamachi collar, AFTER ANOTHER 30 MINUTES! Probably longer, we lost count. It's ironic that all of us feels the salad on the side of the hamachi collar is superb, peak of this pathetic dinner.

And this tormenting ongoing hunger got us a nearly $400 bill! With tip, we each paid $91. Oh damn I type with rage.

So whenever you think of coming, DON'T. Kusakabe, Maruya, Roka Akor... You name it. Anywhere with the same price level is so goooood in comparison to this one.
author: Jass C.

description: We stopped in for lunch before our flight back to Orange County. The food is good, service was attentive with clearing plates however, the hostess was rude upon our arrival and her attitude was cold. One of the sushi chef tended to us but the atmosphere was lukewarm. We tried a couple of nigiri (kanpachi, toro, ankimo), kani age, salmon roll, and the blue crab cucumber sunomono. It used to be one of my favorite lunch options when I worked in the City off Bush and Montgomery. I don't know if I'd come back here again.
author: Mika D.

description:
Omakase w/ Chef Ricky

Poki salad
Tasmanian ocean trout
Seared golden eye snapper
Santa Barbara uni (one w/ Hokkaido crab fat & one by itself)
E-Sake
Ankimo
Hokkaido uni preserved w/ salt water
Uni w/ uni pate
Chu-toro & kaime (Boston blue fin)
Negi-toro roll w/ very strong wasabi
Keiji salmon (dwarf salmon) 1 of 10,000 stops growing
A5 Bms10 Wagyu w/ shaved truffle

Amazing! This was yesterday. Back again today!
author: melanie t.

description:
Succulent, ultra-fresh fish draped over the best sushi rice I've ever tasted. 

While somewhat more expensive than most, this sushi restaurant is worth every penny. Tucked into a tight hallway tricked out with lavish wallpaper on one side and gritty exposed industrial brick on the other, it can be hard to hear your companion on a busy night. However, that won't matter much because your mouths will be too full of scrumptious, pristine nigiri and sublimely tweaked versions of classic rolls to bother with conversation. The "kitchen" selection of cooked items offers the fanciest, yummiest battered fried squid and dreamy crispy fried sardines.

The specials menu features rarer versions of standard offerings (here you can find smoked mackerel rather than the usual vinegar cured stuff), plus treats like young barracuda and sea urchin.

Attentive servers make helpful recommendations, & keep wine/sake/beer/water glasses filled.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Sian K.

description:
After reading all of the reviews, I was excited about treating ourselves to the omakase at Akikos for our anniversary.  We were not expecting Tsukiji Market deliciousness but were looking forward to what many have said to be one of the best sushi experiences here in SF.  

Unfortunately, the only thing we experienced was disappointment.  I made the reservation through Opentable and noted that this was for our anniversary.  We arrived a few minutes before the reservation and the table was ready and in the front which was nice as it was more private and probably had the best view (street).  

The food:
The sashimi was definitely fresh, buttery, and delicious - included some favorites like blue fin tuna, yellow tail belly, and mackerel.  And there were a few solid sushi dishes (uni) served as part of the omakase but there were also misses.  Don't get me wrong, none were bad but some were just meh and definitely not worth the price paid.

The service:
Good attentive service - quick to clear, explain dishes, refill water, adjust menu to tastes, etc but the service was slow and not fluid.  There was a 20-30 minute break mid way through the service.  Also nothing was done to make it feel special (as we noted it was an anniversary) - not even a "Happy Anniversary".  I am assuming the table assignment was their only contribution?  But that have been just luck.  Places like N/Naka or Craft in LA may have ruined it for us - they go out of their way to make the experience memorable.

At about $130 per person (no alcohol), I was not impressed.  The sashimi was the only redeeming part of the experience and the only reason I would consider going back.  But the slow service, unimaginative dishes, and lack of a truly unique dining experience will probably have me trying the other options in the Bay Area or going for the budget (but good) sushi restaurants.
author: Roy L.

description: Such a wonderful dining experience! My friend is a sushi master, he basically tried all Top 10 sushi places in SF and took me to Akiko. Since my stomach can't digest rice,so every sushi pieces I had was in sashimi only. The Kobe beef was a must try. Seasoned with aged soy sauce and dipped in egg yolk, and finally rolled together with Japan-imported seaweed ($1 per slice according to the chef). One taste you would never forget. I tried all kinds of oily fish they had that night and they were all heavenly tasty. Also three kinds of uni, two from Japan and one from Russia. I was even licking the spoon after finishing my bite. Five stars for sure.
author: Alice Q.

description:
I really love the atmosphere, very low key but a quite comfortable setting. The waiters are very nice as well.

Fish is superb here. We tried amaebi, scallop, uni, unagi, sweet fish, etc. All of them are fresh and the rice is in the right portion. Their yakimono beef is phenomenal, juicy and tender. A must try!

Would definitely want to come back for a third time! Tip: make reservation ahead!
author: Olivia H.

description:
Probably the best high end sushi you can get in the city for this price. There may be better spots, but not at this price range in the city. You are getting a good deal for the quality.

Sit at the bar. You will be restricted from the kitchen dishes, but that shouldn't be why your here. I always get the hotate (scallop). Come for lunch and get the shiro toro (white tuna belly) -- they'll run out by dinner time.

If you're a sake/maguro (salmon/tuna) type of sushi eater--like most American sushi eaters start out to be--get out of your comfort zone and try the omakase to get exposed to the good stuff. This is the place to do it without burning your wallet. 

Also, the wagyu nigiri always blows newcomers away. If you've never had this extremely marbled meat, you must get it.
author: Steffie H.

description: Great food, great chefs, great staff. Price is not bad for what you get.  The food is super fresh, i dont think i have had a better nigiri before. Def. commanded
author: T K.

description: Four of us came here for a work lunch. We shared the rainbow roll, 49er roll, veggie tempura, tofu, 24 pieces of sashimi, and two orders of uni negeri. The fish here is so fresh. We were all raving about how this is some of the best sushi that we've ever tried. The services here is a bit slow, but the waiters do their jobs very well. The restaurant is pretty small so definitely make a reservation ahead of time.
author: Alice W.

description: Most of the fish comes from Japan.  The place is very small. The service is not that good but the food is definitely solid.  I would definitely go there again.  It's not cheap but it's well worth money.
author: Rahadian G.

description:
The boyfriend took me here for my birthday dinner last July. From the outside, it looked like your ordinary sushi restaurant. Which made me almost mad that he took me here when we could have just went to our usual go-to spot. 

But once I sat down and saw the menu, I knew why. It's pricier than your typical sushi restaurants. But the price is really what you pay for. We ordered tuna sashimi and it tasted so fresh. It didn't taste frozen and thawed fish. But literally tasted like the sushi chef had just cut off the fresh flesh from a tuna he caught hours before the restaurant opened.

Besides the sashimi, we also ordered the spider roll (very tasty, soft shell crab was crisp and not soggy), and the ika (calamri). The ika was my favorite. It was so addicting to eat, especially with my saporro.

We also ordered the uni but the server said they had run out. Which was a bummer because we've never had uni before and wanted to see what all the fuss was about. Instead, our server recommended we tried the wagyu. And we were really glad we did. That was probably our favorite thing we ate all night. The beef was so tender and left your mouth salivating for more.

Overall a good experience. Staff was very friendly. Place was very clean. It is tiny and can be arm to arm with the table next to you. But very intimate for a special date.
author: Liezel D.

description:
I've had consistently good experiences here. I usually sit at the bar and order omakase. So many choices. Stuff you don't find outside of Tokyo. Well prepared in an understated but elegant setting. 

The chefs do a good job of understanding what's out of bounds for you. Tell them what you like and don't like. Have an open mind. 

I do find that the service disappears at times. This might be because I'm at the bar. They do need to be more attentive to your drink level. However it's not enough for me to knock it down a star.  

Make a reservation. It fills up fast.
author: Eric D.

description:
Akiko's is some of the best sushi I have ever had. While the prices are high, this is as good as it gets in SF. Be warned, this is not a "$$" restaurant. This at least a "$$$"

I went with a friend for their famous Okasama and was not let down. The sushi was high quality, fresh, and melted in my mouth.

Be sure to make a reservation and enjoy!
author: Travis M.

description: Whoooooo-weeeee. I love akikos. The food is soooooooo damn good. I made reservations like a month ahead of time and it's sooooo worth it. When I got there they tried to seat as the very corner near the entrance and it was a horrible spot, so I was like nuh uh. This is a no go. So we waited another 15-20 minutes to get a seat inside the restaurant and it so worth it. Btw if you're all about the experience you should request a bar seat. I think watching people make my sushi is quite an experience. Anyways we got seated and ordered the omakase. I highly recommend anyone going to akikos for the first time to order omakase. It's basically the chefs choice and its damn near 12 plates of perfection. Every dish was at the very least a 8/10 dish. I'll be honest going through the whole Omakase did not get me all the way full though so be prepared to order a few more dishes or eat a bigger lunch. Overall the meal was about $380+ for two but it was sooooo worth it. Highly recommended.
author: Jennifer P.
Jie M.

description:
It's a tough challenge trying to explain to well traveled sushi eaters why we don't have world class Tokyo Ginza style sushi in SF Bay Area. 

To me the answers are obvious. Some of it boils down to lack of demand, and lack of talent, and even though people know about ordering omakase, the general level of sushi eating knowledge is actually not as high as that of other cities for destination sushi stops (e.g. LA and NY). Plus, not many of us have money coming out of our cornholio$ to be able to afford such supreme luxuries.

Too many "enthusiasts" got pumped up after seeing Jiro Dreams of Sushi, then proceed to go to places like Ino Sushi to show off their knowledge. Particularly guys of a certain ilk, to impress their Asian girlfriends. e.g. I witnessed some doofus next to me at Ino telling his Korean gal that he Googled SF for the best sushi in town, and told her "yeah right here, Uni sushi", to which she replied "uhh, it's INO Sushi". I almost choked on my nigiri. Surprised Ino didn't kick his a$$ out.

The original owners of Akiko's handed the reins down to their son, who then decided to take things a different direction some years back. Suddenly the chefs are different. The vibe seems swanky, friendly to non Japanese, and the fish is SUPER DUPER HIGH END EXOTIC! 

Afraid of Ino, but want fish quality on the level of LA or NY's finest where you do not have to speak a lick of Japanese, but don't want to have to fight with Alice Waters or Chris Cosentino for a coveted bar seat at Sebo? Well then Akiko's is the place. 

This might just be the best we have in SF (to compete with NY & LA).

Get a reservation at the bar. If it is your 1st time, bring a credit card with a high limit, or a very thick wallet stuffed with a couple Benji's. Primo seafood of the highest exotic caliber, costs a pretty 24k gold penny and it's downtown where tourists run amok. You can take the reins yourself or you can just have the chef decide (omakase) which you may want to see the daily specials exotic fish they have (try not to faint when you see the price$). 

From 6/28, one piece nigiri each

-Kuro maguro (akami Bluefin from Nagasaki prefecture). On par with the Kyushu Bluefin I had in Hong Kong. Meaty dorsal cut.

-Wild Copper River King salmon. I try not to eat farmed salmon as sushi, but very hard to resist America's wild finest .

-Kamasu (Barracuda from Mie Prefecture)

-Aodai (Blue snapper from JP). Pristine white fish.

-Shiro Toro (albacore belly). Does not taste like albacore. Beautiful knife cuts.

-Ayu (sweetfish / river trout). Very unusual to have this as sushi. For shioyaki, get it at Sumika Los Altos. Quite excellent.

-Hamachi belly (sunazuri). Shaved lime zest a nice touch on top.

-Matsukawa Karei (flounder from Hokkaido prefecture), served with its seared fin (engawa) on top. Sexcellent.

- Ensuii uni (unprocessed Hokkaido sea urchin kept in its original saltwater). "A spoonful of sea butta, makes the medicine go down....la de da"

-Nama hotate (overnighted fresh Hokkaido scallop, never frozen). True original scallop flavor. This is what the ocean "tastes like". A light brush of preseasoned soy and a tiny pinch of sea salt does the job.

-Ji Kinmedai (single pole line caught alfosino from Chiba prefecture, cold smoked and light seared with a special salt on top / Moshio). Very very nice take on this fish.

-Black Imperial Shrimp / Kuruma ebi from Hokkaido prefecture (fried head, raw body). The fried head tastes like freshly fried shrimp chips from Indonesia (the good stuff). Haven't had a wild shrimp with intense flavor like this in aeon$. So good.

-Kuro maguro chu toro (medium fatty tuna). Sublime. Umami indeed.

-Hatsu Katsuo (spring bonito / Skipjack from Chiba prefecture). Great, would have preferred a bit more garlic on top.

-Kihata (Yellow Grouper from Nagasaki prefecture). Daikon oroshi infused with yuzu juice, thin slivers of shiso/perilla leaf. Very interesting.

-Aka Mutsu (red fish, light sear, ponzu, shio, fish liver from Chiba Prefecture). Very tasty. I love Japanese white fish.

-Nagasaki Prefecture seared Bluefin (meat near eye socket) with Santa Barbara uni on top. It's like a ménage a trois (or 3P as they call it in China or Taiwan).  

- Russian "Tokujyo" uni from Kaigara island. This is the high end caviar of uni. Some think it's not worth it, but it's subjective. 

- A5 Miyazaki Wagyu (high end Japanese beef) seared with shaved French Black Winter truffles on top. One ounce of thinly sliced fatty marbled J-beef seared on one side, rolled up, and truffles shaved on top of it. It's like sending Anna Chapman over to Edward Snowden in a Ferrari to live in an underground castle with an unlimited supply of blow.

I prefer Ino's rice a lot more, but the fish here is undisputed (comparable to Sushi Ta-Ke and Sushi Mori in Hong Kong even!). 

An expensive "happy ending", but treat yourself! You only live once, YOLO or some BS like that?
author: Ken K.

description: this place isnt as good as i remembered it! super sad face.  akiko's is definitely the best sushi downtown / fidi area (maybe with the exception of Pabu). came here for lunch last week and ordered lots of nigiri, the spider roll, and a lunch combo with tempura (you get 4 nigiri and miso soup so it's a really good deal.. but the service was really cold, and the fish i thought was average quality?! favorite was probably the ankimo and sake... WAH! probably wont be coming back for a while..
author: Christina L.

description: 2 dollar signs my ass!! This is a review for the price as Yelp says $$, but it ended costing us $460 dollars between 4 people with alcohol. Food was good quality but not worth the price. Didn't even leave stuffed. My friend had to get pizza after...
author: Bryant L.

description: Horrible service don't bother! Came here at 615 just me looking to sit at the bar; place was half full plenty of seats at the bar and they told me I could sit till 7 when they had reservations. What!! Don't bother the hostess was also pretty snooty about it
author: Michele D.

description:
I would like to give Akiko 4.5 stars because the sushi here is very good.  Extremely fresh.  Served at the right temperature.  Most places will put most of your order on one plate and bring it out.  What ends up happening is that the fish gets warm while all of that sushi is being made.  Akiko brings out your order course at a time.  That means you get the sashimi or roll or whatever you order pretty much right after the chef slices and plates the dish.  

The chefs are also quite thoughtful with how the dish is seasoned.  Two different house made soy sauces are offered.  One for Sashimi which is a lighter flavor and one for rolls which has a darker richer soy taste.  Most places give you soy that overpowers the sashimi.  The veg and salads are thoughtfully sauced and presented.  The blanched spinach is particularly good.  

Service is very friendly and knowledgeable.  They are willing to offer their opinion about what is good and will tell you good detail on how its prepared.  

They also have a menu of fish of the day from all parts of the world if you wish to explore and spend a bit of money.  

Pretty much everything I had was good and I got to eat some new fish.  Barracuda anyone?  (Super good BTW, but leave it to the pros to prepare, it can be poisonous).

I do wish they had some rolls and appetizers that were a bit more creative.  From what I did eat, I think the talent is there to make some interesting appetizers or seasoned rolls.  I am not looking for a massive menu, just a few more dishes perhaps as specials that showcases the creativity,  That is a pretty high bar, I know, but this place is not cheap.  Without alcohol we came close to $100 pp.  At that price level, I would expect to see a bit more of the chef's personality on the plate.  So 4.5 stars is what I would say is good for this place.
author: Scott C.

description:
I'm a fan of Akiko's but if you go on a Monday night, be forewarned that they may be out of half of the items on their menu.  This was the case on a recent visit...

It seemed that every other item my friend and I wanted to order was 86'd.  From the spider roll to tempura shrimp, a couple of other nigiri, and every dessert.  My friend is gluten free, so considering the limited selection, it was difficult for her to find enough to eat.  I will say that our waiter (who may have been the owner), was patient and helpful in trying to help her out.  

We ended up with edamame to share, salads (hers with a special dressing), she had a couple of special rolls and I had a scallop handroll, a rainbow roll, and a Rock N' Roll.  (Yes, I was very hungry!)  The service was a bit on the slow side, but we were fine with that as we had a lot of catching up to do and didn't mind a leisurely meal.  I had to remind our waiter about my last roll though.  It was all delicious and quality.

The restaurant is conveniently located and quiet, moderately priced for SF sushi, and despite the limited menu we had to choose from, I would return in the future.  Happy sushi eating!
author: Gabi M.

description: Best sushi in town! I've come here so many times I lost count. The only problem is that I can't get a reservation whenever I want to. Tip: ask for the special Akiko roll that is not on the menu.
author: Alberto T.

description:
This place is NOT easy to find.

A client and I walked up and down Bush St., looking for Akikos, but only found Subway and an Irish Pub. Where IS this place? I checked the address and it turns out that Akikos would be a great location for sushi entering the witness protection program; I was standing right in front of it!

The entrance to Akikos is below the sign for the Irish Pub and there is not a sign in sight depicting proximity to Japanese cuisine! 

After peering through the window, I was able to determine that numerous people eating rice-clad dishes with chopsticks was probably, in reality, NOT something I would find in an Irish pub, so I walked in.

Instantly, the ambiance awakened my taste buds. The décor was simple, but attractive and comfortable. The sushi bar takes up the bulk of the tiny establishment's dining space, but the back dining room has a very cozy, warm feel.

The hostess is sweet, attentive, accommodating, friendly, and always smiling. I love it when customer service includes status updates to ensure your expectations are met. The hostess did just that. We were waiting for a table for about 15 minutes and she offered us beverages, review of the menu, and conversation about the restaurant while we waited. She also kept us very informed about the patrons who were supposed to vacate the table we were waiting for. Basically, she set the tone for a great experience.

We had yellow-tail hamachi, a variety of nigiri, warm edamame, a few tuna rolls (I did NOT like the "burnt sesame" flavor they deliberately put on those rolls. It was a hostile-palate-takeover), and chicken with rice. The food was nowhere near the caliber of Japonessa in Seattle, but it was good enough that we went back a second time within the same week. Unfortunately, the second time wasn't quite as good as the first, but it was still decent. The fish didn't taste as fresh as it did on our previous visit and there was a pool of water at the bottom of my bowl of Hamachi, which (no surprise) tasted recently-thawed or watered-down.

Still, if I'm craving sushi during lunch time, I will head back to Akikos. They seem to be the best option in the area and the ambience is nice and relaxing for a quick lunch get-away. Reservations are REQUIRED, especially between 11:30am - 1:00pm.
author: Heather A.

description:
I know the story of Akiko's restaurant and I ate there 8 yrs ago. 
LAST NIGHT it was a MEMORABLE experience !
I am a trained chef in Japanese cuisine and I eat Sushi all over The Bay. 
I tried 3 rolls and all three were amazing. The balance of flavors and the proportion was the closest to perfection. Until the last part of the bite went to my stomach, I could savor all the different elements. That is precious. 
I tried two different Hotate and both amazing. The one from Okkaido made me feel back in Tokyo years ago. 
California Uni excellent. Ikura had a very personal marinade. 
A White Fish was over priced. 
The 49rs blew my mind for the above mentioned reason = Best ever !!!
author: Bruno S.

description: Really didn't live up to the hype. I've been to hundreds of sushi places, all over the world, and this falls in the lower quartile. The black maguro sashimi ($32) was the only good thing, albeit meager portions.
author: Ian R.

description:
Akiko Restaurant offered a tasting plate at the Plate by Plate event in SF this past weekend. It was the best plate there!! 

They offered scallop and uni on a crunchy nori, it was DIVINE. It's all in the details!! The servers were so generous and kind to offer such an awesome dish for such a great cause! 

I'm definitely a fan and will be visiting very very soon!
author: Cecilia N.

description: Quite pricey and portions are super small. MAKE SURE to make a reservation like a couple days ahead to ensure yourself a spot. Perfect little spot to take your date for sushi. Very fresh fish!! Don't go here when you are like starving status! Once again, the portions are SMALL! The place itself is SMALL. Even the tables are small, so if you don't like random strangers sitting too close to you, this is not the place for you, buddy.
author: Katy W.

description:
I had high hopes for delicious sushi in San Francisco. We came here on our honeymoon and the restaurant knew it was our first meal on our trip. 
There were many items we wanted that were unavailable, like avocado. Not really sure how a sushi place in a huge city runs out of avocado. The service was unremarkable - the waiter seemed harried even though it was a quiet Monday evening. Bummer.
author: Mo F.

description:
I brought my Japanese mother here for lunch. She ordered the moriwase which was 6 pieces of sushi. She ate 2 pieces and said it didn't taste good. I ordered the sashimi and tempura lunch but was served sushi and tempura.

The quality of the fish is excellent. The proportion of rice to fish was correct ( able to eat it in one bite). The rice under some fish was brown which horrified my purist mother. The texture of the rice was good.

The tempura was tasteless under a heavy batter. The pieces were all HUGE and generally unidentifiable. The pieces at the bottom of the stack were soggy. I could see the blotting paper was saturated with oil.

Service was ok but generally lackluster. Come for the fish but stay away if you're a purist. The food was disappointing.
author: Michele K.

description: I didn't have much time (and money) when I visited, so I just ordered 2 makis as dinner, which are delicious. I think the best way to dine here is probably ask the chef to recommend some sashimi or nigiri, which however will be more expensive than $$.
author: Yow-Bang W.

description:
I truly wanted to fall in love with this place, since most of the reviews were so good! Also the pictures looked amazing. But sadly I was EXTREMELY disappointed with the food and service. 

My boyfriend made reservations for my birthday while we were in SF, he put in as a note that it was my birthday. (Nothing special was done, so just a little pointer for everyone, don't waste your time writing in the little comment box, they don't pay attention)

The food: HORRIBLE!!!! If I had to choose between Akikos and take out sushi shops, I would so choose the take out sushi shop. The quality of the fish was hard to swallow, literally I was having the hardest time, The sake was the only thing helping me to swallow the horrible food.

The service, nothing to do with our server, he was very nice. But I think just how long it took them to bring out the food was horrible... I know we ordered the omakase but it was VERY long for each dish to come out (way too long for a birthday girl to wait) and as the minutes went by I felt sicker and sicker from the food. 

I really did want to like this restaurant so much. But for the quality and the price we paid. Heck no. We def got ripped off. I would never come back and pay $300 plus for their omakase again! 

Never again going to Akikos......Unless I wanna throw up.
author: Kayla R.

description:
I've finally gotten around to writing a review for Akiko's after my third visit last night. Each experience has been just as amazing as the last! Always on the search for authentic Japanese food, especially fresh sashimi, I always know I am getting quality ingredients here. 

They have a variety of unique rolls, and all of them are different in some way. The volcano roll is no longer on the dinner menu, but it is one of the most unique rolls I've ever had. The Forty-Niner roll is one of my new favorites, with a shrimp tempura roll topped with salmon sashimi and the most thinly sliced lemon. That little extra lemon zest on top of the salmon made for the perfect bite, and added something that a lot of rolls don't have. 

All of the raw fish that they have to offer is amazing. I recommend ordering a dish in which you can get a good sampling of the different variety. My favorite is always some kind of salmon, but their toro is also great. The hamachi kama seems to have gotten a bigger portion size, but the fish is grilled perfectly and paired with a fresh salad and pickled vegetables. The ponzu dipping sauce adds a nice acidity to the moist, buttery fish. Even the skin is grilled to a crispness that makes you devour the entire thing down to the bone. 

The dining experience at Akiko's will not disappoint, and if you're willing to pay for high quality food, then this is the place to go to again and again.
author: Ashley T.

description: With so many raved reviews , I decided to try it during lunch time. Had the 12 piece chef special for $32 with tofu and edamame and the bill was like $50. I didn't think it was worth it. The quality of fish was ok, didn't like the white tuna. Only thing I really enjoyed was the salmon. Other than that, for the price I can get elsewhere with same or better quality.
author: Nhung T.

description: Outstanding sushi!!! Quiet little place. High quality sashimi. Everything was made with great, high quality ingredients - shrimp tempura roll to the Calamari, everything was amazing.  Service was great and super helpful.
author: G V.

description:
***EXCEPTIONAL SUSHI HOUSE***
***HIGH QUALITY FISH & UNIQUE DISHES***

I have been here twice.  Once for dinner a few months ago and just today for lunch, around 1pm.  There was a 3-5 minute wait for a seat at the sushi bar because the restaurant was busy. 

The service does not even need mention.  It is exactly the type you would expect at a higher end sushi house. 

I highly recommend the Sake Avocado roll ($7).  It is a very simple roll with a spicy green sauce on top (just a little) and what appears to be some type of ground nut.  It's like nothing I've ever had before. 

I also recommend the Hara Sake Sashimi ($16).  Simple fresh salmon sashimi. That's it. 

The shrimp/scallion gyoza ($6) is a good value and tasty but didn't stand out to me. 

You will find my favorite sake here, a nigori called Sayuri.  At $32 a bottle, I'd stick with a single serving ($6) for the first time.  Try it with a squeeze of fresh lemon.
author: Ravi M.

description: So good at lunch yesterday I went again today for super. Absolutely amazing sushi. Not too loud inside and fairly priced for the top quality
author: Ian V.

description: Excellent. Had a quick lunch there, Sashimi all the way, fantastically fresh, great staff, beautiful restaurant.
author: Neil O.

description: Got 4 tiny pieces of fish for $37. Location is convenient. Good music. Quite speedy service.
author: Rusty S.

description: Love the food here. The fish is super fresh. They get very busy often, so it's highly recommended to make a reservation.
author: Julie D.

description: Awesome sushi and the uni was on point for lunch.  Wish they took walk ins though.
author: Jay H.

description:
This is the most amazing sushi I have had in San Francisco!  Excellent!
Some favorites: Golden Eye Tai.  Toro, Uni from Hokkaido and North of Hokkaido.  Everything.  Just ask for omakase.  Can't wait to come back for dinner.  Make a reservation!
author: Betty L.

description:
Had another wonderful experience on 5/22 for dinner--a double date night with our foodie BFFs. We had omakase, which didn't disappoint. We loved the selection of cold, hot, sashimi and nigiri. 

Bill was appx $350 per couple (included a couple of rounds of sake), tax and tip. We weren't surprised by this as we know how omakase pricing works. 

Our server, Ryan, was great! So personable, knowledgeable and attentive.
author: Ali A.

description: Why do I always leave piss drunk after leaving this establishment? I have had some of the most memorable dinners at this place. Dined here 10+ times and each time totally killed my wallet. The sushi chefs just keep going and going then you get your surprise bill at the end. There are a few omakase pieces that I dislike but everything else is superb. The wagyu is heavenly and absolutely melts in your mouth. Totally worth it and this place is one of my top 3!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Despite the evident popularity of their Volcano Roll, this isn't where you go to get mayo-laden, fried, sauce-heavy maki rolls. Sitting at the sushi bar, I quickly discovered that they have been moving away from this Americanized version of the Japanese cuisine toward simply showcasing amazing fish. 

While I can appreciate what we've done with sushi in this country (when it's done well), sometimes you just need something clean and simple. And after a week of binging on pork, all I wanted was that. The mixed green salad and the 6-piece nigiri tasting couldn't have been better for the situation. 

The salad is light, and fresh, with cucumbers adding a bit of texture. The avocado is well-seasoned, and the soy-ginger dressing delicious enough that I want the recipe. 

The nigiri was nearly impeccable; generous portions of buttery, clean fish, it was the absolute antithesis of everything I'd been consuming for the past week...and yet, just as delicious. 

I left thoroughly satisfied, and only having embarrassed myself with fish hanging out of my mouth once.
author: Peter D.

description:
Honestly some of the best sashimi in the city. 

Even got my mom to enjoy veggie tempura that tasted light, crispy and refreshing.

Will be coming back again and again!
author: Emily D.

description: If you're looking for the true Japanese experience, this is the place. Small and intimate and amazing attention to detail and quality. My favourite.
author: Fredrick L.

description: Good service on this tiny sushi place. A much wider variety of fish than I've ever had before but each piece costs $6+ so after spending $150, the two of us left hungry.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I loved the energy of Akiko from the moment I walked through the door. It's a tiny spot so be sure to make a reservation unless you want to sit at the bar. 

We were a group of 5 and were seated immediately. We ordered some edamame and shishito peppers for the table. I ordered the volcano roll but asked for it without salmon skin and they were very happy to accommodate (yay for restaurants that accommodate!). 

The volcano roll was awesome! It came in a big bowl and was covered in the most delicious tempura flakes! Spicy salmon was wrapped with avocado, scallion and toasted sesame. 

They are not getting 5 stars because our waiter was a little brusque and service a little slow. But overall a great meal and I would definitely return!
author: Brittany F.

description:
My sushi obsession is at an all time high so I was on the hunt for a "best of the best" restaurant to get my fix. After searching, Akikos seemed a good choice as a top tier sushi place without the formality of some of the other options. Needless to say I left deflated. 
     The reviews insisted a reservation was necessary so I procured mine and waited anxiously for a week to be slapped in the face by the sushi gods. Also from the reviews, I imagined being overwhelmed by amazing service and only having to say "omakase" to the chef to get this party started. From start to finish, my every expectation was insanely incorrect. 
    First I waited out front for the restaurant to open and my 5:30 sushi bar reservation. As the gates open a handful of people came in. All without reservations and all sitting next to me at the sushi bar  So much for that reservation thing.  One guy even strolled in on his work break and sat down next to me. 
     At a sushi restaurant of this caliber, I imagine an old Japanese chef who has been doing this for years. Not so much. My chef was a young white guy that had just started the week prior. I have been getting sushi for 20+ years and never have had anything but a Japanese chef. Not that it's a big deal but it was a little surprising....I guess. 
     After getting my water I never saw a server again. I was interested in some help navigating the sake menu but my menu was taken and no one checked in on me afterwords. I just asked the chef who I ask about drinks to and told him to just get me a beer.  Grrr. Lame. 
     After all this I was hoping just to yell "omakase!" and have all my negatives subside. So I did. I was told they don't do that. Hmm. He said just tell me a few things I want and we will go from there. So I did. He said I misunderstood. WTF is going on here?!! He explained he would just pick some sushi and "walk me" through the menu.... I thought that's what I asked for? Blah. 
     The sushi was all fine. I never got any of the crazy high end stuff even though I requested it. No wagyu, O toro or grouper for me. Must have not been my day. $175 later, I used my ride home to be extremely pissed. Not that the food was bad, just the experience. For this kinda money I want to be wined and dined. Not feel like I'm hanging at my local bar for happy hour and friendly conversation.  I guess if u just walk in without reservations or expectations you might be satisfied. But for me, if ur restaurant is on all of the "best of the best" lists, u better bring it. Sushi fail.
author: Mark N.

description:
After booking a table for four a week in advance and from the Yelp reviews, my friends and I had high expectations. However, I was warned that Akiko's Restaurant is pretty much popular for its location -- not its sushi. It was a little too late to cancel, so we decided to try it anyways. 

When we arrived, the atmosphere was confusing. You could tell that they're trying to make it feel sophisticated with the candles and interior decor, but it was a cramped and crowded space. Not exactly a place I would have thought to book well in advance. 

We were left to explore the menus on our own, which had a limited selection at quite the high price. The four of us decided to get a bit of everything to share. I ordered a nigiri duo (with teriyaki beef) and a wakame salad. My friends ordered salmon teriyaki, saba, fried squid, and a few rolls. 

The wakame salad was good, if just a bit salty. The assorted nigiri and saba tasted very good. However, the cuts for the nigiri were inconsistent. They should not have served a nigiri with a brokenly cut piece of akami. The salmon teriyaki was good, and the beef teriyaki was even better! Very tender and soft. The rolls were average. The 49er was actually terrible because adding too much lemon completely covered the taste of anything else in the roll. Despite having a decent slice of salmon, I could taste nothing but lemon. The fried squid was average too. We found the food overpriced for the quality. Sure, the quality of the fish is great, but good ingredients do not always make for good food.

Service was just bad. We kept getting food we didn't order brought to our table. They weren't able to read our confused faces either. We had to explain to them that some foods aren't ours. Two of our orders never came, so we had to ask about them. Perhaps they got taken to another table! After that, we mistakenly received a duplicate and after table's order. Get it together, Akiko. 

When the fried squid finally showed up, the waiter apologized for the wait and said that because of it, this dish was on the house. That's nice. Then maybe ten minutes later, a roll finally shows up after waiting forever and they didn't put that on the house. It was the same waiter too! I wonder if he thought that to be odd -- not putting the even later order on the house.

By the end of the meal at Akiko's Restaurant, we were all undoubtedly disappointed. They were right -- the pricy food tastes average, but is in a good location.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Came here for an 8:45 reservation with a friend. The place is tiny and has a really great vibe.. Reminded me of NYC. 
 
The fish was pretty good and fresh but unfortunately they ran out of almost everything that night so really didn't get to try much. It was good but nothing blew me away. 

Will have to come back for the sushi bar at an earlier time before they start selling out!
author: Lauren Y.

description:
This place ticks all the right boxes for me - relaxing decor and quiet dining experience, service that is good but not overbearing, and food that is amazing. And good sized portions!

My recommendations:
Scallop and shrimp gyoza - very unique, tastes amazing, and just the right crispy skin on one side. Plus, it's a bargain... Six gyozas for $6!!

Rainbow roll - just heaven with soft shell crab inside and slices of fresh fish on top. It has a bit of a spicy kick too, so if you're afraid of spice do let them know when you order.

Yellowtail roll - at $5 for the whole roll, this is am amazing bargain. Doesn't taste as good as the rainbow roll, but at this price it doesn't matter.

Will definitely be returning here again when next in SF!
author: Boon K.

description:
The best ever I've had: King Salmon and Amber Jack. F'ing amazing. Will come back. New fav sushi in SF. PS- three kinds of Uni. Who does that?
Uni tasted like candy just melts in your mouth. Great sake selection too!
author: Mike B.

description: My friend and I have never had better fish ever. OMG good. The salad in itself was amazing. Rolls were amazing. The host was really nice and the waiter was awesome with recommendations. Such a great find and worth the money!!!
author: Stacy W.

description:
I can never say "no" to eating sushi, so I gladly accepted when a friend invited me to Akiko's.  It's a very small place that's kind of tough to find.  However, you'll be in for a treat once you set foot inside.  My friend ordered for us, so I just had to sit back and enjoy.  

What I enjoyed most of all was the freshness of their fish.  It practically melted in my mouth.  In addition, the variety and selections were incredible.  I enjoyed it all, but I have to admit that the Toro, Monk Fish Liver, Uni, blue snapper, Shiro Sake and Kanpachi were my favorite.  

Besides serving some awesome food, they explained what each dish was and their recommendations for how to eat it (dip in Shoyu or not).  I can't say enough about my fabulous meal.
author: Lon H.

description:
Overall experience: 3.5/5
Service:4/5
Food: 3/5 (It was def pricey, so I had higher expectation)

We opted for the omakase meal. There was SOOOO much food. Towards the end of the meal, we had to force ourselves to consume the last few pieces of fish and skip out on the rice. 

Highlights: 
1) Uni
2) Sashimi pieces, esp the salmon--so fresh!
3) Fried shrimp heads
4) Toro 

Overall, great experience, but will probably order a la carte if I return.
author: Jen H.

description: This restaurant is so legit that it doesn't even have a restaurant sign. It is tucked away in downtown San Francisco. Make sure you have a reservation because it is a pretty happening place. The sashimi set me got was super fresh and delicious! Pair it with some Sapporo and you are set! It is good for a casual hang out with friends our a romantic date!
author: Timothy Y.

description:
Loooooove this place! Used to go here all the time when I lived in Nob Hill. The food is amazing, the staff friendly and atmosphere cozy. Good for a romantic dinner as well as dinner with friends. It is rather small so not good for large companies and always make sure to make reservations here, even for lunch. 

My favorite roll in the whole world is made here: The 49ers Roll. It is shrimp tempura roll with salmon and paper thin lemon on top plus some delicious mystery sauce. To die for! I need to go here every time I go back to visit San Fran to have that roll. I have never had a bad meal at this place and I have tried most things on their menu, so you really cannot go wrong no matter what you order.

Plus for the art work on the walls.
author: Annika B.

description: Yelp failed us on this one. I consider myself a sushi (nigiri) connoisseur. Saw the pics and  reviews on yelp and was very excited. Went for lunch, waited an hour for a table to have a very slow and expensive lunch. Took forever to take our order and each dish took 10-15 minutes each to deliver...and this is nigiri...nothing complicated. 1hr 20min, we were out and that's giving the guy my credit card when he handed me the last dish of nigiri. Plus it wasn't even busy! $106 for eight pieces of sushi and tako salad. I don't mind paying but service was way below average. Only why I'm giving 3 star is because the sushi was AVERAGE. We won't be coming back or recommend to anyone.
author: John V.

description:
Wow. Great food but the WORST service ever. For real. I'm not a huge complainer about service but this was DESPICABLE. 

Ordered a some lovely nigiri for myself and agedashi tofu app.  Husband ordered the teriyaki and tempura dinner. 

About 5 minutes after we ordered, 2 pieces of nigiri arrived. Very odd. I wasn't sure what exactly to think about this. Ten minutes later the rest of my nigiri shows up. Yes, the entree came before my appetizer. About 2 minutes later my appetizer shows up. Twiddling thumbs...awaiting hubs food. My husband waited 10 MORE minutes until his dish arrived! What were they thinking?? How awkward is it to sit with your app and entree as your date sits with NO FOOD FOR 10 MINUTES? I don't usually criticize service but this was one of the worst I have experienced. To top it off, we were brought the check without being offered the dessert menu. I asked the waiter if they were out of all of their desserts. They were not. They were just clueless. 

Akikos is the epitome of disorganization. Though I enjoyed my nigiri (above average) and the teriyaki and tempura dinner was average in flavor, I will never be back due to such incredibly poor service.
author: Kris L.

description:
The BEST sushi restaurant in San Francisco...hands down!
