I've lived in the city for almost 6 years, and I've been to many sushi spots.  Akiko's on Bush St. is by far the best.  My husband and I have been coming here since they first opened for business, and they've definitely gone through many changes--some good, some bad.  

Before they became so popular, we could get a table without making reservations.  Now, it's at least a 2 week wait for dinner.  This is a testament to how good the food is here.  I love that they've gotten so successful, but selfishly, I long for those days when we could just walk in and get a table.

The old sushi chef left (from everything I've heard, it was because he went on to open his own restaurant).  I was afraid the quality of the food would go downhill, but that wasn't the case at all.  The menu changed a bit, but every dish is just as delicious and fresh.

The portion size of each dish definitely got smaller (when compared to the portion size when they first opened), which was a bit disappointing since I could eat a lot of sushi.  And it's certainly NOT cheap.  But don't let this stop you from trying this place at least once.  It's really that good!!!
author: Khristine A.

description: Very fresh and good selection with excellent service.  The price at this place should be a lot more than 2 dollar signs.  I walked out for a decent size meal od sushi for no 100 less and than tack on 20%.
author: robert s.

description:
Great ambiance, good service, decent sushi, overpriced.

We had the omakase (nigiri only) and it was OK. I didn't find the fish particularly fresh, and the rice was really dry. 

It's a great place for a date though and the waiters were attentive. Not sure I would go back though. Food quality is just too important to me for that price.
author: Rachele L.

description: Thank you chef Chris for the beyond incredible omakase meal. I will not forget the great care, beautiful freshness, and superb variety of each nigiri you served me.
author: Nancy A.

description:
Cute place that looks small, but actually has a hidden back room that fits way more than you'd think! For noon though, it still gets pretty packed, so if you're looking for a lunch spot, I'd still recommend reservations, which I did, smartly!

The trip was all worth it for one of the most delicious sushi rolls I've ever had! I'll even forgive the name... the Forty Niner - shrimp, salmon and lemon. It was incredible. And the reason was the lemon. It gave it this burst of flavor that was incredible. It really blew all the other rolls away. If it was called the Steeler Roll, maybe it would have been even better... Okay, I lied. It couldn't. It rocked my world!

I wish I could tell you the other rolls, but since the Forty Niner blew me away, I don't remember! Even at $16. But that's probably a steal in SF, right?!
author: Rachel C.

description: Absolutely A+ in quality, service, and value for $. Had a group of 9 and everyone was thrilled. Would go hear again in a heart beat.
author: Evan R.

description:
Really loved the sushi here.  Definitely coming back.  Ordered the 49ers roll, and sake and hamachi nigiri. My friend ordered the chicken teriyaki and sashimi sampler.  Everything was so fresh and delicious.  Their green tea also has jasmine in it which I liked.  Probably $35 per person before tip and tax.  

The restaurant was a bit difficult to find - I didn't see the name anywhere and there is a sign above the restaurant that was confusing as it directs you to Irish Bank in the alley.  But anyhow it is next to 425 Bush where you would expect it to be.
author: Vivian W.

description: Came here for dinner the other night, around 6. Turns out they did not have half the items on their menu and would suggest a substitute. You would imagine the suggestions would be at least comparable to the nigiri you ordered but...nope. Quality was good. Service was not great, pretty slow. May I suggest a daily, or at least weekly printed menu? Would make it 10x easier to order and know what you're ordering.
author: Susan T.

description:
Ate here the other day and was very disappointed! After waiting and waiting and finally getting a reservation at the very busy Akiko's, my boyfriend and I were so excited to go for dinner with our friend to celebrate his promotion!

We got Omakase which was NOT traditional at all. We were seated at a table, not the sushi bar and we repeatedly saw the sushi chefs finish our nigiri but the wait staff leave it on the counter for 10 minutes or more. The service was very, very slow and inattentive. We were there for 2 hours!

The fish, while fresh and seemingly good quality, was poorly prepared and the sushi was bland. It was prepared not by one chef, but assembly line style by multiple people. I've never seen sushi prepared this way. It felt impersonal and cheap. And as I said, the sushi sat around for a while before reaching us, so the temperature of most of the pieces was off.

We left Akiko's feeling cheated and worst of all, $350 later, we left still hungry.
author: Cydney S.

description:
Before I start this review, let me say that I'm a harsh critic when it comes to sushi. i've eaten my fair share so I'm just a little bit more picky when it comes to fish. You can say that the bar has been raised and Akiko...well they definitely jumped, but they slammed themselves right against the bar. I came here with two of my friends and you probably already know how we do. OMAKASE SON!  (actually we never intended on getting that, but right when we got there we were like...dang it. YOLO)

Atmosphere:
This place was poppin. It has two rooms in which one where you can sit near the bar and the other which is in the back that looks like some James Bond movie where you are chased down an alley way with hooligans about to shoot you in the face. But the ambience here was nice and I was definitely digging the decor. They get 4/5 from me on the layout of the room.

Food:
What can I say? Service was great, the chef himself was awesome (he even reminded me of a samurai warrior the way he maneuvered his knife around), and the timeliness of getting our fish served was great! I really enjoyed the spread of the food, however the one thing I will say is that certain pieces tasted a lot better than others. It wasn't that it was bad or anything, it just wasn't the best out of the best. I think a better way to put it was that the quality consistency of each fish was just not there. We ended up eating about 12-15 pieces I would say and I definitely enjoyed it. I would highly recommend getting the Japanese Uni over the Santa Barbra. Not that I tried it, but the Japanese one was just so on point that it was amazinggggg. It also came in a wooden spoon. Hipster shit. That's all I gotta say and it definitely gives a +5 to the taste. Oh apparently there was a beef wagyu that looked really yummy that I didn't eat. It had some truffles stuff on it. Get it.

Price:
Price is consistent on what you see from San Francisco. It's most definitely more expensive than Seattle. Seriously it is. Just don't think about it when you eat it. It's all part of the experience and if you wanna eat Omakase...well you gotta pay to play or you're not even in the game.

Overall this place was cool. I really enjoyed the ambience, but I've definitely had better and there are better places in SF for Omakase. I just wasn't completely satisfied by the time I left the place. Is that weird? Nahhhh.
author: Nathan L.

description: Perfect place for lunch :) we went and sat a bar, which had a really cool environment, and got their lunch special. The fish was fresh and almost slightly sweet, the rice was perfectly seasoned with vinegar/salt/sugar and good temperature, and the tempura was also good, too. I would definitely recommend!
author: June S.

description:
Bring your tastebuds and your big boy credit card! 

This is a place for amazing flavors, not your mothers california roll kids! I have tried this place twice and both times have been blown away by just how good the fish is and how the chef staff puts it together. Trust your server but a word of advise.. give them a budget to work with or your end of meal surprise could just make you have to call for a credit limit increase...LOL The truth is its expensive but worth it!
author: Brook M.

description: The food serves a "5", the service an average "3" so my rating a four.  It's easy to miss the restaurant from the exterior but it's a quiet and exceptional meal.  I tried the aji (mackerel) which has become my testing staple at sushi bars and I was very pleased.  Each piece served individually to allow all guests to receive some food was tasty and prepared without the need to drench the food in soya sauce.  The nigiri pieces were in the smaller side but the rolls larger than excepted.  I will certainly return and probably have the omakase next time.
author: Greg L.

description: What a great little sushi joint. This place is incredibly small, and seating is limited. The sushi is fresh and very inexpensive. We had 5 rolls and out total meal was under $55. Service is top notch and the setting is casual yet intimate. What a great little gem.
author: JB A.

description: The sushi was delicious but no baked rolls.  Sushi chefs very friendly, great environment.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I'm not sure that I woudk brand this "best sushi in town" but it was definitely good. I just wasn't overly impressed! We ordered a few rolls and sashimi. The first 49er roll that came out was actually prepared differently than the second order. The two other gfs I was with noticed since they had dined before here. It was really slow yet it took long and the rolls came out staggered. What was odd was they were really annoying about taking reservations when it was 11:30am on a holiday week. I feel like they keep that air about them which I wasn't impressed with.

Nonetheless, the rolls were good. We also had the Rock n Roll roll which was pretty good - prices were average but I feel like I've been elsewhere and it's more bang for your buck. Sashimi was tasty we had a 6 piece order and I found that on the slightly pricier than most. 

The sake was so not impressive! We ordered a large and another small between the three of us - granted we wanted to drink! It just felt so dinky it came in this clay pot so it was extremely deceptive in size. Our total was a little over. $90/3 and I feel like I've just had better despite the fact the quality was good.

Ryokos is better!
author: Priya S.

description:
This place was a bit hard to find as there is no signage. It's located a block down from the Chinatown Gate on the corner (next to the alley) where the sign for the Irish Bank is located. Since it is downtown, there's only street metered parking or paid parking garages. The restaurant is tiny with only a few tables and bar seating. For dinner, walk-ins that night were all turned away. So get reservations, and get them early! We went on a Thursday night and all the reservations were taken except the one I managed to grab early that morning.

We came here to celebrate my friend's birthday a little late since we weren't able to see her on her actual birthday. She wanted sushi and this restaurant is easily BART-able as it's about 2 blocks from the Montgomery Station.

~~ Our Order ~~
Edamame: $3
Agedashi Tofu: ($9) Fried House-made Silken Tofu, Roe, Dashi
Nigiri Tasting: ($23) 6 pcs
Rainbow: ($14) Fresh Crab, Selection of Fish, Avocado, Cucumber, Tare
Beef Teriyaki: ($13) Cubed Niman Ranch N. Y. Strip in Teriyaki served w/ a bowl of rice
Tekka Maki: ($12) Tuna, Scallion, Avocado, Crispy Shiso, Pickled Carrot, Sesame
Mebachi Maguro: ($9) Big Eye Tuna nigiri
Sake Maki: ($10) Fresh Salmon, Avocado, Scallion, Yuzu Jalapeno, Tare, Toasted Sesame
Okuden Kantsukuri: ($10) Mirror of Truth
Shizengou: ($11) Rich, Deep Aromas & flavors of Hazelnut, White Pepper & Mushroom

Portions are small but of high quality, so I wouldn't really come here starving unless you don't mind spending a lot of $$. When we were first seated, we were asked for drink orders and if we would like edamame while we waited for another friend to join us. Take note, the edamame is not complimentary. We weren't told this unfortunately and I find it odd that such a high caliber place would charge for it. For sake, get the Shizengou if it's available (it tends to sell out).  I'm not a fan of sake because of the strong alcoholic burn afterwards but this one is so smooth! We didn't taste the hazelnut though which was why we ordered it in the first place. Initially our waiter had told us that it was sold out but he somehow was able to find some for us. It wasn't a full glass but at least we were able to taste it and we were so glad that he did! Definitely will order again next time. We had ordered the Okuden Kantsukuri since the Shizengou was out as suggested by our waiter. It was good but definitely not as good as the Shizengou.

For appetizers, we ordered the agedashi tofu. I liked the broth for the agedashi tofu, but personally, I prefer slightly more firm tofu. For an entree, I had ordered the Nigiri Tasting and felt that the fish was a bit on the warm side, so I was a bit concerned. However, the texture of each of the fish was so buttery soft! It was so good! The favorite roll of the evening was surprisingly the Tekka Maki because of the slight crunch from the crispy shiso. One of my friends just ordered it randomly too. The rainbow roll was good, especially with the fresh crab. The birthday girl loved her Mebachi Maguro. The meal definitely satisfied her sushi craving.

Service was very attentive, prompt and courteous. Dishes were quickly cleared away and water/tea were consistently filled.

Great place to go for a quiet date night or for a celebration. Highly recommend!
author: Kitty K.

description:
I love Japanese food, but when it comes to Sushi, you have to really impress me especially if I'm going to shell out a ton of money for it. I came here and had the omakase simply because this is the best way to experience the skill level of the chef as well as the true ingredients.

Walking into this place, the ambiance was awesome,discreet store front and inside, you have a cozy modern, chic decor. We sat at the bar, and had an awesome chef. Straight from Japan, it was great watching him at work putting together a variety of plates. I couldn't have asked for a better environment to spend time with friends, even the water pitchers were on point. 

Now, the food, was about average for me and that is the main driver as to why this place is receiving 3 stars. I love all types of sushi, and when it's good you know it is GOOD, but at the same time, it is very easy to tell the difference between the quality of fish you are getting. That being said, as we went through our different pieces, you could distinctly tell that some pieces were fresher and more flavorful than others. For me this is a problem. To be a top tier sushi restaurant in my book, you need to provide consistency across the board.  This in no way is a reflection on the chef, but rather on the ingredients he was given to work with. 

Although, this is listed as $$ on Yelp, if you are having the omakase, expect to pay pretty similar prices to other sushi restaurants. Overall, this place had good vibes, friendly staff and decent food. I will be back here to try some of the other dishes.
author: Alex L.

description: I'm so disappointed: They no longer serve the main entrees for dinner (e.g., salmon teriyaki, tonkatsu, etc.).  They used to, but not any more. Instead, this has become a place that is essentially a sushi bar menu: omakase, nigiri, rolls, and small items and plates, etc. So, if you want both sushi and Japanese meals, head to Mikaku or Sushi Rock, both just a block away. If not, and you want to splurge (with money to burn) head here (for smaller scale, more intimate) or Pabu or Akor (for large scale).
author: Randy M.

description:
This place is great!!
It's actually my 2nd time coming here. My first time, I simply stumbled upon this place via yelp and didn't really have that high of an expectation until they surprised me by how traditional their techniques are.

I grew up in Asia where Japanese food is everywhere, easily way better than places in the U.S, and tons more affordable. So it takes a lot for me to five this place 5 stars!

This time, I got the Omakase and spent $117 excluding tip - I honestly felt the price was fair given the quality of fish that was served to me.
My omakase included 
1. ponzu vinaigrette Japanese seaweed + smoked scallop - delicious, not only am I a big sucker for anything yuzu flavored, but this appetizer was balanced with sweet, salty, spicy, and sour.
2. big eyed tuna poke + ponzu albacore - I didn't care for the tuna poke, I'm not a big fan of overly marinated sashimi and I also get this impression that poke is made with scrap pieces. But I was pleasantly surprised by the albacore. I normally dislike albacore since it tends to have a strong taste. The texture is leaner and stringier, if not sliced right, the fish tends to look spoiled. But the chef put it together nicely. Ponzu sauce was elevated by a few additions (one of which being ginger), and the albacore was garnished with chiffonade shiso which so I saw the chef chop himself. This guy has good basics!
3. Cod & Ocean Trout - The ocean trout was fresh and good, but it's like salmon so I don't have a whole lot to say about it. But the cod was delicious! The chef had stacked a small piece of seared meat and added a very light smokey dimension.
4. Santa Barbara Uni and horse Mackerel - Santa Barbara Uni was cream and delicious and I thought I was satisfied, but no, I later found out in my Omakase that there's an even better one.
5. Shima Aji (Striped Jack) and overnighted Hotate (Scallop) - Besides uni, I also really love scallop, but I like it served in a very specific way - butterflied, dressed with yuzu, with a pinch of kosher salt. But today's scallop was different, not creamy and sweet like how I normally get to have it, but it was more like crispy! I suppose that is how fresh scallop taste like! The fibers are very distinct and separates easily as you chew it.

Ok you get the point there are actually 5 more courses after that which two nigiri sushis each.. But the biggest highlight of my meal was probably the Tokujyo Uni. I didn't think I would be able to tell the flavors apart from the different kinds of uni... oh but you can! Tokujyo is much much sweeter. Now I'll never forget Tokujyo Uni as my favorite kind of Uni.
author: Melody K.

description:
Akiko's raises the bar for sushi in San Francisco.

At Akiko's, the only way to go is to sit at the sushi bar and do omakase.  Chef Ricky will take you on a magical mystery tour of fishes you never knew you loved.  Over a period of at least two hours you will enjoy an endless series of fish and vegetables complemented by various innovative sauces.  You will be treated to an array of temperatures, textures, and cooking methods--all of which are awesome.  Don't hesitate; just do it.

While the rolls are good, at Akiko's you should head straight for the sashimi and nigiri.  The monkfish liver is sublime. Don't miss it.  If you think you do not like urchin, try the Russian uni. Its delicate, creamy taste will change your mind about spiny sea creatures.  Rich and delicious, the keiji salmon has a higher fat content than toro and shouldn't be missed.  Toro (tuna), hamachi (yellowtail), unagi (grilled freshwater eel), saba (mackerel), sake (salmon), hotate (scallop)--all the fish is of the highest quality, perfectly prepared, and artistically presented.

Service is hit and miss.  The sushi chefs are great, but, while friendly and informative, the wait staff assigned to use would sometimes disappear for long periods of time.

Tips:

- Make a reservation; do not try to walk in, as you will be disappointed
- Skip the crowded dining room with its closely spaced tables; sushi bar all the way
- Bring your gold Amex; the prices reflect the quality of the fish

Overall Akiko's puts out some high quality fish at commensurately high prices.
author: CJ G.

description: Amazing! The best sushi I've ever ate! Great service, delicious sake, the freshest and the most delicious fish. Highly recommend.
author: Sasha Z.

description:
Looking for a nice sushi joint in SFC?  The sushi is always fresh and the atmosphere is really nice and elegant.  The service is great here. 

Can't go wrong with this place.
author: David C.

description: Made a reservation here on a whim on a Friday night and was surprised they had an early reservation available at 5:30 even though I booked at 4:45. We were pleasantly surprised and LOVED the sushi. They used quality ingredients and their fish was super fresh. Service was amazing, the whole wait staff was so attentive. We will definitely be back very soon.
author: Sommer A.

description: This is a beautiful restaurant. The decor is really lovely, the wait staff provided exceptional service and the atmosphere was really great. Small menu, but it was well curated and the food was very fresh and very well made. Nice wine list as well.
author: Dana C.

description: Best sushi place in SF but definitely more than two dollar signs. Don't get the rolls, which are very mediocre, get omakase or at least nigiri and maybe a dish from the kitchen to fill you up since only eating nigiri here will cost 200+ to get you full. I recommend the soft shell crab.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to an Akiko dinner!  This place does not disappoint.  Some of the tastiest, well prepared nigiri and hand rolls i've ever had - you can taste the quality and thoughtfulness that go into each piece that is made.  These sushi/sashimi chefs seriously know what they're doing.  Total sweethearts (and cuties) too.  My favs:   tekka roll and suzuki (sea bass) nigiri - yum.

My only gripe:  my gal pal and I came in here at 6PM on a Wednesday - place was EMPTY and we were asked if we had reservations, we did not.  She made us sit at the bar (which turned out to be just fine - got to sit next to the cool sushi chefs and service was excellent).  However, the entire place was EMPTY, she said they were booked with reservations.  Wouldn't be a big deal, but as we left, the place was still just as empty as when we arrived.  Oh Akiko.
author: Jana S.

description:
Yum yum! 

Walked right by it at first, but then found it! Small place so you should have a reservation, but delicious and fresh sushi! A little expensive, but worth it on a night out, although it does feel a little cramped in the back.
author: MaryKate M.

description:
The sushi here is about as good as it gets.  Delicious high quality fish that has been properly stored and prepared.  The pieces of fish they give are also on the medium/large side.  However, the portions overall are rather small and very expensive.

My rating here is based wholly on the food quality (I did consider taking off 1 star), which was far beyond any other sushi spot in the area.  Just be ready to pay 2x the price, as you get what you pay for here.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Great place, very fresh and tasty fish.  Must come back and try the chef recommendations. I wasn't that adventurous to try all the different types of nigiri but next for sure I will.  

The beef teriyaki and nigiri combo is good too!
author: Byron L.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding down due to the smell of human excrement floating into the dining room during our dinner. More details about that later..

There isn't a sign on the door, so make sure you look for the number 431 on Bush Street! If you are coming for their omakase, or to try the speciality sashimi/nigiri options off the nama menu, don't be an idiot like I was and come on a Monday. Fish deliveries usually come on Tuesdays, so there is much less selection available. And I was wondering why it was so easy to make a reservation for Monday night on Opentable. In any case, we decided to stay since we were already there, and opted to sit at a table in their dining area versus the sushi bar since we were a party of 3. The restaurant is pretty small, so reservations are highly recommended. We told our server we wanted the omakase, and he let us know it would take at least 2 hours. The restaurant is quite dim, so apologies for the ugly picture quality. Our omakase consisted of:

-Poke ($9.16, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA): Just ok. The tuna was fresh, but some pieces seemed a bit stringy. The soy sauce was also a little strong for my preference.
-Sashimi: Kodai/Wild Tai Snapper ($4.40), Hirame ($5.50), Hamachi ($5.86) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#XxQVZ0fwlGwmiHyCH1pyXA) Australian Ocean Trout/Umimasu ($5.13), Seared Walu/Escolar ($4.40) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#wPXdrb-4YVtmHQvfTaTrrw): The hamachi sashimi was by far my favorite. I normally love escolar, but didn't like that they seared it- it gave it more of an oily mouth feel. Everything was really fresh though, and sliced well, although I didn't care for the kodai or ocean trout.
-Ginger, Wasabi, Pickled Wasabi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#1TY3JjrVsCKZ1kLJu68PIg): The wasabi wasn't very strong, and the pickled wasabi was interesting but I didn't like it with my sushi. My friends liked it a lot more than I did.
-Black Chu Toro/Kuro Maguro Nigiri ($9.16, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#bUFdNQMmNMGfldCxVkn1nQ): Delicious, and almost melted in my mouth. 
-Hokkaido Uni Nigiri (From Russia, $10.99, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#LVmxZfE7hndCPEWT1aELCA): Yum! The uni was really sweet tasting, and very different from your normal uni.
-Umami Ikura w/Truffle Nigiri ($5.95, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#f5Ike985hqmUjpeINqEqWQ): The ikura was delicious! I normally love truffle oil, but in this case, it overpowered the freshness of the ikura.
-Hamachi Belly/Sunazuri ($3.66, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#GHgJlw0AQZpuwraSH7gLxg): Super good, and one of my favorites that night.
-A5 Wagyu Nigiri ($11.42, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#wDrXMxhhnO2foBwtYR8Q8Q): I was really excited to try the A5 grade waygu, and this was good, but I wasn't super amazed. It was worth a try though!
-Sesame Ice Cream? (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/akikos-restaurant-san-francisco?select=krdc8cCBl5AKukKttY6gzA#SCR22I2akDLNi2nNYDwWfg): Since it was my friend's birthday, they were nice enough to give us a complimentary dessert with sesame ice cream and some other components that I unfortunately cannot remember. 

Our server was friendly and informative, but would sometimes disappear and we would try and flag someone else down. For such a small restaurant, it was sometimes difficult to find someone to help us! Also, the table runners would deliver the dishes at times, and it was really hard to hear what they were saying/understand them sometimes. The worst part of the dinner was the bathroom incident- the sole bathroom stall is at the corner of the dining room, and there isn't much ventilation in there. Apparently, one of the workers had to go poo, and the smell wafted out and lingered for almost half an hour. Thankfully we were winding down, but it was an awful experience that I hope never happens to me at a nice restaurant again! Since a lot of their premium fishes were out of stock, the total for our omakase came to $82.24. I was full, but only because I had to eat some of my friend's portion since she had a really late lunch that day.

Overall, I may still come back to try their speciality nama menu items, but will ensure I sit at the sushi bar versus the dining room with the bathroom!! Parking here can be difficult, but there are spots available for street parking, and it's pretty easy to find on a weekday night (especially Monday). However, the traffic on Bush can be heavy during rush hour.
author: Amy D.

description: Really great, short menu which was refreshing for a sushi place. Food was excellent and great Sake selection as well.
author: Sacha M.

description:
Pricey sushi but is fresh and delicious. In order to feel full here, I would have to order about $60 worth of food. The Sashimi Tasting comes with 12 pcs of salmon, tuna, etc and is very good but leaves you still feeling hungry. We also ordered the tekka and negihama rolls which were excellent- I highly recommend! Both have raw tuna and are quite tasty. 

Despite the yummy food and spending $60 between two people, my friend and I were still hungry after this meal and decided to get ramen afterwards to feel fully satisfied. I don't think it's a great value here so I won't be coming back.
author: Lillian C.

description: I've heard great things about this place even before visiting. We decided to go one night and were able to get reservations for the same night. The food was good, albeit a bit pricey. The dinner service is a bit long. The staff was very courteous. Their fish is fresh and their wagyu nigiri... melts in your mouth. Would definitely recommend.
author: Alvin The Chipmun K.

description:
Dining at Akiko's is definitely a treat. The first time I was taken here by a couple of awesome friends, one of whom knows one of the sushi chefs (now former). That experience was pretty unforgettable as we sat at the bar and indulged in individual plate after individual plate of delicately prepared and indescribably delicious bites of nigiri, dressed with fish, wagyu, shaved truffle, and other amazing elements.

Last Friday, I returned with a couple of my coworkers, as one of them was leaving us to start her maternity leave. We decided we needed a GOOD meal and headed to Akiko's.

The restaurant is unmarked, so it's easy to just walk pass it, which I pretty much did. We got there at around 1:30pm so the lunch hour rush had died down for the most part. We were asked to wait a little bit as our table was cleared and prepped, and were pretty promptly seated by the street-facing window.

Initially, service got off to a bit of a shaky start. We just sat there browsing our menus and waited for someone to come over and check in with us. A gal who seated us didn't really come back, nor did anyone else, and we had to physically flag down someone and ask if we can order. At a fine dining restaurant like Akiko's, we didn't expect that kind of service. They had a lot to make up to make the lunch spectacular.

Luckily, things turned drastically around for the better once food started to arrive. We ordered Sake (fresh salmon) Roll, a salad to share, Kani-Age: Fried Soft Shell Crab, Nigiris (Hara Sake: Seared Salmon Belly; Ankimo: Monkfish Liver;  Shiro Maguro: White Tuna; Uni: Sea Urchin, Amaebi: Sweet Shrimp), the recommended Kampachi (Amberjack) head and collar, broiled and tasty.  

The salad was presented in a lovely fashion, even accompanied by tiny little lavender flowers, edible I guess since I ate them. There were tiny arugula looking leaves. Very adorable. The dressing was just right. Refreshing and a good accompaniment to the textures of the greens.

The Kani-Age (Fried Soft Shell Crab) was cooked excellently. It was lightly battered and crunchy on the outside, juicy, hot and delicious on the inside. We savored each tiny crab leg that was fried to perfection.

All of the Nigiri were delicious and the fish portions were pretty generous. The Ankimo pieces far over draped the rice, so you could really taste the liver flavor. The fish is incredibly fresh here, and the sushi chefs look like they're master artists while creating these creations. We thoroughly enjoyed each nigiri. The Amaebi came accompanied with friend shrimp heads, which was really crispy and the gushy brains tasted extra good. What a sin! 

The Kampachi (Amberjack) head and collar was a good choice because as it arrived, all we could see was the giant eyeball staring up at us. Definitely photo-worthy right by itself! The meat was well cooked, and there were plenty to go around as we just dug into dish and shredded it to pieces. 

The host was very attentive (far surpassing the initial hostess we had). He came to our table and explained each dish as they were delivered to our table. We were admiring the beautifully plated food, and he came over and told us not to let the sushi sit on the table too long because the temperature will change the taste. We quickly stuffed our mouths as soon as we heard that! 

At the end of our meal, we were so satisfied with our bellies full of super tasty food. Akiko's was just as I remembered! For me at least, this is a special-occasion kind of place, but I think that just make each visit that much more memorable! See you next time.
author: Jing D.

description:
It's been a while since I've last ventured to Akiko's, but I still recall the state of bliss I was in with my friends when we stumbled upon this little popular sushi restaurant. First off, you must make a reservation here to guarantee a spot during the weekend. My friends and I were fortunate enough to grab a table right as they opened without a reservation, but we definitely lucked out. As we settled in, all the tables quickly filled up, so we knew this was a legit spot! 

We ordered calamari and several rolls, and everything came out extremely fresh and delicious. The calamari was the best I've ever had, so here's a tip: get the calamari! 

Friendly and hospitable service paired with delicious food result in a return fosho!
author: MyLinh P.

description: My boyfriend and I have been looking all over San Francisco for our favorite sushi spot, Akiki's is it. They tend to get fresh fish in around the middle of the week, so if you want their very best, I would recommend going on a Wednesday night. Their fish melts in your mouth, it's that delicious!
author: Samara C.

description:
I always come to Akikos with high expectations and Chef Ricky always exceeds my lofty expectations.
1. Make reservations via open table
2. Sit at bar
3. Do omakase menu
4. Now enjoy a truly memorable meal!
author: Dennis E.

description:
I don't think there is anything about Akiko's that stands out from the millions of other sleek 'n' chic sushi restaurants playing pulsing music and offering sushi favorites at slightly-above-average prices. But that's not necessarily a bad thing. Who doesn't enjoy a well-made rainbow roll and a glass of wine after a long day?

Speaking of rainbow rolls, Akiko's is tasty and well-portioned with lots of fresh fish. It is made with scallions, which I don't understand (SF sushi restaurants seem to really love putting scallions in rainbow rolls), so if you're not a fan of green onions like me, make sure to request no scallions. I also indulged and got some sea bream nigiri, one of the specials of the day. It tasted fresh but was a tad too....warm? Like it had been sitting under a lamp for too long. 

Prices are standard (not dirt cheap, but not exorbitant either) and service is decent. I wouldn't make a special trip to come here, but if you're in this part of FiDi, it's a good dinner option. Just make sure you make a reservation. The restaurant was full even on a Monday night.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Dear Akiko, 

I gave you a chance by going out of our usual spot at Zushi Puzzle on my lovely bf's birthday. I even cancelled the sushi bar reservation at Zushi just because a friend recommended you to me. I asked you for 2 things: please beat Zushi Puzzle omakase, impress me! (in writing) and asked for a little something small with a candle for his birthday on the phone. And you said yes! Guess what? You failed both miserably

In details: The food was good but not exceptional. It was much more expensive compared to the other $$$ sushi place... surprisingly when you only have $$ sign on Yelp. Or maybe you think it's okay to put whichever price on for omakase. I was honestly so upset that there was not even a little mochi ice cream with the candle at the end when the bill came out to be over $400 that all the little good things you present over the omakase meal was technically gone. And I couldn't ask for it since it would just be an awkward situation. Even at Zushi Puzzle, a strange guest who pays that much would at least have a spoon of strawberry sorbet just so you know, Akiko!

So 1 star for your waiter and another for your food! 

Your sincerely!
author: MS T.

description:
First of all there is no sign outside...so I assume yelp is so powerful now that as long as a place has a lot of yelp reviews a business doesn't need a sign anymore.

So we were looking around Didn't see anything so I google mapped it and I thought it moved unknowing there is an Akiko sushi bar a couple blocks away!? Wish the person taking the reservation would have let us know. Anyway don't make that mistake. We ended going to the other place and then coming right back.

So the sushi chef was nice. Omakase price was "aq" not sure what that meant...but it must be code for EXPENSIVE! We got a decent amount of pieces but I think if we didn't stop the chef our bill may have been out of this world. Unfortunately we couldn't get a reservation for Kukusabe so we ended up here.

Sushi was well prepared, we liked the fact that the chef dresses the pieces so we don't have to worry about soy sauce etc.  None of the pieces really wowed us like other sushi restaurants we've tried in southern cal. But they were unique pieces including sardine, baby yellowtail etc the Uni and toro was ok also $25 for two pieces. Shima Aji was my favorite.

Service was good and people were friendly.

The bill was the shocker. Didn't expect to pay as much as we did for a fairly par tasting of fish. We had about 12 pieces and we're still hungry. We didn't even order alcohol.

Overall...it's not a mind blowing experience maybe for the first time sushi goer but if you are a sushi lover don't expect anything amazing.
author: Simon S.

description: I've only tried their Sashimi and Sushi Omokaze. Unfortunately, sushi didn't meet the standard as the sushi rice wasn't done right. Sashimi was good but most Sushi joint in SF can do Sashimi pretty well if they can source good quality fish but if they can't get the rice done right, that dissipate the experience... maybe it was their bad-rice day. Perhaps I'll just need to stick to rolls and stuff next time if I do go back. The interior is pretty neat and trendy. Bar seating recommended.
author: Bomin K.

description: I have never had the most freshest, melt in your mouth sushi in my whole entire life! Bf took me here for our 2nd year anniversary. No words can explain how delicious and grateful I am!!! I had tears of joy after this experience. Place had a warm atmosphere. I felt cozy, comfortable and like a welcome home feeling. We sat next to the window. It was more peaceful, away from the bar. Our waiter was very knowledgeable, talkative, friendly and nice. My bf decided to take the omakase. Everything was perfect!!! THE BEST!!!
author: Sharmaine M.

description:
Decent Sushi - it is fresh and presented in a visually appealing manner. 

But nothing so outstanding that I would specifically come back here and pay the prices.

The place is spendy, and the waitstaff acts mechanical and a bit standoffish. The atmosphere just wasn't welcoming or inviting -- more I felt like I was just tolerated. 

Sadly, I've found that San Francisco doesn't seem to have very friendly or helpful people at their tourist places and dining establishments.
author: Joe H.

description: Definitely worth the $$$ come for the fresh fish, skip the traditional rolls.. we had Toro, butter fish, yellow tail belly, uni, A5 wagyu beef...reservations only...
author: jonathan h.

description:
A little bit disappointed with the quality and pricing. The FiDi location is extremely convenient but I expected more for the pricing for both the nigiri moriawase (6 pieces is hardly enough) and the kani-age (fried soft-shell crab). You could probably get similar quality a few blocks towards Union Square at better pricing.

Wako still remains my favorite sushi in San Francisco proper (however it would be impossible to get there for lunch)
author: Food E.

description:
By far, one of THE BEST sushi experiences I have ever had. We made a reservation in advance, which is highly recommended (if not required), we asked to sit at the bar (which I highly recommend). For the first hour, the business at the bar was relatively slow, so we had chef Ricky all to ourselves. We ordered two different kinds of sake, both were delicious! We had the omakase and specified around 15 pieces for approx 100/person. We added a couple of rolls (chef's choosing), the Russian uni (which is A MUST). 

The omakase consisted of EXTREMELY FRESH direct from japan over-night-flight fish. They were all exceptionally delicious and fresh. What really stood out for me was the fish that was topped with the pate, the scallop, the fresh ebi shrimp (the one at M.P.), the russian uni, and of course the wagyu beef topped with rendered beef fat and TRUFFLES! 

The service was fantastic, the fish was phenomenal, and the price (~370 total for 2 people) I felt was very fair for the quality you get. I will be back soon!
author: Long C.

description:
This place is my BF's and my favorite restaurant in the city. We've come here three times and would most likely continue to come. 

Like I said in the previous review, they have a very romantic decor going on. It is usually a bit dark but there are candles on each table. The waiter is really nice and attentive. My BF and I haven't been here for a couple months and the waiter said "welcome back" Great memory! 

The first time we came with our friend I believe we received complementary edamane. The last time we went the BF got the udon while I got a donburi. We received two miso soups. I assume the one my BF received is complementary. 

The service is great!
The ambiance is delightful!
The food is delicious & bountiful!

COME HERE!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Fantastic experience. I loved the coziness of this place.

Must have their passion fruit cocktail, its the only one on the menu. The fish was fresh, and having just gotten back from Japan a few months ago, I would have to say the sushi quality is comparable. It was so good I've made another reservation to visit soon.

The service was great too!
author: yana Z.

description:
I work in FiDi and I tend to stay late at work. I always hear good things about this place and wanted to give it a try tonight. 

"We don't do take-out." That was the response I got from the waitress. After giving me a mean look, she took the menu from my hands and walked away. Excellent first impression and you lose a customer forever.
author: Ada C.

description: The meal was like summer poem mashed up with an action film starring John McClane.  These guys are in a league of their own and have created something to be proud of.  I've spent my life and career eating in restaurants with a critical eye.   At this point I rarely justify spending large sums on a single meal, however, not in this case.  This meal was worth the build up and certainly everything I wanted it to be.  Venture away from the standard rolls and leave it up to the team.  The know what they are doing.  Flavors were clean, creative and compelling.  Keep crushing it Ray and team!
author: blair w.

description:
I was looking for a place to get sushi for lunch, and Akiko's was recommended at the salon I was at. It was a bit hard to find with so much construction around, but I didn't give up! And I am glad I didn't. 

It was busy during the lunch rush, but since I was on my own I was seated pretty quickly. I had the spicy tuna roll and green iced tea - both were good, and I was so happy to have sushi again.

Fun find!
author: Sarah C.

description: I could give this place more than 3 stars but I won't do it. The food was great and fresh. The problem I hate abt this place is Racist. I ate here with my friend on 7 June @ lunch time. We r Asian and the guy who served us was Asian,too. However, I was shocked because of his attitudes. He was cold, he didn't ask us if everything was ok.   He only took care of Western customers around us. So sad...
author: Bo T.

description: Simply the best sushi I've ever had.  It was pricey, but worth it.  Be sure to try the truffled wagyu beef - it melts in your mouth!
author: Chris O.

description: Some of the freshest sushi I have ever eaten.  Overall, a pleasant experience with great service.  I thought the ambience was minimalist and somewhat intimate.  The lighting was dim and a great place to go for a business meal or something more casual.  The only complaint that I have would that the menu font be darker and less modern.  With the fine modern thin line font and the dim light, it was a bit of a challenge to read the menu.  Dont get me wrong, I have decent eyesight and have worked in dark rooms before... but it was quite hard to make out what I was ordering.  That aside, I wish the soy sauce containers were a bit bigger.  Ours kept running low and we didn't even use that much.
author: Henry M.

description:
The food is more like 3.5 star... HOWEVER, with the way the restaurant runs, it really should be a 2-star.

This is my third time here and I am not basing it off  by a single visit. 

I understand restaurant gets busy and service could be slow. However, it is not the case in Akiko's. I think the host and waitress are just not attentive. We went there for lunch and it was not busy at all. We waited for 25 mins for our food (tonkasu rice bowl...) and no one came in between to add water / tea or apologize. You will need to get their attention to even get some water.  

Tonkasu was not even good... see picture ...

The cooked food here is not impressive at all but the sushi / sashimi are usually fresh.
author: sharon l.

description:
Expected so much more after the raving reviews but THE FISH IS NOT FRESH. We ordered the sashimi 12 piece tasting platter.   
3 other rolls not worth mentioning. The first three pieces might have tasted good because I was starving. 

If it was a blind taste test Id think I was tasting samples to a boba cafe. It was just Plain gooey. 

Yellow tail: grass jelly
Tuna : black boba 
Salmon : popping boba

You get it. 

Leave it to the Fi Di to overcharge for poor quality food once again!

One star for attentive staff.
author: Lily T.

description: I'm a big sushi fan and this is one of the best sushi in the Bay Area.  Not to be confused with "Akiko's Sushi Bar" on Mason.  My sister and I tried the sashimi platter as well as orders of Uni and Scallops Nigiri, and Toro sashimi (very buttery).
author: Alex T.

description: Sushi was fresh and delicious. Staff was friendly and made the dinner more enjoyable. Tad pricey for the environment and sushi though.
author: Jeanette K.

description:
Sushi is special occasion. It should be. No one should eat that much fish consistently. It can lead to a myriad of health issues. When I go eat sushi, I go to the best I can. I spend the money to ensure the fish I get is from waters that are clean and handled by professionals. The advent of the All You Can Eat sushi factories and Sushi Boats spots have inundated us with mediocrity disguised as authentic. In the Bay Area, when I do sushi I go to Sushi Ran, Ebisu, Hanna Sushi, and Akikos. Let's focus on Akikos shall we?

So I'm going down the current reviews for Akikos. Solid reviews except this one from Lily T. Lily, you are an idiot. Anyone who compares Akikos fish to Bobo is a food noob. I take your review with a "whatevs"
I have a sake bomb waiting for you at Ozumo. 

Let's just let it all be known, Akikos is not the same without our brother Ricky representing. It's not worse it's not better. As far as Ricky is concerned, It's like when George Michael went solo from Wham. Good for him, but in the long run, was it? Who gets laid at a rest stop?  Good luck bro. 

Akikos is Ray. He sources the fish, he does the R&D, and he pushes his boys to geek out on their craft. And boy what a craft. The rice cooker they use is some serious Kit Knight Rider stuff. The soy they glaze some of there fish with has been sonically emulsified to thicken and soften the flavor profile. Sous vide?  Check. Blast chiller?  Check. Boxes straight from japan to age there tuna?  WTF is that?  Aged tuna?  Damn straight. Check out the knives and chopsticks used by these guys. Oh my!

The rice is great. Individually distinct grains with just enough vinegar to hold your attention without making you stand up.  Toothsome and warmed above body temperature, it's how sushi rice should be.  

I always do the omokase so I let the boys decide on what my mercury intake for the night will be. The fish is always good. Ray sources with an eye for unique and delicious product from Tskiji, local, and national waters. Only gripe is that I find them garnishing too many of there dishes with lemon. 

Sake list is great. Have one of their little hotties choose for you. Pricey but again, special occasion. I can't read the the damn label so someone translate please. These guys always get me the right bottle cause they always talk to me bout what I like. They can communicate to me cause they all speak engrish. 

See, that's what I love about Bay Area Japanese cuisine today. Communication. The chefs speak to you in English. The cult of the sushi nazis is dying out. From Ichi, to Ramen Shop, to Akikos, the next generation is speaking unbroken English and that's great. I can converse with the chef and it's no longer a mystery. It's just plain simple service. Without the R's and L's getting jacked up. 

The call. Order as much Russian Uni you can get your hands on. Oh my beautiful little sea urchin. I prefer to call it ocean vagina. It's an acquired taste but damn I just wanna shove my face in it and come out looking like a glazed donut. Nuff said. Maybe TMI.
author: Chris K.

description:
This place is super easy to pass by. There's no signage or anything.. except for the Irish Pub which hangs on the corner - just makes it more confusing.

Once you're inside, it kind of feels like a grungy Italian restaurant.. definitely not a nice sushi restaurant. I guess it's the hipster servers that give it away.

Ordered a craaaaap ton of food. 2-4 orders of about 15 items on the menu. Some of the best salmon sashimis I've ever tasted.. they literally melted in your mouth. 

The quality of this place is 5 stars. The one thing that makes me take off a star is that they keep the temperature inside way too hot.. which in turn makes the sashimi warm.
author: Angela L.

description:
Sit @ bar, omakase is the way to go. Wow, fantastic. Couldn't get out for under $500, but worth every c-note.

Making reservations is a must. We saw 5+ parties being turned away at the door due to no rez.
author: Jen H.

description:
seating by reservation only. everything was incredibly fresh, however, the golden eye snapper kama was undercooked, someewhat slimy, and had very little meat compared to hamachi kama. i felt like they tried to sell us leftover fish parts. don't order it.

i love that they have amberjack... the ankimo is delicious, and the rolls are amazing :).
author: Judy L.

description:
You still have to wait even though you have reservations unless prior parties leave early. 

I did not drive here so I don't know too much about how parking is but there is parking lots everywhere near by as well as street parking (metered).

Ambiance is noisy as if in a lounge. Even if you and a friend or significant sits across from each other, expect to lean forward a lot to hear one another.

Also if you have asthma like myself. While sitting inside to eat (very very narrow room). Its hard to breathe. No air circulation and candles makes it that much harder. 

Waiting area is very tiny, its technically not even a waiting area. So if they are busy, expect to wait outside. Waiting inside means you are cramped in the center between a bar, a few tables and the door. Once those table food comes out, you will be moving to your right/left often to get out their way.

Food: it was good! Will I come back again? Honestly its 50/50. The salmon sashimi was delicious. That would be the only reason why I'd come back. Even than...I would most likely just do an order to go. Not worth to wait another 30-45 min after my reservation time just to be seated.
author: Julie B C.

description: Hands down the best sushi place in San Francisco If not in the entire the Bay Area. This is simply the closest Tsukiji / Edo style sushi experience you will get around here. Fantastic fish selection, authentic cooking. Do yourself a favor and get what the chef recommends.
author: Andy M.

description:
As a visitor to the Bay Area with limited time, a sushi bar visit was squeezed into my tight itinerary.
I did my research and found this place.
I took my wife and daughter here, and it didn't disappoint.
We were seated on time, and was greeted by a very friendly sushi chef. This place gave a good vibe and the fish quality was amazing.
We took the omakase and every piece of sushi he served us delivered great values of authenticity and freshness. We ended the meal with this seared Wagyu beef sushi that was to die for.

I will definitely come back after such a positive experience.
author: Kalvin C.

description:
What a rude place!!! I came in 40 minute before they close for lunch and the hostess said they can not take any walk in's for one!  They were going to close and didn't want to have to serve anyone at this point... Wow.  And they had several counter seats open and a few tables open too! 

Not only are they rude but dumb.  I work a few blocks away and would have love to have found a great sushi place.  I guess this is not IT!
author: Steven C.

description:
amazing fresh buttery raw fish!
our server was very polite yet excited to share the food with us.
there is a difference when you feel the sincerity of the staff
food and sake selection is sublime!
omakase is the way to go!
author: Marie r.

description: After a long day of people & city chaos, Akiko's Restaurant was a perfect find. Small with a peaceful atmosphere. Food & Service was excellent. Worth the price!
author: Susan R.

description: Delicious fresh sushi spot in downtown SF, what a find! I suggest the sashimi and a reservation. Also, go with a good friend who loves sushi, you'll have fun!
author: Erin W.

description:
It's hard to find high quality sushi in fidi, and i think this is the best i've had in the area.  I came here for my birthday lunch with one other person. We sat for 10 minutes before our server came by, but we noticed him chatting with the hostesses. One hostess actually walked up and tried to take our menus before we had even ordered drinks.

finally the waiter approached us, and we were ready to order drinks/food since we had limited time. The waiter nodded that he was ready to hear our order, so we rattled off "green tea for us both, 2 rolls, cucumber salad, seaweed salad and hamachi nigiri" 15 minutes later our salads arrive. still no tea. Then our rolls arrive, still no tea. he walks up and i ask him for the tea, and he has a blank look on his face. Having been a waitress, there is nothing wrong with writing down orders, especially if you cant even remember something as simple as tea. We finished our rolls, and realized we were still waiting on hamachi. At this point we were finished. we weren't going to wait another 20 minutes for 2 pieces of fish. Told him to cancel the order. he stared at me with a blank look, again. 

Although i think the sushi here is amazing, service is a huge part of my dining experiences, and this was pretty disappointing. I will probably go back, but i will not sit in this waiters section if i can help it. 

That being said, the cucumber crab salad was delicious, and the tekka roll was one of the best rolls ive had in quite some time, especially the crispy shiso inside the roll, i could eat just that roll and be satisfied.
author: Ania F.

description: The quality of the sushi was good. Nothing amazing. But the value is terrible. Really, it should be rated $$$ or $$$$. My wife and I went after having a lot of food at happy hour, spent $130 here, and left still hungry. The portions are tiny and very expensive. Expect to spend anywhere from $4-$10 per BITE. To top it off, the waiter offered to surprise us with a few items he liked, we accepted, and he served us the most expensive items, 4 bites of food for $40.
author: Cameron A.

description: Best sushi I have ever tried ! The sushi chef is very friendly! Luckily I got a seat without a reservation. Very poplar place!
author: Mengze Z.

description: Good sushi but very small portions and over priced. We sat at the sushi bar right in front of the chefs and they forgot to give us our food after 30 minutes of us waiting around! The chef was unfriendly and unhelpful when we asked for suggestions and made us feel unwelcome. Not worth another trip I know so many other places  with better service and food! P.S. I should have known that this place wouldn't be great when none of the workers are Asian lol
author: Deidra H.

description:
Had the omakase here last night, but wow the service level here is horrible... Slowest service I've experienced in months! For over 100 a person I expect to wait less than 25 minutes in between each dish... In fact, in between my meal the workers took sake shots... All in, I'm pretty disappointed.

Food wise everything was fresh and pretty solid. I recommend the wagyu + toro... And the uni.. Bomb..
author: James H.

description:
I've been going to Akiko's for over 6 years and I loved their sushi. It was fresh and tasty and interesting. I went there several months ago and it wasn't as good as it used to be but I chalked it up to an off day since every other time I'd been there over the last several years it'd been great. Then, a month or so ago I went there with a friend for lunch and they informed us that they had changed to being a  "reservations only restaurant". It was later in the day, around 1:30, and there were empty tables but even though the tables weren't reserved, they would not seat us because we did not have a reservation. 

I knew I was going to be in the city today and wanted to go there for lunch so I made a reservation. I went there with two friends and . . . wow wow wow - have they changed. They were AWFUL. I mean, amazingly bad. 

First of all, the menu was completely different from what was on their web-site. The web-site has their old menu which was fantastic but NOT what they're actually offering now. The old menu was focused mostly on sushi - some fresh and different combinations that were really great - with some traditional items like tempura and teriyaki. The new menu is a menu you would see on any average Japanese restaurant anywhere in the bay area. Tempura, teriyaki, some salads, some sushi, etc.  And the sushi options that remain on the menu are common sushi options you would find anywhere. Nothing interesting or innovative. 

Needless to say, we were all very disappointed but decided to go ahead and eat there. Wow, such a mistake. The prices on the menu are the same pricey prices which they had when they had an innovative menu and great food but sadly, the food was awful. Honestly some of the worst Japanese food I've had.

Friend #1 ordered a combination lunch of sashimi and tempura. The sashimi consisted of four different types of fish very thickly cut but was decent. He said he would give it a 7 out of 10 (which, to me, is scary for sashimi - since sashimi is raw fish, it should be a 10 out of 10 otherwise I'd be worried about the freshness). The tempura was horrible. Instead of the golden brown, crunchy and fluffy batter that tempura should have, the batter on these were a medium brown, hard as a rock, and greasy. Yuck.

Friend #2 decided to order some sushi. She ordered the spicy tuna and rainbow roll. In the past, the rainbow roll had vibrantly colored (hence "rainbow" roll), juicy, fresh fish on top. What came out today was pale and looked stale - you couldn't tell the different types of fish apart and it definitely did not resemble a rainbow. The spicy tuna looked like something you'd grab from the Safeway deli. In fact, they both looked that way.  Her assessment was that she'd give them about a 4 or 5 on a 10 scale.

Not seeing anything interesting on the menu, I thought I'd go with some Japanese standards so I went with a chicken teriyaki and tempura combo (yes, I know that JFC invented teriyaki as a way to sell soy sauce in America but my Japanese grandmother made great teriyaki and I love it, if it's good). The chicken consisted of 8 small slices of chicken that was grilled on one side - the non skin side - and not on the other so the skinless side had char marks and the skin side was flaccid and . . . can't even think of a word for it. A thin teriyaki sauce that was HEAVY with star anise or Chinese five spice flavoring (neither of which should be in teriyaki) was ladled over the chicken. The overpowering taste of the anise/five spice was really all you tasted so, not good. The tempura . . . well . . . see above. Yuck. 

We were all very disappointed since we have been going there for years and had high expectations. So, when the waiter brought our check, I asked him what happened and his response was to say that they can't continue to serve the same menu for 18 years without changing and that they were trying to move away from heavy fried foods to lighter, fresher, healthier options. The problems with this answer are:  1) yes you can if people love it and are ordering it which - they were; and 2) but . . . the original menu was lighter and fresher and healthier and the new menu has more deep fried, heavy stuff on it.  

I mentioned that the original menu was more innovative and fresher and better and that the new menu was more of a menu that you would see on any average Japanese restaurant and he said that they had great fish and they were trying to focus on that and do new and interesting things like fish soups and stuff - there were no fish soups on the menu and, frankly, his answer didn't make any sense. I kind of felt bad for him because I'm assuming that's what he's told to say but I really wanted to ask him, "Do you believe anything you're saying?" 

I heard that the son recently bought the restaurant from his parents and I'm guessing that's why the changes. So sad. Time to find a new sushi place. You've lost at least 10+ customers, just today (us + friends and family).
author: Patricia G.

description:
If you like trendy and overpriced then this is the place for you.  The first time we (3 of us) went for lunch we were turned away because we did not have reservations.  We made a reservation and returned the next day.

The quality of the food was very good however the quantity was extremely poor.  My meal was $30 and I left still wanting more. The menu is confusing and when I asked the waiter questions he was cold and abrupt.  The Sashimi arrived first but my colleague ordered a cooked dish that arrived when we were done.

With all the great Sushi in SF I'm not sure why anyone would eat here.  It was a disappointment and I would not return.
author: John C.

description:
Make sure you come to Akiko's Restaurant, NOT Akiko's Sushi Bar (auto result for "Akiko's" on Google Maps). You should make a reservation; they aren't always able to accommodate walk-ins or have long wait times (over 1 hour). 

Akiko's is on SF Chronicle's Top 100 Restaurants, so you know that this is some quality food. The menu looks like a standard Americanized Japanese restaurant (specialty rolls, nigiri, set dinners, etc), but the individual items tend to be more tapas-sized. 

- Negi Toro (MP, $15 that night): 5 pieces, with tuna belly/toro, scallion, pickled daikon, sesame. This is the best toro I've had; the fish is so tender and melts in your mouth. The additional flavors complement the fish without overpowering.

- Negihama ($10): 5 pieces, with yellowtail, scallion, shiso, sesame. Yellow tail is my go-to sashimi option because it's hard to mess up an inherently high quality fish. Akiko's does no wrong with this roll.

- Beef Nakimono ($13): We ordered the Hamachi Kama, but they had run out for the night (it was only 7PM!), so the waiter suggested we get the beef instead. The Niman Ranch beef is cooked medium and arranged in a tetris-fashion with Japanese pumpkin and carrots. I usually do not enjoy teriyaki-ed meat, but I was impressed by the beef quality. We ordered this after finishing our rolls and it took 20 minutes to come out, so order up front to avoid the wait.

I shared these three dishes with my friend, and we both felt that it was a light dinner. We probably should have ordered 2 more dishes to eat our fill, so I would probably tip Akiko's to a $$$ restaurant, rather than $$. The quality is worth the price tag, especially on the fish.
author: Jessica F.

description: Omakase for $100 had monkfish, uni, sashimi, and about 8 nigiri.  I liked it.  Nothing really unexpected but it was all fresh.  I would go again.  Next time I probably will just order nigiri.
author: Niniane W.

description:
I sear they are paying people to write glowing reviews. Because after my 3rd times here over the past year, this place is a constant disappointment and it gets more empty everytime.

My first time we ordered the omakase, everything was average and over priced. The food was warm? The heck?

2nd visit:we ordered akimo nigiri and rolls. The ankimo was fishy, gross! Other things belong in a super poor quality Americanize tourist trap restaurant. 

3rd time: ordered a few special if the day, uni, eel and their shahani and nigiri bento. 
The eel texture was rubber, the snapper had light sweet sauce on it to cover the poor taste and texture.  Tempura was decent as well as my grill mackarll. But for a bill of $ 120 for 2, the quality of food belongs in a shitty sushi place in the sunset that cost less then 50 bucks.
author: jasmin t.

description:
Great ambiance, courteous and helpful staff, take reservations.

We got the omakase and really loved the sashimi. However we also felt they seared too many of the other nigiri pieces. Don't get me wrong- everything we had was wonderful and there was no part of the omakase that I didn't like- we just preferred their lightly seasoned nigiri over their seared pieces. Their rice is also very unique and it just wasn't what we were looking for. Overall, they had an amazing selection of fish both from Japan and elsewhere and they pay attention to all the right details. I'd probably go back for their sashimi and more traditional nigiri, but don't think I'd splurge again for the omakase.
author: Mattheus K.

description: Terrible service!!!! Took 20 minutes just to bring miso soup. Other tables being served first. When asked about our order the waiter gave a rude answer saying it was "out of his control" and "are there any other concerns?" And they completely forgot an entree we ordered!!! Awful experience!!! Never again!!!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Akiko has been on my list to try for quite some time now. Finally had the chance to go last week and it definitely did not disappoint!
We didn't go for omakase this time since we heard it could take 2 hours, also we didn't sit at the bar to make the experience worthwhile.
We ordered a bunch of nigiri including:
Kanpachi
A5 Wagyu with truffle shavings: expensive, not sure if it was worh it.
Chutoro (Otoro was out that night, sad)
Normal nigi including salmon, barracudo etc...)
Everything was really good, the nama uni though, was the best uni I've ever had. My bf and I are not even uni lovers and we definitely loved the uni here! I can say now that I'm a convert!
For cooked dishes, we ordered the miso black cod, which is also the best black cod I've ever had. My bf and I were fighting over the dish.
The special of the night was bbq ribs (I know, a pretty weird choice for a sushi restaurant) but it was worth it.
Overall, I would come back and try the omakase. This place is def one of the best sushi places in SF.
author: Ngan B.

description:
Some other ones we have tried:

ume-madai - $10
sake shiro - $10
kurodai - $9
hotategai live - $16 - so good, sashimi and nigiri and the muscle cooked - so delicious!
hiramasa - $8
aji - $16
author: Gloria H.

description:
OMG. The sushi and sashimi are out of this world! The fish is so fresh (even though the sushi pieces are a bit small) and worth every penny of $7-$20/order (comes with 2 pieces per order)!!!
The staff is very helpful with the selection and friendly. The sushi does take a long time to come out though...but I attribute it to the sushi gurus putting extra love into each piece. I especially loved the kani (trust me on this), the seared salmon and the hotate (scallop).
For the cooked foods, I loved the hamachi kama and fried ika. YUM!
The hubs really enjoyed the amaebi, but he said the uni wasn't the freshest he's had. I don't eat either one, so can't help you there...
The place is really small, so make a reservation and come hungry!
author: C K.

description: Wonderful New Years Dinner.  We had a traditional New Years duck soup special that was phenomenal, essence of Umami rich duck flavor.  The fried silken tofu was melting and crunchy simultaneously and the mixed greens, as is always the case were well curated, arranged and dressed.  We love Akiko's rolls, had two.  The sashimi and sushi courses were perfect, we went for a combination starting with light white through medium and culminating in their aged fish offering.  All first rate.  Our server and all of the wait staff were the perfect combination of personable, efficient and knowledgable.
author: M W.

description:
Not only the best sushi in the Financial District, potentially the best sushi in the city. Bold statement? Yup, but it is exceptional.

The staff is friendly.
You'll need some time (hopefully you booked more than an hour).
The ambiance is nice.
You'll need a reservation.
The spicy scallop handroll and [variety] of Uni are amazing!
author: Bjorn P.

description:
Some of the freshest sushi I've had. Well seasoned and unique in flavor. I ordered a rainbow roll and miso soup. Delish! 

Side note, the bathrooms were spotless and the restaurant had great ambiance. Easy to miss when walking by though as the restaurant is unmarked, but I personally thought this added to the "cool" factor.
author: Olivia W.

description: Really good but a bit expensive if you are hungry. Try the hot sake by the way, it's excellent.
author: Toma G.

description:
Truly terrible, awful service. Our waiter was rude and a complete jerk with zero sense of courtesy or manners. Sushi is mediocre at best. I've had cheap sushi that was more satisfying than this. 

We had 8pm reservations for two and had to wait a bit for the table to clear. No problem, we get it. We were very excited to eat here so we were cool with it.

Got seated, knew what we wanted to order right away because we were waiting a while to get seated. Waited a very long time to get the waiter to even pay attention to us. Tried to flag him down  3 times and he finally came and took our order.

- Half the items on the menu were not available. 
- Wanted ikura nigiri, was told that they were out of ikura which boggles my mind. It's quite standard. 
- We were later served agedashi tofu WITH IKURA (see photo). So he lied. 
- Waiter knocked over my chopsticks. As in one of them flew into the air and then both fell onto the ground. Waiter didn't even apologize or pretend to be sorry. 
- Agedashi tofu was lukewarm and soggy. Sushi was extremely petite and not good quality
- Waiter forgot to put in an order for the roll we order.. Instead of apologizing or immediately offering to place the order he kept telling us we had no roll. We literally went back and forth 3+ times with him arguing that we didn't order the roll. I have no idea why we were even arguing. How hard is it to just place the order? We just wanted to eat. Waiter clearly does not have the word sorry in his vocabulary. Stone cold and unapologetic about everything. 
- He also forgot to put in an order of edamame for the table next to us. 
- Tried multiple times to flag waiter down to get the bill. My girl friend and I at one point were so bewildered by our awful experience (this place is rated really well) wondered if he had something against females and if he ignored/hated us because we weren't men. Everyone else seated around us were and he hustled to serve them. Yes, it was that bad. 

I don't believe for a second that this was a one-off. I think he just can't be bothered to act like a decent person and provide decent customer service. Manners and courtesy and the word "sorry" don't just completely disappear. Either you have it or you don't. 

I've talked to others and the sentiment is the same. Poor sushi, no passion, terrible service, know nothing about fish. All they care about is the money. Someone joked that Akikos is so terrible I should dump the guy that took me there (luckily my girl friend took me I adore her).
author: M K.

description:
I've never had omakase and upon hearing how great this place was, my hubs and I decided to try it out. Holy amazeballs of fish! The quality of the fish was exceptional and every piece we had was just mindblowing. You can tell that a lot of thought and detail went into each piece of fish.  It was an experience and I can see why people completely rave about this place. Truly, a terrific, terrific meal.

My only (relatively big) con is for noobs like me who don't truly understand how omakase works. The menu said it would range $80-100 and I figured with the quality of fish we got, it would be a little higher than that. What I wasn't prepared for was the $500 bill we got at the end of the meal that was NOWHERE close to the $80-100 listed on the menu. Yes, NOW I know that the price is based on the fish but I really wish they had told me this beforehand so I wouldn't have gotten such sticker shock at the end. This is probably just me since I didn't know what to expect getting omakase but it kind of ruined the dinner for me. It's not great when you're half expecting a bill around $250-300 and then you get a bill that's actually $500. Even a little warning would have be nice (maybe they assumed we knew but unfortunately, we did not. 

Logistics: make a reservation a few weeks ahead on OpenTable and let them know you want to eat omakase so they can try to seat you at the sushi bar.
author: Diana Y.

description:
After duly booking 2 months in advance (this place was always full when we tried to go on the fly), my husband and I finally had an exquisite dinner at Akiko.

The ambiance is a mix of modern and Japanese, with wood everywhere and very nice finishing. It puts you at ease as soon as you walk in: you're going to have an intimate atmosphere and privacy throughout the meal.

We ordered the sashimi tasting menu, edamames and the egg roll, with a bottle of nigori sake. We were very satisfied with all of it. The sashimi tasting was amazing - almost as good as what we had in the Tokyo harbour! It amply accommodates 2, with a side like edamames. We were a little disappointed by the egg roll though - the rolls were too big and not as delicious. My husband really enjoyed the sake (he's the connaisseur here). Overall, a very good meal.

The staff was courteous and not "all over us", which I really appreciate. I would definitely recommend it, but remember to book in advance!
author: Valentine A.

description:
As I sit here hoping the frequent bathroom trips will stop after being in agony for hours now, I curse myself for not walking out during the meal.

I am allergic to avocado. It's one of those allergies that most people can't believe but it's true. My bodily reaction to having avocado is one I wish no one would have to suffer....except maybe my worst enemy.

We were enjoying our omakase when I noticed avocado on the bar. It wasn't that much cause for alarm, at first, until a couple dishes later.

My bf had gotten the attention of the chef and said we can't eat that - I'm allergic - to which the chef smiled and nodded assuring us it was for the roll.

I noticed, one dish later, my tongue started to tingle and my throat felt a little tighter and then the tell-tale stomach pain started creeping on. As I looked at the bar, I saw what the chef was doing. There he was scooping out the avocado and wiping the spoon on the same towel that he used to wipe his hands, the blade, and the board he was using - repeatedly. He would do this with more rolls and I was mortified.

If someone tells you they have an allergy - be respectful. Maybe have someone else (there were 2 other chefs) handle the rolls or get a clean towel. Do not use the same tools that can contaminate the food.

I'm sticking to Maruya - it's far superior - and it is roll and avocado free.
author: DeLune Avec DeBussy B.

description:
I wasn't WOW by the experience. Having  high expectation and was craving for good sushi from Akiko's didn't help. I was disappointed with the rice. It was sour and mushy.
The sourness taste sucks with me throughout the dinner.

Follow what most suggested from the reviews...we had the omakase. The choice of fishes was good and fresh. Two side dishes ( he age dashi and crab cucumber side was made to perfection), a sashimi platter with hamachi, sake, and albacore, followed with 8-10 pieces of nigiri ( ankimo, truffle ikura w/ sage, uni, madai, and kodai) and soup full of hokkaido crab) and end with chu toro -- fatty tuna. Lastly, dinner ended with sesame and red bean mochi.=)

Ambience was nice however the ventilation was bad. 

Service was definitely a 4 stars.
author: Theresa T.

description:
Very good sushi and by the far the best sushi in the area.

Lovely ambiance, unobtrusive service (traditional Japanese), wide variety of options on the menu, and excellent recommendations if you trust your server and the sushi chefs (you're silly if you don't). I often do 50/50 - pick what I 'must' have and have them pick the rest.

Every time I visit, I hear a lot of Japanese patrons. Very good sign.

Arrigato, Akiko's - you rule the 'hood for sushi.
author: Meredith R.

description:
It's impossible for me to take a trip to San Francisco without trying to find some good sushi. This place looked like it could be good, so I gave it a shot.

This place does not have a sign on the outside. I showed up to the approximate location it should have been on the map, looked inside the building, and saw a sushi bar. It turned out to be the correct one.

I sat down, and just asked the chef to make me 8-10 pieces of sushi. As far as I'm concerned, you can't tell how good a sushi place is unless you have omakase. 

I'm not entirely certain what everything I had was, but here are a few of the selections that stood out:
baby barracuda - this cured fish had a light, but distinct, flavor, not as briny as more common cured fish like mackerel.
scallops - fresh and delicious. Not hard to find scallops, but when they're done right, it's a treat.
Russian uni - I'm not sure where they got this, but it seems like it's not quite as sweet as its West Coast counterpart.
