Toro hand roll - I requested this one; very well done, with pieces of pickled radish to augment the flavor.
kinki - AKA shortspine thornyhead aka idiot fish. Turns out this little guy is endangered! Mark that one off the list...

This wasn't all; it's just what I recall off the top of my head. I also had tamago made with a chicken stock that made it some of the most distinct, and tasty, tamago I have tasted. 

Besides offering a whole slew of interesting fish, the chef just did it right. The rice was the right temperature, the fish was perfectly garnished, and it was just one of the best flavor rides I have enjoyed.

As far as price is concerned, you can always expect to spend north of $100 on a meal like this, but considering the quality, it really wasn't too far north. The other places I have been in SF (Sakana and Sanraku) were both good, but I think Akiko's is the first place I have found in SF that I'd consider a top 5 sushi experience.
author: Jeremy P.

description: weekday dinner reservations...table seating omakase....prefer sushi bar, but full...starting with compressed cooked spinach...tangy saucing and light start...mouthful of lump crab nigiri and ankimo delicious...white tuna, trout and salmon fresh...silky melting uni fine...fish slicing generous and great, but distracted by the sushi rice...questioning the rice used...told a red vinegar seasoned rice...giving brownish/reddish colors...unusual earthy tangy odor...finding a bit unpleasant...rice was too hard and dry...undercooked texture also unpleasant...remaining nigiri courses of seared, seasoned and unique good...$265 omakase dinner for two...going little over menu stated pricing, but pre-warned before ordering...
author: Hen A.

description:
I want to say right away that the sushi in this place are out of control! 
BUT
the service is out of control too. Sadly, it is not so great.
We booked our dinner for 6:45 a week ahead (because nothing closer was available).
As we roll in the hostess tells us that it's fine if we want to sit at the bar (we asked it with our reservation), but they have another reservation at 8 and we have to be kinda quick. It is a bit tight for dinner and we were about to have omakase! So we request to be seated at a table if that will give us more time, but none of the tables are available either.
Isn't it what reservations are for? How are they expect people to eat dinner during 1 hour?

The sushi were great! Each and every bite of it was the burst of flavors! I just wish we had more time to enjoy it.
author: Kate A.

description:
Damnit, Asia has spoiled me when it comes to Asian food. Especially Japanese food. 
Freshly flown fish from Japan with authentic sushi chefs in Japanese run restaurants was the norm in Singapore. I like not fully understanding the Japanese chefs as they proudly display their craft. I like the traditional look and feel of the small Japanese establishments that made you feel like you were in the real deal.

I should've known I was in for a rude awakening when we walked past the Caucasian and Southeast Asian sushi chefs at the bar. Multicultural staff, which I can appreciate in most settings but the Asian in me doesn't like it in my Asian restos (I mean, imagine if you had a multicultural staff serving you in a Chinese restaurant... the first thing I would do is RUN). But hey, I'm in SF now and gotta accept the fact. 

But then we get relegated to the back room in the back corner by the bathroom. It was like being in a tiny little cave where you could here everyone's conversations (or at least they could hear ours, I'm fairly sure). 

To be fair, the food was decent. The sashimi, while cut in a fairly nontraditional fashion, was fresh and not grainy or sinewy. The salmon teriyaki, while a tiny portion, was melt-in-your-mouth tender. The rolls, while with slightly too acidic and moist rice, were fairly generous. 

But was it enough for me to return? Not until I get rid of this long-drawn Asia hangover...
author: Vic C.

description:
Food quality was on average OK. The rice for the nigirizushi was not at the appropriate temperature or stickiness. Specifically, it was too cold and too crumbly. 

After placing my order, I was informed that the restaurant was out of both Amaebi and Uni. However, the same server who informed me of the lack of amaebi set down a pair of nigiri and announced it as "Amaebi." It was not amaebi, but some other set of shrimp pieces. Curiously, I later saw a set of proper amaebi prepared. 

Later in the evening, I heard an order placed by a server for uni. Additionally, I overheard my server asking a colleague to make sure a certain couple left the restaurant soon, because, "they had been there too long". 

The workers behind the counter were incredibly disorganized, made several errors with getting orders correct, and in general, lacked professionalism in their conduct.

Sushi is one of my favorite things, and the quality of the food and the staff at Akiko's Restaurant is subpar. I recommend Saru Sushi, Sushi Ran, and Domo. 


My Order
Tea 4/10 (tasted like watered down Jasmin tea)
Agedashi Dofu 8/10
Miso Soup 6/10
Chicken Udon 7/10

Nigiri
Hamachi 7/10
Sake 5/10
Unagi 6/10
Uni n/a
Tamago 8/10
Inari (never arrived)
Amaebi 2/10
Hotate 6/10
author: Bradley T.

description: Highly dissatisfied with the service and the sashimi tasting (12pc), multiple pieces were discolored and tasted terrible. I did order some decent nigiri, which is why this review is 2 stars as opposed to 1. The service was just as bad, maybe because 4 young adults dont have a lot of money? Even though our bill hit around $300. Our server was a male with long hair on the top and shaved sides, just a heads up if you end up getting him. We didnt even receive a thank you when leaving.....
author: Nick M.

description:
I LOVE their sushi. Sashimi is a must here. Everything is fresh. Service was wonderful. Def will be coming back.

TIP: you will be needing a reservation unless you luck out on a slow day.
author: Hepsie C.

description: I would eat here at least once a month, on occasion once a week. They have a great selection of sashimi/nigiri and I particularly love their Saba Shio-yaki. I used to be able to walk-in but these days it takes some planning but it's worth it.
author: Leia R.

description:
Quality sashimi, melts in your mouth.  Artfully crafted.   Menu has a long variety of nigiri or sashimi ranging $5-$8 (2 pieces), a few specialty rolls ranging $8-$14 (8 pieces), and the small rolls ranging $5 (6 small pieces).  Also, udon and other appetizer items.

Omakase is a sitting of 2 hours minimum where the server brings the chef's recommendations (approximately 13-14 pieces) priced around $100-$120 depending on what is offered to you (each piece is itemized on the bill later).  Choice of nigiri or sashimi for the omakase order.

Big selection of sake and wines.  Must make reservations (they were turning away walk-ins all night)!
author: Ju D.

description: Closer to a traditional Japanese Sushi/Sashimi restaurant. Nigiri Sushi Omakase; best was barracuda. Chef uses curing, cold smoking, searing to bring out and accentuate specific fish textures. Unique approach. Excellent experience.
author: Doug C.

description: I highly recommend this sushi place! It is classy, delicious and affordable, which is rare in SF. We had sushi rolls and LOVED the Tekka roll and Gyo steak.  I don't normally eat slowly, but every bite needed to be savored slowly because it was so flavorful.  The service was great too and you can make reservations online, which was very helpful in the city, especially on New Year's Eve.
author: Crissy V.

description:
This is a short and quick review to provide my 4 star rating.

Decor: nice and modern. 

Staff: fun and friendly 

Food: a very nice menu selection. Quality of food was very good. No complaints. The Wagyu beef with shaved truffle was delicious and my most memorable dish there

Service: quick and on point

Get Reservations..come early. We were the first customers when they opened...sat sushi bar as always...ordered everything my stomach and eyes wanted at the time.

Overall, no complaints. Akiko serves good food with a friendly smile. But for me, it was missing something...maybe a down to earth and not so swanky vibe? Iono...something...for some reason i can't really put a finger on it. I just know that I don't really care to come back. I came, I saw, I ate, and it was cool. My typical re.visits in the bay are ichi, sushi ran & sushi sams...I think of themmmm when my mouth craves for sushi... :) Akiko is just not in my thoughts.

I do recommend this place though as I am confident they will not disappoint
author: .I I.

description:
Yummy sushi! Very fresh with is the most important thing in sushi.... 
Small and cozy, definitely recommended. 4 stars because its a bit pricy for the small portions and there is no atmosphere.
author: Yana A.

description:
Akiko was good but damn dude the price is outrageous. 

I'm not going to say Aliko is not good, it's good but I can't say that it's worth the cost. $32 for a 6 piece nigiri sampler?  Come on guys, you aren't exactly Nobu here. 

Two people for lunch and $140 later I was still hungry. Look, I'm not cheap or a fatty that needs a buffet but the ROI just isn't there to endorse Akiko. I wish I could but it is just not worth it.
author: Austin Y.

description: Nice vibe and decor. But like one previous Yelp review, I too sat infront of the sushi chef who appeared to have "dirty nails". Despite how good the sushi was, the nails were a distraction... I needed answers! As I was about to exit I pulled one of the waiters aside and politely raised the question. He told me the chef got that from sharpening the blade and that leaves a stain. Ah, at last mystery solved.
author: Jazz Z.

description:
Mmmm the cucumber salad is light and sweet with the perfect amount of crab. Miso soup.
Rainbow roll.  I am in love.
Very fresh fish.  Interesting ambiance.  Great service.
author: Jamie P.

description: Great ambience, high quality sushi! The happy hour is so worth a visit!
author: Christina H.

description: Akiko's Omakase was abosolutely memorable.  There are meals that you dont forget, and Akiko's Omakase is that!  From beginning to end these guy knew what they were doing.   At first glance of the menu i knew this meal was going to have my sushi mind blown.  They had Russian uni!  I never even knew Russia had uni this good, absolutely buttery with a bite of the ocean. The pomfret with kelp reduction was out of this world.  We had hokkaido sardine and believe me these sardines are not the same one that came out of can, buttery with a flash of  savoriness.  I can go on and on about how great this meal was, but the only way to really know is to experience it for yourself.  This is one of those meals that is not to be missed in the bay area!
author: Win L.

description:
Let me preface by mentioning that I absolutely LOOOOVE sashimi and would go out of my way to get my fix.  Having heard good things about Akiko's, I was excited to come here for a friend's birthday.  However, good quality sashimi does not give you a free pass on customer service.  

THE STORY (skip to the bottom for review of the food)
I went with a group of 4 around 2pm on a weekday.  Note: this time was already past the downtown lunch rush.  My party of 4 wanted to sit close to coworkers who were also a party of 4.   Akiko's told us that they do not seat groups.  Given the size of the restaurant and their tendency to be busy, we understood.  

However when we looked inside the restaurant, we saw that they had two empty tables next to each other, both of which sat four.  "Perfect, both our parties could take up those two tables!"  Or so we thought.  When we asked the hostess if we could sit at those two tables, she told us that she would ask her manager.  We told her that we would not change the seating arrangement (out of respect for them), but would just like to sit closer to one another.  She asked her manager who told her no and that our parties would have to sit at separate tables.  

Let's stop and think about this for a second.  Two separate parties, check.  Two open tables, check.  No problem, right?

The manager, a younger gentleman who stayed in the office, came out to speak with us.  He did not look happy.  When our group tried to explain that it was a coworkers birthday and that we would like to respectfully take the two, four person tables to enjoy lunch, he repeated that they did not seat groups.  We asked why this was not possible since we would not move the tables together.  He only looked annoyed and sarcastically said, "Well, you guys will be talking to each other won't you?  I think that's called a group."  

This was shocking to us since we did not expect a manager to behave in this manner.  Not wanting to push the matter further, one party took a table of four closer to the door while the other party was seated on the other side of the room.  To add salt to the wound, the manager promptly seated the other open table with another party of four.  Even the hostess apologized multiple times for her manager's behavior.

THE FOOD
I had the chef's special, seaweed salad, and the agedashi tofu.  I must say that the seaweed salad was a delightful little appetizer being fresh with just the right amount of crunch.  The agedashi tofu was soft and the sauce was light enough to add flavor but not overpowering.  The cuts of sashimi were a good size, soft and buttery - though a few were stringy.  Honestly, I have had better sashimi for the same price elsewhere.  I enjoyed the appetizers most, though.

In conclusion, the food was decent, but I expect better service.  Two stars.  We will not be coming back again.

EDIT IN RESPONSE TO RAY'S COMMENT
Hi Ray,

Your response to my review tells me a lot about how much you care about your customers.  (I guess I should have known from the way we were treated at your restaurant.)

Let me explain to you, again, how I felt.

Although it was frustrating that you do not seat groups (my party complied to your policy), it was your attitude that pushed me over the edge.  Was it really necessary to make such a snide comment to your guests? 

We were polite.  We were respectful.  There was no reason for us to be treated the way we were no matter how good you think your restaurant is.  As the owner, you should have been the prime example of excellent customer service.  This, however, seems too much to ask.
author: Kristy L.

description:
I come to Akiko's whenever I get major sushi cravings. (Remember, when making reservations make sure it is Akiko's on BUSH street, not Akiko's sushi bar on Mason... !! )

This place is the Sh*t. If you want good, sophisticated sushi, there is no better place in the city than Akiko's.

They do sushi right, and they also have their own style. Chef Ricky and his team are constantly experimenting and coming up with innovative styles of sushi making, they also do really creative a la carte dishes. 

The atmosphere is never tense like traditional sushi restaurants. I like Akiko's more than most sushi joints because the last thing I want to feel to be TENSE. No phones no photography no loud laughters kinda place... = not for me.

My most recent visit on my friends birthday was absolutely mind blowing. Chef Ricky and his team went above and beyond to make my bestie's sushi dinner feast an incredibly memorable one.

This is without a doubt my favorite sushi place in the city. Come spend your money here at the sushi bar and I promise you, you will not regret it.
author: Amber S.

description:
UH, YUM.

I'm sure this is mentioned already but me and a girlfriend walked passed this at least 3 times following the dot on google maps in confusion. Doh, there's no sign! Clearly addresses mean nothing to us.

Back to the YUM part. You should probably get the beef teriyaki and sashimi combo. I was never a sashimi gal until Akiko charmed me with all the big fish descriptions and cute plating. The beef was frikken steak and damn it was heaven.. but truly, it was all tasty and I wish I had more but I didn't want to pay $20 for another meal and look like a fatass.

Small place, I'd make a reservation. Actually I think you have to lol.
author: Ally J.

description: Definitely a good spot for sushi in San Francisco!! It is located next to the Irish pub! When I was there, no sign was in front if the restaurant, so I almost missed it. This place is quite popular with a wide selection of local fish to impaired fish from Japan. Therefore I would recommend any potential visitors to make a reservation! My personal recommendation is the Wagyu Beef sushi!!
author: Ben R.

description:
This place is one of the best, if not the best, sushi places I've been to. As a sushi-lover, I've gone to a fair share of sushi restaurants but this one tops it all. 
The different, unique types of sashimi they have are heavenly and fit all tastes. You can tell the chef and the servers are genuinely happy to work there and share their love of their food. Our server recommended the best fish and when they were out of the ones we chose, gave us alternatives that were delicious. The service is amazing and the ambience is very relaxed and welcoming. Definitely a place you should try for all true sushi lovers.
author: Margaret K.

description:
The food was great, it was an interesting experience. 
A bit pricy though: I had about 10 different pieces of nigiri and 2 beers and the price was 100$ just for myself without including the tip.

It was my first night in town, I had just arrived from the other side of the Ocean and had no internet on my phone. 

When I asked for the wifi password to the girl at the entrance she replied "I'm sorry sir we don't give out the wifi password" it was insulting for such a 'fancy' place to not have the courtesy of sharing their wifi.

3 stars because it was REALLY expensive and because of the wifi rudeness. 

It was good, but definitely over priced.
author: Antonio S.

description: Friendly service. Surprisingly decent pricing, if you don't drink. I did get some sort of rash on my face after eating here. No, I'm not kidding. I think it was the scallop.
author: Ina H.

description:
You know you are in an authentic Japanese  restaurant when you are surrounded by WIERD people. We are sandwiched between 2 utterly awkward first date couples. The fat japanese guy on the right somehow lands a pretty date,  but is running on fumes trying to maintain a conversation. I dont speak full Japanese but a staring contest reads awkward in any language. He reminds me of the classic japanese TV series, 101th proposal. 

The guy on my right is the polar opposite. He is rapping out his glorious life story to the (quite interested) girl across the table, voice cracking now and then with excitement. When he laugh,  he's would clap and have face banged on the table,  and make exaggerated pose. The girl would giggle with "oh you are so funny".... Before our dinner is served, we've already learned about his CEO mom and professor dad... mmmmKay.

Oh, the food? It was DELICIOUS. 

Update, to our right was actually a girl and her gay friend, what a twist to the story!
author: Cheng F.

description: I like the service. The fish was very fresh but the skill needs some improving. For even the basic rolls, the cut was quite uneven and for sushi, the rice was too loose. Overall, I feel the menu is overpriced.
author: Sydney C.

description: Ordered the omakase and it was pretty delicious. It's been awhile so can't recall exact menu but I recall that everything was delectable and perfectly done. It's hard to find with no clear signs. It's cozy inside and simple but elegant decor.
author: Ina K.

description: Wow!!!! So delish!!! My husband and I know our sushi and are really picky.  This place fits the bill.  We had the chef pick some of the freshest fish out for us and ...just wow.  Make a reservation or prepare to wait up to 30ish min. Our bill was $250 but honestly worth every penny.  We did have a moderately priced sake.
author: Steffany D.

description:
Misguided, disorganized, expensive sushi here. They aim high the sushi chefs clearly know what they're doing (beautiful presentation, perfect rice, some nice fish) but it's as if somebody doesn't know how to run a restaurant or doesn't care or maybe they just got out of the wrong bed this morning. 

Staff came in a few minutes late and was hand carrying wine bottles in the front door past 5-6 parties that had come early to score a walk-in. They took a long while to seat us, then a while to order in the bright mid-afternoon summer haze. Our first appetizer, a delicious wakame (seaweed) salad arrived almost instantly but despite telling them we didn't have much time and their telling us they needed the table soon for a reservation, the other apps took a full 20 minutes at which time the waiter said that three of the 7-8 items we had ordered were out, basic stuff like agedashi tofu. Are they having management problems? Somebody had a car accident? Kitchen explosion?

A few of the dishes were beautiful, ankimo was sublime. The kappa roll -- thin slice of cucumber in a skinny roll, a pure test of sushi hand skills -- was flawless. Other dishes were over-seasoned and swimming in a pool of cloying sauce. This is the kind of place that serves each sushi selection on its own expensive plate (they use Heath Ceramics here), and where the chef adds exactly as much wasabi and sauce as he thinks is proper -- which is way too much, as if he's anticipating American tastes -- so you don't have to. The exception was the humble kappa roll, for which they pre-poured a deep portion of homemade soy sauce into oversized bowls (which, manners-wise, is considered rude if you do it, the Japanese equivalent of pouring half a bottle of ketchup on your plate next to the fries). Nevermind, they were nice bowls, the soy sauce was delicious, and it was the best item of the night.

A word about the bathroom. It looked just fine. But it has a door that nobody can figure out how to lock and a motion sensing faucet that is completely unintuitive to use, I think you have to pat it on top like it's a dog. To compensate there is a hand-written sign, in sloppy handwriting, taped to the bathroom backsplash wall where the mirror should be (there is no mirror) with colorful carpet tape of all things, with an unhelpful explanation that nobody understands. How long has this place been open? What are they thinking? If there's a problem with the bathroom, please fix it for goodness sake. At most restaurants at this price point you would expect stuff like this to be fixed on the first night before start of service.

If the service, and maintenance, and menu concept were as good as the chef skills and plating presentation, Akiko's could justify its 4 and 5-star Yelp reviews, and perhaps even its high price. As it is, they have to do better if they are going to last.

At least we didn't order too much. You know how sometimes after eating unfulfilling sushi you feel like going out for a hamburger? After we left Akiko's we felt like going out for sushi, which we did, at a much less expensive place that technically wasn't nearly at the same level of sushi skill, but was a lot more fun and enjoyable and satisfying.
author: Gil S.

description: I think this is actually the best sushi I've ever had. Excellent food, great service, and a cool vibe. Reservations are a good idea!
author: Sam T.

description: Great food and atmosphere.  Blackfin tuna otoro and scallop were the best I have ever had.
author: Sean C.

description:
This is one of those reviews I hate to write because I want to be able to get a reservation there next time I need one. ;)

Akiko's on Bush Street is very likely the best sushi in the city. 

It isn't just the fancy stuff with truffles and Wagu or the uni, it was basics; the albacore nigiri, the sake, the hamachi. It was simply the best, creamiest albacore I have ever tasted and I've eaten sushi 1-3 times a week for 30 years. Sliced just right, it is worth every penny. Why? Because I am still fantasizing about it 5 weeks later.(I tried to go back last week but there wasn't a reservation until the following Tuesday :( Not even if I wanted to eat dinner at 5:30.
 
We let the chef choose and he didn't hold back! Everything was amazing and being surprised with what would come next was half the fun. Each serving an edible art show, we gasped "wow" as the chef handed it over the counter like Haute couture coming out the curtain and down the runway. Bill came to $300 for 2 of us including tip; for the quality, I think it was well Worth the price. Impressed by each selection - every dish made our eyes light up!  It all tasted even better than it looked.  I think that it is out of my budget to go there as often as I'd like, (three times a week) but then again, how often does a bill for 2 hit over $125 - $150 for something completely forgettable? Perhaps we should eat out less, and spend more. 

Best sushi in San Francisco in my opinion.
author: Robin K.

description: Great find - loved the sunomono and calamari starters - both were sharp and slightly spicy. The udon and sashimi deal is wonderful - a huge bowl of udon noodles and a side of four pieces of sashimi. The fish is fresh and prepared with love - and I am not going to complain about the portion size, because I love my fresh fish. I must have been a bear in a past life...
author: Angie C.

description: Low key, high quality.  Amazing sushi, and comfortable enough for a novice.  We loved it!
author: Jamie L.

description:
I went twice to this restaurant. The first time I had a 3-4 star experience. The second time, however, I did not. Here is what happened.

I had a 6:30 dinner reservation for a party of 1 on a Saturday. I arrived promptly to the restaurant and checked in with the hostess. She checked me in and lead me to the bar. I looked at the bar stool and it did not have a back support. I told the hostess that I have a back problem and the bar stool will not provide me w/ the needed support. She said that tables are reserved for parties of 2, even though I was seated before at a table w/o asking, and that they are fully booked and that she will try to find a table.

Scanning around a restaurant, I could see that they had 3 open 2-tops and 2 open 4-tops along w/ 2 open bar stools.

She got back to me and said that if I want a table, I have to wait, and that my seating will be limited to an hour. I told her that I was planning to have the omakase and that an hour is not enough. She said that I have to set at the bar if I am to get the omakase.

She made me feel that my reservation was less valuable than other reservations. I was about to spend $150+ and I was not about to risk back pain for that. I told the hostess that I was not about to risk getting back pain and left.
author: H N.

description: Let me start by saying that the food was exquisite.  Probably some of the freshest fish I have ever eaten, expertly prepared and arranged into beautiful sushi. So, why the 2-star rating?  Well, my friends and I were relaxing after our delicious, Friday evening dining experience - enjoying our wine, etc. - and our bill was brought to us by the hostess. As she was placing the bill on the table and giving the "thank-you" spiel, she says "I'm sorry, but this table is now reserved for another party."  Like seriously, as I'm looking over a bill where 3 people just dropped $450, _that's_ what you're going to tell me?!?  You've just spent a lot of money and now you've overstayed your welcome?!??  We were so shocked we didn't know what to say!!  But I will say here that with that one statement, yesterday evening's went from one of my best dining experiences to one where I cannot recommend this establishment to my friends.
author: Trudi B.
Johnny T.

description: Fish is great and fresh. I think they just need to replace the hostess with a friendlier one and better attitude. Otherwise, I have no complement on the food and the waiter.
author: Christopher L.

description:
A very nice Japanese sushi located near chinatown and downtown. I saw the really good yelp reviews so I decided to come here. I think that it is a little overpriced for my taste, but the quality of the fish and the rolls make it worth it. The california rolls were made from real crab. But since I'm not a sushi expert, I didn't think this was super outstanding.

Pro:
+ very nice interior
+ excellent service
+ fresh cuts of fish
+ presentation was gorgeous

Con:
- small servings, only about 5-6 pieces per roll (I had to order 3 rolls, with each roll around 7 or 8 dollars)
-beef teriyaki was a little hard

Tips
+make reservations!
author: Carmen C.

description:
Loved this place! I would highly recommend this place to anyone who loves sushi! 

Make sure you don't walk right by the place, there's no signage!
author: Kiran J.

description:
Great food! Salmon Nigiri, Albacore Tuna sashimi and Mango Mochi were my favs.

The place doesn't have any sign 
:)
author: P D.

description:
Located in an Irish Bank? Came here to try the omakase due to the reviews.  
Service - 4 stars - staff was attentive, refilled our drinks and took our dishes away consistently.  It helps that we sat at the bar, next to the kitchen.

Food - 4 stars - sushi was above ave quality.  We were served 15 different dishes.  Fish was fresh, but felt certain dishes were underwhelming.  Although, i would say about half of the dishes were amazing.  Presentation was great, as the chef was very detailed. Soy sauce is tastey, although I dont use much of it when eating high quality sushi.

Value - 3 stars - although the quality of the sushi here is higher quality than most sushi restaurants, the value isn't.  I've spent 2/3rds less for comparable omakase quality back in orange county. The price of omakase here is based on what the chef adds during the meal, so you wont know the final bill until you open the little black book at the end.  All the other places I've been to have set prices for omakase.  Be prepared to spend here.  

Atmosphere - 4 stars - place is nice and clean. There is a japanese/ lounge feel to this place.  There is a modern feel, with artsy sushi plates instead of just wooden blocks.
author: Blaise U.

description:
I've heard about Akiko's but finally got a chance to try it for dinner.  My friend brought me here and I had no idea what the name of the restaurant was until we sat down.  It's a great spot for dinner or a date located near Union Square/FiDi.

Food:

Agedashi Tofu (pass on this dish, not served traditionally and really over done)

Uni Nigiri/Salmon Sashimi/Hamachi Sashimi: Really fresh fish and reaffirmed my love for California based uni.  Their uni was from Santa Barbara.

Volcano Roll: Their house special shrimp tempura roll topped with lots of goodness such as salmon skin and tempura bits.  I couldn't find the sushi underneath but definitely worth trying if you're looking for what they're known for.

Spicy Tuna Roll: I like the kick it has to it with the spicy tuna and cucumer and avocado.

Will definitely be back here again!  Great service, my water was never empty and the staff was really nice.
author: Carli F.

description:
One of the best sushi places in San Francisco.  

Backstory:
It's a pretty old mom 'n' pop place and the "mom" and "pop" are actually there, working in the back to prepare some delicious Japanese cuisine.  Apparently their son has now modernized the place and oversees the restaurant. Cool right?

Anyways, the layout and decor of the restaurant is very chic, but casual.  There is pretty much no chance to get a table for dinner unless you make a reservation (which you conveniently can via opentable).  Apparently, for lunch it's a little different considering they get the financial district's lunch hour crowd.  

My boyfriend and I sat at the sushi bar and were amazed at the freshness of the fish.  We tried a variety of sashimi including umimasu (australian ocean trout), walu (seared escolar), kanpachi (amberjack), the black tuna and many more!

Everything was so fresh and amazing.  Don't go if you are a fan of chicken teriyaki or california rolls, because Akiko's is not that type of place.

Tip: When making a reservation, request the sushi bar - you will learn a lot about the fish from the entertaining sushi chefs!
author: Juliana K.

description:
We had a wonderful experience last night at Akiko's! The nigiri were perfect, I loved the Tonkatsu, the fish is incredibly fresh, and there's a wide variety of options to choose from - most coming straight from Japan.

We asked for a recommendation on the sake, and were not disappointed!

We wouldn't recommend the Passion Fruit Saketini however.
author: Olivier L.

description:
Ok the sushi is very good.     And the location is just a few blocks off union square.    Know that the place is TINY ie tokyo style light woods w a few tables looking at the sushi chef.    
The fish I'd fresh and delicious.     And service is very kind.    
Thank you YELP for suggesting.
author: chris b.

description:
My husband and I came here for my birthday dinner, 
We both order omakase, and It was really delicious and super fresh!

My husband found his favourite uni here recommended by our server. 
He is really helpful by introducing us the courses, and make sure we have enough water at all time. 

But I asked for a quieter seat, so I was expecting like corner area.
It is relatively a small place, so they squeezed us in the middle
author: Abby L.

description:
Unnecessarily rude manager. 

Came to our table once our meal was finished to say that there was an $85 minimum (per person!) for a party of 5. Not including drinks. What? 

Who can eat $85 worth of food. And who should have to?

We left so upset we had a second dinner at Tadich grill a few blocks away which was significantly better!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Been here three times and omakase is the only way to go. 

Great service and chill cozy atmosphere. 

Fantastic sake menu. 

Reservations are a must and if you don't lock it down.  Good luck. 

If you're looking for dragon rolls and other strip mall sushi nonsense you best turn around and give your seat up to someone who appreciates a quality sushi experience. 

Highly recommend this place but not for the novice sushi eater.
author: Ro S.

description:
I don't agree with Michael Bauer much, but when I do it's when he gives 3 out of 4 stars (which means it's HELLA GOOD. No, I'm not quoting Bauer's rating scale).

http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Akiko-s-is-a-sushi-classic-in-the-making-4833728.php
author: Al L.

description:
Akiko's was fantastic - higher quality sushi and generally good service!

-We ordered the omakase and enjoyed the variety.
-We ordered hot sake and came in a really cool warming pot.
-Had pieces from Tsukiji which was really great.
-The sea urchin was not as 'oceany' as one would find at most places.

Would recommend! Wasn't a 4 out of 5 because attentiveness to service could have been a little better (relative to the prices you're paying for the experience) and we have had better in the Bay Area. Nonetheless good experience.
author: Raymond C.

description: A bit disappointed by the quality of the sashimi but overall it's a nice experience. It's more like a 'fushion', than authentic Japanese restaurant. The sushi is not bad, very good firmness in the brown rice,  which is pretty surprising to me.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
Came for a late lunch while visiting and was able to get a table without a reservation given that we would not take over an hour. I heard it was a little hard to get a table here so I guess we just lucked out. 

The selection was pretty decent and fresh, although not exceptionally so. I enjoyed the ankimo and umimasu, but otherwise wasn't blown away as far as sushi experiences go (especially at that price point).
author: Daniel L.

description:
Great sushi place in downtown
The hamachi kama is good 
Nigiris and sashimi are fresh 
Nice atmosphere and great service. Highly recommend!
author: Peetas M.

description:
I'm not sure that Akiko's is *the best* sushi in the city, but I would recommend it to friends.

- Most of the 4/5 star ratings pertain to Akiko's omakase offerings, so do that if you and your wallet are in the mood. Otherwise, their standard menu fare is not worth a special visit. If you don't like surprise bills, ask how much that day's omakase will cost. 

- Don't expect every single bite to be mind-blowing-- that's a pretty unreasonable expectation even for Michelin-starred restaurants. You're going to get a mix of decent everyday items with some imported/wild-caught items that change throughout the year based on availability. The opportunity to taste the latter is what you're really paying for when you do omakase here. 

- From the previous reviews, it sounds like they don't always provide the friendliest service, but they were plenty accommodating on our visit. Be polite and keep reminding yourself that you are not the Queen of England (unless you really are) and you'll likely be fine. 

- Not going to review their food because by the time you visit, you may be getting a slightly different menu. Browse the photos if you want an idea of what you'll get into at Akiko's.
author: Lily N.

description:
Must try once in your life. 

O M A K A S E $150 a person. Not worth it in my eyes, but the Truffle Wagu Beef was perfection!!! $30 for 2 pieces. The raw shrimp was $20 for 2 pieces, after that I was like jeez! I really enjoyed the fish here and my friend loved the uni. They gave a decent amount. I had better and cheaper elsewhere, but glad I came to try. Dinner only took one hour, but we were so hungry, we were probably eating too fast. I believe they use brown rice to make their sushi. Just don't get the mochi. One piece cut in half is $4. Lol! 

Service was great.
author: Karen H.

description: The over priced sushi was good! But it was the inhospitable service that truly left a bad taste in my mouth. As we sat at our 2 hour reserved sushi bar seats, we were already being rushed out after the 45 minute mark. Our sushi chef looked at the manager at the end of the bar and dragged his finger across his neck, making a knife across the throat noise, indicating our party was finished or just not ordering fast enough. We decided "slitting throat" signs was not conducive to a happy meal and flopped out the door like fish out of water. Think twice before spending your paycheck here!
author: Chelly D.

description: Tasty fresh sushi. We stopped in here on a whim trip to San Fran while awaiting a member of our family to fly into SFO. With no reservation our table of 4 was seated quickly for lunch. The miso soup was tasty. It was served without a spoon, so get ready to drink from the bowl in the traditional style. The rolls we had was good, as was the nigiri. Ultra-fresh fish was just what we needed.
author: Jeremy K.

description: Who stops serving on a Saturday night at nine. ...in a first tier city. I suppose they don't need the business.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
From the outside, this place looks low key.
But when you enter and see the layout and feel the vibe, you know you are at home.

I ordered the Saba shioyaki but the waiter said they were out of it.
So I perused the fine menu and selected Salmon. Then I asked if I can get my salmon done shioyaki style.  The waiter smiled and said 'sure'. Nice.

In ten minutes your food arrives on nice plating and artfully arranged.
The fish quality was of good quality and properly cooked. A bit dry but none the less higher quality fish. A couple florets of broccoli and sliced carrots graced the salmon.
A bowl of rice contained quality rice: little nuggets of plump sweet rice.

Tea: higher quality tea

Decor: ok. 

Music: cool beats

Customer service: very good.

Can't wait to return =)
author: Bert K.

description:
For the price, ( by the way it's $$$) , the quality is good. Simple menu, very simple Our food came in parts when they were supposed to be duos or combos. The space is very narrow and intimate and wouldn't really go out of my way for this one but certainly worth a try. 

Quick tip: reservations are a must, they will not seat you otherwise.
author: Johanna P.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 4
Service: 4

Came here Friday night for dinner around 8:30pm after making a reservation 15 min prior (they've been full the past two times I've tried booking a reservation, so I guess I got lucky).

1. tennen sawara SPANISH MACKEREL [KAGOSHIMA PREFECTURE] 12
~Pretty good. Usually not a huge fan of mackerel, but this was actually quite tasty.

2. nigiri tasting - 6pc 23
~Pretty good. Fish was fresh, although I didn't taste any wasabi.

Service was good, although they didn't bring out ginger and wasabi until I had eaten three pieces.
author: David L.

description: too expensive andthe serive, food not worth it.during our dinner, our water and tea all run out, but noone comes to add watet. the black cod is so small but cost 28 bucks. not worth it, will never come again.
author: Shiming R.

description:
Shocked with the 4 star rating - inland tourists?

To sum up this place - premium pricing, low quality sushi.  Especially overpriced if you order from the special menu, which our waiter steered us toward.

Nigiris & portions are the smallest I've seen in a Japanese restaurant.  Fish tasted flavorless, mushy and must have been frozen and thawed repeatedly.  

4 orders of nigiri sushi, one small California roll, boiled spinach app 2 glasses of wine = $95.  

I'd skip this place...
author: Paul K.

description:
Had reservations and was seated promptly at the reserved time. Great service. Zero complaints with the hostess and the waiter I had.

Food wise. Omakase was amazing. 

Most notably: The uni was out of this world and that A5 wagyu was the bomb diggityyyy!! Uni was fresh and had a huge burst of flavor. The wagyu was buttery and melts in your mouthhhhh. Amazing.
author: Adrina W.

description:
Dare I say this is the best sushi I've ever had? Hmmmm. Without question it's the best sushi rolls I've had in a couple years. This was my first visit to a Japanese restaurant where literally every roll satisfied me in some way. The Firecracker, VV, Volcano, and Dragon were especially phenom. Of the eight rolls we had, I think the Dynamite and Spider Roll were the least favorable. 

The decor is also super cute: floral designs along with bamboo. Service was a bit slow in the beginning and I think they could've been a little more attentive when pouring beers, but overall I was highly satisfied with the experience. Even on weekdays - we went on a Wednesday - I recommend reservations. It's in a central area on Bush and Grant so there's popular street activity. Sitting up front, I saw a lot of people turned away because they were walk-ins. Also, sit in the back! The front tables got a little chilly (though I also take blame for being a bit underdressed based on SF August weather).

I think based on the quantity of pieces in each roll, this place is also very reasonably priced: 8 rolls, an app, glass of wine, and prob 6 bottles of Sapporo for $155. So happyyyy!
author: Amanda V.

description:
Finally made a reservation(not a walk-in joint) to try my neighborhood sushi spot and I'm glad we discovered it. Small modern space with a selection of small plates and sushi which are reasonably priced. 

Had the tofu, veggie tempura, octopus, hamachi, and soup; we were full and content after our meal. The speedy and attentive service had us out of there in an hour and 15 on a Friday night. They try to turn the tables over quickly due to the limited amount of tables. The bar seating is also another option for a quick bite. Will come back soon when we remember to make a reservation:)
author: Maria C.

description: This is an awesome place for experiencing fresh preparation when seated at the bar. The selection of rolls and pieces is very mindfully listed on the menu. I would suggest a reservation if possible otherwise you could wait for a while as this place is packed.
author: Sid B.

description:
OMAKASE!!  If I had to sum up Akiko's in one word then it would be OMAKASE.  For those of you who don't know what Omakase stands for, it's not a fish or a Japanese dish, but rather a Japanese phrase that means "It's up to you" (from Japanese , entrust). If you're a true sushi/ nigiri/ sashimi fan then my suggestion... don't even open the menu and just tell your server "OMAKASE!! "  (Hint: it's not on the menu).  The chef will prepare a specialized tasting menu in a variety of courses.  Just let your server know when your table is full at any time.  

My friends & I have been coming to Akiko's for over a decade now.  We used to order the rolls and some of the cooked items as everyone else who have left reviews here on Yelp.  But you won't find too many who have ordered OMAKASE like we do. This is a great way to try their daily specials and seasonal favorites.  Ray takes great pride in flying fresh delicacies in from around the world such as from the internationally recognized Tsukiji Fish Market in Japan. I actually forget how many courses we ended up having a few weeks back but I'm sure it was easily over 10 courses.  The Hanasaki Crab alone came prepared three ways. (photo posted)

Here's the nama selection from June 24:

White (from Tsukiji Fish Market, Japan)
-kochi flathead
-isaki threeline grunt fish
-ishidai rock bream
-renkodai sea bream
-kodai red sea bream
-kintoki jellynose
-kanpachi japanese amber jack

Vibrant (from Tsukiji Fish Market, Japan)
-buri mature yellow tail
-toro sustainable blue fin belly

White (New Zealand)
-ebisu dai golden snapper 

VIBRANT (Alaska)
-sake wild copper river king salmon
-shiro sake ivory wild alaskan salmon

NIGIRI DES
-sake seared salmon, spicy aiolo, fling fish roe, tare
(**)-uni smoked sea urchin, salmon roe, quail egg
-ebi tartar fresh laughing bird shrimp, avocado, spicy sesame, punzo, gyoza chips

CRUSTACEAN (Hokkaido, Japan)
(**)-hanasaki crab

(*) = Normally I would list my favorites here, but we enjoyed every dish that came out & since we ordered OMAKASE, I'm going to put a (**) next to the ones that are a definite MUST to try. 

Akiko's menu is always evolving and changing so be sure to visit often as you'll never know what surprises will be in store for you.
author: Stacey L.

description:
A bit confusing finding the place as no signage outside, but very small and cozy inside.  I was dining by myself as in SF for work/conference.  Got seated at the sushi bar.  Two other single guys on my left and three women together on my right.  I made reservations, but Tuesday at 8pm, probably didn't need to do so.  I'm presuming at other times this place can get jammed.  Both sushi chefs were very friendly and talkative.  I always like that.  Later the women left, and two more single guys on my right.  I guess that's par for Tuesday evening after 8pm downtown...

Got a Japanese ale (name escapes me) ... very hoppy for an ale, but not bad.  I started off with sashimi 12-piece sampler...very good.  Very fresh.  Then got a spicy tuna roll and spider rolls...always my favorites, and their spicy tuna was very well done.  Highly recommended.  Spider rolls were only OK.

As I was still hungry (I'm still growing ... as they say.. sideways), ordered the salmon teriyaki ... came with 4 nigiri, miso soup, and rice.  The teriyaki was done perfectly ... nice and crispy, without too much sauce.  Perfect.  Bravo.  Miso soup was also very good.  I now felt too full .... I guess never a happy medium.  Anyway, I'd highly recommend this place.  Service was very attentive and excellent.

I'll also address the amount of food for the cost that other posters noted ... I'd say that if cost/sushi is what you're looking for or volume of food, don't go here unless you're willing to spend a bit as the sashimi can get pricy (lots of offerings from Japanese waters)... go to Japantown or elsewhere.  For a place within walking distance of Union Sq ... very good.
author: Robert S.

description: Food was good; service, however, was terrible. Our server (young gal with short dark hair) was ambivalent at best- barely tolerating our presence at worst. She did find time to flirt with the tables of single young men. Fortunately the rest of the staff was more attentive.
author: Julia C.

description: Finally a place that takes fish seriously and treats it with the much needed respect it deserves. The way the chefs treat there fish is an art form. They don't disrespect the fish by over saucing. There is such an amazing balance here it is insane. I look forward to my next Omakases here!
author: Sol R.

description: Yes. This place is very good. We had negi hama roll,California roll, tempura, beef teriyaki, and chicken teriyaki. The rolls were fresh and beautifully prepared. Teriyaki was yummy. Even the miso soup was excellent. Nice vibe inside. I'm a fan.
author: Lewis C.

description: Am I in love ? Not quite. Perhaps it's b/c I'm basing it on the standards set by Maido in Lima, Peru. Now that is awesome sushi. Akiko is good but not spectacular that I would 'die' for it or have dreams about it. It is a small place, popular with the FIDI locals plus a few tourist. Tables are close together so you will hear ur neighbors conversation even if u don't want to. We tried a variation of rolls, sashimi, nigiri .. Nothing was bad, none was standout! Pricing is ok ..we spent about $170 for a party of 3 with no drinks.
author: Jay S.

description: Meh. Service was friendly. We went right before they closed. We did not feel rushed. The fish within the sushi was minced... Which I expect in a spicy tuna roll, but not all of their fish rolls.
author: Tommy A.

description:
Best sushi meal I've had in the Bay Area. Caveat #1: I have NOT been to Sushi Ran yet. Caveat #2: my brother's friend prepared most of the dishes that we had, so I'm sure he made sure we had the best dishes on the menu. Despite those two things, I was very impressed and very satisfied with my meal at Akiko's. we had a table of six, and very beautiful, very delicious dishes kept coming out, starting with some delicious vegetables, a couple sashimi plates, and then delicious nigiri, piece by piece. 

I really loved the cucumber salad with crab, agedashi tofu, Spanish Mackerel sashimi, the blue shrimp, and the tuna shoulder (I can't remember what kind). Then, at the end, we were completely BLOWN AWAY by the black tuna belly with uni and the wagyu beef, which was just slightly seared and topped with truffle. WOW. Just two of the best bites I've had, and just a perfect way to end the meal (until the delicious mochi ice cream came). We also tried the 49ers roll, which was good, but nothing special -- stick with the nigiri and sashimi! Not a cheap meal, but it was definitely a great place when you want to splurge on a great meal. Can't wait to go back again!
author: Pilan C.

description: The hostess and server were awesome!  Food was just standard and beer was not cold.  Chefs were pretentious and made the atmosphere stale. Get over yourselves, poser chefs!
author: Chris W.

description: This portion like for who? Insects? Very expensive and we left place almost hungry. Manager of the place open door near our table and didn't want to close it even when we told her that it's little bit cold. She did it only when we asked her will she pay of we get ill.
author: Ev K.

description: I didn't quite believe it the first time, so I came back again. Confirmed. It's the best meal in town.
author: Fred S.

description:
Had a great lunch at this restaurant! It is a simple and sort of minimalist place that combines bamboo wood (I think) and steel making it very pretty. 

The staff could not be more nice! Last seat is at 14.30 and they kindly explained and waited until my party arrived minutes before.

The meal was great. A bit expensive but first class quality. You can choose between many fishes around the world! Beer and Sake from  japan as well. It was not too much in quantity but enough to leave happy

I would definitely come back.
author: Matias D.

description:
This place is tiny! I felt squished and the tables for parties of two are so tiny. I felt like I was encroaching on my neighbor's space with my purse and jacket. The lighting is good and the light bulbs were quite fascinating though. I love that you can sit at the bar and watch the sushi chefs do their magic.

Water: Inconsistently warm and then slightly chilled. No ice in my water, which was cool with me because it was cold that day!

Wasabi: Delicious - it has a nice heat to it with a really addicting sweetness. I found myself snacking on the wasabi during the meal because it was so good.

Ginger: Unimpressive and a little too sweet for me.

Tako Nigiri (Octopus): Tiny, but fresh and had a great chewiness to it. 

Spicy Tuna Roll: This was no bueno for me. I could not taste the tuna at all amidst the spicy mayonnaise and the extra sauce drizzled on top of the roll, which also didn't seem to go well together for me.

Nigiri with Salmon Teriyaki: I thought this was a forgettable dish and regretted I ordered this instead of loading up on the sushi. They serve four pieces of nigiri first and while the salmon was not cut very cleanly, it tasted deliciously velvety; the rest of the nigiri were forgettable and had little flavor. Small portions of rice, small portions of salmon but well flavored and had a great crisp to the fish. Vegetables were extremely mushy.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
1) Make sure you go to the right one (there are two with the same name very close, this one in on Bush Street next to the Irish Bank) 
2) Get a reservation, don't walk in. They are getting more popular (with good reason)

This is really as good as it gets. Having eaten Sushi all over the world, the quality and preparation here is as good as Tokyo's best.  Enjoy!
author: Tom J.

description:
Wow. This sushi was exceptional. Super fresh, authentic, and every dish was perfectly executed. We also had wagyu beef, which was incredible. Sake selection is on point.

Ambiance is perfect for a date or friends night out. Cozy and intimate yet refined. 

My new favorite sushi place.
author: Diane D.

description:
I vacillated between and 4 and a 5 (only because I *rarely* give 5 on a first date), but I really cannot refuse them a 5. 

Mumsy was fancying sushi downtown and I'd heard about this place from a co-worker so booked a table. After being interrogated by Mumsy (is this place new? is the owner/chef Japanese? where do you get your fish from?) she was satisfied well enough to even look at the menu (and you think *I* am a sushi snob!). 

Everything was delightful. The service was awesome, everyone was friendly, the decor was a fusion blend of Japanese and San Francisco (love it!), the presentation was beautiful (sushi came on slate slabs), and even the hot sake came in its own little custom-made bottle of hot water (classy!). 

Of course the food is the MOST important, and we were not disappointed! We had hamachi (buttery), the salmon (perfect), the ikura (we had two orders - it's house-smoked in a little soy, sake and mirin, I believe), the ama-ebi (perfection), and saba, finished off with some takuan-maki. 

Their fish is so fresh, perfectly cut and the sizes were generous without being overwhelming slabs (one bite!). The rice to fish ratio was perfect too. It was so delightful and refreshing to see sushi done soooooo right! 

I'm drooling just writing this review...I wonder how soon I get back there?
author: Mi M.

description:
If I could only eat one type of cultural cuisine for the rest of my life, it would have to be Japanese: udon, tempera, and the sushi -- all nom nom nom!

So, It's your typical Friday night. My girlfriend and I decided to go out and since we haven't had Japanese in awhile, I scrolled up this little bookmark to hit up a dinner reservation. I had high hopes for tonight due to all the great reviews, on and off Yelp, but to only be shot down with disappointment.. 

Chicken Udon - [http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6UiO6BuqQqMXzl-qZUCAOg/l.jpg]
I was under the weather so I wanted something to warm me up. The broth was good but the dish hardly had any chicken, whatsoever. I wasn't expecting a lot and that's exactly what I got.

Volcano Roll - [http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/L2P_rQBv8bnLf7chWYVI6w/l.jpg]
Eh.. I'm not much of a fan for CA rolls overly topped with "crunch", which was exactly what it was. Despite the mediocre CA rolls, the "crunch" topping wasn't a bad highlight. But yeah, I get it -- It looks like a volcano and all so I give it to you for creativity, but for the price I'm paying, I'm not here to eat toppings..

Dragon and Negi-Hama Roll - [http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xoKqQhcpVBNpx6M4CJXwTw/l.jpg]
In a nutshell: The hamachi was fresh and cheap and the dragon roll was the best roll, taste-wise. 

Anddd.. here it comes. However, what was up with the rice on the sushi? (See photo) [http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/TKwM7AtDvX5qAYjrS-uN4w/l.jpg] 
Why was it so compressed and so poorly rolled? We notified our waiter to ask if it was normal for all the rolls to be like this, which they responded with a newly made set of rolls, but only to see that the new rolls were no different.. (We didn't bother asking a second time.)

I was looking forward to some good sushi but it was definitely a downer. The rolls were either overly compressed or fell apart when trying to pick it up.. I know Akiko isn't a fine dining joint but it's still a tad pricier than other underrated sushi restaurants out there that need recognition.
author: Albert L.

description:
So glad I found this place on Yelp! Wow, their salmon sashimi is probably the best I've ever had! I'm not kidding! I'm not from
SF and as much as I love trying a new spot when eating out on travel, I will say, "I'll be back." Service is excellent. The servers are so friendly and knowledgable! Thank you!
author: Jenn K.

description: Very poor experience with this restaurant. On Open Table it said we could only make a reservation for 4 but if we called in they could accommodate a larger party of 6. We called this restaurant 4 times, about an hour In between each call and never got an answer. We figured that at this point since we had made a reservation that we could just ask them when we arrived since we hadn't gotten a response. It was my brother's birthday and he is one of the biggest sushi lovers I know. When we arrived we were told there was no way we could be accommodated. No apology, just frustration that we were even asking. We told them we had called multiple times and they just said their phone lines were down. I can't rate the food since we never got past the very impatient hostess. But the night was saved because we went to a different sushi restaurant that exceeded our expectations and made the night fantastic.
author: Karly B.

description: Some of the freshest sushi I've ever had!! Loved the decor and feel. The service was amazing and always attentive of our drink levels, which I appreciate. The cucumber salad was really yummy. My favorite roll was the one with the lemon paper. Was sooo good. All the rolls we got were just as yummy and fresh! Definitely my new go to for sushi in the city!
author: Ashley E.

description:
Sometimes you just want to make sure you have sushi the way sushi was meant to be eaten.  If you were ever gonna do Sushi Omakase, this is the spot to do it.

This place will cost you a grip of cash (approx $100ish w/o alcohol), but you will enjoy every bite.  I love food more than money...

You need a reservation.

Eat at the bar, trust the guys behind the counter.
author: Steven F.

description:
I hate to review this place simply because I fear it getting popular. I also couldn't live with myself if I didn't write down how great this place was for me. Automatically I knew it had to be good when I found out it was near Irish Bank and Claude Lane two of my favorite places in the city.  

The second we walked in all eyes on the staff greeted us with a hello or a nod.  Something I always look for when going to intimate places such as Akiko's.  We were warmly greeted by a member of their wait staff and taken to our table. The room is small, cozy, and stylish. 

Our servers were all very helpful and extremely friendly.  We had 3 people attending to us and they all took turns warming up to us. It didn't matter which one showed up they all took our questions as each of them had full knowledge of all the things the restaurant did and served.  It is really rare when that happens so when it does it's a real treat. 

As far as the food it was a true sushi lovers dream.  They take great care in their fish and rice. The quality is some of the best around by far. We did like that even if you are into the more non traditional forms of sushi served at other restaurants they cater to those folks as well. We would imagine that those items from the looks of it at the other tables are just as good and as well prepared as the traditional items. They have a daily menu of what is fresh and the server was nice enough to share their delivery dates with us and even suggested that the day after delivery is usually the best as far as taste and flavor. We learned quite a bit about sushi that we hadn't known about and even got a lesson in nigori sake from the woman who brought us drinks. Needless to say this was one of the best sushi experiences I've had. 

As we left each of the people who greeted us on the way in took the time to acknowledge us on the way out. Overall I love this place and look forward to returning very soon.
author: Joco F.

description:
Fair sushi, cool space, but with all 'good' restaurants, if the service is bad it mars the entire experience. 

From the getgo this place had a odd unwelcoming aire about it. We sat at the bar and was continually fronted with conceited, gruff and 'everything was a little too much trouble' service, it was if there was an management-staff feud taking place.

The icing on the cake was when we were unceremoniously told to move to the end of the bar for a four top, high rolling, Russian family arriving.  From then on I had the hump.

I requested the bill prematurely, left zero tip +some comments and departed (I don't remember the last time I didn't tip.. it was that bad).
author: Matthew R.

description:
since my friend took me to lazy bear, i decided to repay the favor and treat them here.. ive been wanting to go here for yrs and they haven't been back in a while..

best sushi experience to date! i wish i could go here every month

step 1: get reservations (at the bar)
step 2: order omakase
step 3: be ready to stuff yourselves silly

omakase: 
-sunmono scallop
-kinmedai
-tenjyou buri
-madai
-hotate 
-isaki
-kamasu
-umimasu
-iwashi
-kuro maguro: 2 types
-a5 wagyu
-uni
-tenen hirame
a few other things i dont remember/ wasn't on the receipt

our chef trevor was the best and we had a great time talking to him the whole time.. trevor used to work at ozumo then a short stint at pabu before coming here..

i need to come back soon!!
author: Raquel T.

description: Two years after going to this restaurant, they called me at 11pm (central time) in Chicago, woke me up, to tell me that I had a reservation and they were going to cancel it if I did not show up on time.  Um, what?  I don't even live in San Francisco and haven't been there since 2014.  I guess there was some glitch in their system?  Seriously?  Get it together.
author: Sam M.

description:
Conflicted on this place.  Friendly and attentive staff.  Professionally presented sushi, but a glaring problem:  Despite the cool weather, the establishment was sweltering that night.  With the crowds and tight space, it made things somewhat claustrophobic and  uncomfortable.  I can handle the heat, but when it starts to impact the product itself, then there is a problem. Every staggered order arrived at room temperature, which under normal circumstances is a good thing, but all the sushi was markedly warm-not a good thing.  It actually alters the flavor-to the seafood's detriment.  

Nothing struck me as tasting particularly fresh or outstanding in any way and at this price point, that shouldn't be the case.  

Nothing bad, but nothing stood out as good, especially at this price point, other than the service.

Disappointing meal, which was a huge surprise after reading so many stellar reviews.     I have never had sushi arrive that was warm to the touch.
author: Terry W.

description: We ordered the omasake: the server ask what we like and somewhat tailored it to our liking. The quality of the food was on point but the service was just average.
author: young o.

description: The sushi is good, no doubt about it. But the staff is really arrogant. No need to be pretentious just because you're serving high quality fish, imho. Also somewhat overpriced.
author: Andreas H.

description:
I really, really wanted to like Akiko's Restaurant - a hip sushiya with modern original dishes and snazzy ambiance. In the end though, Akiko's was just a 3/5 experience. I'm not quite convinced that I can give Akiko's a badge of sushi excellence.

Positives
* The Chef speaks Japanese, appears to care an have pride for his food.
* Decor and vibe rocks - great place to spend time.
* They carry Orion, a great beer from Okinawa.
* Carry 3 kinds of Uni (Santa Barbara, Hokkaido, Russian Tokujiyo from Kaigara)
* Cryogenically frozen Monkfish Liver (Ankimo) shaved on top of Uni!!

Negatives
* Bar unsuitable for sushi enthusiasts - it's thin and too short, hurts your arms to rest them on the edges of the counter.
* Very pricey, every order of nigiri comes on a separate plate instead of being set on the same Geta (Samurai Shoe) like in traditional sushiya.
* The fish underwhelming - not very fresh but not old either - for the price this was definitely expected. Just the look of the fish in the neta cases revealed this.
* No real wasabi - instead just run of the mill horseradish with wasabi powder. Did have wasabi paste (which is better) but the waiter took my plate while I was eating it...
* 2 Chefs was clearly not enough for how busy it is, counter sitters get neglected
* no salmon roe (ikura), guessing no demand

All in all there was enough good things about Akiko's that I'll probably give them another chance, but considering Sanraku doesn't do any of the negatives listed above - I might have a hard time.
author: Grayson K.

description: Absolutely rudest hostess (Elise) I've ever met. Told her I was looking for a friend and she refused to let me just peek into the back of the restaurant. After recommending an out of town friend to go here, I will never step foot in the restaurant or tell anyone to come here. Just because you're working for a popular restaurant doesn't mean you get to be a complete B and rude.
author: Kenny L.

description: Went in for lunch on a Friday as soon as they opened and thoroughly enjoyed the omakase experience. Beautifully crafted. Every bite was an explosion of flavors delicately balanced. The service was superb. I felt very taken care of during the hour I was there.
author: M J.

description:
Outstanding food. If stars were based on food alone, this would easily be a 4.5. I was joking with my friend about asking people at other tables if I could take pictures of their food for instagram, because everything really looked that incredible.

Unfortunately, our overall experience was a little less enjoyable. A friend and I went at lunch in the middle of the week, and were seated fairly quickly. Beautiful atmosphere (although they really crowd the tables in), and the sushi bar looked really impressive. 

Our waiter was a little slow about getting to our table, and when he was finally ready to take our order, I asked about why types of fish were included in the sashimi sampler that came with a dish I was considering ordering. His response was "the typical ones." Maybe he didn't know the answer, but as someone who is a little picky when it comes to sashimi, I wasn't really satisfied with his response. I ended up ordering something else, and that was that. 

Our food ended up taking about 30 minutes to arrive, which for a rice dish and udon seemed like a really long wait. My friend's udon was brought the to table a few minutes before my meal, which I always find to be a little irksome. Little things that I typically don't even think about, like water being refilled promptly, didn't happen. 

I'd go back, because the food was really outstanding, but I'd definitely make sure I have enough time for a longgggg lunch in my schedule.
author: Eve D.

description:
This place screams snooty-patooties for the SF Financial District from the lack of signage, unwelcoming seat staff for those that look "unworthy", and pricey food.

For a meal that cost $80, I'd at least want to be satisfied and full. My date and I tried two sashimi dishes and a roll and were sadly disappointed. 

The alleged "sashimi flown in last night" wasn't that spectacular. 

Also, the 49er roll tasted only a tad better than a $10 roll at joe-schmo Japanese restaurant.

Bottom-line: if you're a posh SF food connoisseur that likes to throw money at places, they require reservations.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
What makes my experience so disappointing is that Akiko's had everything it took to become my favorite sushi restaurant in SF, but just failed miserably.

Now, I will definitely give credit where credit's due: Akiko's has some of the freshest, unique, and delicious fish that I've tried in SF. The Ankimo (monkfish liver) here was amazing, the Russian Uni was the best uni I've ever had, and Hamachi nigiri was perfect. The ambiance of the place was incredible -- the brick wall blended with pipes and stucco felt like I was in some cool underground bar, but the lighting and atmosphere felt like I was in a tranquil spa in Kyoto. 

Where it goes miserably wrong, though, is with the service. Aside from the extremely slow service (it took about 15 mins for them to even acknowledge us at our table), our server Ray was a nice guy (I'll give him that) but it really felt like he was pushing orders on us way too aggressively. We felt like we were being upsold by a Comcast representative and it just wasn't pleasant. It was like he was only trying to get us to order only the most expensive sushi, rather than actually helping us with choosing items that we'd actually enjoy. After we put in our order, our drinks were forgotten and we had to ask a busboy twice to get us the beers that we ordered. They didn't arrive until our third dish had already come out. 

But honestly, even that's excusable.

What really pissed us off was that we ordered the Kuro Maguro (Chu Toro), since all of us really go to sushi restaurants for toro (everything else is a nice plus). First off, they ran out of every kind of toro, except for the Chu Toro, so we ordered that. Another server (not Ray) brings us our "Chu Toro" that obviously did not look like belly, so we asked him what it was. The server said it was the Chu Toro and we said "Are you sure? That doesn't look like Chu Toro." He says: "That's the shoulder cut, you ordered it" and walks away. It wasn't until after the dinner that our server (Ray) comes and says: "Oh by the way, we ran out of Chu Toro so we substituted it for the bluefin tuna shoulder cut." 

The whole exchange was just extremely shady. If you run out of toro, then you come tell us that you ran out of toro and ask if we'd like to order something else instead. You don't sneakily throw something in there that we didn't order and try to trick us into thinking it's what we ordered. That whole experience really left a bad taste in our mouths.

And by the way, what sushi restaurant runs out of 3 different types of toro on Friday night at 8pm?? I can't trust any sushi restaurant that can't get their inventory straight, especially for toro.

---------------------------------
FOOD:

EXCELLENT: Ankimo, Russian Uni, Hamachi
VERY GOOD: Hamachi Kama, Santa Barbara Uni, California Maki
GOOD: Aka Mutsu, Kamasu, A5 Wagyu w/ Truffle, Shiro Maguro, Sesame Ice Cream
MEH: Amaebi (Blue raw shrimp), Unagi, Ikura

---------------------------------

Akiko's definitely has great sushi (when it's even available), so I'll give it the 3 stars that it deserves for the food. The experience that we had, however, can't push it any higher than that.
author: Roy C.

description:
Wow, wow, wow! This is seriously good sushi! The rolls, the sashimi, the nigiri, the freshness... AKIKO'S RESTAURANT is definitely my new goto spot for sushi!

Located on Bush near the historical entrance to Chinatown, my friends and I were immediately seated at a great corner table near the window. Within moments we had water as well as the specials sheet which was filled with fresh fish choices.

It seemed like we were left alone for a while but then a waiter returned and we ordered a feast, multiple rolls, different fish and a bottle of sake to boot! My buddy ordered one of the special fish which the server said they just ran out of, he then immediately recommended a different fish which was similar in taste. We went for it. 

Now Akiko's also has Blue Fin Tuna on the menu and before you get up in arms about it, they are the first to tell you it's sustainably farmed Blue Fin Tuna and our server went through great lengths to answer all our questions and quell our concerns, well done.

The food came fast and furious and it was excellent. The rolls were large  and packed to the rim with fish & veggies and I am extremely happy to report that the SPICY TUNA ROLLS had a nice heat to them, they truly lived up to their name. The FIRECRACKER and VOLCANO ROLLS were also well presented and very tasty. As for the fish, the AMBERJACK, the UNI, the MACKEREL and the farmed BLUE FIN TUNA were all excellent. Our sake was kept cold at the table in it's own bucket of ice and the housemade Soy Sauce was a fantastic companion to all the fresh fish.

Akiko's Restaurant was a winner and I will be going back!
author: G C.

description: Love the atmosphere! Very petty decor and wall paper is really cool! It's a very very small restaurant and there's no sign outside of restaurant. We had hard time finding it first. You definitely need the reservation here. Fish is very fresh, but I would love to have more variety of choice of sushi and sashimi. It's a little limited for me. Great service and I would go back again when I go to San Francisco!
author: Keiko C.

description:
The freshest fish I had. I will never forget the taste of that uni in my mouth. It was so...flavorful and amazing.

My sister took me here for my birthday for dinner. I was blown away by the way the sushi was served and how pretty everything looked (ITS LIKE ART). Overall, there is a good selection of different kinds of sushi and fishes. However, don't come here for a cheap and filling meal.

Towards the end, my sister and I were still hungry after eating our sushi dishes so we needed to order another bowl of udon to fill us up (sad I know)...

FYI: You can always tell if a sushi place is legit if the uni is on point. THIS UNI HERE WAS ON POINT. Come here for legit sushi--legit meaning like "I probably can't go to Japan anytime soon so this is as good as it gets."
author: Eileen W.

description:
Really great spot for the sushi aficionado. There wasn't a visible sign outside, so that may be a little confusing, but it's the corner spot just outside the alleyway. Pretty cozy and small in there, the hostess will actually tuck you in if you're sitting against the wall (amusing and kinda of a strange aspect of what otherwise feels like a more upscale dining place). Service is very good, polite and attentive. Small, more traditional menu for sushi (hooray!) with more of a focus on fresh fish and "gourmet styled basic" rolls (your Sake roll will have more than just salmon and avocado) - which by the way, was delicious. They use brown rice, and the seaweed was a little moist/soft so it made it a tad chewy, but the pieces were all bite sized so it wasn't a problem. 
Tried the barracuda nigiri (fresh catch that day) and the white tuna toro - both were delicious, fresh - no fishiness, the toro was buttery of course, and the barracuda was great - had the texture more on a steak side of the fish (like swordfish) rather then the buttery thick slab of salmon. 
Easily could overspend here, so maybe save it for a special occasion, and definitely make reservations!
author: Adrienne L.

description:
I found Akiko's a couple of years ago. I've been a loyal fan since. I come to SF from Minneapolis for business about once a month. I try to eat there at least twice each trip. 

Joe and Mary (owners) are lovely people. Together they produce a great sushi experience. When I first came it was when few people were eating out (winter of 2009). Since then Akiko's has grown in popularity. My favourite dish is the crab and cucumber salad. It is so good it should be illegal! Everything is always fresh and the sushi rice is perfect. 

Come hungry and order anything - especially items recommended in other reviews. You won't be disappointed.
author: Rhoda B.

description:
Fantastic Sushi. Reasonable prices.
Its a tiny place so plan on waiting, even if you have a reservation. 

Excellent spot. Go there
author: Brian W.

description: Best fish around!  Omakase is a the way to go.  It does get pricey, however.  They require reservations.
author: Alex G.

description: Hands down agree with all reviews. Fish was amazingly fresh. Staff was attentive, courteous, on point. Can't wait to come back and explore more.
author: daniel D.

description:
I discovered this place after a co-worker highly recommend it. The exterior is not much to look at but once you get inside you will find a beautifully appointed restaurant. It's not very big so I "highly" recommend reservations. Everything I tried was fantastic. The quality of the fish was excellent, it pretty much melts in your mouth. The menu is not very big however I was able to find everything I wanted. The staff was awesome so even if they don't have something you want I feel confident they would make it for you. I looking forward to my next visit.

Second visit and it's still great quality sushi. They receive a fresh shipment on Tuesday. I recommend Tues night dinner or Wed lunch. Simply Amazing!!
author: Chris M.

description: Heard a lot of people raving about the sushi in San Fransisco so we decided to try it out for dinner. Akiko's was one of the first sushi restaurant I found on yelp and decided to go there. Tried calling a couple times to make a reservation but no one answered. Took us about 20 mins to find the restaurant because there were no sign on the front, just the street number which made it nearly impossible to find if you're not from the area. When we finally found it, the hostess was rude and pretentious. She told us that it was full and there were no more reservations available that night. Although we could be on a waitlist that was not a "guarantee" and would take an hour and a half to be notified. I put myself in the waiting list and asked how many people were ahead of me and she told me there were four. We took a stroll in downtown and the hostess from Akiko's called back under TEN MINUTES and told us there were seats available. Unbelievable. She could of simply told us "yes or no" there is a wait time...instead of leaving us discombobulated about the waitlist and no guaranteed seating. We came back to Akiko's and were seated in the back.
