The interior was nice with some industrial theme. The service was excellent overall besides the bitter incident earlier. The food was so-so nothing extraordinary. I would recommend the scallop sunomono, fresh scallop and ika.
author: Enova H.

description: It was ok. The music was pretty good, and the vibe was fun, but don't go here expecting to find a dive bar sushi place with good prices and excellent quality. You pay more for the cool vibe than you do for the dish. They do not have fresh crab (but they have soft shell crab tempura) so everything else is imitation crab meat, There are not many raw rolls.  I ordered hamachi, tuna, salmon sashimi. The salmon was very fatty to the point of of the white fat lines actually felt a bit harder than the rest of the fish. The price for the two slices of sashimi was $7. So it's not as expensive as other locations but pricey for the quality.
author: Katie J.

description: Probably the best tasting avocado roll I have had outside of Nobu. It was so creamy and yummy. I can't even remember what else we had because I loved the roll so much I couldn't stop talking about it or thinking about it! It was a funky shaped restaurant. Good service. I would go back. I didn't give it 5 because the menu is weird and you couldn't just bring anyone there because it is a limited menu in my opinion.
author: Amy V.

description:
I recently visited Akiko's again after I heard the place got a complete revamping. I believe it's reservation only now, so I went online and booked one on Opentable easily.When we arrived, our table was ready without any waiting time.

My boyfriend and I went for the omakase menu since that is what people were raving about.

All in all, the sushi was very good, but nothing mind blowing. I remember the salmon being exceptional and so was the ikura (which we added on top of the omakase). Price wise, it was over $130 per person for omakase, 2 additions of ikura and uni, and a corkage fee for the wine we brought. I felt like this was kind of overpriced given I've had MUCH better sushi for relatively the same price in New York at Sushi Nakazawa.

I also had a omakase meal in Hawaii recently that was $75 a person and much more filling and memorable so Akiko's unfortunately does not meet my par right now.
author: Michelle N.

description: The Bomb! Top 5 in the Bay for sure!
author: Sean K.

description: Absolutely delicious.  My boyfriend and I went with the omakase and had a variety of dishes made for us.  My favorites: scallops with kiwi in squid ink, THE UNI (freshest uni I've ever had), A5 wagyu and their octopus.  Our server also recommended an excellent sake to pair with our meal.  Love this place!!
author: Anna Y.

description:
accessible to many types of eaters, filled with a variety of clientele, and seems a bit polarizing based on reading other's comments.  I had a nice rapid experience at the bar during a busy time.  certainly their variety of sourced product is impressive, and brushed soy places like this are preferred.  here they use red vinegar with the rice, which gives it that browner color.  the vinegar level was good, slightly drier rice but matches well with the slightly overused blow torch.  almost every nigiri is dressed -- ginger, shiso, zest, lemon, yuzu, miso, etc.  makes me think of Sushi Sam's.  I could do with less of the extras.  also if I were being very critical, then there were occasions where the knife work wasn't perfect and the placement needed work like the ice fish with a large gap from the rice and seaweed wrapper.  guided omakase selection:
Hara Sake -- seared salmon belly
Shiro Maguro
Toro -- torched
Kegani -- awesome
Nama Hotate
Tenjyou Buri -- wild mature
Madai
Kamasu -- a bit over dressed
Ice Fish+Tako
Tairagi Gai
Kohada
Hokkaido Uni -- never fails to impress
Anago
Aka Mutsu -- quite awesome white toro-like, fatty but more textural play
to try all the overseas fish would take a very large appetite.  pricing for the less common items is slightly higher but the product is solid.
author: Rob C.

description:
My husband and I are huge sushi fans, after trying many sushi restaurants in San Francisco and Bay Area, we finally found Akiko's!

We've been going to Akiko's at least once every 2 to 3 weeks for the past year and we still can't get enough of their amazing selection of nigiri. If you love large varieties of exotic nigiri/sashimi and great creativity then Akiko's is the place to go! They import their fish from Japan everyday and are carefully prepared and served on the same day. If freshness is what you are looking for then you won't be disappointed!

The ambiance is nice and relaxing and the staff are all very attentive to our needs! Akiko's is definitely our go to place whenever we need to have amazing sushi!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Disclaimer: I gave Akiko's Restaurant 2 stars because the poor service I received on 11/15/12.

The sushi and sashimi were fresh and had great texture.  I would have enjoyed my meal a whole lot better if I received better service from the waitstaff.  It seemed like they paid much more attention to the patrons they knew of.  I however got the cold shoulder from them the entire night.  It was very disappointing.  I spoke with the manager and he apologized and asked if there is anything he could do (e.g. reducing the bill) but I paid in full anyway, albeit only a 15% tip.

 In summary, I liked the food but not the service.
author: Clarence M.

description:
4.5 stars!

One of the best sushi restaurants in The City.  That being said, I'm giving it 4.5 stars in my book because it's definitely not the best I have ever had (that would be another city) but it's one of the better sushi experiences (of many) I have had in SF.  Very fresh cuts of fish, quaint, authentic, consistent, easy parking/access, good sake, and $10 corkage fee.
author: Marina S.

description:
One of the best sushi spots in SF! Came up to the city for a quick weekend trip and decided on sushi last minute. Thanks to Yelp we were able to come across this little gem. The fish was fresh and practically melted in my mouth like butter. The rolls and saki were also really great!

Ambiance is great and the service is exceptional. The decor is also modern and very clean but a bit tight. If you aren't ok with being a little intimate with strangers, then this isn't your spot. 

This places gets super packed so be sure to make a reservation ahead of time. We we're lucky enough to get seated in between reservations so make sure you plan ahead if you want to make a stop here. Huge fun - can't wait to go back!!
author: Jen S.

description: The place is cool, the service is not bad, the food is fresh but beside FRESH I can't make more compliments on it. I don't feel I tasted the "real Japanese " here and it's absolutely overpriced for this kind sushi place.
author: Yuyu J.

description: The freshest sushi-grade fish in San Francisco. We had the omakase. Some of the sashimi was flown here from Japan. Every fish we tried was deliciously mouthwatering, but I think my favorite was the crab in buttered miso.
author: Mimi J.

description:
Sushi is expensive but amazing here.  Have dined/lunched here 6+ times and have had great sushi every time.  The real treat is to order the omakase, but that will set you back real money... but I would rather skip eating sushi 3 times and have omakase once.

Make reservations.  Lunch is packed.
author: Neil M.

description: Here's the thing, I eat a lot of sushi, it's my favorite food. And, there is some really great sushi at Akiko's so I hate to only give it 3 stars; however a friend and I ordered the omakse, which is basically a chef's selection which ended up being around $150. For that we got about 14 pieces of sushi (so 7 each). Additionally, they were brought out 2 pieces at a time with intervals almost 20 minutes... So again really good sushi, but that particular item was a long wait... Especially for the price, just my opinion.
author: Braden S.

description:
Akiko's really hidden in plain sight and the hardest place to find since they literally have no store sign. The best way to find it is to look for the building with a "Irish Bar" sign. That's where Akiko is and the sign is really misleading. The decor of this place is not really a Japanese restaurant either which makes it hard to guess what it is looking from the outside in. It's kind of a hip trendy looking place from the feeling it gives off.

== Food ==

Tonkatsu with rice. The tonkatsu was really really well done. Nicely crispy on the outside with very soft pork on the inside. The rice was not your average cheapo white rice either.

Tuna sashimi was really fresh and amazing. I can literally taste the freshness of it.

== Service ==

Service is really good. The place has a business dining luncheon like to it.

== Overall ==

Really expensive but the quality is definitely on par with the price. There's a lot of business people here, which makes me suspect they cater toward that crowd. This place is either a treat yourself or a great place to have a business lunch.
author: Steven B.

description: The best sushi in financial district.  You can drop some money here, but its all good!
author: Minh P.

description:
Wow, just wow. 

We had omakase for the first time and I'm so glad we had it here. What an amazing meal prepared by Chef Ricky!! 

First of all he is a totally chill dude and so easy to talk to. Really funny to joke around with and the energy between him and the other 2 sushi chefs were awesome. It made sitting at the sushi bar so much more fun and exciting!

Secondly, we had 14 "rounds" in the omakase, beer, and one sake and it came out to about $300 for 2 people with tax+tip. Quite pricey but very worth it for a once in awhile dining experience. 

I can't remember EVERYTHING we had but we started with:

- Poke, the tuna was SO good. Literally like butter in my mouth. Nothing like I've ever had even in HAWAII.
- Hotate nigiri (scallops). Wrapped around a little rice and brushed with that sauce. So good and sweet.
- Umami ikura - the fish roe. I was scared at first because I don't like the big fish eggs, but really good with the hint of wasabi.
Kuro Maguro akami - blue fin with a simple brush of sauce, so good i'm dying 
- Japanese Uni
- Sake Copper r. - salmon. I usually don't like salmon but this one was nice and fatty and delicious
- Kinmedai - like a snapper. Seared and was I think one of my favorites of the night
- kuro maguro chutoro 
- Katsuo
- ShiroSake from Alaska
- Aka Mutsu
- Skip Jack Tuna (I think??)
- Shiro Toro
- A5 Wagyu with TRUFFLE.

I'm forgetting 1 because he didn't charge us for one of them! 

But the STARRRR of the whole meal was the wagyu. Seared with a little bit of rice. Topped with a black truffle compote, a sprinkle of salt, then topped AGAIN with black truffle shavings!!! It was the best thing I ever ate!! So rich and luscious. I want to cry because it's over. 

DEFINITELY will be back!! Thanks chef Ricky!!
author: Jenny A.

description:
Best sushi in SF!  Fresh & tastefully prepared. Order the cucumber salad with crab, soft shell crab, sashimi chefs choice & spicy tuna roll. The flavors and freshness were tantalizing!  Also, awesome selection of cold sake by the glass. 
There's no sign outside. Underneath Irish Bank sign on Bush St. Make a reservation. 
Great experience.
author: Rosetta P.

description:
We had a strange experience. Found this place via Yelp, but when we arrived we were told we had to have a reservation. So we left and our group made a rezo for 4 on Open Table for 45 min later. Meanwhile, had a drink next door. When we returned, we were refused service and told our reservation was no good because the empty tables were reserved for other reservations. I was a little embarrassed and very confused. 

So, no idea if the food is good. Service will prevent me from going again. If you go, be sure you make a reservation!
author: Suzanne G.

description:
My friend was in the city visiting just for a day and asked for some good Asian food, preferably near his hotel, so to the Yelp I went!  I found Akiko's, made a reservation and waited patiently for the day to arrive.  Throughout the week my friend was doing research on the menu, sending me links about the restaurant which only made me hungrier.

I've never called myself a foodie but my friends seem to be under the impression that I am one.  If foodie means I love and appreciate food that tastes good then it's true.  We decided to splurge on the omakase (also because I was having menu overload and had no idea what to order) and told the waiter we were aiming for around a $75 omakase.  

It was delicious, every bite of fish was amazing!  About 60% of what we were served came off the nama menu and there was clearly a difference in the taste of the fish from that versus the "standard" sushi menu.  The uni, tori and this pale pink (forgot the name - obviously not a true foodie) fish were my favorites.  They were buttery, full of flavor and downright "close your eyes" delicious.

We had a total of 7-8, maybe 9 (I lost count during my food bliss) dishes and I left very full and very happy.  It was almost too much fish for me, almost. ;)
author: Victoria Y.

description:
had the omakase, which was delightful.  but if i just had one tip:

order the AKAMUTSU .. best bite of sushi i've ever had.. easily topping toro, hamachi, and other types of fatty fish
author: Jason T.

description:
I don't know.  I may have to try more items to have a better understanding of why a great deal of folks gave Akiko's a solid four stars, including some of the yelpers I'm stalking...I mean following.  I had a quick lunch with colleagues today and had a pretty decent bowl of beef udon.  It was pretty good, albeit slightly bland, but the beef strips were nice and tender.  My colleagues' sushi rolls looked okay, but my they were pretty small for the price and my colleagues were not too impressed by them either.  

It's a bummer that they do not have lunch specials here, just regularly priced items that will probably run you $15-$20 for a filling lunch.  I like the charming and intimate mom-and-pop feel.
author: Angel S.

description: We went for the full experience. Omakase sushi was on point from start to finish. Ryan, our server, was extremely attentive and the entire staff was welcoming. Can't wait to come back the next time I'm in SF.
author: Alicia M.

description:
We had dinner here before going to a show, and were really happy with our experience. 

I was impressed by how knowledgeable our server was. He seemed to know where every fish on the menu was sourced from, and he wanted to tell me about the owner's efforts to be ecologically friendly. I love that they are providing local, and sustainable options. Yes, it is a little more expensive, but don't we all want to still have sushi to eat in the future? I wish more sushi places would do this... 
(Ok, stepping off my soapbox...) 

The sushi can get expensive, but the other items are surprisingly inexpensive. My guy's tonkatsu was also one of the better ones I've tasted. (he orders it all the time, and i always steal a bite.) 

I loved my sashimi and nigiri. Everything was so fresh, had such great flavor, and was cut perfectly. 
If this place was a little more convenient to get to, I'd definitely return.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and the place wasn't hard to find, it just didn't have a sign. Just remember it's at the corner! 

Anyhow, the omakase was amazing! The ingredients were fresh, as the fishes get shipped to the store twice weekly. I really enjoy the Russian Uni and the Imperial Shrimp, which is more unique and uncommon in most regular sushi restaurants. The uni was not briney at all and the texture of the shrimp was very tender (since it was killed before it was served..ahh). I also really like the Passion Fruit Saketini, very fruity yet such a creeper. 

The hostess and the waiter were amazing and helpful. There was a homeless that was bugging my boyfriend and I at the window; and the hostess being very petite, decided to walk out and waved him away. Very brave of her! The waiter was great at recommending food portions and drink suggestions. He also check on us and make sure we are doing well.

Yum, would love to go back any time any day! Just remember to make reservation!
author: Mandy C.

description:
Sushi is my favorite food, and I make it a mission to try out the best spots in SF--and Akiko's is definitely one of them. 

There is a great variety of fresh fish and the quality is great. I got the sashimi platter with four different kinds of sashimi. It was some of the most buttery fish ever.  The person I was with also got the tekka roll (not usually a fan of this, but it was great), and a spider roll. I don't like spider rolls either, but this one tasted really good. 

We ended our meal with wagyu beef with truffle oil and shaved truffles. I don't think I even need to tell you how good that was.

Some people below complained about the service, but I thought it was great. They were very attentive. They forgot my sunomono, and when I asked where it was, they gave it to me on the house and brought it out within 5 minutes. 

It's pretty expensive so I would not go there all the time, but it's definitely one of the better sushi places in the area.
author: Ashley H.

description: Great sushi spot.  Make sure you ask for the specialty sushi menu as you will see fish items that are rare in other spots.
author: Keith B.

description: I highly recommend Akiko! The sushi is some of the best I have ever had. It was fresh and authentic. The menu is long and includes specialty roles along with classics. The staff were friendly and gracious. I will definitely be back the next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Heather T.

description: Best sushi in SF in my opinion! Their stuff are soooo fresh... The sake nigiri is just blowing... The wait is pretty long, so we always make reservations. You can find a perfect time and day when you want to come if you book 2-3 weeks in advance. They have walk ins too, but since the place isnt big, the wait might be long on the weekend. Great date night spot! They have big variety of fish and they are all really good! The service is always great there and mochinice cream was great too. Its on the pricey side, but definitely worth the price, since quality is high!
author: Nataly S.

description:
It seems odd that it's so difficult to find great sushi in San Francisco.  We do have quite a bit of water nearby, and a decent sized Japanese-American population.  

Consider Akiko's -- there's no sign (which I find a little annoying) but the sushi chef is outstanding, as is the quality of the ingredients.  

the one quibble i have is the miso soup tasted very odd to me, like it was made iwth chicken broth?  so i'd skip that next time.  

You can definitely find sushi at a cheaper price elsewhere (of course not of this quality though), and if you prefer vegetarian sushi or something like California roll, you may not share my enthusiasm, but as for me, this is the best i've found in the city so far.
author: Jaina S.

description: I can honestly say that this is one of the best sushi restaurants that I have ever ate at. The price was on a bit of the high side, but I can honestly say I will definitely eat here again. Their Kobe beef nigiri with black truffle shavings was honestly one of the best things that I have ever ate.
author: Vlad M.

description: Fresh, delicious fish. The place is tiny; make sure you make a reservation. Not quite sure how bar seating is determined. Their website said to note it in your reservation, so we requested it on our Open Table reservation but bar seating we did not get. Aside from that, we had a good experience. Tasty food and friendly and attentive service.
author: Monty B.

description: 3.5 stars. Sashimi is fresh but did not wow. The wow factor comes in the aged wagyu beef nigiri. Ooh yeah it's pricey but if you live up in nob hill, this should be an obvious choice for sushi. Aside from the difficulty finding a dinner reservation from this place, be sure to come physically prepared to be squeezed into a seat in their tiny little closet of a sushi bar. Wow this place is TINY.
author: Taffany H.

description:
Everything at this lil gem is imported directly from Japan.  Really cool small place - have to wait for a seat on any given day, even at the sushi bar.  I would love to go back there except that SF has so many small sushi places that are amazing that I feel like I should try different ones before making a come back here.  But highly recommend their sashimi menu, I think it's the way to go there...it's fresh and awesome.  The location/facade of the restaurant is inconspicuous so you may miss it the first time around...  
It is not uber expensive but kind of pricey.  The environment is cool and friendly...I would highly suggest sitting at the sushi bar and chatting with the sushi chefs.  They are a wealth of knowledge about fish and all things sushi!  :)
author: Galina M.

description: Great, fresh, delicately prepared sushi.  Not your typical rice and rolls place.  It's all about the fish.
author: Tarri S.

description: Truly delicious. Their sashimis, nigiris, and sushi rolls are to die for. Their tuna and salmon are so fresh that they melt on the tongue. This is the restaurant where I had the best Japanese food so far in my life. The price is definitely not $$ however: it's more like $$$$. Count about $100 a dinner per person with sake and a large sample of their delicacies. Also, the restaurant is pretty small and you have to reserve long in advance. It's worth it. The waiter we had was particularly helpful and friendly, and contributed to a great experience. There is no name on the restaurant's door, and it's next to an Irish pub with a prominent sign. So finding Akiko was slighlty challenging.
author: Sebastien C.

description: What an icing on the cake after a day of getting our hairs did! We lucked out and showed up at the right time with a cancelled reservation.  We did the okamase as an cop out of identifying what to order from the cornucopia of fish and shellfish.  Everything was amazeballs and wished we could of ate the whole menu if we weren't full from the okamase.
author: Sid E.

description:
Sushi was good and fresh. . We waited very long for our food. The 4 of us was very unpleased with how long our food took.

Prob bad timing on monday
author: Austin L.

description: Overpriced...underwhelming....I should have known based on the "organic sake"...I run from all things organic....Bill just for me $140...I'm still hungry....I'm eat sashimi everyday...wasn't bad fish but overpriced by FAR!  Gotta pay that sf rent I guess..The ball is passed onto customer......enjoy....
author: Jae L.

description:
Best sushi experience so far in SF...still waiting to fly over to Japan though. 

-We had the chef's tasting/choice option.---our sushi chef, was very nice and asked us what we liked for our preference of fish. 
-The fish is imported straight from the fish market in Japan.
-The restaurant is family owned, which is really nice to see. 
-The dad of the sons who run the restaurant even came out with a special grilled salmon to share with us. We felt welcomed.
-I did not have any of their specialty rolls, but that was not our intentions to began with. (Im sure they were just as delicious as the sashimi)  
-a few items that I remember that we had, a flying fish sashimi, kobe beef, and uni. 
-Price about $270~ plus for two people including drinks and a chef's choice option.
-If you are wanting a real sashimi this is a great place to visit. 
-make reservations!!!!!!!
author: Jackie W.

description:
Like a parking ticket you forgot to pay, a few of these rolls came up and smacked me in the face. By nature I have wussy mouth syndrome, so spicy food is constantly sneaking up to slap me around, but when I tried the firecracker and the dynamite rolls, I was genuinely surprised at the heat.

Undoubtedly, someone out there will read my words, order one of these rolls, and be disappointed that it doesn't even warm their tongue. Again, people, I've got a hardcore case of wussy mouth syndrome, so for me it was surprising enough. 

What I can say with certainty is that this joint is intimate and perfectly lovely. I had a nice dinner here with friends from work and we were able to score a long table in the back with plenty of room for our hefty group. Not that we're each hefty. Just that the size of our group was hefty. You'll probably want to get a reservation if you're seating more than a two-top. I was here on a weeknight and it was pretty full.

It's simply decorated and I'm a sucker for exposed brick. The menu is simple and although I didn't get the sashimi, it looked to be nummy and well-cut so don't overlook that part of the menu.

Rolls are moderately priced. Some inexpensive options down at $7-8, and some higher priced up near $15. Still a steal for the quality coming out of the kitchen and they were generously sized. By the end of the night, our group was a little more hefty. Not in number, but in actual measurement. Good sign.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Made reservations months in advance for 4 for a Friday night.  Had very high expectations and they were certainly met.  We arrived early and had a drink while we waited for our companions .  Our server Allan, who was absolutely fantastic, recommended a great sake choice.  

We were seated in the back which was nice (next time we'll do the sushi bar.)  Place is very small, maybe a little cramped, but with a great ambiance and not too loud.  We threw caution to the wind and had Allan order sashimi and sushi for us.  Everything was great, fish of the highest quality, and perfectly prepared and artistically displayed--a very earthy, mushroomy abalone sushi and white salmon sashimi (never had it before) were the standouts.  Our least favorite was too sweet sauce on scallops and oversized amaebi.  Service was attentive, and the food delivered promptly over time (and not all at once which can be very annoying at sushi places--so thanks!)--the whole staff seemed to be pitching in to deliver and explain the items.  

One thing that bugged me is the hostesses didn't wear uniforms--looked like they just came in off the street--but who cares really?  

Place is very expensive, but well worth it--we will definitely be returning to try the sushi bar experience.  I haven't had a better sushi experience in the city.
author: Archer W.

description:
Some facts: 
-smallish, with tables and some seats at the sushi bar 
-I believe they stop seating at 9pm
-the staff are polite and attentive
-the sushi chefs are fun and knowledgeable
-it is not easy to find from the street (look for the Irish Bar/Pub sign hanging and it's right under there)

Other thoughts and personal opinions:

Be ready to drop some baaannnkkk, BUT it is totally worth it.  I sat at the sushi bar and enjoyed watching the chefs craft edible art for their customers.  Sushi Chefs Ricky and Geoffery were both knowledgeable and fun!  I ordered sashimi, nigiri, a roll, and some gomae.  Lots and lots and lots of delicious fish.  I cannot remember all the different kinds of fish I had because there were so many!

I will return when I want to really treat myself to a delicious sushi dinner.
author: Chantal B.

description:
High quality fish, and friendly chefs.  I sat at the bar a few weeks back with the girlfriend.  We ordered mostly nigiri, which we enjoyed thoroughly.  The chef talked us into some tuna that was tagged and later hand-caught by a scuba diver (which somehow translates into a less-stressful death for the salmon which somehow translates into tasting like butter -- whatever, still delicious).

We also ordered a fried roll (don't remember what kind), and it was fried deliciousness.  Couldn't really make out the fish, but the overall taste was excellent.

I'd definitely head back.  Bill was about $30 per person after tax and tap (food only).
author: Bill H.

description:
My vote for the best Japanese restaurant in SF proper.
Sat at the sushi bar and watching the staff work was also a treat.
author: Leonard H.

description: Solid sushi in the Financial District!  It's usually difficult to get a table here, so you're best off making a reservation.  Great interior, and traditional sushi preparation.  I ordered the Tekka roll (tuna, scallion, avocado, crispy shiso, pickled carrot)  and their Futomaki (egg omelette, avocado, cucumber, and spinach).  Both were fantastic - I really enjoyed them.  The Futo, often cumbersome to eat, was a perfect size, and both rolls were bursting with flavor and texture.  Great service.  This restaurant is a keeper!
author: Zach S.

description:
Wow.  This place is really really really good!  I haven't had this quality of sushi in San Francisco.  For those from Los Angeles, Akiko Restaurant is on par with Sushi Nozawa and Sugarfish!

I ordered the Nigiri w/ Chicken teriyaki, and ordered an extra spicy tuna roll.  Lets just say i didn't need the extra roll.  I didn't realize that you get miso soup, 4 pieces of fish, and a lot of chicken and rice with the Nigiri / Teriyaki combo, which would have been enough.

That being said the spicy tuna roll was great, not too spicy but you can tell the freshness of the fish.

I got 1 pc of Salmon, tuna, yellowtail, and mackerel with the order.  All fresh, buttery and great.  Note the freshness was extremely fresh.  The tuna was very red!  The Chicken Teriyaki was also fresh. You get a plate full of nicely grilled marinated chicken with a side of rice.

Since it was lunch i didn't order any drinks but they had beer and saki.  I will go back and order drinks.

I spent $28 on lunch.  I can honestly say, when I bring my wife here for dinner, we will probably spend around $200 because everything I shoved in my face was incredible.

If I was to knock 1 aspect of the establishment, the servers at the bar were "sushi snobs".  When I asked "what kind of fish is that" and pointed to a piece of fish on the plate, the guy said "sashimi".  I said "no...what is this piece of fish with the stripes", and he answered "striped bass".

Other than that, I thought everything is grade A, and will be back.  This is my favorite sushi place in SF.
author: Jeremy E.

description:
Probably the best sushi in San Francisco. Overall taste and presentation was excellent. I enjoyed the calamari and the 49er roll.

This place is much nicer than your average sushi place. It is still small and the sake menu is impressive. If you know someone that is particular about their sushi, take them here. The mochi ice cream was a nice touch at the end as well.
author: Ryan M.

description:
This is an over-do review from 2014.

Given the great reviews, I was excited to try their omakase with my fiance. 
We sat at the bar for omakase. If I sit at the bar for omakase, I'm expecting the whole sushi experience - and yet I noticed the chef was not explaining what each fish/dish. When I asked what a particular fish was called, he paused and couldn't answer. Silence. Awkward and completely unprofessional. He also let a few of the pieces fall to the side after he placed them on our plate (...maybe he was new!?) Sounded like most of the chefs had great culinary experience but no deep sushi specific training...

Fish was decently fresh but this spot isn't a top tier sushi restaurant that can warrant $100+ pp for omakase. I most certainly prefer Kiss Seafood, Saru or pay a bit more and go to Maruya.
author: D L.

description:
Wow, I can't believe my original review of this place was about 4.5 years ago!  Akiko's Restaurant has changed a lot since then, but only in appearance.  The walls have been repainted, the menus are stylish, the music has a trendier feel, and the place is more crowded for dinner.  BUT (and this is the most important thing) the food is just as delicious as it always has been.  Might even be better.  I originally started coming here because my dad lived just down the street, but even though he moved away a long time ago, I still try to make it across down as often as possible to get what I consider to be the best sushi in SF.

I always sit at the sushi bar, and love talking to the chef (usually Joe, but there is another guy there too - sadly, I did not catch his name) about what is fresh and how to best eat it.  Apparently not everything should get dunked in wasabi/soy - stupid American!  I love that they only order small quantities of each fish, and never freeze anything.  Yes, that means they might occasionally be out of something, but there is always a delicious alternative.  

On a recent visit, we had their last order of Kindai, a sustainable blue fin tuna from Japan.  We also tried the Copper River Salmon from Alaska...this was amazing!  Like no salmon I've ever tried before, it melted away in my mouth and was such a vibrant color it looked like candy (see the pic I posted of it).  The star of the meal, at least for me, was our final dish - the Uni Nigiri Das.  This was smoked uni, with salmon roe and quail egg yolk on top of rice, wrapped in nori.  Popped the whole thing in my mouth, and the flavors just exploded!  I didn't want to eat or drink anything else for a few minutes after, so I could continue to savor the delicious-ness.  Seriously amazing!

Can't wait to come back!!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I am wary of places that are too dressed up for sushi. I don't like fusion sushi or fish that is way dressed in something that ruins the taste of pure fish. Sushi-snob I know. 

But this place is great - the specials proved to be fantastic. We ordered the omakase and even though I hate Saba Mackerel, the horse mackerel was pretty good. I love the tekka poke tuna dish they give you - huge chunks in a good marinade. The red snapper, ebi, and halibut were also among my favorites there. We tried extra things like tempura (not that great) and the scallop was just alright. I'd stick to the special fishes for the day! Plus, make sure you make a reservation b/c I saw so many get turned away thinking walk-ins were welcome. Also, don't confuse this place with Akiko's Sushi Bar in Chinatown. The story is the sushi bar used to be where they were but they moved and sushi bar kept the name. This place is hard to see because it's not clear (no shop sign) it's right next to an alley for an Irish pub (I had the view from my seat right next to the main door)
author: Jamie T.

description:
I eat here for lunch at least once a week, have been know to go as four times a week.   Its that good.   Sitting at the bar having a seaweed salad (I think the best in the city) and 5 piece sashimi  is like watching art before your eyes.   The mainstay staff (Trevor and Paul) is awesome -- they have had some recent turnover and finding a hostess is extremely difficult these days with the economic boom (so they get a pass from me).   

They also offer a lot of interesting sustainable fish as well as interesting selections both local and from Japan.   For instance, at their recommendation, I recently tried uni from Hokkaido Japan, Santa Barbara, CA and Russia.   I learned a lot about the nuances of uni!    

Go.   I'll probably be there...
author: Lynn P.

description:
Where I first tried octopus! Recommended, along with the gyoza.

Haven't been back to this restaurant in a while, but I need to make another trip! 

It IS easy to overlook because there's not really a sign but it's right next to that open bar/restaurant area on this block of Bush St. Also, be aware that it's closed from 2:30- 5:30. It's definitely a more intimate setting with dark lighting and candles - great for date night!
author: Navjeet K.

description: I give a 3-star if it weren't because of the uncooked rice! I was blindsided by the good yelp ratings and their photos.... Our 6 piece Nigiri Sampler ($23) were tiny and the rice weren't even cooked thoroughly (crunchy in the center)! The fatty white tuna belly weren't fatty at all ($10), then the Hamachi belly was okay ($10). Turns out I like Akiko's Rainbow Roll ($14), it has a bit of citrus or plum sauce (can't distinct) and deep fried soft shell crab ($10 4 pieces) was fine as well.
author: Dawn C.

description:
For my 700th review, it has to go to Akiko.  Kevin L brought me here for my bday and it did not disappoint.  The best way to describe this place..... A modern day rendition of the classic sushi restaurants such as Ino in San Francisco and Yume in Alameda.  They have taken classic Japaneses sushi and created their own twist.  However, they were still able to keep it simple and let the fish shine.  I have been to other Japanese establishments that have twisted it so much that the integrity of the fish is lost in translation.  For me, putting all of that sirachi and mayo sauce, it just kills the fish.

They receive most if not all of their sushi from Japan.  The explanation on where the fish came from and how it was prepared gave me a better appreciation, respect, and understanding.  It's all in the details and it shows when it is presented.  If you are confused on what to get?  Get Omakase, Chef's choice.

Things that you have to get here

A5 wagyu sushi, amazing how they nitro oxy the fat and sprinkled it on top
Russian Uni, the creamiest uni I have ever tasted
Toro, very fresh
sous vide diced ankimo,  sous vide ankimo?!?  YES
Walu
Tuna Belly
Arctic char
Black prawns from Japan........I wasn't a fan of this but my friends loved it
Scallop
Wild King Salmon
Kanpachi........not a fan of this fish

We didn't order any of the udon, tempura, bento box combo.  I just went with what they do best, their fish.  It was amazing.


And I shit you not..............there's one dish that you have to get here.  It's the California roll.  Yes..........I know.  They ground fresh toasted sesame seed and layer it on top of the California roll that just made this come together.  Just get it.

This place is a bit pricey but based on how the fish was imported, it is expected.  So bookmark this place, it's definitely a must try.
author: jason g.

description: This restaurant has a the best sashimi I have ever had. Also the staff were really nice and they told me that the sushi is usually less than 3 days old when served. Along with the staff being very kind it also had speedy service, but when coming to your table they gave a five-star presentation to serve the hot sake. The exterior of the building isn't something to be proud of though, it's boring and doesn't have any sign at all. This has caused me to walk pass it a couple of times thinking it was part of another restaurant. When I figured out that it was in fact its own restaurant inside it had a very interesting atmosphere that I half liked; half was modern and the other was the original wall. The first time going there I was seated in the half of the room with the original wall which would have been cool if they put something over it to make it look less like an abandon castle. The second time every thing was nearly perfect with a modern atmosphere at the sushi bar.
author: Sasha G.

description:
After living several months in London without satisfying my sushi cravings, I went on a sushi rampage when I returned for the holidays to SF, land of seafood aplenty.  Since I was working for the week in FiDi, I decided to drop in to Akiko and see how long the lunch wait would be.  The hostess provided an estimate of 45 minutes since I didn't have a reservation, and I decided to window shop for a bit.

Received a text 20 minutes later, much quicker than expected, and I dashed over.  I'm sure you could see the fish silhouettes all over my irises.  I was seated at the bar Sashimi special for $32 and uni for ~$9 was just what I was craving, beautifully cut assortment of fish.  Each piece was generous and delicate, and exactly what I had been craving for months.
author: Minnie M.

description: Was it because we were sitting at the table instead of the sushi bar?? Or was it just a off day??  Other then the house cured Ikura & A5 Wagyu with truffle, the omakase was just ok.
author: Prascilla L.

description:
My wife and I use to frequent Sushi Joints quite often when we first started dating.  Then after the birth of our son, it just seemed harder to go to places that are more intimate like most sushi places.

SO for my birthday, she surprised me with dinner at Akiko's!

We decided to go with the omakase.  I told her that places in Japan generally don't let you chose omakase when not at the bar, but in this case it worked to our advantage.

Omakase (December 2014)
-Agedashi Tofu: This was super subtle but super good.  Whatever he put in the ponzu was amazing.  There were subtle hints of spiciness on top of the flavor which was very pleasant!
-Salad: I thought this was only so-so, but my wife loved it.  There was a green there that had a very fresh-herb taste but also had a slight bitter aftertaste.
-Hotate: The scallop wasn't super fresh.  This is normally one of my wife's favorites but she didn't enjoy it either. It had the sweet initial taste of a quality hotate but the after taste was a bit fishy I'm afraid.
-Shiroebi: Kind of the same problem as the Hotate.  The initial flavor of the shrimp was sweet and the texture was there, but it had a fishy after taste.
-Kuromauguro (toro) Probably one of the worst toro I've had.  The fish was a pale pink.  The texture was sandy/grainy and the pieces we had, had that hard/stringy peice that I hate with sushi.

At this point, my wife  was pretty upset.  Out rare night out and we didn't like anything except the tofu so far???

Then the turning point was 1/2 way through the service.  The server (who seemed like either a head server/host/part owner).  Whoever he was he started talking to us and letting us know about the fish coming out.  instead of just the name.  this was when the freshness of the fish jumped up a few notches.

Kinki:amazing.  Great flavor.  Sweet and rich.  Amazing texture.
Kenpachi: Was good.  Par for the course.  Good flavor and fresh.
Umimasu: The trout had a great texture and was also fresh!
Kamasu:Barracuda-I've only had it two other times.  Once in San Diego and the other in Austin TX.  This one was up there with the both of them.  Such a good flavor!  
Shiromaguro: Again, par for the course.  I love white tuna and this was fine.
Kinmedai: Okay, now were talking!  This was incredible!!!!  The reddish skin seemed to be slightly seared because it had a different texture.  And the smokey flavors!  The oils.  The texture.  The after taste!  I was in sushi heaven!
Sawara: I've always been a fan of the mackerel.  It's just hard to prepare well when it has so many bones and the texture isn't the best, but this Spanish Mackerel was OFF THE HOOK!
Madai: This snapper was also filled with natural oils and an amazing smokey flavor.  Such an amazing taste!  The final trio plate is the only reason why I would say Akiko is one of the top sushi joints in the City!

The night started off really shaky.  The place is super stuffy and maybe I'm spoiled but during omakase, I'm use to getting some 411 dropped on me, not just the names of the fish.  Ray (I think was his name) was awesome.  He gave us attention, he dropped knowledge.  Was super friendly.  And the last 5 on the list above were AMAZING!  Totally made up for the horrendous first half of the meal service.

My advice: Don't order the omakase and order off the special/seasonal menu.  Don't go for the normal nigiri you see everywhere else.  If you go this route, this will be an amazing night out.  Will go back again!!

2.5stars for the omakase and stuffy atmosphere.  4.5stars for the special nigiri and Ray (I hope that's his name. Dude was awesome).  Avg=3.5stars
author: Anthony L.

description: I ordered 2 rolls. The Sake roll with salmon and the Tekka roll with fresh tuna. The fish was absolutely divine. Very fresh and they ratio of fish to rice in the roll was decent. The actual size of each rolls were smaller then anticipated, leaving me hungry for more. The place is a bit pricey, so expect to drop around $30 each person for a meal if you're really hungry. The sake had huge chunks of salmon that was the best tasting and freshest I've ever eaten. The Tekka roll highlight was the crunchy component that added to the chunks of tuna. Due to the small portion and high price ( and the fact that I'm not rollin' in dough) I will not come here again. If you can afford it go ahead and blow a couple bills on this place!
author: Manisha S.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots and that's saying a lot because I love me some sushi. It says $$ but it is definitely on the border of $$$. My average bill there is $160 for four people. Although I do tend to order the toro bellies. All in all, it is a nice restaurant with really fresh sushi.
author: David D.

description: Small Japanese restaurant in Union Square.  I wouldn't expect a great service here, since it's so small and the tables are always full.  Expect yourself to entertain your tastebuds with some good sushi, and you'll be satisfied at time of departure.
author: Lindsey O.

description:
Akiko is the name of one of the sushi chefs, the little female one behind the sushi bar. Hayashi Shiyo-san is the man behind the sushi bar, who speaks Kansai or Osaka Ben (dialect). Together they have owned this restaurant for 13 years, and they anchor down all the sushi orders at this nice little gem downtown, which seats 49 total, with 8 at the sushi bar. If you want to go here and you don't pay attention walking by it, you'll miss it, as the signage is not ostentatious at all. 

My colleague and I came in on a Wednesday night, and it was pretty much full. However the Sushi bar had seats, and so we sat where I always prefer to sit, at the sushi bar, to see the craft and converse with the sushi maker.

Once I knew he and Akiko were actually Japanese and not Korean, Chinese or something else, I felt comfortable ordering sushi Omakase style (Chef, I leave it to you) for $50 per person. I also asked for a preference to Nigiri ("Nigiri de').

Chef Hayashi made a range of Nigiri creations that were understated, but had nice little accents to them. Many of the servings had a double order plate of 4 pieces, so that my friend and I could each get a couple to enjoy. Below is what we had, with the order size (1=2 pieces, 2=4pieces)

Hamachi (1)  $5.50
HIrame (2) $11
Shiromaguro (2) $10
King Salmon (2) $14
Kodai (2) $12
Walu (2) $11
Suzuki (2) $12
Madai (2) $12
Uni (1) $8
Aji (1) $7

As you can see, the sushi is very reasonable, especially for downtown San Francisco. Hayashi-san added little touches, like a dab of green chili sauce, or finely diced negi (green onions), chopped ginger or a little brush of sweet honey syrup to add complexity to the nigiri flavors, without overpowering the fish. 

Granted, the sushi were smaller than regular sushi you would find in Osaka, Japan, where Hayashi-san is from, but many Japanese sushi-ya in Los Angeles and San Francisco have gone to the smaller piece to provide more variety and keep the cost reasonable. The smaller rice balls fill you up less, too. 

We had 2 large Kirin beers ($7/ea) and a small Hakushika Sake (cold, $15), so with the $29 in booze, Hayashi-san served us Omakase for almost exactly $50 each, as requested, because the bill was $131 before tax. 

Umai-shi, Yasui-shi, Subarashii-shi!
author: Wanugee N.

description:
My wife and I came in for the Omakase and it was Amazing. Closest comparison I could give is Sanshigo on the Balboa Peninsula. 

The fish was extremely fresh, each sushi/nigiri was tastefully balanced with flavors of shiso, fresh truffle and ponzu to name a few.

Would definitely recommend the place to true sushi enthusiasts. The price was by no means cheap but in the end still worth it.
author: Solomon D.

description:
A nice warm evening catching up with a couple of friends to celebrate our recent engagement.  We had a wonderful dinner and ordered all the rolls, (you can't go wrong with any), 12 piece sashimi which again, were all delicious so we added 6 more, a $66 bottle of sake which was recommendation to us based on a bottle we liked but they didn't have, (good job!), then an order of monk fish liver.  Ok, let's pause on that.  I've had monk fish liver once before, many many years ago and I do recall it tasted like a can of cat food.  Not that I've had cat food before, but what I would imagine cat food would taste like based purely on the smell.  Let me just say their monk fish liver was DELICIOUS and rich just like our beloved foie gras.  I just wish they served it with some kind of bread.  Popping the piece into my mouth was like popping a good size piece of foie into my mouth.  

So, why 3 stars?  Our food was amazing, or recommended saki was amazing,  heck, even our 2 bottles of beer were amazing.  Our server was also extremely helpful and not overly attentive.  This would have been a perfect mini celebration but just as we were about to get up and go, a random server asked us to leave since there were people waiting for our table.  HOW RUDE!  

We were there for just under 2 hours and spent a whole bunch of money.  Our reservation was for 7pm and as we left the restaurant we checked our watch at it was almost 9pm.   I've never experienced this type of service  at any respectable eating establishment.  I've never even been kicked out of a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant where the table turn over rate feels like every 30 mins.  If he had just given us 2 more minutes to gather our things we would have left without being asked to leave and I would have written a raving 5 STAR REVIEW because the food was amazing!!!  

What a horrible way to end a wonderful evening.  Goes to show how much service does matter and how a slight like that can effect how the rest of your night goes...
author: Rosalind S.

description:
This place is such a hole in the wall that the sign on the front says something completely different. Please fix the sign.

I got Sushi, miso and Udon here. The Sushi was pretty bomb! The service was great too. It's a little loud but very solid Japanese food. Would go again if I was in the area. I went with a friend who had lived in Japan and she said it was great!
author: Sam L.

description: amazing fish. great wagyu, not too fatty. excellent service. would come back! butterfish sushi!!!!! arctic char sushi!!!! negi toro sushi! agedashi tofu!
author: Veba M.

description:
Yes, definitely not cheap and they have their own way going about things but the food is exceptional.

Fish, very fresh. Service, very fast and attentive. Saki, super fecken delicious two rounds down da hatch.

Came in for dinner at 5:50 and was out by 6:50 satisfied. Portions are definitely not huge so wouldn't go here to stuff myself as I know it would get really expensive.

With that said and IMHO the quality warranted the price and will be going back.

Client/date spot for sure! Downtown sushi spot FTW!
author: Jason P.

description:
Popped in here for a quick light lunch.

We got the omakase and it was pretty great for the price. Don't get me wrong, compared to places in where i'm currently living this place is expensive, but for NYC its a damn good value. 

It's pretty far from exceptional but unless you are ready to spend $500+ you can't beat the price.
author: Joshua L.

description:
So, these people complaining about the portions & timely service...this was my experience:

It's sushi. Japanese food in general does not come in "USA" sized portions, it never has. You may be surprised but not all countries feel the need to gorge themselves every time they sit down for a meal. The portions were fair and generous for the price.

Also, I think most people forget that despite it's trendy atmosphere; this restaurant IS NOT A CHAIN. It's a FAMILY OWNED & RUN restaurant. I had no issues with the service even during busy dinner hours. They were super friendly, it was easy to get their attention and they were spot on with everything. The chef even smiled and said, "Thank you" as we left. :)

The food, was good. We have had our fair share of Japanese food around San Francisco and I thought the food was one of the best in the city. 

We were being pretty piggy, I thought, with a bottle of sake, 7 piece chef's choice sashimi plate (consisted of sake (salmon), "big eye" maguro (tuna), & sea bass), 2 miso soup cups, edamame shared, 3 rolls (Dynamite, Volcano, Firecracker), and 4 pieces of mochi for dessert. Cost us roughly $68.00 for 2. That is incredibly cheap for sushi in the city!

*I might add, 3 tempura style rolls, wouldn't recommend it & will not do it again.

+1 For the atmosphere.
+1 For the friendly staff.
+1 For the delicious food.
+1 For the price.

Thanks Akiko's!
author: Sara M.

description:
Uh, I had such high expectations for this place.  Sat at a table next to a couple that were cuddly, annoying, and feeding sushi to each-other with their own chopsticks.  Clean it up people!  I usually sit at the bar to avoid situations like these but since Akiko's is pretentiously reservation only, you get where you're put upon arrival.  Food was decent, good specials, but they ran out of scallops, ocean trout, and Chu toro that evening.  Scallops?  Really?  Fail.  Too much yuzu and seasoning on most of my nigiri in general.  Fish was fresh but really expensive.  Orion beer from Okinawa, solid, Echigo not on menu...  Why?  You're already overcharging for beer anyway.  It should be.

I've travelled through Japan extensively, enjoy Japanese food with a passion and knowledge (way beyond the use chopsticks and *not* putting wasabi in soy sauce) and can tell you this place is pretty average.   For kaiseki and omakase I prefer kiss seafood, for fish I prefer Ariake, Ebisu or Oyaji.  

Time for another Japan food adventure...  It's necessary.
author: Scott S.

description:
YES.  

This was some of the best and most inventive sushi I've had in quite some time. 

I ordered the volcano roll which arrived literally looking like a volcano - the roll was cut up and stacked long way up, with drizzles of tempura bits spilling out of it like lava.  The seaweed was unusually on the inside of the roll, with the rice on the outside.  

Of course, presentation is nothing without taste.  It was delish.  Just the right combination of chili (to be honest, I would have gone for a bit more had I had the choice), crunchy tempura, and soft cooling avocado.

The setting is modern, clean lines, but with nice soft lighting which gives an air of calm and tranquility. 

I would however agree with some previous reviews that it was relatively difficult to get hold of the servers, and then, they weren't particularly friendly or accommodating.  But that seems to be the trend in San Fran, so why deviate from the norm.

Either way, I thoroughly enjoyed my meal and wouldn't hesitate in going back.
author: Emily C.

description:
One of my best experiences in San Francisco.  I was staying in Union Square and YELPed for the best nearby Japanesse.

I sat at the sushi bar and was introduced to a number of fish flown in from Japan.  The cut of the fish was perfect and selection was superb.  Presentation was excellent and the chef was very attentive for the almost two hours that I ate and chatted with other patrons.

A must stop if you are in the Union Square area.
author: Steven C.

description:
I came here for lunch with a friend and we arrived early to avoid the crowd. The plan worked out well because by the time we were done, the place already filled up. 

I took the recommendations from the reviews here to try the Volcano Roll and it lived up to my expectations. Spicy, crispy, and the food looked like a volcano with lava flowing out. We also had their hamachi and spicy tuna sashimi pieces and topped it off with a Rainbow Roll.

The service is prompt and efficient even when the place was super busy during noon. The food did not take long to come out and we took our time eating. 

I recommend this place with a solid four stars for the food, ambiance and choice location. It is very difficult to find good sushi in the Financial District that is within walking distance for lunch. This is conveniently located next to Irish Bank on Claude Lane.
author: Tim G.

description:
I absolutely love this place!

This place is owned by the head sushi chef and his wife, who also works there. It's been a while since I've last come here but everything on the menu is delicious. Modern sushi restaurant with an old style feel. Sit at the sushi bar if you want the freshest cuts and chat up the sushi chef. The tables around the restaurant offer cozy seating.

The fish is always fresh and the service is great. The Volcano roll is so yummy and their udons and other dishes are just as good as the sushi. They work really quickly to get you your food as fast as possible. This place is on the smaller side so for all those in the financial district or visiting the area, I would recommend coming before or after peak dining times.
 
If you work in the neighborhood and are looking for a quick sushi fix, i would definitely recommend this place. Usually I don't like to order to go sushi or take sushi home because it gets all soggy and unfresh tasting, but the take out here is amazing. It's as fresh as if you were eating at the restaurant. YUM !

- jenn
author: Jenn Y.

description: Lunch review: solid spot for a "fancier" lunch.  I'm totes against sushi in the form of a burrito so it's nice find a balance among Trendy AF, Not-Just-Picturesque and Nomz in the food form sushi here in San Francisco (*sigh of relief).  Price is right; fish is fresh; chefs and staff are courteous and friendly; ambience is pleasantly weighed by the wooden decor and the instrumental beats playing at the right volume.  You should eat here.
author: Angelica P.

description:
I remember the first time I came here I was blown away - thought it was the freshest, most delicious salmon sashimi I've had in my life.  I mean those pink slabs just melted in my mouth like omega-3-fatty fish butter.  Must try, and worth it even at $3.50 a piece.  Since then I've come back several times and not been as mind-blown as the first time, but their Volcano roll is delicious, dusted with yummy crispy fried bits.  I've brought all my family and a couple of friends here.

This place is relatively small and is often fully-booked so I've been turned away several times.  Lesson learnt:  make reservation.  The sushi chefs and servers are really cool and friendly, and the decor is elegant.
author: Letitia L.

description:
I've eaten here a couple times and been impressed both occasions. I know if you look at my other reviews I've mainly been giving out 4 and 5 stars but these places have all exceeded my expectation in service and food, including Akiko's. 

Both times I've went to Akiko's for dinner I've had reservations. It's a smaller sushi place so they do turn people away. But I must say there aren't too many sushi restaurants that have wowed me like this. I've had a variety of dishes from the menu. From rolls to sashimi and from poke to steak and ribs. "Steak?" you say? Yeah, how crazy is it that a Japanese sushi restaurant can make such a great steak! The fish is super fresh and I've had sea life that I've never heard of before. 

I can rave on about this place for days but I won't. Instead I'll be heading back to Akiko's with camera in hand to show you just how awesome this place is!

The Good:
- fresh seafood (a must at a sushi restaurant)
- great selection of sake
- personable sushi chefs
- small and intimate

The Bad:
- n/a
author: Anthony M.

description:
Salad greens, cucumber, avacado, soy vinaigrette, wonderful and so fresh.  Miso soup, very flavorful.  I chose the sake roll and didn't love it but my husband got the rainbow and it was great.  He would only give me one piece.:(  
There is no sign, by design I'm told, so you have to go by address.  The $$ rating should really be $$$ and they ask if you have a reservation - for LUNCH.  It is good.
author: Pat A.

description: I was really excited to eat at Akiko's, and I am pleased to say it did not disappoint at all! We made reservations about three weeks earlier but still could not get a table until 8:30 pm. We were several minutes late because we walked past the restaurant twice without noticing it - there is no sign! Once we realized where we were, we found a very small and intimate restaurant with an exceedingly friendly and accommodating staff. We opted for the omakase dinner and relied on the chef's recommendations. Not one of our courses disappointed. We had an excellent bottle of wine to accompany our food, which was recommended by our server. For the last course, our server asked if we would be interested in the Wagyu beef. Coming from beef country, we were not really looking for beef but agreed to give it a try. That was the best piece of beef I have ever eaten. The service at this tiny restaurant was spectacular. If you are in the area and want some excellent sushi and Japanese fare, you cannot go wrong with Akiko's!
author: Brian F.

description:
Great service, yet lack of vegetarian options. 

Since my friend, who gets obsessed of eating sashimi after his first visit of Akiko, highly recommended this restaurant, I decided to come here rather than my favorite Japanese restaurant Umami. Although my friend has only been to Akiko once awhile ago, the sushi chef and one of the waiters immediately recognized him and shook his hands. This shows that Akiko not only cares about the food, but also the people. This is prominent in particular when the sushi table was full even around 11 p.m. when my friend and I left the restaurant. 

According to my friend and his other friends, the sashimi at Akiko is extremely fresh and the sushi is well executed. Similar to the sushi chef at Jiro's Dream of Sushi (an award-winning documentary about a Japanese sushi chef), the sushi chef at Akiko thinly brushes a thin layer of soy sauce on the sashimi and a thin layer of wasabi on the rice in order to bring out the original flavors of food. If the food at Akiko is not so fresh, the sushi chef would not have been to do this. 

The only reason that I gave Akiko three stars rather than four stars is that it lacks vegetarian options. I could barely order anything there. Thus, unless you can eat or love eating deep sea fish, you are better off going to a different Japanese restaurant. Nonetheless, the tamago sashimi was hand-made and well-executed. I would not mind coming back to Akiko just for the tamago. However, I think the chef put way too much scallions in the miso soup that covers the original flavor of it. 

Overall, LG and I had a great experience there, and I would recommend you going to Akiko.

Food: 4
Service: 5
Decor: 3
author: May Y.

description: Service was friendly and attentive, but who cares when the sushi is mediocre at best. 12 piece sashimi came with 3 piece big eye tuna, 3 piece salmon. And the cut was tiny triangular pieces. Definitely not worth the money. At this price point I expect way more. And better variety of fish in "taster" sashimi.
author: Samer N.

description:
My partner and  I had our dinner here last night.  As I was approaching it, I realized I've been here before, many, many years ago, when the place was still quite rustic.  How it has transformed into a very modern, stylish place today!!! 

As others have mentioned, the staff are very friendly and attentive (maybe even too much if you're looking for some intimate chat).  We asked for, and got some excellent recommendations, with the Russian uni at the top of the heap.  It is more briny but also sweeter than the standard uni and is just more intensely flavored.  I enjoyed the head of the blue shrimp better than it's body.  The head has so much meat on it and was fried perfectly.  The body, on the other hand, is rather chewy with not so much flavor to sufficiently reward you for all your troubles.  We also enjoyed the wagyu nigiri with shaved white truffles on top.  The light sear truly enhanced the flavor of the meat.  However, at $30 for 2 pieces, I'll probably pass next time.  

This is probably going to be the place for us to go back to the next time we look for more unusual sushi options.
author: Yvette F.

description:
The thing that really stood out to me about my amazing omakasi meal at Akiko's Restaurant is how unique every dish I was served tasted.  I've enjoyed sushi since I was a child and at high end establishments across the world, so I know what all the standard sushi dishes generally taste like.  At Akiko's I was amazed at how every piece of fish served redefined my perceptions of what that fish should taste like.


Akiko's is truly unique and special.  If you think you know sushi come here and get an education in a new level of fish preparation.  This is at the top level of sushi in San Francisco.
author: Cary N.

description: Dang. Definitely one of the better Japanese restaurants I've been to in the city. I think it might even displace my previous favorite Umi (Potrero Hill). Their 6 piece sushi sampler was amazing albeit pricey.
author: Thomas C.

description:
So, my experience here did not start out great to the point I wanted to give them like 1 to 2 stars. We had a reservation for 3 people for 8 PM. We arrived on time and noticed there were a lot of people waiting and that one couple was already very upset.

After about 30 minutes of waiting & a lot of tables being seated I realized we were going to waiting a long time for a table because all their tables are two seaters so for there to be a big enough table to fit 3 two table would have to leave. Finally the hostess offered us a free beer for our wait which was a nice start to the long wait. 

Well at 8:50 or so the 9:00 reservations start to arrive and be seated. At that point a spot opened at the sushi bar that would fit 3. We inquired about it and were told that they were working on getting us a table and proceeded to seat two gentlemen at the sushi bar spot, note they had walked in like 5-10 minutes before we mentioned that spot. Well at this point of an hour of waiting we were all hungry and pretty frustrated. I inquired why we were not seated at the spot at the sushi bar and were informed that the two patrons were VIPs and the manager told the hostess she had to seat them there because it was the best seat in the house. I then asked to speak with a manager because that is just bullshit after waiting an hour! Well the manager would not come over and by then another spot at the bar had opened up, so basically the manager avoided us.

We sat down and were served a free app pretty quickly and choose our sushi as quickly as possible. The sushi came and was AMAZING! The manager kept coming to visit and gave us a free sushi roll, hot sake, and dessert which was a nice touch after waiting an hour when we had a reservation. However, if the food had not been so awesome I would never consider going back again. RECOMMENDATION: DO NOT GO IF YOU ARE LARGER THAN A PARTY OF 2!
author: Pam J.

description:
How have I not reviewed this place. There is absolutely no better sushi (nigiri) better in San Francisco.

If you want rolls, go somewhere else, if you want cooked food, go somewhere else. If you want to spend good money, getting wonderfully put together Nigiri, come here.

I've eaten 6 or 7 times here now and this is what I can tell you:
1) You must have a reservation. You can typically get one a couple days in advance, so it isn't the worst thing in the world, but you can not walk in
2) Order Nigiri.
3) If they have it then get: Umimasu (Ocean Trout), Wagyu Beef, and "whatever else they have special that night."

You do not need to add soy sauce to what they serve you, they've made it to order as best it should be enjoyed.

This place isn't cheap, but it is worth it.
author: H B.

description: If you want to celebrate, this is the way. Soul shatteringly good 3 hour omakase experience. Nice modern decor, especially the sushi bar. EVERYTHING was like butter - including the salmon belly and hamachi belly. The blue fin tuna maguro from Boston was amazing. The uni on a spoon (I say "spuni") was delicious! We sat at the sushi bar, watched the skillful preparation, and ate like champions. We paired with sake, which was also enjoyable. We ended with the waygu beef with tons of truffle.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Came in for lunch to try one of my favorite dishes.....Chirashi. While Omakase may be the way to go for dinner .....a great Chirashi is what I am looking for in a great sushi bar for lunch!!  With the great reviews I was expecting to be sitting in front of Jiro himself. I did think the fish was good, but it did not have the variety a great Chirashi should have. It did have Escolar, however that is not one of my personal favorites. The dish was served in a cool ceramic bowl, but it did not impress me at all with presentation. This was definitely the priciest Chirashi I have had..... unfortunately not close to being the best.   I may try this place again for dinner ; however, I am not convinced this place warrants comparisons to Japan just because they get the fish and kobe beef from there. 
3.5 stars
author: Shane S.

description: Akikos is a great Union Square spot - it's hard to find a quality spot in the neighborhood. The service was attentive but not overbearing and the fish is delightfully fresh. As one reviewer commented I wouldn't categorize Akikos as $$ but rather $$$.
author: Krystal F.

description:
The Sashimi Tasting was average compare to other typical place but cost way above others.
The fish selection was very ordinary (albacore tuna, big eye tuna, sea bass, king salmon, yellowtail). 

The  kamasu and nama uni was very good. However, overall 80 dollar for an individual meal and it was not memorable.
author: Adam T.

description:
Big Rick

Very cramped and zero privacy. Not the place to go for a new meet or a private moment. Truly a boutique establishment eat but don't plan on being there more than an hour or they will ask you to move on to make a table turn available for the waiting list. Not very classy but I understand why a popular spot with an aggressive waiter might want to move patrons along so they can grab the cash.

At $100 for 2 people (no alcohol) this did not deliver the experience I was expecting.  Might return for lunch if process are better but dinner was a failure on value and user experience.
author: Rick C.

description:
It's taken me a while to write this review because I'm so torn. The sushi was very good, and the atmosphere was fun. It was a nice spot for a cozy date night with the hubby and even here we were attempting to make it more of a cheap weeknight date than a splurge. We felt this was clear from what we ordered, and let me make it clear that we always tip well when we are cheap because we don't want to punish the waiters. 

When ordering we asked our nice waiter for a recommendation on the nigiri. He responded with a special tuna that was on the menu that night. It was listed as 'market pricing' but considering nothing else was that outrageous we decided to go with his recommendation. He came back a few minutes after taking our order to say that the chef recommended the other cut of the tuna we had ordered so we went with it. Never once did he mention anything about the price. 

When the bill came it was $25 for the order of tuna nigiri, almost doubling the bill. I understand that it is priced where it should be, but a little warning that it was so much more expensive would have been the courteous thing to do. No good waiter points out only the most expensive item when asked for recommendations without also giving more reasonable options. To be honest it ruined the whole dinner for us. Not sure we'll be back.
author: Emily S.

description: I've been to Akiko's quite a few times and for the most part have always enjoyed it. Went for my birthday with my mother and had a great time. This one star review is regarding the new hostess with bleached light blue-ish hair. I went with a friend for lunch and was told there would be a wait (I totally understand, they are very popular and therefore very busy). She said there would be a table in half an hour so we went walking around. Came back after 25 minutes and when we approached her, the same hostess just stared at us with a look that implied "why are you bothering me?" I thought it was obvious that we came back to check on the status of any available tables, but since she just stared at us and didn't say anything, I felt the need to explain myself. I said, "oh... we're just here because you asked us to come back in 30 minutes" She kept staring and eventually said "I still don't have a table for you." So then I asked, "will it be more than fifteen minutes?" and she said yes firmly. I'm not sure if she understands the role of a hostess (I've worked every role in the FOH of many restaurants, so there's no excuse that I don't know what I'm talking about) but part of her job is to make guests feel comfortable, not like they're bothering you with their presence. Please don't take for granted that I would like to spend my money at your place... for that reason, I would like to be treated with some courtesy. I would like to apologize in advance because I know it's unfair to let this one experience with a rude (and obviously inexperienced) hostess define my feelings towards Akiko's, and to assure the business that this is not the case. I certainly will return and I will update this review based on any positive future experiences I have there.
author: Jordie H.

description: After doing my research to find a good Sushi Place in the City. I took my wife and daughter here for lunch. We Made a reservation on Open table and they called about 2 hours before to confirm. It is really unnoticeable from the outside, but very nice inside. I'll cut right to it...the food and service were excellent. Our servers name was Allen and he did a nice little tasting Menu for the 3 of us that was fantastic. He was an excellent server! It started with a 12 piece sashimi tasting platter, that included ocean trout and tuna belly. Then we had several different Nigiri dishes brought to us and 2 different rolls. The Akikos roll was one of the best rolls I have ever had. When the menu was complete it was about $140 for the 3 of us including a beer for the Wife and I. I said wait we need MORE! So we ordered 6 pieces of our favorite Nigiri. It was the Smoked Salmon Belly and it just melted in your mouth with amazing flavor. My Daughter loved everything she devoured! We will definitely go back.
author: Wesley C.

description:
last friday was my second visit to akikos.  the first time we were there for a friends birthday and it was a set menu.  the food was delicious.

this time we got the whole experience, making the reservation, etc.

we arrrived on time to our reservation but we waited a good half an hour before getting seated.  once seated we waited another good chunk of time before they paid attention to us.  once they paid attention to us, our server asked us if we were in a rush and that if we were for us to be aware that things are going to be slow.  that comment irked me a little bit but overall the food and service were pretty good. we basically sat down and asked for our server twice.  thats not too much is it?  we ordered beer and they forgot it.  we reminded them and they brought it right away.  they also accidentally left it off the tab too.  we knew it was accidental because he told us so after.  no freebies here!  haha

anyways onto the star of this place, the food!  we ordered a couple specials the copper river salmon, the special yellowtail.  i thought the salmon was super buttery and delicious.  ive never had a thing for yellowtail.  we also got the waloo which was lightly seared with salt.  i loved it.  i think searing the fish lightly brings out the butter flavor yum yum.  ikura, tobiko, tomago all super delicious and fresh.  if youve never tried ikura, try it here because its not fishy and they serve it ice cold.

we also had the saba shioyaki, which was moist and yummy.  agedashi tofu.  i actually cant remember what else we tried but their standouts are definitely their nigiri.  the rice to fish ratio is insane!  litterally a small sliver of rice to big pieces of fresh fish.

we came back again to try their omakase.  so delicious!  definitely one of the best sushi places in the city.  they are hard to find!
author: claudia y.

description:
One of my favorite (top 5) sushi restaurants.  Love the IKURA and WALU.  I was told to always come on Tuesday or Wednesday because items will run out.  Also, most fresh on those two days. 

Enjoy!
author: Jessica P.

description:
Loved this place! Hope they didn't hate me.  I was trying to take a pic of the yummy dishes for YELP and I dropped my phone right on the dish.  ENLARGE PHOTO AND YOU WILL SEE THE BREAK.  The break was so loud, everyone looked over at me.

(Yes, I did change this review from another restaurant.  Like a dummy, I had reviewed the wrong place! I didn't realize it until I tried to take a couple friends to eat there. LoL)
author: Natasha Y.

description:
Went to Akiko's based on reviews and I must say the reviews were spot on. The sushi was the freshest I can remember having. While the sushi menu is not extensive, there are a good number rolls and creations on the menu such as to not overwhelm you while still presenting you with a fine selection. The sake list is good as well, try the sake sampler. 

It's a smaller place with a chic decor and good lighting. Reservations are definitely recommended. It was a pleasure watching the sushi making process from the sushi bar. Try the ocean trout! 

This is my new favorite sushi spot in SF.
author: Claus S.

description:
Visited Akiko's a few weeks ago and was very impressed.

This is a reservation only establishment, but let me tell you, it is well worth doing some planing to make time for this gem! It is definitely a popular destination and is small, so weekend rez might be tough, so give a weekday a try!

So far Akiko's has been the best sushi I've had in San Francisco! 5 Stars all the way. Great food, service, ambiance and overall experience.

We had a variety of sushi/sashimi and rolls and found everything to be incredibly fresh, beautifully constructed/presented and most importantly everything was awesome-sauce delicious!

Our server had some great suggestions from the daily special for us to try and he hit the nail on the head with a salmon from the west coast waters that was UNREAL!

Additionally, we had some Udon and it was fantastic as well. I'd highly recommend anyone to check out Akiko's NOW!
author: Justin O.

description:
Thought I already wrote a review for this place, but I guess not.  

Hands down best Japanese restaurant in the Bay Area right now.  Yep - you heard that right.  Everything here is truly fantastic.

Sit at the sushi bar, and ask them for the chef's choice for sashimi.  The fish here is super fresh, and all the prime cuts are flawlessly buttery.  They are generous with their portions, and you can usually start a great chat with any of the sushi chefs at the front.  No really, the Hamachi here is simply amazing.

They also have japanese imported Kobe here, which they will serve nigari style for you with truffle shavings.  So if you are asking for the chef's selection (omakase), you might well do this too.
