Lastly, the owner here is always trying to do something tech related with food.  You might spot him taking film and pictures here and there.  Since they will them present their best, this is always quite a treat!
author: Mark M.

description:
I know I was supposed to love this place but it really fell short of my expectations. 

No doubt the fish itself was fresh and buttery. However, the roles were sub-par and the Ikura (cured in house, apparently), was incredibly under salted. 

It's also rather pricey and the service was only acceptable -- we weren't checked on at all during our meal.

While if I'd had sashimi only, I may have been happy, everything else was only okay. I don't think I"ll go back.
author: Rachel M.

description: Nice spot for lunch. Fresh fish and their _ teriyaki dishes have a really good twist.
author: Orien W.

description:
No need to think twice about this place. Just go !

Wagyu sushi with truffles!!
author: Anthony V.

description: The restaurant was small and and laid out properly. The staff was prompt and attentive. Now that I have that out of the way... The quality of fish set this place on the top of my sushi destinations. Just be ready to pay for it!
author: Ian M.

description:
Hands down, the food and service here are exceptional. I've been to this restaurant a few times already and they never disappoint. They have many dishes to choose from, and I feel like I never have to stick to one particular "safe" dish each time I visit. 

Once I ordered octopus much to the waiter's surprise (and delight?), which made me confused at first. He arrived with the plate, and when I started eating a piece and couldn't seem to find a moment to stop chewing on it, I noticed the Japanese chef who prepared my dish was laughing at my efforts to eat octopus. I didn't realize how tough octopus could be, and it's perhaps rarely ordered at the restaurant, but I still enjoyed (and finished) it. It was a fun experience, and I think the chefs do an amazing job.

I guess one downside would be that you have to make reservations in order to eat here, but honestly, I didn't have to make any reservations too far in advance. It's a rather close and intimate setting, so I'd definitely bring a date to impress!
author: Alex D.

description: I do not write many reviews, but felt moved to do so for this wonderful restaurant.  I really know high quality sushi and sashimi and my dinner at the sushi bar tonight, served by Dwayne, was truly terrific and among the few very best in San Francisco.  I had the omakase, which I recommend.  Thank you Akiko's
author: PK S.

description:
Delicious! Great atmosphere and service. 
Our waiter was really helpful with sake and sashimi recommendations. The fish was incredibly fresh and presented beautifully. Easily the best sushi I have had in the city.
author: Anneka M.

description:
I'm gonna give this place 5 stars for its 1 free order of sake for my friends bday which was on the waiter. that was pretty cool! We came in around 7 but like the waiter said they already doublebooked another group at 8 but we could still get seated. however, in the end they cancelled which was pretty good. This place is great for groups/parties of more than 4. Definitely really pretty but small area to sit! Our waiter was really nice and he came by often to refill water and serve. We ordered mostly rolls
-dynamite
-dragon
-rainbow
-firecracker (pretty spicy!)
-volcanoe (it literally looked like a volcanoe with little deep fried pieces like tempura)
-cucumber salad (my favorite!)
-tempura
-spider
-2 udon beef

I thought all the rolls were DELICIOUS! The fish was sooo fresh! I also liked how they didn't overly deep fry the firecracker, it was crispy and just right. We shared all these and were pretty full. oh and the sake was good! It got really busy around 8. 

The decor was pretty and dim. It had a nice ambience to it. It's close to subway! (the sandwich shop). 

Another star for fast service, and for desert we had

- kona coffee mochi
-green tea ice cream

the kona coffee was a bit icy. it was alright. i liked the green tea ice cream though. $4 a pop.
author: Julie Z.

description: Food was delicious and delicate. The toro was ON POINT. The only reason I wouldn't give a 5 stars is because the service was VERY slow. We were the first seated and people who ordered their food after us still got their food faster and left before us.
author: Justin C.

description:
I had a great time here! Made a reservation the day of, and was seated right as I walked in. I was even able to change my seating from a table inside to right in front of the chef. Dinner and a show! 

I got the omakase because, honestly, I know nothing about sushi and I liked not having to decide what I wanted to eat. I wish I could say what we got, but it was all over my head. All you need to know is that it was DELICIOUS. The chef was pretty cool and talked to us the entire time, and I can honestly say I enjoyed every piece. My favorites had to be the russian uni, wagyu beef, and the ama ebi.

I'd give it 5 stars, but I'm cheap and the place was a little pricey for my tastes, about 120 per person. Service was great, always had servers filling up my glass/taking away old plates. My lady friend was impressed though, so I guess it was worth it. I'll definitely come back here again. The chef mentioned that Mondays were a little less interesting due to it being the weekend's scraps - try coming after Wednesdays!
author: Kevin Z.

description: Very small and quaint with  Only 4 tables and bar. We stopped in for a snack and was immediately greeted for a table. The menu is very diverse and well  priced. I recommend the kamikaze roll. Great sushi regardless or price. Must go.
author: Davis W.

description: I like interviewing candidates here. Solid, traditional sushi.
author: David S.

description:
The fish is decently fresh. But that's about all I can say about that.

1. Super slow service and we went right when they opened (aka beat the lunch rush).
2. Chirashi barely had any fish in it...maybe the dinner version is better, but the lunch one was majorly dissapointing for $20..they could have added at least 2 more slices of fish
3. Our friend's dish came out 15min after all our dishes and he only ordered one roll. 

TIP: Try your luck at the sushi bar instead. Our table experience was terrible. At least then you can order directly from the sushi chef at the bar.
author: Kristen C.

description:
I'd like to give this a 3 star due to poor service, but the food was simply too good to warrant such a pedestrian rating.

The seafood selection is by far one of the most comprehensive from what I've seen in most sushi restaurant even going as far to the place of origin. And freshness is a premium easily found at this little restaurant.

The food is finely made, beautifully assembled and simply a delight to consume.

However, the service is a bit hectic due tot he small side, and we were downright ignored for a good half an hour. We had asked for 2 minutes to look at the menu, and were unfortunately bypassed for a good while. I'm not sure if this is a server thing or  a lack of proper restaurant flow, but it was a disappointing start of such a fine meal.
author: Justin N.

description: Went for my guy's bday. He wanted to finally try an omakase with me. Was warned due to the time of night, the entire meal would take 1.5 hrs. Entire meal realistically took 2 hrs. Only 4 courses. Such a disappointment. Nothing special in the omakase what so ever. Spent 300 on sushi we could've got elsewhere for less than 100. Worst part of our vacation.
author: Deborah S.

description: The fish here is incredibly fresh, but they were 'out of' several items on the menu.  Mind you, it was 8pm on a Friday so...not late and not an obscure night!   It was frustrating having the waiter tell us 'no, we don't have that' multiple times and for items listed on their menu. Not sure if I'd go here again... there are plenty of other great sushi restaurants in SF that will be able to serve what's listed on their menus and also have even greater selection.
author: Debbie L.

description:
I yelped "top restaurants in Union Square" and Akiko's was on the list.

After a day if shopping we got there right when it opened at 5:30. First ones seated! They mentioned that their kitchen was closed and were only serving sushi. That kinda gave me mixed feelings at first but didn't bother us too much since we were there for the sushi.

When I came back from using the bathroom, the restaurant was packed! Mostly everyone in there had reservations. Once it got packed, they started turning people away! We were shocked and asked them why they do that . There explanation was "so we could focus our time on the customers here and not have to feel rushed." also they make EVERYTHING fresh so they take their time with their food. I was impressed. 

So overall, the service was great! I love it when servers really converse with you. The food was THE BEST SUSHI I'VE EVER HAD!!! You must try the Volcano roll that everyone yelps about as well as the Forty Niner roll! Oh, and make sure you make reservations! We lucked out by being the first ones there! The prices were a little pricey for sushi but you're paying for great quality AND quantity. Each of our rolls came with about 10 pieces.
author: Alyssa T.

description: This hard-to-find spot definitely deserves all the hype it gets.  You can't go wrong with omakase here.  The uni and scallop nigiri were my favorite.  It's a very small restaurant so make reservations at least 2 weeks in advance.  Also, prepare to shell out at least $60 per person for an authentic and fresh sushi.  This is definitely one of the best sushi spots in SF.
author: Michele L.

description:
Best. Sushi. Meal. Ever.

Seriously, you won't find a better traditional sushi meal outside of LA and Tokyo - every experience I've had here has been genuinely superb. First off, you'll want to make reservations. We've been turned away due to lack of space on Tuesday nights! Once you're in, if space allows sit at the sushi bar ask chef "Joe" to simply make you what's good (omakase nigiri) and he will BLOW YOUR MIND. I've had so many different varieties of fish that I never even knew existed, and experienced flavors I had no idea could come from fresh fist. He even convinced my wife to like Uni, which is something that even The French Laundry failed to do!

I'm not sure what their rolls are like but, in my humble opinion, you'd be underutilizing your time, dollars and some awesome fish if you order rolls here. Stick with dishes that highlight the fish and you won't be disappointed!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Had a wonderful lunch here while doing the procrastinated Xmas shopping. It's funny because I passed here numerous times when I worked nearby and never went in; always seemed close or something and/or I didn't want to cough up that much for a lunch back then.

Sat at the bar and was attended to quickly and mindfully for the entire meal.

Ordered the tuna roll and 49er roll and both were excellent! They also had Asahi on draft, by the way.) Each roll was freshly and carefully prepared. I especially loved the thinly sliced pieced of lemon atop the 49er roll. Yum!

It's been a while since I had excellent sushi and I was stoked to finally find a place that stood out. I'll return for dinner in the near future!
author: Art O.

description:
So I don't know if this is true, but my friend was telling me that this restaurant used to be a church...???!! I guess it's plausible, given that there was a huge wooden cross next to the door that went downstairs(?)
Anyway, thank you to some higher being for allowing Akiko's to exist and serve hungry people delicious food!

It was pretty empty when I arrived here with a party of 8 others, so I don't know if that's why the staff was super attentive...not that it's a bad thing! I'm just wondering...the server actually poured the soy sauce for me!

Food-wise, Akiko's was super yummy! One girl got the volcano roll (EPICNESS), I got the Futo roll (egg, avocado, cucumber, spinach), and I shared wakame salad with my friend. I can't really judge this place since it was my first time, but so far, so good! The guy next to me was raving about the sashimi and he was talking about how the chef has been involved in the art of crafting sushi since he was 13, SO I'm thinking next time I come here I will have to order something fish related!
author: Kei H.

description:
After hearing about this place so many times from a good friend of mine. We finally found some time to make a reservation check this place out.

Now for a first timer, thr place may be a little hard to find being that there is no real sign stating the name of the place and etc. You'll just have to remember their address.

Overall we made reservations, was accomdated easily and had some outstanding service! 

Dishes I tried: 
- Unagi Nigiri 
- Fourty-Niner 
- 6 Piece Nigiri
- Vegetable Tempura

Dessert
- Black Sesame Seed Ice Cream

Loved the freshness and taste of the sushi! The presentation was on point as well, loved their plating! 

The decor was amazing also! Fairly small place, but very welcoming. 

Best sushi place in SF in my books, can't wait to go back!
author: Jerry R.

description: Finally made it to Akiko's for Sushi.   I ordered the 12 piece Sashimi sampler and the Rock 'N Roll.   As always when I'm in Sushi mode, I ordered a tall Sapporo to wash the meal down.   The fish was absolutely fabulous.  My only regret was not knowing what each delectable piece of raw fish actually was.   I wrapped up my lunch and gobbled my Maki.   Let's just say I couldn't have eaten another bite.   This is a great Sushi bar and I'm glad I finally got to experience their excellent food.   I'll definitely be back, availability and time permitting.  :)
author: David O.

description:
Probably the best place downtown to get sushi if you're in the mood. Sadly, the Financial District is lacking in this department - but really does make up for it with a plethora of other great places. As expected, the sushi is by no means "cheap" (if it is, you've got a problem).. But I was pleasantly surprised in that it wasn't AS expensive as I expected and was excellent. Too often you get overpriced and/or sub-par sushi here in the city.

We had the firecracker roll and volcano roll. Awesome! I was a bit bummed that they did not have the hamachi kama, but we can save that for another day.

Service was outstanding. Be sure to make a reservation as they rarely (if ever) take walk-ins!
author: Brad Y.

description:
Great place for good sushi when you're in the heart of Union Square.  I always stick with ordering the authentic nigiri and simple rolls and they totally delivered what I was looking for.  Fresh fish, well made seasoned rice with the proper proportions.  

Also get the tazmanian trout with a sliver of shiso put on it for that extra kick.  

Is it worth a trip just to visit - probably not but it's a very healthy option instead of all the French bistro/catalan/Contemp. American food around union square.
author: Jae H.

description:
I had pretty high hopes for this place.This was one of the few that I still had on my list of sushi restaurants to try in the city along with Kiss. After eating at probably 30-40 different sushi restaurants around the city, I think I have a pretty decent list of dining experiences to give a meaningful review and not either blast it at 1 star or say it was the greatest sushi ever at 5 stars. I'll break it down into these areas

Service - Surprisingly slow. Given the size of the restaurant and the atmosphere, I anticipated a more attentive dining staff. Maybe I should have eaten at the sushi bar? We ordered sake and that took maybe 15 minutes before we received it. The actual first course took maybe another 10 minutes after that. If it wasn't for the fact I was enjoying the company I was with, it would have been a painfully long dinner. 

The Food - is it good quality? Yes. Is the fish interesting?  Yes. But is it so different and so tasty that it justifies 12/15 for Nigiri? Not at all. A lot of this fish I have tried before at other restaurants but I think Akiko's does a better job of presenting it to you on their menu as specials where other places may just have it on a white board and you have to ask. It's the same fish though. They just try to make it sound classier because they name the region of Japan it came from vs. just saying - Japan, or Australia, or California. In addition, they focus a lot on presentation, but that only goes so far at these price points. 

Sashimi/Sushi Roll Comparison - I prefer sashimi but I do appreciate a good roll. We tried two rolls, one with unagi, one with salmon. They were both very good, but we noticed they put so little actual fish in the roll and try to mask it with avocado and fancy sauces. Pretty disappointing. The sashimi is very fresh, no question. But they also cut very thin slices and still give you the standard 3 pieces in a sashimi sampler of 4 different fish. 

In short - good spot if you have some money to blow and its a first date and you want to make a good initial impression. Can't go wrong. For a true sushi lover, you may walk out a little disappointed. You will need to drop an easy $80-$100 per person before alcohol to try a wide selection of the fish and may leave hungry.

See my other recommendations for other sushi places if you want to know what is good and why I like it.
author: Adam W.

description: This place is extremely hard to find. I walked in when they just opened for service and wasn't able to get a table, just a seat at the bar. Sadly everything I wanted was "not available". I settled for the sushi and sashimi tasting. They should have that right? The food was mediocre and over priced. Paid over $75 and left hungry. This is definitely not a $$ restaurant.
author: Michele H.

description: ive been to lots of super expansive japanese places。this is the best ever。always make reservations。
author: Momo W.

description: Nice little japanese restaurant in Union Square.  I remembering just ordering a few sushi rolls and two miso soups and that was it.  The restaurant was very narrow and the service was really good.  Just wished I ate something super spectacular to raise the score.  Maybe I need to try this place again.
author: Ying F.

description: Intimate sushi bar, but well worth it! Staff is very friendly, quality food and service is quick. Carmen is awesome!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I love this place! Great service, good atmosphere, and of course, great food and drink. (Did someone say sake?)

Just be sure to make a reservation in advance!!!
author: Rebecca L.

description: Try to sit at the bar so Chef Ricky can work his magic, handcraft each dish to perfection, suggest what to drink with your dishes and send you on a surreal journey...He's what I call a "sushi consultant/sushi therapist" and knows how to make sure you leave satisfied. Get ready to become a repeat customer...
author: Arthur V.

description:
I've been to Akiko a couple of times now so I was actually surprised to realize that I hadn't reviewed it yet. I really love this small restaurant. Like so many places I eat out at in the city it feels really cozy with nice lighting and exposed brick walls. There isn't a ton of seating so if you have a big group you'll probably want to make reservations, but I've never had trouble getting a table for two during the weekdays just by walking in.

The beer and wine selection is so small there isn't a menu you just say you'd like red or white wine and your server can tell you your two choices. However, the service is really on top of things and that's quite nice.

We usually end up ordering mostly sushi rolls and a couple pieces of fish and everything is always really fresh. I like that there is some creativity in certain rolls and I'd say my favorite roll that I've had so far is the dragon roll because it has a fairly spicy sauce that comes with it. But, I've never tried anything I didn't enjoy here so I think it's a safe bet no matter what you're ordering.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Very well-presented sushi, with knowledgeable and informal wait staff. They were a little hurried and had to act it, but that's really a small quibble.  It didn't hurt the service, just the demeanor.

The sushi was just amazing - I've never had sea bream or sea trout before and they were so creamy and tender, I thought they were just always that way.  But then the saba, hamachi and sake were as well. So they just know how to find REALLY good fish.

My only reservations between this great experience and five stars are price, the ankimo (just okay), and the crowded ambiance.  But I will definitely come again when I want to pay what it takes for REALLY good fish.
author: Sean D.

description:
I'm usually not a big sushi fan, especially in SF where many of the sushi bars are way too trendy and overpriced for a meal that won't fill you up.  However, Akiko's was a refreshing change.  The food was great, the menu had a lot of options to choose from, including all the standard rolls, but everything was straight forward and surprisingly inexpensive.  Ambiance is really cool- not too loud, trendy but not cold and modern, and was actually pretty romantic for my girlfriend and I.  Only complaint was the service was pretty slow - there seemed to be one server for our area.

Overall, I'm a fan and would definitely go back again.
author: Jon R.

description:
Avoid the entrees at all costs - order sushi instead!  

The entree portions are ridiculously inconsistent. I had the salmon teriyaki, which was small enough to be an appetizer.  On the other hand, my table-mate ordered tempura udon, which came in a HUGE bowl.   Strangely, the nabeyaki udon was exactly the opposite - an extremely small portion. 

The service was incredibly slow and awkward: my table-mates were served entrees one at a time, so by the time my salmon arrived, some people were almost finished with their entrees. On the bright side, I did get a chance to sample their sashimi, which by itself was definitely 5 stars.  

Maybe I will get a chance to review this restaurant for their sushi bar, but their entrees and service are definitely not spectacular.  Also, forcing customers to make reservations is a nuisance.
author: Stanley H.

description:
I took my boyfriend out to dinner for his birthday and made reservations here. 
When we got to the restaurant , it was small , but the interior was very clean and beautiful. It's not a place for big groups ; it's very intimate. It gets a little hot in there , though. Anyway.

We ordered , 
: Sashimi with Tempura ( you get 4 pieces of sashimi )
   - It was cut nicely and it was such fresh sushi. It was absolutely delicious.

: Santa Barbara Uni ( his favorite )
   - The best uni we've tasted so far. Made well and there was a nice sweet taste to it than the usual uni we get from other places. It was delicious. 

: Kurodai. 
   - I forgot what it was , but it was silky and chewy. It was pretty good. 

: Sake Roll ( some kind of sake roll. )
   - It had sesames on one half of the roll and it was glazed in some kind of sauce that complimented the roll very well. 

: Spider Roll
   - This roll would probably be the best spider roll I've had from most Japanese restaurants. The sauce wasn't overwhelming and everything complimented itself. Crunchy thaaaangs. I love soft shell crab.

: ( dessert ) Mochi Ice Cream.
   - We had a serving of Green tea and Sesame flavored mochi ice cream and it was great to have in the end. 

The portions of the food isn't what I expected when I first went there , but the quality of everything was amazing. I would probably come back here for a little munch , but it wouldn't get me full right away. 
But I would come back to try out their new things !
author: Alyssa B.

description: Looks like Akiko's are up to their old tricks again. Came here at 9pm - saw 5 empty tables and they said that they are full and the restaurant closes at 9:30pm. When you experience this, just walk over to Mikaku.
author: Lindy H.

description: Felix provides an exceptionally warm welcome and checks to make sure you're enjoying yourself.  Chef Steve made an incredible recommendation of smokes bonito which I not normally order.  His selection for the sashimi lunch was perfect.   The salmon belly is excellent.
author: Morgan E.

description:
Akiko's is one of the best Sushi restaurants in SF, period. It might not necessarily be the most authentic spot but it certainly boats a creatively enticing menu, rustic-trendy wine-bar-esque ambiance, fresh just-out-of-the-water fish, an extensive sake menu and highly knowledgeable servers. What more can you ask for on a night out with the girlfriends or a romantic date with the boy? 

I enjoy creative sushi rolls with a lot of depth and a combination of flavors. And that's exactly the forte of Akiko's. 

I highly recommend the Firecracker and Volcano Rolls. They are both fried, bursting with flavor and feature fresh fish with the perfect texture. Also, we ordered a bottle of sparkling sake... I can't remember the name but I assume that's a testament to how much we enjoyed it. 

So if you're in the mood for some good sushi around Union Square, definitely give Akiko's a try!
author: Priya S.

description:
The place was not busy at all when we were seated for our early dinner at 630ish.  However, we did not even see our waiter for about 10 minutes.  Not sure what was going on?

Anyhow, it was a decent experience overall.  Food was good and pricing was fair.  

In defense of this restaurant, there is nothing wrong with the service or quality of their food at all.  However, nothing we had here was special enough for us to come back. 

We will definitely be exploring other sushi options next time we are in SF.
author: Ryan T.

description: You haven't had great sushi in SF until you go to Akiko's. The otoro and uni are my two favorites - i didnt know uni can taste that amazing. The perfect combination of fresh ingredients and creative preparations. One of the best dishes is the slightly seared wagyu sushi with shaved truffles on top. I can eat 20 of those!
author: C Y.

description:
My girl and I tried this place the other night. And, we were blown away. The fish is so fresh, delicious and well presented. 

It's everything I love about a great sushi spot, smallish, cozy, friendly, dramatic looking food and lots of smiling from both the owners and customers. Can't wait to return. Oh, reservations are recommended...they were required on a Monday night.
author: Dusty B.

description:
One of my top sushi places in SF. Sushi here tastes unique almost like the sashimi we tasted in Japan. All fish here are VERY fresh.
Ordered nigiris:
Japan uni- very rich and sweet tasting
Hotate- fresh and sweet tasting
Ama ebi- again sweet. Also the heads were fried to perfection and are quite different slightly in taste (an awesome way) from other sushi places ive been to
Chutoro- very rich and fatty. The oils on it tastes almost like the ones that came from the Tsukiji Fish Market in Japan.
Masaba- also tastes like the ones from Tsukiji
A5 Wagyu- GOTTA order this one! Melt In your mouth beef with a sauce that drove me crazy! 
Price is kinda higher than other great places like Zushi Puzzle and Sakae Sushi but its got another variety of tastes and style here.
author: Chung L M.

description: Been there 3x in December.  Still the best sushi/sashimi in SF Financial District.  Not your place if you just like rolls.
author: mike m.

description:
I reserve 5 stars for places that are consistently good and raise the bar. The freshness of the fish is obvious with each dish. The dishes are simple but full of flavor. This is not the place to come if you are looking for crazy sushi rolls. This is the place for classic, delicious dishes. 

My go to items are the tempura udon, forty-niner, maguro and butterfish sashimi and wakame salad. This combo hits the spot for two people. Try it!!
author: johanna a.

description:
Dropped by today without a reservation right before they opened @ 5:25 (tried giving them a call 2 times to see if I could get a table, but no answer).  The place was empty and was told by the sushi chefs that it's a possibility, but no promises and to wait for the hostess.  I didn't expect to get a table today since we didn't have a reservation, but was hopeful.  

Two hostesses came out and looked at their pos seating/reservation chart one of them says that they couldn't seat us today and that usually they don't accommodate parties of 6.  I then asked, what if my family and I wanted to come back after making a reservation for next time.  She then goes on the say "Yeh we can't accommodate."  She paused slightly, then says "Maybe sometimes when we have room we can seat your family of 6, but only if all 6 promise to order omakase."  Are you kidding me?!  I mean I wouldn't mind ordering omakase which is what I was going to order with my girlfriend if we ever went there, but the whole party of 6?  We had a couple of underaged teens with us, why can't they eat whatever else you have on the menu?  

Sorry to say, I've been really wanting to try this place but will not be back.  Horrible customer service from the start...no reason they should be in this industry.
author: Eric T.

description: Great service, great authentic quality food, made my reservation online and beat the crowds
author: Bartley D.

description: I had rolls which I supposed is not the claim to fame for this restaurant but it was just okay for the price. The atmosphere was cool and the people where nice.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I liked this sushi spot a lot. From the outside, it looks like an Irish pub with no signage. Once you step inside, it's quite intimate and definitely a place to grab a date.

We ordered the sashimi sampler and a few rolls - 49er, Rainbow and Spicy Tuna. The 49er was pretty good but I really preferred their Rainbow roll especially with the different colored tobiko on top.

A couple next to me was sharing a bowl of udon but I didn't see it on the dinner menu. Maybe it was off a secret menu or their lunch menu. It looked delicious and definitely worth it on a cold night in the Financial District.

Service was quite slow but given that my date and I were chatting a while, we didn't seem to mind all that much. It definitely made us drink more than we ate.
author: Michael N.

description:
This place is literally a hidden gem -- I walked by it three times and didn't even notice it, due to it being overshadowed by the Irish bank.

But sadly, it wasn't the hidden gem I wanted to discover -- the food was subpar at best.

I got the highly anticipated Volcano Roll, which did look like a volcano! The sushi were stacked in four rows of two and looked like a volcano. The salmon skin, green onions, and spicy sauce were splattered on top of the sushi and around the bowl, like lava. The best part of that dish, was the salmon skin, which was crisp and not too oily. The sauce had a hint of spice with it, but also some sweetness to it as well. The roll itself just reminded me of any other spicy fish roll with avocado.

I really really really liked their gyozas though! Instead of the normal pork gyoza, it had shrimp and scallions in it! The shrimp was sweet and you can definitely tell it was fresh upon each bite. I liked how the skin of the gyoza wasn't crazy deep fried, and was thin enough to not overshadow the yummy goodness inside.

Also got the chicken teriyaki with tempura. Tempura had too much batter and tasted like the outside of an onion ring. Chicken teriyaki was nothing special as well. Didn't think it was worth $18 for 8 pieces of tempura (2 shrimp, 5 veggies) and a slab of chicken teriyaki.

FUNNIEST THING THOUGH: was celebrating my friend's birthday, and for her birthday dessert, they put one of those trick candles that won't blow out unless you dose it with water! I thought that was pretty unique, but they also charged us for the birthday dessert so that's a no go. Also, their azuki ice cream tasted like melon....weird.
author: Evelyn S.

description: Food is pretty good, not really authentic. service is pretty bad. for how much they charge, get better staff. Skip this place.
author: ji k.

description:
I was really excited about this place when i read all of the great reviews but I had an awful experience here.  I got food poisoning from this place! Don't come here unless you're prepared to spend a night by your toilet.  

I should have known something was up when I watched the sushi chefs make the sushi. Both were grungy looking young guys (a redhead and an Asian with a beard) and they had dirt under their fingernails.  They never washed their hands once the entire time we were sitting at the bar.  Both made sushi for us so I'm not sure which sushi chef gave it to me but trust me, for the money, you can go to cleaner and better sushi restaurants!
author: Emily T.

description:
Came here years ago and was sorely disappointed. Tried it again for lunch and was very happy that I gave it another shot. 

- 4 Nigiri + beef teriyaki: combo was great, beef was ok but I'm generally not a huge fan of teriyaki dishes
- Sashimi sampler: great, fresh selection
author: Jay K.

description: there's always a first for everything: I was reminded when I tried to walk into this place for lunch last Monday. I was turned away for not having a reservation. It was close to 2pm, the website said "reservation encouraged", but apparently this is a must as my pleas were denied at the reception despite the sushi counter being empty and some tables vacant. I would think that one could walk into just about every restaurant in the city without a reservation and they'd gladly welcome you if there was an open seat. but not here. I walked out into the street shocked, hungry, and pissed.
author: Alex B.

description:
This was a very good sushi dining experience.  The food, service, and ambiance combined to provide the base for an enjoyable meal.

Food:

For the most part, I turned the ordering over to my dinner companion.

I selected Vegetable Tempura.

http://tinyurl.com/3st7uq7

She selected Dumplings.

http://tinyurl.com/42u3twu

She selected Uni.
I selected Unagi.

http://tinyurl.com/3ub36lo

She selected Himachi Jawbone.

http://tinyurl.com/3e5g5ov

She selected  Himachi Nigiri.
She selected Tai Nigiri.
She selected Sake Nigiri.

http://tinyurl.com/4y2ls37

She selected Chicken Yakatori.

http://tinyurl.com/3ljq9mu

She selected Volcano Rolls.

http://tinyurl.com/3elbzdz

The food was prepared very well.  I am not going to break it down dish by dish.  The seafood was very fresh.  The non-sushi foods were very tasty.  The only exception was the volcano roll.  It was just heavy handed and lacked the delicate flavors of the other dishes.  The presentation was clean, simple, and classic.


BTW - I had never tried Himachi Jawbone.  I will definitely be having it again.  The fish was so delicate and tender.  

Service:

The service was friendly, professional, and polite.  We were seated quickly. Even though there were only two of us, they seated us at a table for four.  Lol, we needed the room for all of the food we ordered.  The food came out in an orderly fashion with dishes being removed promptly along the way.

Ambiance:

It is a nice room.  It is cozy and comfortable.  One negative note, if you are offered to sit at one of the twos along the interior wall of the back room, you might want to pass and wait for another table.  They appeared to be very cramped.  Plus, there is only one restroom and there can be a small line that forms bordering these tables.

Overall:
I enjoyed the dining experience at Akiko's.  The food, service, and ambiance melded together quite well.  There were no significant negatives.  I would not hesitate to return.
author: Mark D.

description:
Went to Akiko because of all the good words 
and given the price certainly expected more sophisticated service. I ordered sashimi, a salad and hamachi. Everything pretty much arrived at the same time which was not fortunate as I was at the bar and there wasn't room.  Plus I had to eat the hamachi before it cooled. Dessert was not discussed. Think they need to expand or come to terms with their limited space and not give substandard service.
author: Fran H.

description:
Eh, not particularly impressed. Nice ambiance, with tons of gorgeous oil paintings on the walls. Seems like reservations are mandatory if you want to come here for dinner. Service is a bit slow, and they serve each "course" one by one, slowly. My sister and I ordered two rolls to share and seaweed salad. We waited awhile for the salad, and gobbled that up. And then we had to wait awhile before the waiter came and took away our plates and then a few more minutes for our rainbow roll. Gobbled that up right away - and then again, we had to wait for our dishes to be cleared, and then it took forever for our volcano roll to come. 

In terms of the quality of the food: the sushi was fine; the fish is fresh. The rainbow roll wasn't anything spectacular. The wasabi could be A LOT hotter. The volcano roll was good, but too much tempura on top of it, not enough roll.
author: Ivana N.

description: This place has decent sushi but the quality is not consistent which is disappointing. On our recent visit we recommended omakase to a friend who was eating there for the first time and they served all ten pieces(all nigiri too) at once, and not very good selection of fish nor direction to eat(which one needs to be consumed first and how to clean your palate in between) I wanted to pretend that never happened...
author: Cher B.

description: Excellent dining experience.  Sushi is almost as good as the ones you get in Japan.
author: Miyuki H.

description:
Surprisingly good find in an unsuspecting location. Unsuspecting, in that, you don't normally find anything too great around Union Sq.

Past the hustle and bustle of Claude Lane, keep an eye open for the little store front on the corner of the next alley or no doubt, you will walk right by.

Prices of the freshly-flown-in special were slightly off-putting (~2x the regular menu offerings of nigiri/sashimi), but certainly were more unusual options, including a variety of crustaceans not often seen frequenting sushi bars in SF.

Beyond the expected offerings, the remainder was categorized by cooking style: grilled or fried and a slew of combo dinners and noodle dishes.

Oshitashi was light, flavorful and a perfect starter. 
Gyoza, steamed and grilled, were delicate and some of the better I've had.
Saba (mackerel) is an enormously flavorful fish on its own. The grilled dish (shio-yaki) may have hit the heat for a few seconds too long, but the flavor was all present, garnishes aside. I'd opt for basic saba nigiri next time.

Sake novice, I normally skip it or opt for a Japanese beer, but it was a celebration dinner and we ended up with two bottles.

Dinner for two, pre-tip, came to $60; incredibly reasonable considering the sake.

Ambiance is a fusion of classy-contemporary-trendy-borderline romantic. It's whatever you want it to be - catching up with an old friend or a date, it works. Just leave the group outing for another time.

Service was extremely attentive, water glasses always filled and dishes brought promptly.

Reservations? Win win.

I'd not hesitate to go back if I'm looking for an option in this neighborhood.

Arigato gozaimasu
author: Alissa A.

description: Literally THE BEST SUSHI I've ever had. The fish is so fresh and melts in your mouth. I've been coming here for years and every time it just gets better and better. The ambiance, the food, the service - everything is impeccable. Definitely make a reservation and do it at least a couple days in advance. This place is always crackin! Every single thing that I've ordered has been amazing! You cant go wrong with Akikos :)
author: Sheila S.

description: It is important for me that when it is that time of the month for a girl and she needs a restroom, to find one quickly.  After walking blocks with my girlfriend almost in tears we popped in here, before she squatted on the sidewalk.  Im sorry to say we were not customers as we were informed they were not serving any more.  The hostess was less than accommodating.  Told us to go next door, where there was a $10 cover charge.  I would think as a girl she would understand another woman.  She did right by the business but not right morally, in my opinion.  I hope she never finds herself in the same situation.  Hasn't using the streets as a bathroom become a serious issue in the city?  I think we all have to do our part and for god sakes it was a woman on her period must i spell it out, i used the dark doorway up the street beforehand
author: Scotty G.

description:
One of the best sushi meals of my life.
Fortunate enough to have lived in NYC and now SF so access to high quality sushi.
Expense account helps too. 
Akiko offers  fantastic variety without any pretense. I love the wood cuts substituting for the traditional little ceramic plates.  I recommend sitting at the sushi bar in order to receive recommendations  and witness firsthand the best quality of sushi available in SF.  I am only upset that I walked past Akiko for the past fourteen years assuming that the tiny little sushi restaurant nothing special. Man, was I wrong!
author: Mark A.

description:
I was told 45 minutes before they closed and at least 3 empty seats at the bar that they were 'short staffed' and could not serve me. If you are short staffed then pick up the silverware from the open spots on the bar. I got the distinct impression that I was not 'high class' enough for this place. I had just got off from my software engineering job and had put on a pair of flip flops, to which the classy hostess looked at and denied me. Do yourself a favor and wear a tux to this place. I would hate to have nice plans here and be shut down for not meeting their sight test. 

I ended up going up the street to sushi Toni and spending $90 on an awesome feast. They even didn't mind my flip flops.
author: Jason B.

description:
Let's see, where to begin...I'll start with the good.

Pros:
-Love the location as it's close to the FiDi which makes it convenient for a weekday dinner
-Nice plateware, which I read on their website is from Heath Ceramics
-Miso soup - one of the better miso soups I've had in Japanese Restaurants
-Friendly sushi chef, although when we talked about some other Japanese restaurants we eat at/have been to, he talked some smack about each place, which I didn't think was entirely professional

Now onto why I give these place 2 stars: Given the rave reviews on Yelp, I was sorely disappointed with this place. The night didn't start well, as I had an 8 PM reservation, which the server had given away because they only hold tables 15 minutes after the reserved time. My friend and I were at the restaurant by 8:10 PM by my watch, and my watch is always 1-2 minutes faster. Luckily a party at the sushi bar was just finishing up so we didn't wait too long for seats at the sushi bar. 

I knew this place would be pricey given its location, but seriously, the portions here are tiny! Slices of sashimi and nigiri were super thin and I couldn't help but thinking why they were being so stingy. I mean, I wouldn't mind if pieces are small, but super fresh, but I was incredibly underwhelmed by the quality of fish here. 

I ordered the chirashi ($17) and there were some pretty stringy fish in the mix I got that I really had to tear through. I do think he gave me more pieces than normal though, because this portion was relatively reasonable compared to everything else we ordered.

My friend ordered the sashimi and saba dinner combo ($21), which came with miso soup and rice. Wow I tried some of the saba, and it was definitely either overcooked or an old piece of saba. Dry and completely unmemorable. Also super tiny - portions were about palm size. 

Ankimo ($8) is served nigiri style, and wrapped in seaweed. This was actuall pretty good, but tiny portions.

Oshitashi ($3) good, but standard.

We were still hungry so decided to order an order of the hamachi belly ($8 for 2 pieces of nigiiri), thinking maybe individual orders of nigiri might be better. Wow, what a mistake! Another underwhelming dish. There was absolutely no wow factor, nothing spectacular, tasted squishy....I was utterly disappointed.

I wanted to like this place, I really did. It's so convenient and the sushi chef was friendly, but at these prices and this kind of quality, I just can't justify a reason to come back. What a shame :(
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Life changing sushi experience. Fresh, rich, unbelievably delicious fish. Fantastic sake options as well. We come from Louisiana so we have our fair share of great seafood, particularly amazing oysters and shrimp. We came to San Fran to find the best sushi next to Japan, and Akiko's definitely spoiled us. Don't think I will look at sushi the same way again. There are a few other good places we tried - Arctic char is amazing if you can find it, but everything at Akiko's was superior. 

We stuck to nigiri and sake. A few reviews criticized their rolls, but I think this is a place you come to appreciate pure fish in sushi or sashimi form, not rolls. 

Great service too. Had a cozy corner to ourselves on a Monday night. Best. Sushi. Ever.
author: Kelly L.

description: Guys, I LOVED this place! Everything we ordered was amazing! Hubby and I love raw sushi rolls, so the nigiris were the highlights, super fresh! Also the 49ers roll and the spicy tuna roll, because the last one is not only a simple one like the other restaurants! If I lived in San Fran I would come here all the time! :)
author: Roberta S.

description:
Sushi, sushi, I love myself some sushi! I was tempted to go back to a place I know and love (Ryoko and Umami to name a few), but decided to be a good yelper and try someplace new.  And then I realized just a few minutes when going to Yelp it that I've actually been here before. So much for new!

I ordered a huge yummy seaweed salad for myself and lots of rolls for our table of 8. Everything was delicious, but the faves were the volcano and firecracker. 

Our waiter was a bit slow and forgetful (never got our edaname and soups), but apparently so am I since I don't remember dining here just a year ago. There's lot of good sushi to be found in SF, but I'd come here again to get my raw fish fix.
author: Andrea R.

description:
What a cute place.  I was in the mood for udon and almost miss the entrance.  Hung on the side of the door is a nicely engrave Kanjid plaque.  Enter the restaurant and it was obvious that someone spent lots of time decorating this place, and with clear good taste too.

We ordered Nabeyaki, shrimp tempura, and Hamachi Kama.  All portions were small.  Nabeyaki was deliciously done and very satisfying for someone craving for a soupy noodle.  The hamachi kama (fish collar) was grilled and seasoned to perfection.  It was meaty, tender, and interesting to gnaw around the bones.

Tempura was well presented but average in taste.  I would avoid that next time.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: This is a place for those who don't know what good sushi is. Pretencious staff. Always turning away customers even though the place is empty at 5pm. Terrible service for below minimum wage punks. Get over yourselves; you're not that good by any standard. You're not even close Ino's quality. At least I can put up with Ino's nazi chef, coz he knows quality.
author: Dean Q.

description:
Went here for a cozy dinner during a work trip just in time - my regular sushi craving was just starting to nag me. First, I thought it was great that although the place was small they were happy to take reservations. The restaurant is cozy and cool, especially at dinnertime, with candlelight bouncing off the brick walls. 

We ordered a bunch of rolls to share for the table and I for one left satisfied and happy. From what I can remember, my favorite was the volcano roll, the pieces piled high and doused with crunchy tempura pieces. Heaven!

The server was friendly but a bit slow. Our rolls came out sporadically, so we were always going, 'is that everything?' He also forgot our edamame but he was good at keeping our glasses filled. 

I'm glad to have found a non-fast food sushi joint downtown for the next trip to SF!
author: Christina P.

description:
We stopped in at lunchtime without a reservation. We couldn't be seated immediately, but the hostess was very accommodating and found us a reservation time in about an hour. We wandered around Chinatown and got a text saying our reservation was available about 15 minutes early. 

Very friendly and thoughtful service. The nigiri was amazing and the rolls were good too. Be ready though, the bill adds up quickly. 

Nice atmosphere, but some might think the tables were too close together. I was impressed with what did with such a small space.
author: Katie B.

description: Extremely rude hostess. Very pretentious. Not even worth eating at from the way I was treated.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Future is in your hands.

Anything seems possible with Above & Beyond: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VPvU-3fAgQ0

Anything was possible with Chef Randy Yap: Tonight my future was in his omakase menu hands.

Taking notes was a futile exercise. Over two hours a parade of fish, veggies, sauces, rice, warm, cold, fresh, grilled, fried and everything in between.

Including monkfish liver. Don't miss it. You can read more item specifics courtesy of Michael Bauer: http://www.sfgate.com/restaurants/diningout/article/Akiko-s-is-a-sushi-classic-in-the-making-4833728.php

Seems the only thing we didn't get was dessert. Even if we did there might not have been room. Though I could have been easily sold by the polished and informed staff.

Omakase isn't usually my thing and in retrospect might have chosen otherwise. Became hard to tell one from another as the night went on. One great piece blended into one less memorable.

Lacking the palate to distinguish exceptional fish from something less exceptional didn't help either. At $120 + tax/tip you should be more educated than myself.

But hardly a regretted decision. Made for plenty of unforgettable "what is this?" moments and shared exchanges of culinary pleasure with my dining mates.

And you can't put a price on that.
author: Jason B.

description:
Akiko's is a great lunch spot for Sushi in the Union Square / SOMA / Financial District area !!  Some items on the menu are a little pricey, but others are more reasonable, so be sure to "shop" through the entire menu before making your choice. I have consistently experienced very good service here, and the ambiance is quite nice for a sushi lunch spot.  I would even go here for dinner, although I am a much more frequent "luncher" here.

The restaurant is a bit on the small and snug side, with limited seating, and has been completely filled at the lunch hour each of the several times I have come in for a sushi lunch.  I would recommend booking a reservation on Yelp using the OpenTable system, even for lunch.  You may luck out if you're early, but if you come in after 12 noon you may be turned away, which has happened to me once.  I now always get a booking through Yelp.  Of course, the fact that they are busy is also a really positive indicator of how well-liked they are as well.

There are 2 dining rooms -- I would recommend the back room as it is a little more private, with some cool high red brick walls.  The room is a bit narrow and it can be a little loud as the sound bounces back at you off the brick walls, but it's still better than the front room.  In the front, there are a couple of tables tucked in near the front windows, but the other tables tend to get a lot of foot traffic passing by going to the sushi bar (which is also in the front room) as well as folks passing through to the back room.

Akiko's 8 piece Nigiri is $24.  The 6 piece Sashimi is more reasonable, but it wasn't really enough quantity to make a meal if you're on the hungry side.  I have enjoyed the Dragon Roll, and the Volcano Roll looks great.  I also intend to try their Yakimono (grilled) dishes . .  Next time.  I'm definitely going back.  Akiko's is one of the best sushi places I've found in this area (near the corner of Kearney & Bush).
author: Joel E.

description:
When I first walked in I was a little turned off by the "whaddayawant?" casual service, but after they took my order everything was attentive.

And then the Ika (Calamari) came... And I instantly loved this place. The squid was cooked perfectly and breaded lightly. The spicy garlic aioli sauce it was sprinkled with just hit all the right notes for me.

I also tried a Volcano Roll and it did not disappoint. Gordon Ramsey would throw a fit over how much garnish is piled on these, but they tasted great. I had a huge pile of Tempura flakes left on my plate afterward though.

I'll be going there again next time I visit SF!
author: Corry F.

description:
I went to Akiko's on a Friday evening with the boyfriend and some college friends.  We were there from opening at 5:30 pm to closing at 9:30 pm.  The ambiance, service, and food were all good.  

When we arrived we asked if they had a happy hour, to which our server said no.  But later during dinner and drinks, our server announced that it was happy hour by bringing over a couple of bottles of complimentary sake.  It was awesome that we were encouraged to continue our leisurely dinner, and were made to feel more than welcome to take up the table for the whole duration of their operating hours that Friday.  

We shared a variety of sashimi, nigiri, and rolls, and everything tasted fine.  The presentation was very nice and simple.  I can't honestly rave about the food, though, like other reviewers have.  Don't get me wrong, Akiko's has good food, but I can't justify calling it amazing.   We finished dinner with complimentary strawberries and mochi ice cream for dessert.

Overall, the experience was a great one, and I wouldn't mind revisiting Akiko's.
author: Sandy K.

description: Look to the signage? There is none. Look for the "431" instead. Not sure if they are in the midst of getting one or adding to the allure of establishment. I found the fish-grade to be quite excellent here along with the service and surroundings. Great ones included the toro, amaebi, saba, uni, hirame and walu. Surprised to find a great one in the FiDi.
author: Derek N.

description: Always come here when I visit SF.  Great sushi.  Sometimes hard to get a table but worth a little wait.  Yummy!
author: Mary S.

description:
We were here last night and yes, reservations are highly recommended because it is a very small place. I can probably remember how many tables are in there plus the bar-like sitting area. It's a small cute place. Be prepared to sit pretty close with the next table.

I loved the food. We ordered the duo with Nigiri and Salmon Teriyaki, we shared it and it was pretty good. Then we ordered 2 rolls. The 49er roll and the rainbow roll which took forever to arrive but only because our server held the order and forgot to send it BUT that would not really affect my rating because it was so worth the wait! It was the right size and amount. We left there with happy and full tummies!

Oh and to show that they are very sorry for the delay, they gave us a free Sapporo beer because ours was about to be done anyway :)

Price wise, it was OK, on the expensive side if you want to satisfy your sushi craving, but again, it's really good.

Totally recommend the place and don't forget to make a reservation!
author: Czarina Y.

description: I liked this place compared to what else is in the area. Great sushi and service. Not much more to add...except they did forget my seaweed salad but comped it in the end ;)
author: Karen S.

description:
I really didn't like this place. 

The service sucked. Like really sucked. First, the server didn't seem to take us seriously for what I felt because we looked younger relative to the people there. I didn't appreciate that and I sure didn't appreciate that they forgot our food and didn't apologize about it.

To top it all off, I thought this was probably one of the worst Japanese places I've eaten to. The portions are small and the rolls were definitely sub-par.  The only good thing about it is the sashimi.
author: Amy A.

description:
The sushi here is good, fish is fresh, prices are decent.
I think Akiko's gets the 4th star for the experience though. Service was great, super friendly and attentive.

Would definitely stop back in here.
author: Rachel R.

description:
1. MAKE RESERVATIONS otherwise the wait will take forever OR you'd simply be asked to come back at another time.
2. STAY within the arena of SUSHI and/ or SASHIMI.

Make a reservation is pretty much self- explanatory, unless you're willing to wait to be seated at the sushi bar. As I sat there eating, so many couples were turned away and told there weren't any tables available because they were all booked for the night.

And simply order sushi or sashimi because the fish is super FRESH. The raw pieces of fish simply melt in your mouth. We ordered the rainbow roll (super delicious) and the firecracker roll (deep fried and a spicy kick to it if you're into that) which was pretty good.

In addition, we also ordered the nabeyaki udon (which was bland and only lukewarm) and adegashi tofu (which was LITERALLY four pieces of thinly sliced tofu thrown in the fryer with some sort of soy sauce thrown over it, not too impressive at all). All in all, I'd definitely just stick to ordering sushi and sashimi.
author: Ada C.

description:
Delicious!  Sashimi was very fresh and cut in generous portions. Loved the salmon belly, toro, and sea bass! Buttery and nearly melted in my mouth! The plating was clean and classy. Rolls were also delicious; we had the 49ers Roll and the Rainbow Roll.  

The restaurant is very small and intimate with dim lighting...perfect for a romantic dinner date :)  Be prepared to have a slower paced, relaxing meal with lots of conversation.  Things come out at a slower pace.  

The service was pretty good.  Our table got moved a bit after we were seated to allow for a larger party, and the server gave us a free appetizer for our "trouble." That was a nice gesture. I would definitely go back again.
author: Jenny K.

description: small restaurant tucked away, I would recommend sitting at the bar because the gentlemen behind
author: Whitne Y.

description: Amazing sushi. So fresh, the prawns were literally trying to escape off the counter. Some of the best sashimi I've had in the city, and the mango mochi was out of this world :) I can't wait to come back here with friends!
author: Eliza D.

description:
Went here for lunch with some co-workers. It was good, the only thing I didn't like was there was 1 server. He was clearly overwhelmed by all the customers, but hey I got an easy fix. HIRE ANOTHER SERVER :)

Good food though.
author: Jess O.

description:
Consistently good sushi and friendly service. Fish is very fresh and i always get lots of uni. Thank goodness it's conveniently right downstairs from my work, but too bad I can't afford to eat here all the time.

Con: It's pretty noisy in here!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
First time here. I feel like an idiot. Of all the sushi experiences I've had over the last 25 years, this was the best. List all the things a sushi lunatic is looking for, selection, quality, presentation, ambience.....  I could go on and on. I'm a snob, very very picky. Don't want giant rolls. Want extraordinary fish prepared extraordinarily. This. Is. It. I've been to Zushi Puzzle. Love it. Ozumo. Love it. Koo. . Ebisu. O-Toro. I've been to Nobu in four cities. 

This is what you want, if you're like me. Couldn't give it 6 stars, or I would. Best sushi I've ever had. I'll post pics next time. Not that they're needed.  BEST SUSHI I'VE EVER HAD!!
author: John P.

description:
The ONLY legit sushi spot I've tried in the Financial District.  Amazing quality of fish. Simplistic and delicious.  Super friendly owner and staff.  A great spot for lunch, an even better spot to grab some sake and sashimi after a long day.  Reservations for dinner at by OpenTable only and for good reason.  Casual, but still trendy enough for a business lunch/dinner.

Fish, crab, shrimp and other delicious treats from the sea you can typically only get at spots like Sushi Yasuda they have. 'nuff said.
author: Tim W.

description:
Akiko's Sushi is a great sushi place in downtown SF. The employees were great, very friendly and very helpful. They introduced me to some versions of tuna I've never tried before that was buttery and fantastic. The decor in the back room is cool and overall, it's a definite place to try again. Very good place for a quick meal and if you have time, make sure to ask about what special items they are currently offering. It seems that they pride themselves on unique and hard to find items that set them apart from the others.

Cheers

Posted to Yelp via the coolest new App from the iTunes App Store called @TongueTango App 

http://youtu.be/CGFlmQ5ruTM

http://youtu.be/r0Yvw7jRYHM
author: Millard M.

description: Simple. Fresh. Service is friendly. Cozy little place. Chefs at bar. Expensive if you want the fish from far far away.
author: Odi K.

description: I got the omokazu (I know I butchered that name but whatever) which is where the sushi guy lays out his best stuff until he hits $80, and it was some of the best sushi I've ever had. Yes it was not cheap but well worth it. It was not just a meal, it was a culinary experience.
author: jeremy m.

description:
I was totally disappointed by my experience.  I was really looking forward to eating there after hearing such great things about the place.  First when we were seated at the bar, I notice a very foul smell.  As I looked around I notice the trash can was placed right in front of the door as cars driving by the smell blew into the restaurant.   I ask politely to have the door closed...they looked at me as if I was bring a picky patron.   But they finally did....but from there I had already lost my appetite.  The smell had linger into the restaurant.

My husband went on ordering.  We ask about the specials...they rudely said we don't have any everything is in the menu.  Then as we proceed to order our meal we order some nigiri and sashimi it was decent, but I have had better and nothing extraordinary where you can't get from any decent sushi bar.  When we order the negitoro maki, we notice it was a package of frozen tuna mashed that cost $3 at the store, that they charged $18.  (If you know what I'm talking about it's not even fresh tuna nor is it toro quality...if you read the package it's frozen tuna with grape seed oil to give it that oiliness of what they called toro). When we received our order that took long because they were trying to throw it out the whole time by stalling was still frozen.  We also had order some items from the kitchen but only got one of the item...even that item was not what I order.  By then I just wanted to leave.  I don't mind spending money for good quality food.  

Overall experience chefs we're not friendly and inexperience, food quality was ok as long as you're ordering straight from the case....but I've had better.  Disappointment overall
author: Gsk A.

description:
This place has really, really tasty sushi. We were not disappointed with our food. I particularly liked their Misou soup as well. The spicy tuna roll was my favorite. 

The waiter was attentive. The place was a bit chilly. You might also walk by it and miss it. 

I'll be back.
author: Joanna G.

description: Appointment only, get one and be amazed. Just leave the fish selection to the chef! They even have fresh wasabi (if you ask) which instantly upgrades your meal.
author: Preston B.

description:
Pricey but super fresh. No fish will ever taste the same after you come here again. 

Even mixed "americanized" rolls like Rainbow or the Giants tasted really good and not weighed down by sauces like mayonnaise.

It's a bit pricey (I think I paid $16 for a special roll), but I guess if I had a fulltime job with benefits working downtown.... it would be nice to hit up for sushi cravings. For now, I'll go to Kiki's - but when I just can't take cheap fish anymore, Akiko's here I come.
author: Christal Y.

description:
I had an amazing experience at Akiko's that I had to go out of my Yelp hiatus to review about it.

The sashimi was amazingly fresh and we ordered mostly everything from the market menu: black tuna (melt in your mouth delicious, with freshly grated wasabi!), uni (so sweet and briny and perfect), kanpachi (so fresh!), and hamachi.  We ordered the spider roll too, which wasn't too special, so my big recommendation is to go with the market menu so you're guaranteed amazing fish (although this would put your price way above the $$ rating to the $$$$).  I don't think the other rolls on the menu do this place justice (and the complicated rolls do not really count to me as sushi, i think) - you really have to appreciate the place for the purity of taste in its fresh sashimi/sushi, the main stars of the show.  Plus, they make their own soy sauce (true sign of the real deal!).

We also ordered some other dishes, including the hirimasa head/neck, vegetable tempura, and the nabeyaki udon.  All great.

Good sake selection, lychee sorbet from Japan.  MM-MMM!

Ray, the owner, was also our server and was very attentive to our table.  All in all, a highly enjoyable experience, especially if you're looking for authentic Japanese food in a very nice, comfortable atmosphere.  (Also - came here on a less busy night - Tuesday, so that might have added to the experience as well).
author: Carolyn L.

description: Came here for lunch, had nigiri + udon, $20. For $20, I'd expect more. Those were the thinnest nigiri I've ever seen and the udon was plain. I've had a killer teuchi (handmade noodle) udon in Tokyo (the rent is as high as it is in SF) for $12. I think it's way overpriced.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Its ok for a financial district sushi place, the alcohol was good but the japanese dishes were a bit westernized to some extent.  The cuts of nigiri fishes were not done with skill, but whatever, its the freshness that counts right?

Well, sitting in the sushi bar, i saw the non-japanese sushi chefs removing is long hippie hairs from the cutting board, the knife, and the rag which he wiped the board and knife with... it was a bit unappetizing.

Got the hamachi kama, which was good, the agedashi tofu, terrible, the udon, so so.... i
author: B H.

description: Been here twice for lunch and I wasn't impressed with the food either time. The sushi rolls ranged from decent to bad, depending on which ones you order. The 49er roll is perhaps my biggest recommendation. For the more 'traditional' dishes such as udon or rice bowls, there are vastly superior choices near downtown SF. The huge redeeming factor is their ice cream mochi. There are times that I want to eat just the dessert from Akiko's. In addition to the subpar service, I feel that the price isn't worth the food served.
author: David Z.

description:
It's a decent place, they handled our last minute reservation for 12 people (!) with great ease. It looks like the seafood udon was good, however I opted for the nigiri sampler. I found the shari (rice bottom) to be really inadequate but the fish was fresh. For me, sushi is an "experience", so even though fresh fish is often hard to get, it's a real buzzkill when the rice does not work with it. They also have creative rolls but they're a little pricey.

It's nice that the sushi guy is always the same. That's something you don't get everywhere, either.

At any rate, I don't think I'll come back to this place on purpose, it doesn't blow me away. Well, maybe when Yo's Sushi Club closes and I get desperate, maybe. (Yo's is a great example of a place that does wonderful things with fish that isn't necessarily top quality.)
author: Josh K.

description:
Charming wood decor.
Nigiri was delicious.
49ers roll creamy.
Volcano roll has a lot of crispy bits overflowing and not worth eating.
Tea tasted like loose leaf but nothing special.
Lunch service on this Monday not quick.
A bit pricey.  Lunch, 4 people, $80.
author: Ethan K.

description:
The food was generally fresh and satisfying.  We enjoyed tasting various nigiri, but the shrimp tempura was really heavy on the batter.

The service brings the rating down.  Waited 20 minutes after being seated before anyone greeted us, at which point the waiter just said "thanks for waiting."  This is not a big place, so I don't get how that can happen.  The service continued to be curt and rare, so we were pretty annoyed by the time we left. The food was good, but for those prices the service should be way better.
author: Mark C.

description: If you want to eat theeeee best sushi in SF, then make a reservation now. Order everything. Ask Ricky, the sushi chef for recommendations. I trust him so much, my man and I text him often on where else to eat in the city. Amazing quality, fresh, melt in your mouth fish. The end...
author: Sara K.

description: I was looking for a place near public transportation and near a coffee shop for my quarterly girls get together which was my turn for hosting.  I looked under Japanese restaurants in SF on yelp and came upon this place which may be alittle hard to find, considering that their sign is barely noticeable.  They are right across from the Academy of Art and a few doors from Le Central.  I made reservations through Open Table for 5 and 3 of us took public transportation while the other two found street parking right after 6 PM, not a problem.  Service was fast and food was fresh.  Some of the items we had were:  wakame salad (tasty), saba and sashimi, salmon teriyaki and sashimi, chicken katsu, and hamachi kama.  All were delicious.  In the sashimi, we had four pieces of fish:  salmon, tuna, butterfish and red snapper.  Alittle on the pricey side but this is to be expected in the Union Square area.
author: Karen W.

description:
This is by far my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. The fish is very fresh and the service is prompt and efficient, (these guys don't want to know how your day was, but they are more than happy to help you with the menu.)
If you are a die hard sushi fan I would stick with either the sashimi or the nigiri. The specialty rolls are good, but I found the sauces and extra attention they receive drown out the flavor of the splendid fish. 
The restaurant is a little cramped and is always busy so make sure you make reservations as you will probably not get in otherwise. Also, avoid sitting by the door if you can, you will be very cold every time the door opens.
author: Will M.

description:
Con: Hostess was pretty rude initially, but seemed to get nicer throughout the night

Pros: Everyone else working there was very nice
Food was very good. I found it to be better than Sushi Nakazawa in NYC. I also really liked that I could just tell the itame what kind of food I liked and they just made it for me (ie: white tuna, scallops, Wagyu, and etc) 

I highly recommend spicy scallop rolls, black tuna, and any dish involving wagyu. I was not a huge fan of their white tuna dish because they seared it, and I prefer raw.

Hot sake was also great. I would definitely come back when I am in SF again!
author: Richard Y.

description: Came here today for dinner and it was amazing. I went for the chef special which consisted of 7 different orders sashimi and 6 individual nigiri. I also listened to others and ordered the wagyu beef. If you are here this dish alone is a must. The sea urchin and wagyu beef is the best I ever had in my life. The toro is definitely third in line. I would come back in a heart beat. Our waiter was very nice and checked on us frequently. Expect to drop a couple here depending on what you order. Lastly, this place is a hole in the wall and has no signs. Just look for the Irish bar sign and its right beside it.
author: Mike T.

description:
A few things:  
  
You have to have a reservation.  Even for lunch (according to their site) - I did not want to chance a walk in.  
  
The portions vary widely - my buddy got an Udon soup that was HUGE.  I'm pretty sure "his noodly appendage" could have been hiding in there.  On the flip side, my chicken teriyaki must have been cut from a nano-chicken.  
 
Pricing in general is pretty good.  However a few things are oddly expensive.  Consider the above mentioned  teriyaki was $19 on the lunch menu.  Compare that with a specialty sushi roll we orders which was only $8.  
  
The sushi - is EXCELLENT.  This is what I would come back for, if I came back.

Service was quite decent - actually friendly and accommodating.  

It could easily have been a 4 star, if not for the inconsistency in portion and price.

Give it a shot.  You can do a lo worse.
author: Adam P.

description:
Once you've had sushi in Japan, it's a little more difficult to satisfy a sushi craving here in the states, but definitely possible. You can't just walk into any sushi joint and be satisfied (though in Japan you can go ANYWHERE and the sushi is on point), if only it were that simple and easy. Cue Akiko's.

I came here on NYE and had their prix fixe menu and in that menu contained a nine piece omakase. Nine pieces of nigiri heaven, YUM. While everything on the menu sounded amazing, the omakase is what I was most excited for. It was definitely super satisfying, but what really hit it out of the park were the add-ons we got. I couldn't help it. If I wasn't planning on returning to this place for a long while, I wanted to make my trip worth it. We added on the uni, both the Hokkaido and Russian. The Hokkaido was creamy and light, not like any uni I've tasted (I usually eat Santa Barbara)... no other words to describe it other than "fresh". Not fresh as in it was flown in overnight to preserve it's freshness (which it likely was), but fresh as in the freshness of eating an ice cold watermelon on a hot summer day. Maybe refreshing is a better word for it? If uni could be refreshing, the Hokkaido uni is just that. The Russian uni on the other hand... it's rich, creamy, and full in flavor. So, so good... best uni I've ever consumed, I totally wanted more.

One of the other add-ons was.. can you guess? Yep, otoro. Of course, it was melt in your mouth delicious. Without a doubt everything you'd expect from a good piece of otoro.

If you're looking for good omakase I highly recommend Akikos.
author: Kimberly F.

description: Very fresh sashimi and my salmon teryaki was also spot on! Plus nice decor. Will definitely come back here!
author: Minh N.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets!

Tip: always sit at the bar for omakase and make a reservation ahead of time they're always booked for dinner especially on weekends!

Enjoy!
author: Huy V.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded down.

I don't know why, but the food I've been eating lately hasn't been blowing me away.  What's up with that, San Francisco?  I love you so much, but you keep disappointing me!  

Add this to the list of okay but not-spectacular food.  Another 3.5-er.  

Let's break it down now.

My friend and I got four rolls: the forty-niner (your basic shrimp tempura roll), philadelphia, volcano (spicy salmon and the works), and the sake (a regular salmon roll).  Everything tasted fine.  Nothing tasted omg-amazing.  The forty-niner was my favorite; I liked the crispiness of the shrimp a lot, and they do it right.  The volcano seemed to have an explosion of deep-fried batter decorating the plate of sushi stacked like a volcano.  I like batter too, but not THAT much.  And this was truly batter explosion.

Dinner was $41 before tip, so I guess it's averagely-priced for four sushi rolls.  The portions were also decent.  We left feeling pretty content with the amount of food we had just consumed, which was nice because I normally leave sushi places feeling like I haven't been adequately fed. But this time, it was that feeling of: "Well, I COULD get an order of delicious, deep-fried and perfectly hot onion rings from Burger King next to Sephora on Powell Street and enjoy sitting there munching on the grease explosion in front of me, but I don't HAVE to."  You know? 

Another note: this place is kind of hard to find.  Because it's right under a sign that says "Irish Bank."  Not sure why they haven't changed the sign yet!  Confuse! Do not like! 

I guess if you just want some standard sushi, this'll do for your sushi craving.  But warning: there's nothing particularly exciting.  And would I come back?  Probably not.  There's far too many sushi joints in San Francisco, and this one is like all the other ones.  Plus, they're slow.  We were the first ones in the restaurant for dinner, and it still took them a long while to take our orders and get us our food.

So, overall, if you're in the area, REALLY have a craving for sushi, this is fine for you and decently affordable.  Just keep in mind that it's got no pizazz, no sparkle, no jazz fingers!

It's just alright.
author: Vivian C.

description:
First thing I noticed was a loungy music - not very sushi-like.  Another thing is that I heard no customers speaking Japanese.  
The prices on the menu were shocking. They weren't the $$ kind of prices as shown on yelp. They were more like $$$, and could reach $$$$. I don't understand how they got the $$ rating. Every reviewer had a small stomach and ate only 4 pairs of nigiri sushi and no drink?
Sushi were good and they were using fresh fish, but for this price, they'd better be.
author: Kamome K.

description:
this is my new favorite sushi spot.  sushi is always fresh and tasty, service is great.

if you can afford it, get all the specials.  they have an insane toro selection.

and i always always get the cucumber salad with crab.  ah mazing, dressing is perfection.

my regular sushi spot now.

reservations a must.
author: Josie M.

description:
Great stuff. As good as it gets compared to qualities that I have had in Hokkaido. I mean, the store cryogenically freezes the ankimo, otoro and wagyu beef. For a restaurant of that size that is willing to invest in a deep freeze chamber, it speaks lots about the amount of integrity it is putting into the food it serves.

Definitely get botan ebi if you have a chance. Very hard to get ones that are as fresh if not in season. The Kin-Medai and the Aka matsu are also great selections.

Although the other things on the menu are good, you should fork out the money and do omakase. That's the jewel of this place. Great find.
author: Michael C.

description:
The food here is excellent. The sushi is very well made and well presented.  I liked the sashimi and the forty nine roll, which has a marvelous lemon flavor. Lastly, the miso was great. 

I would give this place five stars, except for a couple things. I like that the place is small, but it's really uncomfortably warm in the back. The service was ok. We ordered and we were never asked about how our food was or whether we needed anything. Better service would have made this a five star, but it's still a great meal and great sushi.
author: Dave G.

description:
Meh. 

Needed a place to meet up with friends while in the city before racing to the airport, and wanted sushi. Inserted all those factors into the yelp-o-meter and out came Akiko.
