I easily made reservations on OpenTable for 4 at 6:30 and when we got there we were seated quickly. 

Their menu is not that large, as compared to other sushi places. Also as others have said, pricing is out of wack. 

Not like I can suggest another sushi place in the area, but I wouldn't go back. The food was tasty and decently portioned but not mind-blowing. The decor and service was also not memorable. I'm betting that there HAS to be something better in the area.
author: Jasmine H.

description: Came here for dinner and had the omakase, which was excellent.  No issues at all with the food, but the pace of the meal could have been a little quicker.  The price was really steep - after tax and tip and including a couple of beers it came to $150/person.  Good sushi is never cheap, but the prices here will keep me from going back anytime soon.
author: Holger B.

description:
I went there on the way to see the Book of Mormon with friends, we found it on Yelp and had a great dinner. I like the atmosphere, kind of odd and strangely shaped. 

Big portions, great rolls. Outstanding Rock & Rolls. Pricey.
author: Kate G.

description:
Having asked a number of people who worked around Union Square and most everyone saying there wasn't any good or reasonably priced Sushi in the area I decided to turn to yelp and found some good reviews of Akiko's. We walked from Union Square and finally found Akiko under and old Irish Pub sign. 
The Sushi was wonderful and the Sushi chef was excellent. They actually had real Wasabi which I had never tried, not near as hot as you standard green horseradish, but very yummy.
All in all one of the better Sushi restaurants I've ever been to. We will visiting whenever we make a trip to Union Square.
author: Jesse S.

description:
The sashimi was very good but not fantastic. The prices were steep.
Most of the seating is the back of the restaurant and is very dark, no windows.
Noise level reasonable so you can converse.
Service only OK.
Waiter forgot to bring ordered drinks twice.
So overall an average experience.
author: Libby M.

description: Excellent food, service and atmosphere  menu special for that day all tons of exotic fish . A bit pricey but highly recommend you should make reservations
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Really glad we walk out of Akiko Sushi Bar which is just a few blocks away, so make sure you don't walk into the wrong shop. 
I gave Akiko 5 stars for their special menu, everything sound fascinating and they are.  If they have Hokaido's Uni and shrimp (raw) and you are a lover of both - splurg and order them.  Hokaido Uni here is so far the best I had, it is smooth and very fresh.  
The original menu I would give it 4/5 stars, they were delicious as well.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This is my go-to sushi spot in the city when I want good quality fresh fish. I have come here several times in the past year and it has yet to disappoint me. What I love about their menu, is that they change it according to whichever is the fresh catch of the day. I've had their Chirashi-don and a good assortment of their Nigiri. Also, the Volcano roll is absolutely to die for as everyone here has already written; it's got a good kick of flavor+spice to really appease those taste buds. This place is certainly not cheap though, so expect to pay at least 20 dollars on your tab. ;) 

Oh, and it is HIGHLY advised to reserve your seating prior arrival. It makes their job seating you easier and you have less waiting to do.
author: Amery Z.

description:
I am not sure why the review is so high with this restaurant. I don't think this restaurant  merit a 4 stars. 

The food is good, but the price is way too high for what you are getting. It is not  traditional Japanese food, but Japanese food with Taiwanese twist. It is like paying French restaurant price for eating at Chipotle. 

If you have the opportunity to taste the real Iron Chef Level Japanese cuisine , which is about the same price, you would understand what I am talking about. I mean Chef with  real Japanese national certificate. 

I give this restaurant a 2 stars for lack of value. Only go eat, if you have too much money.
author: Oishi S.

description:
It was our last meal in SF and we were kind of running late so we had to dine quick. We sat at the bar, ordered:

tempura/chicken
agedashi tofu
organic sake sashimi
hamachi sashimi
bowl of rice

$55 +tip

Not bad. We really rushed it. The food portions were not disappointing, but they're higher end so it's not like you're going to say DAYAMN to the portion sizes = standard what you'd expect for that type of restaurant. Couldn't tell that it was organic, but the sashimi tasted pretty fresh. Service was okay, nothing to complain about. We were in and out in 40 mins.
author: Tania L.

description: Amazing sushi, the spider roll was especially spectacular.  Highly recommend, you won't be disappointed.
author: Molly R.

description: Beautiful contemporary restaurant. The food is artfully plated. The sushi is amazingly fresh. The hot food menu is limited but you would come here for sashimi. They fly fish in from around the world.
author: Ann S.

description: I don't even know where to begin with Akiko's. I've been here twice, and both times had the omakase (chef's choice), and it tasted amazing both times. I also loved the Tonkatsu, the fish is incredibly fresh, and there is a wide variety of options to choose from - most coming straight from Japan. I asked for a recommendation on the sake, and was not disappointed. However, I wouldn't recommend the Passion Fruit Saketini. Thank you Akiko for an unforgettable experience and excellent food. The service can be a bit slow, but if you with a large group you probably won't notice - and their amazing food is worth the wait.
author: Oscar C.

description: The food was very good but we were disappointed with the service. The server and the chef both ate in front of us. The server often approaches us with mouth full. When it came time to pay the bill the server closed the wrong check. Upon realizing what she'd done she asked us for cash to pay the difference. She tried to get me walk to an ATM down the street. I refused and said she could run the card again for the difference or void the payment and re- run the cars. She eventually phoned the owner to find out what to do. While on the phone more customers came in. She yelled across the room that they were closed. It was 9:30 on a busy Saturday night. This was apparently not their policy because the chef panicked when he realized the owner was still on the phone and could hear they were closing early. The checkout took about 15 minutes to resolve. Bad form all around.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I loveeees me some good sushi!! Especially there volcano and rainbow roll which are my two faveeess!  No lie, no lie, no lie-ee-i-ee-i 
This place is always a must if I'm in the city! trust!
author: Yazmin G.

description: Came here for a quick dinner with friends. The sushi selection looked impressive but I wasn't really in the mood to splurge, so I had their combo dinner instead. I got the 4pc nigiri with tonkatsu. Portion was slightly on the smaller side considering the price was $19. Sushi quality was decent, but didn't blow my mind. It's kind of in the limbo between cheap low quality sushi and expensive high quality sushi, which isn't something I usually go for.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Yes the food was good.  My wife liked the 49er roll with the sliced lemon.  Very tasty.

Ambiance excellent.

Value was below average.  I would classify this as $$$ because you have to order more to be satisfied.  Have other sushi restaurants on the east bay the are as good with more food.
author: scott c.

description: After a few recommendations I decided to check out Akiko's.  Great food, great service! The staff pays close attention to you, and doesn't constantly bombard you with "how's everything?". Love that!
author: Shannon W.

description: Akiko's is definitely one of my favorite sushi spots.  The fish is super fresh - I don't think I've had anything here that wasn't delicious!  The menu here is extensive, but I almost always go for the omakase.  The dishes are always inventive and never disappoint.  I gave it four stars only because when it's full (which is always - you definitely need a reservation), the service really slows down and a dinner can end up taking upwards of several hours.
author: Liz D.

description: wooo hoooo ! The best! High quality ingredients. I made the reservation for my birthday there already.
author: Asak B.

description:
Best selection ever.

Never have I been to a sushi bar that has a better selection of rare, sustainably caught fish.

We opted for Omakase and were treated to one of the best sushi meals I've ever eaten. This is now my favorite sushi bar and I will make a point to visit every time I come back to town. It's pricey, but oh so worth it.
author: brandi g.

description: Incredibly delicious sushi, and probably the best monkfish liver I've ever tasted. Portion-size is pretty small though so it can get pretty pricey to get full. Definitely more of a "special occasion" spot.
author: Kai C.

description: Nice ambiance, service was ok but the food was not. Uni was good but it seemed that every roll had the same sweet sauce drizzled over it so it all tasted the same. I was still hungry but could not bring myself to order more food as it would be a waste of money. I will stick to traditional sushi bars and avoid the hoidy toidy sushi joints. This review should account for two as my lunch date feels the same way. Oh and one last think, who puts daikon in Tekka Maki??
author: G A.

description:
Simply the best sushi I've had yet in the city.  The fish quality and selection is on par with Sushi Ran, which is saying a lot.  

Just sit at the bar and let the chef order for you.  Boom.  Flavor country.
author: William F.

description:
In order to spice up this review, I'm going to intersperse it with fun TRIVIA FACTS! Watch out!

---

Super classy sushi place. But it's not, like, IN YOUR FACE classy, which I appreciated. Low-key classy. It won't get all up in your business.

**TRIVIA FACT**
I think you need to get reservations here but I don't actually know because I didn't get them for my group.
***

Things are kind of pricey, especially if you stick to the sashimi or nigiri. I guess that's how it is at most sushi places---but since this is a more upscale joint, you can drop, like, 25 bucks on what basically amounts to two small slices of fish.


***TRIVIA FACT***
The bathroom door is kind of confusing. You'll... you'll see what I mean?
***

Service was glacially slow. We were famished, and waiting for sushi, and really really wanted to eat sushi, and waited a little bit more for sushi, and then the sushi came. It's something you'll just have to deal with. Highlights at our table were the salmon nigiri and the volcano rolls.

***TRIVIA FACT***
My recollection of the price is a bit biased in the expensive direction because we were paying for the dinner of one of our friends who was going away, and because I have no ability to account for cognitive biases.
***

The rolls are actually a pretty good bang for your buck. If I come back, I'll definitely be getting more of those.

***TRIVIA FACT***
That's all! I'm done now.
***
author: Greg P.

description:
I had the 12pc sashimi tasting menu.

It was very, very good.  It was very expensive ($32) considering the portion size.

I guess I can look past the price because it's in a touristy neighborhood.

The only negative was that the back room where we were seated was hot as all hell.  Not sure if the AC was broken or the restaurant is always that hot.

Summary: excellent raw fish but you will pay for it.  Small, crowded restaurant but intimate ambiance.
author: Michael S.

description: Dinner at Akiko's always puts a smile on my face.  The fish is top quality and everything I have had here is delicious.  While they have a full menu of a la carte options, I'm partial to their omakase. It never disappoints.  If you don't get the omakase, make sure at some point to try the truffled wagyu beef for a little slice of heaven.  Beyond the food, I love the ambiance and the cozy feel of this small little spot.  Enjoy!
author: Kari F.

description:
Yum! I love this place. You need a reservation to get in.

They do simple, delicious, clean, fresh sushi. Not overloaded on any sauces or no cream cheese in sushi (eww what a gross idea...).

Their fish was ultra fresh, the service amazing. There was one waiter who was mainly tasked with making sure the water was always full in our glasses the whole night, and another waiter who took our orders. It was a lot of attention!

I don't want to review highly because other people will crowd this place out, but I simply can't say anything bad about this place.
author: Lilo And P.

description:
Having been to Akikos on a few other occasions, I was stoked when my wife surprised me with a Saturday dinner there to celebrate our anniversary. But this visit turned out to be our last, because it was one of the worst restaurant experiences ever.

It all began when we inquired about a 12-piece Sashimi tasting. Not a fan of Mackerel, I politely asked if it could be left off the selection. The waiter abruptly replied "No" as it was the chef's decision. Ok, fine. I get it. But what ensued the rest of night was outright ridiculous. While trying to decide on our meal, which couldn't include Toro, Black Cod or Wagyu because they were out despite appearing on the menu, we finally made our wine selection. They were out of our first choice of course, a $42 bottle of German Riesling. So we settled for a $46 bottle of 2012 Hugel Riesling. The waiter showed up with a 2013 bottle instead, and we again settled. But the wine was rank, and we sent it back. The waiter proceeded to lecture us on the taste of Riesling wine, of which we have had plenty.  We decided to just drink beer instead... a standard Sapporo. 

When it came time to order, our selection off the standard menu included Ikura and Seared Salmon Belly, both of which were unavailable all night also.  At this point we were pretty pissed. How can you be out of so much and charge the same prices for inferior products on a Saturday night in San Francisco?! We placed our order, and I got up to ask for the manager to discuss the poor service. But apparently Akikos was out of managers as well, so I ended up speaking to the expeditor. He offered his apologies, said he would pass on the word and offered us Sake on the house. I kindly declined, but he later appeared with a Nori cracker topped with Spicy Tuna, and said drinks were on the house for the evening.  A step in the right direction, right? WRONG.

Not wanting to abuse the gesture, we inquired about the three other Japanese beers, one costing $9 and the other two, $13. But guess what? Out of the latter as well! So we sipped on our $9 bottle from Okinawa.

After overhearing the waiter tell the table next to us that they had Yellowtail (not on the menu), we ordered a few additional Nigiri, which were quite tasty, but nothing out of this world. With our glasses still full, the waiter removed our plates, but rather than asking if we wanted any dessert, he disappeared and quickly returned with the check. This was the last straw. We hate, I mean HATE, being brought the check without having asked for it. Even more so when there are plenty of empty tables available for sitting people. We finished our beer, paid and left no tip whatsoever, and headed out the door for our last ever visit to Akikos.  A terrible experience for a place that has only gone downhill since our first visit. Check out their website. Their drinks menu doesn't work and their blog hasn't been updated since 2012. Pretty lame for a place that charges what it does. Sayonara, Akikos!
author: Matt G.

description:
I'm a rookie when it comes to sushi, but I found it to be very good here!  I also had teriyaki salmon and miso soup, both of which were amazing.

The waiter we had did an excellent job at explaining the menu to us and was very patient.  Overall a really nice experience.
author: Nathaniel M.

description: Excellent sushi, friendly service, nice atmosphere.   Sake list is also very good.   Will be back whenever I'm in the area again.
author: Dave M.

description:
I'm always happy to see Akiko's hopping with business, even if this means I wont be able to get a table during peak hours. This family owned and operated business is on the short list of my all time favorites. Any haters need to meet me for a boxing lesson, your choice of venue.

After not being in for sometime, I can walk through the door, be recognized and welcomed back. I took my kids to lunch here today; sashimi for me with wakame, assorted rolls and tempura for the rest. It was the usual outstanding service and quality food and usual here is why I like coming here so much.

Akiko's is simply the best sushi downtown.
author: Steve S.

description: Excellent. The fish selection was superb. If I had any criticism at all it would be that the shari was not seasoned quite enough (for my liking) but a small issue relative to the overall experience. Best sashimi plate I've had in the US.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I have probably passed this place on the street about 100 times and never knew it existed until I went last week with my cousin.  It's a really cute little spot, right on the corner of St. Marks Lane.

We had some amazing sake - Komekome. It was almost like a Riesling, but not as sweet. I never knew that sake could be so floral and delicious.  And, my cousin said that she hasn't been able to find this sake anywhere but California.

We ordered the firecracker and the dynamite, and although both were really good, they were too similar.  I wish that we had ordered something that gave our dinner a little more variety.  Both were flash fried and spicy, which made them hard to distinguish.
author: Taylor L.

description: We ordered 2 orders of omakase and was very disappointed. Although the fish was very fresh, all 15 pieces was brushed with the same house special soy sauce. There was no creativity in their omakase considering we paid $100 pp. it all ended up tasting the same. I definitely don't recommend the omakase if you come here.
author: Whitney N.

description:
Even though I've walked past this restaurant for several years, I found it through Yelp!  Delicious with good shelving. I had miso soup and sat at the sushi bar an hour before they closed to prep for dinner.  The fish were presented in thick cuts.  Does any restaurant in the city serve a crunchy roll?  

I had to grab my chopstick rest/soy sauce dish from the setting next to me.  We were given a carafe of ice water too.  The people next to us were satisfied with only a vivi + spider roll. This is next to the Financial District.   While Joe knows his Japanese fish, he is fluent in Chinese. 

I recommend the kampachi.  The flower silhouettes on the menu and walls are pretty.  The sushi chef was very friendly. There were only a couple of diners at a the bar and window table.  We ordered salmon sashimi, sea urchin, and white tuna belly nigiri.
author: Ai M.

description:
Our favorite sushi place near home in Chinatown. The fish is exceptional, though the nigiri portions are not large. Rolls are delicious and a great value, and the secret standouts are Oshitashi appetizer and volcano roll. 

- Make a reservation (OpenTable or call them) - they frequently fill up completely
- Everything is fresh and wonderful
- Try the Walu both ways (seared and raw)
- Sit at the bar, the chefs are adorable
- Their wine list is my #1 source for newfound favs
- Pull hard on the bathroom door to overcome the wind tunnel's effect. You'll see.
author: Megan G.

description:
Had an early reservation made with OpenTable, running late, pushed it back 45 minutes (I thought) got there and wasn't on the list. Realized when I changed the reservation I actually moved it to the following evening accidentally (I'll blame jet lag). But the waiter/host found us a table and sat us right away. Made a potentially disastrous mistake absolutely fine.

Food was spectacular. I'm from Buffalo, NY, I have some sushi places back home I adore, but this has totally recalibrated my scale for rating sushi restaurants. I knew the seafood would be fresher, but I wasn't prepared for how good this was going to be. I honestly don't know if I'll ever enjoy sushi the same way again.

Started with gyoza, wife had chicken teriyaki and some unagi nigiri. I had a spicy tuna roll and their 49er roll. The spicy tuna was legitimately hot with super fresh tuna inside. The 49er roll had a bunch of stuff in it including really crunchy shrimp tempura and was topped with a sliver of paper lemon peel. That lemon peel just made the roll pop and made my eyes bug out of my head when I ate the first piece. Wife was worried something was wrong by my reaction. When she tried a piece she understood. Wow.

Also, their wasabi had more kick than any I've ever had.  

Was worried about slow service based on other reviews, but it was very speedy. Maybe they were trying to speed us through since we were an unplanned table, but the service was impeccable, not slow, not rushed, and water frequently refilled. Space was really inviting, attractive, and hip.
author: John A.

description: I'm from NY on a long term project here in SF, so I've been searching for a sushi place in SF  .  I'm spoiled by NY sushi AZABU, Brushstroke, Ushiwakamaru and others, so finding a sushi place in a town i'm unfamiliar with is not easy.  First time I came here, I thought I had found an equal to the NY sushi places i'm used to, sushi was great quality, rice was perfectly cooked and service was great.  But things went downhill on my second try, the rice was ALL WRONG, which made the sushi really BAD.  I've complained "more like commented" and they were very nice.  Surprised me at the end by taking out my bottle of sake from the bill.  So I tried this place for the third time and again seems like the sushi quality is going down and fast.  I don't plan to go back.  It's not cheap and for the price I expect consistency.
author: Kwan K.

description:
The exposed walls and industrial decor gives Akiko's an unusual look for a Japanese restaurant.  Oddly enough, It still maintains an austere and zen-like feel.  The space is small (as most of the places are in FiDi), but comfortable.  The food we had today was excellent!  The 49'er roll, Rock 'n' Roll, and fried spicy tuna roll were all delicious.  One lunch buddy had the oyako-don and seemed to enjoy it immensely.  I had the nabeyaki udon which was good (especially the perfectly cooked soft-boiled egg), but not as interesting as other versions I've had elsewhere (i.e., there were pieces of white fish, but no mushrooms, shrimp tempura, or fishcake).  The broth was really good, though.

For lunch, Akiko's can get a bit pricey.  We definitely can't afford to come here every time we have meetings in the City but, luckily, it is one of many great places to choose from in the area.
author: Sherri C.

description: Decent sushi, but for what you will pay, you can get way better in SF. The biggest issue I had with this place was the staff / manager. Read other reviews and you will get the gist. Pompous, rude, unaccommodating, unprofessional. We nearly walked out of the place a few times and now I wish we had. Go to Ryoko instead. Cool space, great sushi, and sweet people that make you feel welcome.
author: Chris K.

description: The omakase was pricey but worth it.  The sushi was fresh, especially the uni, which I normally don't like unless it's the absolute freshest.  Creative, well prepared, and good variety.
author: Neill T.

description: In my fatty opinion best omakase I've had in the city so far.  I haven't been to Roka SF yet but I will get there someday.  This place is definitely not a tourist trap.  Its a little bit difficult to find if you don't live or work in teh area but the food is freakin amazing.  I highly recommend bringing a date that you actually like here.  Its too expensive for a coffee meets bagel chick.
author: Fatty A.

description:
I think I'm only giving them a 4 because there are NO decent sushi places in the Financial. =P 

Came here for lunch with a buddy of mine. Jeebus service is slow. It's raw fish, does it really take THAT long to cut it?!

Chirashi ($16): A surprisingly decent selection and amount of fish. However, some were fresh while others mushy and obviously were not handled properly during the freezing/thawing process. The chirashi came with sake, wakame, tai, walu, tobiko, ebi, unagi and maguro. I think that's it. Maybe hamachi as well? Like I mentioned, some were fresh, some weren't. Overall this is a decent place for sushi in the FiDi. 

Side note: Service is slow, prices are a bit high for lunch but hey, you're kinda limited on choices around here.
author: Beverly T.

description: After walking everywhere to find a sushi restaurant that was open on New Year's Day, well night actually, we stumbled upon this place. Initially we were going to ryokos but it was closed. We had to wait about 10 minutes in the cold but it was totally worth it!! It was so nice and cozy, and the service was very good and quick. The food was so fresh and delicious. My next trip back to SF I'm def coming back here!!
author: Tori N.

description: This place is a hole in a wall. You can't really find them because they don't have the name. This place is just a small sushi and bar style kind of restaurant near Chinatown in San Francisco. The atmosphere is cozy and relaxing. The staffs weren't really attentive. I needed to ask them for drinks and when I wanted to order food again. I ordered dragon rolls. Don't get me wrong, what I had was just fine. The presentation and the taste just failed. A little pricey too. Tourist trap kind of restaurant.
author: Manisa K.

description: So there has been a lot of hype about this place.  My gf and I decided that we should give it try and see what all the hype was all about.  I have to say,  akikos is by far the best sushi place I've been to.  Words can't describe what the experience was like.  The fish was so fresh and delish!!!  The restaurant gives you a feel of a taste of Japan.  There are soo many great things I can say about Akikos.
author: Lucy H.

description: No sign at this place, reservation for 9pm and was seated promptly. Great rolls, including the tuna one that was market priced (forgot what it was called). The grilled saba (mackerel) fish was too salty, but our server took it off the bill. Other than that, service was great. One of the most polite waiters, actually!
author: See L.

description:
went for lunch
good service
fresh fish
enjoyed the nigri and rolls
tonkatsu/tempura tasty
author: Justin K.

description: Delicious, fresh sushi. The mochi ice cream is an absolute must! As other reviews have said, this place is a little hard to find, but well worth a look.
author: Laura M.

description:
I'm gonna share one of my sushi strategies with all y'all: Order anyting that has anything to do with a volcano, hot lava or any kind of explosives.

At Akiko's, I'd say that strategy was a hit. Out of the many, many maki that my group ordered, the Volcano Roll, Firecracker Roll and Dynamite Roll were my favorites. Some of the others were slightly less exciting for me, but that's not to say they were disappointing. I didn't try a single thing I didn't like.

I would have liked to taste some of the sashimi, but since I was with a big group, it didn't make as much sense. And speaking of groups, definitely make a reservation if you are coming with a crew. The restaurant is cozy, in a raw kind of way---with some cool murals on the exposed brick.
author: Annie D.

description:
I'm a bit conflicted; the rolls were the low point of the meal. We got the volcano, a sort of fried crab leg dish and the vv. I thought the volcano was way overpricedand over hyped. To be honest I couldnt even tell there was fried crab in it, it could have just been fry batter. The vv was just ok. The fried crab leg thing was a distinctive taste but I didn't particularly care for it.

The nigiri was the better of the night, I enjoyed the diverse selection and tried some things out of my comfort zone. So that was good.

The service is very slow but attentive when they're there.
author: Jay C.

description: Went here with a friend last month. They were able to accommodate us last minute for a Friday reservation 5:30pm. We were seated by the front door (glass in between so no draft and fun to watch people walking in) which ended up being a spot I would ask for in the future.  For example, if I were on a date (which may take divine intervention) I would want this table. Our fantastic waiter suggested we let him pick for us. He also chose cold sake pairings which will haunt me not b/c of my horrific hangover, but the cold sensational taste which complemented the most fresh, delicious sushi I have ever had. I almost cried a few times. It was that good.
author: Win S.

description:
I came here with an old-coworker because we were craving good sushi and it was paycheck day (YAY!)

I definitely recommend making reservations for this place because on the night we went was "reservation only" night. The interior of the restaurant is very rustic and cozy, decorated very nicely. 

We had ordered a variety of nigiri with fish other than sake (salmon) and maguro (tuna) and a few hot dishes that I can't seem to recall. Everything tasted delicious. The only thing that concerned me and that I'd to warn everyone is the spicy tuna roll. It looked like a harmless spicy tuna roll but each bite was packed with a PUNCH. Unless you really like spicy food and have a high tolerance for it, this is the roll for you. The burn for each bite last for a good 10 min and there were at least 8 pieces in the roll. At the end of our meal, we asked the waiter what made it so spicy. He told us that it's made with habanero peppers. Imagine our faces: -___________- 

I wish the restaurant had mentioned that on their menus.
author: Samantha K.

description:
This place is A-OK!

Came here with the gf for our SF trip.

Just some expensive HIGH quality sashimi and rolls with EXCELLENT service!

I suggest that you make a reservation for dinner though as I've seen people be turned away without one.
author: Stewart C.

description:
The trick to having a great experience here is twofold: 

The first part is when you come. It's not hard to get a reservation here, but peak hours can be troublesome: The layout can make it hard to get your server's attention. Service, however is often fantastic, seldom sporadic. Come right after or before peak hours.

The second is what you order. Stick to anything where the chef chooses what's fresh, ie sashimi platters or chirashi. Order off the daily menu. Sure, it's a little more expensive but Akiko's has the best sashimi I've ever had. 

Tonkatsu is good, as are the teriyaki dishes. The firecracker roll is great and the nigiri des are often so good I will order one and try it and immediately order another.

 PS, the 2 seat table in the front may be the most romantic spot I've ever had the pleasure of dining.
author: Tom M.

description: I like this place. They love sushi and so do I. You can tell that they love sushi because of the careful and creative way they present it. Also, they field your questions happily and with expert insight. It's a treat to dine at Akiko's.
author: Jason H.

description:
Friday night, after work, gym and overall exhaustion, I tried to make a reservation at Akiko using Open Table.  Done and done, or so I thought.  It was busy and I was so proud that I snagged last minute reservations.  Host "We closed open table already - we don't have any more reservations available." I argued he must have been mistaken and as I am doing so, I pull out my phone and realize, OOPS!, I made reservations for next Friday.  
The host smiled and then graciously offered two seats at the end of the bar.  SOLD!  We had great service and the fish, oh, the fish, was amazing!  Tasted like it jumped out of the ocean and into my mouth.  The decor is gorgeous with nice artwork.   Don't be fooled by location - this is the opposite of a tourist trap, it is a local gem.
author: Amireh G.

description: Great little place to get fresh sushi! I thought considering the high quality of the sushi the prices where quite reasonable. Very home style place not fancy at all. Staff was friendly and helpful. We were there on the early side of a weekday evening and we got seated right away with out a reservation, they told us that they would like the table for a certain time for another reservation but the kitchen was a little slow and we could not leave with in the expected time but they did not bother us or try to rush us at all. Overall a great experience!
author: Garden Lover S.

description:
Excellent Sushi. The yellow fin was cut fresh and sliced right in front of us.

Very nice choice for Sushi. Awesome
author: Jay F.

description:
I was so very happy with the variety of sushi available!  This is a great place to eat sashimi because the quality is very high and very tasty!

We had a reservation for three for 6:30 on a Thursday, and it was already full.  

Live Scallop - I was put off by this because, silly me, I thought you eat it while it's moving.  It just means that it was shipped live to them, so it was very fresh, and so very delicious! My friend mentioned that they should not have sliced it so thin, and I agree since I like that pillow-y texture of scallops.  But still it was very good.

Sake Sashimi - Delicious!

Hamachi Sashimi - Delicious!

Uni - Pretty good.

Monkfish Liver - My friend loves this but I'd never heard of it before.  I love trying new things though. Reminded me of uni but more creamy,  maybe it will grow on me.

Sake Avocado - Loved this roll!

Dynamite Roll  and Firecracker- Roll - one had scallops and was good, one had eel which I thought was sweet and did not like.

Spider Roll - good

Grilled Mackerel - I'm not into this is all I can say.  It had a lot of fish oils which I'm sure are really good for you.


We ordered the hot sake and I like that it comes sitting in hot water so that it keeps warm.  The bottle is too small though. Every person needs one bottle for themselves, yet I believe it was for a pretty penny.  Service is very friendly, but it does take a while to get your food and orders, so I wish that the sake size would compensate for that :P  All in all, a very enjoyable dinner.
author: Erica D.

description: Delicious, but pricey for what  it was.  Nice decor and ambience.  Ordered omakase, but felt slow and very spaced out.  Ordered blue crab on top of the chef's selection and wasn't a big fan. Service was attentive, but forgot some details.  The spotted prawn and the octopus was my favorite.
author: Jamie L.

description: This is the second Akiko restaurant in the area and, surprisingly, not related (anymore) to the first (I think). Anyway they share the same name and perhaps original owners but this is a more upmarket experience. The other place -although also 5 stars (see my review) - had excellent food with some incredible dishes (hamachi belly); this place -- where a reservation is required--is like the posher big brother. Here every single piece of sushi and sashimi I tried was mindblowing with the piece de resistance being the Kobe wagyu beef nigiri (at 25$ for one piece) as well as the various types of toro (bluefin tuna) sashimi and nigiri. I also tried the sashimi tasting menu. Never had such fresh sushi. The drinks menu was also very extensive and some of the sake was also outstanding. Service was also very good and the chefs were friendly and brilliant, explaining each dish in detail. Obviously you pay more in a place like this but, with a 20% tip, my bill came to just north of 150$ but I had the very best sushi of my life. Definitely go there on a special occassion or to treat yourself or if you are looking for a great place for a romantic dinner date which serves astonishingly good sushi.
author: Asif J Z.

description: One of the best omakase I've had the pleasure to experience.  Nice mix of treatments and toppings to the nigiri pieces which did not heavily rely too much on "smoky" or "spicy" flavors.  Personally I loved the number of snappers available and the quality of the uni and toros.  The wagyu + truffle was gobsmacking, but my personal favorite was the sous-vide abalone (new for me!).
author: Grace V.

description: By far the best sushi I have ever ate, and I've eaten at some of the best spots in LA and SF. The chef was very polite and added to our experience.
author: Krikor G.

description:
Akiko has fresh fish. This is evident, in pictures taken by other Yelpers, and in the food itself once you visit. 

But there are reasons I will not visit again: 

1) We placed 5 orders of nigiri and out of the 5, our waiter had to inform us later that they had ran out of 3. Our dinner reservation was at 5:30! If you run out of fish basically before dinner time, I have only 1 question: WHY?!?! The strange part is that our order wasn't specialty seafood, which I would understand if the restaurant had only limited amount--all we wanted was sea urchin, yellow tail belly, and toro. So... WHY?

2) too hipster. pretentious as hell. I like real food. Grub food. Street food. Mom and Pop food. Sushi and sashimi CAN be such food. Just because it's Japanese and has an upper scale feel due to the price doesn't mean it can't be mainstream in a way that diners can enjoy, eat large portions of, accompanied by hearty alcohol, and have a merry ol time. One such place is Sushi Sam in SM (except it's usually packed). 
At Akiko, all I saw were white couples whispering, one in dreadlocks, one or two hip Asian folks in Warby Parker glasses and straight bangs... ALL whispering. Ordering California rolls, "seaweed salad", Spider roll AT MOST (but you are really kind of pushing it), 6 pieces of salmon sashimi (too dangerous and exciting!) and alas... MOCHI ICE CREAM IN EXOTIC FLAVORS: sesame- what!? lychee- OMG. and green tea- PHEW~ "safest Oriental flavor" I can't. Seriously. This is just too SF for me. I am a lame duck suburban kinda girl and witnessing all of this in one night is too much. 

3) the wait. As part of the SF hipster sushi experience, we first waited 20 minutes for our first order (fried tofu) while the couple who came in and ordered after us got theirs, then 15 minutes for 2 pieces of nigiri, another 20 minutes for the other 6 pieces, and another 10-15 minutes for a small roll. WHY?!?!  It was 5:30pm and half of the restaurant was empty. I watched as a waitress kept replacing and rearranging the 2 pieces of ginger on a plate waiting to be served. I have no idea WHY, but she just kept rearranging them, literally for 5 minutes, maybe wanting it to look "perfect". I was dumbfounded. Details and presentation are important naturally, but this is not the type of arts and craft experience I want to be part of. 

By the end, I just kind of lost my patience. Even though my partner and I weren't full, I didn't know how much longer we'd have to wait for 2 more pieces of sushi. Did they drive all the way to the Bay to fish? Maybe that's why the food was so fresh, regardless, I didn't want to spend time in there anymore.
author: Salamander L.

description: Wow, I'm amazed. I didn't have any expectations and it beyond exceeded mine! We were able to sit at the sushi bar on Friday night during their first seating. Hubs & I got the omakase which was about 15 courses/pieces. The fish was very fresh and we had a few things we haven't had before, extra bonus! We enjoyed every bite but the more memorable ones - aji, umimasu, hotate, karuma ebi, uni from russia, crab porridge!, Wagyu topped with truffle :) Service was quick, and reservations are highly recommended. Love, it's our new sushi favorite in SF!
author: Meredith K.

description: Hands down- The best sushi I have had in the city to date. I was recently complaining that the japanese food in SF couldn't compare to LA- but Akikos sushi was AMAZING. Very fresh and absolutely delicious! Would definitely come back for dinner or special occasion.
author: Megan M.

description: The service here is horrible and the hostess is a piece of work. I'm never going back.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Excellent quality, great tasting sushi. (Go for the Volcano Roll!)

Great, friendly service. Clean. 

Note: Tables are close together so don't go here for a personal conversation.


Hard to locate as there is no sign in front, but just remember the address is 431. (Next to an Irish bar)

Great date spot!
author: Thomas R.

description:
I popped into this place cause I was looking for some good sushi. The design of the place looks real good. Great for a casual date. 

Although its a little expensive, of you're looking for some good sushi....this place will hit the spot. 

Definitely recommend the volcano roll. It's a little spicy but it's very tasty and the little breading that comes with it is like eating chips, you'll just keep picking at it. 

The service is very friendly and fast.  

I've eaten here a few times and enjoyed it every time.
author: Michael H.

description:
I love this place!!!! Sushi in this restaurant are so great!!!

I ordered Uni, negihama, spicy tuna and hirame and all of them were beyond my expectations. Especially hirame surprised at me! I was asked if I wanted a Japanese style hirame, so I answered yes. Then, I got a little marinated style hirame with "yuzu-kosyo", which is Japanese special seasoning. I had never thought I could meet this special Japanese style hirame in SF, so I was suuuuper happy!!

I will definitely come back to this place soon!!
author: Machiruda Y.

description:
Looking for a new sushi place in downtown SF, my wife and I came across Akiko.  In keeping with our tradition of Omakase, we let the chef provide his selections.  Wonderful atmosphere, on the smaller side, active but still not too loud, and absolutely top notch sashimi  and nigiri.  Plenty of exotic fish, and friendly chef.  Highly recommended.  Price for 2 with sake just shy of 2 hundee.

Saw 2 parties turned away on a Sat night for not having reserversations, but there were tables available.  Get a res!
author: J H.

description:
A hidden wonderful sushi place. The service was wonderfully attentive. They were pretty busy but were able to squeeze us in on a Monday night. (A sushi place open on a Monday!) It's a fairly small place so I would recommend reservations as the sushi bar is also covered by reservations. Definitely a good date place. 

The sushi was fresh and tasty! We ordered a couple of the combo meals (comes with miso soup), salad, and some nigiri including sweet shrimp (yay! Fried shrimp heads!). They also have a decent selection of drinks and sake. 

No complaints other than it's a little more than what I'd spend everyday otherwise I'd be there for dinner multiple times a week!
author: S C.

description: Our group wasn't blown away, but we received good food and overly attentive service.  I wish our meal wasn't brought out in 15 different installments, other than that it was fine.
author: Kristina G.

description: I'm not sure how they got 4 stars. Definitely should be 5. Fantastic sushi, great service and a pleasant decor. What else do you want!
author: Jerry F.

description:
Notes when choosing to eat here:
1.  Make reservations
2. The volcano roll is only during lunch hours to reserve appropriately
3. Don't bring a cheap ass not down to pay more for fine sushi dining

I was pretty disappointed when I was told that delicious volcano roll everyone keeps talking about is only during lunch hours when I came here for dinner.  Either I got to excited and missed that little information or no one bothered to mention it!!  lolol oh well! It's an easy to get to place from downtown and I'd definitely come back.  The fish is fresh and they have special kinds that they don't serve at most Japanese restaurants.  I came here with a terrible i-don't-even-want-to-consider-a-date and I won't go into detail but seriously -- if you're cheap and you're not down for some fine dining, don't bother.  The menu isn't super expensive but it's not cheap either.  IDK maybe I just never mind paying more for sashimi that melts in your mouth.  It's a pretty tiny restaurant, with a dark romantic kind of ambiance.  I'm definitely coming back here for lunch for that volcano roll. Anyone care to join me sometime? :D
author: Lisa L.

description:
My boyfriend tried to surprise me by bringing me here for our anniversary dinner. Little did he know that I've already tried this place and was planning to bring HIM here for a surprise. -___-

The food was as good as the first time I tried this place, although the service wasn't as wonderful. We ordered the Volcano Roll, the Rainbow Roll, and the Fourty-Niner. Our server wasn't too friendly, but he was quite knowledgeable. 

Everything was very fresh and carefully prepared, so again, I was impressed. I highly recommend the Rainbow Roll. It's a party in your mouth! (no dirty joke intended)  

note: Make a reservation well in advance (no matter what the occasion) because this place tends to get booked very quickly.
author: Lillian D.

description:
Wow, I had all ready written off the fact that there was no good food in the Financial District so I walked in here with kind of low expectations despite the good yelp reviews.

This place does sushi right, the decor is really cool and urban.  The place is small and cozy with brick walls with paintings hung on them and pipes protruding from the walls at certain points.  Service was really good and explained each and every fish including the location it was caught.  They never hesitated to refill drinks, including pour our beer or sake for us.

My girlfriend and I ordered the sashimi platter, a few nigiris, some cucumber salad and miso.  Everything was on point and amazing.  The fish was all ridiculously fresh and I am really starting to like uni.  All the different cuts of fish literally melted in your mouth.  Standouts were salmon ( can't remember where it was caught but it was a specialty one), uni, the hamachi (I believe it was Russian?  don't quote me though), and the white tuna.  Come to think of it everything was pretty much a stand out!

The miso was also really tasty and not to be forgotten.

This place is great, prices run a little on the high side but you are definitely getting quality here.  Next time I will have to try a couple of rolls but for the sashimi this place is hands down a winner!
author: Ryan J.

description: The spicy tuna roll was fantastic - probably the best I have had anywhere. High high quality tuna. The salmon was fine. The Hamachi was disappointing but the sushi overall is clearly of the highest order
author: Salim M.

description:
Excellent sushi, so-so service. Started out a bit bumpy - we had reservations, but waited about 10 minutes to be seated, so not the end of the world. Got seated and waited about another 10 minutes to really get anything going. I wasn't feeling particularly good about things. The guys working there (all I saw working there were guys which was a bit odd to me in a restaurant like this) seemed a bit overwhelmed/disorganized considering how small the place is. The earbuds they wear to communicate didn't seem to be helping - perhaps that's the problem, they can't get anything accomplished with each other in their ears.

Anyway, things turned around after that. The food was excellent. Rivaled my favorite sushi place in Seattle. From then on everything was delicious and came to the table in a timely fashion. The anal-retentive positioning of things on the table and attention to presentation was commendable, but perhaps part of the reason they seem to have issues with quick service.

Overall, excellent food and a nice little restaurant despite the bumpy beginning. I'd be back again and again if I lived nearby.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Atmosphere is great. We sat at the bar and it was casual, fun, yet still a little trendy and upscale (compared to your hole in the wall cheap sushi places). Sashimi was really good, the fish was fresh and delicious. The roll we ordered was average. Sake was great...4 bottles later! 

Service was a little slow, but it was nice not feeling rushed. Would go there again.
author: Beth R.

description:
Outstanding! Discovered this place last year when I was in town in business. Went again last week - it's just as good as I remembered! 

Had the firecracker roll, which was a delicious combination of flavors and spice,  flash fried to perfection.  The unagi was probably the best I ever had. Was also delighted that butterfish was on the list of specials. So good that I went back 2 days later for lunch.
author: Vic F.

description: Omakase all the way. Very intimate spot (ie great for dates but prob not large parties). Super friendly staff as well :)
author: Annie K.

description: One of the better sushi bars in the area. Service, good. Decor, over the top. Sake, good. Food, amazing. The uni here is to die for. It is a bit pricey, yes, but it is well worth it.
author: Yosef M.

description: I understand that you are small but you can't accommodate walk-ins for two people? Dumb... And I was half hour early to do so. Fail.
author: Mitchell G.

description: Most authentic Japanese style sushi you can find in downtown SF. Simple and fresh.
author: Yunah R.

description: Nice little sushi place in the city.  Quality of the fish and preparation is excellent.  It's one of the better places for sushi and the price reflects that.  Omakase is the route to go if it's your first time or you can't decide what's good.  This will delight you with flavors outside your comfort zone.  The Madagascar Blue shrimp, toro, ankimo, and king salmon were my favorites.  The wait staff is prompt and knowledgeable which made the evening pleasurable.  The decor and ambiance was also inviting.   Reservations are a must and be prepared to spurge a bit! ;)
author: MTBer I.

description: we went there for lunch, one of our ritual ladies lunches.. sushi sashimi, fish fresh. then we ordered a cooked food, cod fish. my friend cod's came first and waitress told me, sorry, please wait for a while, they are still cooking the other cod fish. i had to asked couple times n same answer. finally my fish came another 30 mins later. what a terrible service.. if they have problem with the kitchen or the fish, they should have told us and we could order other dishes.. my poor friend had to eat halfway and waited for my fish to arrive...
author: I P.

description: Really good and fresh tasting sushi. Cute atmosphere.The service was just okay, would have liked some recommendations and the menu is really small.
author: Desa F.

description: Great service, excellent fresh food.  The place was a bit tight and cramped in regards to seating, but is an otherwise intimate and relaxing setting.
author: Trey W.

description:
Good sushi, not really blowing me out of the water, though. It's located in tourist-y land here by Union Square so no matter what I feel like you're going to get high prices and mediocre food in this 5-block radius, unless you REALLY want to fork over top dollar. I'd go there again if I was dying for sushi and in the 'hood.

Service was really, really slow and they brought out our food in a very random order. It took 15 minutes to get a cup of tea. Maybe it's our fault for picking the 12:00 rush spot, but for 3 of us our lunch lasted an hour and a half... don't pick this spot if you're in a hurry. 

I had udon soup, and it was good. Had a couple rolls which were ok. One was over-done and so gigantic I could barely fit a bite in my mouth and the other one was painfully average. The sashimi was fresh and probably my favorite part of the meal.
author: Amber C.

description: Akiko's has become my favorite sushi restaurant.  Reservations are a must as it is popular.  The owner will sometimes recommend omakase, which we always go with and are never disappointed, as they always seem to have locally caught fish available.  It provides a unique selection, not found elsewhere.
author: Arlene C.

description:
This place has a door that is very hard to open.  I'm a well-muscled man and I struggled to open the door to this place -- almost to the point where I thought it was closed.

Anyway, back to the important stuff: the food.  I had a sashimi duo, which is basically a platter of sashimi, rice, chicken katsu, rice, and miso soup - you know the standard Japanese fare. Overall the food was merely ok; nothing stood out.  I did like the ambiance though and its cleanliness goes a long ways.
author: David H.

description: We ordered a variety of nigiri here and it was absolutely delicious. The fish is super fresh. We were a bit disappointed with the rolls, which tasted like they came from a cheap sushi joint instead of a high end sushi restaurant. Service was very good.
author: Diana G.

description:
I was very excited to go to this restaurant and try it out! I am a huge sashimi and sushi fan and went for my birthday lunch.
I was disappointed by the food :/ I ordered the chef's special sashimi and it was ok. I expected better :( 
The restaurant was very cute and great for a date.
Also the service was just ok (but the hostess was great!). Me and my 2 girl friends were eating next to a couple that was treated significantly better because they were spending a lot of money on food and alcohol. I understand they want to please big spenders but it was to the point that we felt like we were not even there.

Recap: I was super excited to try this place out and I thought I would like it very much but that was not the case :/
author: Flo P.

description:
Great sushi place located right next to one of my most favorite bars, The Irish Bank.

But the Bank aside, this is a great place to have in your back pocket.

Sometimes I need my sushi fix.  And when I'm craving some quality Nigiri this is my destination.  They have AMAZING Nigiri.  Halibut I regularly die for. Tai that literally melts in your mouth.  And something I've only had here.  The Japanese Snapper is insane.  I dream about it.

I wish I could give them 4 or even 5 stars.  They're sushi quality is defintely deserving of such a high rating.  But unfortunately I have been here more than once (try like 3 times) where the service has been absolutely horrible.  Forgotten rolls - miso coming out at the end of the meal (wait what?). Management has always been gracious and understanding about comping things that just took INSANELY long to make their way to us.  But they need to improve their service.

I'll be back though, the sushi quality has me swimming back.

And there was that one time Tony Hawk was eating there while I was there, so if it's good enough for the Hawk man, well then it should be good enough for you!
author: Chelsea C.

description: This sushi was by far the best sushi I've ever tasted. The rolls I ordered were the rainbow and 49er. Something unique about everything I ordered. The Katsuo was so good, it literally melted in my mouth. I would recommend ordering that last. You do need to make a reservation though so don't just show up, they'll turn u away even though it looks dead. The iced tea was bomb too, but they do charge you for each drink. Totally worth it ;-)
author: vanessa c.

description: I've been to Akiko several times before and have always left the restaurant feeling hungry, even after spending $$$. Because of that I have to give it 3 stars. The fish is nice but very expensive. I don't mind dropping $$$ (and often do when it comes to sushi) but only if I leave feeling satisfied with the amount and quality of fish. You could get the same quality of fish elsewhere for cheaper.
author: Q C.

description: The service and food are always top notch here.  We have been here a few times and are never disappointed.  Husband had spring lamb and swoons over it every time.  Prawns, grape leaves and corn appetizers are so tasty!
author: Kate S.

description:
I cannot comment on the food at Akiko. This review is specifically addressing their hostess, who was working on April 5, 2013. My friend and I went to the restaurant and were met by a hostess who asked if we had a reservation and then, upon learning we didn't, asked if we wanted to be put on the waiting list. We asked her "how long is the wait?" A very common question. She answered that because it was sushi, she could not give us an exact time. I gestured to the many empty seats and asked about them-- she responded, "they're reserved." 

Then,  we asked her, if she could give us an approximate window. She said, "I think that approximate and exact are the same thing." I was astounded. I've eaten in some very nice restaurants in my time and I've never been met with such rudeness, poor customer service, or basic understanding of concepts like approximate vs. exact. In any other restaurant, the front staff have always been able to give us an approximate window, be it 30 min, 40 min, 2 hours...etc...  

I replied, "They're not the same thing. Check a Thesaurus." And we left. We went to Ramen Underground. It was good enough food sans attitude.
author: Julie H.

description:
Was looking for a good sushi place nearby the Financial District and even though I had to walk a ways to get here, I thought the sushi was very good and for a reasonable cost although I wouldn't call it cheap.

The rolls weren't particularly imaginative, but they were well done and tasty.  I had a simple California Roll, Dynamite Roll (nice and spicy) and some salmon nigiri with miso soup, all for about $29.  

The place was very busy for lunch, but I was able to sit right down at the bar.  It seemed like larger groups would have a hard time without a reservation.
author: Jared W.

description:
My favor Japanese restaurant, no others! 

Me and my husband travel to Japan at least 2-3 times a year, it's really hard to have the taste of Japanese food, I found it in Akiko!
author: Irene L.

description:
Went by one day for lunch and couldn't get in without a reservation; we managed to get a table this time without calling but the service was pretty slow.

The food was spectacular; we ordered enough food that I'm pretty sure we got the, "Damn, piggies," face from the waiter, but it was all great and we ended up eating most of it.  Great nigiri, excellent rolls, and the teriyaki were great.  The only thing I found less impressive was the tempura; a little heavy on the breading, a little greasy, and the vegetable tempura selection was a bit uninspired.
author: Adam H.

description:
Best sushi in the city! Just be warned that after eating here you won't be able to eat sushi anywhere else because they set the bar real high here. Do yourself a favor and make a reservation now!

Bring friends!!!
author: Mark C.

description: Just visited akikos for the second time last night and was again impressed. The fish is so fresh and beautifully presented. I definitely recommend getting the chef's selection, or, if you have time, the omakase. I've tried lots of things I'd never order or thought I didn't like. Last night Monkfish Liver was a nice creamy surprise. My only beef is that the place is not labeled so it's hard to spot. I kept walking past because I thought it was an Irish pub.
author: Valerie A.

description: Great casual/trendy sushi spot! fresh fish, nice presentation and the BEST amaebi I've ever had! Succulent tails lightly dressed and perfectly fried heads with sea salt and lemon. Add a Sapporo and it's perfect!
author: Rob H.

description:
Rolls are delicious and avg about 15 a roll.   Its worth the premium if you like the taste of fresh fish.  

I reccomend their sashimi bowl, rainbow roll, and volcano roll. 

   They add a citric taste to add a new flavor to their sushi.

Call in to reserve space.  It fills up quick
author: Fabe A.

description:
Really good restaurant, the fish couldn't have been more fresh. It was just delicious and not really expensive.
I highly recommend it. One of the best sushi place in town. 
Must try the Forty Niner and the Rainbow ;-)
author: Laure B.

description:
I went to Akiko's with the full expectation that it was to be a 'hipster'  sushi spot as noted by other reviewers here.

I was impressed by Akiko's freshness of food and, in all honestly, I felt the work here left a greater impression on me than that of Morimoto's in Napa.

I haven't explored a wide variety sushi places - but Akiko left me with a positive impression of what sushi can be.

My only requests are that the dishes could have explained with more detail (as was done with the couple next to me) and the menu could use a bit of reorganizing. I'd like a bit more written explanation as to what I was ordering so I didn't have to ask your server every new sushi eater question in the book (e.g. differences between Sake types, etc.). But, that being said, every waiter took their time in helping me make a decision.

I ate 1. A white tuna Sashimi. Solid and tasty enough on its own. 2. Tako nigiri (ocotpus with rice) - much less 'chewey' than other octopus I've ordered. The only pieces I added soy sauce to - but still greater. 3. Hibachi belly Tuna - super rich and tasty. A much 'buttery-er' version of the White Tuna I had previously. 4. The Waygu truffle nigiri.

I was left in shock and awe after the truffle+waygu combination... I'm not sure if there's anything much more indulgent in the world. As the chef said - it's one of their 'show stoppers'. If anything at all - come here for this. I was still in awe nearly 20 minutes after I had finished the meal because the Waygu truffle was truly that good. An 'umami' explosion of meat and truffle.... It was everything I wanted it to be and more...

I will come back to Akiko's. I want to leave my choices more up to the chef next time and explore more of what quality sushi is. 

Even though some people can perceive Akiko's as a 'hipster' spot - it remains dedicated to providing fresh sushi and excellent service. There are a lot of things here I don't think you would find on a typically sushi spot menu and I appreciated the effort that was put into every piece of sushi I ate.
author: Kyle M.

description:
The food is top-notch at this restaurant. The sushi is very fresh and well-prepared, and the tonkatsu chicken was cooked to perfection. Even their regular sake is the best I've tried in a long time. However, I agree with previous reviewers in that Akiko's service is slow, hence the one-star deduction. It took 15-20 minutes for our food to be served at lunch time on a Monday. Kind of ridiculous. I can only imagine what it's like at dinner.

In short, as long as you're in the area and not starving, I definitely recommend this place.
author: Ash V.

description: Good food and really good drinks. It's a good 'date night' spot. A little expensive but definitely worth trying their chefs tasting menu. Left STUFFED. Amazing quality of the fish, miso black cod was to die for, and the presentation was incredible. Check it out but be prepared for a hefty bill.
author: Mike L.

description:
Came here for our 6 year anniversary, and we are sooo glad we did!

Service here is awesome!  Be sure to make a reservation before you go; I don't think they allow walk-ins.  I came a little earlier to bring a surprise cake for my girlfriend and they were kind enough to store it in the back for later.

We came in and were promptly seated.  The ambiance is pretty nice; it's kind dark, with little candles lining the wall.  Atmosphere isn't too loud, which we likes.

For our meal, we ordered:
-1 4-piece Nigiri with Udon
-1 4-piece Sashimi with Beef Teriyaki
-1 Kani-age (soft shell crab)
-1 Rock n' Roll

The sashimi/nigiri is oh-my-god fresh.  I used to not really tell/care since it's all food to me but wow... after coming here, there really is a huge difference.  There might be better, but I ain't paying for that.  This place is good enough.  Fish is nice and lean and just melts in your mouth in such a yummy yummy way.  Love love love it.  Girlfriend even thought it was good enough to finish ALL of hers :)  She normally eats just the salmon, and passes the rest to me but she liked 'em this time.

The udon is kinda standard, but it was huuuuuuge.  Pretty darn good, seeing as it wasn't super salty.  My beef teriyaki was nice too.  Came with a little bowl of rice, but it was filling enough.  The Rock n' Roll was pretty good too!  Girlfriend looooooves unagi so this was a perfect fit.  Nice big pieces of unagi, and the sushi pieces themselves were really big.  The Kani-age was alright; I think it could use a little more flavor, but I don't order this dish enough to compare and see if it's good or bad.

When we finished the meal, the guy came out with the cake, and my girlfriend was suuuuprised :)  They didn't even need me to signal or anything.  Super awesome peeps.  It was a $2 cake fee, but who cares.  They did it perfectly and I couldn't ask for more.

This place is super duper yummy, super duper awesome, and super duper wonderful.  Highly recommended :)  It's not out of this world expensive, but it's a super good value.  Love this place!
author: Filmer Y.

description: Rolls are all fine, though we did not love the yellowtail. Sake (salmon) roll has changed - miss the tastier original. The udon is good here, as is the service.
author: Dennis W.

description:
Place a small. But the decor is very fresh and clean
 We sat by the door not a good idea since it's cold today. Food was great. Good size portions. I would say the only thing con is that they have no signs in front.
author: Max J.

description: I am usually not a fan of japanese food since I don't really like raw fish but I tried it there and it was awesome. Really good nigiri, I also recommend the 49ers rolls. Surprised by how good the wasabi was too! This is fresh food. The only negative point might be the service which was not really fast but still ok. It might be a bit expensive but the food is of quality.
author: Antonin A.

description: Best sushi in this neighborhood by far for a work lunch that doesnt break the bank!!! Mega fan
author: Lilia D.

description:
This is the best sushi place in SF. I give this place a five stars because of the good food this place got. I came here for dinner with my friends and I was introduced to whole new varieties of fish. I was never a fan of salmon but Akiko's salmon is so fresh here. All of their sashmi are really fresh! I've almost tried some of the rolls here as wells. And the best rolls of them all is the Firecracker! This roll is so good,its like putting fire in your mouth. Oh yeah, their salmon roll are pretty good here too. The California roll here are made of real crab meat which is really good. OH! Their hand rolls are really good here. Man, let's just say this place got great foods!!

I would definitely come back here for the fresh sashmi!!

I would recommend the tuna salad, salmon rolls, and if you guys like spicy food then the Firecracker is the best!
author: Nhung C.

description:
This is one of the better sushi restaurants I've been to in the city. The place isn't huge, and I'd strongly recommend making a reservation so you can get right in. My friends and I started with a bottle of cold sake, and ordered some edamame and a bunch of rolls. I'd suggest the following rolls to order as they were extremely delicious:

-spicy tuna
-firecracker
-49er roll

We also ordered a couple other basic rolls and everything was really good. This place does fresh fish well, and didn't disappoint. The sushi chef was friendly and said goodbye to us when we walked out feeling quite satisfied.

Prices were very decent with rolls ranging from $6-$16 or so.
author: Ashley D.

description: Expensive and tiny sushi rolls. Environment is decent but it's really loud in there so if you want a quiet place to eat at then stay out.  Can find better sushi elsewhere.
author: Dionna T.

description: Great sushi rolls, great ambience, and great presentation, however service was a bit slow when I went at lunch time, not sure how it is during dinner.
author: Katherine L.

description:
This is a gem of a restaurant tucked away near Union Square. Went there for dinner and set ourselves up by the sushi bar, giving us ample opportunity to watch the food being prepared. We ordered omakase, which pretty much give the sushi chef free reign to pick whatever he thinks will hit the spot (though you can give him tips on what kind of things you like/want to try). 

The food was great, all made with fresh ingredients and explained to us by the chef himself. Had a great meal with tasty food, good service and a nice ambiance - would definitely go back.
author: Anil P.

description: My daughter highly recommended this place for my birthday. They did not have / ran out  any yellow tail that night - a Friday night at 6.15 PM. I was extremely disappointed...!!  Anyway, my daughter ordered the scallop sashimi, the Santa Barbara Uni, red snapper sashimi and mackerel  sashimi for me. The texture were perfect enough to melt in my mouth. My family ordered some rolls, they looked  fresh and my family said they were good. This place's prices seemed in line with the other bay area restaurants, however, it was still too pricey for the food portion.
author: Rita L.

description: We have been this restaurant twice so far. The second time was on the New Year's Eve. They had a special course for the New Year's Eve. We were served 13+ special, scrumptious and  fresh dishes. Needless to say the course was a very expensive, (thank you, darling) but they surely served the unforgettable dishes. Services were good as well.
author: Akiko M.

description:
brilliant omakase. no one can deny that the boys here know their stuff, from source to cut to flavor to plate. 

careful not to mistake, though, this place is top of the line! get ready to appreciate that incredible quality! $$$$

thank you, akiko's!
author: Alice L.

description: Amazing sushi, I recommend the chefs choice. I loved the black tuna and monkfish liver.
author: Misty W.

description:
Thanks Yelpers for the fantastic recommendation!

This was some of the most complex and interesting-tasting sushi I've had in a long time. The restaurant is beautiful, the service was great and the prices were reasonable ... for sushi.

My out-of-town guests were totally impressed.
author: Kim C.

description: I would say 4.5 stars.  I hate to give 5's but chef Jeff and his selections were great.  Sit at the bar and let him surprise you.  All very simple, understated where the emphasis is on great seafood.  I loved it all and with little fanfare.  I highly recommend.
author: Tim M.

description:
Dinner
Food: A+ - fresh, fabulous, high quality
Price: A - Excellent
Menu: B+ - traditional Japanese sushi restaurant
Service: B
Atmosphere: A - cool, hip, tight
author: JM H.

description: Came here to celebrate my birthday and 1st time here last night!  OMG!  I cannot wait to come back here!  I had the 6 piece nigiri and everything was just delicious, fresh, and melted in my mouth.  The 49er roll was super delicious and the other nigiri was amazing!  My friend and I especially loved the sake nigiri, tai nigiri, shiro maguro, and the shiro toro nigiri.  I would pass on the beni toro (seared salmon belly) -- it was ok but nothing to write home about.
author: M. T.

description:
Absolutely BEAUTIFUL. 

My boyfriend took my on a date here, had flowers brought to the table when we sat down (very nice touch that the restaurant offers that), and they sat us tucked away in the back as to keep us away from the noise.

The decor was classy. By far the best sushi I have had in this city.  
Perfect place for a date
author: Myoko S.

description: I went here with a good friend for lunch.  Food was only ok, not sure why people like it that much.  It's probably because there aren't very many good choices for good Japanese food in the FiDi.  Their omakase was $100, so I didn't order it.  I'd rather go to Kusakabe to pay that much (which also wasn't worth the money - see my other review).  Overlal, just average, not great. We went to Super Duper for an ice cream after because we were still hungry.
author: Sophie H.

description: Ordered mackerel, beef and one roll, bill was over $80! Overpriced and average flavors. Service, not terrible but not great. When the father owned this restaurant the quality and portions for the price were much better. I wanted to place an order to go, while dining, for my co-worker and was told they don't do takeout (?). Portions were so skimpy I had to buy lunch again later at L&L - a much better value for the money. I won't be returning to Akikos.
author: Derek T.

description:
Extensive menu full of delicious choices, fresh fish at normal sf sushi prices, good service, and a chic yet intimate atmosphere.  I had a great lunch here with a good friend and we were able to have a conversation in relative peace and ate some really good sushi.
I would easily come back here.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Damn good sushi! The fish & rolls were super fresh, and the sake was fantastic (Sayuri sake - check it out). We dropped in around 6:30pm, and even though we didn't have reservations, we were seated promptly. This place is perfect for couples, because it's a small space with tables spaces made for two, and it has a great ambiance (I was impressed with the music and the overall vibe of the place). 

We started with the seaweed salad and the miso soup, which were both really good - the ginger dressing on the salad was the best. My husband had the uni (sea urchin) which was fresh from Santa Barbara, and he loved it. We then had three rolls (Volcano, Spider, and Dynamite or Firecracker -  not sure which, but it was really spicy and delish). We ended up taking half of it home. 

The only reason why I give it four stars is because of the service. Our waiter wasn't very attentive towards the end, but I could tell that he was pretty busy, and the other waiters made up for it by taking up our plates and cleaning the table when we were finished. We ended up paying cash because we were ready to bounce by the end of the meal, and our server was with other peeps (and ignoring us). I would highly suggest trying this place out if time is not an issue.  Sushi = 5 star, service = 3 star.
author: Nicole W.

description:
I loved this place!!

While on the smaller side, it's a perfect place for a date or friend reunion. It's warm and cozy and decor is friendly. Yes, decor can be described that way. 

What's even better is that the food is good and the prices are decent. I thought I'd blow my wallet on sushi downtown, but actually I did not! The Firecracker roll was only around $12, and it was a big portion of sushi. I couldn't really breathe after eating it because it was so spicy but that was fine. Friends got delicious rolls as well (lion king, etc.). 

Would definitely come here again! 

The only downside is there is no large sign (or at least I didn't notice one) outside so I thought the place didn't exist for a while...
author: Adele Z.

description:
Tried: Sashimi 7 piece combo, spider roll, volcano roll, miso and wakame. 

YUMMMMMMMMM. Fish is fresh and melts in your mouth!

Its a nice lunch spot in the financial district. Its definitely one of the better sushi spots in the area but it can get a bit pricey.
author: Amy S.

description:
hm, not bad in that it was easy access in the FiDi area but bad that it was expensive for someone who forgot their wallet that day.

My fave for the poor-at-the-moment was the shioyaki saba:  mackerel broiled in the oven with a salt rub.  The fish was salty but very tender (an oily fish) and savory.  With a little soy sauce, it was perfect paired with their equally fresh and vibrant white rice.  The grains squeaked between my teeth..........signs that it was not too done, or undone.

Sushi is mediocre.....the arrogance in me makes a note that I've had better elsewhere in the city.  Service is pretty bad, but from what I remembered, service in Japan was slow motion too.  Unless I was in their token French restaurant and the dish cost $50: service was pretty inventive then!

Had to stop here, because my sister's name is Akiko

(^_^)
author: Miika M.

description: This spot is quite the gem in the middle between the Financial District and the edge of Downtown SF. There are two locations and this is the best one! It is far from being a whole in the wall; though it's hard to find. The quality of the sushi and sashimi is so fresh. The tempura is fried to perfection. I almost feel like I'm in a small Japanese sushi house.
author: Em G.

description:
For me, a 5 star dining experience is a culmination of small great experiences all throughout the meal that makes it an everlasting memory for life.

I am all about intimate cozy restaurants.  It lends a feel of closeness and family.  I immediately feel comfortable.  There are maybe 10 tables top, but without any hesitation, my date and I head directly to the chef's bar.  

Since this was my 1st sushi restaurant in San Francisco, and my date, who I met the evening before, definitely wanted to show me the best.  We introduce ourselves to the chef, and both blurt out "Omikase!"  Let the gastronomic whirlwind begin!

A bottle of daiginjo sake arrives while we watch our chef masterfully prepares our 1st course.  Smooth and earthy.. kampai.  

- tuna seaweed salad.  Very good and fresh.  I've had similar before and this was just as good.  But this is where my previous sushi experiences pale in comparison....

- Sake Toro (fatty salmon).  This salmon is rare.  Only 1 in 10,000 will meet this mark.  Typical salmon have a fat content of 10-15%, whereas sake toro is between 45-50%.  Completely out of this world!!  The taste and texture is completely different than regular salmon.  

- White tuna toro.  This is what "melt in your mouth" texture is judged against.  To try to explain the flavor in words is like trying to explain the experience of skydiving.  You just have to experience it.

From the special bay uni, to the Kushi oysters, to the genuine freshly grated wasabi, everything was pure, fresh, clean.  Akiko has spoiled me for a sushi experience.  5 stars!
author: John Y. C.

description:
Came here for an early dinner w/ my co-workers. The place was empty at 5:30pm on a Thursday night, but quickly filled up as the evening progressed. I absolutely loved the cozy and dimly lit atmosphere here. It's very romantic and a great place to take a date, although it could get a bit loud since all the tables are situated so closely together.

The 6 of us shared the: Volcano roll, Firecracker Roll, Dragon Roll, 49er roll, Spicy Tuna maki and some edemame. 

Standouts were Volcano Roll and Firecracker. Both had a good spicy kick to it.

Pros: 
1. Very cute atmosphere. From the plates and glasses they use to the decor (awesome wall artwork and candles everywhere!)
2. Attentive service
3. Fish was fresh
4. Rolls creative

Cons:
1. Expensive (Volcano roll was $14, small bowl of miso soup $2.50!)

The bill came out to be about $20 per person after tax and tip. Not too bad, except i was hungry again at 9pm. :( All in all, this is one of the better sushi places i've tried in downtown SF, so do check it out when you're nearby and in the mood for some good fish.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
