I was here last night with the girls.  We got the best seat in the house!  We arrived at 6:30, and were seated right by the window.  It's a great place for people watching.

The food was delicious.  I got the Firecracker Sushi.  They ran out of plum wine, but I would love to try it next time. 
 
The server was extremely attentive in the beginning; he checked on us three times, we took a lil too long to decide what we were having.  But when it started getting crowded, it started getting hard for them to keep up.  It took a little too long to get our check.

Overall a great experience,  I will definitely go here again.
author: Anoo L.

description: I went here for a business lunch--out of town friends/colleagues at a meeting and I am always scrambling for a place to go in this area, since I don't go to this part of the city often. However, a friend who seems to always have insider knowledge said good things about this place. I wondered, because I had heard that it was run by people from Taiwan. It has been my own experience that non-Japanese Asians have different tastes than someone like me, who was weaned on my grandmother's Japanese cooking. But it is always good to keep an open mind (open palate?). This place did not disappoint. First off, it is tough to find. There doesn't appear to be a sign out in front, but I spotted it by the diners near the front windows eating tasty looking Japanese food! The interiors are lovely, decorated more in a 1930s Shanghai style with a modern twist, than traditional Japanese. The food was delicious! The fish was first rate quality, but more importantly, the sashimi was prepared properly (ie, cut properly to maximize flavor and texture--yes, there is an art and technique to this. It isn't just about getting out a ginzu knife and slicing away any which way). My friends wanted the hamachi kama, which was delicious and perfectly broiled. The meat was not at all dry. Nice sake selection. Sushi was perfect, although I would prefer to just eat sashimi (raw fish only, without sushi rice) at a place like this! Service was prompt, efficient and courteous, even on what may have been a typical packed lunch crowd. However, I would skip the agedashi tofu. Nothing special, and they served it in tiny squares with more of a katsu coating (bread crumbs) than batter. Still tasty and perfectly season sauce, though. We also ordered mixed greens, which I had hoped would be oshitashi (parboiled leafy greens, pressed and served with a soy sauce based dressing) but was instead a basic mixed greens salad (also tasty, but nothing special).  The only disappointment was that the staff did not seem to know how to pronounce menu items correctly--or did they intentionally mispronounce items so that the mostly non-Japanese customers would understand?
author: 和子

description:
Akiko's is one good sushi restaurant. Tasty food. Great look. Could be even better...

Love the seaweed salad. Love the rolls, especially the Rock & Roll. 

Wish the service was a bit more attentive, the bathroom needs a freakin mirror above the sink, and for Pete's sake, they should buy hand towels. (Drying your hands on a clean toilet seat cover is sanitary but completely ludicrous.)

All in all, a lovely little place to go. Perhaps someone will read my review and make it perfect!
author: Wendy W.

description: Everything was perfect. Ray was our server and he was so helpful and knew so much about the menu and current offerings. I think that I may have found my go-to sushi place in SF.
author: H. M.

description: F'en terrific.  Been to tons of sushi places in SF both good and bad, but Akiko's is by far the best.  We had a short wait despite reservation.  Hostess was kind enough to provide us some hot sake to whet our appetites.  After a short 10 minutes, we settled into our bar seats and told the chef to fire away.  Crab salad, mackerel, halibut, sea bass, shrimp, uni ...  Everything was delicious and it was a blast to watch the guys make sushi.  I will gladly eat here again (as soon as I get my finances back in order).  This place is super expensive, but well worth the cost.  Special thanks to Chef Jin, who made the evening a success for me and my wife.
author: Robert C.

description: Good sushi. Reasonable prices. Loved their oyako donburi. Egg wasn't overcooked, but just the way I like it- slightly runny. Favorite roll was the vivi. Spicy tuna was good too- not creamy like most.
author: Sophia B.

description: Tried their Nigiri tasting menu, tamago, scallops and seared salmon belly. highly recommend this place - even in comparison to some of south bay's best sushi places (sushi sam's), this place does not disappoint. i will definitely be going back to this place.
author: Karen K.

description:
Dinner at Akiko's was the BEST MEAL I had in San Francisco!

I loved everything about our dinner. We walked in and sat at the bar, the sushi chef/owner Joe-san had the biggest smile on his face the entire night! I loved his energy!! After chatting with him I found out that the place is run by himself as the sushi chef, his wife working the kitchen, and his boys as front staffs. So cute!

As for the food.. we started with the 5 pcs chefs recommendation (Omakase). which is such a good deal!! it's $20!! hello?? Where can you find $20 omakase?? 

Joe-san made us a yamaimo (Japanese mountain yam) appetizer dressed with yuzu vinegar on a bed of mixed greens. So very refreshing! Then our sushi was served.. With every sushi, he does something different to it. Some he adds some ponzu, some he'd sear, he also has a sweet soy he puts on that is absolutely delicious! Of course, the ones whom should be left alone, he does not mess with! 

He's so careful and detailed with the sushi.. it's truly an art! Everything he did was to enhance the flavor of the fish, and to bring out the perfect balance. Every bite was a little piece of heaven in my mouth! (drools as i type away.. )

We also tried to volcano roll that was highly recommended by fellow yelpers. It was indeed very delish! It reminds me of orange chicken in a good way. I love how they make unique rolls, but also make the perfect traditional nigiri sushi. 

Also, Joe-san was so generous and made us several special dishes to go with my sake! He made a special shrimp ceviche dish that was to die for!! It's mixed with avocado and dressed in sesame oil and some other Asian seasoning.. you eat it with some fried wonton chips.. OHHH my it's soo good! n he made us a grilled yellowtail belly that melts in your mouth.. 

I made a promise to myself that from now on, every time I visit San Francisco I will dine at Akiko. They're my new found family in North Cal.. 

OH! and gotta mention, price is VERY reasonable.. please go and let Joe-san take you on an exciting party in your tummy!!! :)
author: Ann C.

description: Worth the visit.  It's a little hard to find so  just look for the address cause there is no sign.  Warm atmosphere and kind, attentive staff.   Great sashimi and nigiri.  Definitely recommend.
author: David W.

description:
Very fresh fish, creative rolls, friendly service.  

We came here on a double date with friends and were charmed by the interesting decor and impressed by the food. 

We ordered a spread of sushi to share, including the tasty firecracker roll, sake nigiri, and two types of hamachi nigiri. The sushi was extremely fresh, buttery and flavorful. For my entree, I ordered the chirashi sushi. The sashimi was really good but it was one of the more disappointing chirashis that I have had; only about 6 pieces of sashimi, a bit of wakame salad and a sprinking of tobiko over sushi rice. 

My dinner companions all ordered udon and were very satisifed with their dishes. 

This restaurant has daily sashimi and sushi specials, some flown in from the famed Tsukiji Fish Market in Japan. Not bad for a hole-in-the-wall restaurant near Union Square.
author: Jenny K.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here with my boyfriend, was impressed by the food and atmosphere but not the service. Got served sake before water, ended up asking multiple times for water.
author: Dana M.

description:
... not too sure about this place...

The people were really nice, got there at 11:50am so I beat the lunch rush on a Wednesday so I got seated right away, but the service was really slow.  Took us a long time to get 2 rolls and a sashimi place.  Had to ask for my tea a few times before I got it =(

But the food was good... I'll be willing to come back but probably not during the lunch rush.
author: Lynda N.

description: Service was slow when I came here. The fish quality was great, but service really made it hard to focus on the food. Definitely grab a reservation before coming here.
author: Ami D.

description:
I came here for my birthday just last night with 8 other friends and I must say Akiko's is AMAZING. They provided such great service and they worked with me to create a custom birthday menu that included amazing sashimi, rolls, nigiri, and other delicious items. Halfway down the menu for the night my friends and I were STUFFED. But we kept eating because it was so good.

Seriously, some of the best sushi I've had in San Francisco and am so glad to have tried out this place! The fish was great quality. Fresh, buttery, and yummy. Normally I end up eating somewhere in the mission or I go to other sushi places that are really good, but I wanted to check this place out. So happy i did!

The chef came out to greet us after the meal and they all sang happy birthday to me as well! What a great night. Am definitely coming back here as often as I can. Highly recommend this place to anyone. I'm a big foodie and so are my friends. You won't be disappointed here!

Thank you Tony and Ray for helping me create such a great menu and serving delicious food.
author: Yvonne C.

description: My favorite sushi place in San Francisco. Definitely need a reservation. Their miso soup is amazing. The sushi and sashimi is marvelous. Service is OK. Highly recommend the forty nine roll - yes, its not "real" sushi. Get it
author: Dave G.

description: I think food is good. But their service level is not something I appreciate.  I had a reservation, and there was no table ready on the time.  The waitress told me "there's a table (gesturing to point the back of the restaurant) that is paying now, so it will be 10 min.  Or you can take a counter seat."  I said I can wait.  Then 20 minutes after, the waitress was suggesting the table in front of the entrance, where there was a couple a few minutes ago sitting and they moved to somewhere in the back.  That's just rude, but I didn't wanna wait any longer so I took it, but I won't probably go again.  There are enough many Japanese restaurants in the city.
author: Takashi M.

description:
Stumbled upon this place for dinner with 2 girlfriends around 6pm on a Friday night. We were seated immediately at a table that's reserved for 7:30pm so the waiter straight up said we have to eat fast.

Aside from the first waiter blatantly telling us to eat fast, the service was great. We got water immediately and after we got a pot of hot tea, waiters came and helped us refill our cups. We didn't order a lot of plates overall, only 3 rolls. We got the Spider, Rainbow and VV and they were all noms. Props to the sushi chef b/c he rolled them tight, none of the pieces fell apart for any of us. The fish on the rainbow was super fresh too. The plates were also presentable and the prices were not too bad considering the location and atmosphere. The sushi rolls averaged $10 per roll. I have to say I left hungry since the three of us shared three rolls. I think if you want to have a decent meal, expect to pay around $30 per person after tip and tax.

Definitely make a reservation because it seems like everyone else had one. The restaurant isn't very big, a front section with tables for twos and fours, and a back section with more tables. I definitely want to come back here to try the sashimi. Also forgot to mention, the waiters here are pretty cute IMO. At least ours was when his eyes disappear whenever he smiles... yes, I want to go again to look at them eye candies. ;)
author: Lucy D.

description:
Tasked with finding a delectable sushi dinner in Union Square I was surprised to find that my options were somewhat limited. I was lucky to land a reservation for three at Akiko's the night before our dinner. I didn't quite know how lucky until I arrived to find a sign on the door signaling that if I didn't have a reservation I was out of luck because the restaurant was fully booked for the evening.

The atmosphere is positively adorb, with stylized cherry blossoms on the wall. The fish was incredibly fresh, the selection lovely (escolar!). Don't miss the crab and cucumber salad - wowza that was yummy. 

The service was super accommodating, letting us check in late for the reservation (two of our party ended up at a different akikos) and then bringing us 3 pieces for the nigiri instead of two so everyone would have one to try. Sometimes we felt a smidge abandoned at the front of the restaurant, but nothing egregious (perhaps I felt moreso because I was incredibly dehydrated and needed my water glass refilled often).

Finished off the meal with a dish of black sesame ice cream for me, green tea ice cream for MB and a Dynamite roll for MB's bro, PB.
author: Sarah T.

description:
This is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants.  I've been here on multiple occasions and the food is always great!  My usual order:

Tempura Udon - love the soup base! udon is just the right amount of chewiness and is always cooked to perfection.  Occasionally the tempura is deep fried a little too much but still is good (4stars)

Volcano Roll - absolutely the best roll ever!  It's the most unique roll ever, whenever I go to other places and order a volcano roll, it's nothing like Akiko's.  Akiko's is way better!  It's topped with crispy tempura bits and has a yummy spicy sauce.  I can eat a whole roll by myself but that would leave no room for my udon.  (5stars)

Shiro Toro Nigiri - love this!  they put a little of green onion on it, makes it so much yummier!  (5 stars)

Service typically is on the slow side, but if you're not in a hurry - this is not a problem :)  The wait staff is really nice but sometimes it's hard to get their attention.
author: Veronica N.

description:
The food is very, very good.  Fresh, flavorful fish with excellent presentation.  Based on reviews from Yelp, we had the Firecracker and Volcano in addition to an interesting vegetarian roll and sashimi.

The service left much to be desired, but they recognized we were frustrated with empty wine glasses and forgotten orders and comped us a drink.  I think acknowledging the mistake is notable.

Akiko's has the potential to rate five stars, but the service needs to improve before they get there.

The quality of the food definitely made the meal worthwhile and we will return again and hope to add more stars to the review.
author: Ruth R.

description:
This place is awesome!

All the sushi is very fresh and delicious!
Appetizer was just normal, don't try Gyoza.
author: Jikhan J.

description: This is by far the BEST sushi restaurant in the city that I have come across yet. And I will update my yelp reviews if I find something better. The fish is fresh and tasty. The rolls are phenomenal. The service could be friendlier and more accommodating however you can get past it once you receive your dish. The restaurant is small and space is limited so call for a reservation!
author: Ajna V.

description:
This place is delish!!

We went here today for a coworker's 40's birthday celebration based on Yelp! reviews and the proximity to the office.  They were able to accommodate a large group reservation made last minute, and had the table ready and waiting for us upon our arrival.  

The food was really good and fresh.  The decor was neat.  The rolls were presented nicely.  They were friendly, although looked to be a bit understaffed as we waited often to get attention.  

The prices here are decent ~ not quite your everyday lunch place price but you also don't need an expense account to go here. I can't wait to go back here again for another special occasion lunch!
author: Cindy C.

description:
Pretty tasty japanese place right next to the Chinatown gates.  Not too pricey either.  $22 omakase sushi was pretty good.  I didn't leave full, even with additional appetizers, but the sushi was good.

Note to the owners: Please fix the bathroom door! We sat in the back near it, and the draft from the bathroom was horrible! Other than that, the ambiance was good.
author: Mas M.

description:
Nothing about the lunch experience was better than your average sushi spot, but the price would suggest otherwise.  The decor is cool, but the servers gave the impression that they were so slammed that they took away from the overall experience.

Unfortunately, with so many other options in the area, I can't say I'll make a point of coming back.
author: Mike D.

description: First time here we shared a sashimi platter and sake. The sashimi and sake were some of the best I've had in a very long time. Second time here we ordered rolls. The service took quite a while and the rolls were of just average quality. Will definitely be returning but will stick to the sashimi (so fresh!) instead of the rolls.
author: Sophie K.

description: Well, it doesn't have Unagi don for lunch and Chirashi was $30.00. Definitely not cheap and the price was different from what it showed online. I got a seat at sushi bar. The sushi chef was super nice and friendly. And cute :P. The 49er roll was so yummy. I love the hint of pepper flavor in it. And big big thumbs up for lemon slices. It's a great place for date, but not for working lunch especially when your lunch break is only half hour :(
author: Jady Z.

description:
This place is soo good and the service is really friendly.

We came here for lunch and found the fish super fresh.  The entrees and rolls, though not particularly as inventive as other places, still had the excellent fish going for it.  I thoroughly enjoyed my lychee saketini.  Twice.  Good sake selection.

This place was full and people were waiting out the door.  I recommend making an OpenTable reservation.

I will definitely come back for more sashimi!
author: Lynnie P.

description: Dish was so excellent,Friendly staffs and Thanks to Rayloved this place! Compact cozy place
author: Jane R.

description: This is NOT the fun, upbeat sushi atmosphere we were looking for. After trying to find the place for 10 minutes (there is literally not one sign out front) we finally wandered in to a very confused looking hostess when we asked, "is this Akikos?"  This restaurant is VERY small, literally 8 tables lined against a wall. You are so close to the table next to you, you might as well start talking to them because they can hear your whole conversation. The food was good, fresh fish, but very plain, bland rolls. I would not recommend this place for a fun night out..... Or for an intimate dinner.
author: Jessica L.

description: My goodness. One of the best Japanese restaurants I've been to. My friend was raving about this place, and I didn't believe it until I actually went and tried it for myself. It is THE bomb. Their fish is so fresh and tastes incredibly clean! And knowing that Akiko's big on sustainably caught fish - two thumbs up - tastes even better. We got standard rolls like the rainbow roll and rock n' roll but those in itself tasted really good - fresh and the flavors were just right. We also got white tuna and wow, it melted in my mouth... so freaking good. Their restaurant-brewed soy sauce was perfect for dipping - the right amount of flavor and not too salty. I definitely recommend their special sashimi - we got 3 different types - not exactly sure of the names but they were all imported straight from Japan. Very unique and very fresh. We also got a hamachi head and the fish was cooked perfectly, and it was served with a light ponzu sauce for perfection. The service was also impeccable. Our server Alan knew exactly how to meet our needs and when the kitchen ran out of certain items (because we came late at night), he gave us similar suggestions right away. He was super friendly and definitely embodied the true spirit of service. Can't wait to come back Akiko's!
author: Naomi S.

description:
i'm writing this review so late.
i went here i think around august (i forgot somewhere around that time). 
since i don't really remember what i ordered, this place didn't wowed me. the part i would remember would be the price is on the pricey side for the portion and quality. the rolls were o-k. if i remember correctly, the fish i think was not fishy, which is good. the appetizers i ordered didn't really wowed me either, we had agedashi tofu and the fried ika, it was nothing special to me. this 3 star rating is really for the price and the portion and the most part, food was not that memorable for my tastebuds. I have very high expectations for sushi, and this place was just ok. i would probably rather order chirashi sushi here rather than rolls.
*this review is strictly based on the food
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
I like this place.  It's my first time dining at Akiko.  The ambiance is very soothing, cozy and yet sophisticated.  

I felt everything was finely prepared and presented, but as for quality of the sashimi, I need to go back and try a few more varieties in order to be more accurate on my review for this restaurant.  Two big disppointments I had with them are 1)they were out of the grilled Hamachi Kama and 2) the Chef's sashimi combo only came with tuna and salmon.  I was anticipating more varieties.  

The service was very good and the ambience is very elegant.  I would recomend that you call before you dine at the restaurant to be sure they have what you like in stock.
author: Gina W.

description: Best sushi hands down. Verrry cute ambiance. Made accommodations to my reservation. Wasn't too busy on a Friday night. Definite sushi spot when I make my way to the city.
author: Ariel T.

description:
I already had a preconception that there weren't any good sushi restaurants around downtown San Francisco. I had came to this acceptance because I've never given a recommendation to any, which prevented lazy me from trying out any myself. 

I was craving sushi, so I decided to rely on Yelp to steer me in the right direction. This was the winning pick, as it was close enough to me and had sufficient reviews. 

We did not have reservations, but when we arrived around 6:45pm it was pretty empty. The decor very modern and had a hint of fancy dancy-ness, but when I scanned the prices on the menu I thought it was reasonable. I would say it's a nice place for a date. 

My bf and I shared the Spider roll, Firecracker roll, and a Chicken Katsu Donburi. The Spider roll was good; I like the use of soy paper in lieu of nori and the softshell crab was crispy. The Firecracker was spicy! but additively so; It was flash fried so there was a thin crunchy crust and the flavors worked well. I can't handle spicy, but still managed to eat almost half of the order. The Chicken Katsu was on the pricier side, but the chicken was moist. It was good, but not worth $11 (unless they provided another piece of chicken, THEN it'd be a good order). 

Overall this place gives me hope that there is indeed some good sushi restaurants around the city. And I am excited to finally make an effort to go try more out myself.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
If there was a way to give 4-1/2 stars, that is what I would give Akiko's but that would only be due to the environment. Let's be clear: this is some of the finest if not the finest sushi I have ever had. That includes Tokyo and Kyoto cities too.

I, too, passed right by the restaurant. The storefront is understated and easy to miss. I walked in and the other reviews are correct: the place is small! Loud too, mostly due to the hard walls and ceiling. The place was totally full although there was one 2-seat table open. Curiously, they said I had to wait and then 10 minutes later they put me at that open table!

Happy to get seated after a long day of flying, I opened the cold sake menu and was delighted by the choices. A minor complaint: the menu font was small and printed in grey and with the low light level, I had to use the candle lamp on the table to read with my old eyes. Prices for the sake were a little steep but there were a number of reasonably priced sakes of good quality. 

Service was a bit frenetic and slow but eventually they came by my table, tucked into the front corner, and took my order. The hostess didn't write it down and it my order was a bit extensive and I figured she would forget something and she did. I had ordered one of the rolls but let me tell you, I am glad they forgot it because the choices of fish were so varied, it left me more room to try them!

Shrimp tempura appetizer was typical. Good and delicious but not a standout. Then the hamachi sashimi came out and it was superb and I marveled at the subtle flavor and buttery texture. The temperature was perfect. If this is what the rest of my meal would be, I was in for a treat.

Uni, unagi, shiro maguro...a mature yellowtail I have never had before...it was all exceedingly fresh, perfectly prepared and absolutely delicious. This is why I was happy they forgot the roll...although they looked delicious, I wanted to try some of the other fish on the menu. One of the servers, Joseph, came by and asked how the food was and needless to say, I expounded on the subject. Turns out the sushi chef, a mature and jolly-faced fellow, has been a sushi chef since age 13. That man makes this restaurant; His knowledge and selection of only the finest quality fish results in a dining experience that is unmatched. 

Joseph went on to recommend some ocean farmed fatty tuna (toro) and it was superb. Turns out the chef is very concerned about tuna sustainability and buys direct from one of the farmers in Japan. 

I cannot see any reason this place deserves less than 4 stars. If you give it less, you simply don't know sushi or are responding to the size or ambiance of the restaurant. I wish the sushi bar was bigger so I could have sat in front of the chef and just had him toss whatever he thought I would like my way! 

After another sake, it was time to go and I went to the bar to give my compliments to the chef. The bill was moderate ($100), but for the quality a bargain in my experience. I have had $150 bills (for one person) in New York and Tokyo and although those places were good, they are measurably  below the quality of Akiko's.

 I am still searching my past experiences to see if any can compare to Akiko and I cannot come up with any that is better. I look forward to my next trip to SFO so I can again partake of this chef's art.
author: Jorge d.

description:
Thanks to Yelp for introducing me to this place. I took my parents and we all really enjoyed it. Pricey (but not crazy), with very nice service, and everything was very charmingly presented and very fresh. The fish was really good, and I got to try kinds I've never seen before at the cheap-o strip mall sushi I usually go to (which has its time and place). 

We got the 12 piece sashimi, dynamite roll (very good, filling, fried spicy tuna roll), beef teriyaki (really lovely), and chocolate mochi. 

I think it's a great place to take dates, parents (if they're game) and best friends.

The restaurant is both cozy and loud at the same time. Reservations are a must for dinnertime. A real treat.
author: Rach T.

description:
I have been here twice now and both times I was blown away by the food.  I definitely recommend going the sushi route as all the fish is super tasty.  But if you are in the mood for something else, the Udon is also pretty darn fantastic.

I am more than willing to walk, take BART, and then walk some more to get my sushi fix here.
author: Jessica M.

description:
This place is terrible! 

I would be willing to give the food a second chance, but you couldnt pay me to deal with that service! 

A friend and I went for lunch and I wanted something filling. We ordered some edamame from who we thought was our waiter, to snack on while we waited.15 minutes later, when it still didnt come, we flagged someone down to ask. Our waiter came out 5 minutes after that with edamame. 1 minute after that, my food came out. Nobody said anything about my buddy's food, they just dropped my plate off and left. 10 minutes after that, his food came out. 

My salmon was fishy, small and cooked unevenly. The pyramid of rice was about two tablespoons of rice. The tempura tasted like it was previously frozen and a couple of pieces were burned to a crisp on the end. 

My buddy got 5 piece nigiri and when it finally arrived, he said it was tasty. He also got chicken teriyaki and the chicken was weird dark meat nuggets. He said it was alright, but it tasted a little weird. 

So we are about 35-40 minutes in when we finish our meal. We sat there with empty plates in front of us for 10 minutes. I got up to ask someone for the check. He brought the check but left the dishes there. Eventually the dishes were cleared and all we needed was my buddy to get his card back. That took about another 10 minutes. We were there for almost an hour to be served mediocre food, ignored the entire time and still pay $50 for two people. 

I left no tip.
author: Adam L.

description: Trendy. Very good selection. Very fresh and delicious! Kinda pricey and space is small but overall its a winner! I'd definitely go back!
author: Chera T.

description:
Despite what other reviewers say, the sashimi did not taste anything short of "flopping on your plate." The rolls were much better than the sashimi and nigiri, only because all the dressing masked the actual taste of the fish. Our sashimi was unpleasantly veiny, but even worse, I got brain freeze chomping into the just-defrosted flesh. The combo "duo" was also quite a joke; it came in a huge platter but the food itself was a splatter: deflated and tiny. The nigiri that came with the entree was waxy and cheap-tasting, and definitely did not come from the same source as their sashimi. 

Not only was the food disappointing, service was irritating. They were friendly, but extremely spotty. Although several tables were empty, we had no idea who our server was since we got a rotation of randoms. Not to mention, it took about 10 minutes to flag anyone down at any time.
author: Nicole L.

description: Ate here for lunch today and stoked I did--this place is awesome! Hard to believe I have not eaten here in the 14 years since I moved here from Japan. They do amazing omakase, Edo-mae style. The house cured ikura was among the best I have had anywhere, and best in SF for sure. Also noteworthy were the aburi-kinmedai, aburi-akamutsu and ocean trout which was served with shiso between the rice and fish. Finally, the uni (from Maine) was delicious. When we were leaving the chef showed us that they have fresh hairy crabs from Hokkaido which are in season. Can't wait to return for dinner and eat me some hairy crabs!!!
author: John D.

description:
The food was good. I don't eat sushi often. Service was fine. The only issue was with 1 of the guys that poured water. He leaned over me and pushed me 2-3 times to grab the water cups. I thought that was unusual. 

The place is a little small, but nice setting. It's not bad for a small size group. We had about 8-10 people fit comfortably
author: Steven L.

description:
I would like to thank Em for reminding me why I am an opinionated curmudgeon who relies on virtual communities for friends, support and acceptance.  That reason lies deep in the belly of a spiny sea creature: the sea urchin!

Today, after many moons, I broke my subconscious fast from uni.  Well, I'm writing this review a few days later because the night I tried to pen this opinion, my kitty was really insistent on cuddles and would not let me type.  Therefore, figuratively, today, I was reminded of the creamy goodness that is uni.

In the financial district, one cannot be too picky about food unless one has a trust fund, a corporate account, a tourist visa, or a job.  I have none of the above.  When Val and I decided to have a nice dinner to lament about the state of our lives and the Union, we were greatly limited by the rain and our budget.  But we had to do it with style and grace.  We're not monsters.  

Akikos is a strange and beautiful conglomerate of FiDi, old world SF, and Japanese aesthetics.  Dare I say, there was even some French Countryside Provencal decor?  The front of the restaurant has the appearance of an old world pub.  Square glass windows superimposed at the foot of skyscrapers, situated between corporate parking garages and the running, running, running of electronic ticker-tape.  While we were on the outside, the world was fast-paced, cars drove recklessly, people darted between the raindrops and anxiety pulsed through the veins of commerce.

Once inside, the breathing slowed.  The warm faces full of concentration turned towards us and brushed the weight of the world off our shoulders.  The lights were dim, the space was well utilized and we were seated.  Above the doorway, the steel i-beams of FiDi created an archway.  In an bit of ingenuity, someone had painted it red to resemble the wooden doorways that dot the Asian landscape of history.  Clever.  Creative.  Working with what is there.  Tim Gunn would be proud.

I ordered chirashi for the first time.  And uni.  And agedashi tofu.  Val got the a.j., edamame, and a miso soup.  I recognize now that I got so much food.  Way too much food.  Because my chirashi came with soup too.  

Agedashi tofu was not the best.  The broth/sauce was a bit dark.  Too much like soy sauce.  The soy sauce was not proper soy sauce either.  Darker, like chinese soy sauce.  Edamame was regular.  Neither good nor bad.  

Uni was fantastic.  After a brief hesitation, I crammed it in my mouth and smeared it all over my tongue.  Sorry.  I tried to think of something lyrical to say, but it was all savage instinct.  

Chirashi was good.  A bit expensive.  I paid $30 for my portion.  It was a lot of food.  And I was well fed.  Good food is satisfying.  This means I won't be satisfied for a while unless I make it myself.
author: Christina C.

description:
Came here on a Friday around 1pm.  The restaurant was only half full so we got the table right the way.

The service was kinda slow but still friendly.  The prices were kinda high.   

We ordered:

Volcano Roll ($14.00):  The presentation was just ok, not impressed.  It was just a brunch of tempera pieces topping covered the California Rolls.  The rolls were too small for the price we paid.  The crunch toppings were little oily too me.  

The Bento Box:

Four pieces Nigiri Sushi and Tempura:  The rice was hard and cold.  The sushi were ok.  Some fish were fresh but some weren't.  The tempura was ok, nothing special.

Overall, this is a decent place for lunch in FiDi.
author: Liza T.

description: Great sushi. Poor service. I was asked to move for a no show party of 2. My order was wrong. The bathroom was disgusting.
author: Scott P.

description:
Akiko's eel sauce, which I had on their dragon roll, is hands-down the best I have ever had. And I'm a slave to the eel sauce. This is the real deal -- sticky, rich, and sweet.

My fiance and our friend also enjoyed the california roll and the veggie roll. We sat at the sushi bar and watched their process (including blow-torches!) which was fun. 

But I'd return solely based on the eel sauce.

p.s. You need to pull really hard on the door for it to open. Same with the door to the bathroom.
author: Whitney G.

description:
One of my favorite cuisine is Japanese and so I was thrilled when my friend suggested Akiko's for dinner. :)

I went as a group of 6, which btw, is a perfect size for this restaurant.
We ordered a couple of rolls and an udon.
The udon is nothing to rave about, but it is good nonetheless.
The rolls were fairly good.  The one that I liked best was the Volcano.  It was a bit on the spicier side, but it definitely was worth it.

Here's the breakdown:
Food = is ok but could be better
Cleanliness = very clean
Service = A+

Happy Eating!
author: Julie L.

description: This place was amazing. The fish was melt in your mouth delicious. After having sushi in Japan at the fish markets in Tokyo, I can say this place rivals in quality and taste. Highly recommend the forty-niner roll...talk about flavor explosion in your mouth. This place earned the food happy dance I did while enjoying every bite I took!
author: C P.

description:
Came here with a friend for dinner after work one night. I was happily surprised at how cozy the inside is, which was small without being confining. The service was great. Very attentive, but also gave us time to talk and weren't rushing or hovering us. 

We both got the 5 piece sashimi plate with a side - which I chose the teriyaki beef. The fish was so fresh and sliced so perfectly. I was impressed. The teriyaki beef was very good as well. The portions are not huge, so you might want to share an appetizer as well. If you don't get drinks the total is about $45 for 2 people getting those dishes. 

It's in a convenient location if you are downtown and at night they have street parking.  I will be back to try more! I want to try Udon next time or some rolls.
author: Natalie N.

description: Wonderful. Come here and sit at the bar. Sushi chefs are awesome and very talented.
author: A. D.

description:
I was pretty psyched about having dinner here after seeing a sample of their sashimi/sushi selection, specifically the variety of fresh fish they had from the Tsukiji Market in Japan.  We arrived at 7PM and the place was relatively empty.  

I started the night off by ordering a glass of the tenth degree sake.  Unfortunately, they were out of it, and I was forced to settle on a lesser one.  No big deal.  Upon arrival of our drinks, we then ordered the following:

1)  Kindai (sustainable blue fin tuna).  They were out of it.

2)    Kanpachi (Japanese Amber Jack).  They were out of it, so the server recommended another option.  I believe it was the Arctic Char.  The server then comes back saying that she "hates to do this to us but, they were out of that as well."  On the 3rd attempt, she finally brings out what I believe was sea trout.  It looked very similar to salmon, but evidently, the fish had not been completely thawed out, as I tasted crunchy ice crystals as I had my first bite.    

3)  Hamachi Kama (Grilled Yellowtail collar).  They were out of it so we ended up ordering the saba shio-yaki (grilled norwegian mackerel).  Quite tasty, the fish was tender and cooked well.  The daikon, wasabi and lemon added a nice combination of flavors.

4)  Smoked uni with salmon roe and quail egg.  The uni was extremely fresh as evidenced by the little dimples, and the smoked flavor along with the texture of the roe and the quail egg made this the most enjoyable dish for me.  

5)  Hon Hamachi sushi (baby yellowtail).  Highly recommended.  Great texture and flavor.

6)  Firecracker Roll.  Quite tasty with a good amount of heat.   A little heavy for my taste, but I would order it again.

7)  Forty-Niner Roll with shrimp tempura, avocado, lemon paper, salmon, and magaso.  Really awesome roll.  

I would rate the food a 4 despite the one sashimi dish we received that was not completely thawed.  What I don't understand is how you can possibly run out of so many items on the menu, especially when you have a menu that is printed on a daily basis.  At some point the server needs to be held responsible for knowing what is out, and mention it to the guest before they order.  The servers themselves were very nice, but extremely slow.  It took us over 2 hours for us to finish our meal.  In addition we waited about 30 minutes between our last course and the one before it.  I'm not sure I would go back again.  Most of the food was exceptional, but I'm not sure I would be willing to sit through a long drawn out dinner.
author: David D.

description:
Came here with my coworkers after a big day of window shopping,. coworker wanted SUSHi and decided to come over to Akiko's! The coworker who suggested SUSHI,. didn't even order sushi, but got udon instead!!! WOW

The place is pretty small,. and really cramped,. but the exterior design reminds me of an Italian restaurant.  We were seated in the back area and the place was really dim and lighted with fluid candles.   

I ordered the spicy scallop nigiri, white tuna toro nigiri and the fire cracker roll.

The spicy scallop and the white tuna nigiri tasted really good,. and it was a great starter for me,..  The fire cracker roll took a while to prepare and didn't come till half way through dinner. 

Wasn't a big fan of the fire cracker roll,. because it was DEEP FRIED and felt like I was eating greasy fried rice.  I couldn't taste anything inside the roll,. since the greasy batter over powered the taste.  I was really disappointed and it def didn't satisfied my sushi cravings.  

I would have ordered more,.. but my share of the bill was already $30 including tip!  

Service was awesome,. but the firecracker roll turned me off.  Don't think I will be coming back ,...
author: Chanel L.

description:
Akiko's is by far one of the best sushi restaurants I have ever been to in the Bay Area.

I was in charge of planning my roommate's birthday, and spontaneously picked Akiko's after hearing nothing but positive feedback from friends and colleagues. 

I was originally concerned that the restaurant would be too small to accommodate 7-9 people, but their back room was just right -- cozy and intimate yet artistically elegant.  Although the exterior looked shoddy and dingy, the inside of the restaurant was beautifully decorated and clean.

Everything I tasted and consumed was delicious:
- Miso soup
- 10 piece nigiri
- Agedashi tofu
- California roll
- Spider roll
- Dragon roll
- Green tea ice cream

My favorite of them all was the spider roll!  Never before have I seen this roll wrapped with green rice paper (rather than seaweed).  The crab tempura was mouthwatering -- as it actually tasted like real crab meat rather than fried bits.  

The cherry on top of our whole experience was the excellent service that was provided.  The staff was friendly, attentive, and quick to serve.

Our dinner at Akiko's was perfect from beginning to end.
author: Judy C.

description:
I absolutely love Akikos! Joe makes the best sushi rolls. The fish always tastes so fresh and mmmm....so good!

I was lucky enough to have my husband throw me a surprise 30th birthday party here. He asked me where I wanted to go for my birthday dinner and of course I said Akikos. (he must have banked on me saying that). So off we drove to the City. We walked into intimate setting of the restaurant and I thought we were in for a great meal and quiet dinner. 

As we walked to the back, the lights came on and 20 of my closest family/friends were waiting to surprise me. Maybe not so much a quiet dinner (which was fine with me) but definitely the a FANTASTIC meal. Platters of rolls and nigiris, bottles of wine and the best company I could ask for.

The owners, Joe, Mary & Ray are the sweetest. They stored my cake in the back (which a friend brought all the way from San Jose) and brought Joe brought it out right after dinner so that everyone could sing Happy Birthday.

The backroom has a great ambiance & is the perfect size for small group gathering, but I've been here plenty of times for an intimate dinner with my husband....and have even come here for a wedding reception. 

Great food, great service!!!
author: Regina P.

description: The first time I went there it was good, the second time, I got sick. A sushi restaurant should have stringent health standard. I probably won't go back.
author: George L.

description:
Do you like your sashimi to practically flap around on your plate? Akiko's must have some sort of fishing line out their back door and into the bay because I consistently get really fresh fish here.

The place is super cute and super tiny. Then again I am not partial to huge dining rooms serving raw fish en masse. That makes me 'side-eye' the kitchen.

But the staff is always really sweet and sometimes I dump a huge to-go order on them for my office and they do their damn best to get my food out the door asap. I don't know what else I could ask for in a restaurant.

I recommend the Volcano Roll everyday and twice on Sunday. The Rainbow and RocknRoll Rolls are solid choices too.
author: Aileen M.

description:
The food was good, after having to ask 5 times to receive it. It wasn't good enough to make me want to come back.

Had a birthday party at Akiko's last night. There were 12 of us there. We all ordered at the same time & the waiter put our orders into his handheld digital order taker. Not sure what went awry in the process, but we were incessantly re-ordering. 

"We ordered miso soup. Hi yes, we ordered miso soup? About that miso soup...." "If you wouldn't mind, we ordered a hot sake. Hey, can we please have a hot sake? A hot sake would be great about now, please."

The rolls were decent, but we all got our food at bizarrely strange intervals. Half of orders here, ages of time would pass and someone else would get another roll. Our entire dinner took forever & it was a strange atmosphere all together. Shame too, the inside is amazing. Akiko has a great feel, but I would never give it another shot, even if the Volcano roll is super impressive.

To boot, it took us ages to get the bill. Maybe they had an off night, but I wouldn't recommend Akiko. Try elsewhere.
author: Tawnee K.

description:
Totally uncertain how to rate Akiko's. Ate here with my good friend who is a regular here. Splurged even though we weren't on an expense account that night. Had the Omakase and was quoted between $110-120/person.

Food: 4 stars - some exceptional fish flown in from varous parts of the world. 1/2 the sushi was really great and special. However, the other 1/2 was solid and I liked it, but they were some of the imported fish so the prices for the okay ones were like $20-25+ for 2 pieces. A few of the basic pieces like salmon was really good. We also got a young hamachi cheek (kama) and although tasty barely had meat.

Service: 5 stars - great service all around. Friendly, engaging service. 

Quality to Pricing (Value): 3 stars - part of the issue I had was some parts of the omakase fish was only okay and not worth the price. The bill came out to $300 for 2 and we only had a few bottles of beer and no expensive sake either. I have been to some of the best sushi/Japanese restaurants around some major cities and I really felt this was overpriced by 50%. Akiko's caters to those with an expense account.

I will come back, but just not order the Omakase anymore. Too many of the Yelp reviews recommended the Omakase. Go for it if you are on expense account, and investment banker, venture capitalist or just sold your tech company. Otherwise, if you stick to a la carte standard sushi/sashimi, then it will be a great experience with good service, at a small, intimate place.
author: Pete T.

description: Incredibly fresh and delicious fish prepared by a knowledgable staff that provides great service. You can't go wrong with the omakase. Treat yourself and a loved one to a meal here, they'll take good care of you.
author: Joe A.

description:
The best sushi I've had in SF. I've never been a huge fan of the raw fish - I always go for the rolls and teriyaki. Going with two purists 
introduced me to some new dishes and they were ammaaazing.

The restaurant is a bit snug - but well worth it!
author: Twinstar G.

description:
We stumbled into Akiko's when a buddy was convinced that happiness came from tempura.  The mood was decidedly dead in the restaraunt and it was surprisingly empty for a 4 star place at 6:45PM.
The menu has a decent selection, nothing too exotic but enough to find something to eat.  I went with a bowl of chirashi which landed up being edible but somewhat small, somewhat uncreative in fish selection & cut, and somewhat low on flavor.  The tempura donburi my friend got was slightly soggy and average.
author: Ivan L.

description:
Single guy in town for business seeks adventurous dinner date.  Tired of boxed lunches and hoping to find a little somethin' to spice up my evening.  Please be clean, classy and reasonably priced.

It turns out I didn't have to place that ad in the personals, because thanks to Yelp I found Akiko's!  On one's own for dinner it makes perfect sense: just grab a seat at the bar and order as little or much as you need.  The fish is fresh, tender and expertly prepared.  I had the tasty "rock & roll" (with smoked salmon, some veggies and topped with avocado & eel) and a selection of "chef's choice" nigiri.  With some miso, a large Sapporo and a reasonable tip it was about $40--not bad, and something I should be able to squeeze into an expense report.

I saw at least one sexy date goin' on at Akiko's that evening--so it looks like it's good for more than just for the after-work crowd too.
author: Nick H.

description: I went here once before and got the shrimp tempura which was light and flaky, very yummy.  So I was looking forward to eating some well done tempura.  Sadly, I ended up with overcooked tempura batter that was tougher than the heel on my shoe.  Why is it so hard to make a decent tempura dish???
author: C L.

description:
I came here with a party of 10 people last-minute on a Friday night and they were pretty accommodating to us. We were seated in the large rectangle room in the back near the bathroom. I liked the atmosphere of this restaurant, cool decor with dim lighting but still able to see. I saw a few couples here on dates that were seated near us, and asked to move (probably because the tables are close together, they didn't have privacy, and we were loud).

We ordered about 6 rolls between 8 people and the other 2 ate soups. The noteworthy rolls include the volcano roll and the firecracker roll, which is super spicy!  All the rolls we got were good. Even my non-sushi friends liked the food.  I got an order of sake on the house since it was my birthday. 

The food is sorta pricey, but that is what you can expect with good-quality sushi.
author: Kristina N.

description: After their main chef left couple months ago, their sushi has become mediocre at best -- Amongst other things, there is no more seared wayu beefi in their omakase.
author: Ann C.

description:
I was craving sushi after shopping around Union Square and Yelp led me to Akiko's. The restaurant doesn't look like much from the outside, with dingy windows and a faded sign. We actually passed it once before coming back and spotting it. The inside is considerably better and looks as if it's been newly decorated. But on such a hot day, I was surprised that there was no A/C on. The tables were so close together that I felt like I was dining with the people at the table next to us. I found this to be slightly confusing; the ornate decor and prices make me think that Akiko's is trying to sell themselves as a high-quality sushi restaurant, but the stuffiness and table set-up make it feel more like a Japanese izakaya.

My friend and I shared...
CHEF'S SELECTION SASHIMI - I always thought that the chef's selection sashimi is supposed to be the most fresh fish of the day, but this... was not fresh. It wasn't bad to the point of being inedible but it tasted as if the fish wasn't stored in the proper temperature. Definitely not worth the price.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IRD_9JUjR-06zztisuTdAA?select=s87qxzWSX_BoCeXcR2Ic4g
DYNAMITE ROLL spicy tuna, cucumber, scallion, flash fried - I'll admit I'm not the biggest fan of fried sushi but this was pretty tasty and the perfect level of spicy. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IRD_9JUjR-06zztisuTdAA?select=Xax3E99B_ALQ1C5TIBkUBw
FIRECRACKER ROLL spicy scallop, crab, avocado, garlic, scallion, flash fried - Odd~ the firecracker roll wasn't spicy. Out of the two rolls, I liked the dynamite roll better.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IRD_9JUjR-06zztisuTdAA?select=VUk11f4Ix-gocC3t62S1gg

My experience at Akiko's was underwhelming and left me wondering how it has a 4 star average on Yelp. On one hand, the sashimi not being fresh enough is a fundamental problem. Is it possible I caught them on an off day? On the other hand, their specialty rolls are fun and worth trying, so I guess I wouldn't be opposed to giving Akiko's another chance. Until then, I'll be nice and round up from 2.5 stars.
author: Amy S.

description: The sushi was very average and the hostess had a major attitude.  She seated us and basically told us that the table was reserved in one hour.  I wouldn't go back.
author: Linda B.

description:
This was among the most delicious and extravagant sushi experiences of my San Francisco sushi-eating career. Everything was absolutely extraordinary -- fresh, delicious, beautifully presented. I tend to dine around the middle of the sushi price scale: not too high, not too low. I don't have the stomach for bad sushi, but I don't have the money for really expensive sushi. But when a friend rolled into town and wanted to try "the best sushi in San Francisco," I did a little research and came up with this place.

Three of us came for lunch, and sat at a table in the back. We each asked for the 10 piece nigiri combo, and were treated to a fabulous presentation and recitation bye Alan, our attentive, but somewhat officious, waiter. Our meal was delivered in waves, with each two-space to 3-piece delivery being explicated and described in detail, along with origins, comparisons, and dipping instructions. Actually, it was a bit overbearing, but it appeared to be the style of the place to super-control how each piece was consumed.

In the end, it really was one of the most delicious sushi dining experiences in recent memory. On the other hand, it was also one of the most expensive: $460 for three people to eat lunch, and I Could easily have eaten twice as much. The price is the only thing that kept this from being a 5-star rating. 

Thank God my friend paid!

Points of interest:
Cloth napkins -- definitely a plus!
Excellent sushi rice -- perfect temperature and consistency.
Extremely attentive waitstaff.
Every single piece was truly extraordinary!

If you ever have a chance to go on someone else's dime, do it!
author: Josh M.

description: This place in NOT easy to find, but FIND IT. Look for the address number 431, there is a sign for the Irish Restaurant above Akiko's. I went there with my wife, sister, and full blooded Japanese mother, if she approves, you know it's good. We shared a couple of cucumber salads to start, excellent, a little real crab in it, ad a touch of dressing. Mom has the combo nigiri plate, I had beef teriyaki, and nigiri, sis had tempura, wife had 5 pc. toro nigiri. Everything was the best in San Francisco by far. I will recommend this place to everyone I know, and I will go here whenever I am in the city. Make reservations, it is a small, and busy place. The sushi rice was not too gummy, and just a little rice on the sashimi, more fish than rice, that's the way it is supposed to be. Mom was in sushi heaven. I would give it 3 $$$ not two, but it's worth the extra $
author: Gene G.

description:
My darling coworker again took me to another eatery that I quite enjoyed. Craving for some udon, she asked if I would like to go to Akiko's with her for a getaway from the office. Of course I was game. 

She made a reservation for 12:45pm, but when we walked in, we immediately took the table right in front of the door. The minus part was the long wait for the water, the food, and the check. Roughly, our hour lunch was 75% waiting and 25% eating. 

My coworker ordered their tempura udon, completely vegetarian. I ordered their tonkatsu donburi. This is where Akiko won my stomach and my smidgen of loyalty. Their tonkatsu was amazing. I love my katsu, brings me back to Hawaii, but this was definitely a Japanese comfort dish that brought me to heaven and definite satisfaction. 

The dish consist of: panko breaded chicken, egg, onion, napa cabbage, and carrots over rice. I wish I took a picture of it, but most people aren't used to me snapping photos of everything I eat. I tone it down for my coworkers. Now rice is always iffy for me because of how different restaurants prepare it. And katsu, for me, needs to be made in a way where it isn't too dry or too fried. Akiko's got it right. Everything was right. The whole dish was dee-licious. And all for $10! 

I would love to go back, but again this is one of those places were the money and timing has to be just right. Can't spend all my hard earned pennies on a bowl of deliciousness all the time, just once in awhile or a week.
author: Jamie L.

description: Really enjoyed the Sushi here. Good flavors, some which I hadn't experienced at other restaurants. Decent service. The only issue is that you need reservations. Usually it's not that hard to get them but sometimes they can be.
author: Amandeep K.

description:
I've been looking to try this place for a pretty long time and finally got the chance. The restaurant was a pretty hard to find considering there was no signage, but I ended up poking my head in and seeing the sushi bar in front. The ambiance was quaint and pretty nice. 

Being that it was my first time there, I went with my staple items of nigiri along with a couple hosomakis. Saba, ikura, shiromaguro, spicy scallop, and a negihama, and sake maki for the rolls, while my friend ordered Uni, seared Sake,and hamachi . The fish was very fresh considering it was Monday (hit or miss day for sushi bars with fish companies being closed on weekends - ex sushi chef). I was especially impressed with their saba (well cured), along with their ikura (one of the few places that marinades their roe). You can usually tell how much pride and effort a japanese restaurant takes from their saba, tamago, and ikura (all time consuming preparations). One thing about their sake maki was their method of curing the salmon. Salmon's one of my favorite fishes, but I'm not particularly fond of using Kombu for the marinade, it makes it taste almost like smoked salmon (dislike, unless it's on a bagel). 

All in all, I'm glad I found this place because I can only take so much Tokyo Express. Not bashing on TE, but they're a different class. I'll definitely be back, hopefully for dinner with a couple bottles of Sake!
author: Andrew K.

description: I have eaten sushi in Japan and Akiko's quality is pretty close. Our waiter was so friendly and helpful in making knowledgable suggestions to our liking. We prefer the buttery fattier nigiri and he made several awesome recommendations. Our favorite, gotta have another piece, was the walu seared escolar. This was probably one of the best pieces of fish i have ever eaten. The Australian ocean trout was also great and very fresh. We also tried the Monk liver fish, or as the called it the foie gras of the sea. It was ok to my taste. Great place with excellent offerings and very fresh fish. The place is smaller so make a reservation ahead of time. There is no sign out front so it's kind of hard to find right away.
author: Karin J.

description:
I've been to Akikos 3 times for weekday lunches. Be warned: You need to make a reservation, (which you can do same-day via yelp/open table) or there will be a very long wait. 

I've had:

Oshitashi - Perfectly tender spinach with nicely flavored sesame-ginger broth. I highly recommend this.

Miso Soup - Excellent. Among the best I've ever had.

The nigiri that I've had has included some of the freshest fish I've ever eaten. The price reflects the quality. If you don't want wasabi dabbed between the rice and fish, be sure to order it with no wasabi. I can vouch for the deliciousness of the:

Sake
Hirame
Umimasu

Negihama roll - delish, but nothing to write home about.
Rainbow roll - Very fresh. Not a huge fan of crab salad, though. Next time I'll order this with shrimp tempura in the middle.
Spicy tuna roll - I added avocado. It was very good.

Service is prompt. Restaurant is pretty small and a little cramped. It's always been very busy when I've been in, so lunch takes a little longer than other places.

This is the best sushi restaurant I've found in this part of the city and I've been working in the Financial District area for 5 years.

This place doesn't get 5 stars because it is pricey, crowded and a little bit of a hassle. But the food is top notch.
author: Kate M.

description:
You ever have an experience at a restaurant where you have a look that basically says, "What just happened here?"  So, the hours at this restaurant says that they close at 9PM, like many SF restaurants [what is UP with that NorCal?].  But they started turning customers AWAY at 8:30PM.  But the weirdest of all, was that they RAN OUT of TEA!!!!  Wow.

On to the food.  The food here is good, but not spectacular.  We got a couple of rolls and we finished it off with fried octopus.  We also got the agadashi tofu, but that tofu was drowned in a big bowl of the broth.  That's not really the way to serve the tofu.

There are many, many great restaurants to go to in SF and I would come back to this one, but probably not right away.
author: Del C.

description:
Great sushi, friendly and efficient staff, pleasant chefs, traditional decor, and non-Japanese music that somehow compliments the whole restaurant.

Salmon belly and yellowtail were both good but not the best I've had.  Shiro toro pleasantly surprised me with its buttery goodness.  Wasabi seems authentic and less pasty than some other places I've tried.  Green tea is tasty and included in the meal for free.  You just have to ask for it.  While sitting at the bar, I saw the chef making a roll with four different colors of masago.  How fun!  My friend enjoyed his seafood salad and commented that his spicy tuna roll was actually spicy and very tasty.

Nigiri sushi was about $5-7 per pair and while I didn't eat anything else, other items (such as udon) were reasonably priced for under $10.  Some combination meals were on the menu - 5 pieces of nigiri or sashimi and a choice item including udon and dontaksu - for $17-18.

I visited for a weekday lunch (walking distance from work) and really enjoyed my experience here.  I'll definitely visit again soon.
author: Ally C.

description: I had my birthday dinner with a couple of friends over here last night. The 1st thing that stood out was the music they played at this restaurant. I have a keen ear for music and they were playing chillout-type of music here. The 1st track I recognize was a Bonobo track and the 2nd one was by Ulrich Schnauss. 2nd thing I noticed was the service. The waiter was friendly and kept our glasses full of water, but the service was very slow. A warning sign should've been when the waiter asked if we were in a hurry to go anywhere afterwards. The positive to the slow service was that everything was at least freshly made and tasted good. I absolutely love Unagi so I got the Unagi Donburi along with the VV and Volcano roll. It was neat that the volcano roll looked like an actual volcano with the pieces of sushi in the middle.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
Went there for lunch, spent about $110 for 3 people.

mediocre quality, overpriced menu. Typical overpriced, hipster restaurant in S.F. 

Lived in Japan for 3 years, grocery store sushi tastes better than Akiko's.
author: Momopu Y.

description: Wow what a hidden gem!  I have walked right past this place without even looking inside for years. Super small restaurant but punches above its weight class.  We just stuck with sushi and sashimi and I can't remember having such a wide variety of incredibly fresh fish.  I don't drink sake but the wine list matched the menu with an eclectic mix of mineral driven aromatic whites that paired and enhanced raw fish very well.
author: Mike G.

description:
Well, when we first got here, David reached for the door, pulled, and it didn't open. We assumed it was locked or something but not closed (since there were people inside), so we wandered around to try to find another door, asked a nearby pub bouncer who said it was the only door he knew of. We came back and I gave the door a go. A little tougher to open than most doors but by no means locked. Unbelievable; guess Panda hasn't been hitting the gym.

Service was pretty good, ambience was typical for a pretty nice sushi place. Got a sashimi duo, which was a couple pieces of salmon, tuna, and if I recall some sort of white fish, along with chicken teriyaki, miso soup and rice. The chicken teriyaki was pretty bad; a few small pieces of overcooked white meat drizzled with some teriyaki sauce. Definitely two star chicken. My fish however was GREAT (which is what I was really here for, lucky for them and their rating): the tuna was flavorful and the salmon was like butter. I don't have plans to come here again, but if I were in the area and wanted some good fish I'd swing by.
author: Rachid G.

description:
$$CHEAP AND YUMMMM-IE

Me and my bf devoured two rolls, miso soup, a side a rice, calamari and sweet shrimp. The server was really nice and the food was BOMB. I don't understand how some reviews gave it 3-1 stars! 

ABSOLUTELY amazing sushi. I grew up in HAWAII where there is an abundance of sushi...AND THIS PLACE IS high up there on my ratings!
author: Jaselle G.

description:
The sushi bar was full when we arrived, so we sat at a table.  The service was good, but our waiter was not real friendly.  Towards the end of our meal a different waiter (shorter) started to serve us, and we love him.  Very friendly and knowledgeable.  The sushi chef was very nice, even though we were sitting at a table, he kept making sure that we're happy with our food.

All the fish was very fresh and delicious, with the exception of the Albacore, it smells a bit like fishy dry bonito flakes.  We had the Hanasaki crab 3-ways.  It was just okay, not real fresh.  The legs are extremely difficult to eat and we eat whole crabs often.  The crab nigiri was okay, the sauce was a bit too sweet for my taste.  The crab chawanmushi was my favorite one of the 3-ways.

We'll definitely return for sushi again, and go early so we can sit at the bar.
author: TopCat W.

description:
It usually takes a lot to upset me but I went here at 11:30am  and had an hour to kill before a meeting. However:

(-) We had to wait at least 30 minutes to get our dish, even though we were indeed the first party to enter the restaurant for lunch!
(-) Ended up having to run the credit cards in the middle of our meal so we could get back to the office
(+) No serious complaints on the food, but nothing to raise eyebrows about either. I had the maki/tuna sashimi as well as the teriyaki combo plate
author: Eric H.

description: The kind of sushi place I expect from San Francisco. Delicious all around. Definitely get the Volcano roll.
author: Scott R.

description:
This is the go to restaurant for my bff and I.  We come after work and usually order the same thing.

They have the best tempura udon! The soup is so good.  It is so good that I dont even want to share! The volcano roll is so good! There is tempura bits on top of it, shredded crab and some spicy sauce! It is good!  Even thinking about it makes me salivate.

I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Carol K.

description: Fish wasn't as good as I remembered. So costly! Although, the seaweed salad was mind-blowing
author: Tracy N.

description: Some of the best sushi I've ever had.  Highly recommend!
author: Nicole C.

description: Great food. Loved the Volcano roll. The gyozas were perfect. Nigiri extremely fresh.
author: Nadav N.

description: I arrived there at 2:34 when my reservation was at 2:30, she told me they were closed and refused to serve me.
author: Gabe A.

description: Just went back last week after Ricky's departure and shocked at the crappy service and new chef's lack of professionalism. Sitting at the bar for omakase, the service was nonexistent; our plates were piling up next to us like we were eating at a sushi-go-round restaurant. New Chef kept asking us what we wanted after only 6 pieces of sushi. It's OMAKASE, keep the food coming until we ask to stop. Also, new omakase had no sashimi nor hot food unlike previous times. The chef also practically threw the sushi plate at us with one hand. I've never experience such horrendous omakase experience. For over $100/person meal, this place is a RIPOFF! DONT GO! My friends and I will NEVER come back.
author: Ohl L.

description: I have eaten here 5 times now.  The food is always good but the service is very slow.  I decided to wait until I had been there a few times to make sure that it was not a one time issue, but the service was slow on every occasion.  If you have plenty of time then it's a great place to go and would get a four star rating if the service was quicker.
author: Simon D.

description: A wannabe sushi joint.  Don't be deceived by all the glowing reviews. This place is no better than a Chinese-owned sushi joint in the suburbs.  This is not authentic sushi from Japan.  You're over-paying for having sushi in Union Square in a place that really smells "fishy"...
author: Jerry N.

description:
When in San Francisco I'm not particularly keen to restaurants in Union Square, but we weren't in the mood to walk super far and the reviews seemed good.  Plus, any sushi in San Francisco beats the sushi we can get in Denver (you know, being landlocked and all).

The atmosphere was very cool.  I'm always a sucker for exposed brick and dim lighting.  Though, the tables were extremely close together so if I was really claustrophobic I'd have some issues. But I'm not. So it's okay.

The sushi was very good.  I don't remember everything we had, but the sashimi was delicious as were the rolls.  I recall the seaweed salad and agedashi tofu being tasty as well.

Though, the service was kind of horrendous.  Not only was the server incredibly unfriendly and standoffish, but the intervals in which our food came out did not make any sense.  I do agree with the traditional serving of sushi (not all at once)...but I'm pretty sure we received a roll before our appetizers and it was all over the damn place.  We had to ask multiple times for one of the rolls we ordered and the amaembi.  

So, it's one of those places you want to love...but you just don't.  It was a satisfying meal, but I think I'll stick with the other sushi places I've been to in SF.
author: Addie L.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place. I don't know if I should tell people that I want to keep this gem to myself but that wouldn't be fair to the owners.

Then why no 5 stars? I've had a meal here once that was average, but the sushi is 5 star. I've only had sushi better one other place and that was in Philadelphia.

The last time I was here he had copper river salmon sushi, I've never seen that on any other menu. Their special this time had little salmon. Only one in 10,000 is caught. Explaining the 20.00 a pc price.

I always walk in and get a seat, but I do eat dinner early. Most people walk right on by on their way to the Irish Bank and miss this gem.

The sushi is amazing! I just love the rock&roll. The miso soup is real not from a packet. 

Try one of the cold sake drinks. Low in calories and they havevsuch a selection. 

it is small and if you get there by 6:30 without reservation your pressing your luck.

On warm days they have the door open so you can enjoy the most beautiful weather in SF.

The sushi chef is just so cool. Not sure how much English he knows but I know enough Japanese to great him and thank him. He seems to be appreciative.
author: Astor A.

description: Very fresh sushi, but came with a price!  Plan for at least an hour for the meal, since some of the dishes takes time to prepare...
author: Mandy C.

description: We were lucky enough to get a table here on a Saturday night when a couple no-showed for their reservation.  Tried nigiri yellowtail, salmon, and black tuna which were all super fresh and excellent.  Rolls were good but average.  Tried monkfish liver which was surprisingly good-the foie gras of the sea.  Hot sake was so smooth and delicious.  Warmed our bellies on a cold city night.
author: Carrie H.

description: I watched the sushi "chef" eat a piece of fish while he was slicing fish for someone's order. Didn't stop to wash his hands. I won't be back.
author: Matt S.

description: Good sushi, fair price. I can see why there are a lot of regulars there though. It seems like the staff likes to have a relationship with those they serve.
author: Wesley M.

description: Sushi was top notch, service was great, warm atmosphere - great for a romantic dinner or a fun nightout with friends.  So good!
author: Susana B.

description: Food is really great and fresh. Not a kids friendly restaurant. NO HIGH CHAIR for kids.
author: Miriam Y.

description: So damn good! The fish was so fresh and the rolls were delicious. You have to try the sumo roll it was amazing. Oh and the seaweed salad. Yummy! Over all the place is small and the service is average but the food itself is enough to keep you coming back! Honestly some of the best sushi I've ever had!
author: Kristen B.

description: Great ambiance, setting, service...oh yea- and the sashimi was perfect. Fresh and slightly chilled. Price was definitely reasonable for SF. We had the 12 pc sushi sampler, the agadeshi tofu, rainbow roll, and 49er roll (which was really good...I too had my doubts because of the name of the roll). The rolls have a unique flavor to it, kind of like the pickled stuff commonly eaten with curry. This place was really small, and you should  make reservations.
author: Mark C.

description:
I went here after a long day of business meetings in the city.  This is a very cozy restaurant - small, but decorated very elegant.  I loved the music that they were playing: NOT techno/house music.  

The service, early in the evening was fantastic.  The person serving me actually knew a lot about sushi, and after taking the time to find out what I like, made some suggestions.  There were awesome!!!

The make is very good/high quality fish.  The preparation/presentation is fantastic.  The rolls are really well done.

An awesome restaurant, will definitely go back.
author: Zeev G.

description: Very good food.  Very fresh and super high quality which you should expect for the price.  Can be a bit pretentious in terms of uber sushi-ness, but worth overlooking for some super good food.
author: Nathan J.

description:
Whoever this Akiko dude is, he deserves a big pat on the back! A few coworkers and I were looking for some sushi sit-down, and when our first option turned out to be take-out only, we pulled out the handy Yelp iPhone app and found our way to Akiko's - conveniently located one block away. 

The Miso was delicious - the tofu was above par and I felt like I had just stumbled upon some magical Obaasan's kitchen. My party went family style on a few rolls, and while they did take more than a hot minute to arrive, when they did, they were phenomenal. The quality of the Sashimi was amazing! I've never felt so many variety of fish melt away as I squished my fat, thirsty tongue upon the morsels of finely cut and presented meat. 

While we arrived to an empty restaurant, and were seated as far back in the weirdly shaped and uniquely decorated dining nook (it's a bit small), the place filled up within 30-minutes and I can't imagine how hectic this place is at night. 

Akiko's is a wonderful choice for FiDi sushi for a casual lunch or even a date!
author: Andrew C.

description: I think this place was overpriced for the amount of food. The portions are super tiny, so you'd need to buy a lot to feel full. So don't come here if you're super hungry like my friend and I were. Quality of the fish is pretty good. Service was slow, the food took forever to arrive at our table.
author: Ella C.

description: We had the omakase.  Uni and fish liver were the highlights.  The rest of the sushi was great too.
author: James M.

description:
We came here last Thur night.  When my "sidecar" dropped me off, I must have walked by it a couple of times.  It is definitely hidden.  Then i thought well maybe it's in an alley... but then I finally saw it... I don't recall if the name was even shown outside its doors.  I do remember it being all dark wood and the address # was barely noticeable above the door unless you were standing in front of it... 
I don't know how the rest of the place looked, because I immediately sat by the entrance at the sushi bar.  I definitely liked the modern trendy decor and friendly hostess who sat us. 
I had my usual to start... a glass of red vino... wasn't in the mood for sake and rarely ever do I drink white:)  Wild Horse (Pinot Noir)... definitely could taste the strawberries.  It was good, but I probably wouldn't order that again.
We started off with edemame and a rainbow roll.  Our sushi chef standing in front of us was cool... Ricky. But I noticed he didn't make our rolls.  I believe we had the dragon roll with eel, avocado and crab or was it scallops... can't remember, but it was amazing.  Oh we also shared the gyoza with shrimp & scallops which was delicious.  My favorite of the night was definitely  the Russian Uni... which Ricky did prepare for us.  But I wondered if that was just a name for the Uni... didn't know Russia had Sea Urchins.
Well all in all, had a great dining experience here.
author: Myra M.

description: The sashimi is unbelievably fresh! I had yellowtail, and it was delicate and flavorful. I also got the oshitashi, which was a cute little cylinder of spinach. Even the miso soup and simple mixed green salad were perfect!
author: Catherine Y.

description:
I've been here for lunch and dinner and would definitely recommend this place. 

For apps, I've tried the cucumber salad, the poached spinach (oshitahi), and the fried soft shell crab (kani-age).  All good stuff! My fav would be the cucumber salad. 

I've had the Chicken Udon which was super satisfying - good cheap lunch. For sushi, I've only had the firecracker and forty-niner and loved them both. If you love spicy rolls - the firecracker will not disappoint.  The forty-niner is not spicy, but has thinly sliced lemons on top of the salmon which gives it a nice aftertaste.  I'm not a big fan of sushi but Akiko's has turned this around. 

It's a small space so if you can, I'd make reservations.
author: Amy N.

description: Have been to about 20 plus sushi spots in the city and this is one of the Best places within the area. Super fresh and great variety.  Veryyy small place but worst it.
author: Ro L.

description:
I was looking for a good sushi place with acceptable pricing. I've seen 2 dollars sign and 4 stars. jumped in. had no reservation. they kindly welcomed saying that the seat is  booked after 7.30 so 2 h were ok for me.

For the first time in a sushi bar, experience is wonderful. Many colors, sounds, atmosphere and watching the guys preparing various different rolls.. interesting.

BUT: the place is pricy. I am not saying this because it doesn't deserve, but 2 dollars sign is an underestimation. You need to be ready to pay like a 100 if you would like to see the "real sushi bar experience".  Anyways, 2 sushi roll plates and 2 beers, 50 bucks.
