author: Mars M.

description:
Really, really good food. Nice, lightly salted edamame, and a terrific cucumber salad. The interior design is very cool, if slightly claustrophobic in the back.

The sushi rolls were definitely the best I've had anywhere near this part of town. The only downside was that the service was strangely slow given that we arrived well after the lunch rush and the place was mostly empty.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Good sushi in the Financial District. Sweet.

I came here with a friend we ordered 3 rolls, including the volcano roll. They were all pretty good. It's not my favorite sushi in the city, but it's hard to beat in terms of convenience since I work nearby.

They appeared to have a pretty standard drink list, though I didn't order any this time.
author: Ben B.

description: What a let done. I took my girl friend there and not only was the sushi chef abnoxious but on top of that the sushi were at room temperature or even above. When the bill came they had charged $12 for almost each 2 piece of sushi. I really felt like I was being gang raped that evening. A tourist trap and a place for YUPs who have no clue about sushi or Japanese culture. Some of the reviews I read have to be fake!
author: Lee H.

description: Great sushi here.  Had some nigiri (seared salmon belly, fatty tuna) - awesome.  Also had the lunch set with the tonkatsu, which was also great.  Highly recommend.
author: Seung N.

description: I loved this place for lunch. Yummy rolls and great atmosphere. The only thing that I wish that Akiko's would do is let you order for take out. Working in the Financial District makes it so sometimes all I have time for is to grab my lunch and go back to work. I would probably come here more than once in awhile if I could order take out. :)
author: Lauren M.

description: Ehh...food is not bad but not great either.  I was really disappointed that our sashimi was cut so badly.  I wish I took a picture but the chef seriously razored our fish.  The environment is nice and it may be an option if I happened to be in the area and wanted Japanese food, but I probably wouldn't come back again.
author: Angie N.

description:
This place is by far the BEST sushi place in the city! Go for Omakase sushi menu and enjoy the most incredible and fresh seafood treats like never before! 
Make reservations, this place is tiny and gets crowded very fast!
author: Alisa W.

description:
49er's roll
Volcano Roll
Rock n Roll 

Volcano roll was tasty and I was in love with it. It was pretty spicy.

49er's roll was very fresh and yummy. 

I love the decor inside! I want to eat here again!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Went for a dinner with friends last night. 
I would give 5 stars, but now I'm just confused with Yelp ranking. SO it is four because I didn't knock me off my feet but I really liked their sushi! I guess it is 4-5 stars 
The food: 
 veggie tempura - it was simple but pretty good.
Dragon Roll - GREAT
49-ner - pretty good, spicy 
Spicy scallops - was good, less to my taste
Some small roll - didn't care for it, so I didn't bother to remember the name
And... I do not remember the rest. 
Service was pretty good, price, tiny bit on the expensive side, but not super bad (we had 5 BIG guys and 1 gal, who all love sushi and we ended up with a bill around 200$)

All in all - a nice place to have a dinner with friends, would recommend
author: Nastia R.

description:
A friend recommended this place to me.   I opted to have the waiter pick selections for the table.    The sushi, sake and overall presentation were excellent.   I really enjoyed letting the waiter drive the experience.   Waiters may vary, but mine was great.

The restaurant was very small, but it had a very European feel to it which I liked.   We made reservations so we had not trouble getting a seat.  Set your expectations if you go.   If you focus on the sushi/sake experience, you should come away happy.
author: Jody S.

description: Best sushi I've had in a long time. Super fresh, high quality in a very cool tucked away atmosphere.  Makes you feel more hip just being there.  I'm half expecting David Chang from Momofuku to come walking in to chat with one of the chefs.  Highly recommend this place.
author: Ted H.

description: New favorite sushi spot in the city! by no means is it cheap in price but the fish is QUALITY!
author: Ilya Movshovich M.

description:
best fish in town.  fresh fresh fresh is how i would describe it.  just like how sashimi should be.

to begin with, the service is spectacular.  the servers are very knowledgeable and friendly, the owner is well traveled and does what is best for his establishment.  he brings in new and unique dishes with stories of his travels around the world and how he came about this fresh piece of [enter his fresh item of the day]...  then we order the fresh piece of [enter his fresh item of the day recommendation] and love it.  he once said the octopus was fresh and to demonstrate he brought out a tentacle and slammed it on the counter;  it began to twitch.

i would recommend sitting at the sushi bar and just letting the itamae decide your fate for the day.  you will get a variety of what is fresh and recently imported from some exotic or far away place.  the owner raymond has always been back there and has great recommendations when you ask.  everything he makes for you will be delicious at that point.  there are a few things on the menu though that i would highly recommend:

seared walu nigiri
black tuna o-toro
(if you call in advance, you can have the kindai o-toro).  if you are unfamiliar with what this is, then i would best describe this as the wagyu of tuna.  if still you don't know then never mind and just try it, its delicious.

if they don't know you there, then you may want to ask for their house soy as they make it themselves.  during their downtime they grind their own wasabi, yes it is that fresh and you can just eat the wasabi alone if you dare.

they typically have 3 types of uni but my favorite is the santa barbara one then the hokaido.  the russian uni was a little to "from the sea" for me.

the monk fish is different and we recently had the mackerel collar, they typically only have 2 per fish so supply is limited.

the copper river king salmon sashimi is the best salmon i have ever had... ever...

end the meal with the roasted black sesame ice cream, you won't be disappointed.

bottom line is that this is the best sushi place i have ever been to.  i used to have tekka as my #1, but it has now been replaced by akiko.
author: Wayne L.

description: Great service, amazing prices, and pretty good sushi! Great place for a client dinner.
author: Alina I.

description: disclosure.  I met the chef at Akiko's while volunteering so I may be getting better service but from what I observe, all the guests (well at least those who sit at the bar) get amazing service.  the chefs are really knowledgable about the sushi and really the best thing to do is just sit at the bar at get omakase (chef's choice).  The philosophy is "I'm going to serve you what I'd want to eat." and that is pretty much the freshest stuff.  And their stuff is EXTREMELY fresh.  And mind blowing.  Their fish is over-nighted from all over the world and it certainly comes through in the taste as well as in your wallet but it is really worth the exorbitant price you pay.  OK, for ME it's worth the price I pay and that's like $100 a person.  For most, I have to say that $100 is just too much to pay for any meal so for those people, this is probably not the place for you.  Always make sure you have reservations going in.  It's pretty impossible getting seats on a walk-in save unless you are a regular then they would probably do their best to try to accommodate you.  Take a seat at the bar and let the chef's take care of you.  Your mouth will die and go to heaven.  Can't say enough good things about this place.
author: Nat L.

description: Akiko's Restaurant is THE best sushi and sashimi in SF! It's tiny and sit at the bar if you can. Joe really knows his stuff and will make your mouth water, for a price ;) not to be missed! Would live there if I could afford it!
author: Paul O.

description: I really liked it.  Only thing that I didn't like is that front staff was a bit rude, and expected us to be thrilled to have dinner there.  Yes, I was with two younger adults, but still don't treat people like that!  I would go ahead and look past the front of the house.
author: I Y.

description:
Found it on yelp, went in and was greeted with "You don't have a reservation?" and I thought "here we go". 

But they promptly seated us at a table right in front. It was excellent. We started with some $3 edamame and had a sushi roll and an entree the service was great and the food was, too!
author: Garry J.

description:
Work in downtown and surprisingly haven't found a great sushi place until I stumbled upon Akiko's Restaurant (not to be confused with Akiko's Sushi Bar close by).

Went here for lunch and sat at the sushi bar.  When i looked at the menu, intially thought, ok, decent selection...but then saw the specials menu with the fish flown from Tsujiki Fish market from Japan and knew i'm in for a treat.  The selection was amazing, heck there were 3 types of Uni ( i ordered the one from Russia and boy was it good)

They allowed half nigiri order (1 piece sushi) so i was able to try lots of the specials.  Also being at the  bar I was able to chat with the sushi chef (came at 11:30 so wasn't too crowded yet since you never want to disturb the chefs at their art)  and knew I was in for a bigger treat.  He knows his stuff.  Watched him opened up unpacked filets of my order and watched him delicately sliced the pieces to perfection.  On top of this, for some of my white fish selections, he put in toppings from Yuzu to other sauces.  Meant "no sauce" needed.  LOVE it when the sushi chefs do this...as this is their interpretation of what complements each fish and you know it's fresh.  the mixed Yuzu topping and pickled real wasabi with the white fish orders was amazing.  Nicely balanced with acid and a little bitterly, which complemented the butterly fish perfectly.  Been to many sushi places and only had 3 places do this "no soy" interpretation.  

Overall was extremely impressed.  Will say that the sushi chef did all the nigiri himself so you need to allow him time to work his art.  It's just not slicing fish, but also to put in his interpretation of what complements each fish.

Summary:

Selection: 5 stars
Food and Taste: 5 stars
Service: 4 stars (water always filled and chef was great), took some time but worth the wait and you can see the chef takes pride in his work.
ambiance: 5 stars - looked cozy, dark, intimate settings
Location: 5 stars for me... can come here for lunch at work.

Definitely coming back.
author: Vien C.

description:
Really liked this place!  Prob the best California rolls I've had because they differentiated by having this crunchy sprinkling of sesame & fish flakes on the roll.  

We also got a spicy tuna rolls which was also very good.  And we ordered a bowl of Chicken Udon to share.  The staff was nice enough to bring it out in 2 bowls.  

Def. going back.
author: Hui C.

description:
Man. I wanted this place to be so much better. The space is awesome. I love the look. Very trendy and exciting. 

The food....just ok. The best thing I had was the gyoza. Well steamed and crispy on the bottom....perfection. Sushi rolls and others, just below par.

I could have forgiven the less than mediocre food, only if it didn't take 20+ minutes to come out. I get it. Small place, maybe they don't have the most chefs to be working on my meal. But on a lunch break, we're on the clock. 

If we can speed up the process, I'll be back.
author: Jon C.

description: It's an ok sushi restaurant. No surprise. Seats are crowded so not too comfortable. The fishes are very fresh though.
author: Wing F.

description: My wife and son joined me for a birthday dinner. I selected Akiko based on other Yelp reviews. We had a reservation and set at a table in the large back room. Rather than order various fish, we elected to have the chef select the fish for us. Turned out to be a great decision. All the sushi was delicious. I admit I'm not a sushi expert, but everything tasted fresh with excellent texture and delicate tastes. Some of the dishes were cured in house like the eel. The wait staff was very attentive as well. If I ever try sushi in Japan, perhaps I could compare to a 5 start Japanese sushi place.
author: Mark S.

description: Solid sushi in the heart of San Fran. Almost daily shipments from Japan, cant get any fresher. The variety of fish was spectatular. An above average wine list to go with above average service. Very friendly owner and sushi chef.
author: Chad B.

description: We were very pleased with the food and service here. The fish was fresh and flavorful as well as the sushi rice. Will definitely be back when in SF!!
author: Pfunk M.

description: Pretty good sushi. Not mind-blowing, just great. My BF and I came here for lunch to try a different sushi spot than the one we always go to. The place is so tiny and it didn't help that we came on a very hot day in SF. We were both so hungry and expecting fast service but it was so slow. It wasn't even that packed. We ordered 3 rolls. 2 came out at the same time and waited for the 3rd. We couldn't wait any longer so we started eating. After about 15min or so and almost finished our 2 rolls the 3rd one came. I've never had  slow service at a sushi restaurant before. I don't think I'll come back because it's a little pricey also. The sushi was delicious just don't go when you're hungry.
author: J.Realis N.

description: Wonderful meal at Akiko's! Many ingredients are imported from Japan. The rolls are OK, but the Nigiri is where it's at. Have a seat at the bar and let the sushi chefs create whatever they want for you. (I think I got several off-menu items) You will rake up a large bill doing so, but it's worth it for at least once in your life :) I have to say I never have had real sushi until now. They taste other-wordly and just melt in your mouth. I wish I were a millionaire so I could eat here every day.
author: Florence C.

description: Tried to walk in at 530 with my family.  We did not have a reservation.  There were only 5 people in the place.  They said come back in 20 min.  They were the most arrogant people I have met.
author: Eric T.

description:
Picked this place for my birthday dinner with 6 friends based on the 4 star reviews. I had made a reservation a week prior and the lady on the phone was adamant on us being on time. She said " If you are not here at 7:00 for your reservations, your table will be given to someone else." So we showed up right at 7:00PM and there was one other table there, it was NOT busy at all and the entire place was practically empty!!!!!!!!!!!!! Oh and it was still half empty when we left at 9:00. 

Btw, this place has no air conditioning and the back room felt like a sauna on a rare hot day in SF. They tried to stuff us at the very end table in the backroom but we requested to move by the door. The menu was meh, everything you expect to see at a average sushi restaurant. I tried the California, the forty niner, and some other spicy roll and everything was forgettable. 

ATTENTION: no sake bombing here. They won't let you drop the sake shot into the beer so if you wanna have a little fun, you would need to pour your sake into the beer which is fine. I understand that some places are for that and some arent but i think it's the the way they approached the situation that was a little rude. I actually overhead a guy, possbily the manager talking to our waiter about us. Pointing his fingers at us and told our waiter that " THEY CAN"T DO SAKE BOMBS". Treat me like an adult please. The price is average, a little on the pricey side but not completely unreasonable given it's location. Right between union square and financial district. 

I think this place would have been better for a quiet date night but definitely not meant for large groups. I felt like the whole night the waiters were keeping an eye on us to make sure we behaved. Not a very good birthday dinner experience.
author: Tenny W.

description:
Driving around the city are tummy's growling and hey let's check this place out! 

 We ordered a bottle of their Sauvignon Blanc they have only three varietals and typically when the wine list is minimal I am a little hesitant. But whomever chose the Sauvignon Blanc chose correctly. 

Our waiter I believe his name was Greg was very helpful, efficient and eloquent. 

We started off the volcano roll which was very good reminded me of orange chicken but only the crispy part of the chicken because there was no chicken with some firer spice! 

Joe made us a special roll I wish I would have asked the name it was very good. It was fresh eel plated on a bed of seaweed the flavors combined where extraordinary. 

The lay out of Akiko's is relatively small I like how they have utilized the space. The background music is soft and inviting, the clear glass lit candles everywhere are beautiful. The color on the walls are light creamy warm colors. 

Interestingly enough I heard they conduct mass once a week not sure if that is open to the public but in my book this place holds tranquility and rolls of passion.
author: Erica H.

description: Meeting friends, I was told that we had 5:30 reservations and that I had to be on time since we had to leave at 7:00 as the table was reserved.  Okay, so I schlepped in the pouring rain and got there at 5:20.  I walked in, introduced myself, and was told I had to wait outside since their policy is that no one comes in until 5:30.  By outside, they literally meant OUTSIDE in the pouring rain.  I don't care if their food is free, I'll never go back to such rude bastards.
author: Michael S.

description: So amazing!  The service was impeccable.  Fantastic recommendations from the staff.  The sashimi sampler was the best we have ever had.. so fresh!!  We loved it so much, we went back the next night.  Can't wait to go again when we are there in February!
author: Brandi C.

description: Love their volcano roll. Too bad they only serve at lunch now. If you're looking for great sushi definitely go here but remember to make a reservation. They almost always turn away walk-ins for both lunch and dinner. Also, their new decor is awesome.
author: Carly G.

description:
So good!  Probably the best sushi I've ever had, and reasonably priced.

Negatives were the noise level (high) and a notable gap in service- it took a very, very long time for someone to take our order.  Other than that the service was excellent.
author: Meghan P.

description:
Easily the best sushi in the Financial District. Although this place is categorized as being in Union Square, I still considered it residing in the Financial District. 

The staff was friendly, atmosphere was on point and the fish was tremendously fresh. I got the sashimi platter and everything was delicious. Especially the tuna. And I always appreciate a place that doesn't frown upon on Saki bombs. 

Akiko's did have a few draw backs though. Their sushi roll menu was lacking in variety and the prices seemed a little steep for how small the portions are. 

That being said, this is now my new go to spot for sushi in the area.
author: Jeff P.

description: Omakase is the way to go, otherwise, the Russian uni is a must, along w/ monk fish liver and black tuna. Attentive servers too!
author: cindy y.

description: wow great salmon roll , organic salmon at that !!! it was soo yummo and fresh. Great appetizers . The roll where very reasonable priced as well ... Going again soon
author: P C.

description:
We came here with friends for our birthday dinner and all the reviews seem to pinpoint us on getting the calamari for our appetizers. All I gotta say is other Yelpers definitely don't disappoint. I'm extremely picky with my calamari so it's rare to find a place that does it right where it's not on the slimy side or too much batter.  Loved the calamari and the sauce it was plated with; however, not enough sauce!! =/ We asked for more sauce on the side and they brought out something totally different. 

All the rolls were reasonably priced and yummy. My only complaint are the dishware selection here, which was a bit awkward to eat from. the sushi/roll plates were the size of most dipping sauce plates elsewhere. it was amusing to have to cup our mouths as we eat our dinner to avoid a big mess everywhere. Other than that, the service was great and quick.
author: Chi N.

description:
What we got:

Sake (salmon) nigiri: $5
Hamachi (yellowtail) nigiri: $5.50
Maguro (tuna) nigiri: $5.50
Shiro toro (white tuna belly) nigiri: $6
Dragon roll: $14
Firecracker roll: $12

I just came back recently from an extended trip from Japan, and have been on the hunt for good Japanese food ever since--don't get me wrong, Japanese food in America can taste great, but it just about always pales in comparison to Japanese food in Japan.  I saw Akiko's on yelp, and the fact that it was a small sushi-counter type restaurant with a Japanese chef made me more willing to trust it and try it out (since it sounded like sushi bars in Japan), willing to expect pretty good sushi.

It's true the place doesn't look much on the outside, but the inside is great and well-decorated.  My friend and I chose to sit at the counter, partly so I could practice my Japanese with Tayashi-san, the sushi chef.  Everyone there was very nice and accommodating, and Tayashi-san was more than willing to converse with me (despite my poor Japanese) and answer questions about the menu.  While the menu had a fairly standard varied selection of Japanese entrees, we chose to stick to makimono and nigiri.  I'm glad we did--the hamachi was very soft and flavorful, and the shiro toro filled up your mouth with its buttery softness.  The maguro and sake were nothing to sneeze at either, and the dragon roll's unagi on top was cooked in a way I had never tried before, but was delicious.  And as with all good Japanese food, there was special care taken to presentation.

The biggest deal for me, though, was that the fish (particularly hamachi and shiro toro) was pretty much Japan-quality, which combined with the experience of being able to converse in Japanese with Tayashi-san made me feel like I was at a sushi bar back in Japan (even if the interior looked like a typical hip restaurant in the SF financial district, which is different from hole-in-the-wall Japan sushi bars).  If I ever take friends out for sushi in SF, I'll definitely take them here.
author: Jason B.

description: Slowest service ever. We waited 30 mins and only got 2 pieces of sushi and still had to wait longer for the rest of our order. And no acknowledgement of taking a long time. Bad way to run a restaurant. Won't be coming back ever.
author: David C.

description:
Very friendly host and very friendly sushi chefs!! Although they only had one server so unless you sat at the counter, service will probably be a little slow. 

Thought I saw Chirashi on the menu online but turns out that's for lunch only. Had the 49-er and the spider. Spider was amazing! The softshell crab was so crispy but not oily either. 49-er was pretty interesting -- quite lemon-y. Worth a try if you are a citrus fan

Can see this being low key date material. Nothing crazy, just nice host, pretty quiet spot and solid food that probably won't disappoint
author: Trevor K.

description: Ah. Tried their Omakase and wasn't impressed at all. If I were a millionaire maybe I would be satisfied with their food at this price range, but I'm not and I personally don't think it was money well spent. Ended up being $100+/person and I left hungry.
author: Anony B.

description: It ain't cheap, it ain't big, you can't just walk in without a reservation, but some of the best sushi I've ever had. Didn't like the flash fried roll, that's about it.
author: Owen T.

description: I can keep this one simple... this was some of the freshest, most buttery and beautiful sashimi I have had in a very long time. Wow. The rolls were amazing as well. Not a single thing that was in front of my eyes or entered my mouth contributed to anything other than a great experience. I will def be back!
author: michael d.

description: Great sushi, awesome service, and stylish ambiance.  Definitely will return to this spot.  Our server was great.  We asked for recommendations and he noticed what we ordered and made recommendations based on that.  Additional servers were on their game, water and beers were always full.  As for price, very reasonable, especially for sushi.  Keep it up.
author: Bhavesh M.

description:
It's been so long since I've been here. Used to frequent this place a lot while I was working at GSP. My team would always order from here.

In the past we've gotten the Volcano: spicy salmon, salmon skin avocado, crunchy tempura, toasted sesame, golden to-biko. They form the cut roll into a pyramid and pour like a 1lb of crunchy tempura batter bits all over. Also, I would get my favorite, a 49er roll: shrimp tempura, fresh salmon, paper lemon, avocado, toasted sesame, masago. Eating it with the thinly slice lemon is key!

For this outing, I went with my cousin while she was up shopping in SF. Akiko is great for its great fresh fish. But be warned, it gets very packed at lunch and it's a small space. But the décor is great and the staff tries to be very accommodating. Don't be turned off by one waiter's "sour" face (sumangot if you're filipino). He's very nice and doesn't smile often, but I've got him to crack open a smile once in awhile.

It always looks like they have the same staff and might be a wife/husband team at the sushi bar. We sat at the bar and the chef asked why I wasn't having any fish. Then before I could answer he was like, "you pregnant?" and I was like yes. He told me, with utmost confidence that I'm having a boy. I'll see if he's right in a week or so.
My cousin ordered the chirashi donburi. Soo jealous! Everything looked so great and fresh. She was very please that there wasn't squid or octopus. I got the safe, tonkatsu. And we shared a veggie tempura appie.

Our food was good, I was surprised that I ate some onions in my donburi. I usually ask them to remove it, not a big onion fan. Disappointed in how long it took to get our food, the appetizer came with the chirashi and my tonkatsu came like 10-15 minutes later. 

An overall great experience and looking forward to coming back again. Hopefully when I can sink my teeth into some raw fish!
author: Karen U.

description:
1st off, I'm not a huge fan of sushi (please save your scoffs, eye rolls, and smirks for someone who gives a d@#$.) However if there is a place that might get me to change position, its Akiko's. And before you go ahead and discount my review, I have eaten here on multiple occasions with friends who ARE big sushi fans and they agree its possibly the best place in the FiDi. 

First off the restaurant is a bit tiny but the extra room in the back does open things up a bit. And the long red clay brick wall does warm up the room. The staff is exceedingly friendly and after a few visits they will definitely remember you and know what your favorite dishes are.

The grilled eel appetizer is fantastic and the donburi and udon bowls are super filling and come steaming to your table. Contrary to what a few others have experienced, I have always found the fish to be fresh and the special rolls are huge! I tired most of the special rolls, a fair number of the maki rolls, and various items off the sushi menu and everything has been tasty. I think a place should be judge on consistency rather than a one-time random occurrence. 

A few draw backs are that the menu is not as extensive as some other places that I have been and the hours of operation are quite limited. But if you are in the FiDi around lunch time and have a hankering for sushi do yourself a favor and check this place out, it will not disappoint.
author: Lenneal G.

description: Really good sushi and great sushi bar service. The Salmon was delicious and the tekka roll was very good. Staff was very friendly and overall service was impressive.
author: Robert T.

description:
Akiko's is my new favorite Financial District sushi place. I like fancy sushi with lots of ingredients (Japanese authenticity is not as important), and Akiko's didn't disappoint.

On the recommendation of other Yelpers I ordered a volcano roll, which includes salmon, avocado, tempura "lava," and tobiko. It was complicated, just the way I like it. The tempora was excessive, there was literally a pool of it encompassing the roll. But it was tasty.

I also ordered an "A.J." roll that was simpler; it included tuna, scallions, and tobiko. It was also very tasty.
author: Adam B.

description: Akiko's is the bomb. This place has a huge variety of fishes. Lots of exotic stuff. We just told the chef to serve us eveyrthing that was awesome. I think we got around 17 diff kinds of fishes. It was delicious. So fresh. Theres a decent amount of parking around there too.
author: Cindy L.

description:
It's been a long time since I've had such high quality fish that I had at Akiko's today. I took a client out to lunch today. Although they generally do not take reservation for two, they did it for me. How nice. 

The client and I ordered Edamame and Soft shell crabs as appetizers. The client also got miso soup. We also got negihama roll, spider roll, kampachi, hirame, suzuki, and uni nigiri. 

I can probably write forever about the amazing quality of sushi I had today, but I won't. Instead, I urge all of you to give this place a try. You will not regret it. 

Minus 1 star for slow service. Note: The chef was not Japanese, but that's ok with me. Get there before noon for weekday lunch. It gets crowded very quickly.

The client loved the food, so mission accomplisihed!
author: Su K.

description:
I absolutely can't have enough of sushi! I always have to have my fish fix every now and then. Did Akiko's do it for me? Yes it did! The fish melted like butta! I came here with a friend of mines for dinner a couple of days ago after spending time with her in the city. The decor was nice and the service was great as well!

We ordered a large bottle Kirin to share to drink with our food. I ordered the sushi and sashimi combo which came with nigiri, some rolls and sashimi. It had unagi, sake, maguro, shiro maguro, hamachi, shrimp nigiri. The sashimi featured maguro, sake and suzuki. There were four pieces of various rolls as well. She ordered the same except for her combo not having sashimi. Pretty much the same lineup as my combo.

This place will be added to my "Best Sushi" list.
author: Darryl P.

description: Wow...top notch sushi in a really nice atmosphere. Went for lunch today with four colleagues from work. Everything we ordered was great - flavorful and fresh. Based on the decor of the restaurant and its proximity to Union Square, I expected small rolls for a big price. Not so. The rolls were generous and fairly priced. I'd definitely go again.
author: ron b.

description: Came here with a party of 5, and the vibe in this place was pretty good, and our server was nice.  We started off with edamame for the table, and I ended up ordering the firecracker roll.  IT IS SPICY!  As a lover of spicy food and sushi, this was definitely a good choice.  The outer layer is slightly fried, so the texture was crunchy, but with a nice soft interior.  The only complaint I'd have is that I wish the roll had some avocado on it, but otherwise...great choice.  Plus, it came with 10 pieces, so definitely you get your money's worth.
author: Liz W.

description: Fantastic sushi! Great quality fish. I love the ambience of this place. The service could be a little better though.
author: Bert K.

description:
The ambiance was definitely nice and the prices were decent but I had a feeling this place caters to a tourist crowd.  The food was pretty sub-par relatively speaking and the service was tortoise slow.

I came here last Friday to catch up with a few old coworkers right after we had drinks at the Irish Bank and luckily got seated right away.  That's always a plus.  Our orders were taken within a decent amount of time however we noticed the couple sitting next to us who had looked like they had been there quite a bit of time - got their orders taken after us.  After we placed our order with the waiter - we had to remind him to serve us our drinks and for ordering dishes that didn't need a lot of preparation, the food came out way too slowly for our hungry tummies.  

I ordered the chirashi here (one of my usuals) and I was pretty disappointed.  Luckily wasn't tough or half-frozen - it was just bland, even stale tasting.  They could definitely do a better job at seasoning the rice too.  Given the number of sushi restaurants out here in this city - this place could definitely do a lot better.
author: Jean A.

description:
It's only getting one star because I couldn't give less.  
First of all, there's NO sign outside so we were walking the street looking for it for a half hour.  When we finally found the address and entered, we were met by a woman who was RIFE with attitude.  i'm a really easy to get along with person so when I asked her questions or made statements, it's difficult to see me as anything but amiable.  Everything I said, such as "We couldn't find your place, there was no sign", was met with a vapid smirk, a shrug of the shoulders, and a response bordering on snide which seemed to turn it around to being my fault.  Not a good way to make someone endeared to your place of business.
When we were finally able to pull it out of her that reservations were NECESSARY, except for her attitude, we might have been willing to come back.  BUT, it was quite difficult to get past her attitude so when she asked if we wanted their business card I was so fed up that I declined it.
NO, I will NOT be back.   If the person at the door can't be welcoming regardless of the situation, I have no interest in giving it a second chance.   Be rude to me once, shame on her; be rude to me a second time, uh uh, aint gonna happen.   And i'll make sure people know how rude the experience was.

We went around the corner to Onigilly which was MUCH MUCH more welcoming and GREAT food to boot!
author: Mike F.

description:
We came here for a friend's birthday and enjoyed it.

This Japanese restaurant is great for small parties of 5 to 10 people. The dim lighted atmosphere gives it a nice feel and complements the art on their walls. On the one hand you have great sushi, sashimi and delicious Japanese appetizers. On the other hand, I wish that restaurants disclosed more details in their menu's on the type of fish they're using. Farmed? Wild? Type of Salmon? Type of Tuna? These are beneficial to know.

Parking is a bit tough to find as it is with any restaurant that's located close to financial district and doesn't have private parking.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
Amazing auth Japanese restaurant! very fresh and taste food! I will guess if they do a better dish display for the food, this restaurant might be one of the Michelin one star. 
Akiko offer seasonal import fresh food for sushi/sashimi, and that selection doesnt make you disappoint. 
few dish worth to mention, first is the Hokkaido uni and osetra caviar! (I actually found this dish from someone's yelp review) it was a good combination,  especially how difficult to find a SF restaurant offer Japanese uni! and the price for that dish is reasonably good, $15 for a order of two piece.
Wagyu (A5+ grade)! if your budget allow, its a must try dish! $25 for order of two for sushi dish or $50 sashimi an order is quit pricy, but.....im telling you, if you want to try wagyu beef, this is it! sashimi was not recommend for wagyu, i guess is becuz too fat. I had so many wagyu beef before, most of them I had from some two or three stars Michelin restaurant, and other I had was in japan. Akiko make this wagyu beef the best I had so far, the taste and how well the meat was cooked just prefect! you will never had enough!  (again, only if you could afford it T__T )
Udon, first i wanna say I dont like Udon at all! maybe its because most japanese restaurant use the Udon noodle you could bought in any supermarket and the taste like shit when it does. But Akiko's Udon noodle was good! again, one of the best Udon I had so far.... the noodle was real chewable but smooth! very nice!

Price for a auth Japanese restaurant is alright, my bill was $150 without tips tongiht for table of 3, and we didnt have any order of drink. 

one thing was disappointed was the dessert menu suck! they only have ice cream and mochi ice cream you can pick from, and sorry, its NOT house make ice cream or mochi! so make no sense to order it. and the restaurant is hot ( I wonder do they have AC?!)

Akiko become my famous japanese restaurant in downtown! will definably come back again! ^^
author: tao x.

description: Amazing food, amazing service, and awesome ambience. By far the best dining experience I have had in SOMA, and perhaps anywhere in San Francisco. Not to mention the cost is a fraction of other options, most of which are not nearly as good.
author: Dave C.

description:
I'm going back, that's for sure.  Popped in solo on eve after having a horrible day and sat at the sushi bar.  Presuming it was the owner who I talked to - cute Japanese man, older, very sweet.  Someone took his photo for Yelp - he's adorable.   I asked for the best nigiri for the day and he gave me 4 orders of perfection.  I did need to place the order thru the waiter which was weird.

I asked said waiter for a to-go menu and he said its online . . .did I miss something?  I don't see it.  

I also asked the waiter for a tiny bit of green tea, really all I wanted was an inch of tea so it would cool down fast for a few refreshing sips.  Instead he filled the cup and I drank none.

I'd asked for a wine list - there isn't one!  STRANGE!  The same waiter gave the name of the grape, I asked for the name of the winery, and he rattled something off . . . .I opted to go wine-free that night (his loss, his tip was lower)

It's those picky things which prevent me from giving them 5 stars.  

In closing - they are hooked up with Clean Fish, a very wonderful org which helps restaurants get truly sustainable fish.  Fix the boo-boo's here and I'll up ya to 5 stars!
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
I've eaten here 3 times now and enjoyed all 3 visits. The space is very cool, the bar and a few tables at the entry and more tables on the other side of the wall - funky brick walls, but clean and aesthetically pleasing.

As usual, I let the sushi chef pick for me. He tends to come with the same fish on all my visits - his salmon is excellent, maguro and hamachi are standards. The last time I had a red snapper sashimi with ponzu that was marvelous. He also loves to serve albacore with smoked herring tucked underneath. It's quite good.

On one visit I had a couple of cooked items, including ribs which were pedestrian.

If you're in the Financial District and want sushi, don't pass up Akiko's - you'll enjoy it.
author: Lefty R.

description:
The freshest fish I've ever eaten. My company took us out for dinner as a reward for hitting our Goal. They decided to do the Omakase ( chefs choice) It was unbelievable.
How many of you have had golden eye snapper and braised Kobe beef from Japan in the same place... and yes it was no game. I left there felling like 1million bucks.
I tip my hat to the Chef (Ricky) who came to our table and gave us  golden eye snapper and braised kobe beef himself.
All in all........ amazing experience.
author: Brandon A.

description:
I went here with about 12 people for a friend's birthday. While the place is small and has a cozy feel, it was surprisingly comfortable. The decor is pretty cool with an underground feeling to it. There was some cool artwork hanging around the place as well. 

I had been munching on food all day so I decided to just get a rainbow roll. Half hour later, while everyone else had gotten their food, I was still waiting. "Strange," I thought to myself. "Other people ordered the same roll but why was I left out?" I inquired with the waiter and he wasn't sure either but he apologized and went to get my order right away. Then, one of my friends realized he had eaten my roll. I felt bad for the waiter since it wasn't his fault my food had not arrived. I explained this to him but to my surprise, our server was extremely kind and offered me a complimentary drink. Huge plus in my book!

Anyway, back to the food. The roll was very very tasty. Fresh fish and well balanced with the sauce. Quanity-wise and with a normal appetite, this would not be enough to sustain me. I wish there was more since it was $12. 

I am very impressed with the outstanding service here! Food is great though I wish there was more of it. I would definitely come back again when I have a bigger appetite.

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Had an early dinner here and it was awesome.  I really like how they brought out one plate at a time so you can enjoy each course before they brought out another.  I hate it when my food gets cold when restaurants bring it all out at once. 

On to the food, each dish was pretty good! Definitely order the hamachi kama and toro!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Best Sushi place in SF! Everything is fresh and delicious. It's all about the Black Tuna from Japan
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I like this place ! the food is fresh, delicious and the environment is cool! really good for friends reunion.
author: Coco S.

description: Ate here like 3 years ago. A little pricey, not super great.
author: Michael E.

description: Best sushi I have had in the city.  Seaweed salad was awesome.  I can't wait to go back here.
author: Sarah S.

description:
This is where you come for fresh fish, with many exclusive items, straight from their connection in Japan.  Akiko's takes pride in the fact that the fish they serve is unique, fresh and sustainably caught.  Many of my favorite items on the menu are cured and prepared in house (i.e. ankimo, ikura, smoked uni, amaebi).  Love the sushi rice, love the pickled wasabi, love that they have had Wagyu beef lately and have been making beautiful things out of it.  This is my "go to" spot for great food, no limits.  
If you ask for the Omakase (Chef's choice), they will blow you away; if you ask for Ray, he will educate you.  He can explain to you where each fish came from, what is special about it, how it compares to other fish, and what to expect when you taste it.  Ray is very passionate about food in a way that is inspiring to see.  His passion is communicated, to the diners at Akiko's, through the information he shares, as well as the the care with which each dish is prepared and presented.  
Remember to make a reservation, this place is getting harder and harder to get into, even mid-week.
author: Kiana B.

description:
holy crap this is delicious! 

I came here with 6 people total at 7pm on a Tuesday no reservations and we were seated immediately. Score! 

We ordered basically family style - 6 people, 8 rolls, and plenty of drinks. I wasn't a fan of their cocktails, but I'm not of fan of sake. All of our rolls were delicious. I used to be a CA roll only girl - not anymore! I'm all about the Dynamite roll and spicy tuna! 

Be warned, the edamame they put on your table is not free. It's $3. We told them that we didn't know that it wasn't free and they took it off the bill no problem. They didn't even look at us funny or question it or ask if maybe someone else ordered it and didn't say anything. No hassles whatsoever.

The server even broke out our receipts for us so that we could pay for what we ordered. On my bill: 2 rolls, 1 appetizer, 2 drinks - $51 including tip. I paid for myself and my sister so that came out to $25/person. Totally worth it in SF.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Good sushi, especially for being downtown. Really flavorful Ikura and buttery hamachi. Ambiance is nice - I've been once just for drinks in the back/booth area but the front tables are also nice - gets a lot of sunlight.
author: Nami S.

description:
As a SoMa resident, I am often underwhelmed by the number of decent restaurants that are open in the evening. And, as you can tell by my nickname, I really enjoy sushi. So when I discovered Akiko's Restaurant, you can imagine that I was pleasantly surprised. 

My bf and I sat at the sushi bar so we could watch the chef. It was an older looking japanese man as the head chef with an older woman as his sous chef. (Perhaps a married couple business?) He was a bit gruff, but throughout our meal he slowly warmed up after we chatted him up a bit. 

The menu was simple. We ordered 3 rolls and some nigiri. The vivi was an unagi and white tuna salad with a garlic sauce. I'm not a fan of saucy sushi, but this was not too over-powering and delicious. 

We also ordered the rainbow roll. I typically dislike crab salad, but he mixed it up fresh right when we ordered it with japanese mayonnaise, and boy did that make a difference! I was really yummy! The fish on top was very delicious too . One of the white fish was so good that I asked the chef what it was (Tai - red snapper) and ordered a Nigiri!

We also ordered the spicy tuna roll, which was a bit too spicy for me. I don't mind spice, but when I eat sushi, I want to taste fish. 

The Hamachi Nigiri was like butter!

It was maybe a teeny bit more expensive than Sushi Toni, but the quality of fish and ambiance was worth it. 

All in all, good food, good service, and good price.
author: Kealie G.

description:
I don't wanna offend anyone, but this place looks almost gross and shady from the outside. But don't let that bother you at all, because as soon as you walk in, you'll see that it's not only very clean, but well-decorated and classy. 

There is very few seating in the front room, which includes the bar. The back room has more seating, but it's a pretty small space, so be ready to be overheard by your neighbors (ie: don't come here to discuss very private matters). 

The food here is delicious! As many people have mentioned, you can't come here and not order the Volcano (I think it's $14). It is phenomenal. So much fried goodness that is poured on top of the rolls in the shape of a volcano. The salmon here is delicious too-- not fishy at all. Where do they get their fish? I wish every sushi restaurant got their fish (esp the salmon) from where they do. 

I almost want to say they're expensive... but I should hold my tongue because what sushi place won't have you spending a minimum of $15 on lunch? I guess what I wanna say is, they don't have any of those $9 lunch specials. But oh well, those lunch specials at other restaurants sometimes just give you crappy CA rolls to fill the space. 
A lot of the appetizers, like wakame salad and tempura, are ~$6.
Rolls range from $6-14. 

The servers and chefs are friendly, and plus, I have a special place in my heart for this restaurant because Akiko is my sister's name! Thank you for repping, Akiko's Restaurant!
author: Saori E.

description: If you're coming here, do not bother getting rolls because the sashimi is so fresh.  It just melts in your mouth.  MUST TRY THE SPECIALS because they are from the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo.  Also try their broiled fish head special - really fun to pick apart in family style dining.  Our server was knowledgeable and attentive.  They did run out of some of their fish, but this just highlights how in demand their sashimi is.  Be ready to spend $50 - $100/ person.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Good food.  Nice space.

but unfortunately TERRIBLE lunch service.  Never again.
author: Java Z.

description: Great price and surpisingly delicious sushi!
author: Allison S.

description:
How many foods can you think of that you crave on a regular basis but are still pretty healthy? How many of those can be prepared and served quickly so that you can be back in the office in under an hour? There's a reason why sushi is the second* most awesome thing ever to come out of Japan.

Akiko's serves fresh, properly cut sashimi and nigiri, all the rolls that we're used to here and some we're not (ever had pickled plum and mint in a roll? it may or may not be your favorite but it's worth trying.) The noodles are generously portioned and tasty as well.

Akiko's only falls short on price (it's fair considering the quality but not a value or someplace I could afford to eat every day) and service (At least in my last couple experiences. YMMV) but is worth a look if you work nearby.

*The '70-'80 Toyota Landcruiser Wagon (FJ55). Did you really have to ask?
** I forgot about Godzilla. Sushi is third and the Landcruiser is second.
*** MUJI and Beard Papa and Guitar Wolf are probably somewhere in the top ten but by no means above Godzilla or sushi or the any of the Landcruisers until '88 or so when they became lame overweight luxury SUVs. They are beyond the scope of this review.
author: matthew r.

description:
The decor is fantastic as is the service. Our party (4 Japanese Americans) ordered sushi, udon, sashimi, tempura and it was all good. We all were impressed by the quality, flavors, and portions.

Will definitely come back!
author: Miharu Y.

description:
I came here with my wife on a lark since we were staying in the hotel next door... we couldn't have picked a better place for our last meal in San Fransisco.  

We were already pretty drunk by the time we got there, so after ordering our first round of nigiri, we just let the chef figure out what we should eat. We ended the meal with something he called "special balls." I think he was fucking with us because we were getting him a little drunk too. Whatever they were, I would eat his special balls again.

Price was pretty good, eventhough we went through three rounds of food and two bottles of sake.
author: Matt W.

description: Went here for the first time lunch - we had the sashimi special - it was okay but nothing special.  The service was excellent, perhaps the rolls are better.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Akiko's was like urban legend for a while. Raw fish in the FiDi? Impossible. I had it bookmarked for months, not truly believing that it really could exist. The possibility of eating healthy slabs of unfettered sashimi daily called to me though, and I went straight to the source with Tinna H and Keane L for lunch.

We started the meal off right with a cold seaweed salad. It was an unbelievable color of green with just the right amount of crunch and a cold tangy sauce on top and little sesame seeds sprinkled around. A good sign of an amazing meal to come, right? My sashimi arrived, all colors of fleshy pink and layed out for my eyes to savor.

$18 later though, I felt a little gouged. The fish just didn't sing in the way that I was craving. Luckily, Otoro Sushi has just opened right around the corner from my house. Fresh fishies, I will have you yet!
author: Nicole G.

description: Not only did the sushi selection encompass a variety of palettes but the fish was fresh and succulent! We ordered multiple sushi rolls, including the Volcano, Avocado and Salmon, and Forty Niner rolls. All of them were amazing, as well as the numerous orders of nigiri we selected. I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu. I highly suggest this establishment!
author: Rona R.

description: Sushi was just alright. The hamachi I ordered wasn't fresh and had a slight smell to it. The servers took forever to seat me and follow-up on my requests even though the restaurant wasn't crowded and they weren't helping other tables.
author: Grace G.

description:
Looking forward to a lovely sushi dinner after a long work week and shopping with the boyfriend. A beautiful San Francisco fall evening, we were both high on life. 

Sadly, we walked in to this adorable restaurant a few minutes after it opened. It seemed promising, great music playing and nice decor. Made us sit by the front window even though we asked not to (cold!) but I think this was to entice people to come in since it was only 5:30.

Both starving, we quickly order calamari to start and some wine and beer. After 20 minutes, waiter comes back and takes our sushi order. still no Calamari... our starter... hmmm..

20 more minutes go by(getting angery at this point from hunger) and finally one sushi roll comes out... STILL NO CALAMARI! what the heck? 

As I watched my boyfriend eat his roll  as mine was vegetarian, I began to wonder why everyone else there now had food(we were the first ones to arrive!) and we still had not received our appetizer.

My chefs vegetarian selection FINALLY comes out, with the calamari(which sadly, was some of the best I've ever had) and it was mediocre at best. 6 tiny avocado/cucumber rolls, two tofu wrapped rice balls, and one thin slice of eggplant and zuccini on the side. How this is a chef's selection of vegetables is beyond me... not to mention I think our server was afraid of us, as he had a girl and the bus boy take over after delivering our food. 

I was so conflicted by the great music and ambiance, but HORRIBLE service and weak vegetable rolls. I would only go back to get a to-go order of that great calamari.
author: Kate V.

description: Every time I go to a new sushi place, I get disappointed as it is never as good as Akiko's, so I decided to give it well-deserved 5 stars. The place is very fun and friendly. My advice: sit at the bar for omakase tasting menu and watch the virtuous chef cook the best sushi plates just for you. Can get pricey, but totally worth it! The rolls and sake are also fantastic! Love it!
author: Anna B.

description: Overated. Fish was not good. No hamatchi. Toro was meh. Sushi rice was too hard. What's up with that brown rice on the sushi? Had better. Save your money
author: Cat B.

description: Just OK, the service was not stellar, just as the other reviews suggested.  The rolls were just OK, sushi is probably better.  Cute decoration, cool music, but lacked on service and roll quality.
author: Aura S.

description: On my trip to San Francisco I was looking for a sushi place near my hotel and not expecting much.  Although we had to wait a few extra minutes to be seated, it was worth the wait.  We had 5 different roles and 4 of the 5 were excellent.  The yellow tail role and the spicy scallop were our favorites.  It was busy and is a small restaurant so the staff kept apologizing for the wait, but we were in no rush.  Everything seemed really fresh and had excellent taste.
author: Nick P.

description: I was the only one in the group eating sushi, but had the white tuna belly sashimi (to die for- melted in mouth!), rainbow roll (very good), spicy tuna (average) and yellowtail roll (average). Overall a good value for the $. Service was a lot on the slow side but friendly enough. Would good back if I am back in SF craving sushi.....
author: Paul K.

description: I cannot comment on the food as we couldn't order any. Nor did we get a chance to order a drink. Came on time for our 7:15 Wednesday night reservation, waited a few minutes to be seated then spent the next 20 minutes being ignored. Being able to simply order a beer would have been nice but apparently that's not on offer. A quick look around the crowded dining room revealed that over half the tables had NO food on them and they all were seated before us. Not a good sign; at that rate we'd be there until midnight just to see a hint of fatty tuna. Took the decision to abort and walked out... Got the "stink eye" from the host... yeh, my bad.....
author: S L.

description: I was in town for the Winter Fancy Food Show and decided to pick a place close to the Worldmark hotel.  Akiko's was only a couple of blocks away down Bush street and a little tricky to find(no sign, just a cool fish painted on the wall). we arrived early (8:15) for our 9:00 reservation and were promptly seated in the dining room (asked to sit at the bar but were informed it was booked). After enjoying a round of beautiful and tasty Nagiri sushi(Hokkaido scallop, NZ ocean trout, salmon and sea bream) and a couple of rolls, we noticed the bar had not filled and asked to move, which they accommodated. we then got to see the Sushi Masters at work, had many more rounds of Nagiri including black tuna, walu, house cured salmon roe and many more! Fantastically fresh with great variety, will definitely go back even though it was pricey (you have you pay for that kind of quality)
author: Brett T.

description: This was the first time that I tried Omakase and boy was it a treat.  I can't even remember everything that I had, but it was all fresh and outstanding.  If you are adventuresome open yourself up to more than just rolls that have sauces poured all over them.
author: Dan M.

description: fresh fish and good service! limited menu, but definitely worth trying
author: Lisa H.

description: Sushi's pretty fresh and melts in your mouth. The portions were well too. It's definitely tucked in Union Sq toward Chinatown, it's possible to miss it. It's convenient for lunch because I work right near there.
author: Ann V.

description: Really fresh sushi and a cool atmosphere. I had the firecracker roll and spicy sushi. Both were well seasoned but not overly so to miss out on the wonderful fresh fish that was inside. I sat at the bar and watched the guys making all the sushi... Many more items to try at my next visit!
author: Raymond T.

description:
(1) easy reservations thru open table/the yelp link to open table.  I made a res at 7:30 for 8:15, party of 2 on a weeknight.
(2) quality--good quality fish, not the highest grade but definitely some of the better fish in san fran, especially considering the union sq location that's chock full of mediocre eateries.  we ordered the spider roll (super good, fresh tasting crab), veggie tempura (perfect--super crispy outside, great big portions of thick sliced carrot, potato, zucchini, eggplant, and broccoli), and a few other rolls--sake/avacado & dynamite I think.
(3) ambiance- such a cute little restaurant, the bf and I were sat at a corner table right in the front of the restaurant with a clear view of the street.  It was a little fish-bowl-esq but still a charming little nook.  Noise level not too loud, cute cherry blossoms painted on the walls.
(4) little touches-the real wooden hashi (chopsticks) were a nice touch, so were the randomly decorated little plates the food came on (not the cheapy plastic plates you get at other restaurants).  
(5) price- not bad considering the quality of the food.  the rolls were priced reasonably, the combination teishokus a little pricey but probably worth it if it comes with all the little sides.  portions looked decent from what I could see around the restaurant.

overall, great neighborhood establishment.  Also, the service was spot on.  The two waiters were no non-sense, super polite, but very efficient.  They brought water consistently, cleared the table, didn't rush us to leave, split the check, brought food quickly, poured the soy sauce into my wasabi dish for me!, all without being too "in your face."  Would recommend this restaurant to others, will be back soon.
author: Courtney C.

description: Just went here with my wife and loved it. The volcano sushi was an amazing concoction of creamy and crunchy and the wife especially liked the firecracker sushi with its subtle favors and slight kick. We would definitely come back next time we come to San Fran.
author: Austin S.

description: I would like to give this restaurant a review but I can't.  We went to Akiko's for lunch at Noon with a 1:00 appointment around the corner.  By 12:45 we had not gotten any food and when we pointed it out to the waiter they were still not able to get us anything by 12:55.  Unbelievable that a sushi restaurant can't deliver a meal within an hour.  Do not go if you want to be waited on in a timely fashion.
author: JR M.

description:
yelp readers who are hopeless romantics, gather 'round. this will probably be the cheesiest yelp review i do. are you ready?

about a month ago, i went on the best date of my entire life. i hear the cynics begin to huff and roll their eyes, but believe me--  a cozy restaurant like Akiko's for dinner with its low lighting, plum, beige and red decor, good food, and mom-and-pop atmosphere provided the perfect backdrop. 

despite the fact that a 12-person bachelorette party was about to be seated ahead of us (they were from Toronto! they love San Francisco! they were very enthusiastic about everything!), we were seated within ten minutes on a busy Friday night.

we sat by the window at a tiny table for two. he ordered some sort of chicken teriyaki and a sake. i got the house salad and the agedashi tofu and boldly ordered a Sapporo. (i only say 'boldly' because i then proceeded to spill half of it all over the table. reaaaaal smooth, y.)

 amidst our non-stop conversation, our food was served with a delightful presentation. the tofu was fried and flavorful, the daikon shredded to perfection, and the garlic-chili sauce at once salty and sweet. outstanding.  

he was enthusiastic about the teriyaki and even more enthusiastic about our music-snob-laden discussions like whether TV on the Radio is actually a good band (WHICH they ARE).

dates are great when they are natural which this one was, and Akiko provided a very calm and friendly setting for easy and relaxed conversation. we weren't rushed, we could enjoy our food and our company without any pressure to pay and leave.

despite chemistry that could cause a bunsen burner to explode, timing is everything. so my story ends here. but i won't forget Akiko's and the nervous and innocent joy of a first real date-- go and take yourself, a friend, or someone who you want to get to know just a little more. enjoy excellent japanese food and bask in the glow of a little gem tucked away in Union Square.
author: Yaamini R.

description: Ugh! The service SUCKS! The sushi is above average, but the abysmal service ruined our night out. There are plenty of other sushi restaurants in this town. I'm NEVER GOING BACK!!!
author: Randolph M.

description: Definitely good. Made a reservation via Open Table a night before, glad I did. It was a tiny, charming place. The fish looked fresh and great. My grandfather ordered tempura with chicken, and it was great. We had also gotten the Rock and Roll and the 49ers roll, which was absolutely amazing. Although the wait for the food was long, I didn't mind because they seemed short on service and very helpful. They kept apologizing and refilling my water. The server checked on us several times, and he was very nice, as was the water refill guy. Someone next to me ordered the nigiri selection, and it looked wonderful. I would most definitely recommend the 49ers roll, it had shrimp tempura, avocado, salmon, and paper lemon. It was refreshing yet creamy, and a new favorite. Would not recommend for claustrophobic people. I would love to come back next time i'm in Frisco.
author: Kayla M.

description: The fish in this restaurant is UNBELIEVABLE. different catches all the time, super fresh.
author: Robert J.

description: This place is way overrated for the price they dared to charged.  I guess they passes they have to pass the costs of premium rent somewhere.  Extremely disappointed consider the reviews they received and their pictures can definitely be deceiving. And serving ngiri with brown rice.. wtf,. That's just not right. If you wanna to pay 5 star price for 3 star food,  then come here.
author: Oyster K.

description:
+1 star for the 49er roll alone. 

i already love joe for his california rolls (w/ furikake!), caterpillar and tempura rolls. also ume maki and inari the crazy sacrilegious firecracker roll. plus super fresh and tasty nigiri (hamachi - yum!).

now i usually like to keep my traditional edo sushi and crazy fusion rolls separate.  but the 49er roll manages to marry the best of both worlds with the shrimp tempura roll crowned in glory with fresh salmon and a tissue thin slice of lemon. perfection...

as my lunchmate said, "some sushi rolls are just magic in your mouth..."
author: Jen P.

description: something is wrong with their online reservations.  they may have turned it off?  which is odd.  can't book anything at anytime on any day. and they don't pickup the phone.  makes it diff for people to go to your place.
author: Food Is L.

description: The food is delicious, although I would say the volcano roll was a bit of an overkill. We went on a super busy Friday and the food took a bit longer to arrive than usual, but the waiter was apologetic and tried to prioritize us as much as possible (as I had to run). I would definitely come back here for dinner. Next time I hope to get more nigiri
author: Shang S.

description: This is by far the best sushi in SF! the fish is fresh, the staff is friendly... I have eaten here many times and it's always an amazing experience. Love it!
author: Vika S.

description:
The first thing to mention here is how fairly priced it is, especially given the fact that many of their rolls are served in generous portions. The quality of the salmon was satisfactory and overall had a very nice vibe inside.

Worth it if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Brian B.

description: Great sushi spot. The sashimi is fresh, rolls are delicious. Volcano roll was my fav.
author: Kathleen N.

description: nice atmosphere and staff, way over priced. better sushi in the city than this.
author: Dane S.

description: the food was very delicious, we had a salad, a roll and they were both very good. the owner was so nice, he let us dine there even when they're supposed to be closed for afternoon.
author: Ru C.

description:
Definitely one of the better sushi places with a solid selection of fresh fish. 
I'm a big fan of nigiris so that's pretty much what I got: you can't go wrong with any of their fish :) Although the unit prices seem slightly pricey but once you taste your sushi, you will understand that it's an awesome deal for the quality of fish they serve you. At many sushi restaurants they try to stuff you with rice, the nigirs here are made the right way, a beautifully sliced piece of fresh fish tightly hugging a small portion of rice with fish overhanging on both ends. 

Awesomeness! Start with an appetizer, get as many nigiris as you can, and finish off with a miso soup :)
author: Ryan C.

description: I know the food is good and delicate (aka a reeeeaaaaal small portion), but the wait is SOOOOOOOOO longggggg. What took the chefs so long?! There were not even that many customers in the restaurant when we came. I don't think the dishes are actually worth the wait. I would give 4-star for the quality of the food. But...the experience just pissed me off.
author: Chen C.

description:
Went for lunch while in the city for training - attracted by high marks in Yelp and proximity.  

Small place - pretty cramped and pretty loud as a result. The service today at lunch was really slow - the food was terrific, but served so late that I had a miserably short time to enjoy. Nobody should have to scarf down tomo...

Food might be good, but experience is important. Just A-OK.

I'd go back to try again, but only if there is no hurry to get back. You'd think an hour was sufficient time at a sushi joint.
author: Topher M.

description: The salad (house green). The wine list (sauvignon blanc) . My two sushi rolls (Dynamite, Firecracker). The service (so nice). The space (not loud on a Friday night in Union Square). The prices ($40 per person). All stellar. Such a find.
author: Catherine C.

description:
I love Akiko's. If you're considering eating here, stop reading this review and call them right now to try to get reservations - sometimes they don't accept walk-ins because they're too busy.

To sum it up:
* Very fresh fish
* Talented chefs
* Excellent service
* Fair price

Their market menu has a lot of tasty things from overseas you won't find too many other places. They have a great selection of rolls and drinks. They also offer non-seafood entrees and even cater to vegetarians. Great place!
author: Shayan K.

description: Great atmosphere and the best Sushi I've had in a LONG time, I am from Memphis after all.  This was a recommendation from a San Franciscoan friend of mine.  I'll definitely be back there on my next visit.
author: Jeremy W.

description: Extremely fresh seafood and great ambiance.
author: Naomi L.

description: Unbelievably incredible fish.  Scallops, dumplings so frickin good!  Just go.  Just go.  Anyone lucky enough to live this close to "clean" water should appreciate this one.
author: Zenobia R.

description: Amazing rolls.  Spicy tuna has a hint of lemon grass.  Volcano roll is a real treat.
author: Allen L.

description: perfect everything. an absolute must. impeccable service and marvelous sushi. a wonderful experience overall. putting this one on my must list for San Fran visits, you're wise to do the same.
author: Puny P.

description:
Thank you, Yelpers!  I was picking up some much-needed kitchen gadgets at Sur La Table this afternoon, and had the forethought to ask Yelp where to get decent sushi in Union Square.  Et Voila!

The quality of the sushi was quite good, and the restaurant has very pleasant ambience.  The service was a little slow, hence the four star rating, but otherwise, it was just what I was looking for!
author: Soo S.

description:
Delicate. Fresh. Wide Selection.

For a small, interesting decorated place, they were able to handle many tables at once. I loved the escular, or butterfish. Our rainbow Roll was also fantastic! Wasabi is really fresh and excellent. 

Fairly priced. Ask for what's fresh from the waiter. 
I'd like to check out their donburi.
author: Jack C.

description: The fish was not bad.  One of the pieces of tuna felt a little too soft like it's been out too long.  The bar seating was a little awkward because there was a cabinetry sticking out.  Get a table if you go there.
author: Byron L.

description: "Walked in, waited 4-5 min. About 3 staff glanced at me. I was a party of 1, no one else waiting, and not offered a seat. I left and went somewhere else."
author: Tracy T.

description: I LOVE SUSHI, and I love Akiko's.....  I've had sushi now from the east cost, to the west cost, and almost every place in-between.  Akiko's first impression is a small, quant, and very desirable.  Even at 1:00 the place is packed, and we had to wait for 10 min or so, while as many as eight other groups came and went due to the wait time.  Wow, was the wait worth it.  By far the freshest sushi I've ever had.  All my senses were awake at Akiko's.  I loved looking at the inside art, seats, plating.  I enjoyed the cheerful conversations that were going on all around us and the smells were heavenly, but the Taste of the Food is the main attraction of any restaurant.  If you're reading my review, please take time to wait if one is required, but make sure to try this place out.
author: Kevin M.

description: Wonderful service and attention to detail. Best sushi I've had in the city so far.
author: Cary Elizabeth L.

description: love, Love, LOVE, Akiko's!  Their sashimi is fresh and delicious.  The servers are always well informed and offer suggestions of other items you make like based upon your selection.  Also who doesn't love a sake box?  Akiko's keeps with tradition in preparation. For those of you new (or masters) to the sushi world, I would recommend this place.  Sit at the bar, so you get a view of the chefs at work.  Very fun!
author: Adrienne O.

description: Best sushi I've had hands down. It's not cheap, but it's worth every buttery morsel.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
You think with SF's relative proximity to Japan, there would be some great Japanese restaurants, but sometime this is not the case.

Akiko's is a rare exception. They are solid. Nothing fancy, but they're always tasty, and they're reliable. Personally I'm not a sushi person, but the chicken teriyaki is really good. 

Great service. Great prices (other Japanese places in the area charge ridiculous rates for some of their dishes.) It has a family owned charm and the decor has a  pretty funky urban/church thing going which is cool.
author: Aaron F.

description: I had a great experience in this restaurant. The food was exceptional. Definitely the best miso soup I have ever had. Food presentation had a creative edge which enhances your dining experience. Great food with great service. Definitely a 'must go' Japanese cuisine lovers!
author: Shuchi B.

description:
The food is great. Just hard to get. The last three times I tried to eat at Akiko's didn't go so well. 

1.) They were out of hamachi and the take-out order wasn't ready when they said it would be. We waited for another 30 minutes.

2.) We were turned away by the hostess who told us the kitchen closes at 9:30. It was 9:32. 

3.) They didn't answer the phone. When we showed up they told us take-out would take over an hour. 

Again, the sushi is really good. Just not worth the trouble.
author: Ryan T.

description:
I came here on a Saturday nigh with last minute reservations after running a quick-and-dirty query on yelp for "yummy sushi". 

This place is right around the corner from one of my absolute fave places, Gitane, and since I walked through Claude Lane to get to Akiko's, I arrived in a great mood. 

I was immediately lead to the back "main" room and seated upon walking through the front door and within a few minutes, a couple glasses of water and a bottle of sake seemed to automagically materialize from thin air. I was really taken with the level of service at this family-run joint b/c it was prompt, friendly, and helpful without being intrusive or overbearing. I chose this place b/c I initially figured it best to have something "light" but in my heart of hearts, what I was really craving was udon. Nabeyaki udon, to be very specific, from Sushi Tomi in Mountain View. So imagine my delight when I saw the "Duo" section listing combinations with sashimi. Who offers udon with sashimi? I mean, really.  At any other resto, I'd probably be stuck trying to split a full udon order with a friend and subsequently, begging for scrap pieces of sashimi.  When the waiter came by, I asked what kind of udon the duo was and he mentioned the kitchen could add chicken or whatever I wished to it. Meekly, I asked if it would be possible to convert it to Nabeyaki w/ poached egg and I nearly exploded with joy when he agreed it could be done and assured me it wouldn't be a hassle (sometimes I feel a bit bad for 'customizing' orders). 

My friend was tasked with ordering the sake and we had the $15/bottle of Hakushika. Neither of us are sake conniseurs and to be very honest, it was between this or a $32/bottle and I wasn't in a spendy (AKA: drinking) kind of mood but we were both very pleased with this selection. It was palatable, not too sweet or dry, was smooth, had some character and it wasn't so complex that you felt like you were drinking something you were unworthy of. 

While the udon I had appeared small, it was practically bottomless. SO MUCH FOOD. I guess I wasn't expecting there to be more seafood at the bottom b/c I was so happy with the veggies/meat/egg already. The duo came with maguro and sake sashimi and on the side, we ordered some type of hamachi (after finding out the kampachi was sold out). My friend had the chirashi which seemed a bit on the smaller side but then again, it was also less expensive (at $18) than most other chirashi bowls I've come across. The fish was fine and while I enjoyed my sake sashimi the most (despite not being a fan of salmon), I don't think I had enough of the fish to make a call on the quality of the fish. 

The only thing I would pick on is the restroom's door. My friend went to the restroom and returned, claiming it was occupied. "I didn't see anyone head that direction" I replied. "Neither did I". Hrm.... about 8 minutes later, I went to the restroom myself, turned the loose knob a few times (it didn't 'catch') and pushed the (heavy!) door open. Ahhhh, I see. Then the thing slammed behind me and I felt bad for the party sitting 4 feet away (altho they didn't seem irritated nor did they seem to mind). Of course, I returned to the table with a smug look on my face and my friend greeted me with much eye-rolling before making his 2nd trip the restroom. Hah :D. 

Again, service was fab. The busser was great when it came to refilling water glasses, the water carafe, taking away dishes, wiping down small spots of soup on the table, bringing extra spoons for dessert, and so on. I guess I take notice of such things due to my days of slaving away in the resto service business. 

Wonderful, atmospheric little gem in the FiDi.
author: Ida C.

description:
This is the best sushi place I've found in the city so far, seriously. I don't even want to write a review about it. 

Just make sure you check their hours. They're really weird.
author: Mike G.

description: This is a sushi resaurant that even adventurous sushi lovers will find something new to try and enjoy. The fish here is esecially fresh and you can find items on the menu that you will not find in most other sushi restaurants. Tokujyo Uni (Russian uni from Kaigara Island), Madai (wild black sea bream), Ji-Kinmedai (cold-smoked golden eye snapper) and Nama Sake (first-run wild copper salmon) were all on the menu during our visit and each piece was ethereal. Our server was an excellent guide through the menu and was very knowledgeable about each item. The sake list is also well-curated. The restaurant is very small, so reservations are highly recommended. We had the best table in the house up front by the window. The main part of the restaurant in the back is very tight and a bit claustrophobic with no windows. You also have to deal with everyone walking thru the narrow passage behind your table to get to the restroom. Ideally, secure a table up front or at the sushi bar. We did go with our 7 and 10 year old kids, and they were able to find items on the menu that they liked as they are used to us dragging them out to good places to eat, but there is no kids menu, and I would recommend not bringing children if they are in any way picky eaters. I would definitely like to dine here again on my next trip to SF.
author: Aaron N.

description:
We had dinner here on a Monday evening and were able to get a table easily despite not having a reservation.  The ambiance is nice and the restaurant is small and quaint.

We shared a nigiri and sashimi combo, an order of gyoza, a volcano roll, and an order of tobiko.  The nigiri here is excellent, but the tuna sashimi was disappointing due to the large amount of fibrous, connective tissue.  The gyoza and tobiko were really well done and quite nice.

I don't understand why everyone recommends the volcano roll.  It's definitely tasty but you CANNOT taste any fish whatsoever.  I really enjoy spicy food, but it was too spicy for my fiancee.  This roll could be stuffed with pretty much anything and you wouldn't be able to tell due to the spiciness and the shear amount of fried crispy bits.  I think they were supposed to be salmon skin but in reality, it's just a bunch of fried batter.
