Overall, I think the food is pretty good but the poorly cut tuna bring down the rating to a 3 for me.  Also, our food took longer than I would have expected for a sushi joint.
author: Michael W.

description:
I honestly can't believe that I've been going to Akiko's off and on for two years, but then again I've had the same hair cut for about 8 years so I guess I shouldn't be so suprised that I have no concept of time...

Ray and his parent do an awesome job, and I'm still waiting for them to open a second restaurant when they arealize they're one of the better sushi places in SF.  

Two words: VOLCANO ROLL!  Awesome, even if "two words" basically goes for every sushi roll.  It used to be a little more volcanoy, but that's okay, I still love it.  

Service can be a little slow at times, but all the food comes out with care and everyone is very polite.  Great place to have a large party for food if you call ahead.  Not to mention Ray has consulted on other restaurants sushi menu's in SF.
author: joe z.

description: Took my sister here for lunch. Still the most delicious and freshest sushi you can find in the Financial District!  Both of us were in sushi heaven. Highly recommend.
author: Rosie S.

description: Udon noodle soup was watery and the broth had no flavor. Volcano roll was just plain ridiculous. Barely any fish. Tons of strange sweet fried stuff sprinkled all over it. Service was very slow. I didn't enjoy anything about my visit and would not return.
author: Eater S.

description: I love the volcano rolls, awesome. The sashimi are fresh and the atmosphere is cool too. But the staffs are not so friendly though. Anyway as long as they are not rude, they are just very polite, I still love this place.
author: Suabot J.

description:
This will be my first review on Yelp.  Yelp virgin!

I was alone so i sat at the bar.  I eat a lot of sushi and go to Japan quite often, so getting a 5 will be hard to do.  I had the hamachi, black cod, butterfish, kampachi, uni and sweet shrimp.  At first glance, looking in the sushi bar glass counter isn't very impressive.   Everything i ordered was very fresh.  The red snapper and maguro looked average, although i didn't try them.  The black cod was really good, but is probalby seasonal.  The uni was very fresh and had a deep orange color.  Prices were ~$5/2 pieces.  Special sushi was $8.  I went on a Thursday night; it was pretty empty.  Overall, I was satisfied.
author: Rich C.

description: Very fresh rolls and convenient for after-work crowd in financial district. Great ambiance. Reasonable price for the area. get the 49'ers roll.
author: Jenny Z.

description: Super tasty sushi that was uber fresh and quite inventive.  Everything had an interesting little twist to it and I basically loved everything I had.   It was a tad pricey for lunch, but thats kinda what happens at any good sushi spot for lunch.  Will definitely go back.
author: Mike H.

description: Chef special is the only way to go!   Not sure how we will be able to go back to regular sushi restaurants after this!
author: Angie K.

description:
I'm definitely a fan! Went there for dinner on a Monday night, and there was plenty of seating. Ok...it was raining outside, so that might have something to do with it. I have to warn you that the service is pretty slow. However, they make up for it with amazing sushi. 

They have some pretty good rolls. We ordered the Dynamite, Volcano, and the 49er. Along with that we got some maki rolls and some nigiri. The sake nigiri was great! We definitely could have done with more of that.  Among the rolls, the 49er was our favorite. Good thing we were a bunch of 49er fans! The maki, however, was a bit disappointing. Again...not in quality or taste, but in size. 

Regardless, I really like this place. The prices are on par with other such small sushi restaurants like Red Box Sushi. The quality is pretty damn good. If you're in the area, definitely hit up this joint and order a 49er.
author: Samir P.

description:
Holy crap.

In a good way.

I was feeling like sushi for lunch yesterday and I yelped this place.  There were some recommendations for the volcano roll, so I ordered that and the seaweed salad, figuring that was a good size meal.

Little did I know, the volcano roll is Ginormous with a capital G.  I don't even know how to spell ginormous but that's what it was.  It's got tons of goodies and the rolls are cut and stacked into a pyramid with tempura and salmon skin all around and crab on top.  Like an erupting volcano.  Love love loved the presentation and it was frickin' delicious on top of that.  It was quite possibly my favorite sushi roll that I've ever eaten.

After a seaweed salad and half the roll, I was stuffed.  No worries - I finished it for lunch today.  Mmmmmmmm!

The restaurant is really cute with cool decor.  Very fancy looking.  With prices to match - no lunch specials and the volcano roll was $14.

Minus one star for slow service.  I'm hesitant to do this because our rolls really were pieces of art, but does it really take over half an hour to make two rolls?  There was only two of us in the restaurant, after all.
author: Nilar H.

description: Eating here was a wonderful experience.  Ricky was my chef and he did not disapoint.  I asked for an Omakase not knowing what to expect.  Ricky did not disappoint.  I hartily suggest coming here and allowing the chef to take you on a wonderful tour of food from the sea.  Thanks Ricky, The Rock Star.
author: Tom M.

description: Make a reservation, even if you are going for lunch.  We were lucky and got a table at the last non-reservation spot open at 12:30 on a Friday.  The food was excellent, really fresh and well prepared.  They give you a tiny little portion of soy sauce and don't leave it on the table, so we had to ask for that, but they were nice about it.  Maybe it was just busy, but the service was slow as hell.  Nice bar menu and great location.  I'll be back.
author: Jamie R.

description: We were able to get in at the last minute for a 6 PM seating, however, as we only had the table until 7:30, we were told we wouldn't have time for omakase.  Luckily, our server Alan offered to give us a "fast" version of the omakase, and boy did it deliver.  There were a few misfires, as nearly any omakase will have, but some of the highlights were among the best pieces of nigiri I've had - and this coming from someone who goes to Tokyo at least once a year.  If I'm counting correctly, we were treated to 16 pieces of top flight nigiri over about an hour and 15 minutes, and the presentation was spectacular.  Highlights included the baby shrimp with caviar that had an incredible texture, searred chutoro that was topped with charred uni (needs to be tasted to believed), and of course, the miyazaki wagyu topped with truffles.  While expensive, it's still cheaper than most top flight omakase experiences in New York, LA, and Tokyo, yet delivers a fantastic sushi experience for even the most practiced palate.  If you are someone who likes rolls and can't appreciate the different between colored horseradish and grated wasab, you might say Akiko's is "overpriced."  However, if you are someone who truly loves sushi, I'd be hard pressed to think of a better option for straight nigiri in San Francisco than Akiko's.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Why aren't there 6 stars? I have just had an amazing sushi experience that deserves far more then 5 stars.

A few disclaimers: I am a sushi purist, ie I hardly ever eat rolls or pre-selected sushi combos and I don't put soy sauce on pieces that don't deserve soy sauce. When my mother was pregnant with me, all she craved and all she ate breakfast, lunch and dinner was sushi (I'm 30 so they didn't know any better back then). Finally, I am from NY and since moving here 2 years ago have been wholly disappointed in SF's sushi offerings ... until today.

The sushi here is very fresh and delicious. The seaweed is very crisp - as it should be. The ika was sliced thin and scored a ton - as it should be. They were almost out of hirame and offered me an alternative that was truly comparable and outstanding (for the record I ordered 2 orders of hirame and got the last order available and one of the alternative). The ikura was sweet and not at all fishy tasting. The white tuna literally melted in my mouth...twice...I had to order another order it was so good. 

Finally, they had not one but two unfiltered sake options - my personal favorite - including one by the glass.

I have found my favorite sushi place in SF. NY better watch out there is some actual competition out here.
author: Alessandra S.

description:
3.5 stars

1.5 stars taken off due to subpar sashimi and no house tea being served with dinner. 

Love the interior of this place. A bit cramped but the vibe and modernity of the place stands out. I got 3 things: the 49er roll, the rainbow roll, and the 6 piece sashimi (2 types of & salmon). This is not one of those places with insanely good sashimi, but at the price point, I did not expect that. The creativity and flavor of the 2 "non traditional" rolls was fantastic. The 49er roll was the better of the two and one I highly recommend. The rainbow roll was truly colorful, as rainbow rolls are supposed to be but are often not, and was also delicious. I highly recommend this place for a sushi fix and a nice ambiance, but don't expect world class sashimi.
author: Ravi A.

description: super yummy sashimi!  its a low key environment with high quality food...i'll be back
author: Greg T.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant in Union Square area.

Consistently great sushi with fun specialty rolls.  

The Volcano Roll is an huge mountain of spicy salmon maki covered in fried salmon skins....  Off the charts.

A big Saporro and you are good to go!

Head chef greets all guests with a smile and parts with a good evening.
author: Joel L.

description:
I tried this place before an event and was very pleased, as I'm usually pretty picky about sushi places.

The atmosphere was nice and typical of that of a sushi restaurant. Nice decor, attentive wait staff.

They have a "Market Fresh" menu as well as their normal menu. I was more than pleased with every dish we got, and this place more than satisfied my penchant for spicy, crunchy sushi. 

Highlights:
-Sake sashimi (literally melt in your mouth salmon)
-Volcano roll (not just a roll, but a bowl!)
-Firecracker roll
author: Lina L.

description:
OMG the best chicken noodles soup EVER!!! 
the sushi was great too! 
the chef is Japanese, cares about each dish , cares about costumers. 
its a small place, very intimate. 
at 8pm the place was kind of empty but 40 minutes later it was packed. 
we will definitely come back ASAP!!!
author: Keren M.

description: Wow, as a local I was surprised how good the food was here. Service was good as well. The sashimi was so fresh and the variety was great. There were a few things they didn't have but all in all the fish was amazing. They were accomodating as well. I will be back for sure and I am picky when it comes to sashimi. If you are in this area, go here for sushi--no other options are worth it. Ask for what you want and you will get it like hot edaname etc :)
author: Susan F.

description:
Great Japanese restaurant.  decor was really great, felt modern but had traditional Japanese architectural components all over to give it that true Japanese feel.  We got the 6 piece chef selection for the night, a sunomono salad, and the rainbow roll.

Sunomono salad was spectacular.  the seasoning was so good and there were tons of sliced octopus that was fresh, and the texture was spot on.  they had a different preparation of the cucumber than i'm used to, but it was really delicious.
The chef selection was really delicious, and preparation was different for each one of them, so you get exciting taste on each piece of sushi.  Everything tasted very fresh, but i noticed that it was on the colder side.  so i was skeptical about how fresh the fish actually was.  but it was good and i didn't get sick (sure sign it's good).
We were still really hungry so we ordered the rainbow roll.  it looked the best out of the rolls offered (since we weren't feeling like spicy stuff).  we weren't expecting too much, since i don't consider california roll as anything sushi-like, or Japanese-like.  well, we were really surprised.  it was really delicious because they used REAL crab.  YAY!  they also used larger slices of cucumber so you really get that crunch, and their avocado was super fresh and tasted great.  

i think the sushi chefs are chinese... not that it's bad because i definitely know non-Japanese sushi chefs that are great.  i just felt a little dumb greeting the chefs in Japanese...

it wasn't the best sushi i've had.  i'm all about my sushi imari and san shi go, so it's hard to win me over.  but i really liked this place!
author: Crystal L.

description:
Went there on a Saturday. It was pretty crowded and you needed a reservation to get a table. Thank goodness I made a reservation. I recommend you make a reservation.

The sushi was pretty good. The Gyoza was not that great but the sushi was fresh. The seating arrangements was kind of tight. You could hear the conversation at the next table.
author: John Y.

description:
Very nice!  Sat at the bar and sushi chef was great. 

Great way to spend some time with the hubs
author: Chon Q.

description: Some of the best sushi I've had. We waited 45 min for our food though... so the service did not match the quality if the food at all.
author: Mirell S.

description:
Butter.

This fish is all like butter.

Thats all I could think when I got my sashimi plate at lunch- holy wow, when sushis really good it makes me sit up and take notice.  I sat up and noticed, and have a new craving in my fidi lunches.
author: Catherine R.

description: The sushi was incredibly fresh and it was decently priced. the atmosphere is nice despite the fact that it will most likely be crowded when you arrive. The chefs take great care to make sure their rolls are done right, and it shows in the quality of their work. In particular, the Volcano roll and the ever popular Rainbow roll stood out for me. The server was a tad pushy in attempting to get us to order the cold over the hot saki, but once my foot was planted down he didn't change the subject. If you go during the prime hours on a Friday or Saturday make sure to make reservations at least an hour before hand, or you will be waiting due to its small size. A fantastic sushi shop at a decent price, never a bad choice.
author: Alexander S.

description: Yelpers have finally let me down.  Came here with high expectations but left with great disappointments. The service was slowwwwww.  We were like the the third table when we sat down and yet we we waited for almost an hour for all the four orders we placed to show up.  The waiting staff was awol most of the evening.  The sushi quality was ok.
author: Eric S.

description:
We were very disappointed by Akiko. We had to fight for service and mediocre sushi.
After reading the Yelp review, we expected good sushi with reasonable service. We got poor service with mediocre sushi. The restaurant was too full and too many takeout orders had been accepted. The service was terrible--the waiter said we couldn't get handrolls because the kitchen was too busy, didn't greet us, never checked to see how we were doing, etc. The saki was off, the sushi rolls weren't great and the fried food we ordered (tofu and tempura) tasted like the oil had been reused. Overall, we were very disappointed with the restaurant and did not enjoy it at all.
author: farrah s.

description:
Just a great experience here. Sat at the bar and I think that made all the difference. Sushi was flat out delicious and the chef could not have treated us better. 

I honestly felt it was the best meal I had in San Francisco.
author: Collin C.

description: Fantastic meal. Had chef's choice of Nigiri and Sashimi. Highly recommend trying this place.
author: Mike S.

description:
I usually rate sushi places based on the traditional, fish/rice only without all the fusion sauces to taste the freshness. This place was NOT fresh at all. The nigiri sushi was stale and fishy. I was very disappointed with both the food and the service. The waiters were not very friendly and they forgot my miso soup. The only time one waiter smiled was when he gave me my check. I would have had more respect for him if he was stern all the way through instead of the last and only attempt to get a good tip (too late).

The ambiance was nice. I didn't try their fusion rolls or cooked dishes, but it failed as a sushi joint. I would not come back as there are way better tasting Japanese restaurants with better service.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This place is great. All of the staff are very friendly. I recommend the Philly Roll although it's pretty generic, but really anything you get is very likely to be good. 

I would make reservations if you're going during lunch or dinner rush or if more than 4 people are eating.
author: Angela M.

description:
So, I wanted to update my previous review to 5 stars. Not only was the food fabulous but the usual surly waiter was actually polite, accommodating, and dare I say friendly? 

It was a refreshing change and I look forward to going back. Now I can enjoy great food and great service!
author: Emily R.

description: Really great dinner. My wife ordered miso soup, edamame, and chicken teriyaki. All were excellent, with the chicken being moist and flavorful. I went the roll route and ordered the Rainbow Roll and the 49er Roll (the Niners won the playoff game today) . I loved both, but a the 49er was one of my all time favorites. Razor thin lemon slices played off the salmon beautifully and three colors of uni roe pleased the eye. I also ordered their cucumber salad with crab. A very generous portion of crab topped the large mound of delicious cucumber slices. I would return just for this salad! Service was excellent and friendly. The owner visited and we will definitely be back.
author: Steve R.

description: This is becoming a regular after work dinner destination on a Friday: it's close enough to walk to, but feels a little more like Chinatown than Financial District. Also good for lunches, I should point out. And 8-person groups. Is the versatility becoming clear? Good rolls, good sashimi, good prices. It's on my list of favorite sushi places in downtown SF!
author: Adam D.

description:
i have been here several times with my friends and i always have a great experience here.  i really enjoy the atmosphere and the food here.  On top of that, the staff is always friendly.
Food-wise, i have sushi here every time, and the fish are always fresh.  Very consistent quality on other dishes.  i particularly fond of their volcano roll, it's one of Akiko's invention, little spicy, little crispy, and lots of freshness from the fish, quite interesting combination.
This is a real nice little gem in the Financial District, it is the choice sushi joint for me when i want to have a good time with my friends.  That to me, deserves a 5-star rating.
author: Phil L.

description:
I recently came to Akiko's for my friend's wedding banquet.  She had taken over the whole restaurant for her party of ~20 people.  Akiko's did a great job with the food, as well as serve the newly weds with special dishes of their own :)

The sushi was amaaazing.  Fresh fish, well rolled (small rolls), and creative.  The non-sushi appetizers were well made (seaweed salad, yakitori, tuna&crab tartar).  There was also an entree of miso cod, which was PERFECT.  Usually when you have a large party getting the same dishes at a restaurant, you get mediocre mass-produced food, but dear god, the miso cod was tender and melted in my mouth.

I'll definitely come here again to see what the menu is like on a regular night, but I'd definitely recommend Akiko's for private parties!
author: Wendy T.

description:
The sushi here is solid, though not as good as I remember it being when I first came here two years ago. For rolls, we had the Rock n roll, Dragon Roll, Forty-niner, and Rainbow roll. All were fine but nothing too special.

I really like the design of Akiko's. The back room area is like a wine cellar, cool temperature with exposed brick walls. It's a very comfortable place to have lunch and you can easily have a conversation with people across the table, unlike some places where the noise level is so high you have to strain to hear your lunch companions. 

All in all, a solid 3-star spot.
author: Dylan S.

description:
Absolutely believe all of the other 4 and 5 star reviews... this place has amazing sushi!!  

My wife and I went on a Thursday night and after setting up a reservation with Open Table a few hours ahead, we were seated within 10 mins of walking in the door. We ordered the gyoza for an appetizer (moist, chewy, delicious), ordered the "Pick Three Sashimi" (the cuts of salmon literally melted in our mouths), and then ordered the Spicy Tuna roll (enjoyably spicy with great fish) and a firecracker roll. 

After chowing down on all that wonderful, wonderful sushi... I just can't get back to San Francisco soon enough to get more! If you like sushi and you're in San Fran, make sure you got to this place.
author: Christian C.

description:
I am not a sushi connoisseur so feel free to take this review w/ a grain of salt (or Saki, whatever helps).  

Though it can get busy, I have always received helpful, prompt service and the food is consistently good.  Great place to have on the fi-di lunch out list.
author: Kiki R.

description: Went to Akiko for business as usual. The women in my office love sushi! I on the other hand find sushi not to be one of my favs. I ordered the tempura chicken plate, which exceeded my expectations! The chicken was flavorful, soup was terrific, and the presentation was great! My Co-workers ordered an array of sushi for the table, and were all smiles. Overall a good spot in the FIDI to get some great sushi.
author: Brandon S.

description:
This restaurant is fantastic. I've eater there at least 6 times. The sashimi is extremely fresh. I once got to try 3 different varieties of salmon, it's amazing how different they all taste.
This place is also family owned and operated. Joe the sushi chef is the sweetest man. His sons run the front, and his wife helps in the kitchen. Very sweet people.
They do get really busy all the time, but that's because the food is AMAZING. 

Also, try the black sesame seed ice cream.
author: K R.

description:
What a cute place!  
So I was planning a friend's birthday party at the last minute.  She wanted to go for sushi (yay sake bombs!)  and we had A LOT of people (22 guests!).  To find an appropriate place that would also be not too expensive and close to lounges and clubs for after dinner drinking (at the kind of place she wanted to go to) was no small challenge.  Therefore, I turned to my favorite website: yelp!  Yes I love yelp and it helped me find this charming restaurant.  

I called them on Wednesday for a Friday night reservation for 18 people.  No problem.  The 8PM time was fine with them and they were very polite and helpful.  I then called on Friday afternoon to add 4 more people to the reservation, this was also just fine with them.  Great!  

I arrived with a couple of people right on time.  The back room was all set up for us and ready to go.  The first thing we noticed was how nice the decor was.  Really cute!  The staff was also incredibly friendly and accommodating and helpful.  They even offered up front to give us separate checks and the sake was flowing.  I really have to say that I was very impressed how cool and helpful they were with such a crowd.  They have excellent waiters.  When we wanted a bit of cake or something so we could sing happy birthday for my friend, they put together a really nice plate with mango slices and green tea ice cream and a candle for her to blow out.

The food was quite good, especially for the price.  The prices were very reasonable and and everyone was very happy with the quality of their sushi.  

Overall, this was a fabulous evening and it was definitely due to the wonderful location and hospitality of the people at Akiko's.
author: Kate B.

description:
I hit Akiko for dinner at least once whenever I'm in SF.  I generally stay at a hotel right around the corner, and though there is a closer sushi restaurant, I prefer Akiko.  I always get takeout, which can take a long time (they quoted me 20 minutes when I called, it wound up taking closer to 40, though they were not busy).  The sushi chef was very nice, bringing me hot tea while I was waiting because he heard me coughing.

The rolls are tasty, especially the volcano roll which is unlike any volcano roll I've had before.
author: Bree G.

description:
Akiko's is the best sushi restaurant I have experienced in the Bay Area.  Sakae in Burlingame would previously have held that position in my mind, but some fish quality inconsistency there in recent visits cause it to fall below the level of Akiko's.  Everything we ate was first-rate in quality.

Akiko's space is familiar in that I remember eating in that space back in the 90's when it was a Mediterranean restaurant of some sort.  It is (in my mind) an optimally-sized restaurant and I like the space very much.

Service is really on the ball.  However, we didn't see any Japanese staff.  They serve tables each individual sushi item (more or less) as a single plate delivered with an explanation by the wait staff.  That is a service-intensive model, but the place is small enough they can pull that off with good timing.

In terms of taste, the house-blended shoyu (of which much is made) isn't really that special.  They might be better served by simply buying a high quality shoyu and saving themselves the trouble.  On the other hand, the taste of the blend might appeal to some people more than it did to us.  The uni they serve was absolutely first-rate, but it was just slightly too little uni relative to the nori wrapping.  So, to taste the uni, you sort of had to move it around in your mouth while chewing.  They might want to address proportions there.  We ordered one cooked appetizer, and afterward would call that a mistake.  This really is a place that is all about high quality nigiri and sashimi.  We also ordered one maki, and while it was very good, next time we won't waste stomach capacity on maki at this place.  The hara sake (seared fatty salmon) was absolutely wonderful as was really all the nigiri and sashimi items we had.  There was no keiji sake (baby salmon) the day we visited, so it just means we have to go back again very soon!

$200 (pre-tip) for two people with no alcohol isn't a bargain.  But, at least you can absolutely leave Akiko's feeling like you got exactly what you paid for.
author: Richard P.

description:
i hardly EVER write review updates. instead i usually just add onto my previous statement unless something changed. and something did change!!

last time i came here, i might have gotten food poisoning. im not pointing fingers but very high probability. i also ordered their rolls. and was very disappointed that almost every roll that i ordered was fried/cooked. 

anyway, this time i came during lunch on the company dollar. we ordered beer and sake! two thumbs up already. but the main difference this time was that i noticed that they had a separate WHITE/RED FRESH FISH of the day menu. might i also add that they had fish from TSUKIJI FISH MARKET in japan. we discussed whether radiation might be a problem. but we unanimously concurred.. F it, we live once in our lives, and we are NOT saying no to sashimi!!! on this little menu, you can order it nigiri or sashimi style. my coworker knew b/c he had been to tokyo a lot and knew which ones tasted better alone or on rice. but i would suggest you ask the waiter as he knows which is best!! 

if you know you're coming here, its a good idea to make reservations b/c its a small restaurant and they're usually crowded. 

in case you still don't believe that this place is good, in addition to their japanese servers and their wonderful chefs, the table next to me sat a japanese business man conducting his business lunch with a guy from europe. if you don't believe a chinese customer, then believe a japanese man!
author: Jen S.

description:
So delicious!!! The service was great. I am so excited to go back here!
I suggest the Dynamite Rolls!
author: Heidi C.

description:
Ray contacted me and took full responsibility for our experience and for that I am grateful.  He obviously does care about his patrons and his restaurant's image-very refreshing!  In addition he voided our check and that too demonstrated that he was sorry for what happend.
Considering all of that I will give them another opportunity since my other half a dozen visits were great!
author: Lizete S.

description:
I was not impressed and I expected more from this restaurant because fellow yelpers gave it 4 stars!
The yellowtail was tough and the rice in the sushi roll was stale. The only thing that redeemed this place was the 49er roll. The 49er roll had perfectly thinly sliced lemon with salmon and shrimp tempura.
The prices here are expensive for the low quality that is served.
author: Ben B.

description: I've eaten here 3 times now for both lunch & dinner.  They really know what they're doing here ... but a tad on the pricey side.  Just a tad.  Other than that .. this place is very simple straight up sushi.  Love it.
author: Mihae T.

description:
Aside from the fact that it's right around the corner from where I live, it's a great little place to go for yummy sushi or donburi (rice bowls).

Their sushi's always nice and fresh, and since it's right on the border of Financial District and Nobhill, it doesn't get very crowded in the evenings and weekends.

As far as their rolls go, my favorite roll has to be the Volcano Roll, it's yummy and addictive (also a bit spicy), and it does look like a volcano!  I'd highly recommend it.

I try to bring all of my friends to this place at least once, so I often show up with what seems like a different "date" (I've got a lot of guy friends) every time I go there.  I think this server who waits on me almost every time must think I have a different date every week!  :)
author: Sophia F.

description: It's a cute enough place, but having tried it once, I wouldn't go back.  We went based on the high reviews, and while It wasn't bad - it wasn't particularly good either.  We ordered 5 different specialty rolls.  I can't speak for the sashimi, but the rolls were all just kinda mushy and bland.  They looked good, and you felt like they should taste good, but they just didn't.  I thought it was just me but I found out afterward that the other two people felt the same way.  Also (and I know that this sounds petty, but it was annoying) - I shouldn't have to fight to get some pickled ginger.  We ordered 5 rolls.  There are 3 of us.  We would like more than 1 sliver each.  What is that stuff - gold??
author: L C.

description:
Simply an exquisite dining experience.  A wonderful combination of fresh, quality food prepared by talented chefs, served by a highly capable and knowledgeable wait staff.  We started with an order of shrimp and scallop gyoza coupled with a poached spinach dish, followed by a trio of amazingly fresh and perfectly prepared nigiri: amber jack, poached eel and copper river salmon.  Our 'entree' of a rainbow roll offered such a stunning array of tuna, salmon and avocado, that we decided to order the firecracker roll so that we could taste more that the kitchen had to offer.  We finished the meal with a creamy, delectable black sesame ice cream that was a perfect finish to a great meal.

One word of warning: the place is small and tables are at a premium every night of the week.  It is best to make a reservation.
author: Keith P.

description:
I've eaten here 4 or 5 times. Until now I didn't know the restaurants name. My wife worked around the corner so this was our Friday night spot.  The rolls are great as is the udon (with anything!).   But the really great thing about Akikos is the Chef. After a few visits in close proximity we walked in one night to a big friendly greeting. He was working on something behind the bar.  He walked out with a plate of rolls, asked us if we liked spicy scallops (Hell Yeah!) and presented us this platter. AWESOME! As we finished this plate another came out. I can't remember what was on it but it too was AWESOME.  
The fish is excellent and the service was great but the Chef was the best.  
I must go back soon ....
author: Graeme W.

description: Yum, yum, yum. My first time at Akiko's and I can't wait to go back. Selection was excellent and the fish was fresh and delicious. Do yourself a favor and check it out.
author: allison r.

description: The server was totally unfriendly and looked like it was going to hurt his face to smile.  The hamachi kama was terribly disappointing (both in flavor--way too much sauce) and amount of fish on it.  The sushi was mediocre according to our party of 4.
author: Jocelyn S.

description:
New favorite lunch place.  
Sushi is very fresh, the service is quick, and it's all tasty.  

Six stars for the asparagus handroll -- divine!
author: K W.

description: The...BEST...sushi...EVER!  order the Kindai tuna, it is wonderful.  Ricky took care of me after I was quickly seated at the bar.  Two Kirin, some Nigiri and 2 rolls later and it was the best night of sushi I have had.  Been around the world, have eaten in some pretty nice places, this one trumps them all!
author: Carlos S.

description:
12/4/07: Updated to 5 stars after many great visits, including parties of 10-15 people. 

My husband and I have officially made this our new sushi joint after trying many places since our favorite spot Ginza closed and we are picky when it comes to our sushi! We want traditional sushi without the haughty attitude. 

Akiko's is bigger than it looks from the outside but is easy to miss. It has an unpretentious but still nice atmosphere, fresh and delicious fish, and no sushi-etiquette nazis! It's affordable for sushi - not cheap, but I wouldn't want to eat cheap sushi anyway.

Joe the sushi chef is friendly and funny. Ray, one of the waiters, is cute and friendly, going so far as to remember our names after only 3 visits.

I hear it's mobbed at lunch but I haven't been. It's nearly empty on weeknights and busier but not mobbed on weekends, which is great because the sushi bar is always open. 

Light and delicious tempura! The potstickers are made with fish, which I didn't like that well. The seaweed salad is great. Ask for the day's fish that might not be on the menu (always a good idea at sushi joints) or do omakase (chef's choice). Joe has some very light-handed and unusual preparations of his sushi that enhance without overwhelming.
author: Laura B.

description:
I love this Restaurant!

The Udon is delicious!  My favorite is the combination Udon with Fish and Chicken.  My next favorite is the Unagi Temaki hand roll and then the Dragon Roll (Eel and Shrimp in Deep Fried Goodness).  The only problem with this place is not having enough room to try everything.  I have sampled the teriyaki and the tempura off other plates and found them to be tasty.  I love their sushi chef.  He looks over his Sushi Bar, to make sure what you are eating is up to snuff.  The staff is friendly, the food is great, the food is always fresh, and the atmosphere hovers between trendy and relaxed.
author: E R.

description:
As part of Kate B.'s large party, I would like to underscore her rave review, and add a little tidbit of my own:

In addition to being very attentive and accommodating, the waitstaff at akiko's is also quite good looking. I don't often go to sushi bars looking for eye-candy, but the selection here was top-notch :)
author: Leslie F.

description:
Akiko's is the first place I've tried sushi in FiDi & I was not disappointed.  The fish is very fresh & the portions are decent.  Dana B. & I tried the soft shell crab roll & the rainbow roll, both of which were excellent.  Skip the veggie tempura though & order more rolls!  I was also excited to see that they serve udon, teriyaki, & other "homestyle" Japanese items.  I'll have to try those on a return visit!

I will have to bring my husband back here for dinner one day!
author: Jenny M.

description:
Quality sushi at a reasonable price.  Was a bit too warm in the back room and service was a little slow, but the quality of the fish was top notch and preparation was wonderful.

Would definitely go back if in the area.
author: Tim Y.

description:
Delicious. Kind service.You won't be disappointed in the flavors.

Must get the 49er roll. Salmon wrapped with this lemon sauce to die for.

Minus one for the fruit flies.
author: Judy L.

description: Ever since my favorite Japanese restaurant Rokko burned down from a kitchen fire, I've been on the look out for a new regular place.  This is an ok place, but sad to say their tempura udon did not meet expectations.  Interesting broth flavor, but too salty.  The sashimi was fresh, but the flavor was diluted, making me think it was frozen, then unfrozen.  The highlight of the meal was the azuki bean and matcha green tea mochi ice cream.  I plan on continuing my search for "the new Rokko".
author: Nicole P.

description:
Delicious sushi. Volcano roll was awesome, tasted kind of like sushi mixed with hot wings. Spider roll also was kinda sweet and smooth. 

Service was pretty terrible. Extremely slow, unfriendly, forgot dishes and charged us for them anyway. 

Overall I would return, but expect it to take some time.
author: Cody E.

description:
Great location, nice establishment (decor, layout), good sushi and good service.

Aikiko's is a sort of a gem in the FiDi 'hood; a place that doesn't get painfully busy, has nice decor, comfortable seating, reasonable prices and decent fish.  Probably a great place to meet a friend or have a small business meeting...in fact last time I ate there with my buddy, there were some guys behind us pitching their website to a VC.
author: Oliver N.

description: Been here a handful of times. I haven't waited for a table here! I love their Udon and always try new rolls. Their cold Sake was delicious.
author: Sarah P.

description:
A long lunch of fresh delicious sushi followed by a glass of unfiltered sake with some co-workers that share my June birthday - priceless.

Back to work-  terrible terrible terrible. 

Highly recommend; even though the wait is long.
author: Milan P.

description:
I have a phobia of raw fish (well, raw meat in general).  

That being said, I cannot comment on anything that contains uncooked fish.

However, I am addicted to their vegetarian sushi combination.  The chef, Joe, is ah-may-zing, and he always has something new for me to try.  He remembers me and what I always order.  I've also had a couple of their non-vegetarian-but-cooked rolls, and the firecracker roll knocked my socks off!

Is there such a thing as sushi-rehab?  I think I need an intervention.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
I've said before that usually I enjoy a sushi restuarant based on the entire experience, so I'm always worried about choosing a hole-in-the-wall place for sushi, when what I really want is a delightful cove of treasure tucked away from the busy streets. That treasure being raw fish, of course! Indeed, my fellow yelpers did not lead me to a disappointing hole, but rather I feel more like geocacher that's just made it to the indicated coordinates and removes a rock to discover the treasure hidden beneath. 

OK, so this sushi place isn't really hidden, but you could almost miss it walking by if you didn't know where you were going. In fact, my friend kept walking even after I stopped, not even realizing we were at a sushi restaurant. His attention was grabbed more by the Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant tucked down the alley next to Akiko's. The outside of Akiko's even looks like it may have been an Irish Pub back in the day. The inside is decorated to look like a run down building, some walls half brick, half stucco, and with wooden posts running diagonally from wall to ceiling.

Bleh, I must be bored at work or something, why am I talking about the building? The sushi itself really was good, but then, I'm not high-maintenance when it comes to sushi. As long as there are enough pieces of raw dead fish on my plate, I'm good to go. I'm not really going to get all huffy about mixed up orders and slow service. Again, I'm there to enjoy my dinner, not hurry through a meal. Many thumbs up, more thumbs than I currently have myself!
author: Kimberly C.

description: My friend and I had omakase and everything was great, especially Russian Uni. The fish was very fresh. Rick San was very friendly and funny. I will definitely go back to this place.
author: Emily R.

description: The fish quality was so-so at best. And why can't they serve udon separate from the combo!? Disappointing in general.
author: John L.

description:
This place is great for lunch!  But you have to go either before Noon or after 1:30 to get seating and decent service, because they get packed like a mofo.  

The hamachi kama here is one of the best I've had, not fishy at all and the accompanying ponzu sauce is yummy.  Their dynamite roll is a good choice for those who aren't daring enough for sashimi.  Because they're busy as hell during the weekdays, the freshness of the sashimi is pretty good as well.
author: Selene K.

description: I get spoiled everytime I come here. The best, most fresh, most delicious sushi. But real sushi is what I come here for. Meaning, not the rolls covered in sauce, but amazing, melt in your mouth slices of deliciousness. Always worth the detour.
author: Lisa O.

description: Good sushi and generous portions, yet affordable. This place is a nice, low-key spot to enjoy some Japanese food. The wait staff is pretty friendly, though my service today was a little slow. I will definitely go back the next time I want to catch up with a friend.
author: Rami R.

description: Rude. Insist on turning you away at sushi counter even when there is plenty of seats.
author: John G.

description: SO SLOW. They were turning away everyone at 8pm on a saturday because the kitchen was so slammed. It took over 2 hours to get our sushi -- and they either gave us the wrong thing or forgot something everytime. Fish was good, but come on, get more than 2 guys behind the bar!!
author: Kate F.

description:
Eighteen months working in the Financial District and this is my favorite Sushi bar there.  The menu is varied and the service is snappy both at the sociable bar and the very well decorated dining room.  The staff is regular and easy to get to know.

Since I discovered this place and took my co-workers they are always clamoring for more!

The only Sushi I like better is Sudachi, but that's waaaaay out at Sutter and Polk.
author: Eric J.

description: Really solid sushi menu and a great place to go after work if your close to the financial district. Service can be slow, but it's worth the wait!
author: Mallory M.

description:
Had the pleasure of trying this place out whilst I was showing a couple of international "aunts" around.  I have to say, Akiko's is definitely worth checking out again.  I was duly impressed by the freshness of the sashimi, especially the salmon which was very creamy and tasty sweet.  We also tried a couple of rolls and the chicken udon (both decent but nothing spectacular) as well as the set meal with sashimi combo and Saba shio-yaki which was jewel of the meal.

The icing on the cake for me was the fresh wasabi.  I'm not an expert on real wasabi as most places serve the paste but this one seemed special to me.  Great kick and almost a sweetness when combined with just a small touch of shoyu.  This restaurant made me re-evaluate my disdain for SF sushi in general.  It was fairly quiet on a Tuesday night so our server was attentive and fast.  The hosts were genuinely friendly and made us all feel welcome.  Thanks Akiko, for impressing my "aunts".
author: Chris C.

description: 3 stars for the very fresh tasting sushi. Not many creative rolls. Pretty basic menu. Decent service on a busy Friday night. Cool decor.
author: Ryan W.

description:
I agree that this is probably some of the better sushi the FiDi has to offer. The fish is always fresh and comes out pretty quick. The teriyaki (sue me, I wasn't in a raw fish mood that day) wasn't really that good, especially for the price. (This place isn't cheap by any means: definitely a good idea to take the out-of-town boss there for a company-funded meal.)

The place offers a nice setting. The back room almost (un?)intentionally offers an homage to the spirit of the Kearny Street corridor. At any rate, it's comfy and quiet.

Service is a little slow, but by no means glacial. Oh, and one of the servers is freakishly hot. I probably shouldn't say so but he's seen me and my dining companions drooling into our miso so many times I doubt it's much of a surprise. Bonus!
author: Aaron L.

description:
I'm quite impressed with you, Akiko!

Not only do you have a name that's really fun to say, your food is fun to eat! I enjoyed your udon, your donburi (even though it tends to arrive a few minutes before the other dishes) and your Sushi Combo A. 

Akiko, you are fun and trendy!

(the kind of fun and trendy that doesn't involve an entire bottle of hair gel)
author: J-Meoww W.

description: Cozy ambiance. Fantastic sushi rolls. Great service.
author: Inigo M.

description: Went to dinner here last night with business associates on Yelper recommendation.  Was pleasantly surprised by the high-end Toro selections - we tried one and it was silky and perfect. Delicious seaweed salad but a rather pedestrian shrimp tempura appetizer led to a very nice selection of sashimi and rolls. All of the sashimi was fresh, firm and treated well. The rolls were well constructed and the presentation was nice, with the exception of the Volcano Roll. While tasty, its presentation was a bit of a hot mess. I didn't try any sake, but their wine by the glass list was well done and broad, albeit small as you might expect. Service was attentive and patient while we made our extensive selections.
author: Ben R.

description: I must have been starving or the food was just that great here.  I left nothing behind.  We had miso soup, edamame, dashi tofu app and nigiri/entree combo plate (each)  Good service, tiny little place.  Everything was great, no compaints.
author: Vareen O.

description: Seriously ordered 8 pieces of sushi and its been an hour now. I mention something to the hostess about it and her response: "We are not THAT kind of restaurant...we're a "slow" restaurant." WTF? Ok fine I can appreciate a "european" mentality when it comes to eating but really? It takes an hour to make 8 pieces? Salmon tasted old and fishy. Amaebi was also a little fishy tasting. Not fresh at all. Overpriced also for what you get. Don't understand what the hype is all about.
author: nyc u.

description: Pondering about the holy trinity on the wall at this comfy little joint, this is the first for me. A 50ish years old chef slices his magic with every delicious bite with his wife by his side. I really like this place cuz its unpretentious, unlike most sushi places I've been to. You can feel the love and care from this chef/owner sushi chef.
author: Diesel M.

description: Best Omakaze place in San Francisco! Nice Sake collections.
author: Nikki W.

description: Excellent sushi here--we always get the dragon roll and the volcano roll, and have sampled other rolls and a couple of the tempura appetizers.  We also tried the chicken teriyaki, I believe it was.  Everything has been very fresh and carefully prepared.  I also like the dark, relaxing atmosphere at the tables away from the sushi bar.
author: Tuesday F.

description:
I walked past this place a hundred times making my way to The Irish Bank.  I'm not sure how I missed this, but this sushi restaurant is a great find!  The maki (rolls) is reasonably priced and quite tasty.  I'm not typically a fan of California Rolls, but I like theirs because they use real (and I know it's fresh because I'm usually allergic to crabs) crab and add furikake to the rolls.  The decor is eclectic for a sushi joint.  

I rated it a 4 because service is somewhat slow.  The wait staff isn't very attentive.  I had to keep asking for water and tea and it took a while before they served the sushi, but the food was certainly worth the wait!
author: Annalynn C.

description:
Excellent sushi! Anu V. introduced me to the wonders of the firecracker roll... or was it the torpedo roll? Or the bombshell roll? Firework roll? Shoot, I can't remember what it was called, but it was really good. 

Hot tea upon arrival on a cold night and tasty miso soup to follow. Not at all crowded in the evening, though I imagine it is packed during the day with all the FiDi people on lunch break. Yum.
author: Flora B.

description:
Tucked into the edge of chinatown, Akiko's is a sushi lovers secret paradise.  The sushi is top quality and the staff is really friendly.  I always see Joe and Mary there.  Joe is the sushi chef and he REALLY knows what he's doing.  Mary is the ever dutiful wife that takes care of things in the kitchen.  They make a great team!

The spicy tuna hand rolls are a must.  The seaweed is crisp, the tuna is nicely seasoned and they never come apart on you. 

Joe gets really creative with his rolls and sushi combinations.  They're extremely busy during the lunch rush, so if you work in the area get there early.  If you like sushi, you gotta check this place out!
author: Lijay S.

description: BEST YELLOWTAIL SUSHI! hands down!...at least when comparing to sushi restaurant from where i'm from. The yellowtail was just so fresh and melts in your mouth, and I just can't wait to go back. They also had the most amazing scallop cucumber salad that i just can't seem to find anywher else, which makes me sad because when i crave it, i can't get it.  It's a really small place and easy to miss, but when in the area; you gotta try it!
author: georrnai t.

description:
Excellent sushi!! Just went there for lunch with 3 colleagues. It's a small place so lunch seating fills up by 12:30 and the service is not super fast but we were in/out ofr there in an hour.
the food is really fabulous: we tasted 4 of the rolls and they are all excellent.  Be ready that they are not small so 3 rolls for 2 people can easily constitute lunch.
The sashimi was top quality - melt in your mouth - fish.
author: Alexandra S.

description: We arrived at 11pm and picked this place because it was still open. What a good choice! Everything arrived quickly and was super tasty. The beer/sake shot was cheap and good, the sashimi sampler was delicious and the sweet potato sushi was great to try (and tasty!).
author: Beth C.

description:
The food was okay. Yes, JUST okay. The service was borderline awful. Our server sat us in  a completely isolated part of the restaurant and proceeded to ignore us. He wasn't clear on what dishes he had already sent out and when and came over to apologize for a dish he thought he hadn't sent out that he had. We were brought water when our glasses were full by the equally as inattentive bus boy and then our glasses were never refilled.  Plates were not cleared in a timely fashion, nor was the bill brought out/picked up in a timely fashion either. 

This may be the best sushi place in the financial according to some people (people who clearly haven't been to Ozumo), but if it is, that's not saying much about sushi in the financial district.  One start for service and one star for food.
author: Dee I.

description: The waiters there are fabulous! So cute and sleek. Reminds me of lost nights in Bangkok! Yummy sushi too.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Went with three other friends at 9 on a Friday. The sushi, nagiri, and sashimi aren't definitely not your pedestrian quality - there's a distinct difference in taste... in the good way. Every tastes fresh and flavorful - you cannot be disappointed. We had a bottle of dry sake on top - great stuff.

Ambiance is also really great, and there're plenty of attractive girls that hang out here.

Not cheap. By not means of imagination is this a $$. It's definitely a $$$, closing in on $$$$.

Price: $63/person after tax and tip
Food: chef's nagiri, chef's sashimi, volcano roll, and 6 other rolls the waiter recommended
Drink: dry sake
author: Jack W.

description:
We ate here a few nights ago.

They definitely know how to do their sushi and sashimi... that was the highlight of our meal.  We ordered a bunch of rolls and some sushi and sashimi and all of it tasted good and fresh.  I haven't eaten sushi in the city in a while, but I thought their rolls were kinda small.  If i'm paying 10 dollars for a roll, shouldn't my roll be larger with like more filling (not rice)?

We ordered the in season special salmon which came with 5 pieces that cost $25.  It was good, but I thought the slices were on the small side.

The wakame salad was good.

Dumplings - not that great
Shrimp tempura - not that great
Udon - so so
Oyaku donburi - meh.  For $11 dollars, we got a lot of rice, maybe a whole small onion, one egg, and a small amount of chicken, but it didn't even taste that great.  I mean for $11 dollars, the ingredients you put in it probably set you back $4 bucks but you still couldn't make it taste good?

Sake was good.

This is a good sushi place, but I wouldn't recommend ordering anything else that isn't sushi/rolls/sashimi.
author: Lillian M.

description:
Came here with my family on a Saturday evening.  We were all looking for a sushi place near the hotel we were staying at.  The place just screamed JAPANESE.  It was quiet cramped inside, but the service was very pleasant.  They attended to us even though the place was busy that evening.  I think we were a party of 12 people.  No one complained about the service.

The food was prepared very well.  All the sushi rolls we ordered were excellently prepared.  The fish was exceptionally fresh.  It is san fran.. so you would expect nothing less.  I would recommend the volcano roll.  It is in my opinion the best roll they have on the menu.

A great spot to hit up if you're around the Union Square area.
author: Emerson C.

description: Hands down, one of the top two sushi restaurants I've ever been to. Both the food and the service were exceptional, and the ambience was perfect.
author: Christy T.

description: Me and my gf just finished lunch here on our small (1 hour) lunch break.  We were seated right away and the place seemed nice.  After ordering 5-10 min within our seating time, it took 35 min for them to bring out our sushi rolls!! You do the math, but our break was pretty much over! As we were waiting, we saw other tables continuing to get 2nd and 3rd rounds of their order without us even getting our first roll!  The sushi was good, but the service was bad and I have never had to wait so long for a simple sushi roll..ever!  The only reason they don't get 1 star is because the food was pretty decent.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Akiko's is one of those small treasures downtown that I am always glad is there. Their food is very high quality, reasonably priced, and usually pretty swift when not primetime.
Their hours have perplexed me a bit, but thats one of the many reasons I'm not in the restraunt biz...
author: Tom S.

description:
Ate here for lunch just now.  It's definitely a good idea to come early for lunch cuz by 12, them office people from the FiDi neighborhood just come swarming this place.  The restaurant itself is kinda small, so I'd guess it would fill up pretty quickly.

The decor is nice and kinda typical Japanese/sushi place; it's nice and comfy tho.  The service?  Ehh.. nothing too special to write about, just don't expect too much from them, I think....

As for the food, I think they're great.  Most entrees and rolls are priced 9-15 bucks, which I think is pretty average for Japanese restaurants.  Oh, for some reason, the tempura's tasteless.  Haven't tried their sushi though, it seems quite popular among other yelpers.  I most likely would come back to try other stuffs.
author: Erik C.

description:
This is a bona-fide family run operation - for better or for worse. The 'worse' is that the workers are all (or are mostly) family, so their attitude is more casual than other places. The 'better' is that Joe, the chef, has been running it for years, and has a number of customers he knows by name. In fact I was introduced to Akiko's by one of these loyal customers whom Joe still corresponds with, even though she nor her parents have been to San Francisco for years. 

THE TEMAKE (hand rolls) ARE THE BEST AROUND! The best deal, the best prepared and the best value. Try the Asparagus Temaki for a suprisingly sinful sensation. 

Go Joe!
author: J. W.

description: Excellent sushi! I have been here twice now. The service is prompt, and the sushi is fresh, artfully prepared, and delicious! This place is a winner and will not disappoint.
author: Chris W.

description: Top Notch.  This is one of the finest sushi places you will find in SF for money vs quality.
author: Shawn L.

description:
I had some friends staying in a hotel downtown, and after a rigorous day of biking, they didn't want to go too far to get some grub.  

After a couple of glasses of wine at Top of the Mark, we headed down hill to Akiko's, which seemed like a decent choice based on our area.

We ordered a few rolls: the vivi, volcano and rainbow.  As I've said before, I prefer Nigiri and Sashimi to rolls but my company was more the roll crowd so I just went with the flow.

The rolls were okay, out of the three the volcano was the most memorable, it certainly had a spicy kick, and I enjoyed the fried stuff that adorned it.

The vivi, I believe, had Unagi and I was kind of disappointed with the general taste of it.

I also introduced my friends to Hamachi Kama.  The collar here was a good sized portion, and not the best ever, but certainly tasty.

Had a couple of drinks and dinner for four with tip was around 98 dollars, not a bad price at all.

I do like the space here, there is something about the dark entry way with small wooden windows.  It has the feeling of previous times.
author: Adam C.

description:
I love to stop in here when I flee the office for lunch. They are very nice and the fish is great. The staff is attentive & friendly & the fish fresh. 
Not a lot of options for good fresh fish in the FiDi so this is my go-to sushi spot. Waiters aren't great on their addition, so check your bill but they are so friendly. Upon writing this review, I'll probably pop back in today!
author: Cbr A.

description:
I love fish, but one of the skepticism I have is on its cleanliness. This paranoia is deeply-embedded, but it's not so disabling that I won't eat out or anything. Usually, it's not a problem, but sometimes....

At Akiko, I wasn't hungry, so I only ordered their rainbow roll. I bit into a piece and heard my back teeth make this sharp crunch as if I had bit into sand. I immediately spat my food out. It looked like most of it was roasted sesame. To this day, I haven't deciphered what it really was, but overall I felt it was a bad move to put anything that remotely resembles sand in a roll.
author: Lily T.

description:
Very good sushi!

I ate here this evening because it happened to be very close-by - almost invisible if you don't look closely for the doorway, but I'm lucky I saw it.  I had the Wakame Salad, the Cucumber Salad, the Unagi Donburi, the Beni Toro, and the Hiramasa.  

Exceptional standouts: the two salads were amazingly good - better than I've ever had.  The cucumber salad has other... stuff in it.  Can't say exactly what, but wow - excellent.  The Beni Toro was great, as well. 

I sat at the bar, and Joe (Jo?) was friendly and made my acquaintance despite my nose being buried in a book.  Service was quick, and friendly as well from the wait staff.  I finished off with a mango mochi, which is surprisingly hard to find at other places I've been to.

I've eaten at many, many sushi places, but not too many in SF yet.  This ranks very high among the best experiences I've had, maybe even five stars after I go a few more times.
author: John T.

description:
first time we were there, i was very pleased.... i sat at the bar and ordered chirashi. the chef warned me that chirashi is 30 dollars there, and he said that instead of treating it like a 'garbage bowl', they actually put in quality pieces in the bowl. i was sold, and the quality of the fish was really good. 

so we went back there again. this time i didnt sit at the bar, and i ordered chirashi again.... however the quality of the fish was not nearly as good as the first time, and i felt like i paid 30 bucks for something i'd get at a much cheaper place...

i am kind of picky, i like when the quality of the dishes are very consistent across all my visits. and this place.... didnt do it for me.
author: Danielle A.

description: Been here several times, food has always been fresh and the nice trendy atmosphere adds to the meal. Take into consideration time to find parking if you don't live close by and don't want to use the garages.
author: Dennis K.

description: They used real crab in my California Rolls. I was in heaven. The quality of everything was superb. Service was great. All was well in Akiko's Restaurant.
author: Sean E.

description: Lived in japan 3 years: Akiko's food and staff are VERY good!!!  Sweet decor too.  Noteworthy sushi quality. Nice mix of traditional and ingenious rolls.  1 tiny negative was mundane gyoza sauce but ask for some hot oil and citrus, maybe some crushed sesame and voila! Go try, you will like it and your guests will be impressed.
author: John S.

description:
Came here on a whim for lunch and boy, let me tell you we were not disappointed. 

So much fish, what to get? TORO of course, wait...sorry no more toro! 

Sadness instills. That is, until the waiter tells me they have some special fish in at the moment.. Kindai - one of rarest blue fin tuna.

Delicious. Just so damn delicious.  (Pics below)

All the other fish was really fresh. I am a fan.

https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.198839106819407.42809.107390295964289
author: Christian K.

description: Nice ambiance, great service and good food. Would definitely return for lunch.
author: Dahlia S.

description:
Very friendly, family owned. Sit at the counter.

Decent sushi. Nice presentation.

A little pricey for lunch..
author: Amanda S.

description: My first night in San Francisco I was craving sushi. I found Akiko's right across the street from my hotel. Although they were booked full for the night I was able to snag a seat at the sushi bar. My server was very friendly and attentive. The sushi? Delicious! I loved the Forty-Niner and Volcano rolls.I talked to a few other patrons at the bar and really enjoyed my time here. I'll definitely come back when I'm in town.
author: Jake J.

description: Had we not mistakenly been to the other Akikos on Mason this review may be different. We managed to  duck in without a reservation to sit at the bar. The sushi was average and the staff a bit stuffy. Personally, I prefer unpretentious service but if you are looking for a posh, hip sushi place then this one is it.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Food is so so, and be prepared to be ripped off!  I trusted the waiter and took their suggestion to do "chef suggestion".  That is you sit in the bar and take whatever food the chef behind the bar offers to you.  It ends up more than $120 for just one person and I still don't feel that I am full.  This is my first time to this restaurant.  Comparing other Japanese restaurant in the same Union Square area, this is way a rip-off.Others only costed me $60 at most, and I felt so full
author: Al C.

description: WOW.. this place was soooo good! the ambiance was great..great design for such a small place.. the restaurant had amazing sushi. the Friend Calamari was incredible. we  had the firecracker roll.. supper spicy YUM!!! and the dragon roll was great!
author: SaraRose C.

description: Excellent sushi! Sit at the bar and let Ricky order your dinner for you - you  will not be sorry. Wow!
author: Tami W.

description: Great atmosphere, nice quaint sushi place. Very good sushi. Specialty items here not found at atypical sushi places. My new favorite sushi place in San Francisco!
author: Rick W.

description:
I used to come to this place once a year with my girlfriend every June when its near her birthday.  We rarely come to San Fran (once or twice a YEAR) and when we do, we always come to Akikos.

The first few times were pleasant and enjoyable.  They had a large menu, quick service, and reasonably priced sushi compared to the sushi places in the East Bay. But this time, i noticed that they took off a lot of the sushi rolls (im not sure about the sashimi, not too big of a fan)
i would always get the dynamite and the volcano whenever i come over but today,  i noticed that their menu changed.  Many of the signature rolls that they used to offer were gone.  I was looking forward to the spicy signature rolls, especially the volcano and the satisfying crunch that this establishment piled on top of a bed of spicy tuna roll.
Another problem (as mentioned numerous times below) is SLOOW SERVICE and a different order or serving us the food? Usually appetizers would come before the entree, in this case, an order of gyoza would be served before any of the rolls. Just my opinion
Otherwise, what we settled for was still good but the fact that our favorite rolls were gone sort of got us thinking of looking for another sushi restaurant next time we come to SF.
author: Xavier L.

description: The restaurant is big but classy with dim lighting. The staff is really friendly and accommodating. I had a rainbow roll which was pretty good and fresh. I did not like the soft shell crab (appetizer) which was cooked with vinaigrette dressing which influenced the docking of the stars. Good but nothing spectacular.
author: Sophia K.

description:
Sushi lunches are difficult in general. This place has very good food, but the service was slow (too slow for those of us with one hour lunch breaks and hungry tummies) and the food is expensive.

Maybe it's a better option for dinner.
author: Shawna S.

description:
I stopped in here with a friend after work and it was nice. I hadn't had sushi in a year and was dying to try some here in San Francisco - a city that's KNOWN for its sushi. 

I was pleasantly surprised. We shared a couple california-ish rolls and a larger shrimp role and were feeling pretty full after. 

The service was good and the atmosphere was nice for having dinner conversation.
author: Megan S.

description: I'm staying at the Hotel Triton right around the corner and was craving sushi for dinner last night, so I stopped in to Akiko's. I had a California roll and a Philadelphia roll and they were SO incredible and affordable! The California roll was rolled in this amazing toasted sesame that I've never had before. I couldn't stop thinking about my dinner so I went again today for lunch and had the same thing. The girl next to me was also raving about her volcano roll. I sat at the bar and chatted with the chef, who was so sweet. He's a sushi master!!!
author: Alyssa G.

description: I have been going to Akiko's for years and I would have rated it one of the best places for sushi in SF. Not anymore. The fish is not the same. The space is not the same. The vibe is no longer that lovely mom and pop place. It really is a shame, it was a hidden jem.
author: Heather G.

description:
I just started going here to get sushi when I'm craving it for lunch.  It's a walk from my office but worth it, especially when I call ahead.  Not only do they have fresh, tasty sushi but everyone is extremely nice and welcoming.  I love that.

So far, I've opted mainly for the sashimi/sushi combinations.  Seems like letting the chef choose always turns out nicely balanced.  The udon is huge if you get that option.

Unfortunately, it's a little too expensive to be an everyday place.
author: Russell A.

description:
kind of a small place but the staff and food make up for that. the staff are all absolutely on the ball. made sure we had everything we wanted and got us what we asked for without a pause or thought. food was great and they have some unique sushi rolls.

we came in hungry and tired.. we left happy and full.
author: Ali K.

description: I love the sushi here! I come here literally every week. With a friend or a few friends. Decent price and really great service and atmosphere. Kinda industrial setting with funky artwork. Totally reccommend it! You might walk past it so look for the hanging sign by the Irish Bank!
author: Sarah A.

description:
This sushi bar and restaurant is adorable and very San Francisco.  The waitstaff is very polite and professional and although they may not be willing to take a sake bomb with you, they will bring the Kirin and sake out in shotglasses for you with a smile and a curt little bow.

I ordered the udon, the Chef's Choice nigiri platter, and a beer with my dinner totaling at less than $30 which was truly a feat at any sushi restaurant.  The udon serving was huge and the second half served as great drunchies later that night in my hotel room.  The nigiri was good, but by no means great.  The cuts of fish were slightly larger than average and while some were super-fresh, the hamachi and shrimp were slightly dried out and not very good.

Overall, a good experience.  I'd return, but I'm sure there's better sushi out there for cheaper, especially in the city.
author: Grace K.

description: This place is a gem! It is hard to find good sushi in the TL area, but this hole in the wall, diamond in the rough quick walk boasts excellent sushi. i'll be back soon!
author: Djamila D.

description: Amazing decor, ambiance. Service was ok - struggled a little when it got busy, but they DID make up for it with a comped roll. Sushi was very good.
author: Mike V.

description: The sushi is amazing here. I have yet to find better. Sit at the sushi bar and ask the owner (or other sushi chefs) what to order. They do not disappoint! The quality of the food and creativeness of the chefs is worth every penny! I will keep coming back whenever I make it to the city.
author: Nikki A.

description: Excellent.  Sit at the bar and chat with the sushi chef.  Intimate and very friendly atmosphere.
author: Sean C.

description: I came here for the udon based on the Yelp reviews I recently read. The udon to be quite honest was nothing special. It smelled like matzo ball soup and tasted kinda like chicken noodle. I have had better as far as udon goes for sure. The staff however was really nice so they get points on that. It is after all a sushi restaurant and not an udon place.  As far as the sushi goes I just tried the hamachi sushi. I don't like that they put a piece of lettuce in between the rice and the fish but the fish itself had really good flavor...not the melt in your mouth kind of yellow tail but a really solid taste.
author: D K.

description: Awesome sushi. Try the 49er roll, has a slight picachones flavor :)
author: Adolfo W.

description: Once again, a very small restaurant, but it's very nice. The setting is very cozy and romantic. There's a candle on every table so it's like you're having a candle-light dinner :) There's only one sushi chef and one waiter. The waiter is very nice and friendly. Their sushi is pretty good and they not only serve sushi, but also udon. They couple who sat next to us were eating it, and my boyfriend told me to ask them if it was good.. but I was too shy, so I didn't ask. But it looked pretty good to me. Anyway, back to our food. I had these two rolls and they were so good. My boyfriend had this bowl of sashimi on rice and he said it was pretty good too.
author: Thao A.

description: Located right next to Irish Bank but still a wee bit too far for me to eat there during my lunch hour since I'm in the Embarcadero and when I say hour, I mean 58 minutes. I'll come back when I'm not so pressed for time and when I'm having a calorie cheat day because I want that Volcano Roll! With it's crumbling, crunchy tempura friend pieces of batter, spicyness, and presentation. The only bummer was that it took forever for it to be done. I'll come back for the uni too. The menu is not that robust but the fish is pretty good, considering it's in the Financial District where good sushi places are sparse. The cucumber salad was also good.
author: Tatiana D.

description: Once again, thanks, Yelpers or Yelps.  Found this place with the trusty iPhone app.  We were already 1 for 1 on our first day visiting San Fran.  We asked the concierge at our hotel for some recommendations for sushi.  After researching her suggestions on Yelp, I was disappointed.  I found Akiko's and we wandered down to it.  We were impressed.  The atmosphere didn't feel like a sushi bar.  It felt like a neighborhood restaurant in NYC.  I mean that as a compliment.  The sushi was quite good and the service was professional.  It's nice and tucked away.  Check it out.
author: Jake L.

description: This place is really nice and cozy. I went there during late lunch time and the place was still kind of crowded. The waiters are really nice and the food is decent. Volcano roll surprised me when I saw it. Didn't wait too long to get our food.
author: Annie H.

description:
I have never eaten in but have gotten takeout a few dozen times.  I've tried a variety of dishes which I will discuss below.

Sushi Rolls I've Tried:  California, Dragon, Dynamite
-  All three of these rolls are top notch.  Even the california roll (which is normally the same at every sushi place is actually pretty good.  They use fresh crab vs. the fake stuff and actually use very good ingredients.  Dragon and dynamite rolls are more of the complex rolls and they are definitely worth the extra few dollars.  All the fish is high quality and the rolls are put together nicely.

Chicken/Salmon/Beef Teriyaki:  I would recommend the chicken, then the salmon and I would stay away from the beef.  Beef seemed a bit chewy and tough, but the chicken and salmon were both really good.

Sashimi/Nigiri:  all legitimately fresh and tasty.  Nothing to write home about but still a solid 4 star quality for the price (5 star would be if you were getting way more than you expected for your money).

Salads are decent and the yakitori is alright as well.  They use the same chicken in the chicken teriyaki as in the yakitori but the veggies on the skewer are very good as well (sauce that comes with this is perfect).

Wasabi:  they use real wasabi! the kind that separates into little balls when you mix it with the soy sauce vs. the tube kind that melts away.

Service:  the service is very good here because the people are very nice. always the same sushi chef and the same guy taking your order.    the only thing I would have to say is that if you're making large orders to go, it's going to take a while.  It's almost as if they don't start the sushi rolls until you get there to pick the food up.  Maybe they've had bad experiences with people not showing up?

Atmosphere:  pretty dark inside and looks pretty ghetto from the outside but it'll surprise you once you step inside.  it's a nice homey feeling.  

Overall:  good sushi, good for pickup or dine in, slow service due to the lack of staff but ok if you go when it's slow.
author: Paul C.

description: One sentence review: This sushi restaurant offers good quality sushi with a nice presentation.
author: Kevin W.

description: Best kept secret. Thanks to Allen that made our experience memorable
author: May D.

description:
Stopped in after my second night at a conference in town.  Was pretty empty, but I saw the great things on here, so I decided to stay and sit at the bar.  Had a couple rolls and a few pieces of nigiri.  The salmon nigiri was to die for.  The rolls were good, but I've had better back home in Seattle.  They had a full menu apart from the sushi as well.

Would have liked to see a full bar, but being across the street from the hotel will have to do.
author: Ryan S.

description: Top class food and service, can't fault the place and good value. Fish is fresh and beautifully presented, it also tastes incredible. Will return
author: Finbar O.

description: I read that the staff was super friendly, so I guess we caught them on an off night.  The sushi was alright, as I have definitely had better.  I went off a recommendation on yelp and ordered the firecracker - I was not impressed, and for the price, I was really not impressed.  It seems they placed way more effort on presentation than anything else.  I like a good presentation when it comes to food, but not at the sacrifice of good service and tasty food.  I did like the octopus on the wall where we sat, that was nice. All in all, it was meh.  I most likely will not go there again.
author: Rita H.

description: Terrible beef udon- overcooked noodles and very few veggies. Overpriced!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Pretty cool place, and nice food. I will certainly repeat in near future.
author: Sean S.

description: Nice modern ambiance. Small, so if u sit by the door it gets drafty. Very fresh sashimi
author: S F.

description: Probably the best sushi in the Financial district. I got a sampler of six nigiri and the fish was very flavorful and fresh. The kitchen was closed that day, so there were no hot items on a cold, rainy day when I really needed some hot miso. I was on my own but I saw many couples and friends and quite a few regulars enjoying the cozy, stylish ambience, great music, and congenial hospitality of the owner and staff. The menu featured fresh Spanish albacore, exotic uni, and scallops flown in overnight from Japan. I would definitely go back, but be sure to get a reservation.
author: Andy W.

description: Easily the best sushi I've had in the financial district. The service is fast, even during the lunch rush and while a little more than places like the "Sushi Boat", you're paying for the quality of the ingredients which is excellent. I've stuck to things like sashimi and nigiri and have not been disappointed.
author: Tara D.

description: When I was in town for a job interview and staying downtown this is one of the restaurants I tried near my hotel.  Overall, the sushi was pretty good. I was most impressed with their blue fin tuna selection. It melted in your mouth it was so fresh and yummy. The service was okay, definitely could have been a little better, no really bad complaints though. The small shot gun layout of the restaurant is "cute" at first, but then you sit 4 drunk women next to you who are dissecting their day of shopping; it suddenly becomes not so "cute'.  Nonetheless, this is a easy spot downtown to grab some delicious sushi!
author: Nichole P.

description: Solid place.  Food was pretty good.  Tables were a bit close, but that's to be expected.  Would go back because it's close to me, but probably wouldn't go far out of my way for it.
author: Mark H.

description: This post is about Jack, the man that greets you when you come in.
