He has an ability to notice everything that's going on in the room, make you feel special as a single person, and exudes a combination of warmth, professionalism, and efficiency,   Most restaurants push the singles into a corner, but not Jack.  I LOVE the food at this place.  I've been going in alone a lot lately, absolutely incredible food..
author: Ellen M.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places! It's classy, but not expensive, what could be better? I always get a rock and roll, or something else with unagi the first time I go to a new sushi place since it's my favorite and then I have a good basis to compare to other places. I have to say, this is one of the best in the city. Highly recommend this if you're in the area!
author: David K.

description:
High-quality fish, cozy feel, and cordial service. I'm a big fan. Intimate ambience and decor, unassuming and attentive service, and deliciously buttery-tender nigiri. Have never sat at the bar, but the chef is always very friendly and greets us when we arrive. I love, love, love the a.j. roll... the spiciness is -- unlike cheap spices or hot sauces -- perfectly overwhelming without being nauseating or disruptive to the flavor of the tuna. 

Dress code is business casual. Very reasonably priced -- a huge plus and pleasantly surprising for this part of town. Reservations are recommendable for groups but not necessary. (Also, check out the lovely restroom while you're there: despite being even more dimly lit than the restaurant itself, it's a world of its own... tiny, relaxing lounge-y feel, no mirror, hip and modern look, great hand lotion.)  

Best sushi in the Financial District, by far!
author: G. J.

description: Love the food here!  My favorite is the Volcano, must order!  Food is delicious, fish is always fresh, their service is good.  For prime location and quality, the price is really reasonable.  I love to go there with my friends after shopping at union square, it's a good place for gathering...pretty good ambiance.
author: K T.

description: Wonderful little family run sushi restaurant. Friendly with great sashimi, edamame and miso soup (in my experience).
author: Duncan M.

description: Amazing sushi. Salad with ginger sauce was top notch. Very busy so make a reservation.
author: Liam M.

description: sat at the small bar and was treated to some of the most delicious fish i've ever eaten.  even fish i'm usually not a fan of (mackarel) i was poppin' back like there was no tomorrow. the uni with frozen monkfish liver shavings was a standout as was the smoky seared golden eye red snapper. awesome.
author: Joe C.

description: Had a great dining experience with my friends.  The wine was so good and gave us the good buzz that we ended up staying in instead of enjoying a night out after our meal.
author: Princez D.

description: Somewhat expensive ($80 for 2 no drinks).  Rolls were good, but not amazing.  Nigiri was good.
author: brett k.

description: I've been to Akikos at least five times for lunch and I keep going back.  Sure, it's a bit more expensive than an average FiDi lunch (I usually average $15), but it's way better too.  Fresh fish, nice space, and friendly staff make this the most reliable sushi spot I've found downtown.
author: Brad K.

description: Coming here for the first time for a dinner on Wednesday night. First impression was how nice and classy the decor looked. The wait staff seemed quite attentive and seated us at the table next to the window the moment we walked in. We ordered the volcano roll, chicken donburi and the 10 piece nigiri and sashimi. One word I must say is - expensive. This place has very fresh and good sushi but for the amount of food we received it was quite expensive - the two $$ don't justify the prices at the restaurant. However, when the food did arrive everything was quite delicious - the sashimi melts in your mouth and the chicken katsu was nice and crispy. The volcano roll was definitely something special with loads of tempura bits on top of the roll which were delicious enough to eat as is. Great sushi and very nice decor but the prices were quite high for the amount of food that was offered and I guess this would be a 3 1/2 stars but I guess the waiting staff wasn't as friendly or as attentive as they should be. Will come back to try it again but the sushi is quite expensive for the quantity given.
author: Aaron P.

description: The sushi was really good - fresh and generous pieces. The spider roll was the best I' ve had. The beef terriyaki was not good. The presentation of the food on the plate is one of prettiest i've seen. I liked the decor and atmosphere of the restaurant. Would definitely go back but only for sushi.
author: Catherine P.

description: I am not sure how this place has an average 4 star rating... leads me to believe that someone got service, it just wasn't me. After making a reservation for Friday night, they acted like they didn't know what we were talking about and lead us to a little 2 top in the back. It was a million degrees in there and we sat with water waiting for over 10 minutes to get a drink menu, something.... so we left. I imagine their food is good, looked good on the menu.  There were others who were there before us who hadn't gotten drinks either thus our decision to bail.
author: Mandy M.

description: We made a reservation for 2 tonight and came here hoping for delicious, fresh sushi. We sat at the sushi bar. The waiter greeted us, was friendly and helpful. However, the sushi bar experience was lame and indifferent. This usually is the best seat in the house...not here! The Asian chef with the mustache, the sous chef, and the owner were behind the sushi bar and did not once greet us, smile, or ask us what we were interested in. They did not even take our order. We flagged down the waiter and ordered the 6 piece sashimi, volcano roll, rock n'roll, and salmon/avocado roll. The fish was very fresh and flavorful. While the food was very good, the indifferent and disengaged sushi chef (younger guy with mustache) and staff behind the sushi bar, slow pace of food coming out, and expensive, small portions just ruined the experience. We paid our bill with no follow-up on how the food was, if we wanted dessert or tea, or thank you from the anti-social sushi chef (specifically the Asian one with mustache in his early 30's, no hat on his head, and constantly wiping his sweaty forehead with his sleeve). He did not thank us but the waiter and busboy were polite enough to do so. Food good...service, portions, and prices fall very short! Won't be back or recommending this place to friends.
author: H E.

description: This was a pleasant surprise. I stopped in for lunch and ended up with some very tasty rolls. I normally try to mix in some Sashimi but, ended up with a few rolls which, after indulging, found to be quite delicious.
author: Brian R.

description: Solid sushi place in SF with nice ambiance.  Came here with my girlfriends for a casual dinner after shopping - it's walkable from Union Square.  The sushi and sashimi were good and tasted fresh, although my favorite place to get sushi/sashimi is still Sushi Sam's in San Mateo.  The place isn't that big, so I wouldn't hold a large party here, but it's great for a date or a small group meal.  The service was great, very attentive.  They have a good selection of rolls and also have a "specials" menu for fresh fish from different regions, although the specials are a bit pricey so we didn't get any of those.  I got the "Duo" sashimi/udon meal which was $19 for a big bowl of beef udon and 4 pieces of sake, maguro, and hamachi mmmm.  We also ordered a bowl of chirashi at our table, which was presented very nicely but the portion was a bit smaller than what we're used to.  End with black sesame ice cream - yum!
author: A C.

description:
I used to frequent this place a lot with my colleagues, however, we felt the need to venture outside our foodie comfort zones. So, by chance, we ended up at our default spot for Japanese food. 

The service is on par with the fanciest restaurants in the City but the food was not quite what we remembered it to be. The quality of their sushi remains but their cooked foods left a little something to be desired. They tend to skimp on the add-ons like the veggies. I'm a carnivore at heart but getting a little more veggie wouldn't hurt.
author: S L.

description: The sushi at Akiko's was wonderful and it's a beautiful little restaurant! The wait staff was friendly and attentive, the fish was fresh, the sauces were chef made, all around fantastic!
author: Kristi C.

description: ricky is the best sushi chef in san francisco, maybe the world.
author: Harold C.

description: My wife & I went to Akiko's while on our honeymoon in San Francisco after reading the good reviews of the place. We enjoyed it. The place is quaint & feels trendy, but in a warm and pleasant way. The food was delicious. The only negative part of our experience was that the service was lacking in attention and friendliness to us. I had to wait forever for a spoon for my miso soup and they didn't really seem to care about the customer's overall dining experience. I'd still recommend going, if only for the great food.
author: Sean E.

description: Great casual sushi place near the Financial District. Standard Japanese fare with attentive but unobtrusive waitstaff. Don't leave without trying the Volcano Roll, a spicy yummy crunchy concoction that will make your taste buds erupt.
author: AdamLowell C.

description:
Was right across the street from our hotel.  Service started off a little shakey, but turned out great.  Sushi was excellent and they even took off my wine when they forgot to put it on the bill and we pointed it out.

Would recommend if you are staying in the vicinity.
author: Barbara R.

description: Nice ambiance, good service, delicious sushi. We especially enjoyed the cucumber salad and sake avocado roll.
author: Teny S.

description: Very good. We had lunch on a Monday, the service was good and the sushi was very fresh. Next time we are in town we will do it again.
author: JJ H.

description: Solid sushi, really nice ambiance, and great service. I don't think you can go wrong with this place. I only gave it three stars because it was my first visit. If I returned and had a similar experience, I'd definitely four start it.
author: james H.

description: The food was AMAZING!  We took our 2.5 yr. old with us and planned to get take away because a previous reviewer has noted that it wasn't a place for kids (which it isn't exactly).  I wanted to note that the waiter was very nice and told us to please have a seat, that the whole family was welcome there.  Once seated, they immediately got rice and edamame out for my son, which was very nice.  We had a lovely dinner, with lovely sushi and continued on our way.  I highly recommend it!
author: Melanie B.

description: Good, but overpriced.  I liked the roll (Yiki, I think) that had garlic.
author: Steve W.

description: Discovered this place on Yelp reviews. Exceeded all our expectations. It is very small. And reservations are must for dinner! Cool atmosphere/decor. Busy but the 4 of could talk comfortably. Super  menu,everything so fresh. Waiter was pleased to help us pick sakes and he was spot on. We always judge sushi places by their uni because it has to be super fresh. We were surprised that they offered 2 uni: one from Santa Barbara and other from Japan. So we tried both...what a treat!  Prices are very reasonable. So... make a res., trust the waitstaff, and go hungry. Akiko's pleases all the senses!
author: Pamela M.

description:
I don't have too much to say about this place.  I was there just moments ago for a lunch with my wife.   The food was good, though not stand out.  The decor was interesting and appealing in a modern artsy sort of way.

The service was really bad though.  I'm not the type that likes overly intrusive wait staff, but checking in every once in awhile... at least enough to take an order and give you the bill is appreciated.  We waited far too long for these activities... and for the 'are you doing ok?', 'can I get you anything else?' kind of check in: non-existent.  

Great restaurants are built by having great food supported by a foundation of great service.  I've seen many an establishment with very average or even poor food being saved by the quality of service; I've never seen poor service rescued by great food.  Akiko's demonstrated this during my visit today.
author: Steven B.

description: Was here like 2 weeks ago and I must say the food is real good. Yes service is a little slow but who goes to a sushi restaurant in a rush it was all good and we were real happy!!
author: Jimmy S.

description: Best sushi in town.  Recommend counter seating for best experience and service.    Ordered Omakase style and Ricky did not disappoint.  Stick with the nigiri. Wine and sake also superb.  Not a cheap meal but well worth the experience.
author: Ken Y.

description: The food here is great, but the experience is not. I've been here twice now. Both times the service was a little slow, but that's ok I guess. Last time our waiter forgot to bring half of the items we ordered, including a bottle of wine. I don't think we'll come back here again.
author: Ian S.

description: A friend celebrated her 21st dinner party here. This place is in the cuts and they don't have a sign that's visible during dinner hours. My friends and I literally walked up and down the street looking for it. The restaurant is cute and also dimly lit but I hated how cramped it was. Our party was early so we stood around waiting for our seats to be vacant and the hostess told us if we could be quiet since people were having their dinner. Is it our fault they don't have a seating area for guests that have to wait, especially on rainy days like the day we went? Stand outside in the rain until our seats are ready? Eh. The food was really good though, I had the  teriyaki bento with tempura. Overall, it was a nice restaurant. I just wish it was a little bit bigger because there's no waiting area and you pretty much disturb others eating if you're just standing around. Oooh, and they have only one bathroom that has only a sink and toilet. There's no mirror.
author: Jessica R.

description: This place is right around the corner from my work and I love it. The sushi is always fresh and delicious. I love to sit by the windows and watch the people walk by, but if you go to the back they have this beautiful exposed brick wall with great artwork displayed. I am a fan of art, so love it back there too. One time it was a bit loud since there was a huge party next to us, but with the food being good, I didn't mind. If you are in the financial district, stop by for some delicious fish.
author: Heather G.

description: Great staff, busy location, and excellent sushi. Akiko's is the real deal for pay by the piece sushi. Well thought out.
author: R S.

description: We had terrible service here.  We were told that two waiters called in sick, so it's possible that our poor service was an anomaly.  However, I still give it a poor rating because the food was bad.  I got Maguro sashimi and it was frozen in the middle.
author: Matthew B.

description: I can take or leave Sushi at most places, but I LOVE coming here to Akiko's.  The hand rolls they make are dee-lish, the tempura fluffy and the noodle dishes creative and filling.  We went there for lunch yesterday since it's so close to work and will come back again and again.  The workers are very friendly and polite and the service was great!
author: Joni M.

description:
One of the best sushi spots in San Francisco!

Excellent food - sashimi is fresh and rolls are unique and delicious.

Service is great - friendly and accommodating staff and sushi chef.

5 stars!!!
author: Michael C.

description: The best sushi I've had in a while, and I'm a big sushi lover! The only problem was that they gave us a table tucked in a corner at the entrance of the restaurant and service was slow/ that area was chilly. I would certainly go back for the food though. The $4 salmon belly sushi was totally worth it!
author: Brin N.

description: Akiko has become our favorite Japanese restaurant, all around everything is great and fresh! Whatever it's sushi, udon, don buri or combination everything has a great presentation and a great tast at a resonable price!
author: Luc S.

description:
The fish was really fresh.  Some of the best I've had anywhere in the city, in fact.  But when the "10 piece chirashi bowl" comes with 8 pieces (maybe they counted the tobiko and wakame as "pieces"?), which are cut sliver thin, they're gonna lose a couple stars.  I could have easily eaten two of their chirashi bowls, which is not acceptable at this price.

Next time I feel like really splashing out for some top notch fish, I'll go back.  But too bad I can't afford to make this place a regular lunch stop.
author: Jeff W.

description: I came here Saturday night with a group of 20 for my birthday dinner. We arrived a couple of minute before our reservation time, but we waited 15 minutes in order to be seated because of a previous group that was still in our designated area. We were seated in the back part of the restaurant, which I guess is usually for larger groups. I really liked the ambiance of Akiko's; really trendy & intimate. Our servers were attentive at the beginning, but we kindof had to track them down throughout the night since there were other patrons that they had to tend to. Our food all came at random times, but came in a timely manner, which was understandable. Their hot sake was pretty good & really warm. Sashimi was pretty good too; pretty fresh but I felt that it wasn't as fresh as Sushi Bistro. The volcano roll was probably the best dish I had. I've had volcano rolls at other sushi restaurants, but Akiko's was one of the best. Oh yeah, no sake bombs? What kind of Japanese restaurant does not do that? Apparently Akiko's. We improvised & just chased our sake with beer. Everyone in my party had a great time, besides the unordered items that were on our bill. I know that we were loud & all, but still .. wth. I might come here again; maybe not with a large group, but with a smaller group or a date. Thanks Akiko's for accommodating 20 talkative 20-somethings!
author: BrendaJoy G.

description:
3 people bill came to $100 for lunch....wait what? yea thats right $100.

We had 12 piece sashimi
Zeeky had the Chicken Teriyaki/Tempura Combo
Jean had the Beef Teriyaki/Tempura Combo
I had the Saba shio-yaki/Tempura Combo
and there was a dinky bottle of sake.

service was good, the guy was nice and mainly the stars are for that guy. I know Jean would of gave them 0 stars. The food was alright. It just wasnt worth the money. The sashimi was not extraordinary and it seemed really skimpy..and furthemore the only thing that tasted good on that plate was probably the red snapper. Even the salmon just didnt cut it. The tempura was not really different from any other place and my saba was a lil over salty, it was not bad but a lil too salty. And it might be a bit smarter to add a bit more rice to the dish. Rice is not expensive, dont be stingy with it.

Now, Jean is our supervisor and she treated us to lunch, yea Zeeky n I didnt have to pay but I could tell Jean was like "huh?" Well you see, her husband owns a japanese restaurant and she was pretty suprised..and not in a good way. I can say that when it comes to food, money isnt really an issue..well as long as its good. The food here just wasnt worth the money and if i had a choice I wouldnt have paid that amount of money for this quality of food

I see all these wonderful 4 star reviews for this place and I'm confused at why. People are saying this roll and that roll is delicious, so maybe I should of ordered a roll. The way I see it is that if they cant do a tempura combination right I wouldnt bother with the rolls.

So two stars for the service~
author: phillip w.

description: This is a cool place with very fresh fish and some unique offerings.  Also, great sake menu.  Very small (6-person) sushi bar - make reservations.  The service was friendly but slow.  I am also a traditionalist when it comes to my sushi chefs.  Though Ricky was skilled and knowledgeable, I was also a bit turned off by his hippie co-chef (see other comments).   Then again, it's SF.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Pretty good sushi and nice ambient.   I had the dragon rolls california temaki,  and shioyaki over rice.  The meal also came with miso soup and tea.  In my opinion, this place is better than the ones in japantown.
author: Jeff H.

description: Very good sushi! Not a huge menu but several good roll selections and a ton of nigiri and sashimi choices. The 49er and rainbow rolls were delish!! Small place off the beaten path but still close to everything. Will definitely go back.
author: Heather S.

description: Sit at the bar and let Ricky be your guide.  You will be treated to some of the most unique seafood in your life.  Sushi is top grade and always fresh.
author: Duc N.

description:
Great sushi, high quality.  49er Roll was very tasty (such fresh salmon!), and the Volcano Roll rocked... and was actually in the shape of a volcano!  California Rolls, while basic, are probably the best Cali Rolls I've had.  Chef's selection plate had some great sushi on it.  

Not super cheap, but not overpriced.  Very happy with the food, the service, and the ambience - funky building with cool faux-finish painted walls and exposed brick.  Good location in neighborhood with lots of great shopping.
author: Kat H.

description:
I love udon and I swear this place provided the biggest bowl of udon.  I had to split it with my fiance (usually I order my own sushi and then try to steal some of his udon lol).   Didn't have to this time!  There was plenty of sushi and udon to go around.  

The staff is friendly and the service is quick.  We didn't explore that much with the sushi rolls but I'm definitely planning on coming back and trying out some of their special rolls.   

Also, my fiance left his credit card there.   We were already four blocks away but the waiter was so nice as to run down and catch up to us!  =)
author: JR Kaz K.

description: Came here based on yelp reviews and had high expectations. I've heard the sushi in San Francisco is exceptionally fresh. That might be the only thing this place has going on. Both the salmon and tuna sushi were fresh and tasty (I gave one star for each). I also had a salmon avocado roll, but it was just bland. But the problems started as soon as we walked into the restaurant. We had a reservation and got there a little late (walked from our hotel and not familiar with the area). The owner/manager/waiter had attitude with us right away and we considered leaving, but didn't. We got seated a few minutes later and then waited probably a good 20 min with the menus before someone attending to us. Finally we ordered wine along with appetizers and entrees. The wine took another 15 minutes and only came to us after I motioned to the "man" that we we were waiting- still. When food actually arrived at our table, we weren't impressed, except for the freshness of the sushi, as I said before. Overall too much waiting, the restaurant was sweltering hot, and the "man" was rude. Don't eat here, I'm sure other sushi places in the area are better.
author: Samantha F.

description: Volcano roll is a must have here.  Very consistent and portions are a good size.
author: T L.

description: Great sushi, good atmosphere (chill), decent price. Will definitely return.
author: Mike L.

description: This place was highly rated and I really wanted sushi in San Francisco, so we went here for dinner. Although I'm from the Midwest, I've had my fair share of sushi, good and bad, from small divey places to upscale trendy restaurants. The service was very good, our waiter was very knowledgeable and friendly. The place has a trendy feel, good for a date night. If you like maki rolls, they don't have a very wide selection, so I was a little disappointed with that. However, the rolls we did have were extremely fresh, and very good. My favorite was their spicy tuna, probably one of the best I've had, seriously melt-in-your-mouth good. We also had an unagi roll, which again was very fresh, and tasty. And we shared two pieces of wild king salmon nigiri, which had that same melt-in-your-mouth effect. I would've loved more specialty rolls to choose from, but I was very happy with the overall experience - the taste and quality of what we ordered, the ambiance, and the service. Definitely recommend!
author: Patti R.

description:
first post! - this place inspired me to join yelp. hah.

checked out this place on a whim to catch up with my girlfriends on a friday night.  when we first walked by, there didn't seem to be anyone inside, but we went in anyway, and found there were other diners in the backroom.

service was great.  per waiter's recommendation, i got the chef's-choice sashimi platter (i forgot what its called now, but its the first thing on the menu) -- $18.  very fresh!!  

also tried the volcano roll which was deliciously spicy and crunchy - paired with some sapporo, the dinner was very enjoyable - i think the food was fairly priced too! 

the only downside i think, is that they close at 9pm - we would have loved to stay longer and just drink/chat.
author: Maxine C.

description:
So this is my first ever review and this place is definitely worthy of it!

I went here on a Friday night a couple of weeks ago with a few girlfriends. Being skeptical of sushi in general, I looked up the reviews and felt it would be a good place to check out. And I was right!

Not only was this the best sushi I've ever had, but the service is amazing. Our servers Ray and Alan R Lee (here's your shout out!!!) were awesome. We received a free sake and and ice cream on the house. 

We ordered the dragon roll, volcano roll, and shrimp tempura roll, along with a plate of chicken teriyaki. Everything was great! We didn't need the complimentary items but it just went to show how appreciative this place is towards customers. I definitely plan on going back soon!
author: A S.

description: O Joe and his sushi. This place has the best sushi ever. Fresh and delicious. Ive been going here for years. Lunch time gets a little nuts, but in the evening it can be very mellow. Good for a date, but Joe is great for the kids to. They can sit at the bar and watch him work his magic. The place is immaculate, and you can get it to go if you want.
author: Melissa B.

description: This is the best Japanese food I have ever had. I used to eat here five times a week when I worked a block away from this place. The sushi is fresh-picked every morning by the chefs at local fish markets and the food is prepared with incredible expertise. My favorites are the miso soup, chicken udon, dragon roll, caterpiller roll, FIRECRACKER ROLL, and the collarbone-looking piece of fish.
author: William C.

description: Loved it. Great great sushi, especially so close to the financial district, and very reasonable prices. Not much more I could ask for. The cucumber salad was a great start to to the meal. The atmosphere was very cozy and intimate.
author: Christina C.

description: This is some of the best Japanese I've found in SF.  Nothing super experimental on the menu, but I think they do the basics well.  Very flavorful, nice presentation.  Cozy place, slightly higher with the cool factor than your standard inexpensive Japanese restaurant.  Great Financial District lunch spot.  I like their fried tofu and seaweed salad best.  So fresh you'll feel like a mermaid.
author: Ryan L.

description: I often come here for my lunchtime sushi fix. The sushi is fresh and good. If you order the mixed sushi plate beware the pickled sock sushi, it's got yellow pickled something, tastes like gym socks, I asked what it was once, and I forget what it's called but she followed it with "its really good huh? very tasty!" sadly I really don't agree. Other than that though I really like everything there. Good miso, salmon teriyaki is tender and good, sushi is fresh and good. And they got a 100 on their health inspection, which is always good to see at a place that sells raw meat. Usuallly pretty fast for lunch if you don't go right at noon.
author: vickie j.

description:
I've been living downtown for over 2 years now, and had never gone to Akiko's before, despite its location (about 2 blocks from my front door). I don't know why I never stepped inside before now, but I do know that I'm glad I finally did! The decor was a bit puzzling (partial exposed brick with some exposed piping and cement, with interesting, if confusingly religious? art on the walls), but welcoming and pleasant.
The atmosphere around 8pm is extremely quiet, unpretentious, and laid-back. The sushi is no-frills on the menu, but comes to the table with lovely presentation and great flavor! I personally recommend the Rainbow Roll. 
The pricing is not unreasonable, especially for good sushi, but is still just a smidge higher than I generally enjoy paying. Certainly it was not unexpected for the financial district. After all, if you want cheap sushi in San Francisco, it's hard to find outside of the Richmond! 
The service was not particularly attentive, but not by any means bad. I suspect that if we had sat closer to the front of the restaurant, we would have received more attention. As it was, we were in the furthest-back corner of the place, which proved to be cosy and private, and made up for the lack of attention.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Food: 86%
Decor: 87%
Service 86%

So I just moved from the land of great sushi..NYC..whered I lived, ate and slept in the office. Despite this misery, I was happy because back in NYC i had an abundant amount of sushi options. 

That dream has been broken since my move to SF. The lack of fresh sushi almost got me to move back to NY. Until Akiko sushi. Thank you Akiko, for providing fresh sushi, cheap and delicious teryaki and quick delivery. All this..and the price of the meal to be below my corporate expense budget. Thank you.
author: Adrian G.

description: Love the tsukemeno and tamago here.
author: Cheri S.

description: This is a great place for sushi.  My wife and I have eaten lunch here twice and we really liked it both times.  The place is fairly small and sometimes a bit crowded at lunch, though we didn't have to wait for a table either time.
author: Richard M.

description: Great Sushi in the Financial District without overpaying as you do with many of the other nicer sushi restaurants in the area. The Volcano Roll and Fire-Cracker Roll are musts when sharing with a large group.
author: Liz W.

description: Walked by this place soooo many times and never thought about going in to it, Irish Bank a bigger draw to me on that block.  But finally went in and was amazed, really great sushi.  Been to lots of sushi places, and most are good but this place was great, maybe I am giving the place 5 stars because the waiter gave us an extra sake after we paid the bill in honor of my birthday, but the food was delicious and beautiful
author: Mickey D.

description: I've mostly only been to sushi restaurants in the East Bay, but this one is way better than those.  No wonder it's always busy! Make sure you get a reservation.  They are also very nice about accommodating large groups.
author: Josh H.

description: The service was slow, but they warned me ahead of time that they were short-staffed.  In that context, the service was great.  Maybe it was just the night I was there, but the fish wasn't very good.  It felt like I was getting leftover scraps on rice and not quality nigiri.
author: milos d.

description: My husband and I are sushi addicts.  We love it and we are PICKY about our fish.  We've eaten at most of the best/most recommended sushi spots in SF - Akikos is our favorite.  Ray (the owner) really knows his fish and is constantly trying to get unique fresh sustainable items on his menu/behind the glass.  The service is great - everyone is friendly and the atmosphere is solid.  Make a reservation - it helps.  This place gets busy and you may have to wait a few minutes for your food, but it's worth it for the quality.  I am wary of empty sushi spots.  Love this place - it's been our go-to for the last four years.
author: Jaime G.

description: Unfortunately I had a poor experience here for my 30th birthday. I called way in advance to make reservations for a group of 18 people. The man I spoke to said that was fine to have a party of that size and they would reserve a table for us. He also asked if we had any special requests. I told him it was my 30th birthday and we were a big group of fun, loud females so to be prepared for that and could we have a fun waiter. I was partially kidding but also partially warning him that when 18 of my friends get together, we can be loud and like to have a good time. He said, no problem. He would take care of it and was happy to have us. My girlfriends wanted to suprise me by putting balloons in the venue at the corner of our table, so they called in advance to ask if that was okay. The guy said no problem. When they showed up with the balloons, the people in the restaurant were all bent out of shape about my friends bringing them which we found odd since they had asked. The waiter was super rude right from the get go and not happy to be serving such a large party. instead of us ordering ourselves, he said he would order the food for us to give us variety, but he must of ordered the most expensive things on the menu. We didn't have very much sushi and it was really expensive. Plus dinner took over 2 hours and each item would come well after the food was finished from the previous dish. The sushi was definitely good, but the high price, the fact that we were all still hungry when we left and the fact that the waiter was so rude to us really put a damper on the experience. He even tried to keep our change at the end of the night even though we had already paid our tip. They shouldn't accept reservations for that many people if they're going to be jerks about it and can't handle bringing food out for the amount of people we had. There are so many good sushi restaurants in the city,  that I'd rather take my business to someone who appreciates it and gives me a welcoming experinece, especially on my birthday!
author: Megan G.

description: In case you thought I give every place 5 stars, here's a precisely 3-star review. The value is decent -- not cheap, but good-sized portions. The quality is passable -- obviously fresh, but poor cuts and poor texture. It's clean, so it won't kill you. But the amaebi was heart-breakingly rubbery. boo hoo! The service was terrible-- only 1 cup of tea for 1.5 hours of dinner. Hmm, maybe this should be downgraded to 2 stars...
author: Surely I Am C.

description: I have worked in the financial district for years and was very pleased to find a great sushi restaurant tucked away on Bush (between Subway and The Irish Bank).  Ray (the owner) is very friendly / professional and the sushi is always fresh.  I eat here several times a week and feel it is a great value for the quality.  I usually order the sashimi.
author: Angie L.

description:
This is my new favorite financial district lunch spot.  The sashimi is the best in the 'hood - so fresh and tasty.  The Rainbow roll is truly the most beautiful roll I have ever seen and it TASTES even better than it looks.  Also lovely decor and friendly staff.  It's cozy but there is usually a table available.

The only item on the menu I didn't enjoy was the flash fried rolls.  Now I bypass these as they are too heavy, bulky and awkwardly fried.  Plus, the fresh fish is so amazing, I just stick to the raw items on the menu.
author: Sarah t.

description: I ordered the spicy tuna roll.  The fish was super fresh and the flavor was right on.  However, the eight pieces that made up the roll were tiny, and I ended up feeling hungry soon after lunch, so I'd recommend ordering either two rolls or a combo dish.  My friends and I remarked that the interior looked like a rustic Italian church instead of a sushi joint.
author: Momo R.

description: Happened to be in the area and found this place on yelp. Delicious sushi and chef joe was very friendly and really knows his stuff. There was a little confusion with the order which is the only thing that kept it from being 5 stars but overall really great. I will say, not as good as kiss seafood but I consider that place in a league of its own.
author: Trent D.

description: Great sushi place in the financial district.  The pricing is a little high, but I'm willing to pay since the sushi is really fresh and the rolls are so tasty!  My dad always tells me you pay for what you get in life. Both the hot dishes and the sushi where really good. hmmmmm getting hungry. close to work so its easy to come by often to my sushi retreat.
author: rasaka s.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE!  If I could give this place a negative star I would!  I dropped in for lunch and walked out 10 minutes later.  The rest. was crowded but not every table was taken.  I stood at the door for 10 minutes to wait for someone to come seat me or even acknowledge that I was waiting.  Of course the wait staff walked around me several times.  They knew I was waiting for a table but didn't even bother telling me that they would seat me soon.  You could tell one of the waiters was upset, totally see it on his face, but that doesn't mean its okay to ignore me.  I suppose that it didn't help that someone was complaining that their order wasn't right.  Needless to say, a rest. that doesn't even care about potential customers is not worth going.  

I've been here before on another occasion too.  There are better sushi places and the salmon was very fishy...but then again its fish...
author: Julie Z.

description:
cute little restaurant. stopped by here last week for lunch (during my 1 hour lunch break, thank goodness i made it back to work on time)

ordered three rolls:  negihama, spider roll & salmon nigiri. it did take a while for the rolls to come out and when it did, i was given the wrong order, but i guess that's what happens when you have a smaller restaurant with just one sushi chef working during lunch. anyways, the rolls were decent and decently priced. all i have to say about akiko's is that the salmon was delicious!! literally melt in your mouth, buttery taste that salmon should be everytime you eat it.
author: Anh P.

description: I have been to many Sushi places, some bad, some good, some great. Akikos lands solidly into my great category. My beautiful girl and I are staying at the Hotel Triton for the weekend and decided to give this place a go because it was right around the corner from the Hotel. We arrived right when they opened for dinner. We spent almost an hour sitting at the sushi bar talking with the Chef / Owner Joe and eating. The sushi was absolutely amazing!! Fresh fish, creative rolls, and just good fun. Joe made us a couple of off the menu items and really showcased his expertise in the art of Sushi!! Thanks Joe, your establishment is now going to be a must go every time we are in the city.
author: Lawrence G.

description: This place really hit the spot yesterday. Their rolls are perfect - not too much rice, fresh ingredients and decent portions. Each of us required 2 rolls each to satisfy. Sad to say that this is one of the only sushi places near Fin District that is not sheeshee (Ozumo) and not a chain sushi factory. It's slightly pricey, hence the 4 stars - plan to spend around $20 for a nice sized sushi meal. They also have a great cucumber salad, Chef salad and Volcano Roll if you like spicy! They can use some new menus - those things are falling apart!
author: Chiaty S.

description: On a chilly afternoon, nothing beats a bowl of udon noodle soup at this restaurant! The broth is sooo delicious and the vegetables are all very fresh. They have a good assortment of small plates that really get your appetite going! Don't miss the sesame spinach! WOW! Service is quick and efficient. And there are a good amount of vegetarian items to choose from.
author: Julie P.

description: This is my favorite sushi spot in the Financial District. Yea ... the sushi is on the expensive side but I think the price matches the quality of the fish they serve.  My favorite roll is the 49er Roll which is a tempura roll with salmon on top and a sliver of lemon on top. It's Delish! Volcano and Dynamite rolls are awesome too ... but they are deep fried.
author: Hiyasmin D.

description: Best sushi place in San Francisco, great value, don't get it confused with the other Akkikos down the street, always good service
author: Bob F.

description:
I work in the financial district and being relatively new to the area, I've been scouting for a good sushi place. I was on my way to Miyabi sushi express, based on them having decent ratings on here, but they had a temporary water problem... so I roamed the streets randomly, which can be very dangerous.

Akiko's restaurant looked dark but coming closer, the bar looked inviting so I entered. Huge smile from the chef - a good start! The service was prompt and polite, and the sushi was amazing - fresh, beautifully prepared, and not that expensive considering we're talking fresh raw fish! I only ordered sushi, but their hamachi, ebi and sake were very good as well as a standard fare of californian rolls - which the chef managed to make interesting and different somehow!

I stayed at the bar but there is more space towards the back and the decor looked amazing - a place to keep in mind for the evenings too.

I've now found my favourite sushi place for lunch : )
author: Elisabeth G.

description: This is a great sushi restaurant!! We had some time to kill and really wanted to enjoy sushi. The food was so incredibly fresh and the variety was just perfect for what we were looking for. We got a perfect seat by the window and the establishment was comfortable. The staff was friendly and receptive ... we didn't have to ask for anything. Definitley worth trying the 49er roll!! Thank you.
author: Debbie M.

description: Amazing experience last night.  Great decor inside, amazing sushi (REALLY good fish), and impecable service from our waiter.  Can't recommend it highly enough.  It gets 5+ Yelp stars from me!
author: Christin A.

description: I really enjoy lunch at this un-pretentious place. The sushi is very good for lunch, and their soups are huge and filling. The miso soup is some of the best I've had, and the environment is relaxing. I wouldn't make this a special destination, but it's good food at a reasonable price.
author: Sahra H.

description:
this is one of the better sushi bars in the finacial district.

i liked this place and was a good stop for lunch. I had sashimi and tempura udon. nice pieces of fish, but not extraordinary. i think it's lunch menu may be toned down since the place is located in the heart of downtown executive lunch eateries. anyways, one of the better, cheaper options in the area.
author: Alex L.

description: So good.  I had a work lunch meeting here today and was so glad I finally popped in to this place.  The rolls, service, and nigiri were all amazing.  The flavors are light, interesting, and TASTY.   I liked the sweetness of the rice in the sushi and have found a new lunch spot whenever I happen to be in SF.
author: Cory G.

description: Akiko's charming space filled up by noon with all kinds of downtowners. The food was a step above similarly priced Japanese restaurants I've been to. My friend got a huge portion of vegetable tempura, and I enjoyed a few pieces of vegetable sushi. If I knew the scallop nigiri was chopped, sauced and roe'd I'd have ordered something else. Never had it served with so much stuff before. Like most sushi, not a good place if you're in a hurry.
author: J. R.

description: Good sushi.  The vivi roll and whatever that tuna underbelly roll was were very tasty.
author: Angel S.

description: Went here today for lunch for a second visit in a month.  Service wa incredibly slow, with miso soup  taking 10 minutes or more to arrive after we ordered.  Server never refilled water and didn't let us know why the check was taking so long (computer was down, we asked).  Every step of the meal was delivered very slowly.  $80 for 3 people for lunch isn't cheap, either.  fish quality is good, but there are better values out there.  Very cool decor in my opinion.
author: Lauren J.

description: Sat at the bar.  Was perfect.  The recommendations, the food, the specials you won't get everywhere.  Very friendly and special pieces handed over directly from the chef. Is it the best I've ever had, no.  Is it very very good with great service, yes.
author: Chris R.

description: Your customary japanese greeting from the sushi chefs, simple menu (donuburis are yummy--especially the unagi!); and cleverly designed space in such small quarters...a nice change from all the cafes and sandwich places here on Bush (French quarters). You can get in and out within 45 minutes for under 15 bucks.  Nothing so edgy about the selections, but that is the beauty of it... check it out!
author: Jaena G.

description: Totally ok.  Price was reasonable, service was prompt, the food was not the best.  My Chirashi (basically shashimi over rice) had some decent fish and some kinda stinky fish.
author: Thomas K.

description: The only problem I have with this place is that the quality doesn't seem to be consistent. The food is a bit over priced, but it's OK because I shouldn't eat too much anyways. The sushi pieces are small, and some fish are fresh, and others are not. I guess I would go back if I can't think of any where else.
author: Judy D.

description: Charming little Japanese place. Good food. Somehow all the little details worked together to create a relaxing atmosphere. And the food was good!
author: N K.

description: The food was really good. I recommend the Firecracker.  The service was very fast and was pleasant. The staff was very friendly. The restraunt is small, quaint, and an overall good atmosphere.
author: ash a.

description: great rolls, one of the better downtown sushi spots.  the service was just okay...especially considering it was not busy when we ordered.  we got five rolls, two specialty, and the total came to $38 with tax for two people.  not bad.  the "staple' rolls (tuna, salmon, yellowtail) were all $5 each, which is pretty solid for a sit down resturant.
author: Joel F.

description: The rolls were mediocre-don't try the firecracker roll 'cause it tastes like an old tempura roll that's been sitting out for a few hours. The service is okay-I think there was only 2 servers and because most of the customers were in the main dining room in the back, we got bupkiss basically. Spider roll was a little on the sweeter than normal side and basically all the sashimi were standard. What threw me off just a little bit was the fact that I never half of what I ordered. I got charged sure, but I never got it. And when we left and I had to come back for my cell phone, there it was sitting on the glass. Of course I'm going to inquire if that was suppose to be for me. It wasn't busy or anything so I don't understand where the confusion is. My friend said "just let it go-not a big deal." But from pen to paper to register, how do you forget to drop off food that's just sitting there? Maybe they were having an off day-I'd rather go to Masu anyhow.
author: Jessica K.

description: We decided to go Akiko's for new experience after seeing the good recommendations on Yelp.   The sweet shrimps were okay.  The uni was fresh, but the seaweed wrapped around the rice was very hard to chew.  We ordered vv roll... nothing special.. We definitely had better rolls.   FYI, we came there on Friday night, and none of the customers were Japanese.........  (A sushi restaurant with no Japanese customer..)
author: Matt W.

description: First time I went to Akiko was almost two years ago. Nothing really stayed with me. I went there again today since many people here are talking about the restaurant. I ordered Chirashi, which had 5 pieces of sashimi, shrimp, and eggs over sushi rice. The service was quick. My order came within five minutes. But I have to say that their sashimi is not the best. It is too dry, and it's very thin. I am a little disappointed. But overall it's a good dining.
author: Iwen C.

description: Great, affordable sushi near Union Square.  The maguro was the freshest we've ever had.  Rocket roll was spicy delicious.  Service was great and waiter was elegant and attentive. There are 3 tables nestled in front windows where you can people-watch, and more tables near the rear of the place, and, of course, the sushi bar.
author: Julie D.

description: Chicken Teriyaki was not the best- didn't really have that teriyaki flavor, was sort of bland, and only came with one carrot & one piece of broccoli.  Didn't really see the point of including them if you're only going to do the onesies.  The atmosphere was nice enough, and the people working there were also on their game.  But as a teriyaki connoisseur, I'm not sure I'll be back.
author: Maria L.

description: I've been getting my hair cut around the block from this place for a while and this was my guy's suggestion when I needed to pick up some soup to bring a sick friend. I accidentally went to a similarly named place near by though! But last week I finally made it here for dinner. Their miso soup totally hit the spot on a cold night and their seaweed salad was delicious as well. The sushi was good, not great. Their deep fried spicy rolls were really interesting, we tried the Firecracker. It was good but I thought the batter should be a little thinner, it weighed down the taste a bit too much. The restaurant is very cute. The only other people eating there on a Thursday evening though was a crowded of loud and rather obnoxious business men. Otherwise is would have been quiet and empty, but instead it was hard to hear the hubs speaking to me from across the table at times.
author: Melissa W.

description: Four of us dropped in for a quick bite before the 8pm show at Shelton.  Fish was really fresh but sushi rolls were so-so.  Hand rolls not bad and prices were reasonable but overall, the experience was not particularly memorable.  If I were in the area, I'd probably try it again.
author: Goodbers G.

description: Great place. Cute little hole in the wall. Nice family running the operation. Terrific food, large rolls at reasonable prices. Firecracker was great, Volcano looked awesome!
author: Gregory L.

description:
Talk about serendipity - I was staying at the Galleria Park hotel and had a hankering for sushi so searched on Yelp for the nearest sushi bar. I was on my way to Sushi Toni when I walked right past this place and decided, since it was closer, to pop in. The ambiance looked inviting and they had a sushi bar, so I sat down at the bar by myself. I ordered a nigori sake and small Sapporo. I had no idea where I was and what I was in store for, I just figured I would get some standard sushi at a quiet, quaint place near my hotel.

I thought about doing omakase, but wasn't really that hungry and had my heart set on some standard nigiri - salmon, spanish makeral, tuna, etc... The waiter came over and made some recommendations and I ordered three nigiri sushi's. They were fantastic. It was then that the sushi chef asked me how I liked it. Turns out, the sushi chef is "Joe" the owner of the restaurant. I didn't even know the name of the place I was eating. I actually asked the sushi chef what the name of the place was and he handed me a card. At that point, I asked Joe to recommend stuff for me. I was not disappointed. In fact, nigiri after nigiri and handroll after handroll, I sat there and really thought hard about what I was about to tell Joe. I wanted to make sure I was being truly honest. He made me a handroll that was the best handroll I've ever had. I've had sushi at some of the best sushi places in Los Angeles, New York and San Francisco and I'd never had a handroll like Joe made me.

I'm so glad I happened upon this place and the next time I come back to San Francisco, this is where I'm going for sushi. Joe is a delight and provided me with some of the best sushi I've ever had. We toasted (kampai!) and had a great time. This place is truly legit and I really, really look forward to coming back.
author: Justin H.

description:
Excellent sushi place!!! fresh sushi and really warm service.
Joe the owner was really cool and happy chap, came over chatted.. he runs it with his wife.
Dynamite, Volcano rolls, black cod were excellent... dynamite had a great kick to it. Topped this off with unflitered sake...again superb!
We'll be bringing back many more friends to this place.....shame it's only open Mon-Fri.... need to find an equally good one for the weekend.
cute place and few bars near by to hop to after also...try it!!!
author: S G.

description: Passable lunch sushi.  The staff is kind of clueless though.  The food takes forever.
author: Nellie L.

description:
Shopping definitely makes for hungry girls. We happened to "run into" this joint as our real intent was to go to E&O, alas, it was closed for remodeling. We then decided to check out the restaurant in the alley, and "ka-pow"... Akiko. We both haven't been here before, so we decided to give it a try. We started with agadashi tofu and miso soup, followed with the spicy tuna roll, sashimi combination, and katsu don. 

The agadashi was not the most flavorful I've had, the broth lacked the sweetness that I prefer. The miso soup was actually pretty decent because it was not salty like other places. That rates in my book. The spicy tuna rolls and sashimi combo (salmon, tuna and yellowtail) were fresh and palatable. The katsu-don, I can't comment on as I did not have a taste of it. But, if I were to rate it based on appearance, it looked it appetizing. My friend said it was tasty. 

My only complaint is the snail's pace of the wait staff. The person setting up and cleaning was quick - it was the person that took the orders that was slow. It took a while, a long, while before he got to our table. To be fair, it was getting packed soon after we got there and he was the only wait person in the restaurant, and on top, we were extremely ravenous. Almost towards the end of our meal, he seemed more attentive and came back to our table to refill our teacups. 

Overall, it would be a place I hit up again if I were in the FiDi and wanted Japanese food. But, I can't really give it a 4 star as I need to try it out once more for consistency...
author: Carmen S.

description:
I went for dinner, sat at the bar and asked the sushi chef to make suggestions for me.  I wanted to try something new and, as I was reading a book about sushi, I have to admit I was sort of testing him as well.  He definitely passed and I thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience.
  The fish was fresh and the hand rolls he made for me were spectacular.  He toasted the seaweed for the wraps, a step which I think is key and a lot of places seem to skip.  
  The ambiance was cozy and on the romantic side - a good place for a date.
author: Jen G.

description: I love this place.  Family owned so I felt right at home.  Great food.  A great place to have private parties.  I had a surprise b-day for my wife and they were awesome with the arrangements.  All the guests had a great time and loved my choice.
author: Alex P.

description: I am staying in the city a couple nights and found this place on Yelp when I landed. It's close to the Hilton - Financial District so it was an easy decision to drop in for lunch. I was dining alone and asked for the sushi bar which was pretty wide open. They stuck me at the worst seat by the register and service station. It makes sense so small groups can sit next to each other but I expected better service since I was in the middle of everything happening. Not the case. I had to ask for several things and ended up stealing a napkin from the spot next to me. Seriously, if you're going to put someone in the worst spot in your establishment, at least have the courtesy to treat them right. Why 4 stars? I had an excellent chirashi bowl. The fish was very fresh and the sushi rice was easily the best I've ever had. The sushi chef was rushed but managed to produce a perfect bowl of the freshest offerings. I did not punish the chefs on the tip as they excelled but someone needs to step up and figure out how to manage the restaurant.
author: Neil B.

description: great place for such a busy touristy location. great and fresh food
author: Vilma G.

description: Meh--the fish was good but nothing to write home about. Given the lack of sushi in the Union Square area, if you are having a craving at lunch time, you will be satisfied, but don't go out of your way.
author: Lauren Q.

description: After giving a friendly nod acknowledging our presence it took 10 min for the waiter to finally stop by. At that point we were hungry and angry . Even if someone stopped by and said Sorry we are a bit busy (although they were not that busy on a Wednesday nifht) it would have been tolerable but they did not seem to care.
author: Alex D.

description:
If you go to a sushi restaurant to sit at a table, and order sauced-up rolls from a menu, and get attentive service during the lunchtime rush, then this review won't help you.  I've never sat at a table here, looked at the menu, tried a fancy-name roll, or visited at any time when they're busy (i.e. never on weekends or lunchtimes).  

But I have come here 15 or 20 times, to have sashimi and nigiri, always on a weekday evening when the chef (Joe) and host/server (his son) have plenty of unhurried time,   And if that is what you like to do, I can highly recommend Akiko's.  

The fish is reliably good & fresh, and often excellent & very fresh.  Joe chooses and cuts it well, likes to talk about the fish and steer you to the freshest choices.  (The uni is particularly fresh.)  After a few visits he'll remember you and what you like.  Then ask him to make you something interesting, whatever he chooses.  It'll be way more rewarding than yet another burrito-sized white person "sushi" roll with a fanciful name.

Update 12/09:  Since posting the initial review, I've been to Aikiko's 15 or so more times, and I'm so happy with the consistency of the quality. that I'm now raising my rating to five stars.   

Just for fun, I figured I'd remember some of the best things I've recently had at Aikiko's bar:
- Hawaiian royal fish - this was divine, succulent flesh, and they only had it for a few weeks (its imported very irregularly).
- Herring pressed in roe - sort of a sandwich of firm white herring flesh and salty yellow roe
- White salmon - "white" meaning very fatty, sort of like the toro equivalent for salmon, delicious
- Oysters - I forget the type, they came in a nice wooden box and we had them on the half-shell, the oysters were small, fresh, and very flavourful
- Uni - Aikiko's continues to have the most reliably good uni of any sushi restaurant where I've been a repeat diner.   Really good uni is fresh, sweet and creamy - the texture is like ice cream - with no bitterness or stickiness.  Here they have really good uni 4/5 of the time and just plain good the rest of the time, and I've never had bad uni here.
- There's more, but not a single roll is on the list.  I have still never had a roll here, and probably never will.  The fish here is really good, and stuffing it in a roll is just not the best way of enjoying it.  For me.
author: John L.

description: This has been my comfort food since I started working in downtown SF, about 9 years ago.  Whenever I was having a bad day I would grab my friend Joyce and we would go here.  I would have the sake nigiri, the albacore nigiri, the california roll (they put a special crunchy topping on it that makes it extra delicious), and the aj roll.  And it would never fail to better my mood.  I'm a little further away now, so I don't go as often, but it's delicious every time.  Joe and Mary the owners are always there and are lovely people.  Their young son waited for a while a few years ago and he was super sweet.  He was later replaced by a bit older guy who has a little more 'tude but is OK  I guess. I don't usually have a lot of cooked food at a sushi restaurant but I do get the impression that the fresh fish is their strong point rather than the cooked food. Anyway it's all about the sushi and for good, simple reliable sushi downtown, this is the place to go.
author: cecilia g.

description: i'm super-picky when it comes to sushi. the owner's are not japanese,  the sushi was paper-thin and the rolls were haphazardly constructed. there were no other patrons visible during dinner.  i know why.
author: Big e.

description: Feeling in the mood for Japanese food, but not wanting to stray far away from home, I decided it was time to pay a visit to Akiko, a small restaurant on Bush Street between Kearny and Grant. On a Monday night, we find this quiet enclave practically empty. Our waiter seated us immediately, at a table near the sushi bar. We barely had a chance to look at the menu before he was back to take our order (talk about quick service!) The menu is not extensive- although there are a variety of sushi choices, when it comes to regular food, the options are limited- a few udon choices, but no ramen or sukiyaki. We decided to start with edamame and a salad followed by various sushi rolls- egg and vegetables as well as the California roll among others. The edamame arrived first, steaming hot, in a cute dish along with a separate bowl for the pods. We enjoyed a bottle of hot filtered sake while waiting for the rest of the dishes to arrive- unfortunately I cannot remember the brand, it was very mild and slightly sweet. Next to arrive was the salad- greens with cucumbers, pickles and a ginger miso dressing presented artistically on a plate decorated with a sesame seed containing sauce as a garnish. I am usually a fan of Japanese salads due to the miso dressing, and this salad was no exception. Our rolls followed- pretty standard for sushi. I enjoyed the egg and vegetable, although the vegetables fell out when I was attempting to eat this bursting at the seams roll. Messy yes, but definitely tasty. In summary, Akiko is a fine place for some Japanese food, but I'll probably venture somewhere else in the future, just to expand my options.
author: Kate A.

description: if you like nabeyaki udon, here is another place that is quite good...with seafood and chicken....their soup is quite tasty and not the type that taste like you were swimming in the sea...if you like specialty sushi then you have to try their dynamite roll...it has good sauce and deep fried to a slight crispiness but just the rice was a big too mushy...but worth trying...very cute decor...but feels more like you are inside an italian restaurant...hehehe! sayonara
author: Mee-stique K.

description: this was my first sushi experience in SF. overall i enjoyed my meal, the rolls were a good size, the fish tasted fresh and was cold (the way i like it). i got there before the lunch rush, but even then the service was only pretty good. two things i didn't like: the prices and the fact that the waitress wouldn't give me a spoon for my miso soup.
author: Toisha T.

description: polite, competent staff serving well presented sushi. the decor is homey, and nicely put together to give you a sense of cleanliness without the sterile feel of cheap restaurant furniture. not the best sushi ive had, but very affordable for the above par fare. nice for a date, and i can see a lunch stop-off growing to be a habit for anyone that works nearby. good folks, give it a try one of these days.
author: Darrell L.

description: The greens dishes, especially the spinach, were beautifully presented and intensely flavorful. The sashimi was fresh and delicious, particularly the hamachi (I've never had hamachi that shade of pink before!.) Service was unobtrusive and the decor was elegant and comforting. This isn't the sort of place that has cutesy names for its rolls or paper lanterns all over the place... It was sushi for adults, but reasonably priced.
author: C. J.

description: really good rolls, love love love the butterfish... our server was nice.  only thing was it took a long time to get our rolls!
author: Gina T.

description: Best sushi in the financial district, hands down. Service could be a little better but they are a small place. Great sushi and pretty reasonable. A good save for Kearny St............
author: Patrick G.

description: I love this place!  The sushi is awesome and the service was AMAZING!  I plan on going back often.  My fiance and I ate our hearts out and it was only $45.  I would recomend this place to everyone!
author: katlyn m.

description: We tried sushi rolls, tempura and chirashi. All of them are average. The size of sushi rolls are rather small. They close early too.
author: Amy C.

description: I'm definitely coming back to this place! I am not much of a sushi eater (yet) but, decided to stop here anyways with the boss. We shared the ebi ten and spicy tuna roll. It was very fresh and none the less delicious! The owner was even throwing free sashimi at us after we finished our rolls to try and asked us if our food was good. The staff is very friendly and attentive and the restaurant itself has a nice chill vibe. Definitely recommend Akiko's and coming back soon!
author: morgan a.

description: Passable dinner expense sushi.  The fish was fresh - not fishy - but he cut it weird so it was all hard and I had a couple triangle pieces.  Plus for ginger being very pale.  Plus for neat decor.  Minus for triangle shaped fish.  I'm not sure I would spend my own money here.
author: M K.

description: Loved this sushi place!  I highly recommend the 49er roll.  I love salmon with lemon and this had beautiful paper thin piecs of lemon on every bite.  The spicy scallop handroll was also outstanding.  The sushi chef asked if I was OK for xtra spice.  It was awesome!  I was visiting from Seattle and asked the concierge at my hotel for a recommendation for a small, casual sushi place.  This place fit the bill perfectly and I'll definitely be back!
author: Stephanie S.

description: I stay in SF for business alot and this place is right around the corner from my usual hotel.  I finally stopped by and was pleasantly surprised by just how good it is.  I started with white tuna sashimi (my new favorite fish right now) which was fresh, buttery, melt in your mouth delish.  then i had the nabeyaki udon.  the cook made the udon fresh for me (i could see into the kitchen from my stool at the sushi counter).  this is the best udon i have had in SF (and any place except hawaii).  the noodles were al dente and chewy.  there was a poached egg, fresh sliced zucchini and onions and little bites of different fresh seafood (fish, clams, etc.).  it was so good i went back for dinner a few nights later and had the same thing except i tried the hamachi sashimi.  unfortunately, that was one the flaw in the experience.  the hamachi was not as good as the white tuna.  it was still fresh but tougher and chewier than the white tuna.  all and all though a good find in the fin district.
author: lily c.

description: Love this place! Great decor and yummy sushi - try their firecracker roll which has a nice kick to it. All the sushi is good and fresh. The service and can be a little slow but this is one of my favorite sushi places in San Francisco!
author: Anu V.

description: Excellent Japanese restaurant.  We stopped here for dinner after work and had two dishes: the chef's choice choice sushi combination and the salmon teriyaki.  Both were some of the best I've had.  The restaurant is attractively decorated and has atmosphere well suited for a date.  Service was quietly competent.  All around solid Japanese restaurant.
author: Kyle C.

description: recommended to me by my roommate, a coworker and i decided to get our sushi fix at akiko. it started out well. the place wasn't crowded at all (we went for an early lunch) and the atmosphere was nice, very cozy with a touch of modern charm. we ordered and were served in a reasonable amount of time, but once we got our food, we became non existant. waiter never came back around and i had to flag him down to attempt to order another roll. he just assumed i wanted the check, but i had to correct him and fenagle a menu from him. we ordered another roll, but this time the service wasnt so fast. sitting in front of the sushi chef himself, i thought it would be slightly quicker but no, 20 minutes later and no roll. the sushi chef asks if we want our check and we say no no we want another roll. waiter boy then suddenly remembers "oh yeah, roll for them". nice one jr. 15 more minutes and we're finally served a decent tuna belly. they have good presentation and decent food, i just don tthink i'll be going back due to the lack of service. oh well.
author: Aly L.
